title: On Broadway, Honeymoon Is Over
description: Honeymoon in Vegas, a madcap musical that won positive reviews but failed to find an audience, will close on Sunday.

title: Review: Ballet West Offers an Eclectic Mix at the Joyce
description: Ballet West has been in existence since 1963, but this Salt Lake City company didnt gain national prominence until it became the focus of Breaking Pointe, a reality show more consumed by the dancers backstage lives than ballet. The program ran on the CW network for two seasons beginning in 2012. Now in the a five-night run at the Joyce Theater, Ballet West had a chance to put the emphasis back where it belongs, on dancing.

title: Energy Company Samson Hints at Bankruptcy
description: When a group of investors led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts bought the oil producer Samson Resources for $7.2 billion more than three years ago, analysts regarded the deal as a triumph.

title: Pillars of Holy Week Processions Put Teamwork and Brawn on Display
description: SEVILLE, Spain  On a recent evening here, a group of 43 men shuffled back and forth as they carefully negotiated a tight street corner during a practice run carrying one of the heavy religious floats that get paraded around this city during its Holy Week celebrations.

title: With Auto Show, G.M. Hopes to Lessen Damage
description: After a huge safety crisis and a revolt by disgruntled investors, General Motors is eager to turn its attention back to cars and trucks.

title: Rollout of New York Citys Taxi of Tomorrow Is Again Halted in Court
description: The Taxi of Tomorrow is delayed again.

title: Seeing a Tax Refund as a Financial Opportunity
description: So far this year, the Internal Revenue Service has processed more than 66 million federal income tax refunds, averaging about $2,900 each.

title: Arizona Orders Doctors to Say Abortions With Drugs May Be Reversible
description: PHOENIX  Once again, Arizona finds itself on the frontier of anti-abortion legislation: Late Monday, it became the first state to pass a law requiring doctors who perform drug-induced abortions to tell women that the procedure may be reversible, an assertion that most doctors say is wrong.

title: Muhammadu Buhari, a Familiar, and Now Less Divisive, Choice in Nigerian Election
description: KANO, Nigeria  The 72-year-old former general elected as Nigerias new president this week is not exactly new to the democratic process: He spent much of the past decade campaigning for the office in three successive elections  and failing each time.

title: East Village Explosion Might Have Followed Attempt to Hide Gas Siphoning
description: Law enforcement officials are investigating whether the explosion that destroyed three buildings and killed two men in the East Village last week resulted from an attempt to hide the unauthorized siphoning of natural gas for tenants in one of the buildings.

title: ADM Announces Plan to Fight Deforestation
description: Archer Daniels Midland, one of the worlds largest commodities suppliers, has joined the growing number of major agriculture and food companies promising to take steps to conserve forests that are threatened by the global demand for commodities like palm oil and soy.

title: Provisional Government in Libyan Capital Forces Out Its Own Prime Minister
description: CAIRO  The provisional government set up by the militias controlling the Libyan capital fired its prime minister on Tuesday. His departure removed a potential obstacle to unity talks organized by the United Nations to try to end the fighting that has divided the country.

title: Indiana Governor, Feeling Backlash From Laws Opponents, Promises a Fix
description: By turns, Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana was defiant then chastened, stern then contemplative.

title: Azerbaijan Bars Entry to a Georgian Human Rights Worker
description: MOSCOW  Azerbaijan on Monday barred a veteran human rights worker from entering the country, the latest in a series of events that international rights advocates have condemned and cited as evidence of increasing political repression.

title: At N.I.T., 30-Second Shot Clock Wins Support
description: Over the last two weeks, the National Invitation Tournament has used a 30-second shot clock instead of the current 35-second one, an experiment that even President Obama advocated for in early March.

title: As Nuclear Talks Drag On, U.S. and Iran Find It Harder to Hear Each Other
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland  As the nuclear negotiations dragged into overtime here on Tuesday, some uniquely American and Iranian political sensitivities were permeating the marathon negotiating sessions, leading many to wonder whether two countries that have barely spoken for 35 years are just not ready to overcome old suspicions.

title: FEMA Awards New York City a $3 Billion Grant for Hurricane Sandy Repairs
description: New York City is set to receive about $3 billion in federal funding to repair and stormproof 33 public housing complexes that were badly damaged by Hurricane Sandy, a grant that officials said was the largest provided by the Federal Emergency Management Agency.

title: Army Offering More a Fast Track to Citizenship
description: The Army will expand a program offering a fast track to citizenship for immigrants with special language or medical skills. Based on guidance published Friday, the program, Military Accessions Vital to the National Interest (Mavni), will increase to 3,000 enlistments this fiscal year and 5,000 in the 2016 fiscal year, up from the current limit of 1,500. An Army spokesman, Hank Minitrez, said the program was extremely successful in filling our ranks with highly qualified soldiers who fill critical shortages. Foreigners accepted to enlist have been legal immigrants on temporary visas. In September, the program also was opened to young undocumented immigrants with deportation deferrals under a 2012 initiative by President Obama. Mr. Minitrez said that a few had applied but that none had been accepted to date.

title: Lawyers Chosen to Present Case for Gay Marriage
description: Gay rights groups announced Tuesday that they had chosen two lawyers to present Supreme Court arguments on April 28 in favor of a constitutional right to same-sex marriage. One of the lawyers, Mary L. Bonauto, a prominent gay rights advocate who was instrumental in establishing a right to same-sex marriage in Massachusetts, will argue that all states must allow such unions. The other lawyer, Douglas Hallward-Driemeier, a former assistant United States solicitor general, will make a separate argument that states must recognize same-sex marriages performed elsewhere. Ms. Bonauto will face John J. Bursch, a former Michigan solicitor general, in the first argument, which is scheduled to last 90 minutes. Mr. Hallward-Driemeier will face Joseph Whalen, an associate solicitor general in Tennessee, in the second argument, which is set to last an hour.

title: Federal Scrutiny of a Youth Immigration Program Alarms Advocates
description: Among the myriad laws and regulations that govern the nations immigration system is a special program, created 25 years ago, that allows immigrant youths who have been abused, neglected or abandoned to apply for a green card.

title: Adviser and Caretaker of de Blasio Family Image Is Leaving City Hall
description: In appointing Rebecca Kirszner Katz as a special adviser shortly after taking office, Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York described her as a close confidante of his wife and children who had become, at times, the fifth member of our immediate family.

title: Finding a Home, and a Muse, at the Algonquin Hotel
description: As comfortable as if he were in his own living room, Michael Colby, 63, lounged in a plush chair in the lobby of the Algonquin Hotel in Manhattan and enjoyed a fruit plate.

title: Conference to Aid Syrians Falls Short of Expectations
description: In an ominous sign of possible donor fatigue, delegates to an international fund-raising conference for victims of the Syrian war pledged $3.8 billion on Tuesday, less than half the emergency humanitarian assistance sought by the United Nations for this year, even as the number of Syrians suffering mass displacement from the four-year-old conflict showed no sign of easing.

title: Why I Moved to Florida
description: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE  When my daughter Deb told me that she was taking a job with The New York Times, humorously writing about crossword puzzles edited by no less than Mr. Will Shortz himself, no one was happier than me. There is something to be said about watching a child that you sacrificed your lifes dreams for grow up and become, if not a Pulitzer Prize winner, at least moderately self-supporting. As long as shes happy, my wife and I said to ourselves.

title: Can Chris Mullin Thrive on Name and Local Ties? Peers Say Yes
description: This was 15 years ago, in the twilight of Chris Mullins wonderful basketball-playing life. Springtime in Indianapolis had matched him and the Pacers against his hometown Knicks, but Mullin wasnt part of the playoff action, not in the way he had so often been, shooting picturesque southpaw jumpers from all over.

title: Yankees Masahiro Tanaka Is a Bit Relieved His Elbow Is Holding Up
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Only Masahiro Tanaka knows whether the small tear in his elbow ligament that caused him to miss two months last season is providing any discomfort or is in some way responsible for a slight dip in his pitching velocity during spring training.

title: Janet Norwood Dies at 91; Led Labor Statistics Bureau
description: Janet L. Norwood, who ran the Bureau of Labor Statistics throughout the 1980s and maintained objectivity when politicians wanted her to interpret jobs data in a way that furthered their parties agendas, died on March 27 in Austin, Tex. She was 91.

title: Knicks Will Set New Low; Only Question Is How Low
description: Some milestones await the Knicks in coming days, and none of them are good. As their awful season staggers to a merciful conclusion over the next two weeks, they are certain to set franchise records for the fewest victories in a season and for the worst winning percentage.

title: Loopholes Seen in New Ethics Disclosure Rules for New York Legislators
description: ALBANY  Lawmakers who are convicted of public corruption may have to forfeit their pensions. Those who are lawyers will be forced to reveal, with some exceptions, the names of their clients. And all legislators will have to verify their whereabouts to collect their daily travel stipend.

title: Nets, Hitting Their Stride When It Counts, Hold Off the Pacers
description: Less than a minute remained in the Nets game Tuesday night, and they were hounding the Indiana Pacers around the Barclays Center floor, their sneakers squeaking in a frantic rhythm as they tried to guard a 5-point lead. The desperation was palpable, and the doggedness paid off.

title: New York City Comptroller Cites Flaws in Hurricane Sandy Recovery Program
description: A company hired by New York City to help homeowners rebuild after Hurricane Sandy had a financial disincentive to act more quickly because it had already been paid millions of dollars upfront, according to an audit released on Tuesday by Scott M. Stringer, the city comptroller.

title: Justified Recap: Has This Been a Love Story the Whole Time?
description: Season 6, Episode 11: Fugitive No. 1

title: Cuomo Gets Deals on Tenure and Evaluations of Teachers
description: A hostile winter of speeches, rallies and barbs between Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and teachers unions ended in compromise on a variety of fronts, with the governor winning some changes in the way teachers are evaluated and granted tenure, and in how the state deals with chronically struggling schools.

title: Fringe Benefits
description: Can I profit from accidentally obtained information?

title: Context for the Debate on Religious Freedom Measures in Indiana and Arkansas
description: Gov. Asa Hutchinson of Arkansas appeared set to join Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana in the national debate over religious rights and gay people on Tuesday as the Arkansas legislature passed its own Religious Freedom Restoration Act just a few days after Indiana passed a similar law that has drawn criticism for having the potential to abet discrimination against gay and lesbian couples.

title: Recipes from Loosie Rouge, a New Brooklyn Bar With a New Orleans Accent
description: In a place you call home, you can see whats missing, says Damien del Rio, a co-owner of the new Brooklyn bar Loosie Rouge. For del Rio and his associates, that home was Williamsburg, and the missing element was a bar that stayed true to the boroughs eclectic and creative spirit. Its not only Williamsburg, but what Ive seen in Brooklyn growing up  the cultural aspects, the things that have been missing from New York for quite a while, says del Rio, who was born and raised in Bed-Stuy, just a few miles from his watering hole, which opens today.

title: A Tree-Scented Trio of Fragrances
description: The tree is the origin of the most beautiful tales and legends, which lends itself perfectly to the values of Liquides Imaginaires, says Philippe di Mo, the creative director and co-founder of the French perfumery whose ethos is to transport an individual through sensory experience. And with his companys newest fragrance trilogy, Les Eaux Arborantes, available stateside for the first time today and designed to represent three elements of the tree, he hopes to propel the wearer into spring: The tree symbolizes the rebirth of nature, he says.

title: Word of the Day | ultimatum
description: ultimatum  \l-t-ma-tm, -m-\  noun

title: Jerry Blevins Is Happy to Be a New York Met
description: VIERA, Fla.  Jerry Blevins was waiting in the Washington Nationals bullpen Monday afternoon when he first noticed something unusual. He was scheduled to pitch against the St. Louis Cardinals, but as the game went on, he was not summoned. Then he saw his manager walking toward the bullpen.

title: Whats On TV Wednesday
description: 8 P.M. (Starz Cinema) CAPOTE (2005) Philip Seymour Hoffman, above, won an Oscar for his embodiment of Truman Capote as he uncovers the story that became In Cold Blood, the novel about the 1959 murder of the Clutter family in Holcomb, Kan., in this drama directed by Bennett Miller from a script by Dan Futterman. Catherine Keener plays Nelle Harper Lee, Capotes research assistant; Chris Cooper is Alvin Dewey, the lead investigator on the case; and Clifton Collins Jr. is the murderer Perry Smith. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called the film a fascinating and fine-grained reconstruction of that period in its subjects life, a time when he pursued literary glory and flirted with moral ruin.

title: Corrections: April 1, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day
description: We need change; people have been tired for a very long time.

title: After Horror in Libya, Christians Grief in an Egyptian Village
description: A gruesome video from Libya that went viral in late February ended with shrouded members of ISIS standing over the headless corpses of abducted Egyptian Christians. The day after watching it, the photographer Jonathan Rashad gathered his equipment for a trip south from Cairo, miles from the scene  but closer to those who felt it.

title: Cancer and Genetic Data
description: To the Editor:

title: Tell Me How This Ends Well
description: HONG KONG  Ive been in China for the last week. Its always instructive to see how the world looks from the Middle Kingdom. Sometimes the best insights come from just reading the local papers. On March 25, The China Daily published an essay detailing how Beijing authorities had launched inspection tours of kindergartens this week to ensure that children are not overburdened with schoolwork. Although Chinese, mathematics and English are supposed to be taught to primary school students, it is not uncommon to see pre-school-age children across China being forced to study these subjects. The essay went on to explain why it wasnt healthy to begin preparing for the college entrance exam in preschool.

title: Ted Cruzs Imaginings
description: To the Editor:

title: Cultural Philanthropy
description: To the Editor:

title: Geriatric Incarceration
The Advantages of Uber
description: To the Editor:

title: How the Tax Code Hurts Artists
description: WITH tax day looming, you can practically hear the cries of creative professionals across the country. Thats because the tax code hits many right where it hurts, by penalizing them for the distinctive way they make money.

title: Making Herbal Supplements Safer
description: An agreement announced Monday by the New York State attorney general and GNC, the nations largest specialty retailer of dietary supplements, should provide protection against fraudulent herbal products that dont contain the ingredients listed on their labels or contain unlisted ingredients that are potentially dangerous.

title: When Self-Made Republicans Leave Others Behind
Mixed Messages in Egypts Military Aid
description: In announcing sweeping changes to Egypts military aid package on Tuesday, the Obama administration used both punishment and incentives to set a new tone for a frayed relationship with a crucial ally.

title: The Supreme Courts Death Trap
description: You wouldnt know it from the death penalty proceeding about to take place in the Boston Marathon case, or from Utahs reauthorization of the firing squad, or the spate of botched lethal injections, but capital punishment in the United States is becoming vestigial.

title: Test Yourself | The Explorers Club
description: Here are several paragraphs from a March 30 article, Modern Explorers Seek a Place in a GPS World.

title: 6 Qs About the News | April Fools Day
description: One of the most famous April Fools Day pranks ever: the BBCs April 1, 1957, report on the spaghetti harvest in Switzerland.

title: New Faces on HBOs Game of Thrones
description: The Game of Thrones saga is sprawling in scale and merciless in its death rate, which means each season brings new characters and settings to fill out its world. Here are some of the new faces and places appearing in Season 5: Read no further if you want to remain unsullied.

title: Lee Daniels Watches Empire  and Talks Back to the Screen
description: Lee Daniels was in his Midtown Manhattan loft on a recent Wednesday night, doing what millions of other people were doing at the same time: getting ready to watch an episode of his breakout hit television show, Empire.

title: For Duke and Kentucky, Theres Blue and Then Theres Blue
description: If Duke and Kentucky meet in college basketballs national championship game, will you root for Pantone 286 or Pantone 287?

title: World Trade Center Ship to Travel to Permanent Berth in Albany
description: After a short, hard life on the water  a brutal one, perhaps, transporting slaves or fighting off pirates  the shallow, broad-beamed, 45-foot sloop docked in Lower Manhattan one day in the late 1700s. And stayed there for two more centuries.

title: Bronx Koreans Cope as Their Population Shrinks
description: The senior center is all of one room on the second floor of a church, because its 120 members cannot afford to rent anything bigger.

title: Female-Run Venture Capital Funds Alter the Status Quo
description: Step into the offices on Sand Hill Road, the heart of Silicon Valley venture capital, and one thing is immediately striking  the almost all-male cast of leading characters.

title: Fashion Has Much to Gain From Honest Documentaries
description: One of the thorniest questions in the fashion world right now  the one that keeps designers and chief executives up at night, and arguing during the day  is not, as you might think, whether it is beneficial for a brand to have Kimye in its front row, or what global currency fluctuations will mean for business, but rather one of access. Specifically, how much should be granted to the outside world?

title: Sophie Turner and Maisie Williams Have Grown Up on Game of Thrones
description: BEVERLY HILLS, CALIF.  Its a bright afternoon here, and Arya and Sansa Stark are singing.

title: Trucking and Rail Industries Turn State Troopers Into Unwitting Lobbyists
description: WASHINGTON  David Latimer, wearing a South Carolina Highway Patrol button on his lapel, was working Capitol Hill one recent morning, warning of the dangers of longer and heavier trucks on the nations highways.

title: Is the Indiana Religious Freedom Law an Invitation to Discriminate Against Gays?
description: Have you been following the news about the storms of protest over a recently passed Indiana law (and an Arkansas bill) that could make it easier for religious conservatives to refuse service to gay couples?

title: Simon Property Withdraws Offer for Mall Rival Macerich
description: The Simon Property Group withdrew its $23.2 billion offer to acquire the Macerich Company after the rival mall operators board rejected an unsolicited bid.

title: ISIS: Inside the Army of Terror, and More
description: A masked militant with a drawn knife, preparing to slaughter a helpless captive: This is how the group that was to become the Islamic State, more commonly known as ISIS, grabbed the worlds attention in 2004. The Islamic State has renamed and reinvented itself many times since then, but it still makes such scenes a staple of its propaganda.

title: Ayaan Hirsi Alis Heretic
description: Following the events of the Arab Spring, Ayaan Hirsi Ali writes in her latest book, Heretic, she came to the conclusion that ordinary Muslims are ready for change. Hirsi Ali has strong thoughts on what form that change should take for Muslims: a major overhaul of their religion. Without fundamental alterations to some of Islams core concepts, she says, we shall not solve the burning and increasingly global problem of political violence carried out in the name of religion.

title: Barefoot Running May Be Harder for Older Runners
description: Experienced older runners who switch to barefoot running may not adjust as naturally to the process as younger runners do, a new study suggests, which could increase their risk of sustaining an injury while running without shoes.

title: Claims of Retaliation in Detention of Chinese Anticorruption Campaigner
description: Supporters of a Chinese anticorruption campaigner who was detained last week on charges of soliciting a prostitute are questioning whether the move represents retaliation by officials angered by his investigations.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: New York Today: Of Fraud and Footwear
description: Good morning on this brisk Wednesday.

title: Marlon James Among Anisfield-Wolf Award Winners
description: The Cleveland Foundation on Wednesday announced the winners of its 2015 Anisfield-Wolf Book Awards, which are given to books that deal with issues of race and diversity.

title: UBS Shareholders to Vote for First Time on Executive and Board Pay
description: LONDON  UBS said on Wednesday that its shareholders would, for the first time, vote on the compensation of its directors and its top executives at its annual meeting in May.

title: Daily Report: Tech Leaders Come Together to Oppose Indiana Law
description: The technology industrys leaders have found their collective voice on a social issue in the last week, rallying with great intensity against a new Indiana law that will allow businesses, they predict, to discriminate against gay couples. The heads of Apple, Salesforce.com, Yelp and Square have all publicly criticized the law, as have some leaders from other industries.

title: Obama Told Iran Nuclear Negotiators to Disregard Deadline in 11th Hour
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland  If American negotiators are ultimately able to conclude a political understanding with Iran on its nuclear program, as they said they were striving to do Thursday morning, the seeds might have been planted earlier in the week.

title: Has American Business Lost Its Mojo?
description: Over the past three decades, the American economy has become less vigorous. An extensive body of evidence shows that the public focus on the success of high-tech companies like Apple and Google masks an overall downward trend in key measures of business vitality.

title: Lufthansa Faces Mounting Challenges as More Details of Germanwings Crash Emerge
description: FRANKFURT  Lufthansa was supposed to be celebrating the 60th anniversary of its postwar rebirth this month.

title: Hotel Review: The Wild Rabbit in the Cotswolds, England
description: Doubles from 135, including breakfast, or $195 at $1.45 to the pound.

title: Camping According to Your Taste
description: For many people, camping evokes visions of fishing, tents and swatting mosquitoes, in areas where outside communication ranges from difficult to impossible. Jim Rogers, the chairman and chief executive of Kampgrounds of America, would like to dispel the one-size-fits-all perception that camping often receives. The company, often referred to as KOA, is the largest privately owned system of campgrounds in the world, with more than 485 locations in the United States and Canada. The campground is an oasis for genuine engagement, Mr. Rogers said. Weve redefined camping, as we now have zip lines, horseback rides and pools at many properties.

title: Restaurant Report: 430 Duval in Key West, Fla.
description: The historic Crowne Plaza Key West La Concha, in the heart of the ever boisterous Duval Street corridor of Key West, has several claims to fame, including its prominence as the tallest building downtown.

title: The Common Mans Crown
description: The 1903 World Series was the first of baseballs modern era. Boston and Pittsburgh were adhering to newly codified rules of play  and also initiating a new code of dress, as no one could have known, least of all the men in the stands, uniformly obedient to the laws of Edwardian haberdashery. The spectators wore derbies, boaters, checkered caps and porkpie hats, wrote Beverly Chico in her book, Hats and Headwear Around the World. Each style signaled a distinct social identity. All are now regarded largely as museum pieces, having fallen away in favor of a hat that offers casual comfort and a comforting image of classlessness. Given our cult of youth, our populist preference for informality and our native inclination toward sportiness, its emergence as the common mans crown was inevitable.

title: Stranger Still
description: I first heard about the writer Kamel Daoud a few years ago, when an Algerian friend of mine told me I should read him if I wanted to understand how her country had changed in recent years. If Algeria can produce a Kamel Daoud, she said, I still have hope for Algeria. Reading his columns in Le Quotidien dOran, a French-language newspaper, I saw what she meant. Daoud had an original, epigrammatic style: playful, lyrical, brash. I could also see why hed been accused of racism, even self-hatred. After Sept. 11, for example, he wrote that the Arabs had been crashing for centuries and that they would continue crashing so long as they were better known for hijacking planes than for making them. But this struck me as the glib provocation of an otherwise intelligent writer carried away by his metaphors.

title: Sydney Leroux and Alex Morgan: Peas in an Exacting Pod
description: Here is a story about the time Sydney Leroux wanted to jump off a cliff.

title: Can I Profit From Accidentally Obtained Information?
description: At a previous job, I was responsible for complex negotiations that frequently involved email exchanges of draft transaction documents. One party would do a redline of the draft submitted by the other party, so that the receiver could see what changes the sender required. On one occasion, our counterparty mistakenly sent back its redline so that I was able to seetext not intended for me: comment boxes and other evidence of what thatcompanys employees were saying to one another about their negotiating positions. This unintended transparency presumably occurred because the writers did not understand how to use Microsoft Words track-changes functions. I was pretty certain that it was a genuine mistake and not a clever ruse. Using this knowledge, I was able to strike a better deal for my employer. Was it unethical to do so?NAME WITHHELD, NEW YORK

title: The Editor Who Went to War
description: On the afternoon of April 1, 1865, over 10,000 Union cavalry soldiers were poised to attack the crossroads at Five Forks, Va. If Five Forks fell, so would the South Side Railroad, the last supply line to Richmond. Gen. Phil Sheridan hoped to end the nine-month stalemate along 20 miles of fortified trenches running between Richmond and Petersburg, Va.

title: Transforming Nursing Home Care
description: Speak the words dementia and nursing home, and youve exposed two great fears among people in developed countries, where living until 80 or 90 is increasingly common. Despite efforts to keep frail elders in their own homes, increasing numbers of people with dementia are likely to spend time in a nursing home.

title: More Management Changes at Standard Chartered Amid Overhaul at British Bank
description: LONDON  Standard Chartered said on Wednesday that Viswanathan Shankar, the head of its business in Europe, the Middle East, Africa and the Americas, was leaving the company as the British bank continues to shake up its top leadership.

description: The singer and songwriter Joni Mitchell was hospitalized on Tuesday in Southern California after she was found unconscious at her home, the folk singers official website and Twitter account said in a statement.

description: Taiwan has expressed its intention to join the China-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, but its effort has encountered protests at home and early snags over sensitive issues ofsovereignty.

description: The supporters in China of five feminists who were detained in early March are continuing to agitate on their behalf, despite intimidation and the censorship of online discussion by the authorities.

title: New York State Budget Is Passed Just After Deadline
description: ALBANY  For Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, on-time budgets are a serious point of pride, a symbol that he has restored order in the capital. This year, he sacrificed many of his top proposals to clear the way for the punctual approval of the budget.

description: LONDON  European bankers saw their pay increase in 2015, though they still lag behind their American counterparts, according to a snapshot of bonuses released on Wednesday by Emolument.com, a salary benchmarking website in Britain.

title: Peekskill, N.Y., a Little Country, a Little Urban
description: On a recent Friday evening, Dr. Chelsea Hollander and her husband, Lorenzo Dominguez, welcomed about two dozen friends for a House of Cards viewing party in their 1887 Victorian on Smith Street. Many were neighbors who, like their hosts, had moved there in recent years from New York City.

title: Rebels in Yemen Battle for Control of Strategic Port City
description: AL MUKALLA, Yemen  Houthi fighters backed by tanks pushed into the center of Aden on Wednesday and were battling for control of the southern port city, despite a weeklong Saudi military offensive against them.

title: 1940: Army of 120,000 Starts Census
description: WASHINGTON  Tomorrow morning [April 2] 120,000 inquisitive persons, whose curiosity is defined and limited by law, will start on the seemingly gigantic task of taking a census of the population of the United States, the abode in 1930, year of the last complication, of 122,775,046 persons, of whom 2,190,791 were babies growing toward their first birthday and 3,964 were 100 years old or more. Experts anticipate that the census for the first time in the history of the United States will reveal a decline in the foreign-born population due to the quota system limiting immigration. In the 1930-38 period, emigration exceeded immigration by 130,000.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 2, 1940

title: Wont Get Fooled Again
description: TIMES INSIDER  It might not be obvious, but The New York Times Crossword has a sense of humor. That aspect of the puzzle is never more apparent than when April 1 rolls around.

title: Obama Expands Options for Retaliating Against Foreign Hackers
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Wednesday signed an executive order aimed at retaliating against foreign-based online attacks on the United States as the government scrambles to catch up to national security threats that are evolving in a world of fast-changing technology.

title: Lively Morgue Tumblr 494  496
description: Lively Morgue Tumblr 494  496

title: Tiger Woods May Return, but Dont Expect Him to Contend
description: Tiger Woods played 18 practice holes at Augusta National Golf Club on Tuesday, sparking speculation that he will return to competition at the Masters after back and other injuries.

title: At Christian Fashion Week,Modesty Is One Policy
description: TAMPA, Fla.  As Tom Ford presented his fall 2015 collection in the modern Sodom of Los Angeles, and Marc Jacobs tended his garden in hell in Gotham-Gomorrah, around 300 Christians were gathering here for a fashion extravaganza of their own.

title: The Enduring Appeal of Roasted Chicken Provenal
description: The designer Steven Stolman, who is 57, first tasted chicken Provenal as a college student, on a visit to New York with a friend, sitting on bentwood chairs in the family kitchen of a townhouse on the Upper East Side. There were cloth napkins, good china, a Tiffany lamp and portraits on the walls. The whole place was done up in what Stolman calls classic late-70s Bloomingdales style.

title: Tune In to The Times
description: The New York Times culture reporter Dave Itzkoff joined MSNBC Live With Thomas Roberts to discuss the  backlash over Trevor Noah, the recently named successor as host of The Daily Show.

title: Cellphones for Women in Developing Nations Aid Ascent From Poverty
description: Here is what life is like for a woman with no bank account in a developing country. She keeps her savings hidden  in pots, under mattresses, in fields. She constantly worries about thieves. She may even worry about her husband taking cash she has budgeted for their childrens needs. Sending money to a family member in another village is risky and can take days. Obtaining a loan in an emergency is often impossible.

title: John Giornos Half-Century on the Bowery
description: The artists three-story loft has played host to everyone from Andy Warhol to William Burroughs to hundreds of Buddhist monks.

title: Tate Britain Director to Move to Portuguese Museum
description: LONDON Penelope Curtis, the director of Tate Britain, will leave her position this summer to become the director of the Calouste Gulbenkian Museum in Lisbon, the Portuguese museum has announced.

title: 1965: Nonlethal Gas Use Examined
description: LONDON  Colonial Secretary Anthony Greenwood told Parliament today [April 1] that Britain had used nonlethal gas 124 times in the last five years. Some members of Parliament were shocked. The left wing of Prime Minister Harold Wilsons governing Labor party has bitterly protested U.S. gas warfare in South Vietnam. Mr. Greenwood said British colonial police had used the gas to disarm and disperse rioters and to quell jail breaks. He said it was used 97 times in British Guiana.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 2, 1965.

title: GoDaddy Shares Jump in Market Debut
description: SAN FRANCISCO  If GoDaddy was hoping to draw attention for something other than provocative ads, it has succeeded.

title: Study Finds No Link Between Military Suicide Rate and Deployments
description: The largest study to date of a rising suicide rate among military personnel, published Wednesday in JAMA Psychiatry, found no connection between suicide and deployment overseas in support of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: A Cheapskates Cheatsheet to Tbilisi, Georgia
description: It seems that everyone loves the country of Georgia. You can barely mention it without people piping up to say how startlingly beautiful the Caucasus mountain villages are, or raving about meats grilled over grapevines, the generous use of walnuts and pomegranates, or internationally beloved acharuli khachapuri, fresh baked cheesebread with a raw egg on top. But what they may leave out is how cheap it is  especially true since the lari has lost 20 percent of its value since last summer.

title: Office Space Is Hard to Find for Silicon Valley Newcomers
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Technology start-ups do not just have to fight to draw attention, customers and money from investors. Finding reasonably priced office space that attracts employees in a hot labor market, then doing it again when the company grows, is a battle unto itself.

title: In Colorado, Marijuana Taxes May Have to Be Passed Back
description: DENVER  In the State Capitol, they are calling it Refund Madness.

title: No Comment Necessary: The Homosexual Lobby
description: Bryan Fischer, the former director of issues analysis for the American Family Association, a conservative Christian group, tweeted yesterday that critics of Indianas religious freedom law were seeking homosexual supremacy.

title: Arkansas Governor Asks Lawmakers to Recall Religious Exception Bill
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  Facing a backlash from businesses and gay rights advocates, Gov. Asa Hutchinson of Arkansas on Wednesday called on state lawmakers to either recall or amend legislation billed as a religious freedom measure so that it mirrored a federal law approved in 1993.

title: With Galaxy S6 and S6 Edge, Samsung Tries to Regain Its Footing
description: Samsungs internal code name for its latest top-of-the-line smartphones, the Galaxy S6 and S6 Edge, is Project Zero, signaling what Samsung calls a return to fundamentals.

description: Notes from the first visit.

title: Hillary Clinton Urges Veto of Arkansas Religious Freedom Bill
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton made a rare foray back into Arkansas politics on Wednesday, urging the states governor to veto a religious freedom bill similar to the one causing backlash in Indiana.

title: Krafts Real Calculus in the Deal With Heinz
description: Kraft shareholders must be a pretty satiated bunch. They awoke last Wednesday to discover they had become partners with the billionaire Warren E. Buffett and 3G Capital, the renowned Brazilian corporate fixers, while merging with the worlds leading condiments maker, H.J. Heinz.

title: App Smart | Tech News Thats Easy to Use
description: Technological advances can now help keep us informed about the latest technological advances. Appy Geek, PopSci and CNET all have easy-to-use interfaces that deliver the latest in tech news.

description: Dr. Hallers Notes

description: Dr. Rankins Notes

description: Scrubs and a brush to up your skin game.

title: For Boehner, Visit to Israel Isnt the Time to Speak Out
description: JERUSALEM  If the speaker of the House visits Israel and does not say anything substantive, does it have any effect on the troubled relations between Washington and Jerusalem?

title: Aftermath of Yemen Factory Explosion
description: An explosion at a dairy factory in Yemen killed dozens of workers, adding to a mounting civilian death toll in the Saudi-led campaign against Houthi militiamen.

title: Notes from Initial Doctor Visits
description: The Patients First Visit

title: ISIS Seizes New Territory in Deadly Attacks in Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Islamic State militants in Syria have seized new territory on multiple fronts in recent days, killing dozens of civilians in the central province of Hama, residents there said, and advancing on Wednesday into the chaotic Yarmouk district on the southern edge of Damascus.

title: Video Feature: Custom Filters to Sift the Torrent of Technology News
description: Keeping track of the latest news about technology and devices can be overwhelming. But many apps are built specifically to sort through the latest tech industry innovations for you.

title: Dr. Hallers Notes
description: Dr. Hallers Notes

title: Finding the Farce in Hitchcock, Again, The 39 Steps
description: The modest double digits in its title dont begin to capture the exponentially increasing numbers conjured by 39 Steps, in previews at the Union Square Theater. Since its British debut a decade ago, this delightfully dizzy little play  adapted from The 39 Steps, the 1935 Alfred Hitchcock film about love (and espionage) on the run  has divided and multiplied itself in ways that would shame an amoeba. It features a cast of four playing 150 characters, who pursue, run from and deceive one another on a basically bare stage that somehow feels incredibly crowded.

title: Dr. Rankins Notes
description: Dr. Rankins Notes

title: Dolce & Gabbana Earrings Fit for a Queen (Bee)
description: Where flowers bloom, bees follow. And so they do in Dolce & Gabbanas one-of-a-kind sculptural earrings that evoke summer in Sicily, Domenico Dolces birthplace. Each handcrafted pendant, part of the Italian houses rarefied Alta Gioielleria, or high jewelry, collection, begins with a daisy of faceted aquamarine petals, its center cut from golden beryl  a pure yellow gem known for its brilliant hue. A two-inch gold drone, a symbol of royalty and natures industriousness, dangles from the edge, seemingly sipping nectar. The bees head, legs and thorax are diamond-encrusted; its eyes are emeralds and its wings are fashioned of painstakingly formed filigree. Alternating bands of curved black jade and citrine create the stripes on the insects abdomen and a large, baroque South Sea pearl hangs from the bottom. They may not make honey, but they will turn heads.

title: Auto Sales Slow After Months of Healthy Growth
description: The optimism of automakers introducing models on Wednesday at the New York auto show was tempered by reports of flat sales in the United States last month.

title: 36 Hours in Lisbon
description: Explore street view, find things to do in Lisbon, and sign in to your Google account to save your map.

title: 36 Hours in Lisbon
description: Throughout this hilly city on the Tagus River, structures and spaces are being stylishly reborn, harboring chic boutiques, galleries and new spots for eating and drinking.

title: 36 Hours in Lisbon
description: Everything old is new again in the Portuguese capital. Throughout the hilly metropolis on the Tagus River, fading structures and spaces are being stylishly reborn. Once-forlorn neighborhood markets have undergone ambitious renovations and currently form the citys newest hot spots for dining and drinking. Formerly decrepit townhouses now harbor Lisbons chicest indie shopping centers, and the once-dodgy docklands boom with emergent night life in multiple guises. Even the citys dowdy, underused central square and adjacent waterfront have been spruced up for lounging and strolling. At the same time, the citys classic historical charms, from art museums to industrialists mansions, remain beautifully intact, complementing their rejuvenated neighbors.

title: Attack on GitHub Appears to Have Ended
description: One of the worlds great coding libraries is safe, for now.

title: Finding Respite on Basketball Court
description: Amid Kurdistans battle against ISIS, womens basketball at the American University of Iraq, Sulaimaniya, has provided a sense of continuity.

title: If an Expert in Day Care Cant Find a Good One, Can Anyone?
description: I am a professor of early childhood education and a former preschool teacher. My primary research interest is preschool and child care quality, and how families select preschool for their children. As a parent, though, I have been unsuccessful at finding a good preschool for my own child.

title: Adam Crapsers Bizarre Deportation Odyssey
description: This past February, U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement officers knocked on an apartment door in Vancouver, Wash., looking for a man named Adam Crapser. A 39-year-old former barbershop owner and auto-insurance claims estimator, Crapser was now the married stay-at-home father of three children, with another baby on the way. He lived a mostly quiet life, playing the guitar and ukulele, looking after a rescue dog and taking his children to the park and the science museum. But the ICE agents at the door were there to inform him that the agency was opening deportation proceedings that could send him to South Korea.

title: Harry Kane, Globalization and the Push to Limit Foreign Players in the Premier League
description: Last week, a 21-year-old soccer player named Harry Kane made a spectacular debut for Englands national team, scoring against Lithuania just 79 seconds after entering the game and then wheeling away with a look of joyous disbelief as a crowd of roughly 80,000 countrymen roared approval.

title: Russian Artists Face a Choice: Censor Themselves, or Else
description: MOSCOW  After a law went into effect last summer banning obscenities in public performances, the playwright and director Ivan Vyrypaev excised the curse words from one of his plays, The Drunks, for its Russian debut at the prestigious Moscow Art Theater. Some actors played the new version straight, he said, while others winked to make clear what was cut.

title: Norway Reverts to Cold War Mode as Russian Air Patrols Spike
description: BODO, Norway  From his command post burrowed deep into a mountain of quartz and slate north of the Arctic Circle, the 54-year-old commander of the Norwegian militarys operations headquarters watches time flowing backward, pushed into reverse by surging Russian military activity redolent of East-West sparring during the Cold War.

title: Next Stop for Chanel on Its Road Trip
description: Beyonc, Julianne Moore, Pharrell Williams and others at Chanels Paris-Salzburg Mtiers dArt show in New York.

title: The Limits of Tylenol for Pain Relief
description: Acetaminophen (Tylenol) is widely recommended for the relief of back pain and the pain of knee and hip arthritis. But a systematic review of randomized trials has found that it works no better than a placebo.

title: Buying Apartment Buildings in New York and Beyond in a Strategic Bet
description: When Luis Rinaldini, co-founder of Groton Merchant Bankers, wanted to add New York apartment buildings to the firms investment portfolio in 2010, he took a chance on two young college graduates to make it happen.

title: Bunny Business
description: The beguiling beauty and arduous hair-care regimen of the Angora rabbit.

title: Dutch Royal Family Acts Quickly After Looted Painting Is Found
description: Tracking down art looted during World War II usually takes decades. But the Dutch royal family achieved the feat in relatively record time: A 16-month investigation of the palace art collection identified a 17th-century painting that the family pledges will be returned to the descendants of the Jewish owner.

title: To Catch a Hacker
description: One reason American businesses and the government remain vulnerable to foreign hackers is that it is incredibly hard to arrest and prosecute those criminals. Responding to that difficulty, President Obama is giving the Treasury Department the power to issue financial sanctions against hackers and the people and businesses that hire them to conduct cyber attacks.

title: Arkansas Governor on Religious Bill
description: Gov. Asa Hutchinson of Arkansas said he was sending the Religious Freedom Restoration Act back to the legislature for revisions.

title: Mark Wahlberg to Help Produce Film on Boston Marathon Bombing
description: A film about the five-day manhunt after the Boston Marathon bombing in 2013 will be produced by a team that includes a son of the city, Mark Wahlberg, CBS Films announced Wednesday. The thriller is the second big-screen project in the works on the same subject.

title: Ready for Hillary Workers Are Ready to Join Campaign
description: Since Hillary Rodham Clinton left the State Department in early 2013, the main group pushing for her to make a second presidential run has been Ready for Hillary, a super PAC that signed up more than four million supporters and  through regular reports about such grass-roots fervor for Mrs. Clinton  helped freeze the Democratic field.

title: Atlanta Educators Convicted in School Cheating Scandal
description: ATLANTA  In a dramatic conclusion to what has been described as the largest cheating scandal in the nations history,a jury here on Wednesday convicted 11 educators for their roles in a standardized test cheating scandal that tarnished a major school districts reputation and raised broader questions about the role of high-stakes testing in American schools.

title: The PayPal Mafias Golden Touch
description: The ride-hailing app Uber, the apartment rental site Airbnb and other darlings of the next generation of Silicon Valley start-ups are reshaping the way people use the web. They are also changing expectations about just how much money private companies can raise while still staying out of the public markets.

title: Palestinians Join International Criminal Court, but Tread Cautiously at First
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  The Palestinians became members of the International Criminal Court on Wednesday, cementing the most significant and contentious step so far in their new strategy of seeking statehood through international forums.

title: Arkansas Governors Son Thrust Into Spotlight Over Religious Exception Bill
description: When Gov. Asa Hutchinson, Republican of Arkansas, spoke on Wednesday about the future of what proponents call the religious freedom bill pending in his state, he disclosed that the proposal had drawn resistance from a particularly noteworthy critic: his son, Seth Hutchinson.

title: Prosecutors Ease Crackdown onBuyers of China-Bound Luxury Cars
description: A luxury car exporters nearly two-year legal battle to recover a Porsche Cayenne and $120,786 seized by United States authorities has ended with federal prosecutors in South Carolina agreeing to return the property and drop a civil forfeiture lawsuit.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Furious 7
description: James Wan narrates a sequence from Furious 7.

title: This Just In: Behind the News Alert
description: When big news breaks  a plane crash, election results, the death of a major figure  the decision to send a news alert is easy. Editors on the News Desk coordinate with editors running the coverage to decide when to send the alert and what it will say. Speed is key, but accuracy is even more important.

title: At the Jewish Museum of Vienna, Enduring Images of Europe
description: Erich Lessing is one of the foremost chroniclers of 20th-century Europe, known equally well for photographing politicians like Charles de Gaulle, Eastern Bloc beauty queens, and daily life  a bar mitzvah boy in postwar Poland, a tailor in front of his war-damaged store.

title: The Rise of the Unicorns
description: Venture capitalists invest in companies in search of breakout hits. These rarities, called unicorns, have grown in size and number as investors chasing returns have bid up their value.

title: Furious 7 (With Movie Trailer): James Wan Discusses Paul Walker and Narrates a Scene
description: With Furious 7, the director James Wan takes a break from the horror films for which hes known (Insidious The Conjuring) to try pure action. In this video, he discussed an exhilarating, slightly crazy scene. Mr. Wan also touched on working with Paul Walker and finishing the film after Mr. Walkers death in 2013. Here are excerpts from that conversation.

title: California Imposes First Mandatory Water Restrictions to Deal With Drought
description: PHILLIPS, Calif.  Gov. Jerry Brown on Wednesday ordered mandatory water use reductions for the first time in Californias history, saying the states four-year drought had reached near-crisis proportions after a winter of record-low snowfalls.

title: John D. States Dies at 89; Doctor Helped Create New Yorks Seatbelt Law
description: Dr. John D. States, whose research and advocacy persuaded New York in 1984 to enact the nations first state law requiring drivers and front-seat passengers to use automobile seatbelts, died on March 26 in the Rochester hospital where he was born. He was 89.

title: Review: In Furious 7, a Franchise Continues to Roar
description: In a recent interview in Variety, Vin Diesel predicted that Furious 7 would win the best picture Oscar at next years Academy Awards. Unless the Oscars dont want to be relevant ever, he added, though that issue may already be settled. If Mr. Diesels prophecy doesnt come true, it wont necessarily be a matter of merit. Movies much worse than this lucky-number episode of an overachieving franchise  movies far less sure of their intentions, sincere in their themes or kind to their audiences  have snapped up statuettes. There will no doubt be better movies released in 2015, but Furious 7 is an early favorite to win the prize for most picture.

title: Political Thunder Over the Iran Deal
description: With a preliminary deal limiting Irans nuclear program apparently in the endgame, opponents are using political thunder to substitute for real information about whats going on inside the closed-door negotiations.

title: Russia Shuts Down TV Station Serving Crimean Tatars
description: MOSCOW  Russia pulled the plug on the last independent television station serving Crimean Tatars on Wednesday, continuing what members of the Tatar minority called a pattern of discrimination because of their opposition to Russias annexation of the Black Sea peninsula.

title: Yes, Your Time as a Parent Does Make a Difference
description: The latest salvo in the mommy wars is that all that time you spend parenting just doesnt matter. But its a claim that, despite the enthusiastic and widespread coverage by news media outlets that include The Washington Post, Vox, The Guardian, The Independent, The Globe and Mail, NBC News, The Chicago Tribune and The New York Timess Motherlode, does not hold water.

title: Ideas for E.L.L.s | Teaching and Learning About Work and Careers
description: What do I want to be when I get older? What career would I excel at? How will I get a job?

title: Karl Lagerfeld Brings Chanels Salzburg to New York
Karl Lagerfeld Brings Chanels Salzburg to New York
description: At Chanels New York staging of its Paris-Salzburg Mtiers dArt show, the designer Karl Lagerfeld, center, had a laugh with Lily Collins, left, and the singer Banks. He never does anything halfway, Ms. Collins said of Mr. Lagerfeld. See more photos here.

title: A Quick Point Guards Unconventional Path to UConn
description: Lorenza Jefferson was listening to a Christian radio station in the late 1990s when the hosts began talking about home schooling. He had never heard of the concept, but it intrigued him.

title: Common Will Not Give Commencement Speech, Kean University Says
description: A New Jersey university has retracted its announcement that the socially conscious rapper Common would give the commencement speech at the schools graduation ceremony in May following an outcry from police officials over a 15-year-old song.

title: The Scrambled States of Immigration
description: A country that has abandoned all efforts at creating a saner immigration policy has gotten the result it deserves: not one policy but lots of little ones, acting at cross purposes and nullifying one another. Not unity but cacophony, a national incoherence  one well illustrated in a recent report in The Times on the various ways the states, forsaken by Congress, are adjusting to the millions of unauthorized immigrants living outside the law.

title: A Haven Between the Hoops in Kurdistan
description: The invasion by the Islamic State, or ISIS, last summer brought tremendous heartache to Kurdistan, the autonomous region in northern Iraq. Thousands of members of the pesh merga, the Kurdish security forces, have been killed and injured, and government employees and teachers have not been paid in months. The future is uncertain. But in Sulaimaniya, a city of about 1.5 million near the Iranian border, things might be looking up for young women.

title: A Puzzle-Solvers Paradise
description: Highlights from the 38th annual American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, which ran March 27-29, 2015.

title: Oil Glut Is a Boon to Shippers, as Buyers Stock Up at Low Prices
description: LONDON  Jonathan Lee has spent 30 years in the shipping business. But he was as excited as a rookie over the scene on his screen one recent day here at the international nerve center of his oil tanker chartering and dispatching company.

title: 13 Weeks at No. 1 for Uptown Funk
description: Mark Ronsons Uptown Funk has dominated the Billboard singles chart since the beginning of 2015, and this week it notches a remarkable 13th time at No. 1. That is the longest run for any song since 2009, when Black Eyed Peas I Gotta Feeling was tops for 14 weeks straight.

title: Religious Freedom vs. Individual Equality
description: Indianas governor is now vowing to clarify a religious freedom law he recently signed in that state, because of what he calls a perception problem about whether the legislation would allow open discrimination against people whose sexual identities defy the heteronormative construct.

title: Purvi Patel Could Be Just the Beginning
description: The prosecution of Purvi Patel began in sorrow and ended in more sadness this week. Patel, a 33-year-old woman who lives in Indiana, was accused of feticide  specifically, illegally inducing her own abortion  and accused of having a baby whom she allowed to die. The facts supporting each count are murky, but a jury convicted Patel in February, and on Monday she was sentenced to 20 years in prison.

title: Senator Robert Menendez Indicted on Corruption Charges
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey was indicted on bribery charges on Wednesday in what prosecutors said was a scheme to trade political favors for luxury vacations, golf outings, campaign donations and expensive flights.

title: HSBC Is Deemed Slow to Carry Out Changes
description: HSBC, the giant British bank accused of laundering money for drug cartels and transferring funds for Iran and other blacklisted nations, avoided criminal prosecution in 2012 by promising to clean up its act.

title: Californias Extreme Drought, Explained
description: California is experiencing the worst drought in its history, and the effects are being felt nationwide.

title: A Presidential Meow
At 38, Vince Carter Drifts to the 3-Point Line and Reinvents Himself
description: MEMPHIS  Vince Carter began to lose his hair when he was about 23, but he still goes to the barber with specific instructions. Last week, he wanted his beard trimmed.

title: McDonalds to Raise Pay at Outlets It Operates
description: McDonalds announced on Wednesday that it would raise wages and offer new benefits to 90,000 employees in the 1,500 outlets in the United States that it owns and operates, responding to competitive pressure from a tighter job market and to labor campaigns drawing public attention to its pay policies.

title: A Puzzle Solvers Paradise
description: Highlights from the last day of the 38th annual American Crossword Puzzle Tournament.

title: Whitney Museum Contemplates a Bigger Future, With Bigger Expenses
description: The galleries are immense, the Renzo Piano design is arresting and the views of the Hudson River are expansive. As it prepares to open its new $422 million Lower Manhattan home on May 1, the Whitney Museum of American Art is pulsing with anticipation as it plans the inaugural events, including a neighborhood block party.

title: Tech Leaders Call for Anti-Discrimination Laws to Protect Gays in all 50 States
description: Technology leaders are looking beyond an Indiana battle over gay rights that united them in the past week, and are calling on all states to enact anti-discrimination protections for lesbians, gay, bisexual and transgender people.

title: New York Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Parking Rules Suspended on Thursday
description: Because of Holy Thursday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Thursday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Menendez Said to Take Hiatus From Foreign Relations Committee
description: Senator Robert Menendez Indicted on Corruption Charges

title: Review: Dennis Lehanes World Gone By Completes a Loose Trio of Novels
description: When The Given Day arrived in 2008, Dennis Lehane described his 704-page magnum opus as the beginning of a possible trilogy. Thats not exactly how things worked out. Instead of sequels, he wound up producing a very loosely linked trio, adding on Live by Night (2012) and now World Gone By. Each is written very differently: first, a research-filled epic; then a lean, classic Edgar-winning specimen of 1930s crime noir; and now a suspenseful but reflective accumulation of all the wisdom these books have offered.

title: Filing on HSBC Compliance
description: The British bank that reached a $1.9 billion settlement to resolve accusations of money laundering still has a long way to go to root out the problems, federal prosecutors say.

title: Climate of Anxiety in Russia
description: Cultural figures in Russia react to laws banning obscenities.

title: Dear Winter Coat: Goodbye and Good Riddance
description: Dear Winter Coat:

title: Spring Vegetables for Passover
description: Home chefs are always looking for a way to add color and flavor to the Passover table. Weve chosen these spring vegetable recipes from Martha Rose Shulman to add to your family traditions.

title: Klaus Tschira, Business Software Trailblazer, Dies at 74
description: Klaus E. Tschira, whose pioneering role in the business software revolution made him one of Germanys richest men, died on Tuesday in Heidelberg. He was 74.

title: Hongdae Style in Seoul
description: When I come to Hongdae, I get inspired just by seeing people on the street, Mina Kwon, an illustrator, said of the hip neighborhood in Seoul, South Korea. Its kind of like Harajuku in Japan. Wearing a Vivienne Westwood jacket, stacked bracelets, a snapback from D9 (a label she designs for) and Timberland boots, Ms. Kwon also gets style ideas from Pharrell Williams. Recently she also did a collection for Forever 21 that includes her street-style take on SpongeBob. This interview has been edited and condensed.

title: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Iraq, Nigeria, Indonesia and Brazil

title: Review: Alexi Kenney at Weill Recital Hall
description: Some musicians take extra care preparing the first bars of a concerts opening piece, to ensure a flawless start to the evening. It certainly sounded as if the violinist Alexi Kenney had done so at Weill Recital Hall on Tuesday evening, immediately drawing listeners in with his beautifully phrased and delicate playing in the first-movement Allemande of Johann Paul von Westhoffs Suite No. 2 in A for solo violin.

title: Winning Defense at the Spring Nationals
description: There were two particularly meritorious defensive plays during the Spring Nationals in New Orleans last month.

title: For Players, Tournament Excitement Gives Way to Morning Classes
description: For the teams headed to Indianapolis this week, the three-week journey to the Final Four is the culmination of an odyssey that began last fall.

title: ClassPass:Deep Discounts, but Some Discontent
description: ClassPass  the two-year-old service that for $99 a month grants members access to a slew of boutique fitness studios  is wildly popular, with class reservations booked in New York City increasing threefold in the last six months.

title: April 1, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Iraq, Nigeria, Indonesia and Brazil.

title: Trailer: Gamera
description: The 1963 Kaiju film was created to compete with the Godzilla franchise.

title: Morgan Stanleys James Gorman Gets 25% Raise
description: Morgan Stanleys chief executive, James Gorman, received a 25 percent raise for 2014, bringing his total compensation to $22.5 million.

title: Review: Sinatra, Alex Gibneys New HBO Documentary, Explores a Legend
description: Few people have led a more examined life than Frank Sinatra did, so a documentarian taking on the subject needs a distinctive approach. Alex Gibney (who also directed the recently-aired Scientology documentary Going Clear) finds at least a somewhat successful one for Sinatra: All or Nothing at All, which has its premiere Sunday and Monday nights on HBO. Still, theres no disguising that the story is awfully familiar.

title: Verbatim: Booker Stands With Menendez
description: Senator Cory Booker, Democrat of New Jersey, on the indictment of his colleague, Senator Robert Menendez.

title: Play Reimagining Threes Company Wins Case
description: A federal judge in New York ruled on Tuesday that the Off Broadway play 3C, a darkly comic reimagining of the TV hit Threes Company, did not infringe the copyright of that decades-old sitcom. In the ruling, Judge Loretta A. Preska of the United States District Court wrote that the play represented a drastic departure from the TV show, which ran from 1977 to 1984 and remains in syndication.

title: Subrosa, a Latin Beat in the Meatpacking District
description: Before the trendy hotels moved in, the meatpacking district was a curious place, with hidden spots behind its battered industrial visage. Sebastian Nicolas, 35, an original partner from the Box, the burlesque club on the Lower East Side, hopes to bring a little of that mystery back with a live music listening room called Subrosa.

title: The Beard Goes Technicolor
description: Has the beard become such a hipster clich that some wearers now need an embellishment to set them apart from every other 20-something with scruffy facial hair?

title: Review: Liz Gerrings Glacier Has Its New York Premiere
description: The eight dancers in Liz Gerrings Glacier keep changing its temperature. At first, the mood is clinical. Dancers walk, run, balance, fall; theyre often on the cusp of pedestrianism. Since much of the movement is big  and some of it is sports-related  thats already arresting. But a kinesthetic impetus soon develops, and this becomes full-bodied dancing that changes my breathing.

title: Staten Island Ferry to Add More Early Morning Trips
description: The Staten Island Ferry is a step closer to running every half-hour around the clock, easing travel for early morning riders.

title: British Challenger Bank Shawbrook Valued at $1 Billion in I.P.O.
description: The Shawbrook Group, the latest challenger to Britains traditional banks to go public, said on Wednesday that it has priced its initial public offering, valuing the company at 725 million pounds, or about $1 billion.

title: Lucy Lawless Brings a Defiant Edge to Salem
description: For its first scripted series last year, WGN America went all in on out-there with Salem, a witchy tale that rivaled American Horror Story in its willingness to be audacious. Few who saw the pilot will forget the scene in which a naked Mary Sibley helped her husband vomit up a frog. With Season 2 beginning on Sunday, how does the channel plan on upping the ante?

title: A New Exhibition Celebrates Le Corbusier, Through the Eyes of Those He Influenced
description: Re-Corbusier, a new exhibition in Paris featuring international artists, explores the influence of the Modernist Swiss architect through others creations. The show, which coincides with the 50th anniversary of Le Corbusiers death, serves as an imaginative counterpoint to the career survey of the architects work that will begin at the Centre Pompidou later this month. Theres a variety in medium, and in generation, the curator Marjolaine Lvy says of the selection. Most pieces are part of a series; these arent one-off works, the co-curator Catherine de Smet adds, which corroborates the artists attraction to Le Corbusiers work.

title: The Indictment of Senator Robert Menendez
description: Mr. Menendez was charged with eight counts of bribery, which carry up to 15 years in prison on each charge.

title: Brunello Cucinelli Clothes Can Make You a Better Man. Provided Youre Very, Very Rich.
description: You never quite know when manhood will arrive, but most certainly, it happens to you before youre aware of it. There are the demands that need to be met, the hands that need to be held, the wisdom that needs to be imparted.

title: Scrapbooking Our Children Into Facebook
description: Its official  or at least, you can now make it official: Your baby can have her own Facebook page.

title: Love and Loss on the Road to Arkansas
description: Nina Robinsons plans for a fun Southern road trip took a detour when her grandmother died. She ended up delving deep into the rituals and routines of her family.

title: A Friendly Pillow Fight, Worldwide
description: It might be the worlds largest flash mob. On Saturday, April 4, tens of thousands of people in more than 100 cities worldwide will take to the streets, feathers flying, for the seventh annual International Pillow Fight Day. This years event includes cities across four continents, from Shanghai to Seattle, Buenos Aires to Budapest.

title: Axwell and Ingrosso at Terminal 5
description: The Swedish electronic dance music maestros played a sold-out show on March 30.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Officials on Iran Nuclear Negotiations
description: Mohammad Javad Zarif, Irans foreign minister, and Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, discussed the status of talks on Iranians nuclear program.

title: Yukos Investors Settle With Rosneft, Russias State Oil Company
description: Yukos, the defunct Russian oil giant whose dismantling a decade ago came to define a countrys flawed property rights system, announced on Wednesday that it had reached a final legal settlement with Rosneft, the state oil company that prospered from the breakup.

title: The D.J. Maestros Axwell and Ingrosso Aim to Shake the Rafters
description: The Swedish D.J.s and producers Axwell and Sebastian Ingrosso, known lately as the duo Axwell and Ingrosso, hid in the immaculate bowels of the Apple Store in SoHo earlier this week, plotting their escape.

title: Liquidity Traps, Local and Global (Somewhat Wonkish)
description: Theres been a really interesting back and forth between Ben Bernanke and Larry Summers over secular stagnation. I agree with most of what both have to say. But theres a substantive difference in views, in which Bernanke correctly, Id argue, criticizes Summers for insufficient attention to international capital flows  but then argues that once you do allow for international capital movement it obviates many of the secular stagnation concerns, which I believe is wrong.

title: Reviewing Sound Bars: An Alternative to TV Home Theater Systems
description: WHEN it comes to great television sound, thin is definitely not in.

title: In a Nod to Past and Future, Clinton Pushes Child Development in Brooklyn
description: For one of her final events before she makes her 2016 presidential campaign official, Hillary Rodham Clinton returned to the cause that started her career in public service: children.

title: A Closer Look at the Details
description: Carlos Quirartes two-room apartment is filled with light and found items.

title: Former I.R.S. Official Wont Be Charged for Refusing to Testify
description: WASHINGTON  Federal prosecutors have concluded that Lois Lerner, a former Internal Revenue Service official, should not be charged for refusing to answer questions before a congressional committee about the agencys improper treatment of conservative groups seeking tax-exempt status, the Justice Department said on Wednesday.

title: Concord Music Group Buys Vanguard and Sugar Hill
description: In an expansion of one of the worlds largest independent music companies, the Concord Music Group  home to Paul McCartney, Paul Simon and a catalog of classic jazz and soul recordings  announced Wednesday that it had acquired two record labels, Vanguard and Sugar Hill.

title: Denim Jackets That Are Far From Old-Fashioned and More
description: The classic jean jacket gets a makeover; post-winter fur; mixing girlish frills with tougher edges; and a fun way to wear summer platforms now.

title: Review: Death Cab for Cuties Kintsugi
description: Desertion  inseparable from its aftermath of recovery  haunts Kintsugi (Atlantic), the eighth album by Death Cab for Cutie. Titled after the Japanese art of mending cracked ceramics with precious metals, its a smartly shaped response to two recent disentanglements, at least one of which seems to have left a residue of trauma.

title: Trevor Noah Learns Twitter Just Cant Take a Joke
description: IN 2002, at a coffee shop in one of San Franciscos less-charming neighborhoods, I stood in front of 10 or 12 people and told a joke about AIDS. It got a laugh. After I delivered it, as I segued into a searing analysis of Destinys Child, I noticed a guy at a table with a Kaposis sarcoma on his forehead. When I was writing that AIDS joke, I figured since I was gay, it was fine for me to talk about AIDS, but in context, looking at the joke through the eyes of my audience, I realized it wasnt something I wanted to do again.

title: California Governor Imposes Water Order
description: Gov. Jerry Brown announced a sweeping executive order that imposes Californias first mandatory water restrictions as the states drought has reached near-crisis proportions.

title: Turkish Police Foil Attack on Police Station
description: ISTANBUL  A day after a Turkish prosecutor was taken hostage and killed in an attack on Istanbuls main courthouse by leftist extremists, the police on Wednesday thwarted another attack, killing a woman in a shootout near the citys central police station.

title: Looking for Cheaper Skin-Care Products? Borrow From the Men
description: Jennifer Quinn, 25, a digital marketing specialist who lives on the Upper East Side with her boyfriend, Ramine Bigdeliazari, was in the shower about six months ago when she ran out of her LOccitane Aromachologie Revitalizing Body Scrub. So she tried her boyfriends Blue Sea Kelp Body Scrub, by the mens brand Anthony.

title: Shopping Events and Sales Happening This Week in New York
description: Bummed about the lingering chill? Stop into the new shopping mall Brookfield Place, where the first 14 stores  including Diane von Furstenberg, Michael Kors, Tory Burch, Paul Smith and Vince  are now open, to stock up on pieces for when the weather finally turns. At 230 Vesey Street. ... The luxury watch brand IWC Schaffhausen is auctioning an IWC Portofino Monopusher Tribeca Film Festival white gold timepiece through Christies, along with a Money-Cant-Buy Tribeca Film Festival Experience that includes V.I.P. access to the festival and hotel accommodation. At christies.com/iwctribeca.

title: Suits That Move
description: Zachary Catazaro and Joshua Thew, both New York City Ballet dancers, donned a few of the freest-wheeling suits.

title: In Four Loops, Marathon Conveys Palestinian Constraints
description: BETHLEHEM, West Bank  The runners looped four times through this city, following a route that took them from the Church of the Nativity, traditionally considered Christs birthplace, down Bethlehems main avenue and alongside Israels looming separation barrier, scrawled with graffiti and blackened from hurled projectiles.

title: Cruz, in Iowa, Commends Indiana for Doing the Right Thing
description: SIOUX CITY, Iowa  The more than 100 people who showed up for a town-hall-style event at Morningside College here on Wednesday heard Senators Ted Cruzs thoughts on the battle over a law in Indiana billed as a religious freedom measure.

title: C.F.T.C. Accuses Kraft and Mondelez of Manipulating Wheat Prices
description: Less than a week after agreeing to sell itself to H.J. Heinz in a blockbuster deal, the Kraft Foods Group has found itself the target of a government lawsuit over wheat prices.

title: Backlash Against Indiana Religious Exceptions
description: The Indiana law has touched off a storm of protests from businesses, local governments and college athletics.

title: Verbatim: Menendez Repeats, Im Not Going Anywhere
description: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey saying at a press conference on Wednesday what he said earlier this month when it was learned that criminal corruption charges were likely: He began his career fighting corruption and he is not going anywhere.

title: How Has the California Drought Affected You?
description: Gov. Jerry Brown ordered mandatory water restrictions for the first time in California history. How will water rationing affect you?

title: S.E.C. Fires Warning Shot About Confidentiality Agreements
description: A sound that delights regulators and strikes fear in corporations  employees blowing the whistle on wrongdoing  is poised to become louder.

title: Nigerian President-Elect Muhammadu Buhari Sets Out His Agenda
description: KANO, Nigeria  Nigerias president-elect, Muhammadu Buhari, did not smile while making his acceptance speech on Wednesday  understandably, as terrorism and corruption were his main talking points.

title: Cynthia Lennon, the First Beatles Wife, Dies at 75
description: Cynthia Lennon, the first wife of the Beatles John Lennon, who chronicled their troubled marriage in two memoirs, died on Wednesday at her home in Mallorca, Spain. She was 75.

title: 560,000-Acre Swath of Florida Land Going on the Market
description: The largest contiguous parcel of undeveloped private land east of the Mississippi River, a vast swath of forest in northern Florida, is going on the market and is expected to bring $1 billion or more when it is sold this year.

title: EBay Begins Streaming Live Sothebys Auctions
description: The buildup was intense. Since July, when Sothebys struck a deal with eBay to have its auctions carried live, the marriage of the blue-blood auction house to the blue-collar online retailer had generated tingles of anticipation. But on Wednesday, when eBay streamed Sothebys auctions for the first time, the event could not have been more sedate, more like a day at the library than a cut-and-thrust bidding war over Cameoware dishes.

title: Tom Koch, 89, Dies; Comedy Writer Invented a 43-Man Game
description: Tom Koch, a creator of the vexingly convoluted game 43-man Squamish for Mad magazine and unheralded author of thousands of comedy scripts for Bob and Ray radio programs that in his words parodied pompous versions of real people, died on March 22 at his home in Laguna Woods, Calif. He was 89.

title: New Stumble in Trial of Former Goldman Programmer
description: The long-running case against Sergey Aleynikov  a former Goldman Sachs programmer criminally convicted, and then acquitted, only to be charged again  has rarely seemed to bring out the best in his government accusers. Take Wednesday, which was set to be the first day of Mr. Aleynikovs new trial.

title: California Drought Is Worsened by Global Warming, Scientists Say
description: The severe California drought that has led the state to order cutbacks in water use may not have been set off by climate change, scientists say, but global warming is making the situation worse.

title: Chris Mullin, Back Where He Starred, Basks in the Glow of a St. Johns Reunion
