description: After talking for nearly two hours  at a formal news conference in front of 1,000 fans, during interviews carried on a dozen television stations and while being photographed with trustees, boosters and the St. Johns mascot  Chris Mullin walked alone through a corridor of Carnesecca Arena and found one of the few faces he did not know.

title: Doubts Intensify About Reports of a Video Made During Germanwings Flights Final Moments
description: It has been described as the chilling final seconds of blurry pandemonium before the crash, with metallic banging and passengers screaming, My God! in multiple languages, captured on a cellphone video shot from the rear of the cabin.

title: New York Detective Put on Desk Duty After Tirade With Uber Driver
description: A veteran New York police detective has been placed on desk duty for an angry, profanity-laced tirade he delivered Monday to an Uber driver he confronted while driving on-duty in Manhattan.

title: 4 Killed in Explosion and Fire on Pemex Mexican Oil Platform
description: Huge fireballs illuminated the early dawn skies of the Gulf of Mexico on Wednesday as an explosion and fire killed four people and injured as many as 16 others on a large oil platform in the southeastern Bay of Campeche, Mexican officials said.

title: Walmart Emerges as Unlikely Social Force
description: Walmart, which has deployed its financial might to squeeze extra gallons of gas out of its trucks and shave pennies off the price of laundry detergent, did something unexpected this week: It muscled its way into a divisive social debate.

title: Mets Have Strange Feeling: Confidence
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets were trailing by three runs in the bottom of the ninth inning in a meaningless exhibition game Wednesday when the reserve players began a rally and the starters began shouting in excitement at the clubhouse televisions, urging them on.

title: Hillary Clinton Joins Chirlane McCray to Promote Child Care Effort in New York
description: The guests spoke of early motherhood, recalling the songs they once sang to their children, and asked others at the education center in Brownsville, Brooklyn, to do the same.

title: A Nuclear Deal With Iran Isnt Just About Bombs
description: To prove that Americans can be every bit as crazy as Iranians, I took my daughter along on my last trip to Iran, in 2012, for a road trip across the country.

title: Arkansas Moves to Revise Legislation as Concerns of Religion and Gay Rights Intensify
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  Facing a backlash from businesses and gay rights advocates, Gov. Asa Hutchinson of Arkansas on Wednesday urged lawmakers to rework legislation billed as a religious freedom measure to ensure that it mirrors federal law.

title: Jeb Bush Seems to Shift Tone in His Praise of Indiana Law
description: Jeb Bush appeared to modify his public comments about Indianas religious freedom law on Wednesday in a closed-door Silicon Valley fund-raiser, telling a small group of potential supporters that a consensus-oriented approach would have been better at the outset.

title: As Lydia Ko Turns 18, She Hopes to Celebrate With a Major Title
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  Before the world No. 1 womens golfer, Lydia Ko, got to work Wednesday on the range, she settled a piece of business. Ko took a $10 bill out of her wallet and approached the caddie Mardi Lunn, a native Australian. Using a black permanent marker, Ko, a Korean-born New Zealander, neatly wrote Go NZ on the back of the bill, signed her name and drew a kiwi, the bird that is a symbol of New Zealand.

title: The Netherlands: New Details on Date of Anne Franks Death
description: The young Holocaust diarist Anne Frank most likely died a month earlier than previously believed, the Frank museum in Amsterdam has concluded. Tuesday was 70 years since March 31, 1945, when she was thought to have died at the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp in Germany. The timing of her death, from typhus, was established by the Dutch Red Cross, which visited the camp after it was liberated by British soldiers on April 15, 1945. Using new witness testimony and documentation related to Anne and her sister, Margot, including a transport list from Feb. 7, 1945, the museum now believes the two sisters died in February, Erika Prins, a researcher at the museum, said Wednesday.

title: Another Arrangement
description: THURSDAY PUZZLE  I truly hope youre not sick of hearing about the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, because were not done yet. Yes, the big boards have been put away, and Im still working on another photo feature called Humans of A.C.P.T., but in the meantime, above are some highlights from Puzzle 7.

title: Agent Was Secretly Investigated During Silk Road Trial
description: The trial of Ross W. Ulbricht on charges he ran Silk Road, a website that allowed people to engage anonymously in drug dealing and other illicit activities, was widely watched in Federal District Court in Manhattan. Mr. Ulbricht was convicted in February and now faces a potential life sentence.

title: What Is Morgellons? Singer Joni Mitchells Disputed Diagnosis
description: Joni Mitchell, 71, was taken to a hospital in Los Angeles on Tuesday after she was found unconscious at her Los Angeles home. In recent years, the singer has complained of a number of health problems, including one particularly unusual ailment: Morgellons disease.

title: Gettys Again Made to Cope With Grief in Public Eye
description: LOS ANGELES  The curious death of Andrew R. Getty on Tuesday at his gated hillside mansion here has once again thrust one of Americas wealthiest and most-troubled families into an unwanted spotlight.

title: Injuries Spur Unplanned Infield Shift for Yankees
description: TAMPA, Fla.  As shortstop Brendan Ryan slid toward second base to field a grounder during the Yankees exhibition game Wednesday against the Rays, second baseman Stephen Drew heard Ryan shout. So by the time the ball bounced off Ryans bare hand, Drew knew something was wrong.

title: Is Yemen America's Fight?
How Has the Drought Affected Californias Water Use?
description: An interactive map shows how much water California residents conserved in April and how much daily consumption they are being forced to cut under new mandatory restrictions.

title: Rights Measures Expose Divisions in G.O.P.s Ranks
description: WASHINGTON  In Indiana, the Republican mayor of Indianapolis argued against the law the Republican governor had signed. In Ohio, a group called the Young Conservatives for the Freedom to Marry tried to remove antigay language from the party platform. In Arkansas, the Republican governor faced a backlash from business and asked the Republican-led legislature to recall a bill seen as discriminatory to same-sex couples.

title: Mets Among Major League Leaders in at Least One Category
description: The Mets off-season was essentially devoid of splashy moves, as the front office chose to make judicious upgrades in the outfield while looking to an existing core of players  some veterans, some fairly new to the majors  to improve on a 79-83 record.

title: Luxury Public Golf Course, Run by Trump, Opens on Former Bronx Dump
description: After decades of debate, false starts and cost overruns, luxury golf finally arrived in the Bronx on Wednesday, as the Trump Golf Links at Ferry Point opened in the shadow of the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge.

title: Damion Hardys Murder Trial Begins, After 10 Years of Sanity Arguments
description: In the decade since federal authorities arrested Damion Hardy and charged him with leading a Brooklyn drug crew and ordering six murders, lawyers have argued over one main issue: Is Mr. Hardy mentally competent to stand trial?

title: Nets Keep Surging Toward Playoffs; Knicks Keep Sinking to Bottom
description: On the Nets second possession Wednesday night, Markel Brown went up high after a lob pass and came down hard, after the Knicks Langston Galloway nudged him midflight. Brown writhed on the court for several minutes, through a timeout. It looked bad. The Madison Square Garden crowd was even quieter than usual.

title: The Americans Recap: The Moment Finally Arrives
description: Season 3, Episode 10: Stingers

title: Broadchurch Season 2 Episode 5 Recap: The Center Collapses
description: Season 2, Episode 5

title: Clip: Felix & Meira
description: A scene from the film featuring Hadas Yaron and Luzer Twersky.

title: Kentuckys Big Blue Machine Is Ready to Refuel
description: Isaiah Briscoe did not have to be there. His Roselle Catholic High School team had just won the New Jersey high school boys championship less than 48 hours earlier. The season was officially over. He had a busy travel schedule of all-star tournaments and events coming up over the next week, so it was a natural time to finally relax  to not touch a basketball for a week or so.

title: With Playoffs in Sight, Islanders Correct Their Course
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  From coach to captain, the Islanders are a relieved group, after a comeback victory over the Detroit Red Wings on Sunday ended a monthlong home losing streak.

title: Landlords Lawyer Blames Con Ed in East Village Explosion
description: A lawyer for the owner of two of the buildings in Manhattans East Village that were destroyed by a deadly explosion last week tried to deflect blame away from the landlord on Wednesday and toward Consolidated Edison, the utility company that provided gas to the buildings.

title: In Monaco, Alain Ducasse Gives His Favorite Restaurant a Massive Makeover
description: Today, the restaurant where chef Alain Ducasse won three Michelin stars for the first time, Le Louis XV, reopens with a new look, a new menu and a new name. Even in Monaco, the glittery Mediterranean principality where cosmetic surgery is a casual form of art, it rates as a dazzling makeover.

title: Amuse-Bouche
description: ON A WINTRY DAY in March, a pair of French expats could be seen shrieking in front of a small storefront on Eighth Avenue in New York. The picture window was filled with varicolored confections that, to the uninformed passerby, looked sort of like elegant Hostess Sno Balls: some bite-size, others large enough to share. But to pastry aficionados and French visitors, the implication was unmistakable: The cult of the merveilleux had finally reached America.

title: Photographic Notes From Underground
description: In this weekly series, Ts photo editors share the most compelling visual projects theyve discovered.

title: Word of the Day | fallible
description: fallible  \fa-l-bl\  adjective

title: James Wood Dies at 85; Revived A.&P. Supermarket Chain
description: James Wood, a British-born executive who prevented one of Americas best-known supermarket chains from, in his words, slipping into oblivion in the 1980s, died on March 26 at his home in New York City. He was 85.

title: Whats on TV Thursday
description: 1:15 P.M. (Starz Cinema) IN AMERICA (2003) With their entire lives packed into a groaning station wagon, Johnny (Paddy Considine), an Irish actor, and his wife, Sarah (Samantha Morton), enter the United States from Canada illegally and try to start over in a battered walk-up apartment in New York after the death of their young son. In this drama, directed by Jim Sheridan, Djimon Hounsou is Mateo, a reclusive painter dying of what seems to be AIDS and is befriended one Halloween by Johnny and Sarahs daughters. Mr. Sheridan (My Left Foot) wrote the film with his own two daughters, Naomi and Kirsten Sheridan, and all three received Oscar nominations, as did Ms. Morton and Mr. Hounsou. This movie, from moment to moment, feels small, almost anecdotal, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. It is only afterward that, like Mr. Sheridans other films, it starts to grow into something at once unassuming and in its own way grand.

title: Q. and A.: Michael Schuman on the Return of Confucianism in China
description: As a veteran correspondent and resident of Beijing, Michael Schuman has witnessed the growing use of the Confucius brand by the Chinese Communist Party in recent years. And he has seen Confucian values manifested in a variety of ways across Asia, where he has reported widely for Time magazine and The Wall Street Journal.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: People should realize we are in a new era. The idea of your nice little green lawn getting watered every day, those days are past.

title: Corrections: April 2, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Love and Loss on the Road to Arkansas
description: When Nina Robinson traveled from New York to Arkansas last October, she had big plans.

title: The State of Scott Walker
description: To the Editor:

title: Military Aid for Egypt
description: To the Editor:

title: President Obamas Letter to 22 Prisoners
description: On Tuesday, 22 people serving sentences of decades or life for nonviolent drug crimes in federal prisons across the country received a personal letter from President Obama, commuting their sentences and ordering their release in late July.

title: Indiana Loses Its Game
description: Last year Indiana chose Honest to Goodness Indiana as its new tourism slogan. Not everyone was charmed. Some critics said theyd have preferred something more cosmopolitan. Although it doesnt seem likely theyd be happier with the runners-up, one of which was Seasoned Just Right.

title: Religious Freedom vs. Discrimination
Students and Parents in the Dark
description: The Department of Education took a step toward transparency this week when it released a partial list of nearly 560 colleges and universities  the majority of them for-profit institutions  that have been placed under student-aid restrictions because of concerns about their finances and their compliance with federal law. But its failure to release all the names is a clear disservice to students who may end up applying to colleges that might be on the verge of shutting down.

title: Our Land, Up for Grabs
description: San FRANCISCO  A BATTLE is looming over Americas public lands.

title: Test Yourself | Here Comes Generation Z
description: Here are several paragraphs from a March 28 article, Make Way for Generation Z.

title: Explosion at Protest in Afghanistan Kills Over a Dozen, Authorities Say
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  An explosion during a political protest in southeastern Afghanistan killed at least 16 people on Thursday and left many others wounded, including a member of Parliament, according to the authorities.

title: 6 Qs About the News | California Imposes First-Ever Water Restrictions to Deal With Drought
description: In California Imposes First-Ever Water Restrictions to Deal With Drought, Adam Nagourney reports on the water crisis facing the nations most populous state.

title: Somali Militants Kill 147 at Kenyan University
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Somali militants burst into a university in eastern Kenya on Thursday and killed nearly 150 students in the worst terrorist attack since the 1998 bombing of the United States Embassy here, laying bare the nations continuing vulnerability after years of battling Islamist extremism.

title: Cold Spring Harbor Lab, Seeking Human Subjects, Teams Up With Hospital System
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, N.Y.  Some of the worlds finest scientists live in a former whaling village on the North Shore of Long Island, in a compound reminiscent of an army post.

title: In Tunisia, One Brother Studied Philosophy, Another Gunned Down Tourists
description: IBRAHIM ZAHAR, Tunisia  The same day that Jabeur Khachnaoui was gunning down foreign tourists at the National Bardo Museum in Tunis last month, one of his older brothers was on the other side of town, attending a rally against terrorism.

title: Harry Reid Hopes to Ensure Democrats Success as Tenure Winds Down
description: LAS VEGAS  Senator Harry Reid, the Senate Democratic leader who announced his retirement last week, settled into a corner booth at the Triple George Grill here, his faced masked by dark sunglasses, evidence of lingering injuries from a workout accident that left him blind in one eye. For the next hour, in a conversation that veered from Washington to Nevada and back again, Mr. Reid made clear that he would deploy all of his resources to make sure Democrats hold on to his seat  critical to any hopes his party has of winning back the Senate in 2016.

title: Do You Experience FOMO When You Unplug?
description: With Twitter, Facebook and other social media, we can know whats going on seemingly everywhere all the time. But what happens when we unplug?

title: A Flying V to Clean the Ice
description: The Flyers ice crew, like others around the N.H.L., must repeatedly clear the entire 200-foot-by-85-foot ice surface of the ice shavings that accumulate during a game.

title: As the Zamboni Idles, N.H.L. Ice Crews Do the Heavy Clearing
description: Chris Jennings glanced up at the video board at Wells Fargo Center in Philadelphia during a Flyers game last month, then at the players slicing along his ice and back up at the video board. Standing by the Zamboni gate, Jennings turned and called out to the eight men and four women behind him.

title: Cindi Leive | Glamours Confidence Chief
description: There are valid confidence lessons for women in Lean In, says Cindi Leive, the editor in chief of Glamour magazine. But she cautions women not to measure themselves against a singular model of success.

title: Eye on the Struggle, James McGrath Morriss Biography of Ethel Payne
description: In our uncertain news media landscape, the black press is not what it used to be. At their height during the Great Migration decades between 1915 and 1970, dozens of weeklies  including The New York Amsterdam News, The Pittsburgh Courier and The Los Angeles Sentinel  reported the news of black America. The Chicago Defender, unofficial organ of the migration, had a national circulation of 130,000. Everything that was fit to print, from the latest racial pogroms to Negro League baseball box scores, filled its pages, giving voice to the voiceless along the color line of American political and social life. In 2000, Vernon Jarrett, a longtime Chicago Defender reporter and a syndicated columnist at The Chicago Tribune, described black newspapers as the most predominant media influence on black people. ... They were our Internet.

title: Air Pollution Takes Early Toll on Children
description: Air pollution can be bad for children  starting even before birth, a new study suggests.

title: Cindi Leive of Glamour on Harnessing the Power of Praise
description: This interview with Cindi Leive, editor in chief of Glamour magazine, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Using Patient Data to Democratize Medical Discovery
description: Steven Keating, a graduate student at the MIT Media Lab and a brain cancer survivor, was the subject of an article this week, presented as a super data cruncher of his own patient information.

title: Saudi Leaders Have High Hopes for Yemen Airstrikes, but Houthi Attacks Continue
description: CAIRO  Two months after ascending to the throne, King Salman of Saudi Arabia bet his prestige as a new leader on rallying his Arab allies for a military campaign to save Yemen from an Iranian takeover  all under the direction of his son, the new defense minister and chief of the royal court.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: The Chinese Billionaire Zhang Lei Spins Research Into Investment Gold
description: HONG KONG  With an $18 billion war chest, he is one of Chinas richest investors. Yet on a recent trip to San Francisco, Zhang Lei and his entourage crammed into a three-bedroom house in the Mission District, rented through Airbnb.

title: Militants Carry Out Deadly Attacks on Army Checkpoints in North Sinai
description: CAIRO  Militants in North Sinai simultaneously attacked two army checkpoints before dawn on Thursday, killing at least 13 Egyptian soldiers and two civilians, security officials said. The attacks ended a lull in such violence that had lasted several weeks.

title: Daily Report: Post-PayPal, and Still Making Waves
description: The ride-hailing app Uber, the apartment rental site Airbnb and other darlings of the next generation of Silicon Valley start-ups are reshaping the way people use the web, David Gelles reports. They are also changing expectations about just how much money private companies can raise while still staying out of the public markets.

title: New York Today: Old-Fashioned Sports
description: Good morning on this fine Thursday.

title: Tinder While I Taper
description: This is the sixth installment of Going Off, a series of Anxiety posts chronicling the authors attempt to wean off the medications she takes for depression, anxiety and insomnia.

title: When Moneyball Meets Medicine
description: Whats worse: Ebola or AIDS? Measles or malnutrition? Lung cancer or low back pain? As individuals, as a nation, and as a global community, where should we focus our time and money to improve lives the most?

title: In Dubai, Swinging Clubs Under the Stars
description: The shadows covered my ball like giant trash bags, and the subtle breaks in the green blended together as if coated in paint. I didnt care  how could I? I was playing golf at night.

title: The Cuddly, Fluffy, Surreal World of Angora Show Bunnies
description: They are basically already sweaters. Not just because theyre mostly wool, with that ludicrous shag frothing out of their nonphysiques; its their total passivity, the way they allow themselves to be handled or arranged on a table, just so, like those sea creatures that, incapable of self-propulsion, get joggled along by the tides. Ask about Angora rabbits, and a word you hear a lot is docile. Theyre generally a pretty mellow rabbit, says one Angora fancier. I heard about one that supposedly fell out of its cage overnight, landed on the back of a dog and stayed there until morning.

title: Via, a Ride-Sharing App, Raises $27 Million for Car-Pooling
description: Be it by land, air or sea, there is no shortage of ways to get around New York.

title: The Many Faces of Tatiana Maslany
description: The grand adventure of a set visit is entering a universe where everyone  absolutely everyone  is a pro at playing pretend. Theyre admirably adult about it. They drink coffee and sit in chairs and operate machines, as if there werent lights so hot that they banish the winter outside, as if its perfectly normal for a sweltering interior to look like a dusty, sunbaked facade. Insides become outsides here, as gravel underfoot transforms a soundstage floor into a sandy desert.

title: Saying I Love You With Baseball
description: WASHINGTON, N. J.  Football may be Americas most popular sport, but baseball is still where our hearts lie, especially this weekend when the season starts anew. Back in 1985, my own heart was firmly with the New York Mets. Most of my friends were Yankees fans, which was precisely why this immigrant teenager fell for the Mets: They needed my help. They won my loyalty when they lost the division to the St. Louis Cardinals that year, proving once again that misery loves company.

title: Today in Politics: Indiana Law Deepens Strain Between Republicans and Business
description: Good Thursday morning from Washington, where Senator Robert Menendezs corruption charges are already becoming a political problem for Democrats. President Obama is heading to Kentucky to talk about the economy, while Speaker John A. Boehner wraps up his big international trip. Jeb Bush seems to have modified his response to an Indiana law seen as both a protection of religious freedom and an invitation for discrimination, while the law has become a thorn for Republicans, especially in their dealings with business leaders.

title: Iran Agrees to Detailed Nuclear Outline, First Step Toward a Wider Deal
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland  Iran and the United States, along with five other world powers, announced on Thursday a surprisingly specific and comprehensive understanding on limiting Tehrans nuclear program for the next 15 years, though they left several specific issues to a final agreement in June.

title: European Commission Asks Companies to Go Public With Google Complaints
description: LONDON  Europes five-year antitrust investigation against Google could soon be heating up again.

title: Morning Agenda: HSBC Criticized Over Compliance
description: HSBC CRITICIZED OVER COMPLIANCE | When United States prosecutors found HSBC had facilitated money laundering on behalf of Mexican drug cartels and blacklisted nations like Iran, the British bank avoided criminal prosecution in 2012 by agreeing to overhaul its money-laundering controls. In their latest update, filed in court Wednesday, federal prosecutors say HSBC still has a long way to go, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess write in DealBook. Progress has been too slow in some areas, the filing said, which was based on a report by Michael Cherkasky, the independent monitor installed at HSBC. The filing criticized the bank for weaknesses in spotting suspicious transactions and for enabling a corporate culture resistant to change.

title: Lydia Davis: By the Book
description: The author, most recently, of Cant and Wont abandoned reading Harry Potter alongside her son: I found the writing flat and shallow, and the characters less than interesting.

title: Lesley Manville as the Unhappy Heroine of Ibsens Ghosts
description: LONDON  Her son was dying in her arms, and she held the bottle that contained the means to kill him. Would she? Could she?

title: Karen, an App That Knows You All Too Well
description: LONDON  Thinking about a life coach but not ready to commit to the real thing? App stores offer lots of electronic alternatives that can be downloaded to your iPhone or Android device. Theres Success Wizard, which promises to help you plan, focus and achieve real and lasting results. LiveHappy, brim-full of exercises from the California psychologist who wrote The How of Happiness. Niggle, for people who want a pocket sized coaching buddy on call 24/7. And soon, from the British art group Blast Theory, an entirely different approach: Karen, a mock life-coach app that develops boundary issues and leaves its users feeling distinctly uncomfortable.

title: Tommy Tune to Receive Lifetime Achievement Tony
description: Tommy Tune, who has collected nine Tony awards as a dancer, choreographer and director, will need to make room on his shelf for a 10th: He will be honored in June with a special Tony Award for lifetime achievement.

title: The Middle-Class Lure of This Rural Nebraska Hospital
description: The draw for many people near Beatrice, Neb., today isnt main street shopping and manufacturing jobs, but the hospital  a symbol of what being in the American middle class now can mean.

title: Poetry Pairing | The Sun Rising
description: We celebrate National Poetry Month with a Poetry Pairing that features John Donnes poem The Sun Rising and the article New Wing at Corning Museum of Glass Invites the Light by Alexandra Lange.

title: Two Ailey Dancers to Leave for New Roles in St. Louis
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater is losing two of its most treasured members this summer. Antonio Douthit-Boyd and Kirven Douthit-Boyd  who were married in 2013  have been named the co-artistic directors of the Center of Creative Arts, the St. Louis organization where Antonio Douthit-Boyd trained. Before they take up their new jobs, on Aug. 15, they will perform their final New York season with the Ailey company at the David H. Koch Theater in June, followed by an engagement in Paris in July.

title: F.B.I. Says Terrorist Was Killed in Botched January Raid in Philippines
description: MANILA  A botched police raid in the Philippines in January that led to a public outcry and jeopardized a peace deal with rebels was successful in killing one of Southeast Asias most notorious militants, according to the F.B.I., which said it had removed the man from its list of most-wanted terrorists.

title: Its Not as if Were Strangers
description: Dear Diary:

title: James Corden Is Fashions New Darling
description: Look out, Seth Meyers. Fashion has a new favorite comedian/host: James Corden, a.k.a. the newish portly British host of The Late Late Show on CBS and baker/star of the movie Into the Woods. After a leading role at the 2014 Glamour Women of the Year Awards, Mr. Corden has been named host of the Council of Fashion Designers of America awards, to be held in June. Its the big industry seal of approval.

title: The Upper East Side Bats Its Eyelashes
description: Nearly two years ago, Mario R. Garca was invited to lecture and teach at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism.

title: A Limited-Edition Tiffany Timepiece That Honors Its Namesake
description: In honor of Charles Lewis Tiffany, who in 1837 founded the famed jewelry house that bears his name, Tiffany & Co. has created the new CT60 calendar watch, which carries his initials. The number references the phrase a New York minute, which he believed contained 60 seconds of possibility. Based on a design made famous by President Roosevelt when he wore it to the Yalta Conference, this model is pure, sleek elegance. Gold numerals made from shimmering metallic powder are set into an 18-karat rose-gold case and attached to a black alligator strap lined in calfskin. The sapphire crystal back reveals the mechanics, decorated with Art Deco motifs borrowed from the 1939 steel store doors. In a numbered edition of 60, this is part of a collection of four new timepieces, the companys first in more than 20 years. It pays homage to the opportunities embedded in time.

title: In West Hollywood, a Hotel With a Westwood Touch
description: The British fashion designer Vivienne Westwood makes a detour from the runway to make her debut as a hotel suite designer at the London West Hollywood in California.

title: Think Like a Doctor: Breathless
description: The Challenge: Can you figure out whats wrong with a 64-year-old woman whose breathing becomes rapid and erratic at times?

title: Is Cubs Kris Bryant a Cant-Miss Prospect? Fans Cant Be Sure
description: Kris Bryant, the consensus top baseball prospect in the country, had a scintillating spring training for the Chicago Cubs. In 44 plate appearances, he hit .425 with nine home runs and three doubles, slugging an improbable 1.175.

title: Musical? Play? All Thats Sure Is David Bowie Is Involved
description: Four decades after his star turn as an alcoholic alien in the film The Man Who Fell to Earth, David Bowie is now co-writing a new stage workbased on the same story.

title: Throwback Thursday | Elite College Admissions
description: Its college admissions season, and high school seniors all over clicked links in the last few weeks telling them if they were  or, in the case of elite institutions like Stanford, more likely were not  admitted.

title: Lux Capital Raises $350 Million Fund to Back Science Start-Ups
description: SAN FRANCISCO  So much of the money pouring into venture capital nowadays has come from investors hoping to get a piece of the next Uber or Dropbox.

title: Bernanke Says Global Imbalances Bedevil the World Economy. Discuss.
description: Ben Bernanke and Larry Summers are in the midst of a vigorous blog debate about why the worlds economy is so messed up and how it can be fixed.

title: 1890: Children Hired to Beg
description: M. Georges Berry, the Paris municipal councilor, has broken many a lance in tilting against old, and in some cases, time honored, abuses, and for his pains has not infrequently heard it suggested that there was a dash of Quixotism in his composition. Nothing daunted, he is ready to break a few more lances. In the campaign he has now started he can receive nothing but commendation.

title: In Life at the Limits, Extreme Creatures at American Museum of Natural History
description: ONE of the great pleasures of science is learning how strange the world is.

title: Bunny Business
description: The beguiling beauty and arduous hair-care regimen of the Angora rabbit.

title: Stampede to Join Chinas Development Bank Stuns Even Its Founder
description: BEIJING  The sudden rush to join Chinas new Asian development bank by this weeks deadline, including last-minute applications by countries hardly considered Beijings best friends, astonished even the Chinese.

title: Indiana and Arkansas Revise Rights Bills, Seeking to Remove Divisive Parts
description: INDIANAPOLIS  After a national uproar over bills promoted as religious freedom measures and criticized as anti-gay, lawmakers in Indiana and in Arkansas approved new legislation on Thursday to remove the most contentious language, though in significantly different ways.

title: The Magazine Talks Sex, and Readers React
description: Lela Moore is a news assistant and comment moderator.

title: Stunning Views of Earth From Space
description: The International Space Station is as far as humans go in space these days, but it is at just the right distance to capture astonishing images of Earth.

title: Muslims Projected to Outnumber Christians by 2100
description: Christianity has long been the worlds largest religion by far, but the population of Muslims is growing so fast that they will match Christians by the year 2070 and outnumber them by the end of the century, according to a report released Thursday that projects the global religious future.

title: Earth, the Marvelous Blue Orb
description: Sometimes, you have to leave a place to appreciate it.

title: Germanwings Pilot Searched Web About Suicide and Cockpit Doors, Officials Say
description: DSSELDORF, Germany  The co-pilot at the controls of the Germanwings airliner that crashed into the French Alps last week had been searching the Internet in the days immediately before for information about how to commit suicide and the security measures for cockpit doors, prosecutors said Thursday.

title: Educators Found Guilty in Sexual Assault of Kindergartners in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  An Indonesian court on Thursday found a Canadian educator and an Indonesian teaching assistant at one of the countrys most prestigious international schools guilty of sexually assaulting three kindergarten students, after a high-profile trial in which defense lawyers and the school asserted that the entire case had been fabricated.

title: Students Describe Attack at Kenya School
description: Students who escaped an attack by gunmen on a Kenyan university described the scene on Thursday.

title: Video Captures Bombing in Afghanistan
description: Footage obtained by Reuters appears to show the moment a suicide bomber attacked an anti-corruption demonstration in Khost, Afghanistan.

title: James Harden Scores 51 and Makes Case for M.V.P. in Big Night for N.B.A. Stars
description: It was a big night for box scores in the N.B.A., and a big night for James Harden in his battle with Stephen Curry for the Most Valuable Player Award.

title: Which Andres Serrano Bunny Are You?
description: A curious fact about this weeks photo essay on Angora rabbits, cut from the text for reasons of space, was that the bunnies we featured  in sumptuous photographs by the artist Andres Serrano  turned out to embody four distinct but equally valid paradigms for ethical reasoning in 21st-century life. Take the following quiz, which consists of questions posed to our Ethicists column in recent weeks, to determine which of these longhair rabbits best represents your intuitive approach to moral quandaries.

title: New Neighbors Revitalize Battery Park City
Cruz Champions a Democrat: President Kennedy
description: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas is a fervent fan of President Ronald Reagan. Mr. Reagan is a constant in Mr. Cruzs stump speech, whether its the conservative coalition he built or his record as president.

title: The Sympathizer, by Viet Thanh Nguyen
description: The more powerful a country is, the more disposed its people will be to see it as the lead actor in the sometimes farcical, often tragic pageant of history. So it is that we, citizens of a superpower, have viewed the Vietnam War as a solely American drama in which the febrile land of tigers and elephants was mere backdrop and the Vietnamese mere extras.

title: Excerpt: Planet of the Apes
description: A scene from Planet of the Apes, with Charlton Heston.

title: G.M. Bets Big on a Resurgent Cadillac
description: I learned to drive in my fathers black 1967 Cadillac, which my friends and I called the Batmobile. With its fins, 130-inch wheelbase and 4,675 pounds, there was no mistaking it for a Mercedes, not that any of us back then had ever seen one.

title: SpaHa Soul
description: Informal, improvised cooking in East Harlem.

title: At SpaHa Soul in Spanish Harlem, Camaraderie on a Plate
description: Artist Thornton wore a red apron as he greeted guests at SpaHa Soul, but when asked if he was the chef, he paused. Im the chef, he said with a laugh, fingers pinching the air.

title: Making Religion the Problem
description: One of the issues that I didnt get around to in the last two weeks, while writing way too many words on the question of whether economics or culture explains the decline of marriage and the two-parent family in America, is the question of what, if anything, conservatives actually think we should do about the problem if it is primarily a cultural one. This is the question raised, for instance, by this Damon Linker column, which argues that scolds of the right dont have a plan, beyond pointless hectoring, to build the kind of familial-communal order wed prefer.

title: Herod the Greats Israel
description: I traveled to Israel last May to search for Herod the Great and I found him, or at least his ghost, at his tomb at Herodium. Halfway up an artificial mountain that the king had conjured from the desert for his final resting place, I stood gazing at what was left of the royal mausoleum: a couple of courses of limestone blocks as exquisitely faceted as jewels. Below, the arcing rows of a Roman theater descended in diminishing semicircles to the disc of the stage. Everything around me, even the contours of the earth itself, had been altered at the decree of this ancient ruler. Time has toppled the columns and blurred the carvings, but the majesty (and hubris) of this place remain intact.

title: U.N. Rights Chief Criticizes Draconian Powers Given to Thai Military
description: GENEVA  The United Nations human rights chief, Zeid Raad al-Hussein, criticized the draconian powers adopted by Thailands ruling generals this week, saying on Thursday that they opened the door to abuses and made the juntas parallel move to lift martial law meaningless.

title: Text to Text | To Kill a Mockingbird and History of Lynchings in the South Documents Nearly 4,000 Names
description: On Feb. 3, 2015, a Times News Alert announced the stunning headline: Harper Lee, Author of To Kill a Mockingbird, Is to Publish a Second Novel.

title: Viewfinder: Nick Frank
description: Nick Franks images of empty subway stations are imbued with a sense of surreal beauty.

title: Trevor Noah Sees Childhood Under Apartheid as License to Speak His Mind
description: JOHANNESBURG  Years before he was chosen to succeed Jon Stewart on The Daily Show, before he made his debut on that Comedy Central news satire or appeared on any American television program, a rising stand-up named Trevor Noah explained why his racial background was both empowering and confining.

title: Rev. Robert Schuller, 88, Dies; Built an Empire Preaching Self-Belief
description: The Rev. Robert H. Schuller, a California clergyman who started his ministry by preaching in a drive-in movie theater and transformed it into an empire, building the landmark megachurch the Crystal Cathedral, writing best sellers and, through television, exhorting millions to believe in themselves, died on Thursday in Artesia, Calif. He was 88.

title: In a Short Time, Ted Cruz Has Raised Big Money From Small Donors
description: Ted Cruz, the Texas Republican senator, raised nearly $4 million in the eight days after he announced his presidential campaign, according to The Wall Street Journal. Whats important about that number is that almost all of it came in amounts of less than $100.

title: The Last Ice Merchant of Ecuador
description: For over half a century, Baltazar Ushca has hiked up the slopes of Mount Chimborazo, Ecuadors tallest mountain, to harvest the glacial ice that covers this dormant volcano. In the past, up to 40 ice merchants made the journey up the mountain at a time; today, however, Baltazar works alone.

title: Two Women in Queens Are Charged With a Bomb Plot
description: Two women living in Queens have been charged with planning to build a bomb, in a plot revealed by a monthslong undercover investigation that found the women had discussed the merits of various types of bombs and had obtained four propane gas tanks.

title: One Title Mike Trout Hopes to Shed: Strikeout King
description: Mike Trout led the American League in four traditional categories last season. Three  runs, runs batted in and total bases  helped him win his first Most Valuable Player Award. The other reflected the reality that, in this era, even the games best player can be a leader of the strikeout parade.

title: Iowa Operative Will Run Mike Huckabee Super PAC
description: The Mike Huckabee super PAC has arrived.

title: Robert Askins Brings Hand to God to Broadway
description: The conceit is zany: In a church basement, a group of adolescents gathers (mostly at the insistence of their parents) to make puppets that will spread the Christian message, but one of the puppets turns out to be more demonic than divine.

title: Michael Fabianos 7 Hours From Call to Stage at the Metropolitan Opera
description: The hot young tenor Michael Fabiano was out running errands near his home in Philadelphia around 1 p.m. on Wednesday when the Metropolitan Opera called, wondering if he could step in for an ailing tenor in its production of Donizettis Lucia di Lammermoor. The curtain would rise in six and a half hours. In New York.

title: No Runs, No Hits, New Era: Baseball Ponders Legal Ways to Increase Offense
description: The old catcher smiled wryly. The topic was offense, and what could be done to revive it. When John Buck entered professional baseball, in 1998, fans were swooning for sluggers. All these years later, the landscape has tilted. Runs and homers are falling. Strikeouts and infield shifts are soaring. Pitchers rule.

title: On World Autism Awareness Day, Gratitude  and a Wish List
description: It is so delightful when your child tries to make you laugh. Lately, my 4-year-old son, Heath, has been recreating a moment when he almost fell in the toilet, which seems about right on the 4-year-old development scale when it comes to a sense of humor. He picks up the seat of the toilet, balances on the edge and looks at my husband and me. He says a mock-concerned Heath! and we all laugh.

title: Manoel de Oliveira, Pensive Filmmaker Who Made Up for Lost Time, Dies at 106
description: Manoel de Oliveira, the acclaimed Portuguese filmmaker whose career began in the silent era, flowered in the 1970s with the end of authoritarian rule in his country and ended with a surge of productivity extending into his 11th decade, died on Thursday at his home in Oporto, Portugal. He was 106.

title: Prosecutor on Co-Pilots Search History
description: Christoph Kumpa, a German prosecutor, said investigators found a tablet computer in the home of Andreas Lubitz, on which the Germanwings co-pilot had researched the safety features of cockpit doors.

title: Antitrust and Other Inquiries in Europe Target U.S. Tech Giants
description: LONDON  It is not a good week to be a giant American tech company in Europe.

title: Breaking Free of Steakhouse Wine List Tradition
description: From the rudimentary masculine places of old, contemporary steakhouses have mutated into higher forms of restaurant life. The menus still touch all the steakhouse basics but augment them with far more interesting options than the proverbial icy shrimp cocktails and prefab Caesar salads. Along with a reinvented menu, the steakhouse wine list has also evolved into a more intelligent, diverse and satisfying set of selections.

title: Hominid Species May Have Coexisted
description: An ancient hominid known as Little Foot may have lived at roughly the same time as Lucy, another famous human forebear, a new study has found.

title: Awaiting Iran News, Obama Delays Travel Plans
Indiana To Make Changes to Religious Law
description: Two republican members of the Indiana legislature, Representative Brian C. Bosma and Senator David C. Long, said changes will be made to the states Religious Freedom Restoration Act.

title: In Felix & Meira, Luzer Twersky Revisits the Hasidic World He Left
description: A decade ago, Luzer Twersky was a member of a Hasidic community in Brooklyn. Now, having left that world entirely, hes only Orthodox in the movies. In Felix & Meira, due out on April 17, he plays Shulem, the husband of a Hasidic woman (Hadas Yaron) who questions her faith and develops a relationship with a secular man.

title: If 2024 Olympic Bid Is a Hot Potato, Boston Has No Appetite
description: After completing its long, complicated and anything but transparent process of choosing a city as its candidate to host the 2024 Summer Games, the United States Olympic Committee has found itself in an awkward position.

title: First Draft Focus: Robert Menendez Goes to Court
Mayweather-Pacquiao Will Have Record Pay-Per-View Pricetag
description: The long-anticipated title fight between Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Manny Pacquiao on May 2 in Las Vegas will cost boxing fans a record price on pay per view: $89.95 to watch in standard definition and, in some cases, $99.95 for the high definition version, two executives familiar with the terms said. The prices were also reported by The Wall Street Journal.

title: Iraq Forces, Pushing ISIS Out of Tikrit, Give Few Thanks for U.S. Airstrikes
description: TIKRIT, Iraq  One week after the start of intensive American airstrikes against Islamic State hide-outs, most of the key parts of central Tikrit have finally fallen to the governments forces  although significant pockets remained contested on Thursday.

title: Uber Hires a Security Chief From Facebook
description: Silicon Valley is home to some of the worlds brightest technical minds. And from Apple to Google, every big company covets the talent of its competitors. Now add Uber, the ride-hailing company, to that group.

title: Juliette Binoche and Kristen Stewart in Clouds of Sils Maria
description: A few years ago the actress Juliette Binoche got in touch with her old friend Olivier Assayas, the French director who had co-written the film Rendez-Vous, which slingshot her to fame three decades ago.

title: Tom Cotton: Opponents of Anti-Gay Law Need Perspective
description: Im starting to long for the good old days, just weeks ago, when nobody had to think about Senator Tom Cotton, Republican of Arkansas.

title: When the Politics of Religious Freedom Divides Families
description: The religious exception bill pending in Arkansas hasnt just added to the growing debate over what proponents call religious freedom bills, which grant people, and businesses, the right to avoid a fine or lawsuit for refusing to obey a state mandate that violates their religious beliefs. Its brought our attention squarely back to one of the big divides in politics: When it comes to things like gay rights (and education spending, immigration, and the environment), the generation gap is back.

title: Criminal Complaint Filed Against Queens Women
description: Details of the charges against two women who are accused in a bomb detonation plot.

title: Mad Men, the Beginning
description: Matthew Weiner shot the pilot for Mad Men in 2006. The show debuted on AMC in 2007.

title: After Nuclear Agreement, Analysts Weigh Deals Effects on Iranian Politics
description: WASHINGTON  For Iran watchers, a possible deal to rein in the countrys nuclear program raises questions about its impact not only on arms control in the region but also on Tehrans complex internal politics.

title: Clip: Ex Machina
description: In this scene from Alex Garlands film, Caleb (Domhnall Gleeson) meets Ava (Alicia Vikander) for the first time.

title: Robert Dursts Lawyers Want to Call the Agents Who Arrested Him as Witnesses
description: NEW ORLEANS  In a bid to keep the millionaire Robert A. Durst from having to face felony weapons and drug charges in New Orleans, his lawyers on Thursday sought to call the agents who arrested him as witnesses, part of their effort to prove that evidence collected at the time of the arrest was obtained illegally and cannot be used against him.

title: Ex Machina Features a New Robot for the Screen
description: Theyve been giant and deadly; theyve been chatty and contemplative; theyve been acrobatic and futuristic. Robots in movies have served all kinds of functions in becoming an important part of the cinema landscape. So when filmmakers place a robot at the center of their work, the way it looks and behaves compared with those that have come before must be considered.

title: Mad Men': How The New York Times Covered the First Season
description: Mad Men starts the final half of its seventh season on Sunday, and its been quite a run for the critically acclaimed AMC drama. But before the shows pilot premiered on July 19, 2007, it was impossible to predict how influential Mad Men would eventually become. Here is a brief look back at how The New York Times first covered the show.

title: Marco Pierre White
description: A look back at the British chefs first cookbook, White Heat, 25 years after its publication.

title: Marco Pierre Whites White Heat: A Game Changer, Revisited
description: In his heyday in the late 1980s and early 1990s, when he was the tantrum-throwing enfant terrible of the London food world, Marco Pierre White had a method for dealing with rude or obnoxious customers in his restaurants. It was called the Whoosh.

title: Finding Neverland
description: Behind the scenes at the new Broadway musical.

title: N.I.T. Winners Seldom Follow Up With N.C.A.A. Tournament Success
description: When Stanford and Miami meet on Thursday night in the final of the N.I.T., they will be competing for a consolation prize. Most N.I.T. winners would have much preferred even a short run in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: After Turbulent Flight, Finding Neverland Alights on Broadway
description: In making the leap from movie mogul to lead theater producer with his musical, Finding Neverland, Harvey Weinstein has fired or lost more actors, artists and executives than most impresarios do on their shows. He has overseen spending of roughly $20 million (before tax writeoffs) on a world premiere run in Britain and then on an entirely new version of the musical, which opens April 15 on Broadway. He has thrown himself into the role of script doctor, huddling over a laptop the other week with the shows book writer, James Graham, trying to punch up jokes. He has even fussed over the dog in the cast, pushing for a real-live version instead of an actor.

title: Nasher Sculpture Center Announces New $100,000 Prize
description: There is no shortage of prizes in the art world, but few specifically recognize sculpture.

title: Space Is the Place Offers Otherworldly Takes on Identity
description: Being black in America is a science-fiction experience, the culture critic and musician Greg Tate once asserted in an interview, articulating the premise for what has come to be called Afrofuturism.

title: Eddie LeBaron, a Star in the N.F.L. at 5-Foot-7, Dies at 85
description: Eddie LeBaron, an undersize quarterback who was a college Hall of Famer, became a Marine Corps hero during the Korean War and then played in the National Football League for 11 seasons, died on Wednesday in Stockton, Calif. He was 85.

title: Details Given of Iran Nuclear Agreement
description: Federica Mogherini, left, the European Unions foreign policy chief, and Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif of Iran announced the details of the agreement.

title: Senator Menendez Pleads Not Guilty to Bribery Accusations
description: Joined by a mutual fondness for good cigars and a round of golf, they spent holidays together in the Dominican Republic, unwinding at a gated oceanfront resort where houses cost as much as $20 million.

title: Kenyan Minister Announces End of Siege
description: Joseph Nkaissery, Kenyas interior minister, said many students were killed during the siege of a university.

title: Across the Creek Is the Other Side of the River
description: Poem selected by Natasha Trethewey.

title: Happy Passover, or Not: Gefilte Fish Is Back
description: The wacky weather of the past few years has wreaked havoc across the nation, from droughts in California to record snowfall in Boston  and Seder tables everywhere in between. Extended freezing on the Great Lakes saw the whitefish haul sink last year, and the supply of gefilte fish fell along with it.

title: Behind Each Breath, an Underappreciated Muscle
description: Some muscles get all the glory. Bodybuilders show off their swollen triceps; sprinters flash their sharp-edged calves. But deep inside all of us, a sheet of muscle does heroic work in obscurity.

title: Obama Comments on Nuclear Deal With Iran
description: President Obama spoke from the White House on Thursday after a nuclear deal was announced with Iran.

title: Senator Kirk Adds Another Republican Vote for Lynch for Attorney General
description: Senator Mark Kirk, Republican of Illinois, announced Thursday that he would vote to confirm Loretta E. Lynch as the next attorney general, meaning she almost certainly has the votes needed for confirmation.

title: Dortmund, Leading Derby Contender, Is Horse Discoverers Latest Star
description: On the first Saturday in May 1996, Donato Lanni, amid final exams to complete a business degree at Concordia University in Montreal, watched the unheralded California thoroughbred trainer Bob Baffert come within a nose of winning the Kentucky Derby with a gelding named Cavonnier.

title: Step Down, Senator Robert Menendez
description: For high-profile politicians who are indicted by federal prosecutors, theres something akin to stages of grief. First comes shock, then anger, defiance and, sometimes, after juries convict and judges are ready to impose a sentence, a bit of contrition.

title: Swiss Votes on Pay Bode Ill for Star Bankers
description: Switzerlands new say on pay rules could make it harder for investment banking stars at UBS and Credit Suisse to outpace their bosses in compensation. All the countrys listed companies face binding shareholder votes on executive compensation this year. But the Swiss publics hostility toward its banks means they could be first in the firing line.

title: Details of Agreement to Limit Irans Nuclear Program
description: Iran and six world powers agreed on key parameters for an accord regarding Tehrans nuclear program, with the details to be negotiated by June 30.

title: Death Toll in Sinking of Russian Ship Rises to at Least 56
description: MOSCOW  Russian emergency workers frantically plucked bodies from the freezing Sea of Okhotsk on Thursday after a refrigerated trawling ship sank in Russias Far East, killing at least 56 of a crew of 132.

title: Verbatim: Trust, but Verify
description: President Obama, announcing a deal with Iran over its nuclear program.

title: With Menendez Out, Cardin Rises on Senate Foreign Relations Commitee
description: The corruption charges facing Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey is creating a shift on the powerful Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

title: Letters: The Age of Acquiescence
description: To the Editor:

title: 1962 | Non Scholae Sed Vitae Discimus
description: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

title: Your Pet, the Art World Insider
description: The ancient Egyptians depicted gods with the heads of dogs and cats. Balthuss 1935 self-portrait The King of Cats includes his alter ego, a cat, rubbing against his leg. The Misers own Instagram account recently was exclusively made up of photos of a beagle he was fostering.

title: The Problem With Math Problems: Were Solving Them Wrong
description: The following question, from a mother concerned about her daughters math education, landed in my email box recently:

title: Lambert and Stamp, a Documentary, Looks at the Who
description: When Kit Lambert and Chris Stamp, two on-the-make British filmmakers, first approached the Who  then a scrappy mod band known as the High Numbers  it was as potential fodder for a movie theyd been planning to shoot. Instead, Mr. Lambert and Mr. Stamp became the bands managers and, in Roger Daltreys words, the fifth and sixth members of the Who, steering the group through its heady ascent from arty street kids to worshiped arena rockers.

title: Weekend Entertainments From the Archives of The New York Times
description: 68 YEARS AGO

title: Cubs Futility Can Be Traced to a Promise, Not a Curse
description: I gave up on superstition long ago, so I do not believe in curses of goats or omens like a black cat running in front of a dugout. That said, I am reasonably certain  or as certain as one can be about these things  that the Chicago Cubs will be playing in the World Series this October.

title: An Easygoing Trip of a Track From the Stylish Musical Project Tennis
description: To hear her tell it, performing at a runway show was one of the hardest things Alaina Moore, the frontwoman of the duo Tennis, has ever done. I had never been to one before, but I think it went super well, she says of hitting the stage at Rebecca Minkoffs spring/summer 2013 show with her Tennis bandmate and husband, Patrick Riley. Rebecca wanted us to play live, but she also wanted a D.J. to spin a playlist of all of the songs that were important to her. So we did this mashup where the D.J. would play 30 seconds of a track and then wed drop in on the same beat. It was such a crazy experience. Im glad Rebecca didnt doubt us, because the whole time I was very nervous. She had no reason to be, as the bands fashion and culture bona fides are well established: Their music has also been picked as a soundtrack for ads for Marc Jacobs and Tory Burch and, last month, a scene on Girls. Moore has also recently begun contributing to the British style magazine Port  a welcome extracurricular break from her daily routine. Since Im constantly on the road which a bunch of guys, I usually have such an unglamorous lifestyle, she says.

title: Report of Missing Israeli in West Bank Proves to Be Hoax
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli military called off extensive searches in the Hebron area of the West Bank late Thursday night after initial reports that an Israeli man had been abducted by Palestinians proved to be a hoax.

title: Game of Thrones Writer George R.R. Martin Posts Winds of Winter Novel Excerpt
description: Winter is coming, slowly.

title: Ted Cruz Takes a Jab at Rand Paul Over a Senate Vote
description: CEDAR FALLS, Iowa  Senator Ted Cruz of Texas has said he will not run a negative campaign in his bid for the Republican nomination for the White House.

title: Disarmament Groups Welcome Iran Framework; Israel Is Mistrustful
description: Advocates of disarmament and reconciliation with Iran embraced the framework agreement announced Thursday that would limit Irans nuclear capabilities, calling it a welcome alternative to war, while the Israeli government and its supporters voiced deep criticism and said the opposite outcome was more likely.

title: Why a Claim About the Irrelevance of Parenting Time Doesnt Add Up
description: In an article Wednesday, I criticized a study that found no link between childrens outcomes and the amount of time that parents spent with their children. Several readers told me that they thought I had drawn the wrong conclusion. Here at The Upshot we want to show you not just what we think, but how were thinking, and so I want to explain my statistical argument in more detail. Its a subtle but interesting issue, and if you get to the end, youll earn an extra notch on your wonk belt.

title: Puerto Rico, Old and New
description: Exploring the archipelago, from Old San Juan to beachfront resorts.

title: Mens Street Style for New York Fashion Week
description: Men showed off their style outside the shows during this Februarys New York Fashion Week.

title: A Three-Pronged Front to Limit Shareholder Litigation
description: Delaware is going to war over shareholder litigation, but will shareholders or corporations emerge victorious?

title: With a New Exhibition, Ari Marcopoulos Keeps His Distance
description: Images in the photographers latest series, L1032015, include far-away landscapes and urban scenes that are almost abstract.

title: Jose da Silva Lopes RIP
description: Sad news: Jose da Silva Lopes, a Portuguese economist and government official who played a crucial role shepherding his country into the community of democratic Europe, has just died.

title: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Iraq, Kenya, Syria and Japan

title: In an Upset, the N.C.A.A. Claims the Moral High Ground
description: INDIANAPOLIS  During his annual pre-Final Four news conference on Thursday, the N.C.A.A.s president, Mark Emmert, reflected on the coincidental confluence of the Final Four being held at Lucas Oil Stadium this weekend and the contentious law passed last week just a few blocks up Capitol Avenue.

title: Carmen Cicero: Early Works: 1970-1980s
description: Carmen Cicero, now in his late 80s, has worked in several styles, none his own, but always with enough panache to establish proprietary claims. In the 1950s, he was a promising second-generation Abstract Expressionist who exhibited regularly, pursuing thatches of autonomist lines on paper and canvas, examples of which are owned by all New Yorks major museums.

title: Alex Da Corte: Die Hexe
description: Alex Da Cortes Die Hexe (The Witch) is a labor of love. That probably describes most works of art, but when expressed with an elaborate environment that takes over interior surfaces of a brownstone gallery  thats walls, ceiling and floors on two and a half floors, including stairs and hallways  and dazzles at every turn, it gains force.

title: A Transgender Bangladeshi Changes Perceptions After Catching Murder Suspects
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  In an alleyway off a marketplace specializing in meat and live chickens, up a few narrow, precipitous flights of cement stairs, can be found the most sought-after transgender crime fighter in Bangladesh.

title: Alice Neel: Drawings and Watercolors 1927-1978
description: Alice Neel is best known for her portraits which, with their controlled painterly drama and psychological nuance, are complete and polished formal statements in a classical genre. Her drawings and watercolors, or at least the 62 in this absorbing show, are closer to diary entries. Ruminative, confiding, sometimes startlingly unguarded in emotion, they add up to a self-portrait sketched in private over some 50 years.

title: April 2, 2015 Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Iraq, Kenya, Syria and Japan.

title: Steve DiBenedetto: Mile High Psychiatry
description: Steve DiBenedetto has been showing in New York since the 1980s, but like many painters working on the slow-burn development plan, hes flourishing midcareer. Expertly constructed but aggressively psychedelic and curiously weird, this is a phenomenal group of canvases.

title: Robert Menendez Indictment Points to Corrupting Potential of Super PACs
description: It seemed like a typical corruption case: A Florida doctor, seeking official favors with a United States senator, plies him with gifts while raising all the money he can for the senators campaign, and for his fellow senators and party.

title: Young and Zazeelas Dream House Is Getting a New Lease at Dia
description: For decades, La Monte Young, a father of Minimalist music, has preached that sound needs duration  far more than a long evenings duration  for certain kinds of meaning to accrue. A one-hour composition, as Mr. Young said the other day, is nothing like a six-year composition.

title: Review: ISIS: The State of Terror, by Jessica Stern and J. M. Berger, and ISIS: Inside the Army of Terror, by Michael Weiss and Hassan Hassan
description: The Islamic State and its atrocities  beheadings, mass executions, the enslavement of women and children, and the destruction of cultural antiquities  are in the headlines every day now. The terror group not only continues to roll through the Middle East, expanding from Iraq and Syria into Libya and Yemen, but has also gained dangerous new affiliates in Egypt and Nigeria and continues to recruit foreign fighters through its sophisticated use of social media.

title: Review: Gustav Klimt and Adele Bloch-Bauer Focuses on Portrait Rich in History
description: In 2006, the art collector Ronald S. Lauder purchased Gustav Klimts Adele Bloch-Bauer I (1907) for $135 million, then the highest price paid for a painting, and made it the crown jewel of the Neue Galerie, the museum he founded in 2001. Since then other paintings have sold for considerably higher sums, adjusted for inflation, including those by Paul Czanne and Paul Gauguin.

title: Review: Cheatin  Conjures a Lusty Film-Noir Dreamscape
description: Cheatin, the latest feature from the feverishly crosshatched imagination of the animator Bill Plympton, is a pulpy, sex-addled opera rendered in fleet penciled lines and watercolor washes. Mr. Plymptons unmistakable style  the scrunched-up faces and elongated bodies, the figures that mutate as well as move, the volatile blending of the sensual and the grotesque  is pressed into the service of a lurid, lusty story that takes place in a colorful film-noir dreamscape.

title: A Forbidden Relationship, From the Other Side of the World
Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Antiquarian Book Fair Offers Victorian Childrens Peep Shows
description: Victorian children peered into mass-produced accordion boxes of paper prints called peep shows, which gave the illusion of depth and motion. The layers of scenes, pierced with viewing holes, represented parks, gardens, battlefields, theaters and engineering feats like canals, tunnels and bridges.

title: Jacob Lawrences Migration Series
description: Works from the new show at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Review: One-Way Ticket at MoMA Reunites Jacob Lawrences Migration Paintings
description: On Easter 1939, Marian Anderson stood on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial in Washington and sang: The gospel train is coming; I hear it just at hand; I hear the car wheels rumbling, and rolling through the land. Get on board. By then, hundreds of thousands of African-Americans had already heard the call, leaving the rural South for the industrial North in search of jobs, homes and respect.

title: For Billie Holidays 100th Birthday, Tributes and New Releases
description: In Billie Holidays I Cried for You, recorded at Clark Monroes Uptown House in Harlem in 1941, time feels unimportant. Shes flooding the entire thing, doing a long yell, a game of phrasing and pitch, with words delayed and shaken and skywritten.

title: Why Does She Like Offensive Music? Try Asking
description: My sister is 26. She has a good job, is working toward her masters degree and has a nice boyfriend. The problem: They listen to this awful music they call hood rap. It is filled with obscenities and derogatory comments about women and African-Americans. When our mother heard it, she decided she had failed as a parent. Can we tell her we think this music is hate speech?

title: NYRA Bars Official and Jockeys Agents During Investigation
description: A clocker for the New York Racing Association and two jockey agents were taken away from Aqueduct on Thursday by security agents and told their privileges were revoked until an investigation by the Queens district attorney, into allegations of unlawful access to a computer system, is concluded.

title: Manhattan Prosecutors Say New York Art Dealer Played Role in Sale of Stolen Artifacts
description: Prosecutors, in court papers, have accused a New York art dealer of selling three ancient sculptures that were stolen from temples in India and Nepal.

title: Comedy Listings for April 3-9
description: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Movie Listings for April 3-9
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: New York City Consumer Agency Investigating Four For-Profit Colleges
description: The New York City Department of Consumer Affairs has begun an investigation into four for-profit colleges over concerns about students dropout and loan-default rates, and the ways in which students are recruited in the first place.

title: Jazz Listings for April 3-9
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Things to Do on Long Island, April 5 to 11, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Opera & Classical Music Listings for April 3-9
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Hip-Hop? She Wont Stop
description: When Janette Beckman came to 1980s New York from Britain, she soon found herself photographing key figures in hip-hops early years.

title: Review: Cut Bank, Looking to Escape a Small Town and Its Eccentrics
description: The comic neo-noir Cut Bank is a far cry from the TV series Fargo, whose mixture of the zany and surreal this film strains to recapture right down to featuring two of that shows stars, Billy Bob Thornton and Oliver Platt. The previous credits of its director, Matt Shakman, include the last two episodes of Fargo.

title: Dance Listings for April 3-9
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Review: Jean-Michel Basquiats Unknown Notebooks at the Brooklyn Museum
description: Language was Jean-Michel Basquiats first artistic language. The words he deftly spray-painted on the walls and buildings of downtown New York in the late 1970s and early 80s  signing them SAMO  were unlike any other graffiti of the time. They had an arresting presence, a combination of graphic refinement, aural strangeness and compressed meaning that made you stop and ponder. Their themes, rhythms and even their letters also formed the foundation for the paintings that would soon fix Basquiat prominently in the still understudied history of the medium in 1980s New York.

title: Pop, Rock & Cabaret Listings for April 3-9
description: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for April 3-9
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Itll Be Groundhog Day on Broadway for Matilda Team
description: The creative team behind Matilda the Musical is reassembling to write a musical adaptation of Groundhog Day.

title: Theater Listings for April 3-9
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Review: Effie Gray Stars Dakota Fanning as a Rejected Wife
description: Bad marriages dont get much stranger than that of the 19th-century British art critic John Ruskin to Effie Gray, his first and (unsurprisingly) only wife. History and Mike Leighs movie Mr. Turner remember Ruskin as an advocate for the painter J.M.W. Turner. Others remember Ruskin as the Victorian who, on his wedding night, was so appalled by the sight of his wifes pubic hair that he refused to sleep with her (ever). What really turned Ruskin off? Who knows? Certainly not the makers of Effie Gray, a serviceable British costume drama about the pathetic affair.

title: An Idea Hits the Beach
description: Blackadore Caye, Belize, is the site of an eco-conscious resort planned by a partnership including Leonardo DiCaprio and Delos, the New York developer.

title: Spare Times Listings for April 3-9
description: Around Town

title: Highlights From the New York Auto Show
description: Press previews began this week at the 2015 New York International Auto Show at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. The show opens to the public on Friday.

title: Spare Times for Children for April 3-9
description: NanoDays

title: Things to Do in Westchester, April 5 to 11, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Occupy Wall Street, the Tour
description: AS throngs of tourists gathered recently at Bowling Green, near the southern tip of Manhattan, a 27-year-old political activist, self-styled historian and private tour guide named Michael Pellagatti stood with a small group and rattled off a list of insurrectionary events that had taken place in the area.

title: Inquiry Finds Excessive Force by U.N. Officers in Mali Killings
description: UNITED NATIONS  United Nations peacekeepers in Mali used unauthorized and excessive force when they fired at civilians protesting outside their base in January, killing three, an internal inquiry has found, resurrecting the question of how to hold United Nations personnel accountable when misconduct occurs.

title: Review: Lambert & Stamp Recalls the Duo Who Helped Ignite the Who
description: In the mid-1960s, Kit Lambert and Chris Stamp were working low-level jobs at the Shepperton film studios outside London. Infected by the restlessness of the times and by their own youthful ambition, they came up with an inspired idea for a movie. It would be a cross between a documentary and an art project, tracing the rise of a rock n roll band. They would manage the group and record its exploits on camera, but the music would be a sidebar. The movie would be a masterpiece.

title: Review: The Forecaster Traces the Downfall of an Investment Manager
description: The Forecaster has the distinct hermetic feel of a documentary that employs an echo chamber of people too close to the material. Pregnant with suspense yet maddeningly vague, the film intercuts the tale of the investment manager Martin A. Armstrongs downfall and his discussions of his predictive models.

title: Review: In The Girl Is in Trouble, a Pretty Face Masks Danger
description: When smart men get to know Signe, a scrappy Swedish hustler bouncing around New York, they toss her to the curb. Not so August (Columbus Short), a Nigerian immigrant whose disc-jockey dreams are as elusive as a regular salary. So when Signe (played by the Polish actress Alicja Bachleda) shows up with video of a murder on her cellphone and blackmail plans in her pretty head, August is more than willing to add accomplice to his rsum.

title: Iran Deal May Be Slow to Affect Oil Sector
description: HOUSTON  The breakthrough in nuclear talks with Iran on Thursday has the potential to cause a seismic shift in global energy markets over the long term, but energy experts said any appreciable impact on an already glutted global oil market was highly doubtful for at least six months and probably more than a year.

title: Rashaun Mitchells Light Years, Surreal Yet Supple
description: As a dancer, Rashaun Mitchell has always given powerfully dramatic colorings to his roles: In his illustrious years with the Merce Cunningham Dance Company (2004-11), above all, he could show feral intensity, quiet sophistication, exploratory innocence, glinting mystery. This March, at Danspace at St. Marks Church, in a shared program, he was an electrifying mover and a vivid theatrical presence. He is an actor, but at a level at which you dont see the acting.

title: Texas-Born Man, Flown Back From Pakistan, Is Held on Terror Charge
description: A Texas-born man who had apparently joined Al Qaeda in Pakistan has been flown back to the United States, where he was arraigned in Brooklyn on Thursday on a charge of providing material support to terrorists.

title: Review: In Manos Sucias, Brothers Reconnect on a Drug Run
description: A road movie set mostly on water, Manos Sucias (Dirty Hands in Spanish) accompanies two impoverished, long-estranged brothers  one shut down by life and the other just opening up to its possibilities  on a drug run along the Pacific coastline. Their starting point is Buenaventura, Colombia, and their destination is a set of prearranged coordinates where their floating cargo, a rusty torpedo filled with cocaine, will be picked up and taken to Panama.

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, April 5 to 11, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: What I Love | William Sanford Nye
description: A rented Manhattan apartment is home to the Science Guy.

title: Review: In Boychoir, Dustin Hoffman Mentors a Troubled Student
description: Boychoir is a well-acted drama that turns too softhearted at the end, choosing a conclusion that is as neat and pretty as the music sung by the group of the title. Theres nothing wrong with being uplifting, but something less predictable would have been refreshing.

title: Review: Wolf Hall, the Mini-Series, Unspools Its Power Plays on PBS
description: The BBC mini-series Wolf Hall, beginning on Sunday night on PBS, is a historical drama of conspicuous quality, like one of the shimmering tapestries hanging in the castles where its 16th-century power players hatch their schemes.

title: Feeling Left Out at Lunch
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: Review: Lukas Ligetis Disparate Interests, on Display at the Stone
description: Eclecticism has always been a dominant feature of the music of the composer and percussionist Lukas Ligeti. In the last decade his recorded output has included Mystery System, which revealed his fascination with the polyphony of sub-Saharan African music, as well as releases with his irresistible Burkina Electric, a band that meshes dance-oriented electronica with the traditional music of Burkina Faso.

title: Review: 5 to 7, a New York Romance, With Nostalgia as Star
