description: Boy meets woman in 5 to 7, a New York romance set at the intersection of nostalgia and wishful thinking that takes off near the corner of Fifth Avenue and 55th Street. Its there that Brian (Anton Yelchin) first sees Arielle (Brnice Marlohe) across a crowded street, smoking outside the St. Regis Hotel. He heads straight toward her, lights up his own cigarette and somehow charms her enough so that the two are soon sharing laughs. Hes 24, single and American; shes 33, married and French. Its chemistry at first blush and, because neither character works for a pay check, they run off to begin the 5 to 7 p.m. assignations that give the movie its title.

title: John Paul Hammerschmidt, 92, Dies; Congressman Defeated Clinton
description: John Paul Hammerschmidt, who defeated Bill Clinton in the future presidents first political campaign and was the first Republican congressman from Arkansas since Reconstruction, died on Wednesday in Springdale, Ark. He was 92.

title: Fighting Over Leftovers From Spains Harvest
description: VILLAFRANCA de los BARROS, Spain  Though the official harvest had ended weeks before, there were still olives under the trees outside this small town southwest of Madrid recently, and Luis Cardenas Travado, 52, was hard at work raking them up in the hope of making some extra money.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties include a five-bedroom in Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Wall Township, N.J.

title: Life at the Limits
description: A look at the new exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Review: That Guy Dick Miller Pays Tribute to a Character Actor
description: A few years ago the Los Angeles repertory cinema Cinefamily ran a screening series, That Guy!, devoted to character actors. The subject of That Guy Dick Miller warrants his own gala evening. Elijah Drenners jokey documentary crowds together admirers and clips in tribute to Mr. Miller, whose working-Joe look and street-savvy shtick have infused countless scenes with instant movie realism.

title: A Promising Nuclear Deal With Iran
description: The preliminary agreement between Iran and the major powers is a significant achievement that makes it more likely Iran will never be a nuclear threat. President Obama said it would cut off every pathway that Iran could take to develop a nuclear weapon.

title: Things to Do in New Jersey, April 5 to 11, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: With Hire, Boy Scouts Affiliate in New York Defies Ban on Gays
description: Taking the first step toward a possible face-off over the Boy Scouts of Americas ban on openly gay adult members or employees, the organizations New York affiliate said on Thursday that it had hired a gay Eagle Scout to work in a scout camp this summer.

title: Federal Flood Insurance Premiums for Homeowners Rise
description: Homeowners with federal flood insurance will get some unwelcome news when they receive their next policy renewal notice.

title: Review: In The Hand That Feeds, Workers Rise Up at a Hot & Crusty
description: Films about labor relations dont always need the massive scale of Harlan County, U.S.A. (1976), which watched a miners strike unfold. The advocacy documentary The Hand That Feeds chronicles organizing efforts at a Hot & Crusty on Second Avenue at 63rd Street in Manhattan. (Some material shot for the film was adapted into a New York Times Op-Doc in 2013.)

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties include homes in Prospect Heights, on the Upper West Side, and in Morningside Heights.

title: Review: Last Knights Has Sword Swinging and Cape Twirling in the Name of Revenge
description: Last Knights, a medieval-esque potboiler, features a lineup of pedigreed jaw-clenchers who can swing swords without letting their paychecks show too much. Among the nimblest is Clive Owen, who makes fast and furious with a sword in between uttering lines like Im Commander Raiden of the Seventh Rank and I follow you, my lord. That would be his liege and ours, Morgan Freeman, whose job here is to gild the mold, as in: During the long, dark period of the great wars, an elite class of soldier rose from battle. Their unbreakable code was simple.

title: Stanfords Elliott Bullock, 25, Makes His Presence Felt From the Bench
description: After Elliott Bullock made the Stanford mens basketball team as a freshman walk-on in 2008, he played well enough to earn a scholarship for his sophomore year.

title: EdXOnline Accessibility Settlement Reached
description: EdX, the nonprofit online-learning venture M.I.T. and Harvard formed in 2012, agreed to a settlement with the Department of Justice under which it will make its 450 massive open online courses accessible to blind and hard-of-hearing students, and to those with other disabilities, such as a tremor that makes it difficult to operate a mouse.

title: Semiautonomous Driving Arrives, Feature by Feature
description: AUTOMAKERS descended on New York for the citys annual auto show this week with vehicles ready to do more than just respond to drivers commands. However, the question of whether drivers want their cars to take charge remained unanswered.

title: This Weeks Movies | April 3, 2015
description: The New York Times film critics review Furious 7, Woman in Gold and 5 to 7.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: The Fruits of Diplomacy With Iran
description: WASHINGTON  IN a perfect world, there would be no nuclear enrichment in Iran, and its existing enrichment facilities would be dismantled. But we dont live in a perfect world. We cant wish or bomb away the basic know-how and enrichment capability that Iran has developed. What we can do is sharply constrain it over a long duration, monitor it with unprecedented intrusiveness, and prevent the Iranian leadership from enriching material to weapons grade and building a bomb.

title: New York Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Parking Rules Suspended through Sunday
description: Because of Good Friday and Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City through Sunday. Other regulations will remain in effect

title: A Base in Texas Is No Guarantee of Lone Star Status for Ted Cruz
description: HOUSTON  Senator Ted Cruz opened his presidential campaign headquarters here this week, a sprawling 11,538-square-foot suite on the seventh floor of an office tower with sweeping skyline views, sleek low cubicles for an open feel, and a playroom with pink and red beanbags and giant teddy bears for his children and those of his staff.

title: Rhode Island Settles Lawsuit on Union Pension Overhaul
description: BOSTON  Rhode Island and most of its public employee unions reached a tentative settlement Thursday to a sweeping legal challenge to the states 2011 overhaul of its beleaguered pension system.

title: In Tehran, Optimism and Talk of Revival After Nuclear Deal
description: TEHRAN  Even after learning about a politically seismic event  a nuclear agreement that could augur an end to the era of sanctions and shouts of Death to America  many Iranians appeared reluctant to express happiness or even react to what was, for most people, heartening news.

title: Arizona Bill Would Ban Local Limits on Plastic Bags
description: PHOENIX  While other places have turned to bans and fees to discourage the use of plastic bags, Arizona is headed in a different direction.

title: Saying the Onus Is on Iran, Hillary Clinton Calls Nuclear Framework an Important Step
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton called the framework for an Iran nuclear deal that was reached on Thursday an important step, adding that while the devil is always in the details in such negotiations, diplomacy deserves a chance to succeed.

title: Kentucky, 38-0, Recalls Little of Preseason Defeat in Bahamas
description: CLEVELAND  Those who think this Kentucky basketball team is unbeatable, take one step forward.

title: In Bygone Days, Menendez Fought Graft, With Courage
description: In the sunshine of Walnut Street in Newark, United States Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, stepped briskly to a lectern set up outside the federal courthouse.

title: Chicagos Odd Couple: Mayor Rahm Emanuel and a Billionaire Republican Investor
description: At a news conference this week, Jess G. Garcia, who is trying to unseat Rahm Emanuel as mayor of Chicago, accused the incumbent of allowing the citys rich to pay to play.

title: University of Mississippi Chief, Whose Ouster Led to Protests, Rejects Offer to Stay
description: ATLANTA  After nearly two weeks of public uproar, University of Mississippi officials said Thursday that they had ended negotiations about reversing the decision to oust the schools chancellor, Daniel W. Jones, whose forceful stands for racial tolerance helped remake perceptions of the campus.

title: Turning a Vexing Stroke Into a Weapon, Lydia Ko Matches a Record
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  All day, Lydia Ko had been hitting hooks by accident. On her 16th hole of the opening round of the ANA Inspiration on Thursday, Ko was forced to try to manufacture one to maintain any hope of salvaging par and equaling Annika Sorenstams record of consecutive rounds under par.

title: A Foreign Policy Gamble by Obama at a Moment of Truth
description: WASHINGTON  On the day he took office, President Obama reached out to Americas enemies, offering in his first inaugural address to extend a hand if you are willing to unclench your fist. More than six years later, he has arrived at a moment of truth in testing that proposition with one of the nations most intransigent adversaries.

title: Not Just for Reptiles
description: On a visit from Sweden, Sophie Loven and her daughter, Elsa, took a moment to bask in the sun on Thursday in Central Park.

title: Sheldon Silvers Lawyers Again Ask Judge to Drop Indictment
description: Lawyers for State Assemblyman Sheldon Silver made a new request on Thursday that a judge dismiss the indictment against him, arguing that the conduct he is accused of simply does not amount to any federal offense.

title: How to Save Water: The California Way
description: Drought is not new to California. Indeed most of its residents have been living with it for years, making them experts in conservation. We asked our readers in California how they have adapted to a life with less water. Here are some of their suggestions and tips on how to live with drought.

title: Californians Who Conserved Wonder if State Can Overcome Those Who Didnt
description: LOS ANGELES  Some Californians are already showering just once a week, with buckets at their feet to catch every errant drop. They are building rainwater tanks in their backyards and replacing their lawns with mesquite and desert sage. They glare at water-wasting neighbors, and post photographs online to drought shame businesses that spray down their sidewalks.

title: Congress Responds Cautiously to Framework, and Demands Right to Review Deal
description: WASHINGTON  Leading lawmakers from both parties in Congress responded cautiously on Thursday to the tentative framework for a nuclear deal between Western powers and Iran, demanding to review any final agreement but pointedly refraining from a vow to kill the accord.

title: For ESPNs New Website on Race, a Fervent Leader in Jason Whitlock
description: BRISTOL, Conn.  Jason Whitlock stood before a group of ESPN employees last week, not in his customary role as a sports columnist, but as the public face of The Undefeated, the media giants soon-to-go-live website that will examine race through the prism of sports. With his baggage lost on the flight east from Los Angeles, Whitlock wore a red T-shirt and black warm-up suit. He was warm and funny, and he occasionally teased his largely African-American staff  a style that appeared at odds with his occasionally combustible writing and his firing by ESPN nine years ago for publicly criticizing two of his colleagues.

title: Review: Skylight, With Carey Mulligan and Bill Nighy, Opens on Broadway
description: They are hardly a well-matched pair, this couple that has been given such transfixing life in two of the most expert stage performances youre likely to see for many seasons. As embodied by Carey Mulligan and Bill Nighy in the heart-piercing revival of David Hares Skylight, Kyra Hollis and Tom Sergeant have none of the things in common that usually make for a fine romance.

title: Very Quick Ears to an Accusation
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  Its always nice to end the workweek with a themeless Patrick Berry puzzle. I found this one to be right in the sweet spot, solving-wise, primarily because I know all about ERIC Cartman and South Park. You have your points of reference, I have mine.

title: Religion Laws Quickly Fall Into Retreat in Indiana and Arkansas
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Roman Catholic nuns and brothers in robes along with conservative activists and lawmakers, all surrounded Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana last week as he signed what was billed as a religious freedom law. Smiling and proud, some of them had cheered the bill as a way to protect religious business owners from having to provide cakes and flowers to same-sex weddings.

title: A Traditional Hindu Spring Parade in Queens Is Canceled as Organizers Feud
description: At about this time every year, members of the Indo-Caribbean population in New York City come together in Queens, and in a burst of color and gaiety celebrate the arrival of spring. They hold a big parade. They sing and dance. And in a signature rite of the festival, they throw colored powder and liquid dye on one another.

title: Ronald Herron, Brooklyn Rapper Known as Ra Diggs, Gets 12 Life Prison Terms
description: That Ronald Herron would be sent to prison for the rest of his life was a foregone conclusion when he strode into Brooklyn federal court on Thursday, winking and smiling at friends and family.

title: President of Saks Steps Down
description: The president of Saks Fifth Avenue, Marigay McKee, stepped down Thursday after 15 months at the department store chains helm. She was replaced by Marc Metrick, an executive at Sakss parent company, Hudsons Bay.

title: In Hollywood, A-List Talent Agencies Battle Over Departure of Agents
description: LOS ANGELES  United Talent Agency poked a bear earlier this week, stealing movie star clients like Will Ferrell and Chris Pratt from the powerful Creative Artists Agency. On Thursday afternoon the bear struck back.

title: Zhou Yongkang, Former Security Chief in China, Faces Corruption Trial
description: HONG KONG  The former head of Chinas law-and-order apparatus, Zhou Yongkang, will stand trial on charges of bribery, abusing power and disclosing state secrets, the countrys top prosecution office announced on Friday, making Mr. Zhou the highest-ranked Communist Party official to be indicted on graft charges.

title: Miroslav Ondricek, Cinematographer for Amadeus and Ragtime, Dies at 80
description: Miroslav Ondricek, a cameraman whose intimate, realist style propelled him from Communist Czechoslovakia to a successful career in Hollywood, where he was nominated for two Academy Awards for cinematography, died on March 28 in Prague. He was 80.

title: Pain and Elation Mix as Yanks Tweak Their Roster
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Windows of opportunity, creaking open and clattering shut, create their own unique rhythms each spring, and on Thursday they created a symphony in the Yankees clubhouse before and after their 6-2 split-squad victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Matt Harvey, on Target So Far, Has Bold Aim: Miss No Starts
description: JUPITER, Fla.  The Mets cleaned out their lockers Thursday, packed their bags one last time and dressed for a long trip. Their belongings were loaded onto trucks. Their cars had been shipped north. Spring training was ending, and Matt Harvey blended into the crowd, wearing what looked like a finely made black suit.

title: Officials Say Klan-Member Guards Plotted to Kill an Ex-Inmate in Florida
description: MIAMI  Three Ku Klux Klan members who worked as guards in Florida state prisons were arrested Thursday and accused of plotting to kill a former inmate by injecting him with insulin, according to an arrest affidavit released by the Florida attorney general.

title: Hotter Baseball Ticket in New York Is to See the Mets, It Appears
description: Throughout their 53 years of existence, the Mets have usually been New Yorks second baseball team. The Yankees generally outplay them and outdraw them, both in the stands and in the television ratings. But there have been exceptions to this state of affairs, most notably in the second half of the 1980s, when the Mets had a vibrant roster, won one World Series, nearly made it to a second and, for the most part, overshadowed their Bronx rivals.

title: New York City Ballet, Pointe by Pointe
description: To the uninitiated, a ballerinas life may seem like a frothy confection of princes, silky pink ribbons and countless curtain calls, all wrapped in tulle. The reality is quite different: hours of practice, day after day, year after year. Nowhere are the results of that effort more evident than at the New York City Ballet, the company founded in 1948 by George Balanchine and Lincoln Kirstein that is home to some of the best dancers in the world. The troupe, which opens its spring season this month with a festival of Balanchines famously stark Black & White ballets and a new staging of current ballet master-in-chief Peter Martinss La Sylphide, counts 93 members in its ranks and hundreds more in its prestigious School of American Ballet. Here, a brief chass through their world.

title: Word of the Day | stipple
description: stipple  \sti-pl\  verb

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: April 3
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images from a Jean-Michel Basquiat exhibit, the site of the explosion in the East Village and golfing at Ferry Point.

title: Suits That Move
description: Designers like Brooks Brothers and Zegna are bending the rules of mens suits. To illustrate the new freedom, two dancers from the New York City Ballet test the limits of the wardrobe staple.

title: A Tour of Carlos Quirartes Bright Loft on the Bowery
description: Name Carlos Quirarte

title: How I Came Out as Gray
description: It was supposed to be our secret. My hairdresser claimed to possess a special elixir that could subtly, naturally, almost undetectably blend away gray hair, which, at 45, I had a touch of.

title: Should Grown Men Use Emoji?
description: A specter is haunting our communications: the specter of emoji. Right now, its likely that someone you know is texting a thumbs-up image to confirm a meeting, or maybe sending off a friendly ghost emoji to say boo to a friend.

title: I Figured Out How to Tie a Bow Tie, No Thanks to YouTube
description: My invitation to Vanity Fairs Oscar party called for an 11 p.m. arrival, so I gave myself plenty of time.

title: Not Your Uncles Gold Watch
description: Al Pacinos Tony Montana chased the American dream wearing an 18-karat Omega La Magique in Scarface.

title: Tools for the Gentleman Farmer
description: Gardening implements that celebrate simple, enduring design  with a high-tech option thrown in, for good measure.

title: The Men Powerful Enough to Wear the Same Thing Every Day
description: Mark Zuckerberg may not seem like a fashion role model, but he is arguably the most visible member of a self-selective group of men who have chosen to adopt a personal uniform.

title: Between Pant Leg and Shoe, a New Calm
description: Springing forward with graphic socks in black and white, striped polos, high-fashion sneakers and, yes, pleated trousers.

title: Honey, I Messed Up the Kitchen
description: Would you like to know what its like being the food editor of The New York Times? Its a lot of cooking, eating, reporting and editing, and about 270 emails a week from people asking whether they can substitute anchovies for nutmeg. Readers want to know what to cook for children, for parents and bosses, frenemies, friends. They ask questions about how to use kitchen tools, how to make pizzas, when to grill and why to broil.

title: The New Mens Fragrances, Aggressively Packaged
description: Targeting the man of the world who harbors an inner Navy SEAL, fragrance makers are packaging their scents in containers suggestive of weaponry.

title: Going Out on Weekends Is No Longer Just for Amateurs
description: For nightcrawling New Yorkers aiming for fabulousness, the weekends have traditionally been the time to triple-bolt your door shut, nest with a movie (or a lover) and avoid the clueless throngs.

title: Ode to the Beastie Boys Deluxe Zine
description: Question: What publication would run a 24-page story on Lee (Scratch) Perry and, in the same issue, a cultural investigation of the mullet as well as Top 10 Old-School Skate Stories by the photographer Glen E. Friedman? Only one: Grand Royal, the magazine published by the Beastie Boys from 1993 to 1997.

title: Waiting on the Elio, a Three-Wheeled Dream Car of the Future
description: Last year, Sean Donahue, a 37-year-old marketing director at a branding firm near San Diego, attended the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, where, amid virtual reality goggles and 4K televisions, he saw a design that struck him as truly futuristic. It looked like something out of the movie Gattaca,  Mr. Donahue said. As a nerdy tech guy, I was enthralled with it.

title: An Ex-Punk Mixes Drinks at Brooklyns Alameda Bistro
description: While growing up in Springfield, Va., Mike Stankovich dreamed of becoming a park ranger. In his 20s he played guitar in several hard-core bands in Washington, D.C.s, punk scene. Now he creates distinctive cocktails behind the marble-topped horseshoe-shaped bar at Alameda, a lovely 47-seat bistro in Greenpoint, Brooklyn.

title: The Ups and Downs (Mostly Downs) of Men in March
description: As you read, or casually scroll through, this review of the male misbehavior that occurred in the previous month, keep in mind that something like it may have been written, or chiseled into stone, or illustrated in berry juice on a cave wall, at any point over the last, oh, 40,000 years.

title: Behold, the Non-Iron Shirt
description: It may seem strange to see a product without a microchip being touted as high-tech or high-performance. But the same marketing ideas that have done so much for cars and computers are also helping sell mens garments.

title: Backpacks Go Luxurious
Mark and Jonnie Houston Shake Up Hollywood Night Life
description: LOS ANGELES  Twenty-something women with perfectly mussed hair and men in stylishly distressed jeans were lined up outside a Victorian-style house on a recent Saturday night. Inside, bearded bartenders mixed Old Fashioneds, while big-band jazz boomed throughout the bordello-esque rooms.

title: A Mens Boutique Owner Answers Your Burning Fashion Questions
description: Odin New York, a mens clothing shop founded by Ed Chai and Paul Birardi, got its start on East 11th Street in 2004. Set apart by its friendly but nonintrusive staff, it now has three handsome spaces, each designed for men to shop in peace. Here, Mr. Birardi provides a boutique owners view of what stylish men have been buying lately.

title: How to Scrub Your Body Like a Man
description: Emerging from a harsh winter, men are shedding their clothing and, sometimes if theyre not careful, too much of their skin.

title: Surfer Kelly Slater Wades Into Fashion
description: His first childhood memory of water is of being held beneath the surface until he thought he would drown. He imagines his last memory of water might be a moment when he is towed into an 80-foot monster he anticipates will take him out.

title: Four Mostly Hangover-Free Bachelor Party Getaways
description: The unsung hero of the wedding party is the best man. Not only must he deliver a toast that will make the guys laugh and the girls tear up, but he also has to arrange a bro-rific getaway beforehand that everyone will remember (and the groom wont regret). Each of the four weekend trips suggested here is offered with a sampling of wholesome excursions and not-so-wholesome nighttime activities.

title: A New Freedom in Mens Suits
description: In the beginning, there were the rules, handed down from the proverbial mount. Thy suit shall be thy prison, in sturdy black, navy blue or gray. Thy feet must ache in polished brogues. Thy weekend wardrobe alone should be a comfort.

title: Iranians Celebrate Agreement Online and in the Streets
description: As my colleague Thomas Erdbrink reported from Irans capital, Tehran, Iranians greeted news of a framework nuclear agreement that could bring an end to international sanctions and isolation warily at first, and then somewhat more loudly.

title: The Men of Cond Nast Photographed in Their Natural Habitat
description: At the publishing empires new headquarters, a lot of editing goes into the office wear.

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: 9 P.M. (13) BILLY PORTER: BROADWAY AND SOUL Mr. Porter  who won several awards as the drag queen Lola, above, in the Broadway musical Kinky Boots  performs jazz-inflected standards from the American Songbook in this Live From Lincoln Center presentation. As he transformed Take the Moment, an obscure song from the Richard Rodgers-Stephen Sondheim musical Do I Hear a Waltz?, into a pop-gospel plea, his performance created the kind of epiphany that a great voice can conjure out of thin air, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. The key lay not only in Mr. Porters innate vocal power but also in his commitment to shoot the moon, no matter the consequences. But the evenings coup was his reinvention of Sunday, from Sunday in the Park With George, as a church anthem, fusing Broadway and gospel traditions. It was the kind of juxtaposition that probably only Mr. Porter could have pulled off, Mr. Holden added, and it struck deep. In Annie Lennox: Nostalgia Live in Concert, at 10, Ms. Lennox puts her own spin on the genre with Summertime, Strange Fruit, God Bless the Child and other works in a Great Performances presentation taped at the Orpheum Theater in Los Angeles.

title: Mens Suits That Dance
description: The brief came while I was in the field, so to speak, reporting at the latest round of international fashion shows. For the first issue of our new, monthly Mens Style section, I was asked to feature suits that move.

title: Phil Jackson Faces Fans and Talks of Future
description: In the opening minutes of an event for Knicks season-ticket holders on Thursday night, Phil Jackson used the words acrimonious, sublimate and gestalt.

title: At Home in Pazardzhik
description: Serafim Todorov defeated Floyd Mayweather Jr. at the 1996 Summer Games in Atlanta, but his victory did not become a pathway to stardom and riches.

title: Serena Williams Outlasts Simona Halep to Advance to Miami Open Final
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  The duel was supposed to happen last month in the California desert in Indian Wells. But Serena Williamss winning streak finally did collide with Simona Haleps winning streak, and it was worth the wait.

description: INTERNATIONAL

description: When I looked back, I saw them. There were five or six of them. They were masked. And they were shooting live rounds.

title: Xi Jinpings Sayings Now Available in Little Red App
description: President Xi Jinping of China is the model of a modern multimedia leader. He has appeared in cartoons,been praised in song, had his travels tracked by a very dedicated Weibo account, and had his book on governance translated into at least nine languages.

title: The Conscience of a Corporation
description: So here is Walmart, insisting that our core basic belief of respect for the individual is at odds with an Arkansas bill that would allow religious-based discrimination. And here is Marriott, slamming as idiocy similar measures in other states. And somewhere in there is the family-run pizzeria, asserting that Indianas new law allows them to deny wedding day pies to people whose choice of spouses they dont approve of.

title: Denmarks Drug-Free Pigs
description: PRESIDENT OBAMA didnt need to issue a $1.2 billion National Action Plan for Combating Antibiotic-Resistant Bacteria, which he did last week, to figure out how the United States could reduce the antibiotic-resistant bacteria created by the countrys agriculture industry. He could have simply spent a day with Kaj Munck, a Danish hog farmer.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Power and Paychecks
description: On Wednesday, McDonalds  which has been facing demonstrations denouncing its low wages  announced that it would give workers a raise. The pay increase wont, in itself, be a very big deal: the new wage floor is just $1 above the local minimum wage, and even that policy only applies to outlets McDonalds owns directly, not the many outlets owned by people who bought franchises. But its at least possible that this latest announcement, like Walmarts much bigger pay-raise announcement a couple of months ago, is a harbinger of an important change in U.S. labor relations.

title: On Conquering Fear
description: Everybody is afraid sometimes, and, at those moments, it doesnt really help to say, Suck it up and get over it! So it would be nice if there were subtler strategies and techniques to conquer fear.

title: Memories of a Seder
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Screen Pilots and Protect Passengers
description: The crash of a Germanwings plane last week and the news that its co-pilot had been treated for depression and suicidal tendencies raise questions about how to keep pilots with mental health problems from possibly putting passengers at risk. One step is broadly adopting recommendations an aerospace medical group made in 2012, after a JetBlue pilot suffered an apparent mental breakdown during a flight.

title: Whats On This Week Around the World
description: Doha, Qatar

title: Test Yourself | Toys of the Future
description: Here are several paragraphs from a March 28 article, A Wi-Fi Barbie Doll With the Soul of Siri.

description: In Shabab Attack on a Kenya University Kills 147, Officials Say, Ismail Kushkush and Rukmini Callimachi report on a deadly attack about 90 miles from the Somali border.

title: U.S. Economy Gained 126,000 Jobs in March, an Abrupt Slowdown in Hiring
description: The yearlong streak of robust monthly job creation was broken on Friday with the Labor Departments report that employers added just 126,000 workers in March, a marked slowdown in hiring that echoed earlier signs that sluggish business investment and punishing weather were exacting a toll on the economy.

title: Hes the Last Boxer to Beat Floyd Mayweather Jr., and He So Regrets It
description: PAZARDZHIK, Bulgaria  The man who beat Floyd Mayweather Jr. lives across the street from a burned-out coffee hut with a giant banana painted on its back wall. Around the bend, leaning in the tall grass, is a corroded shed holding ancient farming equipment. Every so often a horse trots down the craggy road, pulling a splintered cart and a rider toward the center of one of this countrys poorest towns.

title: Tom Cotton Is Not Mailing It In
description: Your last name is Cotton, and this interview was arranged by your communications director, Caroline Rabbitt. Who is your chief of staff, Beatrix Potter? If only. No, my chief of staff is Doug Coutts.

title: When Should Countries Negotiate With Their Traditional Enemies?
description: Ever since the Iranian Revolution and the Iran hostage crisis, the United States and Iran have not had formal diplomatic relations. George W. Bush famously called Iran a part of the axis of evil in his 2002 State of the Union address. But on Thursday, the United States announced that it had reached a framework agreement with Iran to prevent it from developing nuclear weapons.

title: Colorado Furor Erupts Over Charges Filed, and Not Filed, in Grisly Attack on Pregnant Woman
description: DENVER  It began with what one family called an unimaginable loss: Michelle Wilkins, seven months pregnant and excited about becoming a mother, showed up at the Northern Colorado home of a woman who had posted an online advertisement offering baby clothes. There, the authorities say, the woman beat and choked Ms. Wilkins and cut her fetus from her womb with a kitchen knife.

description: Good morning.

description: Question:

title: New York Today: 80s Flashback Friday
description: Good Good Friday Friday morning to you.

title: Daily Report: Regulators in Europe Take Aim at American Tech Giants
description: It is not a good week to be a giant American tech company in Europe, Mark Scott reports.

title: Teenagers in The Times | March 2015
description: Welcome to Marchs edition of Teenagers in The Times.

title: Germanwings Co-Pilot Accelerated During Descent, Data From 2nd Recorder Shows
description: PARIS  The co-pilot of the German airliner that crashed into the French Alps last month accelerated as he deliberately guided the aircraft toward the ground, Frances air accidents investigation body said Friday, based on data from the planes second so-called black box.

title: With 50-1 Bet, Casino Owner Sits Two Michigan State Wins From $1 Million
description: LAS VEGAS  In a town where gamblers prefer the color green over Kentucky or Duke blue and the money that comes through betting windows is classified as either from squares or from wiseguys, Derek Stevens combined his heart with his head and now sits on a potential $1 million payday.

title: Letter of Recommendation: The Thomas Guide to Los Angeles
description: Twelve years ago, when I moved to Los Angeles, I didnt dare to so much as walk to the mailbox without bringing along the Thomas Guide. Known as the bible of Southern California, the thick, spiral-bound atlas was so universally relied upon that businesses and party hosts often cited page numbers and grid coordinates when giving directions. My copy was the 1998 edition, given to me by a friend who left the city right around the time I came. Vowing never to return, she handed it over like a dieter discarding a pair of fat pants: I wont be needing this anymore.

title: Re: The Mother of All Problems
description: Raising a teenager is like trying to nail Jell-O to a tree, Cyndie Dunlap McKiddy wrote on Facebook, responding to Rachel Cusks essay on the difficulty of life with her two adolescent daughters in the March 22 edition of the magazine.

title: Across the Creek Is the Other Side of the River
description: My father told me bedtime stories from mythology. They were cautionary tales, and it wasnt long before I saw how they gave figurative context to lifes ordinary events  how myth could speak to our grief or hubris or vanity. In this poem, Charles Wright gives us a glimpse into a private moment of contemplation with a startling reference to the journey of Orpheus.

title: Ars Botanica
description: When I was about 12, my grandmother went to work for rich people as a live-in governess. I dont know what rich people do on Sundays, but theyre never home. So all of us  my parents and my brother and I  would go visit my grandmother where she worked.

title: How to Avoid Death by Lightning
description: For most of the last 15 years, Michael Utley has been passing out refrigerator magnets that say When Thunder Roars, Go Indoors! If he could go back in time to heed his own advice, lightning would not have ripped through him on a Cape Cod golf course in May 2000. Most important, dont ignore the warnings: telltale rumble, blackening sky, the weather report. It is almost never a bolt out of the blue, says Utley, who gives lectures on lightning safety.

title: Borecore
description: The Vine videos that rise to the top of the heap typically feature dance routines, quick-cut pranks and the occasional clever stop-motion short. But if you tap into the video-sharing apps raw fire hose, a different picture emerges. For example, VPeeker  a site that provides an unending stream of recent Vine uploads  reveals that buried beneath those popular Vines lies a less visible but more intriguing trend: six-second displays of normalcy. Rather than killing time at the mall, in a Spencers Gifts or the food court, young people are filming themselves doing the incredibly mundane: goofing around in a backyard pool, lounging on basement couches, whatever; in other words, recording the minutiae of their lives and uploading it for not very many to see. New services are stepping in too, offering the immediacy Vine cannot. Theres Meerkat, which lets people broadcast video feeds from their phones of what theyre doing at any particular moment. Theres YouNow, which is like Meerkat but primarily the domain of teenagers, who use it to stream video of themselves, bored, at home, in their bedrooms. (For now, its totally innocent.) A cynic might dismiss all this obsessive self-documentation as evidence of generational narcissism, but you could just as easily choose to view it as a developing global pastime. Call it borecore: the never-to-be-viral output that comes from mixing powerful devices and a lifetime of social-media training with regular, old teenage boredom. Seen this way, its predecessors are more prosaic than pathological: doodling in a composition notebook, making scrapbooks, driving around aimlessly. But that simplicity, that sameness, can feel magical when you binge on it: a series of furtive glimpses into the lives of people across the country and around the world doing a whole lot of nothing. Though the technology available to us has far exceeded our wildest imaginations, its still perfectly suited to filling those moments when our imaginations just wont do.

title: How the Slave Trade Built America
description: We dont know exactly when the last sale of enslaved persons occurred in Richmond, Va., known as the great slave market of the South, but it must have taken place before April 3, 1865. On the previous day, the order had come to evacuate in advance of the arrival of Union troops who liberated the city.

title: Fighting TB with a Drive-in Film and Test
description: Some lives hang on the distance of dusty roads, with a cure out of reach. Take tuberculosis, an ancient disease that still kills about 4,100 people each day around the world because the tests to diagnose it and the drugs to treat it are inaccessible to many in need.

title: Today in Politics: Menendez Indictment Could Alter Congresss Role on Iran
description: Good Friday morning from Washington, where the framework for a nuclear deal with Iran has overtaken the debate over religious rights laws as the partisan wedge of the week. Hillary Rodham Clinton weighs in on Iran, and a pledge of support from a Republican senator could clear the way for Loretta E. Lynchs nomination as attorney general. The Labor Department prepares the latest job numbers, as President Obama gets ready to return from a trip out west in time for Passover. The Iran deal intersects with another major story line: the corruption charges against Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey.

title: Video Reviews of Furious 7, Woman in Gold and 5 to 7
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on Furious 7, Woman in Gold and 5 to 7. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: First Draft Focus: Obama Lands in Utah, His 49th State
Bigotry, the Bible and the Lessons of Indiana
description: THE drama in Indiana last week and the larger debate over so-called religious freedom laws in other states portray homosexuality and devout Christianity as forces in fierce collision.

title: Irans Leaders Begin Tricky Task of Selling Nuclear Deal at Home
description: TEHRAN  As word made its way around the globe that an understanding had been reached with the United States and other powers to limit Irans nuclear program, Iranians themselves greeted the news with optimism and skepticism on Friday.

title: The Dancing Garage Attendant
description: Dear Diary:

title: How Will the Saks Shake-Up Affect the Fashion World?
description: Well, that was fast.

title: Leonardo DiCaprio Builds an Eco-Resort
description: In what may be his highest-impact leading role yet, the actor Leonardo DiCaprio, the Oscar-nominated Wolf of Wall Street, is planning to heal an island.

title: The Grand Waldhaus Hotel
description: For over a century, this crenellated fortress has attracted European intellectuals and loyal families drawn to its Old World charm and resolute lack of sleek amenities.

title: 1940: War is real, U.S. is told
description: France is not fighting a phoney war and it will not accept a phoney peace, Premier Paul Reynaud declared last night in a radio talk in English to the United States, which was carried on a national hook-up in America. He said that, once Hitler has been crushed, Europe can return to normal life, eliminating disastrous war budgets and spending billions on social welfare instead of armaments, at the same time returning to a sane conception of exchange and taking up the problem of establishing a federative bond.

title: A Menagerie of Childhood Pets
description: Alexandra Zsigmond and Aviva Michaelov, art directors for Opinion, share some early sketches from a recent Op-Art.

title: When Heirs Fight Over Assets With Sentimental Value
description: ROBIN WILLIAMSS widow, Susan Schneider, agreed that the rainbow suspenders he wore on the television comedy Mork & Mindy should go to his children from previous marriages, but she did want the tuxedo the comedian wore at their wedding. Simple, it might seem, but not in the complicated world of blended families.

title: Luring Renters With V.I.P. Treatment
description: A private tour of Central Park led by its official historian and photographer. Premier seats at a basketball game and a meet-and-greet with a former Knicks player. Front-of-the-line access at hot Manhattan nightclubs. Instant reservations at hard-to-get-into restaurants.

title: The New Job Numbers Show Just How Muddy the Economic Outlook Is
description: For the last few months, there has been a bit of a mystery in the economic data. The American job market seemed to be roaring, with the nation adding around 300,000 jobs a month. But most every other measure of the economy was softer, suggesting more of the slow growth that has been all too typical the last several years.

title: Converting Audio From a Cassette to MP3 Requires an Adapter
Perceptual Sleaze
description: The resemblance between Americas right and a doomsday cult is something quite a few people have noticed: when various prophecies of disaster, from hyperinflation to an Obamacare death spiral, failed to materialize, the people predicting those disasters simply found new ways to maintain their faith. So Jonathan Chaits detailed takedown of denialism about Obamacares success is well done, but not all that distinctive.

title: Over 50 and Back in College, Preparing for a New Career
description: A MONTH before turning 60, Helen White received her masters degree in sport management at George Washington University, and now teaches basketball and pickleball and organizes recreational programs and tournaments for older adults throughout the Washington area.

title: Symmetric Scots
description: Mervyn King gave the Graham lecture at Princeton last night, provoking a crisis of technology: he didnt come with PowerPoint, but did want a lectern, which Princeton proved unable to provide. He had a lot of interesting things to say  boy, is he hard on euro area policymakers, and as I heard him hes surprisingly sympathetic to the current Greek leadership. But wearing my technical international economist hat, I thought the most interesting discussion involved the hypothetical case of an independent Scotland using the pound as its currency.

title: The Many Faces of Puerto Rico
description: Beneath indigo skies speckled with starlight, well-heeled arts patrons and civic leaders spilled out of the opulent lobby of the Condado Vanderbilt, where theyd turned out as much for a pop-up shop of designer fashions and jewelry as for the scene itself. Sun-kissed guests draped in elegant clothing sipped Champagne, chatted and air-kissed.

title: Chinese Anti-Graft Activist Plans Lawsuit Over Detention for Prostitution
description: An anti-graft campaigner who was detained for allegedly soliciting a prostitute said on Friday that he planned to take legal action against the authorities he said set him up and tried to publicly shame him in retaliation for his investigations into official corruption.

title: With Fishing, Suspense Trumps a Sure Thing
description: If youd asked me a year ago whether the day that I caught 25 fish would be better than the day I caught just one, Id have said it would be no contest. But Id have been wrong.

title: Come Out and Live, Shabab Told Kenya Students. It Was a Lie.
description: GARISSA, Kenya  Elosy Karimi curled up in a crawl space, immobilized by fear.

title: The Biggest Hit to Your Retirement Savings: Living Too Long
description: If you have a decent-sized nest egg for retirement, or are on your way to amassing one, your retirement worries are only half solved.

title: Q.& A.: John Isner Advances to His Own Final Four
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  John Isner came into the Miami Open with a losing record for 2015 after struggling in the early season. He also lost both singles matches in the United States first-round Davis Cup teams 3-2 loss to Britain last month. But he has found his range and won four straight singles matches in Miami, beating three players seeded in the top 10: Grigor Dimitrov (No. 9), Milos Raonic (No. 5) and Kei Nishikori (No. 4). Isner, a 6-foot-10 American, has yet to drop his serve and is now into the semifinals, which, in this case, might better be termed the final four.

title: In Rome, Industrial Ruins Take On a Colorful New Profile
description: The Ostiense district fills a milelong wedge in southern Rome between the Tiber River, Fascist-era rail lines and the third-century Aurelian Walls. Once a buzzing industrial hub, the zones broad central artery, Via Ostiense, was flanked by warehouses, factories and power stations, but when these complexes were shuttered decades ago, the area sank into a period of eerie desolation. A recent revival has invigorated Ostiense, as new businesses, cultural spaces, university classrooms and the worlds largest Eataly Italian food emporium have injected it with life. Meanwhile, ambitious street art murals  sanctioned and otherwise  lend a splash of color to Ostienses transformed industrial ruins.

title: Saturdays Sets up Shop, and Its First Cafe, in Osaka
description: With a track record of designing stores that aim to be local hangouts as much as they are places to buy a pair of board shorts, its no surprise that the team behind Saturdays picked the laid-back vibes of Osaka for its new retail location in Japan, opening, appropriately, this Saturday.

title: Queens E.M.T. Who Stole From Ambulance Service Gets 4 Months in Jail
description: An emergency medical technician who stole more than $300,000 from a nonprofit volunteer ambulance service was sentenced by a Queens judge on Friday to serve four months in jail and pay full restitution, the state attorney general said.

title: Stuff We Liked
description: Instead of playing outside in the spring sunshine, our staff found these things on the web to delight you:

title: Q. and A.: Ha Jin on Patriotism, Exile and A Map of Betrayal
description: Ha Jins latest novel, A Map of Betrayal, tells the story of Shang Weimin, a Chinese mole within the C.I.A. He adopts the name Gary, becomes a United States citizen and, unable to return to his wife in China, starts a family with an American woman. When his identity is finally uncovered, China does nothing to save him. Gary takes his own life in his prison cell.

title: Ted Cruz Has a Swag Problem
description: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas has addressed standing-room-only, town hall-style meetings throughout his recent campaign sweep through Iowa. But, despite the crowds and enthusiasm, none of the events have completely felt like a campaign event. Something was missing.

title: Sailor Lost at Sea Is Rescued, but Details of Ordeal Are Hazy
description: The Coast Guard rescue technician was surprised by what he saw as he descended from a helicopter to retrieve Louis Jordan, who had been lost at sea for two months, from a German container ship below.

title: Alabama Man Freed After Decades on Death Row
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  Nearly 30 years after the Alabama authorities relied on analyses of a handgun and bullets to send him to death row, Anthony Ray Hinton was freed on Friday after experts undermined the states case.

title: Upshot Letter: Our Anti-Parenting Bias
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: Neuroscience
description: THE TEENAGE BRAIN

title: Reading Options for Opening Day
description: After a long, cold winter in New York, baseball is finally here, and its time to break out the bats, balls and books.

title: Paperback Row
description: INSIDE A PEARL: My Years in Paris, by Edmund White. (Bloomsbury, $16.) In his 2009 memoir, City Boy, White, one of Americas pre-eminent gay writers, recalled life in New York in the post-Stonewall years. Inside a Pearl finds him in Paris in 1983, experiencing a second coming-of-age: Theres frenetic pleasure-seeking and glittering names  Yves Saint Laurent, Catherine Deneuve, Michel Foucault  as White falls headily in love with the city and its culture.

title: American Dance Institute Changes Focus
description: American Dance Institute, founded 15 years ago in Rockville, Md., plans to spend less time teaching dance and more time supporting dancers and presenting new work  including with a New York season next year, the organization announced Friday.The institute plans to close its ballet school, which has around 300 students, at the end of the summer, and to begin offering scholarships to help young dancers study at schools of their choice. At the same time it plans to expand its Incubator program, which was established in 2011 to develop new works: in addition to giving performances at its home in Rockville, the institute will have a five-week New York season at The Kitchen in the summer of 2016.

title: Editors Choice
description: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.

title: Why Paying for Financial Advice Makes Sense
description: If you are lucky to earn more money than you need each month, there was probably a time when you could have used some advice about how best to spend, save and protect it.

title: Retired Japanese Fighter Pilot Sees an Old Danger on the Horizon
description: NAGANO, Japan  Kaname Harada was once a feared samurai of the sky, shooting down 19 Allied aircraft as a pilot of Japans legendary Zero fighter plane during World War II. Now 98 years old and in failing health, the former ace is on what he calls his final mission: using his wartime experiences to warn Japan against ever going to war again.

title: Dennis Lehanes World Gone By, and More
description: Joe Coughlin was just a wide-eyed boy in The Given Day, Dennis Lehanes epic novel about a family of Boston cops who prospered in the early 20th century, surviving poverty, prejudice, the Spanish flu pandemic and a crippling police strike. In Live by Night, Joe returned as an alienated young hoodlum who rejected his fathers harsh code of ethics, finding a surrogate in the mob boss who protected him in prison and groomed him to take over the family rackets in Florida. WORLD GONE BY (Morrow/HarperCollins, $27.99) continues this sweeping fathers-and-sons tale by holding out the promise of redemption to Joe, while giving him a son of his own to love and betray.

title: A Higher Form of Killing, by Diana Preston
description: The continuing centenary commemorations of the Great War, combined with its liberating recession from living memory into deep history, have inspired a multitude of re-evaluations. The ossified view of exclusive German guilt for its outbreak, the creaky clich of lionhearted soldiers dying as donkey-brained generals quaffed claret, the Vietnam-inspired insistence on its pointless futility  all of these are dissolving under the scrutiny of a new generation of academic and popular historians.

title: Barefoot Dogs, by Antonio Ruiz-Camacho
description: Toward the beginning of Barefoot Dogs, Antonio Ruiz-Camachos lean and beautifully rendered debut collection, a mother tells her young son why they had to abandon their privileged life in Mexico for a lonelier existence in Palo Alto: There were some mean people in Mexico who wanted to take everything we had away from us. The harsher truth is that the Arteaga family patriarch has been kidnapped, putting the lives of the entire clan in peril, forcing them into sudden exile across the United States and as far as Spain. Narrated in alternating perspectives, Barefoot Dogs is a deeply moving chronicle of one familys collective devastation, full of remarkable wisdom and humor, yet unflinching in its portrayal of the horrors sweeping contemporary Mexico.

title: A Spring Chicken Soup With Miso
description: I like soup all year round and applaud its various personalities. Thick soups are substantial and warming; brothy soups are restorative and soothing; chilled soups are refreshing and invigorating.

title: Proving Parental Love, on Snowshoes and Roller Coasters
description: When I was growing up, my father was terrified of roller coasters, but he would still ride on them with my sisters and me. Our favorite, the Rebel Yell, had several towering, rounded peaks and a rickety wooden track. My father would pace nervously for the 45 minutes in line, feel sick in the trek to the top, nauseated on the drop, green and queasy as we rolled back to the gate and then just shake his head the rest of the day in shock and relief.

title: Netanyahu Says Final Nuclear Deal Must Include Irans Recognition of Israel
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel introduced a new demand Friday for the final phase of negotiations over Irans nuclear program, saying the completed deal must include an unambiguous Iranian recognition of Israels right to exist.

title: What Comes Next and How to Like It, by Abigail Thomas
description: Two pages into her third memoir, What Comes Next and How to Like It, Abigail Thomas tells us that I dont know anyones story except my own and I dont even know that. That coy little torque of paradox, the would-be wisdom and confessional pride of the serial memoirist, is a constant throughout this short book, much more so than in its predecessors. In Thomass first memoir, Safekeeping, she wrote of being married three times, of having four children, of the death of her father and her second ex-husband, and about meeting her third husband, Rich. In A Three Dog Life, a moving encounter with grief, we learned about the traffic accident that left the unfortunate Rich brain damaged and cared for in a nursing home. We learned that Thomas had an apartment in Manhattan, a house in Woodstock and, eventually, three dogs. Disappointingly, in spite of her intimate, confiding air, we do not learn where this kind of money came from.

title: The Wisdom of Perversity, by Rafael Yglesias
description: Childhood was the ideal soft metal for the permanent engravings of evil.

title: Act of God, by Jill Ciment
description: Jill Ciments new novel, her fifth, begins in the summer of 2015 in Brooklyn. A mysterious, luminescent mold infestation begins to spread through the apartments of a rowhouse, entwining the lives of its residents: the elderly twin sisters, Edie and Kat, one a retired librarian, the other a failed bohemian; Vida, a middle-aged actress; and Ashley, an 18-year-old Russian au pair discovered hiding in Vidas closet.

title: Meeting the English, by Kate Clanchy
description: In the opening pages of Kate Clanchys lively, charming novel, Meeting the English, a successful writer named Phillip Prys muses about the state of the literary world while brushing his teeth. By the time he reaches for the mouthwash, hes revealed himself to be homophobic, sexist and bigoted, although 62-year-old Phillip believes that his ravishing (and 26-year-old) Iranian wife, Shirin, gets him off the hook on that last count. Hes also indignant. Its 1989, and while his most famous work, a play about miners called The Pit and Its Men, is still read in schools, Prys knows his manly style is going out of vogue. Instead, people are reading posh namby-pamby gossamer, half of it written by women like Angela bloody Carter.

title: The Hunting Gun and Life of a Counterfeiter, by Yasushi Inoue
description: Those works of Japanese literature that win fans in the West tend to look westward themselves: the Wildean imaginings of Junichiro Tanizaki, for example, or Haruki Murakamis jazz-inflected quests. Yasushi Inoue has never enjoyed such international popularity, but his enormous oeuvre  begun in midcentury and only in midlife, after a successful career as a newspaperman  made him one of the most celebrated authors in Japan by the time of his death in 1991. Two graceful new translations, the first published last fall and the second last month, should help expand his audience in English.

title: James Hannahams Delicious Foods
description: When readers first meet Eddie, one of the principal characters in James Hannahams much anticipated second novel, he is struggling to steer a stolen vehicle out of Louisiana and north up Interstate 45, to where hes told his aunt and longtime protector now lives, in St. Cloud, Minn., a place whose very name sounds to him like heaven after the hell he has just endured. Eddie has no hands. How exactly he came to have them severed, a final act of desperation in a novel singularly focused on desperate acts, isnt revealed until the end. But one thing becomes brutally apparent from the start: Eddies mother, Darlene, is overtaken by drug addiction born out of grief over the early, violent death of Eddies black activist father, Nat  and her clouded judgment leads to any number of miseries for herself and her son. When she is tempted in her stupor into a van and into a contract with a company called Delicious Foods, which also gives the novel its title, she is secreted away to a camp where she is forced to work, in order to pay off the debt of her room and food and the diet of crack cocaine overseers use to keep their slave laborers subdued. The drug so utterly annihilates Darlenes autonomy that it speaks for her, narrating her portions of the novel as Scotty  a sinister, wiseass monologuist who often sounds like a cross between Katt Williams and the Devil himself.

title: ASAP Rocky to Take Part in Tribeca Film Festival Talk
description: The crowded Tribeca Film Festival schedule just got a little more packed. Organizers announced Friday that the rising hip-hop star ASAP Rocky would take part in a Tribeca Talk on April 21, discussing music and storytelling with the journalist Elliott Wilson.

title: Eleanor Marx: A Life, by Rachel Holmes
description: Three women possessed of extraordinary political talent loved men who were unworthy of them: Rosa Luxemburg, Emma Goldman and Eleanor Marx. The first two survived these debilitating attachments, the third did not. At the age of 43, upon learning that her common law husband of 14 years had secretly married a 22-year-old actress, Eleanor took poison and died. Had her father, Karl Marx, been alive he would have been not only distressed by her death but, I think, dismayed that a daughter of his could not surmount this level of betrayal, for the sake of international socialism if nothing else.

title: Inside the List
description: The Reformer: At least since the frenzied days after 9/11, some pundits have called on moderate Muslims to criticize the more extreme elements of their faith from within. Ayaan Hirsi Ali would seem to fit the bill: Born in Somalia to a Muslim family, she fled to the Netherlands rather than submit to a forced marriage, and has since been vocal in chastising radical Islam for its embrace of violence as well as its treatment of women, gay people and nonbelievers; in short, shed like to see Islam evolve to become more secular and ecumenical. (She outlined much of this agenda, along with her life story, in the 2007 book Infidel, which spent seven months on the hardcover and paperback nonfiction lists.) So its been interesting to see just how polarizing Hirsi Ali  whose new book, Heretic, enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No.8  has turned out to be. A professed liberal, she applied for work with left-leaning think tanks when she moved to America in 2007, but found no takers. They didnt say it to my face, but I got the feeling that they were uncomfortable with what I had been saying about Islam, she told the author Sam Harris last year. Instead she found a home with the conservative American Enterprise Institute, which seems at peace with her message that Islam is a religion of war. Muslims regard any insult to the Prophet or the Quran as deserving the ultimate penalty, she writes in Heretic  which makes the case for an Islamic Reformation  and this is not an extreme position. To her critics, Hirsi Ali may lack nuance: In fighting fervor with fervor, she can seem less like a moderate Muslim than an immoderate anti-Muslim. (In fact, as she explained in Infidel, she is now an atheist.) Then again, lack of nuance has never hurt a books success. Isnt that part of Hirsi Alis argument, after all?

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Joni Mitchell, Fish Oil and Pain Relief
description: Take the Quiz

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Netflix Says House of Cards to Return for 4th Season
description: Netflix confirmed that a fourth season of its original House of Cards political drama is in the works and will debut next year.

title: Purifying the Sea of PDF Data, Automatically
description: Many government agencies publish data about their work on a regular basis, often daily or weekly. Some conveniently post it in easy-to-use formats such as CSV files. Others, however, seem to disclose it begrudgingly, each week posting a stack of PDF files on a website and removing the previous set, with no archive anywhere. At least theyre publishing at all, right?

title: Court RejectsBhararas Plea to Reconsider Insider Trading Ruling
description: The legacy of Preet Bhararas crackdown on insider trading  his prosecutors won more than 80 convictions as they swept through Wall Street  might now hinge on the most unpredictable of allies: Congress.

title: Snake, Rattle and Roll
description: Scenes from the worlds largest rattlesnake roundup in Sweetwater, Tex.

title: A.L. Preview: Orioles Fine-Tune a Winning Formula
description: The record shows that the Baltimore Orioles were swept in four games by the Kansas City Royals in the American League Championship Series last fall. That is a fact, and anything else may be spin. But here goes.

title: Mens Style: A Guide to Men, the Boneheaded Things They Do and Cool Watches
description: Jim Windolf is the editor of Mens Style.

title: For Republicans, Weak Jobs Report Is a Welcome Target
description: After a week spent debating gay rights and religious rights in Arkansas and Indiana and the merits of monitoring centrifuges in Iran, Fridays tepid unemployment report provided a respite for Republicans seeking safer footing for criticizing President Obama.

title: A New, and Historic, Hike in Ireland
description: A stage coach route created in 1815 through historic villages and sites in southwestern Irelands County Kerry is the new destination of a self-guided hike from Ireland Walk Hike Bike.

title: 10 Ways to Teach and Learn About Spring (While The Learning Network Is on Vacation)
description: We thought last winter was bad, but, as William Grimes wrote on March 20: This is the winter that has made New Yorkers grateful for a windchill temperature above 15 and almost delirious when the thermometer rises above the freezing mark. Never has the hunger for spring been so acute and so palpable.

title: Salmon With Anchovy Butter
description: Melissa Clark makes salmon with a double application of anchovy butter.

title: Rand Paul Has J.C. Watts in His Corner
description: When Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky kicks off his campaign for president on Tuesday, one of the people who will endorse him and share the stage is former Representative J.C. Watts, one of the few black Republicans to have served in Congress.

title: 1915: Anger at Americans Death
description: LONDON  Mr. Walter Hines Page, American Ambassador in London, and Mr. R.P. Skinner, American Consul-General, have reported to Washington the result of their preliminary inquiry into the case of Mr. Leon Thrasher, the American citizen who perished when the Falaba was torpedoed by a German submarine.

title: The Second Avenue Explosion Changed Tenants Lives in an Instant
description: Late last summer, Laura Gibson, a demure singer-songwriter, moved to New York from Oregon, where she had spent most of her life, first in a small town on the southern coast and later in Portland, to pursue a graduate degree in creative writing at Hunter College. She knew that moving to New York as a student at 35 would present certain challenges, but she was fortunate in two regards  her adviser was to be the acclaimed novelist Colum McCann and her living arrangement would take the form of a well-priced room in a relatively spacious apartment in the East Village with friends of friends, a puppeteer and his wife, a poet.

title: Coast Guard Airlifts Rescued Sailor
description: A video shows the Coast Guard retrieving Louis Jordan from a container ship that found him off the North Carolina coast 66 days after his sailboat capsized.

title: Mad Men and Its Love Affair With 60s Pop Culture
description: A look at some of the pop culture touchstones featured in Mad Men, and how The New York Times originally covered them.

title: The Importance of Naming Your Emotions
description: How are you feeling?

title: N.L. Preview: With Rotation of Aces, Nationals Are Ready to Rise
description: In the National League, the first half of this decade has unfolded in a pattern a preschooler could understand: Giants, Cardinals, Giants, Cardinals, Giants.

title: An Easy Salmon Recipe for Weeknight Meals
description: Its rare to find a piece of salmon that actually tastes like fish. Farmed salmon is rich and mild, but isnt really reminiscent of the sea. Frozen wild salmon, which is whats available most of the year, has a deeper flavor, but it often lacks a pronounced saline punch.

title: Revisiting Subprime Mortgages
description: Subprime has been a dirty word since the freewheeling mortgage lending spree that ultimately brought down the economy and propelled millions of homeowners into foreclosure.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Becoming Steve Jobs
description: This week, Brad Stone talks about Becoming Steve Jobs; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Amanda Schaffer discusses three new books about neuroscience; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Becoming Steve Jobs
description: This week, Becoming Steve Jobs and three new books about neuroscience.

title: Something About a Snake Brings Everybody Out
description: You know how every small town has that one thing that the entire town looks forward to? Mike Hurd II told me as he held five dead rattlesnakes aloft, wrapping their tails with masking tape to keep their bladders from exploding as he cut away their skin. Its that one small thing that puts this town on the map.

title: John F. Burns Answers Readers Questions on Experiencing History
description: After 40 years at The New York Times, John  F. Burns, a two-time Pulitzer Prize winner, will next week conclude a distinguished career that included reporting from war zones like Bosnia, Iraq and Libya, and witnessing some of the most significant events of our time, among them the end of apartheid in South Africa and the tyranny of Taliban rule in Afghanistan. He answered readers questions about some of these experiences, his views on our future and his dreams of meeting Mao Zedong.

title: Josh Hamilton Wont Be Disciplined Under Baseball Drug Program
description: An arbitrator ruled Friday that Josh Hamilton, the troubled Los Angeles Angels outfielder, could not face discipline under Major League Baseballs drug program. Hamilton, who has fought drug and alcohol addiction for years, had reported a relapse to the commissioners office two months ago, and the league was upset by the arbitrators ruling.

title: $77,500,000, a Record for Co-ops
description: The $77,500,000 sale of the New York Jets owner Woody Johnsons Fifth Avenue duplex to the Ukrainian-born billionaire Leonard Blavatnik topped the previous record for the highest price paid for a city co-op and was the most expensive closed sale of the past week, according to city records.

title: Jobs Report Adds to Evidence of a Slowing Economy
description: This mornings disappointing employment report confirms what an array of economic indicators has been suggesting for some time: The economy is slowing.

title: The C.F.D.A. Awards Host, Choupette Makes Millions and Competitive Prom Dressing
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: At 54, Jockey Is Closer Than Ever to a Kentucky Derby With El Kabeir
description: Charles C. Lopez has won more than 4,000 races in 36 years as a jockey, with most of those victories coming aboard mediocre horses at middling tracks. Yet he kept the faith that a major opportunity would come. And now, at age 54, one is finally at hand.

title: Movie Review: 5 to 7
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews 5 to 7.

title: Movie Review: Woman in Gold
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews Woman in Gold.

title: Movie Review: Furious 7
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Furious 7.

title: Verbatim: Presidential Passover Wishes
description: President Obama, wishing those who celebrate a Happy Passover.

title: After Wall Street Exit, Banker Finds the Right Fit for His Return
description: Donald Meltzer, who ran Credit Suisses global mergers group during the heady deal-making era at the turn of the millennium, is returning to Wall Street after a hiatus pursuing Jewish studies.

title: Transgender Inmates Hormone Treatment Lawsuit Gets Justice Dept. Backing
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department put the nations prisons and jails on notice on Friday that it regarded blanket policies prohibiting new hormone treatment for transgender inmates to be unconstitutional.

title: The Iran Nuclear Deal: What You Need to Know
description: It Is Only Preliminary

title: Quakes in Oklahoma
description: Maps showing a rise in the number of earthquakes.

title: As Quakes Rattle Oklahoma, Fingers Point to Oil and Gas Industry
description: PRAGUE, Okla.  Yanked without warning from a deep sleep, Jennifer Lin Cooper, whose family has lived near here for more than a half-century, could think only that the clamor enveloping her house was coming from a helicopter landing on her roof. She was wrong.

title: Where the Science Guy Loosens His Tie
description: William Sanford Nye  but surely you know him as Bill Nye the Science Guy  lives in a one-bedroom apartment on the 24th floor of a rental building in Chelsea. Outside his floor-to-ceiling windows: the Empire State Building and the Flatiron Building. Bliss squared. Practically at his doorstep: the N, the R and the 1 subway lines. Bliss cubed.

title: Israeli Response to Iran Nuclear Deal Could Have Broader Implications
description: JERUSALEM  It took President Obama two days to call Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel after his March 17 electoral victory, and any congratulations were couched in an excoriation of Mr. Netanyahus hawkish and divisive campaign rhetoric.

title: The Iran Nuclear Deal: A Scorecard
On Senator Menendez: His Lawyer Responds
Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City region:

title: First Ad From Ted Cruz Campaign Highlights His Parents
description: Senator Ted Cruz, while on the campaign trail in Iowa and New Hampshire, has spoken often of his parents early struggles. And now he has made their story a centerpiece in his first campaign ad as a presidential candidate.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: Spread the Word: Mens Style Is Here
description: Simone Oliver, growth strategy editor for Lifestyle News, describes how The Times is raising awareness for Mens Style, its first new section since 2005.

title: With a New Exhibition, Ari Marcopoulos Keeps His Distance
description: The four-decade-long career of the photographer Ari Marcopoulos has been a varied and vibrant one; he is prized as both an intrepid documentarian and an intimate portraitist, equally at home in the spheres of youth skateboard culture, underground music, Commes des Garons and Jay Z. But his latest works, on view at Marlborough Chelsea starting tomorrow, represent an alternate view of his world: They insert a marked distance between his viewer and his subject, physically and figuratively speaking. With these far-off landscapes and urban still lifes, both shrouded in the opacity of black ink, Marcopoulos aims to create the mood of a faint memory, of a fleeting moment from travel to an undisclosed location.

title: Big Business and Anti-Gay Laws
description: Big corporations like Walmart, Apple, Salesforce.com and General Electric and their executives have done the right thing by calling on officials in Indiana and Arkansas to reject religious freedom laws designed to give businesses and religious groups legal cover should they deny service to gay couples. But the business response to these laws raises a larger issue about the role companies play in the political process. If corporate leaders are serious in opposing discrimination, they should refuse to finance the campaigns of lawmakers who want to deny civil rights to gays and other minority groups.

title: Outdoor Shakespeare Series Finds a New Place To Park
description: Shakespeare in the Parking Lot has found a new home. The 20-year-old troupe, which was displaced from its Lower East Side locale at the intersection of Ludlow and Broome Streets last year, is moving three blocks awayto a parking lot behind the Clemente Soto Velez Cultural and Educational Center.

title: Early Rodgers and Hart, an Album of New York City Blight, and Two Looks at Gentrification
description: Dominic Symonds calls the hook from Manhattan an iconic couplet, even though most people quote it incorrectly. His  Well Have Manhattan: The Early Work of Rodgers & Hart (Oxford University Press) is a meticulous exploration of a songwriting duo whose formative years mirror the development of the Broadway musical between the world wars.

title: Its Not the Inequality; Its the Immobility
description: Income inequality and economic immobility are often lumped together, but they shouldnt be.

title: Alabama Officials Find Harper Lee in Control of Decision to Publish Second Novel
description: The lawyer for the author Harper Lee, Tonja B. Carter, received notice on Friday that an investigation by Alabama officials into whether Ms. Lee, 88, and confined to an assisted living facility, was manipulated into publishing a second novel has been closed and no evidence of abuse or neglect had been found.

title: In New York Waters, Its Time for the Spring Peepers Love Song
description: It is hard to imagine that the dark vernal pools of April, so recently ice-limned, are now at the vanguard of springs incursion.

title: Billy Martins Education of Buck Showalter
description: In February 1988, Billy Martin was about to turn 60 years old. A month earlier, he had been married for the fourth time, which equaled the number of times he had been fired by George M. Steinbrenner. But at spring training that year, Martin was again leading the Yankees. On his staff was a young coach, 31-year-old Buck Showalter, then a promising managerial star of the Yankees lower minor leagues.

title: Prime Cuts for Over a Century
description: Pinos butcher shop has survived the wave of gentrification that has overtaken SoHo, even surviving its landlords attempt to evict it a few years ago.

title: An Old-School Butcher Shop Endures in SoHo
description: On a recent Saturday afternoon, shoppers in SoHo  or at least a certain subset of consumers, who werent headed to brunch or a boutique  were doing what theyve been doing for more than 100 years at 149 Sullivan Street: buying meat. They were greeted by opera music and Buongiorno! called out from Pino Cinquemani, the latest in a line of butchers who have presided over this tiny storefront. Some might even refer to it as an artisanal meat shop, but not to Mr. Cinquemanis face.

title: Miami City Ballet Gets New Funding
description: Miami City Ballet announced on Friday that it had lined up $6.5 million in new support as it prepares to celebrate its 30th anniversary next season with a national tour and a new production of George Balanchines A Midsummer Nights Dream with a dash of Florida flavor.

title: Tiger Woods Will Play Masters, Ending Two-Month Leave
description: Tiger Woods, who has been on a two-month leave from competition to work on his game, will play in the 79th Masters next week, he announced on his website on Friday. He will be in search of his fifth Masters title, 10 years after he last won the event.

title: Clinton Said to Rent Brooklyn Space for Campaign Headquarters
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton has leased two floors of office space at 1 Pierrepont Plaza in Brooklyn for her presidential campaign headquarters, according to a person familiar with the deal.

title: Stop the Presses
description: Most men would like a no-wrinkle shirt. Now they can get it without the itch.

title: Porky at the Bat
description: Porky McDonald, 54, the baseball bard of Astoria, appreciates the importance of quantity.

title: X Marks an Upper West Side Rental
description: If X marks the spot, there might soon be a stampede for 170 Amsterdam, a high-end rental opening this month in the Lincoln Square neighborhood.

title: Cut From the Same Cloth
description: Melvin Miller and Jeremy Britton, one a minister and the other studying to be one, were married on March 14 at Riverside Church in Manhattan.

title: Because Its Friday
description: In a visit to Jimmy Fallon on NBCs Tonight Show on Thursday night, Michelle Obama put to rest any doubts that her dancing ability had diminished during her days in the White House.

title: Cooking Techniques: Making Mayonnaise
