description: Whisk together egg yolk, lemon juice, mustard, water and neutral oil to form this emulsion.

title: Call It the Pisces Effect
description: When he was younger, the Rev. Melvin Poindexter Miller had been torn between pursuing a career in dance or the ministry. After he was accepted into a seminary, though, the decision seemed behind him.

title: Think Like a Doctor: Breathless Solved
description: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to take on the case of a 64-year-old woman who suddenly began to have episodes of rapid, erratic breathing. Nearly 200 of you wrote in with suggested diagnoses. Many of you correctly noted that it was her diaphragm moving abnormally that was causing her chest and abdomen to flutter that way. And a good chunk of you  around 20 percent  correctly identified this as

title: Affiliate of Al Qaeda Seizes Major Yemeni City, Driving Out the Military
description: AL MUKALLA, Yemen  Militants from Al Qaedas affiliate in Yemen tightened their grip on this coastal city in the countrys south on Friday, driving soldiers away with mortar fire so that the city was left undefended, witnesses said.

title: Book Review Podcast: Becoming Steve Jobs
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Brad Stone reviews Becoming Steve Jobs, by Brent Schlender and Rick Tetzeli. Mr. Stone writes:

title: French Bill Barring Ultrathin Models Clears a Hurdle
description: PARIS  Controversial new measures to prohibit modeling agencies from hiring dangerously thin models and to require that retouched photos of models be clearly labeled overcame a major legislative hurdle on Friday, winning approval by the National Assembly, the lower house of Parliament.

title: Humans of A.C.P.T.
description: A look at the people who make the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament a special event.

title: One Final Four but Three TV Versions, Two for Biased Fans
description: Fans have been known to complain loudly about what they perceive as subtle biases from national television announcers. So what will they make of a broadcaster openly cheering for one side or even singing an alma mater?

title: Divorce Isnt an Option, Until It Is the Only One
description: In Unhitched, longtime couples tell the story of their relationship, from romance to vows to divorce to life afterward.

title: Parties Trade Places in Culture Wars Over Rights Measures
description: WASHINGTON  The uproar set off by legislation in Indiana and Arkansas that sponsors billed as religious freedom measures not only signaled a revival of the culture wars, but also threw into stark relief the expectations and tensions in the coalitions that now make up the two major political parties.

title: No Kids for Me, Thanks
description: Chelsea Handler, the television host and best-selling author of My Horizontal Life: A Collection of One-Night Stands, and Geoff Dyer, the critically acclaimed British writer whose 15 books include Out of Sheer Rage: Wrestling With D. H. Lawrence, dont have much in common on the surface, aside from both calling Los Angeles home. But neither has an interest in procreating.

title: Evening Hours | Beauty in Mansions
description: From Boston to New York in one day.

title: Chanels Antidote to Megashows
description: The collection spotlighted the craftsmanship of the brands artisans.

title: Bill Cunninghan | Chanels Antidote to Megashows
description: Just as the Metropolitan Opera toured major cities in spring until the 1950s, Chanels Mtiers dArt show journeyed from Salzburg, Austria, to New York, arriving at the Park Avenue Armory on March 31. The collection spotlighted the craftsmanship of the brands artisans. The scene, so different from many of todays cookie-cutter shows, was reminiscent of Paris couture presentations after World War II, when there were no photographers and no red carpets. The audience consisted of private clients, and the attention was on the details and techniques of each piece.

title: Whats That?You Want to be Buried How?
description: Recently my father called me to make the following announcement:

title: The Memory of Catholicism
description: Its Good Fridayfor Western Christians, so its a good time for a religion post that isnt just about the debate over Indiana, religious freedom and same-sex marriage. (This one wont entirelyescape those issues, but it will try to widen slightly the aperture through which we viewthem.)

title: Lauren Bacalls Eclectic Treasures Auctioned Off
description: Lee Roy Reams, an actor who appeared with Lauren Bacall in the 1970 Broadway musical Applause, was on the phone Thursday, exulting at his winning bid, for $2,000, on two deer antlers mounted on a carved wooden head from the auction of her collection at Bonhams New York earlier in the week.

title: This Womans Job Is to Recast Hillary Clintons Image
description: To get a brief reprieve from the pressures of working in the White House, Kristina Schake, a former aide to the first lady, Michelle Obama, took a class about her favorite painter, Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio.

title: Bahrain Arrests Rights Activist Over Tweets About Torture
description: One of Bahrains most prominent human rights activists, Nabeel Rajab, was arrested on Thursday for posting critical remarks about the government on Twitter.

title: Scenes from a Sustainability Quest, from Leopard Skin Sales to Lionfish Sashimi
description: I apologize for the fairly limited flow on Dot Earth of late. Like many people I meet, I have multiple work (and life) obligations. My two spring Pace University courses and visits to speak at other universities have taken up a lot of time.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Will You Help Tom Cotton?
description: I wrote yesterday about Senator Tom Cottons rather odd obsession with Iran, and wondered why it existed. I still dont know, but in politics, there is always money involved somewhere.

title: How Diller and von Furstenberg Got Their Island in Hudson River Park
description: The group gathered on Oct. 29, 2012, the day Hurricane Sandy roared into town.

title: Review: A.D.: The Bible Continues, an NBC Mini-Series
description: Are there ratings after the Crucifixion? We begin to find out on Sunday night, when NBC broadcasts the first installment of A.D.: The Bible Continues, a 12-episode follow-up to The Bible, a surprise success in 2013.

title: Review: The Undeniable Sound of Right Now, a Lament for a Dying Rock Club
description: Although no special olfactory effects have been employed, you can practically smell the spilled beer and stale cigarette smoke as you enter the Rattlestick Playwrights Theater, where The Undeniable Sound of Right Now, a new play by Laura Eason, opened on Thursday. Ms. Easons engaging, superbly acted drama takes place in a Chicago rock club thats been in business for a quarter-century and looks like it hasnt been given a good scrub since it opened its doors.

title: Our Cosmic Selves
description: JONI MITCHELL beat Carl Sagan to the punch. She sang we are stardust, billion-year-old carbon in her 1970 song Woodstock. That was three years before Mr. Sagan wrote about humans being made of star-stuff in his book The Cosmic Connection  a point he would later convey to a far larger audience in his 1980 television series, Cosmos.

title: What Harvey Weinstein Learned in Neverland
description: What brings Harvey Weinstein to Broadway? Over coffee at his TriBeCa offices, the movie mogul talked about what hes learned as the lead producer of the musical Finding Neverland, now in previews at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater. The interview took place on March 23. These are edited excerpts from that conversation.

title: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
description: Kenya and Elsewhere  Pictures of the Day

title: April 3, 2015 Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Kenya, Switzerland, Iraq and the United States.

title: Arab World Adjusts to Shift in U.S.-Iran Relations
description: CAIRO  Almost as soon as he had announced a nuclear deal with Iran, President Obama called King Salman of Saudi Arabia to reassure him of Americas enduring friendship.

title: A Cranky Blogger Crusades to Preserve the Ordinary in New York
description: Heres an old story: Your favorite dive bar/record shop/little Cuban restaurant gets turned into a Citibank/Apple store/luxury condominium. You pass through denial, anger, bargaining, depression, then inevitably settle into acceptance.

title: Predicting Pilot Suicide
Can We Beat Cancer at Its Own Game?
Learning Through Tinkering
description: SAN FRANCISCO  My 9-year-old daughter is in the midst of a pioneer unit in her third grade class. Its a great example of a project-based curriculum: The kids are developing math skills by determining what and how much they can pack without overloading wagons for a cross-country trek. They roll a twist of fate die that presents (virtual) obstacles they might have faced in the late 19th century  bad weather, loss of livestock, etc.  and then have to problem-solve to get their trek back on track. Theyre reading a variety of historical perspectives, such as Louise Erdrichs The Birchbark House and Laura Ingalls Wilders Little House books. And perhaps most important, theyre learning about self-sufficiency and resilience  and how even the youngest kids needed it in spades.

title: No Springtime Renewal in the Job Market
description: It will take another few months to see if the unexpectedly dismal job market in March was a fluke or the start of something bad. Economists had expectedthe latest employment report, releasedon Friday, to show 250,000 newly-created jobs last month, in line with the encouraging monthly tallies in the past year. But the economy added only 126,000 jobs and totals for January and February were revised down by 69,000 jobs.

title: How Jesse Malin, a Musician and Restaurateur, Spends His Sundays
description: Not all New York notables begin their Sundays at 7 or 8 a.m. Jesse Malin, for one, prefers a gentler start. It depends on how many sodas I had the night before, but I usually get up around noon, said Mr. Malin, 47, a musician and partner in several restaurants and bars in the East Village. Used to be a little later. Mr. Malin, a native of Queens, started hitting the East Village as a 12-year-old punk rocker and never lost his crush on the neighborhood, which is still digging out from the building explosion and seven-alarm fire on March 26. He currently lives alone on Avenue A. His new album, New York Before the War, ruminates on life today in the borough he calls the Old Apple. You walk out your door and a song can unfold, a story, a life, he said.

title: Parents and Teachers Meet in a New York Minute (or 5 if Theyre Lucky)
description: On parent-teacher conference day at Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan last week, scores of tense parents bunched together in the lobby, penned in behind yellow caution tape. At exactly 1 p.m., the tape dropped and the grown-ups stampeded up the stairs, jostling to get to the front of the pack.

title: Son of Iowa Governor Is Trailing Candidates, on Behalf of Ethanol
description: Candidates, welcome to Iowa. Now meet the governors son, who is tracking you.

title: Review: Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo in Detroit
description: DETROIT  Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo in Detroit is the story of two artists, two countries and one city. Filling several galleries at the Detroit Institute of Arts, it is also a serendipitous celebration of this exemplary museums hard-won independence.

title: Why the Trans-Pacific Partnership Matters
description: AFTER five years, American-led negotiations over the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a trade liberalization agreement with 11 other countries that collectively account for 40 percent of the worlds economy, are nearly complete. The next step is for Congress to allow for the same legislative process  an up-or-down vote on the deal  that it applied to recent trade pacts, including the North American Free Trade Agreement of 1993 and the United States-South Korea free trade agreement of 2011.

title: Review: Chamber Music Society, From Mirth to Mortality
description: Loss and retrospection, irony and passion were themes on Thursday when the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center presented a wide-ranging program of contemporary and 20th-century works for strings and piano at the Kaplan Penthouse. The excellent lineup of performers included the pianists Andrew Armstrong and Gilles Vonsattel, the violinists James Ehnes and Arnaud Sussmann and the cellist Nicholas Canellakis.

title: The Look North Inuit Art Gallery in Red Hook for Arctic Sculpture
description: There is a surprising and fluid connection between the indigenous art of the Alaskan Inuit and Red Hook, Brooklyn, and it is Jim Clark. Mr. Clark, a longtime fisherman and first mate on vessels that regularly ply the Bering Sea, also happens to be an art collector. After a dozen years of gathering contemporary native sculptures, he started his art gallery, LOOK NORTH, in 2007. No bland cubed cheese was served at the opening; 25 pounds of king crab vanished almost as fast as an eel in the sand.

title: The Week in Political Pictures
description: Nuclear talks with Iran, early campaigning for 2016, a bribery indictment and an outcry over religious laws.

title: John Galt Hates Ben Bernanke
description: Ah: I see that there was a Twitter exchange among Brad DeLong, James Pethokoukis, and others over why Republicans dont acknowledge that Ben Bernanke helped the economy, and claim credit. Pethokoukis  who presumably gets to talk to quite a few Republicans from his perch at AEI  offers a fairly amazing explanation:

title: Review: Murray Perahia at Carnegie Hall
description: The beloved American pianist Murray Perahia turns 68 this month, an age at which you might expect him to be mellowing as an artist and reaching new realms of profundity.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
Its Easy Being (Collard) Green
description: I think in green in early April, writes Martha Rose Shulman.

title: Bill Cunningham | Flowers and Dances
description: Bostons vines and New Yorks Frick museum dance welcomed spring.

title: Spring TV Preview: Familiar Names and Faces, Some of Them in New Places
description: The spring television season arrives with a bang on Sunday, when Wolf Hall makes its premiere on PBS, American Odyssey and A. D. arrive on NBC and Mad Men returns for its final episodes on AMC. Here are 15 more shows to keep on your radar over the next few months, including Netflixs first jump into the superhero genre, a new series from the creator of Freaks and Geeks and the return of Game of Thrones.

title: Friday Night Music: San Fermin at SXSW
description: OK, a bit of self-indulgence today  but then all of these posts fit that definition, I suppose. I mentioned the great experience I had at SXSW, of which one of the highlights was watching San Fermin come roaring back from technical problems. Well, I missed it, but someone did take a video of one song from that set; they seem to have been just a few feet behind me. And while the audio isnt the best, you do get some sense of what the theatrics  and the audience reaction  were like:

title: Review: Haydns Seven Last Words of Christ, by 2 String Quartets
description: We tend to think of Joseph Haydn as a consolidator: the composer who drew together numerous musical currents to perfect the symphony and the string quartet, defining forms of the Classical and Romantic eras. But Haydn was also an innovator, with what James Webster, in The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians, calls a modernist tendency to problematize music rather than merely to compose it.

title: Review: A Writhing, Emotional Revival of Wagners Tannhuser
description: BERLIN  The straight-arrow, even prissy Wolfram delivers the first entry in the song contest at the heart of Wagners Tannhuser. In the choreographer Sasha Waltzs spare, elegant staging of the opera here, men fall to the ground as he sings, so overcome are they by his stirring performance.

title: Candidate for Chicago Mayor Struggles to Unite Latinos and Blacks
description: CHICAGO  Jesus G. Garcia, candidate for mayor, strode down the sidewalk on Monday evening, trailed by a giddy pack of supporters, volunteers and passers-by. They snapped pictures and chanted his nickname: Chu-y! Chu-y!

title: Deception Again Wins the Day
description: The second excellent deceptive defense at the Spring Nationals in New Orleans occurred during the Silodor Open Pairs. (The first was described in Thursdays column.) It was reported to The Daily Bulletin by Barry Rigal of New York City.

title: The Shababs Horrifying Resurgence
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Kenya is reeling from the shock of the massacre, early on Thursday, of 147 people in an attack by Somalimilitants on a college. At least four Shabab gunmen stormed Garissa University College, about 200 miles northeast of the capital, Nairobi, before dawn. They took students hostage and continued their assault until late in the evening, when Kenyan security forces ended the siege.

title: High-Power Magnets Get Temporary Reprieve From Safety Rules
description: A federal appeals court has temporarily halted new safety rules for high-power magnets, dealing a setback to federal regulators who have spent years fighting to get such products off the market. The ruling was a reprieve for the last manufacturer.

title: The Evidence of Mexicos Missing
description: After 43 students disappeared in Mexico, Christopher Gregory went there to document the traces left by countless others who have been killed or kidnapped.

title: What New Yorkers Get for $150 Billion
description: After much self-congratulation this week, Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York and legislative leaders announced an annual budget that spends too much  $150 billion  for too little. Mr. Cuomo bragged that it is a budget that all New Yorkers can be proud of. Yet the details of this last-minute jumble of a budget yield very little for most people to celebrate.

title: How Many Years Until the Home Run Record Falls?
description: What makes a baseball record unbreakable? Sometimes the game changes and that puts a record out of reach. Sometimes an exceptional performance is too dominant to be matched. When the two combine, the record could last for centuries.

title: The Many Droughts of California
description: MORRO BAY, Calif.  CALIFORNIA has only two seasons, rainy and dry. In March, when the rains stop  assuming they have begun  we must forget about precipitation for at least six months. The rainfall determines our mood for the summer and fall. Where I live, on the Central Coast, 17 inches of rain per winter has been the long-term average. Beating that number  we last did it five years ago  feels like winning the lottery. Lately, the average has been well under 10.

title: Powdered Alcohol Meets Resistance in U.S. Before It Even Comes to Market
description: In 2012, Mark Phillips needed a way to market his new invention: a powdered form of alcohol that could be mixed with water.

title: Study Finds Mexican Troops Did Not Stem Drug-War Killings
description: MEXICO CITY  Rival drug gangs battle over territory. The murder rate rises and helpless residents implore the government to restore order. The government sends soldiers to keep the peace.

title: Embracing Change as a Way of Life
description: Ive become experienced in change. I definitely dont like it. Scratch that  I dread it. But Ive gotten a lot of practice and have learned a thing or two. The part I dislike most are the lasts. The last time playing pickup in the off-season; the last dinner with friends; the last night sleeping in my own bed.

title: Gravehopping: Mel Blanc
description: This is an essay in Gravehopping, a series within The End on visiting grave sites.

title: Rudolph Perz, Creator of Pillsburys Doughboy, Dies at 89
description: Rudolph Perz, an advertising executive who pondered a soulless, squishy, cylindrical mixture of flour and water on his kitchen table 50 years ago and conjured up the genial Pillsbury Doughboy, died on Thursday in a suburban Chicago hospital. He was 89.

title: An Opportunistic Manhattan Burglar Proves Difficult to Pin Down
description: Nelson Colon, 49, looked out the front door of the Manhattan apartment building he manages and sighed. This used to be safe, he said.

title: Main Syria-Jordan Crossing Under Insurgent Assault
description: AMMAN, Jordan  The main border crossing between Syria and Jordan remained closed and chaotic on Friday, with insurgents  including the Nusra Front, Al Qaedas branch in Syria, and Western-backed rebel factions  wrangling for control two days after they seized and looted the crucial gateway.

title: Report Details Flawed Law Enforcement Response to Marathon Bombings
description: While the immediate response to the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings saved lives of critically wounded spectators, law enforcement authorities came under some criticism in a new report for what played out a few days later.

title: In Police Chase Over Marijuana, Boy, 17, Falls From Bronx Roof
description: It began on Thursday night with a group of teenagers smoking marijuana in the lobby of a Bronx building. It ended three or four minutes later with one of them critically injured by a fall from the roof of the six-story building, lying in a dark alleyway with a police officer cradling his head.

title: Racist Emails by Ferguson Officials Released
description: The City of Ferguson, Mo., responding to Freedom of Information requests, has released the full contents of racist emails circulated by the chief court clerk and two police supervisors that were disclosed by the Justice Department in a report last month.

title: McDonalds Minimum Raise
description: The decision by McDonalds to raise workers pay to at least $1 over the local minimum wage offers some help for the 90,000 employees at the 1,500 American restaurants run by its corporate headquarters, but the relief is minimal and leaves out the far greater number of workers at the companys franchise outlets.

title: Fates of 3 Americans Held in Iran Remain Hazy Despite Diplomatic Progress
description: The families of three American citizens of Iranian descent who are incarcerated in Iran, one of them held for more than three and a half years, have been hoping that the success of diplomacy on the nuclear dispute would herald their releases as good-will gestures.

title: Everybody Hit Somebody
description: For the players on a womens football team, age and profession were no barrier to enthusiastically playing with confidence and intensity.

title: Easing the Difficult Path to the Pulpit for African-American Women
description: CHICAGO  Just before the Passover festival, the same point in the calendar when Jesus gathered his closest followers in the Upper Room, the Rev. Neichelle Guidry Jones knelt on the floor of a Hyde Park apartment here in devout imitation of her savior. She grasped a cloth and moved a ceramic basin into place and, in the manner that the Gospel of John described, humbled herself to wash the feet of the disciples.

title: College Teams Add Assault Prevention to the Basics They Teach
description: The Louisville mens basketball team advanced to the N.C.A.A. tournaments round of 8 this season, but it did so without its best defensive player: Chris Jones, a senior guard, who was dismissed from the program in February and shortly afterward pleaded not guilty to rape and sodomy charges. One of his two accusers was a fellow Louisville student.

title: East Village Gas Explosion Reveals Problems in Citys Inspection System
description: In the nearly eight months after utility workers found evidence of a leaking unauthorized tap on a gas line in an East Village building, the city never sent an inspector to make sure the dangerous activity had not recurred.

title: Mad Men and the Era that Changed Advertising
description: With Champagne toasts on a rooftop overlooking the Arc de Triomphe in Paris, John D. Wren and Maurice Lvy celebrated the $35 billion merger between their two advertising companies, Omnicom Group and Publicis Groupe. The trans-Atlantic deal was the largest ever in the industry, uniting the worlds second- and third-largest advertising groups to create a new global leader that would dethrone their archrival, Martin Sorrells WPP.

title: And Now, Political Virgins
description: On Tuesday in Texas, the House of Representatives voted to take $3 million earmarked for prevention of H.I.V. and other sexually transmitted diseases, and spend it instead on abstinence-only sex education. It was a fascinating moment  particularly when the sponsor of the motion, a Republican named Stuart Spitzer, told the House that he had been a virgin until he got married at age 29.

title: With Iran Deal in Hand, White House Makes Sales Pitch to Preserve It
description: WASHINGTON  Even before President Obama strode into the Rose Garden on Thursday to announce a historic understanding to restrain Irans nuclear program, an elaborate White House salesmanship effort for the deal was underway.

title: Michigan States Tom Izzo Looks to Knock Out a Friend, and a Blot on His Rsum
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Itsounds ridiculous to say that a coach with Tom Izzos rsum will try to break through on Saturday when Michigan State playsDuke in the Final Four.

title: An 1850s-Era Oyster Barge Is Saved for Yet Another Life on the East River
description: NEW HAVEN  For years, a shoddy shed of dilapidated wood has cluttered up the boatyard of the Fair Haven Marina, a hub for recreational boaters on this stretch of the Quinnipiac River, just east of Yale University.

title: A U.S. Concession to Reality in the Battle Against Islamic State
description: WASHINGTON  In the battle to retake Saddam Husseins hometown, Tikrit, from the Islamic State, the United States and Iran have found a template for fighting the Sunni militancy in other parts of Iraq: American airstrikes and Iranian-backed ground assaults, with the Iraqi military serving as the go-between for two global adversaries that do not want to publicly acknowledge that they are working together.

title: San Francisco Police Officers to Be Dismissed Over Racist Texts
description: San Franciscos police chief said Friday that he had moved to dismiss seven officers who sent or received text messages that spoke of lynching African-Americans and burning crosses.

title: For a Master of the Past, This Isnt a Nostalgia Tour
description: When Tiger Woods declared his intention Friday to play in the 79th Masters, people who were present for his stirring playoff victory 10 years ago against Chris DiMarco immediately tensed, as if preparing for the unavoidable one-car crash that was about to happen.

title: Sarah Brady, Gun Control Activist, Is Dead at 73
description: Sarah Brady, who became a tireless gun control activist after her husband, the White House press secretary James S. Brady, was shot and left partly paralyzed in the attempted assassination of President Ronald Reagan in 1981, died on Friday in Alexandria, Va. She was 73.

title: An Iran Nuclear Deal Built on Coffee, All-Nighters and Compromise
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland  It was just one of hundreds of arguments between American and Iranian officials as they tried to hash out what may prove to be one of the hardest-to-negotiate arms control agreements in history. But it spoke volumes about how two countries that so deeply distrust each other managed to strike a tentative deal.

title: Two Parts to His Name, but Karl-Anthony Towns Is One Complete Player
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  The given name of Karl-Anthony Towns  the 7-foot Kentucky center who wears size 20 sneakers and just might be the N.B.A.s next superstar big man  often came to represent two distinct personalities braided within one oversize body.

title: Go Back and Forth
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  Well. Someone is feeling his oats. Ned White is back and he has included some entries that will raise an eyebrow or three among you.

title: Nuclear Plant in Iranian Desert Emerges as Flash Point in Talks
description: The site looms up from the Iranian desert like something out of a thriller novel, ringed by antiaircraft batteries, a security perimeter two miles around, and huge tunnels that lead deep into the mountainous complex.

title: China Deports American Jailed on Spy Charges
description: BEIJING  An American geologist who was imprisoned for more than seven years on a vague charge of illegally procuring state secrets has been deported by China and arrived home in Houston on Friday, according to a human rights organization in the United States.

title: Preservationists Fight to Save a Former Asylum in New Jersey
description: PARSIPPANY-TROY HILLS, N.J.  Case number 65935 involved a 44-year-old man brought from the jail in Morris County to Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital on May 29, 1956. Described as rambling in his conversation, found by police wandering aimlessly on the highways, he told the admitting physician, I wrote about 8,000 songs and I got $10,000 for writing.

title: Notre Dame Doubles Down on the Mabrey Family From New Jersey
description: Five years ago, Roy Mabrey and several of his friends flew to Indiana to attend a Notre Dame football game. Mabrey grew so fond of the university that he began to hope his daughter Michaela, a talented high school basketball player, might choose it.

title: State Senate Leaders Says Additional $25 Million in Budget Will Aid Charter Schools
description: No one has ever described New York States budget process as being overly straightforward. But a handful of passages in the annual budget passed in Albany this week are prime examples of how important spending decisions can get buried in generic language.

title: Yanks Try to Maintain Healthy Perspective, but Questions Persist as They Break Camp
description: TAMPA, Fla.  In recent days, a trailer loaded with players luxury cars sat in the parking lot at Steinbrenner Field. Cardboard packing boxes, with each players number, were parked in front of their lockers. Before heading home, the Yankees gathered belongings from the clubhouse.

title: A Strength Coach for Wisconsin Uses an App That Works More Than Thumb Muscles
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Several Wisconsin players are used to the text message that arrives at 11 a.m. Every morning, they are supposed to log in to an app and enter certain data  what they ate for dinner the night before, how their bodies feel, how well they slept. They log in again after practices and answer questions about what they did and how they feel. The information is then crunched for the coaches with a program called Metrifit.

title: Andrew Porter, New Yorker Classical Music Critic, Dies at 86
description: Andrew Porter, a music critic celebrated for his stylistic elegance, immense erudition and polymathic command not only of the work under review but also of everything else in creation conceivably connected with it, died either Thursday night or early Friday in London. He was 86.

title: Obama Ventures Into Red States to Pitch His Economic Goals
description: HILL AIR FORCE BASE, Utah  He did not exactly bowl them over in Utah, or even in Kentucky. But he came anyway and maybe that was the real point.

title: Whats on TV Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) JERSEY BOYS (2014) Clint Eastwood transfers the Tony-winning Broadway show about the Four Seasons and its frontman, Frankie Valli (John Lloyd Young), set amid the Mafia milieu of 1950s New Jersey, onto the screen. Christopher Walken plays Gyp DeCarlo, the Genovese crime family member who watched over the boys; Mike Doyle is Bob Crewe, the producer who, starting in 1962, helps the ensemble (rounded out by Erich Bergen, Michael Lomenda and Vincent Piazza) mine gold with the hits Sherry, Big Girls Dont Cry and Walk Like a Man. Jersey Boys is a strange movie, and its a Clint Eastwood enterprise, both reasons to see it, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about the film, written by Marshall Brickman and Rick Elice, who also wrote the musical. For those with a love of doo-wop, it also provides a toe-tapping, ear-worming stroll down rock n roll memory lane that dovetails with that deeply cherished American song and dance about personal triumph over adversity through hard work, tough times and self-sacrifice.

title: Corrections: April 4, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I want to tell you my experiences in war so that younger generations dont have to go through the same horrors that I did.

title: Hip-Hop? She Wont Stop
description: In the 1980s, Janette Beckman, an expat punk photographer from London, amassed a portfolio of burgeoning New York rap acts like the Cold Crush Brothers, Big Daddy Kane and Public Enemy. It was a labor of love for Ms. Beckman, who had visited New York a few years earlier and was so entranced by the beginnings of hip-hop that she never left. She later collected those images in a book, but she challenges you to find a copy of it today.

title: Kamchatka, Home to Russian Version of Alaskas Iditarod, Frets Over Growth
description: PETROPAVLOVSK-KAMCHATSKY, Russia  When Vladislav Revenok, an Orthodox priest, first participated in the obscure Russian version of Alaskas Iditarod, he found himself in places so isolated that he was mobbed by villagers demanding to be baptized. They told him he was the first priest to visit the outback of the already remote Kamchatka Peninsula in about 50 years.

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photographers featured this week on @nytimes took viewers from a farm in Virginia to the streets of Kano, Nigeria.

title: Jay Edelson, the Class-Action Lawyer Who May Be Techs Least Friended Man
description: When technology executives imagine the boogeyman, they see a baby-face guy in wire-rim glasses. His name is Jay Edelson.

title: Hotel Guests Forage for Meals
description: Cooking classes at hotels are going well beyond the kitchen walls. Participants now forage for ingredients for meals they prepare.

title: Osbornia Revisited
description: As I think Ive mentioned, as part of a longer-term project Im doing some more work on British austerity  the reality, and, even more important, the perception. Its a strange story. For the most part, as we look across the advanced world, the intellectual arguments behind the great 2010 turn to austerity have collapsed  you dont see people invoking invisible bond vigilantes to warn of imminent crisis unless you slash spending, you dont see them invoking the confidence fairy to deny that spending cuts will hurt output. In fact, as Simon Wren-Lewis notes, you see efforts to rewrite the history and claim that nobody ever said the things they did, in fact, say to justify austerity.

title: In Kamchatka, Natural Splendor and a Hunt for Oil
description: Kamchatkas very isolation once afforded a measure of protection for its astounding beauty.

title: Feeding Pigeons and the Results
description: Feeding the Pigeons

title: Humans of A.C.P.T.
description: SPECIAL POST  Its the people who make an event. You can dress up an event in black tie and serve caviar, but if the people arent the type you would like to hang out with, it wont be memorable.

title: tktktktktk
description: tktktktktk

title: 1915: Super-Dreadnoughts Enter the War
description: In 1915, the European edition of the New York Herald reported regularly on the progress made by the Allies in their campaign in the Dardanelles, which, beginning successfully, caused a state of panic at the prospect of invasion in Constantinople.

title: Menendez Has Record of Overcoming Crises
description: UNION CITY, N.J.  Senator Robert Menendez launched his political career from the streets of this blue-collar town, an immigrant haven once considered Miamis cold-weather satellite thanks to its large and influential community of Cuban-American exiles.

title: Variety: A Punny Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  We encounter our fair share of puns here on Wordplay. By far, the most frequent type of playing around with words in our puzzles is the lowly pun and, today, Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon present us with a quote from the book Words Gone Wild, by Jim Bernhard, that is actually one of the few printable, triple puns in existence.

title: Kenyans Identify and Mourn Relatives Killed in Attack on University
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  They gathered by the hundreds outside the Chiromo funeral home and morgue, where the bodies of their loved ones had been brought. Some sat waiting for their turn to go inside, while others stood in a long line. Their faces went pale and their eyes teared up every time someone emerged, wailing, weeping or collapsing on a companions shoulder.

title: A Multimillion-Dollar Markup on a Modigliani
description: Last New Years Eve, Dmitry Rybolovlev, a Russian billionaire, sat down to lunch at the Eden Rock resort in St. Barts. Mingling with the other wealthy guests, he struck up a conversation with Sandy Heller, the New York art dealer and adviser to many hedge fund managers.

title: Sexually Assaulted at UVA
description: IN 1997, I was sexually assaulted by a fellow student at the University of Virginia. At a closed hearing, the universitys committee on sexual assault found him responsible. His punishment? A letter in his file.

title: Taking On Vertical Challenges
description: Jonathan Temple, 34, works for the Liberty Elevator Corporation in Paterson, N.J.

title: Rutgers, That Other Unbeaten Team in the 1976 Final Four
description: Alan Venooks season-preview article in the student newspaper was the harbinger. As The Daily Targums sports editor and a beat writer for the Rutgers mens basketball team, Venook had been around the team long enough to know that the Scarlet Knights would be very good in 1975-76. But looking at their schedule, Venook thought there was also a good chance the team could win every game.

title: Chinese Taxi Drivers Drink Pesticide in Beijing Protest
description: BEIJING  A group of taxi drivers drank from bottles of pesticide in central Beijing on Saturday to protest what they said was poor treatment by their taxi companies, state and social media outlets reported.

title: Measure for Measure, Index Funds Rule
description: Nearly anyone with money in the stock market since 2009 has benefited from the great bull market run. But compared with the overall market, most actively managed stock mutual funds havent performed very well or very consistently.

title: G.O.P.s Israel Support Deepens as Political Contributions Shift
description: WASHINGTON  As the proposed agreement over Irans nuclear program is debated in coming weeks, President Obama will make his case to a Congress controlled by Republicans who are more fervently pro-Israel than ever, partly a result of ideology, but also a product of a surge in donations and campaign spending on their behalf by a small group of wealthy donors.

title: In Death, as in Life, Its Royal Treatment for Animal Mascots
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Butler Blue III toddled about in the morning sun last week outside Butlers basketball court, Hinkle Fieldhouse. He drooled slightly. A 60-pound, 3-year-old purebred white English bulldog, Butler Blue III, known as Trip, has wrinkles over his eyes, speckles of brown on the backs of his ears and a burnt sienna dot atop his skull, part of his red brindled coat. He smelled like a damp towel, though not in an unpleasant way.

title: Elmer Lach, a Small but Tough Canadien, Dies at 97
description: Elmer Lach, a durable, undersize Hall of Fame center who used every one of his 165 pounds in becoming one of the National Hockey Leagues most combative players and in helping the Montreal Canadiens win three Stanley Cups more than 60 years ago, died on Saturday in Montreal. He was 97.

title: California Drought Tests History of Endless Growth
description: LOS ANGELES  For more than a century, California has been the state where people flocked for a better life  164,000 square miles of mountains, farmland and coastline, shimmering with ambition and dreams, money and beauty. It was the cutting-edge symbol of possibility: Hollywood, Silicon Valley, aerospace, agriculture and vineyards.

title: The Trader Who Donates Half His Pay
description: MATT WAGE was a brilliant, earnest student at Princeton University, a star of the classroom and a deep thinker about his own ethical obligations to the world. His senior thesis won a prize as the years best in the philosophy department, and he was accepted for postgraduate study at Oxford University.

title: Digital Neglect at the Library of Congress
description: The Library of Congress has long been a beacon for an informed democracy, evolving in Washington into the worlds largest library and a revered institution built on the foundation of Thomas Jeffersons many books and insatiable curiosity.

title: Joseph P. Riley
description: Joseph P. Riley is the mayor of Charleston, S.C. He will retire next year after 40 years in office.

title: Interview With a Christian
description: AFTER watching the debate about religious freedom unfold over the past week, I decided to subject myself to an interview by an imaginary  but representative  member of the press. Here is our conversation:

title: Young, Dying and Brave
description: Readers discuss the special needs of teenagers with cancer and other chronic illnesses.

title: Justice Kennedys Plea to Congress
description: Members of the Supreme Court rarely speak publicly about their views on the sorts of issues that are likely to come before them. So it was notable when Justices Anthony Kennedy and Stephen Breyer sat before a House appropriations subcommittee recently and talked about the plight of the American criminal justice system.

title: Let Prisoners Take College Courses
description: ATTICA, N.Y.  EVER wonder what prisoners do and talk about? Well, at the Attica Correctional Facility, were all tucked away in cellblocks watching TV. We watch a lot  all day, all night. Then we talk about what were watching. Conversation tumbles through the bars, about movies, ball games and the news on CNN. I hear voices, as if in a trance, rap along to Bobby Shmurdas new music video on BET. The lyrics  about dealing drugs, toting guns and committing murder  sound like an anthem for the lives many of us have lived.

title: Covering Hostages, Without Becoming Pawns
description: TO TAKE up the topic of how The Times has covered the Islamic State kidnappings of Western journalists and aid workers is to venture into a journalistic minefield.

title: Watering Californias Farms
description: Californias snowpack is now so low that when Gov. Jerry Brown visited a measurement station on Wednesday, there was no snow to measure. We are standing on dry grass, and we should be standing on five feet of snow, he said. The low snowpack  at 6 percent of normal  is further evidence of the seriousness of the states drought as well as another reminder of the excruciating choices facing Californias citizens and policy makers as they struggle to cope with it.

title: Turning Clutter Into Joy
description: RECENTLY, I went for a drink with a friend who said, Are you reading that Japanese tidying book everyone is reading? I wasnt, but I needed to be.

title: UConns Domination Is Win-Win for Womens Game,Geno Auriemma Says
description: TAMPA, Fla.  On the eve of another womens Final Four in which heaven, earth and Geno Auriemmas hair may have to be moved in order for a team other than Connecticut to emerge the winner, a predictable question was bound to be raised.

title: Why Evangelicals Should Love the Pope
description: ON Easter Sunday, Christians celebrate an event that inspires more than two billion of the faithful with eternal hope. Jesus spoke often about the life to come. Yet he also spoke about Gods will being done here on Earth. How best to live out ones faith in this world has been a complicated issue throughout Christian history, and it remains so today.

title: Good Riddance, Carrie Mathison
description: WASHINGTON  THE co-creator of Homeland on Showtime revealed recently that when the new season starts, Claire Daness Carrie Mathison will no longer work at the C.I.A.

title: The Real Reason College Tuition Costs So Much
description: BOULDER, Colo.  ONCE upon a time in America, baby boomers paid for college with the money they made from their summer jobs. Then, over the course of the next few decades, public funding for higher education was slashed. These radical cuts forced universities to raise tuition year after year, which in turn forced the millennial generation to take on crushing educational debt loads, and everyone lived unhappily ever after.

title: Thomas Cromwell, a Man for All Centuries
description: SUDDENLY, after 500 years of infamy and obscurity, here comes Thomas Cromwell: blacksmiths boy, petty thief, visionary bureaucrat, shrewd banker, mercenary soldier, multilingual bagman, knife-flashing cutthroat, henchman to a cardinal and fixer for a king.

title: Stuffed Animals With an Agenda
description: TUCSON  ON the outskirts of this city stands a fake-medieval castle with an elk statue atop its battlements. In the courtyard is a bronze relief of a man shouldering his rifle  one C. J. McElroy, a Texan who founded both this International Wildlife Museum in 1988 and, before that, in the early 1970s, Safari Club International, the trophy hunters group thats headquartered here.

title: Forest Green Rovers Tackles Sustainability Feet First
description: Everything about Forest Green Rovers says green, from its name to its jerseys to the rolling hills of the Cotswolds that surround the clubs home base in the Gloucestershire town of Nailsworth.

title: Sentiments and Spaghetti
description: Kino! 2015, a festival of German films that begins Thursday, has drama and emotion, and lets not forget pasta.

title: Basquiats First Editions
description: As a kid, Jean-Michel Basquiat (1960-1988) was a junior member of the Brooklyn Museum, which he used to visit with his mother and where he got a globalist view of art history that would provide fuel for his own later painting. Hes back at the museum now, part of that global history, in Basquiat: The Unknown Notebooks.

title: The Roads Never Traveled
description: Most people live their whole life on a path, says Matt Galland, a runner and pilot who teaches geography at Brigham Young University in Utah. My goal is to get off all paths.

title: Refreshening Postmodern Roots
description: If dance seasons were like fashion weeks, then some trends from the Spring 2015 collections would be legacy projects and tributes to Merce Cunningham. Paul Taylor just ended the inaugural catwalk of his American Modern Dance initiative to preserve vintage dances and champion younger contemporary voices alongside his own. And last month brought nods to Cunningham, who died in 2009, by Compagnie CNDC-Angers from France and Juilliard Dances Repertory. This week, the Stephen Petronio Company wraps up its 30th anniversary by starting Bloodlines, a five-year project to restage important postmodern dances. First up: Cunninghams RainForest from 1968, a work that feels both fanciful and menacing, with layers of drama, innocence and rebellion. Mr. Petronio also contributes a world premiere of his own, Non Locomotor, a companion to last years Locomotor (also part of this program), which confirms that three decades on, hes still addicted to the art of speed. (Tuesday through next Sunday, Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue at 19th Street, Chelsea; 212-242-0800, joyce.org.)

title: Victims of Financial Wrongdoing Need a More Muscular S.E.C.
description: Given the many billions of dollars financial companies have paid in regulatory and legal settlements related to the mortgage crisis, how much money has actually found its way into the pockets of investors harmed by their actions?

title: Giants Who Play Well Together
description: Herbie Hancock and Chick Corea have experienced a lot of jazz history in parallel: as elite pianist-composers in post-bops twilight phase; as alumni of two successive Miles Davis quintets; as bandleaders who defined the arc of fusion; as artist-philosophers, National Endowment for the Arts Jazz Masters and perennial Grammy favorites. Theyre also a mutual admiration society, and companionable partners, as documented on a pair of sparkling albums: An Evening With Herbie Hancock & Chick Corea: In Concert (Columbia) and CoreaHancock(Polydor).

title: The Intimacy of Small Crowds
description: Even chamber music often lacks intimacy in New York: Alice Tully and Zankel Halls, while smaller than some concert spaces, arent really ideal for trios or quartets. But two events this week deliver music for small groups at inspiringly close range. On Monday, the BAC Salon series, a program at the Baryshnikov Arts Center, presents five musicians (the oboist James Austin Smith, the violinist Tessa Lark, the violist Max Mandel, the cellist Edward Arron and the pianist Pedja Muzijevic) in an intriguing program: Mozarts seminal Piano Quartet in G Minor, Berios Sequenza VII for oboe and the solo-piano version of Cages The Seasons. (7:30 p.m., 450 West 37th Street, Manhattan; 866-811-4111, bacnyc.org.)

title: Do You Google Your Shrink?
description: I knew my psychiatric practice was forever changed the day a patient arrived with a manila folder stuffed with printouts and announced that it contained the contents of a Google search that he had done on me. He pulled out a photo of my mother and me, age 7, that had been published in my hometown newspaper; architectural plans for an addition to my house that was never built but apparently was registered locally by the architect; an announcement about my great-grandfathers becoming editor of Amazing Stories magazine in his old age; and my brothers history as a college activist.

title: New Music From the Mountain Goats, Joey Calderazzo, Becca Stevens Band and More
description: The Mountain Goats

title: Twyla Tharps 50 Years of Forward Movement
description: In April 1965, Twyla Tharp spun a yo-yo, stretched forward like a ski jumper while anchored by a pair of wooden shoes and stood in an extended relev. Such were the ingredients of her first piece, Tank Dive, which lasted around 10 minutes and was performed in an art studio at Hunter College.

title: At the Boston Symphony, Andris Nelsons Embraces Tradition but Looks Ahead
description: BOSTON  Traditions are protean things. Some are ancient, some lapsed. Some are vibrant, some arid. As the historian Eric Hobsbawm pointed out, most are invented, responses to novel situations which take on the form of reference to old situations.

title: Chocolations in Mamaroneck Is Frenetic in the Easter Season
description: On a recent Saturday afternoon, Maria Valente and members of her staff in her shop in Mamaroneck paused to consider what to name the four-foot-tall bunny standing in their midst.

title: ILoveMakonnen Is Big Online and Almost Famous
description: Waiting for the real world to catch up to Internet fame can be awkward, especially for a digital native accustomed to a daily cascade of favorites, retweets, streams and followers. Just ask ILoveMakonnen, the 25-year-old singer and rapper from Atlanta (best known as simply Makonnen), whose video for the hit single Tuesday, featuring Drake, has been seen more than 73 million times on YouTube.

title: Italian Cuisine With Imaginative Inspirations
description: Uh-oh, I thought, as I approached the free-standing Tazza Osteria & Bar in Fairfield, yet another Italian restaurant to open in the area. Nothing new here, I anticipated. But after I opened the nondescript-looking menu I began to change my tune, and when the small plates arrived, my apprehensions had disappeared.

title: A Move Toward Islanders Mania
description: I left New Jersey, only to find a new jersey, a new sport and a favorite team on Long Island.

title: A Review of H2Ocean in Cedar Knolls
description: Good seafood is hard to find. Restaurants that serve only wild-caught seafood are even scarcer. A happy exception, H2Ocean Restaurant & Raw Bar, which opened last August in Cedar Knolls, serves only the wild-caught variety of shrimp, scallops, salmon, tuna and other species on its varied menu.

title: Restaurant Review: Hush Bistro in Farmingdale
description: The food speaks is the motto of Hush Bistro, which opened in Farmingdale in November. The attractive, thoughtfully prepared food does indeed have a voice, but people at the restaurant have not been hushed; they are part of the conversation, too.

title: Findings Reignite Debate on Claim of Jesus Bones
description: JERUSALEM  Hailed by some as the most significant of all Christian relics but dismissed by skeptics amid accusations of forgery, misinterpretation and reckless speculation, two ancient artifacts found here have set off a fierce archaeological and theological debate in recent decades.

title: Iran Will Allow Women in Sports Stadiums, Reversing a Much-Criticized Rule
description: TEHRAN  In a major shift, Iran announced Saturday that women would be allowed to attend big sporting events, reversing a rule that had barred them from entering stadiums to watch matches attended by men.

title: Bronx Teenager Who Fell From Roof While Fleeing the Police Dies
description: A Bronx teenager who fell off the roof of a six-story apartment building on Thursday while fleeing police officers died of his injuries on Saturday at St. Barnabas Hospital, the police said.

title: Private Eyes in the Grocery Aisles
description: Mansour Samadpour makes his way through the supermarket like a detective working a crime scene, slow, watchful, up one aisle and down the next. A clerk mistakenly assumes that he needs help, but Mr. Samadpour brushes him off. He knows exactly what hes doing.

title: Washington Governor Puts Focus on Climate Goals, and Less on Debate
description: OLYMPIA, Wash.  In his office, Gov. Jay Inslee keeps a framed image of a stand of magenta paintbrush, an alpine meadow flower and a signature species in Washington, that he photographed while hiking with his wife in Olympic National Park. The magenta paintbrush is threatened by global warming, and the photograph is a reminder, Mr. Inslee said, of all the things that are at risk.

title: Gay Athlete Encounters Divisive Indiana Law, and Support
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Derrick Gordon landed here the other day, a fine guard with the University of Massachusetts, ready to watch two of the better Final Four college basketball games in recent memory.

title: In Westchester County, Teaching Artists Aid Students in Common Core Push
description: The 23 second graders in Betty Borkons class at George M. Davis Elementary School in New Rochelle didnt know it, but a classroom activity in which they were pantomiming what it would be like to be desert ninjas, walking trees and stuck-to-the-ground starfish was not just playtime.

title: A Golf Teacher With a Lions Instincts and a Doves Heart
description: Harvey Penick, the golf oracle from Texas, died 20 years ago this month, on the Sunday before the Masters. He never saw a spindly amateur named Tiger Woods make his first start that spring at Augusta National Golf Club.

title: Choosing to Do Good, Once Upon a Time
description: Amid the armed revolution, the child abandonment, the profiteering, the threatened rape, the attempted hanging and the severed head on a stick, there is goodness. And thats perhaps the strongest takeaway from Yale Repertory Theaters marvelous Caucasian Chalk Circle, shaped into vibrant life by the director, Liz Diamond, and running through April 11 at the University Theater in New Haven.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: A Time When the World Seemed Larger
description: When Nirvana was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2014, Joan Jett was chosen to sing the groups decade-defining hit, Smells Like Teen Spirit, at the ceremony. Kurt Cobain, who had written and originally performed the song  an anthem of alternative, anti-materialist subculture that had gone wildly mainstream  had killed himself in 1994. In a rare show of solidarity, the rock community almost unanimously agreed that Ms. Jett, a punk rock veteran,  was the perfect choice.

title: Getting In: High Low
description: The scores you need.

title: A Chorus Line Revival at the John W. Engeman Theater
description: Everything was beautiful at the ballet is one of the most recognizable song lyrics from A Chorus Line. A similar line, Everything is beautiful at the theater, could be the overall theme of the 1975 musical, which won nine Tony Awards and a Pulitzer Prize in 1976. For the characters in this show about show business, no matter the ups and often painful downs of auditioning, they are never sure they will get a job or, if they do, how long it will last.

title: A Lift Golfers Can Get With Their Eyes Closed
description: The top golfers in the world are like orchestra leaders conducting a symphony of nutritionists monitoring their food intake, trainers tailoring their workout regimens, coaches calibrating their swings, analysts crunching their statistics and psychologists decluttering their minds. The goal is to be in perfect harmony during the majors. But if the players circadian rhythms are off, it is akin to trying to create beautiful music with a percussion section that is a beat slow.

title: After Shift in Nigeria, Entrenched-Party Rule Faces Test Elsewhere in Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG  The historic election results last week in Nigeria, Africas most populous nation and biggest economy, drew worldwide praise and stirred hopes of a democratic domino effect on the rest of the continent.

title: Getting In: High/Low
description: The scores you need.

title: So Close and Yet So Far Away: A Round of 62 in a Major
description: Two numbers are as much a part of golfs most popular debate as any words: 18, Jack Nicklauss record total of major titles, and 14, Tiger Woodss stalled challenge.

title: Its a Good Time to Graduate
description: Employers are recruiting.

title: The Captain Goes Down With the Ship
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  There is a lot to be said for trying to see things from a different perspective. Were used to having our crossword theme entries run across the puzzle, but turn the grid sideways so that they run down and the next thing you know, ships are sinking and Taps is being blown.

title: In His Latest Novel,James Patterson Swaps Guns for Golf
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  Nobody would accuse the author James Patterson of dawdling. He churns out books like blocks of butter.

title: A Litmus Test for the Golden State Warriors, a Sure Thing
description: The Golden State Warriors, who have looked virtually incapable of losing in the regular season, will enter the N.B.A. playoffs as the team to beat. And given the teams that have performed as well in the past, they may want to get ready to celebrate.

title: Baseballs Milestones Map
description: The season begins with a number of players closing in on significant achievements. At the head of the list is Alex Rodriguez.

title: Apparent Saudi Strike Kills at Least Nine in Yemeni Family
description: SANA, Yemen  At least nine people from a single family were killed when what appeared to be an airstrike by the Saudi-led military coalition struck a home in a village outside Sana, Yemens capital, officials said Saturday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: A Simple Fix in Indiana

title: Islamic State Seizes Palestinian Refugee Camp in Syria
description: AMMAN, Jordan  Islamic State militants have seized most of a sprawling Palestinian refugee district in the southern part of the Syrian capital, Damascus, an area that has been under siege and bombardment for nearly two years already, according to Palestinian and United Nations officials and residents.

title: Outline of Iran Nuclear Deal Sounds Different From Each Side
description: WASHINGTON  Negotiators at the nuclear talks in Switzerland emerged from marathon talks on Thursday with a surprisingly detailed outline of the agreement they now must work to finalize by the end of June.

title: Election in Scarred Ferguson Carries Hope of New Tomorrow
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  After months of racially charged unrest over the police killing of a black teenager, activists are making a final push to attract a new generation of voters to the polls on Tuesday in the hopes of changing the face of the predominantly white political leadership in this mostly black city.

title: Robert Burns Jr., First Lynyrd Skynyrd Drummer, Dies at 64
description: Robert Burns Jr., the founding drummer of Lynyrd Skynyrd, the Southern rock band known for the power ballad Free Bird and the anthem Sweet Home Alabama, died on Friday in an automobile crash in Georgia. He was 64.

title: Word Count
description: Youll surely trip over the words leader and leadership on business school websites.

title: Fidel Castro Appears in Public for First Time in 14 Months
description: MEXICO CITY  Former President Fidel Castro of Cuba made a surprise appearance in public for the first time in 14 months, greeting a group of Venezuelan visitors as they toured a Havana school, the Cuban news media reported on Friday.

title: Gerties Babies, Sold at Birth, Use DNA to Unlock Secret Past
description: COEUR DALENE, Idaho  Sue Dockens start in life, in 1951, with a no-questions-asked cash adoption at the hands of a midwife, had strong elements of the crime scene that it was.

title: Business Owners in Brooklyn Heights Start Subtle Lobbying of Clinton Campaign
description: It was a sleepy Saturday morning in Brooklyn Heights, with the post-yoga-and-brunch crowds still gathering steam for the day ahead, and Alfred Tom, an owner of The Heights Salon of Brooklyn, was carving out a pitch to his new neighbor, Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Seeing a Cash Cow in Museums Precious Art
description: MNSTER, Germany  The director of the art museum here dreads the idea of losing some of his towns biggest cultural attractions. He worries about a Henry Moore sculpture that has been on exhibition for almost 40 years, knowing it could vanish along with Renaissance panels and Eduardo Chillida benches in a sale to settle government debts.

title: Masahiro Tanaka Says His Velocity May Be Lower
description: WASHINGTON  Just about 48 hours away from throwing the first pitch of the season for the Yankees, Masahiro Tanaka issued a warning signal of sorts.

title: Duke Shuts Down Michigan State, Advancing to N.C.A.A. Title Game
description: INDIANAPOLIS  At first, the game seemed like a blowout. Then, briefly, it seemed close. Then it looked like a blowout in the other direction. That was all in the first half.

title: Climbing the Ladder
description: A survey of over 12,000 business school alumni on job success and salary.

title: Jeb Bush as Inevitable Choice? Republicans Say Not So Fast
description: Three months into what allies once confidently described as a shock and awe drive to overcome his rivals and dominate the Republican presidential field, Jeb Bushs early campaigning looks like the juggernaut that wasnt.

title: As Serena Williams Ascends, Grand Slam Buzz Grows
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  The womens final between Serena Williams and Carla Surez Navarro on Saturday at the Miami Open was predictably brutal and mercifully brief.

title: Dortmund Romps to 6-0, Rising as a Kentucky Derby Favorite
description: ARCADIA, Calif.  Call it Selection Saturday  three important prep races run in a stretch of 90 minutes to determine which horses have a realistic chance to capture the 140th running of the Kentucky Derby next month. When it was over, there was little doubt about the overwhelming favorite at this moment.

title: A Norway Town and Its Pipeline to Jihad in Syria
description: FREDRIKSTAD, Norway  The real trouble started when they stopped causing trouble. Torleif Sanchez Hammer and his friends  all residents of the same small cluster of clapboard houses in southern Norway  had been having run-ins with the police for years but then suddenly halted their marijuana-fueled gatherings in the basement apartment of Mr. Hammers widowed mother.

title: Indiana Residents Rue Damage to States Welcoming Reputation
description: MARTINSVILLE, Ind.  Michelle Crafton, the owner of a tiny bakery in this struggling town 30 miles south of Indianapolis, is not sure what she would do if asked to cater a same-sex wedding.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 5, 2015
description: We wondered what had happened but were glad when they dropped off our radar.

title: Outlander Recap: The Show Takes a New Point of View
description: Season 1, Episode 9: The Reckoning

title: Final Tweaks to Mets Roster Made With Higher Aspirations
description: In recent years, as spring training wound down and the Mets debated who would fill out their bullpen, their bench and the back of their rotation, it often felt as if they were rearranging the deck chairs on a sinking ship.

title: Wisconsin Ends Kentuckys Undefeated Streak and Will FaceDuke for N.C.A.A. Title
description: INDIANAPOLIS  It was here, finally, after 364 days  long enough for Kentucky to reload and to rewrite history and for Wisconsin to reconcile its paralyzing defeat on this stage a year ago, or at least come close.

title: After Starting Slowly, L.P.G.A. Veterans Make a Push
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  The youth gale that blew a layer of pixie dust on the ANA Inspiration died down Saturday, and a few seasoned pros cleared a trail up the leaderboard. Led by the ageless Australian Karrie Webb, a two-time champion, four former winners of this event played their way into contention during the third round at Mission Hills Country Club.

title: Henrik Lundqvist Nears Top Form; Rangers Near Top Seed
description: Facing a sliding Devils squad about to miss the playoffs for a third straight season, the Rangers rolled to a 6-1 victory at Madison Square Garden on Saturday thanks to Rick Nash, Dominic Moore and Henrik Lundqvist, who made 35 saves in his best game since returning from a neck injury.

title: Joan Jonas: All at Once
description: For over half a century, the artists arresting, inventive and immersive performances and videos have conjured strange mythological landscapes that upend a viewers sense of time. Now, as she reaches the height of her creative powers, the art world is finally catching up with her.

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 10 P.M. (13, 49) WOLF HALL Mark Rylance stars as Thomas Cromwell in this new BBC mini-series  adapted from Hilary Mantels novels Wolf Hall and Bring Up the Bodies  which chronicles his rise in the Tudor court, from his lowly beginnings as a blacksmiths son to his position as King Henry VIIIs closest adviser. The historical drama, presented here by Masterpiece, begins as Cardinal Thomas Wolsey (Jonathan Pryce, above right with Mr. Rylance), having failed to secure the annulment of the marriage of Henry (Damian Lewis) to Katherine of Aragon (Joanne Whalley), is stripped of his powers  placing his hope of returning to the kings favor on Cromwell. Based on two Booker Prize winners and starring Mr. Rylance, one of the great stage actors of our time, its acutely intelligent, luxuriously dressed and well acted across the board, Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. Its also notably serious and quiet, despite the occasional beheading or session on the rack.

title: Nancy-Lauren Raia and John Buechler
description: Nancy-Lauren Raia and John Custis Buechler were married Saturday by the Rev. Lynn A. Sullivan, a minister of the United Church of Christ, at Fox Hollow, an event space in Woodbury, N.Y.

title: Aisha Martini and Eduardo Sanchez
description: Aisha Noel Martini and Eduardo Gabriel Sanchez were married Wednesday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau by Edwina Townes, a staff member of the New York City Clerks office.

title: Shilpa Patel and Miten Shah
description: Shilpa Patel and Miten Ketan Shah were married Saturday in Parsippany, N.J. Pandit Harendra R. Dave, a Hindu priest, officiated at the Hilton Parsippany.

title: Kathleen Kyllo and Nathan Punwar
description: Kathleen Mary Kyllo and Nathan Carl Punwar were married Friday in an outdoor ceremony in the North Woods section of Central Park. Jared M. Chausow, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, officiated.

title: A First-Class Love Starts on a Plane
description: Leslie Patricia Pea-Collins and Paolo Racli were married Saturday by the Rev. Sarah A. Wood, an Episcopal priest, in Washington Square Park in Manhattan. On July 11, the Rev. Jaime Paniagua, a Roman Catholic priest, is to lead a blessing at Santa Teresita del Nio de Jess Mxico Church in Mexico City.

title: Audrey Smith and Vicente Muoz
description: Audrey Rose Smith and Vicente Alfredo Muoz Gallardo were married Friday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Edwina Townes, a staff member of the New York City Clerks office, officiated.

title: First a Note, Then a Home-Cooked Meal
description: Leslie Cox Pemberton and Dennis Bruce Kennemur were married Saturday at Kalmia Gardens of Coker College in Hartsville, S.C. Jean Hoefer Toal, the chief justice of the South Carolina Supreme Court in Columbia, S.C., officiated.

title: Liana Engel and Nicolas Ricroque
description: Liana Laura Engel and Nicolas Georges Arnaud Ricroque were married Friday at the New Mexico Supreme Court in Santa Fe. Barbara J. Vigil, the chief justice, officiated.

title: Corrections: April 5, 2015
description: NEW YORK

title: Born to a Star and Becoming One for Maryland
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Marylands Lexie Brown was cradled in the hands of a slam dunk champion. She had her diapers changed by Pervis Ellison, a former N.C.A.A. tournament most valuable player and a No. 1 N.B.A. draft pick. She was raised in N.B.A. arenas.

title: Facing Death as a Teenager
description: Karly Koch was only 15 when she learned she had a rare genetic disorder that severely weakened her immune system, making her susceptible to many serious illnesses. Her older sister, Kelsey, had died of complications from the same disorder, known as DOCK8.

title: Mom, When Do Grown-Ups Stop Eating Breakfast?
description: Mom, when do grown-ups stop eating breakfast?

title: From 2015: Why Wesley Bell Entered Politics
description: The Times first profiled Wesley Bell in 2015, when he successfully ran for City Council in Ferguson, Mo., in the ward where Michael Brown was killed.

title: 1940: Kitchen Thrift Urged in Britain, Educational Drive to Show Way
description: A 1944 report follows the life of a British family as they struggle with the rationing system.Imperial War Museums

title: Bomb Kills Police Officer and Injures Civilians in Cairo
description: CAIRO  A bomb killed a police officer and wounded two civilians at a police booth on a main bridge over an affluent island in the Nile on Sunday, raising new fears that militants were targeting even the most secure parts of Egypts capital.

title: Californias Wasteful Water Habits Run Up Against a Dry Future  and Past
description: You dont know youre in a megadrought until youre many years, if not decades, into one. So conditions in California could still turn around (which could lead to a shock to trance effect on water conservation efforts).

title: A Regular Worries That the Palms Face-Lift Could Cause Wrinkles
description: Until he saw the word face-lift in the letter, Herbert E. Nass had not thought he would ever need one.

title: Publication of New Internet Rules to Prompt Cheers and Challenges
description: For those who have spent more than a decade fighting for stricter regulation of the Internet, the official publication of the rules in the Federal Register, expected as early as Monday, will give reality to their latest victory. For those opposed, it is likely to touch off a flurry of lawsuits.

title: 1965: Dr. King Joins South African Zulus Fight to Stay in U.S.
description: NEW YORK  The Rev. Martin Luther King has thrown his support behind efforts to fight the deportation of six Zulu dancers back to South Africa. The Zulus, dancers at the South African Pavilion at the New York Worlds Fair last year, have asked for political asylum, saying they face reprisal and persecution in South Africa. Immigration authorities have conducted one hearing on their case and are due to hold a second April 28. Dr. Kings support for their case was made public in a letter appealing for funds and support sent to 20,000 civil rights supporters by the Workers Defense League, a human rights legal aid organization.

title: McDonalds Workers, Vowing a Fight, Say Raises Are Too Little for Too Few
description: Julia Andino tried to ignore the insistent humming. It was after midnight and she was curled beneath the blankets alongside her sleeping child. But her cellphone kept vibrating. She tried to shake herself awake.

title: Furious 7 Wins the Box-Office Weekend
description: LOS ANGELES  Universal Pictures more than proved its mettle over the weekend, releasing the problem-plagued seventh installment of its Fast & Furious action franchise to critical acclaim and record-breaking global ticket sales.

title: Baritone Luca Salsi Pulls a Leading-Role Double
description: Last Wednesday the tenor Michael Fabiano stepped in for an indisposed Joseph Calleja as Edgardo in Lucia di Lammermoor at the Metropolitan Opera, a whirlwind substitution that began at 1 p.m. when he got the call while running errands in Philadelphia.

title: Taking Feminist Battle to Chinas Streets, and Landing in Jail
description: BEIJING  The young Chinese feminists shaved their heads to protest inequality in higher education and stormed mens restrooms to highlight the indignities women face in their prolonged waits at public toilets.

title: Lumire! Inventing Cinema
description: A look at a new exhibition celebrating the French pioneers of cinema, Louis and Auguste Lumire.

title: Review: In Soldier X, Rehana Lew Mirza Explores Issues Off the Battlefield
description: Young Marines traumatized by war fit uneasily back into sitcom-sunny American life in Rehana Lew Mirzas Soldier X, a new play shaped by its unwieldy to-do list of concerns.

title: U.S. Allies Flock to Join Chinas Development Bank
description: China announced that it had attracted 46 founding members for its Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank.

title: Kenyan Authorities Say Son of Official Was Among Gunmen in University Attack
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  One of the gunmen who attacked the Kenyan university where nearly 150 students were massacred last week was the son of a government official  and once a promising student himself  who had recently broken off contact with his family and disappeared, the Kenyan authorities said Sunday.

title: Trade, Geography, and Microfoundations (Wonkish)
description: Its much of a compensation, but one effect of the Great Recession and the Not-So-Great Recovery has been to stimulate some very good economic discussion, including discussion of methodology. In particular, there has been a vigorous back-and-forth over the role of microfoundations, the attempt to ground macroeconomics in the rational behavior of individuals and firms.The microfoundations project swept the field in the 1970s, but the demand that every argument be couched in terms of microfounded models arguably paralyzed much of the profession when crisis struck, rendering them useless or worse.

title: China Escalates Hollywood Partnerships, Aiming to Compete One Day
description: SHANGHAI  Tucked away in a quiet design studio in this fast-growing city, a team of young animators, illustrators and computer programmers is bringing an ancient Chinese village to digital life.

title: Review: Dorrance Dance and Toshi Reagons The Blues Project at the Joyce Theater
description: In her program note for The Blues Project, the tap dancer and choreographer Michelle Dorrance refers to Toshi Reagon, her musical collaborator, as a revolutionary, but simultaneously an artist who honors and embodies tradition. Ms. Dorrance, as full of vivacity as she is fiercely technical, could be describing herself. All worthwhile artists are rebels; the best grasp and revere their history, which, in tap especially, is its lifeblood.

title: Comcast Recruits Its Beneficiaries to Lobby for Time Warner Deal
description: WASHINGTON  The letters have come from all around the United States  from the Nutmeg Big Brothers and Big Sisters in Connecticut, the Houston Area Urban League and even the Dan Marino Foundation in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.  some praising the Comcast Corporation, others urging the federal government to stand aside and approve Comcasts proposed takeover of Time Warner Cable.

title: Israel and United States Congress
description: President Obama on the breakdown of bipartisan debate over Israel and his personal affinity with the Israeli people. This is an excerpt of an interview with Thomas L. Friedman.

title: What Obama Would Say to Iranians
description: President Obama explains why Iran does not need to have nuclear weapons to be a regional powerhouse. This is an excerpt of an interview with Thomas L. Friedman.

title: What Obama Would Say to Israelis
description: President Obama explains why the nuclear deal is the best, and only, option to keep Israel safe from Iran. This is an excerpt of an interview with Thomas L. Friedman.

title: What Is the Obama Doctrine?
description: President Obama lays out his preference for engagement over isolation in his approach to foreign policy. This is an excerpt of an interview with Thomas L. Friedman.

title: Review: Philip Glasss Words Without Music Tells of a Life Full of Changes in Rhythm
description: When Philip Glass was 15, his father, who owned a record store in Baltimore, put him in charge of buying classical albums. Mr. Glass was then a precocious freshman at the University of Chicago and taking the first steps on the path to becoming a composer. When he learned of a new recording of the complete Schoenberg string quartets played by the Juilliard String Quartet, he ordered four copies. Aghast, his father asked if he was trying to put him out of business. To teach his son a lesson, he told him to put the recordings of these atonal chamber works on the shelves with the more mainstream classical records and report back when the last copy had been sold. That took seven years. The lesson Mr. Glass learned? I can sell anything if I have enough time.

title: Lessons From the Negotiations
description: President Obama on the complexity and practical streak of the Iranian regime. This is an excerpt of an interview with Thomas L. Friedman.

title: Congresss Red Line
description: President Obama on the dangers that arise when lawmakers breach traditional channels of foreign policy. This is an excerpt of an interview with Thomas L. Friedman.

title: Obama on Iran and His View of the World
description: In an interview with Thomas L. Friedman, President Obama says that his policy of engagement in Iran and elsewhere doesnt mean the United States isnt ready to defend its interests or that of its allies.

title: Iran and the Obama Doctrine
description: In September 1996, I visited Iran. One of my most enduring memories of that trip was that in my hotel lobby there was a sign above the door proclaiming Down With USA.
