description: Make quick chicken stock by boiling chicken bones, onion, carrot and herbs in a large pot.

title: Creatures of the Wind and Tavi Gevinsons Southern Spring Trip
description: Last September at Creatures of the Winds spring/summer 2015 fashion show, the 18-year-old multihyphenate wonder Tavi Gevinson sat front row and said to John Kobin for The New York Times, Its really nice to see it and also to drop in as an observer. And late last week, she saw it again  this time, in North Carolina, where she co-hosted a dinner with the design duo, Shane Gabier and Christopher Peters, to celebrate the collections arrival at the Capitol boutique there. Tavi has been a friend of ours since the Chicago days; shes one of the coolest people we know, Gabier says. We hadnt been able to hang out much this year, so it was great to have a few days together in Charlotte to catch up. During their stay down South, the three amigos ate top-notch Carolina BBQ and shared a screened-in sleeping porch at the hundred-year-old mansion they called home for a few days. Here, Gabier and Peters recount highlights from their trip.

title: U.S. Weighs Whether to Act or Wait on Insider Trading
description: Last weeks decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit to reject the Justice Departments request to reconsider its ruling in United States v. Newman, which makes insider trading harder to prove, leaves the government with three choices. It can ask the Supreme Court to review the decision, push Congress to adopt a law to define insider trading or live with the outcome and figure out how to minimize its effect.

title: Bruce Jenner to Be Interviewed by Diane Sawyer on 20/20
description: ABC announced Monday that it would broadcast a two-hour episode of 20/20 featuring Diane Sawyer interviewing Bruce Jenner on April 24.

title: Republicans Eyeing White House Take Turns Slamming Iran Deal
description: President Obamas preliminary agreement with Iran on its nuclear program has given Republicans considering a run for the White House a new and easy target to criticize.

title: Forest Fires Threaten New Fallout From Chernobyl
description: On April 26, 1986, the Chernobyl nuclear plant in Ukraine released a plume of radiation that eventually blanketed an estimated 77,000 square miles of Europe and Eurasia. While the worst of the contamination occurred near the plant  an area still closed to human habitation, now referred to as the exclusion zone  the effects are still seen further afield as well. Radioactive wild boars roam German forests, and radioactive mushrooms grow in Bulgaria.

title: Walker Speaks on Admiration for Reagan
description: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, a Republican, talked about Ronald Reagan on Feb. 6 at Eureka College in Illinois, where President Reagan studied.

title: Ukrainian Leader Is Open to a Vote on Regional Power
description: MOSCOW  President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine on Monday denounced calls for federalization of the country, which Russia has endorsed as a way of granting political autonomy to the areas of eastern Ukraine controlled by pro-Russian separatists.

title: How Brian Grazer Got Curiouser and Curiouser
description: Brian Grazer, the Academy Award-winning producer behind films including Frost/Nixon, A Beautiful Mind and Friday Night Lights, credits his grandmother Sonia with validating his persistent curiosity. All the disappointments I had, she acted like they didnt exist, he recalls, and said, Youre going to be special in life. Asking questions is what life is all about, and youre asking the best questions.

title: Victor Gotbaum, the Citys Shop Steward
description: The fatuousness of the man bugs me, Victor Gotbaum once said of Ed Koch, aptly skewering the then-new mayors Howm I doing? shtick. The words were revealing of the man: blunt, honest, not at all polite.

title: Analyzing the Iran Nuclear Talks
U.S. Defense Secretary Supports Trade Deal With Asia
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  Defense Secretary Ashton Carter on Monday threw the weight of the Pentagon behind President Obamas fight to push a trade deal with Asia through Congress, warning that Asian markets are being gobbled up by global competitors.

title: Online Breast Milk May Contain Cows Milk
description: People who buy human breast milk over the Internet may be getting less than they bargained for. A study in Pediatrics found that more than 10 percent of samples of breast milk bought online contained cows milk in significant quantities.

title: Review: What About This: Collected Poems of Frank Stanford
description: When Daddy told me what happened, I couldnt believe what he just said.

title: Walkabout: Alcohol Rules on Ryanair Flights to Ibiza; Free Museums
description: Calming Down After increased levels of rowdiness on flights between Glasgow and Ibiza, Spain, Ryanair (above) is now banning passengers from bringing personal alcoholic beverages on board. (Daily Mail)

title: No Red and Blue Divide When it Comes to Renewable Energy Innovation and CO2 Rules
description: Regular readers may recall my 2013 post describing how energy agreement is often hidden by climate disputes  drawing on data from asustainedsurvey by theYale Project on Climate Change Communicationand George Mason UniversityCenter for Climate Change Communication.

title: The New Wave of Cabana Shirts
description: Quieter prints and subtler colors usher the classic summer staple into the modern era  with a throwback look.

title: Obama at the White House Easter Egg Roll
description: President Obama appeared with the Easter bunny at the annual White House Easter egg roll on Monday to promote the fifth anniversary of Michelle Obamas healthy eating campaign Lets Move!

title: Big Shows Take In Big Dollars at Broadway Box Office
description: Religious holidays, spring break and warming weather brought big money for Broadways biggest shows last week. Nine productions grossed more than a million dollars, including three that crossed the $2 million mark by adding extra performances.

title: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
description: France and More  Pictures of the Day

title: In Hawaii, Chickens Gone Wild
description: On the island of Kauai, chickens have not just crossed the road.

title: April 6, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from France, Ukraine, China and Russia.

title: Focusing the Brain on Better Vision
description: As adults age, vision deteriorates. One common type of decline is in contrast sensitivity, the ability to distinguish gradations of light to dark, making it possible to discern where one object ends and another begins.

title: Review: Music Hall, a Meditation in Stage Poetry by Jean-Luc Lagarce
description: The Artistes feather boa is molting all over the stage, little clumps breaking off and drifting to the floor. Such disintegrating glamour is a perfect metaphor for the desperate state of her career, but this is one of many things she chooses not to see.

title: Review: Daily Life Everlasting at La MaMa
description: How do you live a meaningful life? Should you look to philosophy? Should you study literature? Should you shoot Silly String and dance?

title: In Bess Wohls Small Mouth Sounds, a Loss for Words Leads to a Gain in Insight
description: The playwright Bess Wohl calls herself a true believer in New Age spirituality. She reads the books, she does the yoga, she tries to meditate. So when a close friend asked several years ago if she wanted to go upstate from New York City for a weekend-long retreat led by the Buddhist nun Pema Chodron, a teacher they both admired, it was an easy yes.

title: Kris Bryant, the Baseball Players Union and a Lesson for Labor
description: WASHINGTON  The Chicago Cubs opened the 2015 season Sunday night with a 3-0 loss against the St. Louis Cardinals, and one glaring absence: Kris Bryant, the teams budding superstar. The Cubs sent Bryant down to the minor leagues last week, setting off a 21st-century-style labor dispute.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Review: R&J&Z Is Romeo and Juliet for the Zombie Age
description: At the end of most productions of Romeo and Juliet, six characters are dead. Well, five if you cut the scene when Romeo skewers Paris, which some directors do. But R&J&Z, a gory riff on the tragedy by the writer-performer Melody Bates at the New Ohio Theater, is a little more homicidal.

title: Review: Noche Flamenca, With Soledad Barrio, at Joes Pub
description: If you cant make it to Spain this week, Joes Pub will do. On Saturday, Noche Flamenca returned to that club, where you can experience the troupes celebrated take on traditional flamenco up close and in a congenial atmosphere. A guitarist, a singer, a handful of dancers: thats all this stage can fit, and thats all this party needs. And when one of those dancers is Soledad Barrio, this companys burning star, the experience is pretty much guaranteed to be memorable.

title: Review: Stacy Sullivan, Guided by History and Weather, at the Metropolitan Room
description: Growing up in the part of Oklahoma nicknamed Tornado Alley, the singer Stacy Sullivan waited for 22 years without seeing a funnel cloud, she recalled on Saturday evening at the Metropolitan Room. The combination of fear and excitement that the anticipation of heavy weather can stir up was the driving force behind her audacious, often thrilling new show, her second in less than six months.

title: Review: In The Dance Apocalypse/Solos, the End is Full of Questions
description: What is the Dance Apocalypse and should you fear it? Least ambiguously, it is the name under which Nicole Bindler and Gabrielle Revlock, Philadelphia performers, work together. But what was The Dance Apocalypse/Solos, the show they presented on Friday at Jack, in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn?

title: Viva Jeb Bush
description: Jeb Bush, a scion of one of Americas most prominent WASP families, is a convert to Hispanicism.

title: Viacom to Take 2nd-Quarter Write-Downs of $785 Million
description: Viacom, the media conglomerate that owns Nickelodeon, MTV and Comedy Central, said on Monday that it would take a pretax charge of about $785 million for the quarter just ended in March, reflecting the write-down of underperforming programming and job cuts.

title: In Performance | Tessa Ferrer
description: Ms. Ferrer in a scene from Tracey Scott Wilsons new play about race and real estate in a gentrifying neighborhood. The show, directed by Anne Kauffman, opens on Wednesday at the Public Theater.

title: Muhammad Wilkerson Absent at Start of Jets Voluntary Workouts
description: Muhammad Wilkerson, a premier defensive end who has sought a new contract to no avail, was conspicuously absent when the Jets opened the voluntary portion of their off-season training program Monday under their new head coach, Todd Bowles.

title: Louie Is Back. His Issues Are, Too.
description: Season 4 of Louie was Louis C.K.s art house phase. One moment he seemed to be channeling David Lynch, the next Woody Allen, the next Paul Mazursky. His half-hour comedy, always on the dark and fantastical side, took on a whole new weight  a seriousness that was simultaneously impressive and a little wearing. At times the only laughter it inspired was the nervous kind. That felt funny, you thought  is that where I was supposed to laugh?

title: Vietnam Veteran Files Class-Action Lawsuit Over Delayed Appeals on Disability Benefits
description: A Vietnam veteran who has waited years for disability benefits from the Department of Veterans Affairs for claims of post-traumatic stress disorder and exposure to toxic chemicals filed a class-action lawsuit on Monday, seeking to force the department to expedite a growing backlog of benefits claims appeals, including his own.

title: With Marvels Daredevil, Netflix Looks to Build Its Own Superteam
description: In the pantheon of Marvel Comics, Daredevil might not be the first superhero youd turn to in a bind.

title: Review: Brian Wilsons Nostalgic, Reflective No Pier Pressure
description: BRIAN WILSON

title: Review: Shlohmos Dark Red Puts a Spin on the 1990s
description: SHLOHMO

title: Review: LoftOperas Lucrezia Borgia, With Flying Bottles of Beer and Poison
description: The final aria in Donizettis Lucrezia Borgia, an Oedipally charged melodrama about this most infamous of Renaissance power players, is notoriously difficult to sing. In Era desso il figlio mio Lucrezia, who has unwittingly poisoned her secret son, flips wildly between expressions of private heartbreak and fiery coloratura-spiked outbursts. The virtuosity of the vocal part can overwhelm the poignancy of the moment, especially in staged performances.

title: JetBlue to Fly Between Albany and 2 Florida Destinations
description: JetBlue Airways plans to begin daily service between Albany International Airport and two Florida destinations late this year. Flights will begin Dec. 10 with nonstop service to Fort Lauderdale and Orlando. JetBlue already services Buffalo, Rochester, Syracuse, Newburgh, Westchester and both New York City airports. To introduce the flights, JetBlue offered limited one-way promotional fares on Monday of $16.86  a figure picked to honor Albanys incorporation in 1686.

title: N.B.A. Sending Representatives to a Four-Day Clinic in Cuba
description: Having long marketed its product to the far reaches of the planet, the N.B.A. will soon be planting seeds closer to home, in a country that has been commercially off limits.

title: Welcome Back, Baseball
description: In the Bronx, 48,469 fans filled up Yankee Stadium for the season opener. Explore the scene of opening day in this panoramic image.

title: Big Companies Pay Later, Squeezing Their Suppliers
description: How would you like to have 120 days to pay your creditors?

title: Transportation Safety Board Seeks Stiffer Standards for Oil Tank Rail Cars
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said Monday that new oil tank train cars should come with much stronger ability to withstand high heat and pressure from a crash or a blast.

title: The Rev. Gardner C. Taylor on Slaverys Sacrifices
description: Two years after he retired, the Rev. Gardner C. Taylor returned to his pulpit in Brooklyn with a ringing peroration on the sacrifices America has paid for slavery:

title: Mets Exploit Two Errors to Beat Max Scherzer and the Nationals
description: WASHINGTON  This was not an easy way to start the season. The Mets were playing the powerful Washington Nationals, and their new $210 million ace, Max Scherzer, in front of a pumped-up crowd of Nationals fans with visions of a World Series in October.

title: Weinstein Company Is Said to Be Set to Sell TV Unit to ITV Studios
description: The Weinstein Company is on the verge of selling its growing television unit to Britains ITV Studios for as much as $950 million, following a monthslong search for a buyer, people briefed on the possible sale said.

title: Julie Wilson, Sultry Cabaret Legend and Actress, Dies at 90
description: Julie Wilson, the revered nightclub performer and actress widely regarded as the queen of cabaret, died on Sunday in Manhattan. She was 90.

title: Father and 7 Children Found Dead in Maryland
description: A father and his seven children were found dead in a house in southern Maryland on Monday from what the police suspect was carbon monoxide poisoning.

title: Nice Day for a Drive, Chip and Putt
description: The next generation of golfers participated on Sunday in the Drive, Chip and Putt championship at Augusta National Golf Club, one of the events leading up to the Masters, which begins Thursday.

title: Georgia: Judge Sets Hearing on Request by Transgender Inmate for Transfer
description: A federal district judge on Monday set a hearing for Thursday on an emergency motion in the case of a transgender woman, Ashley Diamond, who is seeking an immediate transfer to a lower-security prison or transitional center so that she can be safer from sexual assault. Judge Marc T. Treadwell also asked Georgia corrections officials to produce all communications  emails, correspondence, messages, etc.  regarding Ms. Diamonds transfer several weeks ago to Georgia State Prison. Ms. Diamond alleges that the transfer, to a prison with a relatively high prevalence of sexual violence, was apparently retaliatory for her lawsuit against corrections officials. Ms. Diamond, 36, is a nonviolent offender and first-time inmate who has lived as a transgender woman since adolescence, but has been held in prisons for men, most of them high-security, for the last three years. She claims in her lawsuit to have suffered at least seven sexual assaults as well as routine sexual coercion and harassment. In addition to safer housing, her lawsuit, filed in February, seeks access to the hormone therapy that is essential medical care for her gender dysphoria. She had been taking hormones for 17 years, she says, until the prison system denied her access. A Georgia corrections spokeswoman saidon Mondaythat Ms. Diamond has been receiving the appropriate treatment assessed by Georgia Correction Health medical staff since March. This is apparently a reference to a hormone patch given to her in response to her lawsuit.

title: The Dow Minute by Minute
description: The Dow Jones, minute by minute.

title: 3-Month Treasury Bills
description: 3-month Treasury bill pricing information.

title: Metal Detectors Become One More Reason to Get to the Ballpark Early
description: Peanuts? Check. Cracker Jack? Yep. Metal detectors?

title: Hollywood Takes a Roman Holiday ... Again
description: ROME  Inside the Cinecitt film studios, originally built by Mussolini in part to produce fascist propaganda, a catapult is parked beside Soundstage 13. Not far away, craftsmen touch up chariots. The props are for the remake of the 1959 swords-and-sandals epic, Ben-Hur, which is consuming much of the vast studio lot, if not all of it.

title: Chris Gibson, an Upstate Republican, Starts Early on a Possible Run for Governor
description: Inside a Knights of Columbus post, far from his Hudson Valley district, Representative Chris Gibson spoke insistently to the Brooklyn Young Republican Club, urging the sparse crowd to get to work rebuilding New Yorks depleted Republican Party before the next campaign for governor in 2018.

title: University of Virginia Fraternity to Go After Rolling Stone for Rape Article
description: The University of Virginia fraternity at the center of a retracted article by Rolling Stone magazine that detailed a purported gang rape by its members said on Monday that it planned to pursue all available legal action against the magazine.

title: For Inspiration, Notre Dame Can Look to 2001 and Niele Ivey
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Ball in the air. Game on the line. Season on the brink.

title: Laurence Tribe Fights Climate Case Against Star Pupil From Harvard, President Obama
description: WASHINGTON  Laurence H. Tribe, the highly regarded liberal scholar of constitutional law, still speaks of President Obama as a proud teacher would of a star student. He was one of the most amazing research assistants Ive ever had, Mr. Tribe said in a recent interview. Mr. Obama worked for him at Harvard Law School, where Mr. Tribe has taught for four decades.

title: Body of a Rebel Leader Is Identified in Uganda
description: The bullet-scarred remains of the No. 2 commander in the Lords Resistance Army, the guerrilla group that once terrorized central Africa, have been positively identified after having been exhumed last month in a Uganda-led military expedition, a person involved in the recovery operation said Monday.

title: Dr. Fredric Brandt, 65, Celebrity Baron of Botox, Is Dead
description: Dr. Fredric Brandt, a celebrity dermatologist once called the Baron of Botox by W magazine, died Sunday at his home in Coconut Grove, Fla. He was 65.

title: Alex Rodriguez Returns as the Yankees Designated Attention-Getter
description: The fans at Yankee Stadium cheered most robustly Monday for a man who repeatedly played us all for fools. And yet, on a most bizarre opening day, you almost could not blame them for showing mercy to Alex Rodriguez.

title: Kenyans Try to Trace a Students Path to Terrorism
description: MANDERA, Kenya  Abdia Noor Abdi sat in the yard, exhausted after all the questions from the authorities. When she saw the face of her son on the front page of a daily newspaper, she pushed it aside and began to tear up.

title: G.O.P. Senator, Bob Corker, Is Key Player in Iran Accord
description: WASHINGTON  While negotiators toiled late into the night in Switzerland, scratching together a nuclear agreement with Iran, Senator Bob Corker was conducting his own tense talks back home.

title: Patz Murder Suspect Could Distinguish Fact From Fiction, Psychiatrist Says
description: A former bodega clerk being tried on murder charges in the 1979 disappearance of Etan Patz did not have a serious mental illness and was capable of distinguishing fact from fiction when he confessed to the police, a psychiatrist for the prosecution testified on Monday.

title: Samsung Beats Analyst Predictions Despite Falling Profits
description: HONG KONG  After a tough 2014 for Samsung Electronics, the beleaguered South Korean manufacturer said it expected earnings in the first quarter of 2015 to beat analyst forecasts, in the first sign of a possible turnaround for the company.

title: Study Forecasts 70% Loss of West Canadas Glaciers
description: The glaciers of the Canadian West could shrink by 70 percent by 2100, according to new research that has implications for predicting glacier loss around the world.

title: Ad Attacking Rand Paul on Iran Will Coincide With Opening of His Presidential Campaign
description: As Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky is set to announce his presidential campaign on Tuesday, a television ad tethers him to President Obamas policy on Iran as part of a $1 million advertising buy painting him as dangerous.

title: Welcome, Commissioner. Heres a New Doping Problem.
description: WASHINGTON  In ways that you would expect, and in others that you wouldnt, Monday turned out to be a fitting way for Rob Manfred to spend his first opening day as commissioner of Major League Baseball.

title: 4th Brooklyn Man Is Charged in Plot to Join ISIS
description: A defendant has been added in the case of a group of Brooklyn men charged with trying to support the Islamic State.

title: Argentina: Ex-Economy Minister Gets Suspended Sentence for Hidden Cash
description: A former Argentine economy minister wept Monday in court as federal judges gave her a suspended prison sentence related to the discovery of thousands of dollars in cash in her office bathroom. Felisa Miceli, the economy minister from 2005 to 2007, had been convicted of corruption-related charges, but last year that sentence was ordered to be reviewed. Ms. Miceli had been unable to prove that she legally obtained the money  cash in dollars and pesos worth more than $64,000 when it was turned up in 2007. Ms. Miceli said Monday in court in Buenos Aires, It would be a terrible injustice if I went to prison, adding, I regret taking the money. The judges also prohibited Ms. Miceli from holding public office for six years and ordered her to repay 100,000 pesos, or almost $11,400.

title: Sports Groups in Indianapolis Fight to Keep Their City Welcoming
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Stand next to the obelisk in the middle of Monument Circle here, and you are within one mile of an N.F.L. stadium, an N.B.A. arena and a minor league ballpark; the American College of Sports Medicine; the offices of U.S.A. Gymnastics, U.S.A. Track & Field and U.S.A. Synchronized Swimming; and the headquarters of the Black Coaches Association, the National Federation of State High School Associations and the N.C.A.A.

title: Complete Without a Break
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  The English language is a funny thing, and I say this not just because I habitually misread the word pedestrian. People who come to the United States from other countries are often BEDEVILED by the weird turns our American English takes, from our colloquialisms to our pronunciation.

title: India: Officers Die in Kashmir Attack
description: Three unarmed Indian policemen were killed Monday by militants in Indian-administered Kashmir, another in a string of recent attacks. The police officers, who were investigating a land dispute in the Shopian district, died when militants shot at them with Kalashnikov rifles and then escaped into woods. In separate extremist attacks, a former militant who was suspected of being a police informer was seriously injured and a police officer in another district was shot in the neck from close range. If you see all the three incidents, they have resorted to attack on soft targets where people were unarmed, S. J. M. Gillani, inspector general of police in Kashmir, told the NDTV news channel. Among other recent violence in the area, a police officer and a soldier were killed Thursday by militants who escaped and last month an attack on a police station and army camp left three police officers, four militants and a civilian dead.

title: Intersection | Orchard Road, Singapore
description: While wearing a masculine yet sexy white jumpsuit, Rachel Lim, an owner of Love, Bonito, a fashion label, says that comfort and experimentation are key parts of Singaporean style.

title: The Iran Nuclear Deals Definition Depends on Whos Talking
description: American and Iranian officials are using different words to describe elements of the preliminary agreement to limit Irans nuclear program.

title: Star Wars Movies Will Be Available at Digital Stores Like Amazon and iTunes
description: LOS ANGELES  Luke Skywalker is finally becoming one with the iPad generation: The Star Wars movies  for the first time  are being made available for purchase through digital stores like iTunes, Google Play and Amazon.

title: Edward Snowden Is Honored, Then Censored
description: A group of artists, who insisted on anonymity, hauled a 100-pound sculpture of Edward J. Snowden, the whistle-blower who is now exiled in Russia, into Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn and set it up early Monday by the Prison Ship Martyrs Monument. Later, parks workers covered it before removing it.

title: Better Call Saul Season 1 Finale Recap: Its Never Stopping Me Again
description: Season 1, Episode 10: Marco

title: For Coaches, Its Nurture vs. Natural Talent
description: INDIANAPOLIS  If theres anything to be taken away from Dukes national championship victory over Wisconsin on Monday night, its a simple axiom: Experience matters, but talent wins.

title: At UConn, Lessons to Respect the Past
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The kid from Philly started with just a bit of hope.

title: Behind Stepans Late Goals, Rangers Take Lead in N.H.L. Points Race
description: Having already secured the Metropolitan Division title, the Rangers entered this final week of the regular season focused on staying healthy and securing the N.H.L.s best record.

title: Duke Defeats Wisconsin to Win N.C.A.A. Mens Basketball Championship
description: INDIANAPOLIS  This Duke team was forged not over years but months, weeks, days. Its genesis was a Friday afternoon in November 2013, when the star high schoolers Tyus Jones and Jahlil Okafor coordinated their commitments to Coach Mike Krzyzewski and a Blue Devils program that was changing before his eyes.

title: On The Daily Show, Jon Stewart Offers Support to Trevor Noah, Despite Kerfuffle
description: Jon Stewart offered his support and encouragement to his coming replacement at The Daily Show, saying on the program Monday night that viewers would come to see Trevor Noah as an incredibly thoughtful and considerate and funny individual, despite a controversy last week about jokes that he had made on his Twitter account.

title: The Perils of Flight
description: For Ts ongoing series, the artist Ugo Rondinone responds to Paul Muldoons elegy for a fallen friend.

title: Victoria Presss Blithe Spirit
description: A true aesthete with a taste for imperfection, the former fashion designer creates her decorating masterpiece  frayed carpets and all  in a storied London townhouse.

title: Can Orange Glasses Help You Sleep Better?
description: Most evenings, before watching late-night comedy or reading emails on his phone, Matt Nicoletti puts on a pair of orange-colored glasses that he bought for $8 off the Internet.

title: Consumer Groups to Ask F.T.C. to Investigate YouTube Kids App
description: Several consumer groups are expected to file a complaint on Tuesday that asks the Federal Trade Commission to investigate Googles recently released YouTube Kids application, a portal for cartoons and learning shows, arguing that the app mixes ads and programming in ways that are deceptive to children.

title: Turning Pro Early, Minnesotas Amanda Zahui B. Could Be Taken First in the W.N.B.A. Draft
description: MINNEAPOLIS  University of Minnesota center Amanda Zahui B., a sophomore and one of the most dominant post players in womens college basketball, declared for the W.N.B.A. draft on Monday, putting her in line to perhaps be selected first over all next week.

title: Nets, Bouncing Back, Move Closer to the Playoffs
description: On Monday morning, the Nets Brook Lopez was named the Eastern Conferences player of the week for the second straight week. That night, he calmly went about his business of dismantling another opposing center  even if, this time around, it was his twin brother.

title: Whats on TV Tuesday
description: 10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) THE PAINTED VEIL (2006) An unhappily married 1920s British couple, Kitty and Walter Fane (Naomi Watts and Edward Norton, above), move to Shanghai, where they drift into a steamy state of liberated coexistence in this third screen adaptation of the W. Somerset Maugham novel. Liev Schreiber plays Charles Townsend, the married charmer who brings Kitty to life  and then close to death when Walter, a doctor, discovers their affair and hustles her into the countryside during a cholera epidemic. As nicely directed by John Curran and adapted to the screen by Ron Nyswaner, this version of the story lulls you by turning Maughams distaff bildungsroman into a fine romance, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Even better, the new film gives us ample opportunity to spend time with Ms. Watts, whose remarkable talent helps keep movie faith and love alive, even in the tinniest, tiniest vehicles. Mr. Norton, she added, is very fine here, especially early on, before his billing gets the better of the story.

title: Diana Taurasi Has Surgery on Hand
description: Diana Taurasi had surgery to repair a broken bone in her hand, an injury she sustained while playing for her Russian club team. Taurasi, who said in February that she would skip the W.N.B.A. season, will be sidelined for four to six weeks, said her W.N.B.A. team, the Phoenix Mercury. (AP)

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I call it the dumbing down of terrorism. They keep it simple. Theyre lightly armed, highly disciplined and relatively well trained.

title: Corrections: April 7, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Leak Causes Another Blast at Chemical Plant Targeted by Protesters
description: A leak at a plant in the eastern province of Fujian has set off a huge explosion, injuring at least 12 people and fueling doubts about safety at chemical factories.

title: Everybody Hit Somebody
description: SNEAK PEEK: This week Lens is featuring a selection of photographers attending the New York Portfolio Review.

title: Better Information, for a Better Health System
description: To the Editor:

title: Clemency in Drug Cases
description: To the Editor:

title: Greece Should Be Wary of Mr. Putin
description: The Greek government is facing a series of daunting challenges. It has to come up with money to pay off maturing debts, revive its devastated economy and renegotiate its loan agreements with other countries in the eurozone. Given those difficulties, it might be tempting  though misguided  for Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras to seek financial or other support from President Vladimir Putin of Russia, whom he is scheduled to meet in Moscow on Wednesday.

title: Is PBS Neglecting Its Mission?
description: LOS ANGELES  PBS has drawn big audiences to Downton Abbey, the epic costume drama about elites in early 20th-century Britain. On Sunday, it began broadcasting a new British mini-series, Wolf Hall, about the Tudors. Dramas like these are helping to revive the Masterpiece franchise and PBSs brand.

title: Money Threatens the Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: What Candidates Need
description: I have two presidential election traditions. I begin covering each campaign by reading a book about Abraham Lincoln, and I end each election night, usually after midnight, at the statue of the Lincoln Memorial.

title: Cuban Expectations in a New Era
description: Soon after President Obama announced a sweeping overhaul of American policy toward Cuba in December, it became clear that change would unfold slowly. Untangling the web of sanctions the United States imposes on Cuba will take years because many are codified into law. The Cuban government, while publicly welcoming a rapprochement, seems intent on moving cautiously at a pivotal moment when its historically tight grip on Cuban society will inevitably be tested.

title: Patient, Therapist and Personal Boundaries
New Prize Rewards Economic Diversity at Colleges
description: Top colleges have many reasons to avoid enrolling a lot of low-income students.

title: Did Rolling Stone Hurt the Quest for Justice?
description: This week the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism issued its damning report about the journalistic lapses by Rolling Stone magazine when it published a salacious, and now-discredited, story about a supposed gang rape at a University of Virginia frat house.

title: How Scott Walker Has Escaped the Inauthentic Label So Far
description: It may be called waffling, flip-flopping or evolving, but every four years new presidential candidates find themselves adjusting inconvenient positions that might hinder their bid for the nomination.

title: Americas Endless War Over Money
description: The Audit the Fed debate is the latest manifestation of a conflict as old as the nation, over the role of a central bank.

title: Big City Life
description: In the third episode of Our Man in Tehran, a video series on nytimes.com, produced with VPRO in the Netherlands, Somayeh Malekian discusses her decision to choose a modern, independent life in Tehran over a traditional future prescribed by her conservative upbringing. Ms. Malekian answered selected readers questions below.

title: In Republican Attacks on the Fed, Experts See a Shift
description: WASHINGTON  At a hearing in February, Representative Scott Garrett, a New Jersey Republican, complained that Congress and the Federal Reserve had traded places.

title: Funding Gap Hinders Law for Ensuring Food Safety
description: WASHINGTON  After thousands of people were sickened by tainted eggs, peanut butter and spinach, Congress passed a sweeping food safety law in 2010 that gave the Food and Drug Administration new powers to prevent additional outbreaks. But lawmakers have not provided enough money for the mission.

title: Mayor de Blasios New Challenge: Paying for 2 Children in College
description: He lives rent-free in an Upper East Side mansion, owns two homes in a prime Brooklyn neighborhood and earns a six-figure salary supervising hundreds of thousands of employees.

title: How to Be Emotionally Intelligent
description: What makes a great leader? Knowledge, smarts and vision, to be sure. To that, Daniel Goleman, author of Leadership: The Power of Emotional Intelligence, would add the ability to identify and monitor emotions  your own and others  and to manage relationships. Qualities associated with such emotional intelligence distinguish the best leaders in the corporate world, according to Mr. Goleman, a former New York Times science reporter, a psychologist and co-director of a consortium at Rutgers University to foster research on the role emotional intelligence plays in excellence. He shares his short list of the competencies.

title: Can You Learn to Lead?
description: What does one learn at graduate business school? Business, one assumes. Or more to the point, the management of business. But peruse the website of any business school in the country  or in the world, for that matter  and you may come away thinking that the biggest topic they teach is leadership.

title: Q. and A. on the Chicago Mayors Race as Voters Head to the Polls
description: CHICAGO  Voters here were going to the polls on Tuesday to choose between Rahm Emanuel, a former member of Congress and White House chief of staff, who is seeking a second term as mayor of the nations third-largest city, and Jesus G. Garcia, a county commissioner known as Chuy.

title: Big City Life
description: Somayeh Malekian chose modernity over tradition after she moved from Irans conservative countryside to the capital, Tehran, where she must fight for her independence.

title: Creating Guitars for Gypsy Jazz
description: PARIS  Pigalle, on Pariss Right Bank, has long been known as the citys red-light district, luring revelers with garish neon, cabarets and hostess bars.

title: M.B.A. Programs That Get You Where You Want to Go
description: With some 13,000 graduate schools of business across the globe, the M.B.A. degree has clearly become a commodity.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Malaysia Resurrects Detention Without Trial, Alarming Government Critics
description: BANGKOK  Three years after abolishing detention without trial, the Malaysian government revived the practice on Tuesday with the passage into law of a highly contentious antiterrorism bill that opposition leaders fear could be used against government critics.

title: Abertis of Spain to Spin Off Wireless Tower Unit Cellnex in I.P.O.
description: LONDON  The Spanish infrastructure company Abertis said on Tuesday that it planned to spin off its wireless telecommunications tower arm, Cellnex Telecom, in an initial public offering.

title: FedEx Agrees to Acquire TNT Express in $4.8 Billion Deal
description: LONDON  Taking advantage of a strong dollar and seeking to succeed where United Parcel Service stumbled, the FedEx Corporation has agreed to acquire the Dutch delivery company TNT Express in a $4.8 billion deal.

title: New York Today: Striving for Success
description: Good morning on this drippy Tuesday.

title: What Rand Paul Would Need to Do to Win
description: Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky declared his candidacy for the 2016 Republican presidential nomination on Tuesday in Louisville. Here is a look at what he will need to do if he hopes to win.

title: Can Farms Survive Without Drying Up California?
What It Really Means to Call Hillary Clinton Polarizing
description: Late in George W. Bushs first term, the conservative commentator Charles Krauthammer coined the term Bush Derangement Syndrome, which he defined as the acute onset of paranoia in otherwise normal people in reaction to the policies, the presidency  nay  the very existence of George W. Bush. In other words, there were a whole bunch of people, presumably on the left, who not only didnt like George W. Bush, but also disliked him to an irrational and perhaps unhinged degree. By coining a syndrome to describe the state, Krauthammer, a formerly practicing psychiatrist with an M.D. from Harvard, was injecting a clever bit of gas-lighting into the debate. (Are you sure theres not something else going on with you, Bush haters? Have you considered getting help?)

title: The Living Beauty of Wicken Fen
description: On a foggy morning last spring, I took my brother and 11-year-old niece for a long walk in one of Britains oldest nature reserves, Wicken Fen, a tiny fragment of a lost marshland ecosystem that once covered around 2,500 square miles of eastern England. We spent hours walking through a mosaic of grassland and sedge, past wet fields cut with scrub-shadow and flashes of open water. Everywhere was bursting with life: singing nightingales, snipe winnowing through the upper air, cuckoos tilting from the tips of willows and rails squealing and grunting in reeds. As we walked on wet grass by one of the fens ancient waterways, a barn owl floated past us, its mothy wings shining through particulate mist; at our feet a drinker moth caterpillar inched furrily across the path like a cautiously mobile mustache. We knelt to watch its progress. Then my niece turned to me and asked: When they made this place, where did they bring the animals from? Did they come from a zoo?

title: Lincolns Triumphant Visit to Richmond
description: Shortly before noon on April 3, 1865, a telegraph operator on duty at the War Department in Washington, D.C., received an electrifying message over the wires. Here is the first message for you in four years from Richmond, it read.

title: Daily Report: Big Data, Human Overseers
description: Armies of the finest minds in computer science have dedicated themselves to improving the odds of making a sale. The Internet-era abundance of data and clever software has opened the door to tailored marketing, targeted advertising and personalized product recommendations, Steve Lohr reports.

title: Today in Politics: Some Hiccups Await Rand Pauls Big Day
description: Good Tuesday morning from Washington, where all eyes are on Kentucky and Senator Rand Pauls event promising a message of big news, and a different kind of Republican to take on Washington. Whatever could the announcement be? Former Gov. Jeb Bush responds to mistakenly calling himself Hispanic, and in Chicago, the polls open in the runoff election for mayor between Rahm Emanuel and Jesus G. Garcia. Though Mr. Pauls efforts to control the rollout of his presidential campaign  oh, thats what the announcement will be  may be hindered by the near-simultaneous release of an ad criticizing his statements on Iran, he will be only the second official entrant in what is expected to be a crowded Republican field.

title: Samsung Shows Signs of a Turnaround
description: HONG KONG  After nearly two years of suffering at the hands of upstart rivals and established industry giants, Samsung may finally be on the mend.

title: Liu Xiang, Chinese Olympic Star, Retires
description: Liu Xiang, the pathbreaking Olympic champion whose later career was tormented by recurring injuries, announced his retirement from competition on Tuesday.

title: Google Dodges a Ban in Turkey Over Hostage Photo
description: ISTANBUL  Google was spared on Tuesday from a recent wave of Internet bans in Turkey after it reportedly complied with a court order to remove links to images of Mehmet Selim Kiraz, a prosecutor  who died after leftist militants took him hostage at an Istanbul courthouse last week.

title: Rand Paul Announces Presidential Run
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky officially declared himself a candidate for the Republican presidential nomination on Tuesday, promising a crowd of cheering supporters that he is ready to shake up Washington and disprove those in his own party who doubt that a fiercely libertarian conservative can be a serious contender.

title: Is There Anything One Should Feel Ashamed of Reading?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, James Parker and Charles McGrath discuss whether any books should provoke shame in readers.

title: In Performance: Tessa Ferrer of Buzzer
description: This weeks video features the actress Tessa Ferrer in a scene from Buzzer, a new drama that interweaves themes of class and racial tension into a story of real estate and gentrification.

title: Journalese: The Sequel
description: My colleague Patrick LaForge offers more examples of news-writing clichs:

title: Iraq Empties Mass Graves in Search for Cadets Killed by ISIS
description: BAGHDAD  Among the mass graves being unearthed in Tikrit, soldiers spotted an old man carrying a large trash bag and trying to sneak away.

title: Apps for Encounters of the Local Kind
description: When Toni Finnimore, a 30-year-old from Brighton, a seaside city two hours south of London, came to New York City in mid-November, she wanted to hang out with locals. She had made the same trip seven years earlier and found myself visiting every tourist attraction the city had to offer, she said.

title: Party Time With an Old Friend
description: Dear Diary:

title: Morning Agenda: FedEx to Buy TNT Express in $4.8 Billion Deal
description: FEDEX TO BUY TNT EXPRESS IN $4.8 BILLION DEAL | FedEx Corporation said on Tuesday that it had agreed to acquire the Dutch delivery company TNT Express in an all-cash deal that values TNT at 4.4 billion euros, or about $4.8 billion, Chad Bray writes in DealBook. The transaction would greatly expand the American delivery giants presence in Europe and comes less than two years after European regulators blocked a bid by United Parcel Service, its global delivery rival.

title: Azzedine Alaa Has a Different Kind of Show
description: Forget frocks and eye-popping knitwear. Think poetry, with a dash of politics on top.

title: A Dual Review of Whats New, Starring Arnold Schwarzenegger and Rene Fleming
description: Arnold Schwarzenegger, cigar-smoking action hero and onetime Governator who plays a protective father warding off zombies this month in Maggie, will be back in July to reprise his iconic role in Terminator Genisys. Schwarzenegger takes on Rene Fleming, the National Medal of Arts-decorated opera singer whose down-to-earth persona has earned her the nickname The Peoples Diva. Shell make her Broadway debut this month as a narcissistic soprano in the new play Living on Love.

title: Its Hard to Lift Wages if the Fed Doesnt Make It a Priority
description: The Federal Reserve is supposed to achieve two goals simultaneously: full employment with stable prices. Yet there is one obvious factor that drives American living standards but risks being lost in this mix: wages.

description: SEATTLE  Most demonstrations of new technology do not involve cooking and then tasting freshly fried potato chips, sprinkled with sea salt and pepper.

title: Measuring Social Trust to Make Loans
description: Alternative consumer lenders tend to fit into one of two camps: peer-to-peer marketplaces like Lending Club and Prosper, and start-ups using data science to parse credit risk, like Affirm, Earnest and Zest Finance.

title: Iranian Border Guards Are Killed in Fighting Near Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Two episodes in a volatile area of Iran near the countrys border with Pakistan have left eight Iranian border guards and three militants dead, news agencies reported on Tuesday.

title: As Baseball Returns for Opening Day, Runs Dont Follow
description: Opening day brings the smell of newly mowed grass, the resumption of peanut devouring and the crack of wood on leather.

title: The Brothers, Masha Gessens Book About the Boston Marathon Bombers
description: There is no episode more disturbing and disruptive in Bostons history than the April 15, 2013, bombing that killed three and injured more than 260  including 16 who lost limbs. It was followed by a violent, chaotic escape attempt during which an M.I.T. police officer was killed, an exhaustive manhunt took place and the governor ordered those in greater Boston to shelter in place. By the time Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the surviving brother of the two bombers, was discovered hiding in a boat dry-docked in a backyard, everyone in the region was touched, either physically or emotionally, by this crime.

title: Canadian Pension Plan and Permira to Buy Informatica in $5.3 Billion Deal
description: The enterprise software company Informatica announced on Tuesday that it had agreed to be taken private in a $5.3 billion deal  the largest buyout so far this year.

description: ITunes Problems

title: Ravensbrck, by Sarah Helm
description: When we hear the phrase concentration camp, we usually envision the huge extermination centers the Germans built in Poland as part of their final solution to the Jewish question, their effort to murder every Jew they could find. But though it was relatively small, and though it wasnt primarily an extermination center, Ravensbrck helps us understand how thoroughgoing an onslaught on humanity Nazi Germany perpetrated, and how central to its identity was its implacable urge to enslave and kill those it considered undesirable.

title: Brian Unger on the Big American Story
description: Have you ever walked, biked or driven by a well-known building for years, only to find yourself wondering about the stories behind it? The commentator, producer and actor Brian Unger knows the feeling. Mr. Unger is the host of a show, Time Traveling With Brian Unger, which has its premiere on April 20 on the Travel Channel.

title: Rand Pauls Challenge: Libertarians Are Still a Small Minority
description: It has become fashionable in recent years to refer to a growing libertarian wing of the Republican Party, and Rand Paul, the Kentucky senator who announced his candidacy for the presidency on Tuesday, hopes to become the first serious candidate to make it part of a winning primary coalition.

title: Vivendi in Talks to Buy 80% Stake in Dailymotion
description: LONDON  The French conglomerate Vivendi is trying to revamp the fortunes of Dailymotion, a video-sharing website that has long struggled to live up to its early promise as the next YouTube.

description: INDIANAPOLIS  It was a scampering, spinning, diving, sometimes airborne affair, this championship match between two fine teams.

title: Style on Orchard Road in Singapore
description: Rachel Lim has a good idea about how Singaporean women want to dress. As part owner and designer of Love, Bonito, an online retailer, she caters to the popular feminine aesthetic and, at the same time, is part of a movement toward more experimental looks, a shift she attributes to social media. We are getting bold in discovering ourselves, trying out new colors and silhouettes, she said. She wore a jumpsuit from her store that she described as masculine yet sexy, Zara platform pumps and a Cline bag. (This interview has been edited and condensed.)

title: Scientists Swarm Around the Twitter Hashtag #IAmAScientistBecause
description: Most twitterstorms are manufactured, like the one yesterday aiming to boost the prospects of Jess Chuy Garca in Chicagos mayoral race.

description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: In Napa Valley, a Bike Ride With Food as Co-Star
description: In a new spin on the chef-driven food festival, the coming Bottega Gran Fondo pairs food enthusiasts and cycling fans for a bike-ride-cum-progressive-feast in Californias Napa Valley.

title: Indian Police Shoot and Kill 20 Said to Be Illegally Cutting Down Trees
description: NEW DELHI  The Indian police and forestry officials on Tuesday fatally shot 20 loggers whom they suspected of illegally cutting down endangered red sandalwood trees, whose wood can be sold in China and Japan for hundreds of thousands of dollars a ton.

title: The Fiscal Future II: Not Enough Debt?
description: Continuing my meditation on Brad DeLongs meditation on the fiscal future. Brad doesnt just argue that governments should be bigger in the future; he also argues that governments have historically not had enough debt, and should have more.

title: Economics of Love
description: Not love as in romance; love as in tennis, meaning zero. Cecchetti & Schoenholtz argue that zero matters in macroeconomics; specifically, both the zero almost-lower bound on interest rates and downward wage rigidity make the case that deflation or for that matter very low inflation is a bad thing.

title: The Auto Show Is in New York, and Cadillac Is Too
description: When Cadillac announced last year that it was moving its headquarters to Soho in Manhattan, it caught my attention. Plenty of tech and digital media companies have set up operations in Lower Manhattan, but no auto companies, let alone an old-economy stalwart like Cadillac.

title: Deployments: Costly. Remembering Why We Do It: Priceless.
description: There is a vintage poster I saw years ago touting the slogan Join the Navy, See the World. Early in our marriage, we fulfilled it, hiking the jungles of Saipan where my grandfather fought during World War II, watching the sunrise at Angkor Wat in Cambodia, exploring the castle grounds in Kumamoto and jumping from waterfalls in the Northern Territory in Australia. Over his first deployment, I met his ship in exotic ports at every chance.

title: 1940: Decree Bans Heat Till Oct. 15
description: From now on the eau chaude label on French faucets will be a mockery on four consecutive days a week, winter and summer, under a fuel conservation decree appearing yesterday in the Journal Office cutting down hot water supply. The same decree stops all central heating, no matter what type of fuel is used, from April 1 to October 15. It will be neither clever nor useful to seek out a Turkish bath or pool, unless you feel like a member of the Polar Bear club.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 8, 1940

title: ABCs World News Tonight Tops NBCs Newscast
description: For the first time in five and a half years, ABCs World News Tonight defeated the NBC Nightly News in total viewers last week. ABCs evening newscast averaged 7.99 million viewers a night compared with NBCs 7.91 million for the week beginning March 30, according to Nielsen.

title: A Reading of With Eilmer of Malmesbury by Paul Muldoon
description: The Irish poet laments a life lost too soon.

description: Soon after the Duke Blue Devils won the N.C.A.A. mens basketball national championship Monday night, Senator Claire McCaskill of Missouri sought to refocus attention on the academic role of student-athletes, tweeting her congratulations to Duke, but adding that she was rooting for the team who had stars that are actually going to college & not just doing semester tryout for NBA.

The shipping firm has agreed to buy its ailing Dutch rival TNT Express for 4.4 billion euros ($4.8 billion) in a friendly, all-cash deal. That seems a full price for a troubled target. But cost savings, cheap debt and a strong dollar could help FedEx realize good returns.

title: As Europes Political Landscape Shifts, Two-Party System Fades
description: LONDON  Sixty years ago, the two main British political parties, the Conservatives and Labour, took 96 percent of the vote in a clearly defined two-party system. Today, as Britain undergoes a bitter campaign before the May 7 election, the two parties are expected to split less than two-thirds of the vote.

title: S.E.C. Gains Support From an Unexpected Quarter
description: Judge Jed S. Rakoff of Federal District Court in Manhattan has been a bit of a thorn in the side of the Securities and Exchange Commission, once describing a settlement with Bank of America over faulty disclosure in the Merrill Lynch acquisition half-baked justice.

description: JERUSALEM  The death in January of a Spanish member of the United Nations peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon was caused by Israeli fire during a clash, an Israeli security official confirmed Tuesday.

title: After Victory Over ISIS in Tikrit, Next Battle Requires a New Template
description: Emboldened as they mop up the last Islamic State forces in the city of Tikrit, Iraqi military leaders are already vowing to follow up that operation with a much more ambitious one: marching into the vast Sunni heartland in western Iraq to root out some of the most significant militant strongholds.

title: In Parched California, Innovation, Like Water, Has Limits
description: Californias drought has not spared A. G. Kawamura.

title: Coverage of Final Leaves Room for Improvement in a Crowded TV Booth
description: Bill Raftery proved that he belonged as the lead analyst for the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament over the past few weeks. He brought his onions, his lingerie and his tin to Monday nights Duke-Wisconsin final  as well as his commentary. Raftery will always win the contest for laugh lines in a game broadcast, so, combined with his often-underrated analysis, why would you need another analyst beside him?

title: Old-School A.C.C. Fan Wins N.C.A.A. Pool
description: It was hard before the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament started to predict that the juggernaut Kentucky team would lose in the semifinals. It was harder still to pick seventh-seeded Michigan State to make the Final Four.

title: Can Rand Paul Win With His Principles?
description: At some point in every election cycle since 1992, when the Republican culture war helped lead to President George H. W. Bushs defeat by Bill Clinton, the Republican Party has made a display of talking about expanding its appeal beyond a base of voters that has steadily grown whiter, richer, more intolerant and more right wing.

title: The New Wave of Cabana Shirts
description: The season of Cabana shirts  also known as Cuban collar shirts, which call to mind mojitos and cigars, and are often emblazoned with kitschy symbols of tropical vacations (palm trees, flamingos, hibiscuses)  has arrived. This summer ushers in a more urbane approach to the classic warm-weather staple: quieter prints and subtler colors that could have been worn by the hip wandering youth in Jim Jarmuschs 1980 gritty New York film Permanent Vacation instead of by a tourist on a beach holiday.

title: Senate Plan to Revise No Child Left Behind Law Would Not Measure Teachers by Test Scores
description: A bipartisan Senate bill revising the No Child Left Behind law, and eliminating many of its most punitive elements, was announced on Tuesday.

description: CAIRO  The United States said on Tuesday that it was expediting deliveries of weapons to Saudi Arabia, a sign of the Obama administrations deepening involvement in the Saudi military offensive against the Houthi movement in Yemen.

description: Coat brussels sprouts in olive oil and roast until beginning to brown.

title: Rand Paul, Caught in the Middle
description: Senator Rand Paul has promised to change the Republican party, but he faces challenges bridging libertarian and conservative orthodoxy on four issues.

title: A Short-Lived Power Failure in Washington Causes a Brief Government Shutdown
description: WASHINGTON  An equipment failure at a Maryland electric plant on Tuesday caused a widespread shutdown across the city and parts of suburban Maryland, leaving the White House and other government buildings temporarily without power.

description: President Obama, at an Easter prayer breakfast, on how he feels as his daughters go on college visits.

title: Low Gasoline Prices Will Continue This Summer, Government Says
description: HOUSTON  The Energy Department predicted on Tuesday that motorists would pay the lowest prices at the pump this summer since 2009, even though falling global oil prices have gained back some ground in recent days.

title: Whatever Happened to Running as a Libertarian?
description: When Senator Rand Paul announced his official candidacy for president today, there were a couple of things missing from the spotlight. One was Ron Paul, Mr. Pauls father, who first ran for president in 1988 and garnered zero states in the 2012 Republican presidential nominating contests. The other was the Libertarian Party.

title: Shelf, iPad, Bed Table: Reading, March 2015
description: How can you rely on someones opinion of a book if you dont know what else that person likes?

title: Elvis Is Everywhere
description: n a small Welsh town, a French photographer discovered a club of Elvis fanatics who took solace not so much in his music, but the promise of the American dream.

title: A Conversation With Anthony Hsieh of loanDepot
description: Mr. Hsieh, 50, is the chairman, chief executive and founder of loanDepot, a nonbank consumer mortgage lender with headquarters in Foothill Ranch, Calif., and Plano, Tex.

title: A New Cookbook Imparts the Art of the Swedish Coffee Break
description: Last year, when the Swedish cafe chain Fika opened a new location near Ts offices, its minimalist interiors, heady aroma of fresh-brewed coffee and toppling towers of baked goods drew in a steady crowd  none of whom seemed to know, however, just what Fika meant. Its a cultural gap the Swedish authors of a new cookbook, Fika: The Art of the Swedish Coffee Break ($18, Ten Speed Press), are hoping to bridge.

title: Review: Judith Millers The Story: A Reporters Journey
description: In late 2002 and through 2003, Judith Miller, an investigative reporter at The New York Times, wrote a series of articles about the presumed presence of chemical and biological weapons and possible nuclear matriel in Iraq. Critics thought the articles too bellicose and in lock step with the George W. Bush administrations march to war. They all included careful qualifiers, but their overwhelming message was that Saddam Hussein posed a threat.

title: A Victorian House in Hertfordshire
description: Set on more than two acres and within commuting distance of London, the house is on the market for $2.22 million.

title: A Duke Title, Just as Tyus Jones and Fellow Freshmen Planned It Long Ago
description: INDIANAPOLIS  As the song One Shining Moment played Monday night, Dukes Tyus Jones, a freshman guard, beamed as his freshman teammate Jahlil Okafor extended his large left hand to grasp Joness shoulder.

title: Rand Paul Taking an Untested Route to the Republican Nomination
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Senator Rand Pauls entry on Tuesday into the race for the White House said as much about his own political aspirations as it did about a vexing truth for Republicans: Many of them believe their party is simply not big enough to elect a president in 2016.

title: Michael Bloomberg, Mayor of London?
description: LONDON  MIGHT Michael R. Bloomberg run for mayor again  this time in London? So The Sunday Times here reported over the weekend. It cited only unnamed friends as sources. An adviser to Mr. Bloomberg quickly brushed off the report, tweeting that he loves NYC too much to leave.

title: In Newark, a Vertical Indoor Farm Helps Anchor an Areas Revival
description: NEWARK  Schools, sports arenas and apartment buildings have sprouted in recent years in this troubled city as part of efforts to revitalize it. Now, its kales turn to take root in a most unusual spot.

title: Irans Leaders Fall Into Line Behind Nuclear Accord
description: TEHRAN  Since the Islamic Revolution in 1979, Iranian hard-liners have been free to take to the streets and object to any form of compromise with the West, and particularly the United States.

title: In Rise of Yik Yak App, Profits and Ethics Collide
description: Do venture capitalists and other highly sophisticated and compensated investors, like those controlling large private equity and hedge funds, have any moral or ethical responsibility for the investments they make?

title: Russian Nuclear Submarine Catches Fire During Repairs
description: MOSCOW  A Russian nuclear submarine caught fire while undergoing repairs in a dry dock outside the city of Arkhangelsk and smoke billowed from it through the day on Tuesday. But emergency officials told Russian news agencies that the submarine posed no risk of leaking radiation because its nuclear fuel and armaments had been removed before the work began.

title: Recent Commercial Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Review: The Comedians, Starring Billy Crystal and Josh Gad
description: The two stars of The Comedians are mighty good. The premise theyre given to work with, though, has its limits.

title: Review: Berio to Cage to Mozart at Baryshnikov Arts Center
description: Concert programmers often work hard to create thematic links between seemingly unconnected pieces and events. So it was refreshing to hear the pianist Pedja Muzijevic say lightheartedly, when introducing a performance at the Baryshnikov Arts Center that juxtaposed John Cage with a Mozart piano quartet, that there was no particular formula behind the choices.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Review: In About Elly, a Middle Class Enjoying Itself Is Engulfed in Change
description: If the setup of the Iranian filmmaker Asghar Farhadis devastating film About Elly sounds familiar, its because this story of a young woman who disappears during a festive weekend outing at a coastal resort resembles that of Michelangelo Antonionis classic LAvventura. In both movies, a frantic and futile search ensues.

title: Museums Begin Returning Artifacts to India in Response to Investigation
description: Several American museums have begun returning possibly stolen artifacts to India in response to a major federal investigation into the activities of Subhash Kapoor, a dealer identified by authorities as having once run the largest antiquities smuggling operation on American soil.

title: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
description: Kenya and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Larry Kramers Novel The American People Adds a Gay Dimension to History
description: Fourteen years ago, the playwright and activist Larry Kramer was preparing to die. His liver was failing, and the prognosis was grave.

title: Kansas Limits Abortion Method, Opening a New Line of Attack
description: Kansas on Tuesday became the first state to sharply restrict or alter the most common technique used for second-trimester abortions, opening a new, emotionally charged line of attack by anti-abortion forces who hope to take it swiftly to other states.

title: Another Serial Chapter, From Group of Lawyers
description: The story behind the hit podcast Serial is not over. The podcast focused on the 1999 death of Hae Min Lee, a Maryland teenager, and the subsequent conviction of her former boyfriend, Adnan Syed, who is serving a life sentence for murder. It became the fastest podcast to reach five million downloads, according to Apple. Starting Monday a group of lawyers and advocates connected to Mr. Syed will debut another podcast, Undisclosed: The State v. Adnan Syed, which will examine and explore the case in greater detail, from an investigatory perspective instead of a narrative one, according to a statement. Undisclosed is being presented by Rabia Chaudry, a lawyer who has been a longtime advocate of Mr. Syed  as Serial fans know, she was the one who suggested that Sarah Koenig, the host of Serial and a longtime producer for This American Life, look into the case  along with two other lawyers, Susan Simpson and Colin Miller. None of them represent Mr. Syed but each has been investigating the case, Ms. Chaudry said in an interview Tuesday. New episodes of Undisclosed are to be released every two weeks. The podcast is sponsored by the Adnan Syed Legal Trust, which, according to a page on the crowdfunding site LaunchGood, is dedicated to Mr. Syeds defense and has raised $93,000. In November the producers of Serial said that a second season was coming. In February a Maryland court agreed to hear an appeal from Mr. Syed, who has said that he is not guilty of Ms. Lees murder and that he received ineffective legal counsel at trial.

title: Pakistani Court Orders Ex-C.I.A. Officials Charged Over 2009 Drone Strike
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A Pakistani court on Tuesday ordered criminal charges to be filed against a former C.I.A. station chief and a former C.I.A. lawyer over a 2009 drone strike that killed two people.

title: April 7, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Kenya, Russia, France and the United States.

title: Rand Paul and the Empty Box
description: Nate Cohn tells us that Rand Paul cant win as a libertarian, because there basically arent any libertarians. And thats true. I wish I could say that Rand Paul cant win because he believes in crank monetary economics, etc. But the truth is that these things matter much less than the fact that not many Americans consider themselves libertarian, and even those who do are deluding themselves.

title: Video Shows Fatal Police Shooting
description: In video provided to The New York Times, a police officer in North Charleston, S.C., is seen shooting an apparently unarmed man after a scuffle following a traffic stop.

title: Carried Interest Should Be Disclosed on Tax Forms, and to Private Equity Investors
description: Writing in The Hill, the economist Eileen Appelbaum argues that private equity funds should be required to disclose on the tax return the partnership files for informational purposes the amount of carried interest paid to the general partner. Carried interest is the percentage of an investment funds profits  typically 20 percent  paid to the funds managers as incentive compensation.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: South Carolina Officer Is Charged With Murder of Walter Scott
description: WASHINGTON  A white police officer in North Charleston, S.C., was charged with murder on Tuesday after a video surfaced showing him shooting in the back and killing an apparently unarmed black man while the man ran away.

title: Q. and A.: Cao Fei on Art, Motherhood and Walking the Political Red Line
description: Cao Fei was still a student at the Guangzhou Academy of Fine Arts in 2000 when she was discovered by the curator Hou Hanru, who introduced her to the international art world. Since then, Ms. Cao, 36, who is best known for her multimedia and video work, has exhibited widely, including at the Venice Biennale, the Serpentine Galleries in London, and the Guggenheim Museum and Museum of Modern Art in New York. She was a finalist for the Hugo Boss Prize in 2010 and won the 2006 Chinese Contemporary Art Award in the best young artist category.

title: What You Get for ... $900,000
description: This weeks properties include a Space-Age place in Seattle, a farmhouse in Pennsylvania and a cottage in Florida.

title: Lawmakers Take Step to Remove Putin Critic
description: MOSCOW  Russian lawmakers took a major step on Tuesday toward ousting Ilya V. Ponomarev, the only member of Parliament who opposed the annexation of Crimea last year and one of the few elected officials who have repeatedly dared to challenge President Vladimir V. Putin publicly.

title: Living in Sugar Hill
description: The Harlem neighborhood is almost entirely residential, and much of it falls within the rowhouse-laden historic districts.

title: 2013: Rand Paul Discusses Immigration
description: Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, spoke about immigration and the Latino vote at the Iowa Republicans Lincoln Day Dinner in Cedar Rapids in May 2013.

title: Funeral Masses Held for 2 Killed in East Village Explosion
description: They were four years apart, but death came for them in the same instant: in an explosion in the East Village on March 26, engulfing a block in smoke and destroying three buildings on Second Avenue. Moises Ismael Locn Yac, 27, was busing tables in the midafternoon lull at Sushi Park, a restaurant on the first floor of 121 Second Avenue. Nicholas Figueroa, 23, had just paid his lunch bill there.

title: Ralph Sharon, Jazz Pianist Who Accompanied Tony Bennett, Dies at 91
description: Ralph Sharon, Tony Bennetts longtime accompanist, who in the early 1960s persuaded Mr. Bennett to sing a song originally written for a Wagnerian contralto  about the fond intersection of a large muscle in the chest with a Northern California city  and in so doing created a Grammy-winning standard, died on March 31 at his home in Boulder, Colo. He was 91.

title: Airbnb Offers Accommodations in Cuba
description: Airbnb, the San Francisco-based home and room rental company, has added rooms for rent in Cuba.

title: Obama Makes Walker the Exception, Again
description: President Obama generally refrains from talking about the candidates vying to succeed him in 2016, but when it comes to Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, hes made a couple of exceptions.

title: Royal Dutch Shell in Talks for BG Group, a Gas Producer
description: LONDON  The British oil and gas producer BG Group said on Tuesday that it was in advanced discussions with Royal Dutch Shell over a potential sale. A deal could top $50 billion.

title: HP Comes to Terms With the Cloud
description: A year ago, Hewlett-Packard thought it was going to change cloud computing. Now it looks more as if cloud computing is changing HP, just as the company enters one of the greatest attempts at reorganization in the history of technology.

title: The Dow Minute by Minute
description: The Dow Jones, minute by minute.

title: Online Tools Can Ease the Burden of Being Executor of an Estate
description: Being named the executor of a family members estate can be overwhelming: At at time when youre grieving, youre called on to handle a host of unfamiliar administrative duties.

title: Signs of Trouble Before New Jersey Centenarian Killed Wife With Ax and Took His Own Life
description: ELMWOOD PARK, N.J.  Three months ago, Rosalia Juskin dialed 911 from behind a locked basement door. She said her husband, Michael, 100, was ignoring her pleas, so she asked the police for help opening the door. When they arrived, Ms. Juskin, 88, described the episode as an accident.

title: Peter Diamandopoulos, Divisive Adelphi University President, Dies at 86
description: Peter Diamandopoulos, a Harvard-trained philosophy professor whose divisive 12-year tenure as president of Adelphi University on Long Island culminated in his unceremonious ouster over lavish spending and conflicts of interest involving university trustees, died on April 1 in Manhattan. He was 86.

title: Turkey and Iran Put Tensions Aside, for a Day
description: ISTANBUL  President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey accused Iran last month of trying to dominate the region through its proxies in Iraq, Lebanon, Syria and Yemen, suggesting to some that Turkey was shifting toward confrontation with its neighbor and joining a Saudi-led coalition to push back against Iranian influence across the Middle East.

title: Director ofVoice of America Is Planning to Step Down
description: WASHINGTON  David Ensor, who as director of the Voice of America has presided over significant growth in the news agencys audience despite budget cuts, announced Tuesday that he was stepping down.

title: Massachusetts: Boston Marathon Bombing Jury Continues Talks
description: A federal jury on Tuesday began deliberations in the case of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, 21, who faces 30 federal charges for his role in the deadly bombing at the 2013 Boston Marathon. Mr. Tsarnaev has pleaded not guilty to the charges, 17 of which carry the death penalty, even though his lawyers have admitted in court that he and his older brother, Tamerlan, set off the bombs and, several days later, led police officers on a fiery chase in which the older brother was killed. If Mr. Tsarnaev is convicted on any of the capital charges, as is expected, there will be a second phase of the trial to determine his sentence. The jurors deliberated all day Tuesday and passed two notes with questions to the court; deliberations are set to resume on Wednesday.

title: Pearl River, Chinese Emporium in Manhattan, Will Close at Year-End
description: When Pearl River Mart opened its doors as a tiny downtown store peddling Chinese knickknacks in 1971, few if any businesses in New York and in the country sold goods imported from the Chinese mainland.

title: A Prehistoric Giant Is Revived, if Only in Name
description: For anyone who has ever been told by a smarty-pants 7-year-old, Theres no such thing as Brontosaurus; its called Apatosaurus  it is payback time.

title: Charles Grassley Questions Diversion of Fannie and Freddie Earnings
description: For almost two years, shareholders of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac have been asking the United States government about its 2012 decision to divert all of the mortgage finance giants earnings to the Treasury rather than let them repay taxpayers under the original bailout agreement.

title: White House Seeks to Soothe Relations With Venezuela
description: BOGOT, Colombia  A White House official said Tuesday that Venezuela was not a threat to the national security of the United States, backing off language in an executive order that had inflamed relations with the South American nation and drawn criticism from other countries in the region.

title: Questions of Bias Are Raised About a Teachers Exam in New York
description: A federal judge is questioning whether a new exam for aspiring teachers in New York is discriminatory against minorities, a case that could derail the states efforts to create a more rigorous set of tests for entry into the profession.

title: For Masters Champions, Only a Year to Throw on the Green Jacket
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Some topics never go away at the Masters. One of them is the many things that newly crowned champions do with the green jackets they are awarded.

title: James Best, Bumbling Sheriff of The Dukes of Hazzard, Dies at 88
description: James Best, who played the oafish sheriff Rosco P. Coltrane on the hit television comedy The Dukes of Hazzard, died on Monday near his home in Hickory, N.C. He was 88.

title: More South Sudanese Seek Shelter at U.N. Bases
description: In a sign of worsening problems in South Sudan, convulsed by civil war and intensifying hunger for more than a year, the United Nations said Tuesday that an increasing number of displaced South Sudanese are seeking shelter and protection at its peacekeeping outposts.

title: American Epic TV Series Examines 1920s Recordings
description: The 1920s are an almost mythical time for the American recording industry, when record labels scoured the map and recorded a huge variety of folk, blues, country and ethnic songs by now-legendary acts like the Carter Family. But who were the people involved, and how did the technology work?

title: Mexico: Gunmen Kill 15 Police Officers
description: Gunmen ambushed a Jalisco State police convoy, killing 15 officers in one of the deadliest attacks on security forces in eight years of the drug war, state officials said Tuesday. The convoy was attacked as the police units were traveling through the remote western mountains of Jalisco toward Guadalajara. The gunmen are believed to belong to a powerful gang called the New Generation Jalisco Cartel, Jaliscos security commissioner, Alejandro Solorio Archiga, said Tuesday in a radio interview. A man suspected of being one of the gangs leaders, Heriberto Acevedo Crdenas, was killed in a shootout with security forces on March 23. Four days earlier, 11 people were killed when a federal police convoy was attacked in Jalisco.

title: At Masters, Tiger Woods Savors Sharing the Augusta Experience
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  As he makes his 20th appearance at the Masters this week, Tiger Woods has begun to recognize which tournaments have been landmark moments in his life.

title: Stan Freberg, Madcap Adman and Satirist, Dies at 88
