description: Stan Freberg, a humorist whose sprawling imagination fueled a multifaceted career that included pretty much inventing the idea of using satire in commercials, died on Tuesday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 88.

title: Tiger Woods on His Return to Competition
description: The golfer spoke on Tuesday before the Masters tournament, saying he was happy to again be playing at the highest level.

title: With Details of Iran Deal Still in Flux, White House Opens Sales Effort
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has compared the preliminary accord on limiting Irans nuclear program to signing a contract to buy a house, emphasizing that the deal is not done until it closes. But a more accurate analogy might be that the administration bought a house under construction and is still haggling over where the windows and doors should go.

title: Israels Unworkable Demands on Iran
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has gone into overdrive against a nuclear agreement with Iran. On Monday, his government made new demands that it claimed would ensure a better deal than the preliminary one that Iran, President Obama and other leaders of major powers announced last week. The new demands are unrealistic and, if pursued, would not mean a better deal but no deal at all.

title: Rahm Emanuel Wins Runoff Election to Secure 2nd Term as Chicago Mayor
description: CHICAGO  Mayor Rahm Emanuel, the former White House chief of staff whose cutting personality and centrist policies earned him the nickname Mayor 1 Percent among his critics, was re-elected mayor of Chicago on Tuesday, surviving a challenge from Jesus G. Garcia, a county commissioner who was seeking to become the citys first Latino mayor.

title: New Girl Star Lamorne Morris on Writing This Weeks Story Line About Race and the Police
description: The Fox comedy New Girl isnt known for its commentary on world affairs  in fact, its stories are largely confined to the apartment its four main characters share. But on Tuesdays episode, Par 5, the plot took an unexpected dive into a conversation about race relations.

title: Study Warns of Diet Supplement Dangers Kept Quiet by F.D.A.
description: Popular weight-loss and workout supplements on sale in hundreds of vitamin shops across the nation contain a chemical nearly identical to amphetamine, the powerful stimulant, and pose dangers to the health of those who take them, according to a new study. The Canadian health authorities in December called the chemical, BMPEA, a serious health risk, and pulled supplements that contain it from store shelves.

title: Golfing Analyst Knows the Thrill and Agony of Wisconsins Season
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Across the street from the hotel where the Wisconsin mens basketball team was staying, Andy North stood next to his wife, Sue, staring blankly into the distance. It was the same look he had 70 minutes earlier while shoulder to shoulder with Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers in the Badgers section at Lucas Oil Stadium.

title: Jenrry Mejias Arm Injury Highlights Sore Spot for Mets Staff
description: WASHINGTON  Last year, as the Mets converted the right-handed starter Jenrry Mejia to a reliever, he would become anxious about not having a set schedule, about not knowing exactly when he would throw or enter games. He feared he would get hurt  again.

title: Review: Cry, Trojans! Is the Wooster Groups Take on Troilus and Cressida
description: Theres smoke rising from the tepee that occupies upstage-center at St. Anns Warehouse in Brooklyn. But as hard as you may look, you wont find the fire  dramatic, emotional or intellectual  in Cry, Trojans!, the befuddled and befuddling work in which the mighty Wooster Group lays siege to Shakespeares Troilus and Cressida.

title: Review: Hand to God Features a Foul-Talking Puppet
description: Stand down, Inspector Javert, vengeful foe of bread-snatchers. A more formidable villain now stalks the Broadway boards, one who makes you seem about as frightening as a French pastry. His name, Tyrone, is not the scariest handle, but hes as ruthless as any dedicated evildoer, with a spectacularly foul mouth and a thirst for young flesh.

title: Sound of an Air Kiss
description: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE  Im torn about my feelings for this puzzle theme. On the one hand, Im an animal lover and am therefore anti-TRAP. On the other hand, Im also an inveterate New Yorker, and can see the utility of having someone develop a TOURIST TRAP, especially in the summer months, when it is apparently tourist mating season and they seem to multiply like rabbits. [Ha ha! Shes just kidding. Please dont sue us.  Ed.] [Fine. What if we just lure them into nice, air-conditioned movie theaters, so they stop walking the wrong way down the sidewalk?  D.A.]

title: New Criticism After New Jersey Posts Text of Exxon Settlement
description: Environmental groups and some New Jersey lawmakers issued new criticism on Tuesday of the states proposed $225 million pollution settlement with Exxon Mobil Corporation, one day after the state made the text of the deal public.

title: A Removed Snowden Sculpture Inspires a Hologram in Its Place
description: Having presided briefly over Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn on Monday morning atop a column, a 100-pound bust of Edward J. Snowden was shrouded by parks workers, removed  and stashed in a city storage facility somewhere.

title: Long an Unfinished Puzzle, the Nets Find the Missing Pieces
description: The Nets were fresh off their 11th victory in their past 14 games, and their locker room at Barclays Center on Monday night was just a few notches short of festive. Bojan Bogdanovic fielded questions about the teams strong bench play. Brook Lopez reminisced about the teams defunct mascot, BrooklyKnight, and his old pals, Sly Fox and Mini Sly.

title: UConns Win Isnt Pretty, but Title Is a Perfect 10th for Geno Auriemma
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Connecticuts third straight N.C.A.A. womens basketball championship was impassioned, not pretty. But in the end, it was perfect.

title: Judge Cites Prison Guards Letter in Granting New Trial in Death of Nashville Inmate
description: A federal judge in Tennessee has granted a new civil trial in a lawsuit over the 2010 death of an inmate at a prison in Nashville, citing the emergence of new evidence.

title: More Teens Using Long-Term Contraception
description: The use of long-acting, reversible birth control like intrauterine devices and implants has risen sharply among teenagers in the last decade, new federal data show. Researchers from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention studied the use of such contraceptives at clinics that receive federal money under the Title X program, which focuses on low-income adults and teenagers. About eight million young women ages 15 to 19 sought birth control at the clinics from 2005 to 2013. At the beginning of the study period, just 0.4 percent, or about 4,000, were using long-term birth control. By 2013, the researchers reported, that had risen to 7 percent, or about 40,000 teenagers. Federal officials say that although long-acting birth control is by far the most effective method, its use among women over all still lags, and they are encouraging providers to take steps to increase the numbers.

title: Lawsuit Challenges U.S.D.A. Rule Change on Organic Farming
description: A coalition of grocers, seed growers and consumer and environmental advocates filed suit on Tuesday against the Department of Agriculture over a change it made to the process used to determine which substances may be used in organic farming.

title: Tumblr 497  505
description: Tumblr 497  505

title: Justified Recap: Then I Have Already Won
description: Season 6, Episode 12: Collateral

title: No Charges for Officer Who Killed Pace University Student in 2010
description: The Justice Department will not bring civil rights charges against a white police officer who fatally shot a black Pace University football player outside a Westchester County bar in 2010, the United States attorney in Manhattan announced on Tuesday.

title: As Rangers Return to Playoffs, Devils Again Exit Early
description: NEWARK  The Rangers and the Islanders are gearing up for the playoffs again. The Rangers, who clinched the Presidents Trophy for the best regular-season record on Tuesday, are intent on defending their crown as Eastern Conference champions. The Islanders are nearing their second postseason trip in three seasons.

title: Ferguson Elects 2 Blacks to City Council, but Rejects Activist Candidates
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  In the first municipal election here since a black teenager was shot to death by a white police officer last year, voters elected two black candidates to the City Council on Tuesday, increasing the number of African-Americans on the governing body to three.

title: Can I Hire Someone to Write My Rsum and Cover Letter?
description: The ethicists answer reader questions about job applications and whether hospitals should admit to making fatal mistakes.

title: SummerStage Expands Its Schedule, Beginning With a Concert by Tedeschi Trucks Band
description: SummerStage, the annual free concert series organized by the City Parks Foundation, will celebrate its 30th season this year with an expanded schedule, hosting more than 140 music, film, dance and theater events across the citys parks from May through October.

title: Visually Arresting Graphic Rugs That Value Asymmetry (So as Not to Compete With God)
description: The art director Alex Proba (of StudioProba, A Poster A Day and Kickstarter) and the rug and textile designer Aelfie Oudghiri (of Aelfie) are two of a kind  both create colorful, arrestingly graphic work; originally studied to be doctors in Europe; and are pillars of the collab-happy Brooklyn design community. And so one thing led to another, and a new series of limited-edition rugs and other decorative items, debuting Monday at Shop Cooper Hewitt, was born. The five rug styles ($1,675 each) and three pillow designs ($105 each), hand-dyed and -loomed in the Uttar Pradesh region of northern India, take cues from Kurdish weaving motifs and early Internet graphics, and feature hand-knotting techniques that make them look, Proba says, more 3D than they actually are. Many are asymmetrical, like the designs in Probas poster series: Thats one of the reasons I was excited about her work, because you have to work at looking at it, Oudghiri explains. Thats a huge tenet of rug weaving; you keep things asymmetrical as a form of humility because you dont want to compete with God. And for those who might be, as Proba puts it, afraid to commit to the high-impact textiles, the shop will also be selling posters ($155) of the original flat designs.

title: Iris van Herpens Intelligent Design
description: At a time when Silicon Valley is trying (and failing) to be fashionable, the Dutch designer is taking a different route  borrowing the discoveries of scientists, architects and even the military to create artistic pieces of great beauty.

title: Giving Out Private Data for Discount in Insurance
description: Andrew Thomass life insurer knows exactly when he arrives at his local gym. The company is notified when he swipes his membership card, and 30 minutes later, it checks that he is still there, tracking his location through his smartphone.

title: Wisconsin Re-elects Liberal Judge, but Opens Door for Conservative Chief Justice
description: In a result befitting politically polarized Wisconsin, voters on Tuesday re-elected a State Supreme Court justice seen as liberal, but passed a constitutional amendment that will most likely lead to the installation of a conservative chief justice.

title: How Chicagoans Voted and Why
description: An exit poll was conducted by Edison Research in 30 randomly selected Chicago electoral precincts. There were no supplemental interviews with early or absentee voters.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The exit poll was based on questionnaires completed by 1,497 voters on Tuesday as they left polling places throughout Chicago.

title: Whats On TV Wednesday
description: 8 P.M. (13, 49) ANIMAL HOMES In this three-part Nature special, the ecologist Chris Morgan evaluates and deconstructs various animal dwellings, from their materials and aesthetics to their neighborhoods and locations  and tries to build a few himself. He begins with the nest, works of art constructed  with just a beak  from fur, grasses, twigs, bones and spider silk as well as colorful twine, bits of wire and even plastic bags. After examining nests at the Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History, Mr. Morgan tours Connecticut, visiting ospreys in Greenwich and salt marsh sparrows in Madison, before returning to New Haven, where he subjects his own nest to a stress test. (A blueprint is above.)

title: Duke Welcomes Home Its Latest Champions
description: DURHAM, N.C.  About halfway through the 11-mile drive along Route 15-501 from Chapel Hill to Durham stands a green sign that welcomes drivers to Durham, or as it says, the city of champions. The sign, which features the Duke logo, bears reminders of national championships the Blue Devils have won, including the 2010 mens basketball title.

title: A Writer Whose Fan Mail Came From the Famous
description: Herbert Warren Wind turned some of the most iconic sportsmen and entertainers of the 20th century into writers, and many of their letters to him are at the Yale University Library.

title: Corrections: April 8, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day
description: When youre wrong, youre wrong. And if you make a bad decision, dont care if youre behind the shield or just a citizen on the street, you have to live by that decision.

title: Economic Disparity Is Seen in California Drivers License Suspensions
description: Drivers in California who are unable to pay traffic fines for minor infractions are frequently having their licenses suspended by traffic courts  a policy that has had a disproportionate impact on poor and working-class people, according to a study released Wednesday.

title: Elvis Is Everywhere
description: SNEAK PEEK: This week Lens is featuring a selection of photographers attending the New York Portfolio Review.

title: Royal Dutch Shell to Buy BG Group for Nearly $70 Billion
description: LONDON  Energy companies have spent months in a state of strategic paralysis, wary of making big moves with oil prices plunging.

title: U.S. Coal Leasing Program
description: To the Editor:

title: A Lawyers Personal Beliefs
description: To the Editor:

title: Better Health Coverage
description: To the Editor:

title: A View From Monsanto on Herbicide Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: McDonalds Turns Progressive
description: You could almost feel sorry for McDonalds. Thats an odd sentiment when you consider that the companys revenues in 2014 were $27.4 billion and its stock price makes it worth something like $92 billion. Its among the worlds most valuable brands and has three times the United States market share of Subway, its nearest competitor.

title: Dont Let Statistics Ruin Baseball
description: ONE of the charms of baseball, which started up again this week, is the exhilarating departure it offers from the noisy bustle of daily life. Come early for batting practice, have a scoring book ready to capture the game in pencil and lean back to take in the crisp musicality of a ball hit on the screws or track the near-perfect route a fleet outfielder takes to run down a fly ball in the gap. Baseball is a language unto itself, a language to be enjoyed and understood by any fan  at least until the talk turns to Babip, FIP and WAR.

title: Successful Investing for the Long Haul
description: For more than a month now, the White House has been vetting a proposal by the Labor Department that would require financial advisers to act solely in the interests of clients when giving advice on retirement accounts.

title: The California Drought: How to Adapt
Al Qaeda Is Capitalizing on Yemens Disorder, U.S. Warns
description: TOKYO  The new American defense secretary acknowledged Wednesday that Al Qaedas affiliate in Yemen had exploited the tumult partly created by the Saudi-led airstrikes there to capture territory, in what has become a broad expansion by the Sunni extremist group.

title: Ivy League Trailblazers
description: What is it like to be the first member of your family to go to college? First-generation college students must learn to deal with the privilege and the challenges.

title: To Become a Bridge
description: In 2013, Travis Reginal wrote an essay in Education Life about making his way from Jackson, Miss., to Yale, as a first-generation student. In his admissions essay, he had examined his love of writing poetry. He updates his journey, in his favorite format.

title: First-Generation Students Unite
description: Ana Barros grew up in a two-family house built by Habitat for Humanity, hard by the boarded-up buildings and vacant lots of Newark. Neither parent attended college, but she was a star student. With a 2200 on her SATs, she expected to fit in at Harvard.

title: Chicago Is Waiting to See if Runoff Battle Has Humbled Rahm Emanuel
description: CHICAGO  By some measure, everything ended just as it had begun. After an unexpected and unprecedented runoff election in the nations third-largest city, Chicagos brash mayor, Rahm Emanuel, was still Chicagos mayor.

title: Obama Takes His Hopes for Cuba to Summit Meeting
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas push for a historic opening with Cuba faces its first major test this week as he travels to a summit meeting in Latin America, where he hopes to highlight momentum toward ending a half-century of isolation from the island nation.

title: A Golf Writers Term, Forever: Amen
description: The whorl of wind will be easier to negotiate than the swirl of memories this week when Ben Crenshaw plays the 11th, 12th and 13th holes at the Masters for the final time in his fabled career.

title: A Section of the Berlin Wall Will Again Stand in Manhattan
description: A generation ago, in Berlin, citizens attacked the wall with sledgehammers. Today, in a New Jersey warehouse, conservators are reattaching flakes of paint to the wall with daubs of adhesive so tiny they must be applied by syringe.

title: For Eager Cubans, Big Opening in U.S. Relations Is More Like a Crack
description: HAVANA  With a castoff pizza oven churning out pies, Marialena Perez aspires to be the Dominos of Havana one day, with lofty dreams of a chain of stores, maybe even a branch in the United States.

title: T. C. Boyles The Harder They Come
description: The Harder They Come, T.C. Boyles 15th novel, takes on the paranoia of the far-right sovereign citizen movement and off-the-grid/mountain-man survivalism, as well as more mainstream American notions of independence. This could easily have been an opportunity for a writer of Boyles comic gifts to go full-tilt satirical, but Boyle takes a darker and more restrained approach. He has written a compelling, complex and intimate novel about three particular people in a specific time and place, a novel that tells us something unnerving about certain precincts of the American Now.

title: The Childrens Crusade, by Ann Packer
description: How do we become who we are? There are many ways of approaching this slipperiest of questions, from the experimental rigor of cognitive neuroscience to the teasing excavations of psychoanalysis. It is, of course, natural territory for the novel, and though Ann Packers The Childrens Crusade follows one nuclear family, its scope is broadened by its attempts at an answer.

title: Mothers Exercise May Lower Heart Risks in Newborns
description: Exercise in mice substantially lessens the risk that a pregnant mother-to-be will give birth to offspring with serious heart defects, according to a new study that could have implications for women who are or hope to become pregnant.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: For Male Politicians, Dieting Is a Campaign Issue
description: Is fat really an electoral issue?

title: New York Today: Whos That Tapping?
description: Good morning on this blustering Wednesday.

title: Palestinian Stabs 2 Israeli Soldiers and Is Killed
description: JERUSALEM  A Palestinian man stabbed two Israeli soldiers in the West Bank on Wednesday, seriously injuring one and lightly wounding the other, before being shot to death by security forces at the scene, according to the Israeli military.

title: Open Sesame
description: We sat eating dinner on a dark, cold night, talking soberly about what could possibly be in season when the soil had been frozen for so many months. My companion looked up in sudden knowledge.

title: Restaurant Report: Museum of Spirits in Stockholm
description: For seven years Petter Nilsson ran one of the most celebrated creative neo-bistros in Paris, La Gazzetta, tucked behind the Gare de Lyon. This Swedish expat brought the country to the city, as he put it recently, cooking in clay and hay before everyone else did, celebrating vegetables over proteins before that became a global trend, too. In late 2013, after more than a decade in France, he returned to Sweden.

title: A Warm Welcome in the Caucasus Mountains
description: The clotheslines that extended from balconies in Stepanakert showed an extraordinary degree of precision, if not obsession. In this city of 50,000, families had ordered the clothes from smallest to biggest: pink toddler socks gave way to slightly larger red and black ones for children and adults, then underwear (sorted by color), and finally a sequence of ever-larger shirts, hung upside down with sleeves outstretched, like an army of invisible superheroes swooping down from the sky.

title: Overruling My Father
description: When it came to offering medical interventions to severely ill patients with no hope of recovery, my father had a fiercely strong opinion: They were inappropriate. For decades as an infectious diseases specialist, he had been asked to treat infections in dying patients. Whenever possible, he said no.

title: Can I Hire Someone to Write My Rsum and Cover Letter?
description: Im looking for a new job in the nonprofit sector and am considering using a rsum service to write my rsum and cover letter. Part of me feels morally conflicted about this process. Is it fair to have someone else write the two materials that show the quality of my writing skills to my future employer? NAME WITHHELD, WASHINGTON

title: Will Infighting Help the Republicans in 2016?
description: For the first time in recent memory, key members of the corporate establishment, including businesses with close ties to the Republican Party, have publicly defied social conservatives in nationally publicized confrontations.

title: Hotel Review: Mitsui Garden Hotel Osaka Premier
description: From 11,500 Japanese yen (or $96 at 119 yen to the dollar).

title: Toni Morrison: I Know How to Write Forever
description: The Nobel laureate Toni Morrison, known for Song of Solomon and Beloved, died at 88. We interviewed her in 2015. Watch as she reads from her novel, God Help the Child.

title: The Radical Vision of Toni Morrison
description: Not too long ago, Toni Morrison sat in the small kitchen attached to the studio where she was recording the audiobook for her newest novel, God Help the Child, telling a roomful of strangers stories that I will never forget. The studio, a small, refurbished barn in Katonah, N.Y., was more than a hundred years old, but only a few rustic touches remained, like a sliding barn door and knotty pine floors. A solid kitchen table had been laid with fresh fruits, muffins and tins of jam. Beams of sunlight reflected off the blindingly white snow outside the glass window. A young woman from Random House kept mentioning her sunglasses, how it was bright enough to wear them inside. Everyone giggled at her nervous chatter, but they seemed to be mostly laughing at her brave attempt to make small talk in the presence of Toni Morrison.

title: Today in Politics: Obamas Trip to Panama Includes a Cuban Subplot
description: Good Wednesday morning from Washington, where a short-lived power failure briefly shut down the government. Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago gets to keep his job after a runoff, while Secretary of State John Kerry will meet with Jewish leaders to try and ease their concerns over a possible nuclear agreement with Iran. Representative Charles B. Rangel has recipe suggestions, and Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky hit the ground running after announcing his candidacy. President Obama begins a trip to Panama where he may or may not have a much-watched meeting with President Ral Castro of Cuba.

title: The Bull Rider
description: Growing up in the Netherlands, I was fascinated by the iconic Western movie cowboys, who lived an understated yet high-stakes existence against a spartan, other-worldly backdrop. Sure, much of this was a Hollywood fantasy, but the West truly was once the land of cowboys and Indians. Things changed pretty quickly. Instead of sprawling ranches dotted with quiet loner types, the landscape is now largely populated by homogeneous residential communities and big-box retailers.

title: The Bull Rider
description: This short documentary profiles the champion bull rider Gary Leffew, whose insights on rodeos apply far beyond the sport.

title: Private Profit, Public Gain?
Morning Agenda: Shell to Buy BG Group for Nearly $70 Billion
description: SHELL TO BUY BG GROUP FOR NEARLY $70 BILLION | Royal Dutch Shell said Wednesday that it had agreed to buy BG Group for nearly $70 billion,  Stanley Reed and Michael J. de la Merced write in DealBook. Shell said that it would pay for the acquisition with a mix of cash and stock and that its offer represented a 50 percent premium to BGs closing share price on Tuesday.

title: Rescue Mission in Yemen Proves to Be Boon for Chinese Militarys Image
description: Chinese military experts are engaging in a bit of exuberant backslapping over the naval evacuation not just of more than 600 Chinese citizens in Yemen, but of hundreds of other foreigners. It was the first time China had deployed warships to carry out such an evacuation, and the fact that so many people from other countries were welcomed on board and ferried to safety was seen as polishing the countrys image as a helpful hand in an international crisis.

title: Our Push for Passion, and Why It Harms Kids
description: Standing on the sidelines of my sons soccer game I chatted with the younger sibling of one of his teammates. I dont really have a passion like my brother yet, he explained, glancing over at the field. But my parents are helping me look for one. I waited for the note of irony that never came.

title: Peter Sarsgaard as Hamlet at Classic Stage
description: Shakespeare wrote many great roles, but few, if any, rival Hamlet and King Lear in terms of complexity (and potential glory). Both roles offer meaty challenges for actors, and it is practically a rite of passage to assay at least one of them in the course of a career that includes the classics.

title: Apple Watch Review: Bliss, but Only After a Steep Learning Curve
description: It took three days  three long, often confusing and frustrating days  for me to fall for the Apple Watch. But once I fell, I fell hard.

title: Dear Diary: My Week Wearing an Apple Watch
description: I picked up my Apple Watch last Wednesday at Apple headquarters in Cupertino, Calif. After interviewing some of the designers and engineers who worked on the device, I was given a guided tour of the watch, similar to what customers will receive when they buy one at an Apple Store.

title: Can the Apple Watch Free Us From Phones?
description: The technology columnist Farhad Manjoo asks whether the Apple Watchs new taptic engine will give us an alternative to constantly checking our phones.

title: Labco, FrenchMedical Diagnostics Firm, Files for I.P.O.
description: LONDON  Labco, a French medical diagnostics firm, said on Wednesday that it had filed to pursue an initial public offering in Paris in the first half of this year.

title: Oyster to Sell E-Books Alongside Its Subscription Service
description: The e-book subscription service Oyster is starting its own digital bookstore, taking aim at major retailers like Amazon, Apple and Barnes & Noble as well as rival subscription services.

title: Daily Report: Apple Watch Bliss Comes With Steep Learning Curve
description: It took three days  three long, often confusing and frustrating days  for him to fall for the Apple Watch. But once he fell, he fell hard, Farhad Manjoo writes.

title: BB and the Permahawks
description: Ben Bernanke comes down firmly against the idea that concerns about financial instability should lead central banks to raise interest rates even in a depressed economy. Good  and I was especially pleased to see him citing the Swedish example and the Ignoring of Lars Svensson as a case study.

title: Putin Meets With Alexis Tsipras of Greece, Raising Eyebrows in Europe
description: MOSCOW  With Russia and Greece at odds with Europe, this weeks visit from the Greek prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, could not have come at a better time, President Vladimir V. Putin said Wednesday.

title: Pacers Chris Copeland and 2 Women Are Stabbed Outside Manhattan Club
description: A former New York Knicks forward who now plays for the Indiana Pacers was stabbed in the abdomen during an argument early Wednesday outside a club in Manhattan, the authorities said.

title: Eye to Eye With a Hawk
description: Dear Diary:

title: 5 Womens Rights Activists in China Are Being Held Illegally, Lawyers Say
description: BEIJING  Five womens rights activists are being held illegally in Beijing because the police have failed to ask prosecutors to formally arrest them, the lawyers for three of them said on Wednesday.

title: C.I.A. Director Says Irans Economic Peril Helped Drive Nuclear Deal
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  The director of the Central Intelligence Agency has provided the first public glimpse of American intelligence assessments about why Irans leadership agreed to the tentative nuclear accord last week, saying that Irans president persuaded its supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, that their countrys economy was destined to go down unless he reached an understanding with the West.

title: Fashion World Mourns Maria Luisa Poumaillou
description: Before there was Colette or Kirna Zabete, before Fivestory or Merci, before most of the other so-called concept stores became shopping destinations from New York to Shanghai, there was Maria Luisa, a boutique on the Rue Cambon in Paris whose concept was simple: buy and showcase whatever is different and attracts my eye, by talent that is out of the ordinary and by what is long lasting, its co-founder, Maria Luisa Poumaillou, told The Business of Fashion in 2013.

title: Sugar Hill, Rich in Culture, and Affordable
description: The section of Upper Manhattan known as Sugar Hill, poised on a bluff overlooking the Harlem Plain and distinguished by graceful rowhouses and elegant apartment buildings, achieved renown in the 1930s and 1940s, when it was home to prominent African-American professionals, political leaders, artists, musicians and writers. The song Take the A Train, written by Billy Strayhorn and popularized by Duke Ellington, commemorated the neighborhood, where both lived. Nowadays, though, some newcomers say they had not heard the name Sugar Hill before they arrived.

title: Quotas Not the Best Way to Add and Retain Women for Corporate Boards, Study Finds
description: It has been an age-old question: Are quotas the best way of getting more women on boards and keeping them there?

title: Slovakia to Sell Stake in Slovak Telecom Through I.P.O.
description: LONDON  Slovak Telekom said on Wednesday that the government of Slovakia planned to sell its 49 percent stake in the company through an initial public offering.

title: Studio Visit | Iris van Herpen
description: The wildly inventive fashion designer Iris van Herpen brings T into her Amsterdam studio, where technology meets fashion.

title: If We Dig Out All Our Fossil Fuels, Heres How Hot We Can Expect It to Get
description: World leaders are once again racing to avert disastrous levels of global warming through limits on greenhouse gas emissions. An agreement may be in reach, but because of the vast supplies of inexpensive fossil fuels, protecting the world from climate change requires the even more difficult task of disrupting todays energy markets.

title: Iraq Starts Drive Against ISIS, but Reports on Scale Differ
description: BAGHDAD  The Iraqi Army and militia forces carried out an attack against the Islamic State outside the city of Ramadi on Wednesday, with some local officials claiming it was the beginning of a major offensive in western Anbar Province, though others said that was premature.

title: $900,000 Homes in Seattle, Florida and Pennsylvania
description: SEATTLE

title: Make Minestrone Soup Without a Recipe
description: Kenzi Wilbur and Sarah Jampel of Food52 show you how to make minestrone soup without a recipe.

title: House Hunting in ... England
description: AN EIGHT-BEDROOM VICTORIAN HOUSE IN HERTFORDSHIRE

title: Easy Toppings for Fast Weeknight Pizza
description: Over in the Food section, Suzanne Lenzer has a recipe for easy, fast pizza dough: the kind of artisanal crust you want in as little time and with as little effort as possible. Her crust mixes up in the food processor, rises only briefly and then awaits your toppings in the freezer (pull it out in the morning for an evening meal) or fridge.

title: Fun Home, the Musical, Takes Alison Bechdels Life to Broadway
description: BURLINGTON, VT.  The gender studies students sat in a circle, just beneath a periodic-table poster, and, bashful or bored, ran out of questions before class was over.

title: Mostly Mozart, With Some 21st-Century Sounds Too
description: It may be the Mostly Mozart Festival, but this season it will also have some George Benjamin, who will be the festivals composer-in-residence.

title: Reaction to Walter L. Scott Shooting
description: Family members of Walter L. Scott, a black man shot to death by a white South Carolina police officer, reacted after the mayor of North Charleston said the officer would be charged with murder.

title: A Mother Fights to End Violence in Honor of Her Slain Son
description: On my second day in New York in August 2008, I wound up in Harlem after a wayward subway ride. I saw elderly people dancing in the street. I joined their dance and learned they were members of the Frederick E. Samuel Community Democratic Club so I decided to join the club. I attended its meetings and grew increasingly interested in the clubs discussions, as I come from Serbia, a country where democracy was relatively new.

title: Debt Talks Begin With Russia and Greece
description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece met with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Wednesday to discuss ways to increase economic cooperation between the two countries.

title: Mayor Rahm Emanuel Makes Nice as He Finally Holds Off Challenger
description: As Mayor Rahm Emanuel took the stage at a Chicago union hall on Tuesday night to declare victory in a re-election fight that had threatened his political future, he sounded uncharacteristically contrite. He said he had gotten a second chance. He said he was humbled. He said he heard what his city was telling him.

title: Household Bleach Tied to Respiratory Illness in Children
description: Cleaning with bleach at home is associated with higher rates of respiratory illness in children, a new report has found.

title: QualifyingRules Keep Masters Field Small and Distinctive
description: It is a field unlike any other.

title: 1965: Pope Aims to Win Over Atheists
description: VATICAN CITY  Pope Paul VI, who has engaged the Catholic Church in dialogue with separated Christians and non- Christian religions, today [April 8] went a step further by setting up an office to talk with atheists.

title: Officer Who Killed Walter Scott Is Fired, and Police Chief Denounces Shooting
description: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C.  The police officer who was arrested on Tuesday after shooting and killing an unarmed black man has been fired from the department and the police chief here said Wednesday that he was appalled by what a video of the encounter revealed.

title: Rand Paul Questions the Today Show Questions
description: Barely a day into his presidential campaign, and only a couple of months after a testy exchange with another reporter, Senator Rand Paul is facing more criticism for his brusque tone with a television interviewer.

title: Online Lenders Offer a Faster Lifeline for Small Businesses
description: Yaniv Liron has pulled cash and credit from every available source to keep his 11-year-old web design and development business, Lumina, running smoothly  a situation familiar to many small-business owners.

title: Rand Pauls Online Blunders
description: The Interwebs have been having a lot of fun at Rand Pauls expense since the senator from Kentucky announced his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination.

title: Love and Loss
description: In childrens books, parental love can be a surprisingly hot-potato subject. If a parents emotions seem somehow too enormous and complex, a book about endless devotion can end up striking many as unsettling rather than reassuring. Take the latest round of debate over Shel Silversteins classic The Giving Tree. Is the books depiction of all-in maternal self-sacrifice beautiful, or disturbing and patriarchal? Impassioned arguments persist on both sides. That split recalls similar objections to Robert Munschs Love You Forever, first published in 1986, which features a new mother rocking her baby and singing a little song that ends, As long as Im living / my baby youll be. She repeats the song as she snuggles up to her child through his childhood and teenage years, and even when he is a grown man. Some see in the tale a straightforward, reassuring depiction of the boundlessness of a parents love. Others think its just too smothering and creepy, especially the way the woman crawls into her adult sons bed.

title: U.S. Coalition Service Member Killed in Afghanistan Shooting
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A service member with the American-led coalition in Afghanistan was killed Wednesday during an attack in the eastern city of Jalalabad.

title: Dirty Work
description: The dwindling prospects of Europes coal miners.

title: Boston Marathon Jury Goes Into Second Day of Deliberations on Dzhokhar Tsarnaev
description: BOSTON  Deliberations in the capital-murder trial of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, accused in the 2013 bombing at the Boston Marathon, went into a second day on Wednesday at Federal District Court here, as jurors weighed 30 counts against him, including 17 that could lead to the death penalty in a later phase of the trial.

title: Legal Conflicts on Medical Marijuana Ensnare Hundreds as Courts Debate a New Provision
description: BLOOMFIELD, N.M.  Charles C. Lynch seemed to be doing everything right when he opened a medical marijuana dispensary in the tidy coastal town of Morro Bay, Calif.

title: App Smart | Trivia Game Fun
description: There are lots of trivia games for the smartphone and many have social media features that allow you to play against friends or strangers.

title: Video Feature: Take On the World With Trivia Game Apps
description: WHEN Im out with friends I sometimes challenge them with a few trivia questions for fun. But plenty of trivia quiz smartphone apps can do a much better job than I do, and they have social media features too.

title: Making Hollandaise Sauce
description: Learn how to make the rich sauce that is served with Eggs Benedict.

title: Reviewing Your Corporate Life in Real Time
description: A long-anticipated product from a showman of business technology  and who runs a company now valued in the billions  made its official debut on Wednesday. The products ambitions, and weaknesses, say much about the current state of a fast-changing market.

title: Marine Le Pen, Leader of Frances National Front Party, Splits With Her Father, Its Founder
description: PARIS  Marine Le Pen, the head of Frances far-right National Front, has openly split with her father and the founder of her party, calling his recent comments, including those on German gas chambers, political suicide and an attempt to harm her.

title: Mylan Offers to Acquire Perrigo for $29 Billion
description: As the pharmaceutical industry continues to consolidate, even companies once considered stable stalwarts are scrambling to strike deals.

title: Neil MacGregor, Director of British Museum, Is Stepping Down
description: LONDON  Neil MacGregor will retire as director of the British Museum at the end of December, the museum announced Wednesday.

title: College Hockey Embraces Its Role as the Marathoner of Winter Sports
description: When Nebraska-Omaha and Providence open the mens Frozen Four on Thursday afternoon at TD Garden in Boston, it will be three days after the N.C.A.A mens basketball championship game and four days after opening night in Major League Baseball, as well as the first day of the Masters.

title: Bank of America Names New Investment Banking Heads
description: Bank of America has shifted the leadership of its global investment bank, naming Karim Assef and Diego De Giorgi as its co-heads, according to an internal memorandum sent on Wednesday.

title: Piling Sand in a Disputed Sea, China Literally Gains Ground
description: WASHINGTON  The clusters of Chinese vessels busily dredge white sand and pump it onto partly submerged coral, aptly named Mischief Reef, transforming it into an island.

title: 1940: Five Red Leaders Arrested in Paris
description: Details of the methods used in tracking down and arresting the general staff of the Communist party in north Paris were revealed by the Prefecture of Police in Paris last night [April 7].Four men and a woman, described as the propaganda and organization leaders of the Communist organization, were trapped Friday night while meeting in a caf in the rue de Maubeuge, police reported. To obtain conclusive evidence of the exchange of funds earmarked for Communist work and to link the group with the communist International, police allowed the unsuspecting group to discuss its plans at length before making the arrest, the Prefecture said.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 9, 1940

title: Rights Advocates in India Call for Inquiry Into Killing of Loggers
description: NEW DELHI  Human rights advocates in India on Wednesday called for an investigation into the deaths a day earlier of 20 loggers in a raid on what the police said was an illegal operation in the state of Andhra Pradesh to cut and sell endangered red sandalwood trees.

title: Lessons in Journalism, From Rand Paul
description: Senator Rand Paul sees a bit of a gotcha game going on with some journalists who cover him.

title: Silicon Valley Not So Friendly to Families: Reporters Notebook
description: When I was reporting a story on paternity leave last year, I kept hearing something surprising. I assumed that Silicon Valley offered generous parental leaves, and it does. But in my interviews with tech workers, I also kept hearing something else  that Silicon Valley was a really difficult place to be a parent.

title: F.C.C. Fines AT&T $25 Million for Privacy Breach
description: The Federal Communications Commission fined AT&T $25 million for failing to protect the personal information, including Social Security numbers, of its customers, the agency said on Wednesday. The penalty is the largest the F.C.C. has ever issued for data security and privacy violations.

title: Swedish Company Asks F.D.A. to Remove Warnings From Smokeless Tobacco Product
description: WASHINGTON  For 50 years now, all tobacco products sold in the United States have had to display warnings about the health risks they carry.

title: 2 New Ebola Vaccines Pass Important Early Test, Researchers Say
description: Two new Ebola vaccines have passed an important test, protecting monkeys against the strain of the virus responsible for the current deadly outbreak, researchers reported on Wednesday. Only one dose was needed, and there were no apparent side effects.

title: Pesticides Linked to Honeybee Deaths Pose More Risks, European Group Says
description: PARIS  An influential European scientific body said on Wednesday that a group of pesticides believed to contribute to mass deaths of honeybees is probably more damaging to ecosystems than previously thought and questioned whether the substances had a place in sustainable agriculture.

title: Maya Lin to Lead Redesign of Smith College Library
description: The artist Maya Lin, best known for her work on the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, has been chosen to lead the redesign of the Smith College library, a historic structure built in 1909 that has been added to three times over the years.

title: Judge Refuses to Let Obamas Executive Actions on Immigration Proceed
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge in Texas on Tuesday angrily denied the federal governments request to allow President Obamas immigration executive actions to proceed, even as an appeals court signaled that it might disagree with the judge when it takes up the issue next week.

title: Sex Education in Europe Turns to Urging More Births
description: COPENHAGEN  Twenty-five Danish 13- and 14-year-olds gathered in a circle to talk about sex. This was going to be awkward.

title: Judge Drops 2 Terror Attacks From Arab Bank Case
description: A federal judge in Brooklyn on Wednesday largely upheld a jury verdict that found a Middle Eastern bank liable for 24 terrorist attacks, but agreed to drop two of those attacks from the verdict.

title: Quebec Music Festival Will Feature Foo Fighters, Keith Urban and Iggy Azalea
description: The Festival dt de Qubec, an 11-day citywide event, will run from July 9 to 19 and feature performances by Foo Fighters, Keith Urban, Iggy Azalea and the Rolling Stones  on the final date of the Stones summer tour  organizers announced on Wednesday.

title: Dzhokhar Tsarnaev Is Guilty on All 30 Counts in Boston Marathon Bombing
description: BOSTON  In the silent well of Courtroom Nine, a clerk read out the jurys verdicts: Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. The word echoed in the courtroom as the clerk pronounced it 30 times, once for each of 30 main counts.

title: Scant Data Frustrates Efforts to Assess Number of Shootings by Police
description: WASHINGTON  The murder  charges filed on Tuesday against a white police officer shown in a video  shooting and killing an apparently unarmed black man as he fled have raised a question about policing that not even the Justice Department can answer: How often do officers across the country fire their weapons?

title: DiCaprio Just the Latest Celebrity to Join the Hotel Business
description: The actor Leonardo DiCaprio recently announced his plans to build an eco-resort on private Blackadore Caye in Belize, a property expected to open in 2018. But hes far from the first celebrity to enter the hospitality game. He joins a cadre of fellow actors, musicians and athletes, including the 11 below, who have broadened their portfolios (and their brands) with properties around the world.

title: Years After Fleeing the Taliban, a Player Hopes to Lift a U.S. Womens League
description: BRICK, N.J.  Nadia Nadim did not know soccer was for her until she was about 12. This was after her father had been executed by the Taliban, after she and her mother and her sisters had fled their native Afghanistan, after the trip through the dark in the smugglers truck.

title: Decision on Arab Bank
description: A federal judge on Wednesday dropped two of the 24 terrorist attacks that a jury found Jordan-based Arab Bank liable for by granting a motion by the bank that argued the plaintiffs had not sufficiently demonstrated that the terrorist group Hamas had committed the attacks.

title: Fed Policy Makers Seem Cool to Rate Increase in June
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve is looking increasingly unlikely to start raising its benchmark interest rate in June.

title: Quiz: For Athletes in New York, Some Bad Nights Out
description: New Yorks nightlife scene has seen plenty of fracases over the years involving pro athletes. Can you identify the sports figure who participated (allegedly, in some cases) in each of these?

title: 36 Hours in Antigua, Guatemala
description: In Antigua, Guatemala, visitors can browse markets, sip espresso at a working coffee farm, eat regional food and hike up volcanoes.

title: 36 Hours in Antigua, Guatemala
description: Explore street view, find things to do in Antigua, Guatemala, and sign in to your Google account to save your map.

title: 36 Hours in Antigua, Guatemala
description: Less than an hour away from the concrete sprawl of Guatemala City, Antigua feels like a portal to another century. The nearly 500-year-old city is cradled by three volcanoes and filled with colonial-era mansions, churches and convents, many with orange and yellow facades. In the evening, residents gather in the jacaranda-lined plazas to listen to musicians tapping mallets on marimbas, or wander between lively night spots. Once the capital of this Central American country (before a series of devastating earthquakes forced the colonial government to move to Guatemala City in the late 1700s), Antigua, population 41,000, is a Unesco World Heritage site. Yet in addition to the striking 17th- and 18th-century ruins right in the center of town, the city offers an array of restaurants, boutiques and bars with live music. Visitors can browse the craft markets or sip an espresso at a working coffee farm, while those with a more adventurous streak can hike up one of the looming volcanoes, or strap on a helmet, lock in a carabiner and hurtle through the rain forest on a zip wire.

title: In South Carolina, Shot in the Back as He Ran
description: I am truly weary, deep in my bones, of writing these columns about the killings of unarmed people of color by the police. Indeed, you may be weary of reading them. Still, our weariness is but a dim shadow that falls near the darkness of despair that a family is thrust into when a child or parent or sibling is lost, and that family must wonder if the use of deadly force was appropriate and whether justice will be served.

title: Robert Durst Indicted on Gun Charges in New Orleans
description: Robert A. Durst, the estranged member of a prominent Manhattan real estate family, will not be going to Los Angeles anytime soon to face murder charges.

title: In Unfriended, Horror Unfolds on a Desktop Screen
description: A Google search or an iMessage may seem an unlikely source of dramatic tension for a movie. But the new horror thriller Unfriended, opening April 17, takes these routine actions in our daily digital lives and turns them into moments of fear and dread. Its one in a recent spate of horror movies playing out on computer screens that might be likened to the found-footage horror genre that The Blair Witch Project started in 1999. But now the frights rely on an active Skype account and a strong Wi-Fi signal.

title: The Whistleblower, Gone But Not Quite Forgotten
description: When the news-addicted satirist John Oliver interviewed Edward Snowden in Moscow, where the national security whistleblower waits in exile, he had some fun showing interviews of people in Times Square who were clueless about who Mr. Snowden was.

title: Rick Reed and Chris LaCivita, Partners in 2004, Now Work Different Sides of Campaign Fence
description: In the 2004 presidential campaign, the Republican strategists Rick Reed and Christopher J. LaCivita worked together on Swift Boat Veterans for Truth, the group of Vietnam veterans that ran scathing attack ads questioning the military record of the Democratic nominee, John Kerry.

title: Representative Lois Capps Announces Retirement
description: Representative Lois Capps, a California Democrat who has represented the Santa Barbara area in Congress since succeeding her husband in 1998, announced Wednesday that she would not seek re-election next year.

title: Woman Smothered Son, 1, in Manhattan Restroom, Prosecutors Say
description: Prosecutors say the mentally ill woman who was found last month in the restroom of a Manhattan restaurant with her unconscious son had used her bare hands to smother the 1-year-old.

title: Review: Jo Nesbo, in Blood on Snow, Tries a New Kind of Hero
description: Jo Nesbos Harry Hole novels have established him as perhaps the noirest of Scandinavias current wave of noir writers. Harry is, as Mr. Nesbo has noted, a kind of black hole, where everything is kind of pulled in, and nothing escapes. A brilliant Oslo police detective, Harry is also a troubled lone wolf who has a lot in common with the criminals he pursues.

title: UConn Sees Lone Loss as Turning Point in a Championship Season
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Had the Connecticut womens basketball team initially listened to Coach Geno Auriemma when practices began in October, the Huskies may have very well ended this season on an 84-game winning streak dating to 2013.

title: A Muse for Bill Cunningham
description: Out and about in New York.

title: Johnny Jewel Shines a Light on Chromatics (and Scoring Films with Ryan Gosling)
description: Johnny Jewel, the mastermind behind the spatial electronic quartet Chromatics, is the first to admit that he isnt a real musician. Its a strange dismissal, given that the group  which comprises Jewel, the vocalist Ruth Radelet, the guitarist Adam Miller and the drummer Nat Walker  has helped usher in a contemporary resurgence of noir-seeped 70s disco. Whats more, Jewel recently composed the atmospheric score for Lost River, the directorial debut of his friend, the actor Ryan Gosling.

title: Frank Huang to Succeed Glenn Dicterow as New York Philharmonic Concertmaster
description: Filling the chair that for 34 seasons was occupied by Glenn Dicterow, its longest-serving concertmaster, the New York Philharmonic on Wednesday announced the appointment of Frank Huang, currently concertmaster of the Houston Symphony.

title: U.S. Deports Salvadoran General Accused in 80s Killings
description: After a 16-year legal battle, a former defense minister of El Salvador once embraced by Washington as a close ally during the civil war there in the 1980s, was deported on Wednesday after immigration courts found that he had participated in torture and killings by troops under his command.

title: In Paris, Revisiting the Aesthetic Shock of Antonioni
description: An exhibition and retrospective celebrate the filmmaker  and offer some context for his groundbreaking work.

title: Turkeys Online Censorship
description: The Turkish governments unrelenting crackdown on free speech continues unabated. On Tuesday, Google narrowly avoided being banned in the country after it complied with a court order to remove links to a photograph showing militants holding a gun to the head of a prosecutor.

title: A Rich Day for Banks Advising on Big Merger Deals
description: On one day alone, Goldman Sachs has helped shepherd roughly $100 billion worth of merger deals.

title: Chris Christie and the Lane Closings: A Spectators Guide
description: Here is a guide to key players and issues to watch.

title: The Met Breuer Heralds a New Season in the Whitney Museums Former Home
description: After months of guessing and contests on Facebook, are you ready for The Met Breuer?

title: Mark Pincus, Zyngas Founder, Returns as C.E.O.
description: When Mark Pincus hired a new executive to run Zynga, the online game company he founded, he wrote on Twitter, calling the executive, Don Mattrick, an Internet treasure.

title: Vivendi, Under Pressure From Hedge Fund, Increases Payout
description: Vivendi, the French media conglomerate, said on Wednesday that it planned to raise the amount of money it will pay to shareholders, settling a fight with the American hedge fund P. Schoenfeld Asset Management.

title: Behind the Poster: Switzerland
description: In Joanna Murray-Smiths play Switzerland, the American writer Patricia Highsmith (played by Laura Linney) is near the end of her life. Shes living in self-imposed exile in the Locarno district of Switzerland, having already achieved acclaim for her novels Strangers on a Train and The Talented Mr. Ripley. One day an assistant (Seth Numrich) from the office of her New York publisher shows up at her front door and tries to persuade her to write another Ripley book. She being an eccentric novelist obsessed by tales of sociopaths and murder, and he being a stranger with possibly shady intentions, tension builds fast in the weapon-filled room where the show is set.

title: After a Quarter-Century of Legal Wrangling in India, a Rock Opera Can Go On
description: NEW DELHI  In most cases, temporary can mean days, weeks, even months. But for one district of Kerala, a state in southern India, it meant a quarter-century.

title: Sharing Soda With the Shabab: Reporters Notebook
description: I first met the Shabab militant group in 2006, when they were operating in the open.

title: Being a Night Owl May Be Bad for Your Health
description: A new study suggests that early to bed and early to rise makes a man healthy  although not necessarily wealthy or wise.

title: American and US Airways Get Single Operating Certificate, Advancing Integration
description: American Airlines and US Airways received their single operating certificate from the Federal Aviation Administration on Wednesday, an important step in the integration of the two airlines.

title: Fatal Police Shootings: Accounts Since Ferguson
description: A selection of police shootings that have been reported by news organizations since Michael Browns death in Ferguson, Mo., in August.

title: Shell Poised to Win in Deal for BG
description: Royal Dutch Shell sat out previous waves of energy consolidation. Now Shell, a British-Dutch company, has struck the first megadeal of the latest oil rout. Paying $70 billion for the smaller, gas-focused rival BG looks like a smart and opportunistic way to increase growth.

title: HBO Now Makes Game of Thrones Easier to See, if Not Follow
description: THE popular television show Game of Thrones has become harder to follow, with all the characters that come and go. But it has also become much easier to watch online.

title: Rand Paul Tangles With Democrats Over Abortion Rights
description: Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky maintained his aggressive approach to fielding tough questions on Wednesday, suggesting that the chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee should have to say when it was permissible to kill a seven-pound baby in the uterus before he would discuss when abortions should be allowed.

title: Wales Album Inspired by Seinfeld Is No. 1
description: A rap album inspired by the TV show Seinfeld  and featuring Jerry Seinfeld himself  has opened at No. 1 on Billboards chart.

title: Seeing Path to Justice in Video of Shooting on Bystanders Phone
description: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C.  It was at a vigil Sunday for his slain brother that Anthony Scott found out what he had believed was true all along.

title: In Paris, Revisiting the Aesthetic Shock of Antonioni
description: Antonioni Was Here, announces a Julian Schnabel painting at the entrance of the exhibition Antonioni: Aux Origines du Pop, which runs tomorrow through July 19 at La Cinmathque Franaise. Indeed, the iconic filmmaker left an indelible mark. He was an explorer, an inventor, a man in perpetual inquitude regarding the cinematographic form, remarks Serge Toubiana, the director of the Cinmathque, which is also hosting a complete filmic retrospective running through May 31. Toubiana cites the sense of narrative shock, aesthetic shock Antonioni brought to cinema  whether featuring a fashion photographer modeled on David Bailey in the swinging London of Blow Up or casting the exquisite Monica Vitti in a trio of films (LAvventura, La Notte, LEclisse) about indefinable human malaise. Although never quite celebrated or completely understood in his native Italy, he won accolades internationally, some of which are displayed in the exhibition, including a Palme dOr from 1967, and an honorary Oscar from 1995 (represented by a mislabeled replica, as the original was stolen during a burglary).

title: Victims Brother Speaks About Shooting
description: Anthony Scott, whose brother Walter L. Scott was killed by a police officer in North Charleston, S.C., on Saturday, talked about the shooting in an interview with The Associated Press.

title: Indictments May Be Near in George Washington Bridge Scandal
description: It has been falsely predicted many times in the last year, but now it seems to be true: The federal investigation into the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge appears to be coming to a head, with an announcement of indictments as early as next week.

title: Two Recipes From Tracy K. Smiths Kitchen
description: After the poet Tracy K. Smith appeared in this weeks Close at Hand column, many readers inquired about two recipes that were mentioned: poundcake and Alabama lemon cheese cake. One reader went so far as to call the omission of a recipe absolutely criminal.

title: Catherine Masto, Ex-Attorney General in Nevada, Announces Bid to Succeed Harry Reid
description: The race to succeed Senator Harry Reid in Nevada has its first candidate.

title: Review: In Staatsopers Elektra, an Ax-Wielder With Royal Bearing
description: VIENNA  Most sopranos in the demanding title role of Strausss Elektra go heavy on the oil-stick makeup. The character ends up looking like a wild-eyed, wild-wigged vagrant in a soiled overcoat, with harsh high notes to match.

title: For Some Teenagers, 16 Candles Mean Its Time to Join Uber
description: For generations of American teenagers, obtaining a drivers license was a rite of passage. But when Jonathan Golden, a scruffy-haired high schooler who lives in Santa Monica, Calif., turned 16 in November, he couldnt be bothered with the bureaucracy of the Department of Motor Vehicles.

title: Shorter Stature May Pose Higher Risk of Heart Disease
description: To the surprise of researchers who had thought the very notion a joke, an international consortium of investigators reported on Wednesday that shorter stature increases the risk of heart disease.

title: Review: Resident Advisors Brings Playground Humor to the Dorms
description: Hulu announced on Tuesday that its big-deal series 11/22/63, based on the Stephen King novel about the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, had added Chris Cooper and Cherry Jones to its cast. Thats good stuff  Netflix- or Amazon Prime-level stuff.

title: White House Uses Twitter to Take a Poke at Netanyahu
description: Is the White House trolling Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to sell the nuclear framework deal with Iran?

title: Former F.B.I. Agent Sues, Claiming Retaliation Over Misgivings in Anthrax Case
description: WASHINGTON  When Bruce E. Ivins, an Army microbiologist, took a fatal overdose of Tylenol in 2008, the government declared that he had been responsible for the anthrax letter attacks of 2001, which killed five people and set off a nationwide panic, and closed the case.

title: Familiar Victors at the Jacoby Swiss Teams
description: Theres nothing quite like a team on a hot streak.

title: Review: Eliane Elias Honors Generations of Brazilian Composers at Birdland
description: Eliane Elias breezed into Birdland on Tuesday on the heels of a lush new album, Made in Brazil, which reaffirms the South American roots of this singer, songwriter, pianist and arranger, who was born in So Paulo but has lived in the United States since 1981. Recorded in So Paulo, this appealing album is her first made in Brazil since moving to the States, though seven cuts include strings that were recorded in London. A mixture of aural dreaminess and percussive drive gives Ms. Eliass natural friskiness a soft focus. It might be described as make-out music with a beat.

title: Looking Ahead to Photos of Old Age
description: Shaken by his parents deaths, Phil Toledano confronted his anxiety by making a series of pictures that show him beset by various frailties.

title: Postal Service Wont Reissue Maya Angelou Stamp
description: WASHINGTON  The Postal Service said Wednesday that it had no plans to reissue a stamp honoring Maya Angelou that features a quotation from a book by another author.

title: A Police Shooting in South Carolina, Caught on Video
Will the Apple Watch Make Us Happier?
description: The Apple Watch promises to make users lives better in a number of ways, from helping them stay on schedule to tracking their physical activity. But early reviews of the product suggest another possible improvement: It might get us to quit staring at our phones.

title: Courtney Love, Devendra Banhart, Amy Poehler and More Celebrate Allen Ginsbergs Howl in L.A.
description: The event, an evening of music, verse and funny people, was put together by the music producer Hal Willner.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Pictures of the Day: Singapore and Elsewhere
description: Singapore and More  Pictures of the Day

title: April 8, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Singapore, Iraq, Kenya and Sudan.

title: Review: Stephen Petronios Bloodlines
description: The history of the leading figures of American modern dance can sound like lines from the Book of Genesis. Senior choreographers nurtured company dancers who in due course became choreographers in their own right. To adapt the King James Version, Ruth St. Denis and Ted Shawn begat Doris Humphrey and Martha Graham; Humphrey begat Jos Limn while Graham begat Merce Cunningham and Paul Taylor; Mr. Taylor begat Twyla Tharp. ...

title: HowAmal Clooney Took New York
description: At 10:30 a.m. on Monday, Amal Clooney walked into Classroom 103 in William and June Warren Hall at Columbia Law School. The human rights lawyer and wife of the actor George Clooney was dressed in a cream textured coat and floral Oscar de la Renta slingbacks and carried a tangerine bag the size of a large toaster.

title: International Pop
description: A look at the exhibition opening on Saturday at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis.

title: When the World Went Pop
description: MINNEAPOLIS  For art lovers, and certainly for the collectors now paying tens of millions of dollars per painting at auction, Pop art and its trademark images  Marilyns, Ben-Day dots, Coca-Cola bottles, lipsticked lips  have become 20th century classicism, as canonical as Cubism and as appealing as candy.

title: Portraits of People and Paper
description: Fascinated by a classmates braid, Patricia Voulgaris started doing pictures that were a mix of body parts, folded paper and collage.

title: Review: In Daredevil, a Superhero Is Sightless but Not Blind to Crime
description: I admit the possibility that I have unfair expectations for the new Netflix series Marvels Daredevil, 13 episodes of which will be available to stream on Friday.

title: Outerwear for Spring, Dresses for an Evolving Day and More Style News
description: Semitransparent raincoats, effortless designs, an eyewear line from Acne and a crocheted bag.

title: In China, a Climate of Mistrust in Medicine
description: Chinese patients are fed up with their doctors, and doctors are fed up with their patients.

title: At the New Whitney Museum, the Party Has Already Begun
description: Scaffolding was everywhere, the art had not fully been hung, and opening night was a month away. But that didnt stop more than 100 guests, including artists, socialites and fashion designers, from walking past construction materials stacked under blankets and orange cones to attend a private preopening dinner at the Whitney Museum of American Art last Thursday.

title: On Waxahatchees Ivy Tripp, Katie Crutchfield Sings of Emotional Debris
description: Not all wounds scab. Sometimes they remain red, raw, gaping. Sometimes, after a while, the wound is the thing. If it healed, it wouldnt feel real.

title: Courtney Love, Devendra Banhart, Amy Poehler and More Celebrate Allen Ginsbergs Howl in L.A.
description: As the man who produced one of Allen Ginsbergs last recorded works  and who virtually invented the tribute album as standalone art form  the record producer (and current music producer of Saturday Night Live) Hal Willner was truly the only person who could have put together last nights celebration of the Beat poets masterpiece, Howl, at the Ace in Downtown Los Angeles. Willner assembled a glittering line-up for the event, a three-hour-plus evening of music, verse and funny people to benefit the David Lynch Foundation: those featured included Nick Cave (the first person he called), Beth Orton and her husband Sam Amidon, Courtney Love, Macy Gray, Lucinda Williams, Tim Robbins, Van Dyke Parks and a handful of SNL alums. In the 60s, this was called a Happening  a bunch of people in the same room that you would never see in the same room, Willner said. Were just missing a plate spinner!

title: For Manolo Blahnik, a Career-Crowning Award
description: There comes a time in a young mans life when the parties in Tangiers dont beckon the way they used to, the young-broke-and-fabulous friends of yore grow older and richer (if no less fabulous), and the accolades come thick and fast  but now they are of the lifetime achievement variety.

title: Clinton and Bush Are Already in Hollywoods Sights
description: LOS ANGELES  Hillary Clinton should keep an eye on George Clooney: Behind that smile, he is producing a movie satire inspired by the antics of some former Clinton advisers whose wildest war stories might best be forgotten.

title: International Criminal Court Says ISIS Is Out of Its Jurisdiction
description: PARIS  Fatou Bensouda, chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court, said on Wednesday that her office had received ample reports of crimes of unspeakable cruelty by the extremists of the Islamic State but that the court had no jurisdiction over Iraq and Syria where the acts occurred or over the groups leaders.

title: A.I.G. Receives Approval From F.A.A. to Use Drones
description: The American International Group said on Wednesday that the Federal Aviation Administration had approved its request to use drones to conduct inspections.

title: Shopping Events and Sales Happening This Week in New York
description: On Thursday, L.K. Bennett will open a Madison Avenue flagship, the British accessible-luxury labels first free-standing New York City retail space, where youll find store exclusives like canvas block heels ($425). At 655 Madison Avenue.

title: The Walter Scott Murder
description: The horrifying video of a white police officer in North Charleston, S.C., shooting and killing an unarmed black man  while the man is running away  may still come as a shock to many Americans. But this heinous act, which the officer tried to explain away by claiming that he feared for his life, strikes a familiar chord in communities of color all across the United States.

title: Phone Cameras and Apps Help Speed Calls for Police Reform
description: The video of the fatal shooting of an unarmed black man by a white police officer in South Carolina is seen by some advocates of police reform as evidence of the rising power of technological weapons in their fight.

title: Want That Game of Thrones Glow? Beauty Tips From Natalie Dormer
description: The English actress Natalie Dormer, 33, knows her way around a corset. She has played pivotal roles on The Tudors and as the clever Margaery Tyrell on Game of Thrones, which is back for Season 5 on Sunday. Ms. Dormer has also had screen roles in Rush, The Hunger Games series and the coming horror film Patient Zero. Born in Reading, England, she has lived in London since she was 18.

title: Paul Jeffrey, Saxophonist Who Played With Monk and Mingus, Dies at 81
description: Paul Jeffrey, a saxophonist who was a mainstay of the great pianist and composer Thelonious Monks last working group and later a prominent jazz educator, died on March 20 at his home in Durham, N.C. He was 81.

title: Network of Super PACs Says That It Has Raised $31 Million for Ted Cruz Bid
description: A network of new super PACs said Wednesday that it had raised $31 million to support Senator Ted Cruzs presidential campaign, a sum that could upend expectations in the race for the Republican nomination and rewrite the political rule book for outside spending.

title: Clip: Dont Think Ive Forgotten
description: A scene from the documentary about the rock music scene in Cambodia in the 1960s and 70s.

title: At Goyard and Valextra, Leather Goods That Are Durable, Versatile  and Invisible
description: Four years into its life span, my Bottega Veneta purse has assumed the shape of a jellyfish. It is so comfortable resting on my shoulder that it registers as less of an accessory than a utensil, even when jammed with small objects.

title: Amazon Web Services Takes Fuller Aim at Enterprise Computing
description: Competition for the corporate dollar didnt take long to heat up.

title: Prosper Marketplace Raises $165 Million in Latest Funding Round
description: SAN FRANCISCO  To keep propelling its growth, Prosper Marketplace is turning to a new round of investors  including several banks that once could be seen as competitors.

title: Rand Paul Gets the TV Spotlight and Turns It on Interviewers in Testy Encounters
description: NASHUA, N.H.  Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky is spending the week trying to introduce himself to Americans as the sensitive, softer-edged face of the Republican Party. He talks about how helping his grandmother as she lost her sight inspired him to become an eye surgeon  and how on a volunteer mission in Guatemala, he enabled a husband and wife to see each other clearly for the first time in years.

title: The Adventures of Alice Laselles, Story by 10-Year-Old Queen Victoria, to Be Published
description: Queen Victoria was one of the most notable graphomaniacs of the 19th century, penning an estimated 60 million words of diaries and letters over her lifetime.

title: In the Gritty New York of the 70s and 80s, Not Exactly a Model Life
description: Snow was swirling early last month, and Brad Gooch was sipping coffee in his new Chelsea office, a Zen-like studio of pale wood and orderly book-filled shelves.

title: Playing Nice at the Premiere of Veep
description: On HBOs Veep, politicos skewer one another with insults, but things were all smiles Monday night when the cast gathered to premiere the shows fourth season at the SVA Theater in Chelsea.

title: I.R.S. Shortcut to Tax-Exempt Status Is Under Fire
description: Battered by a scandal over delays in approving groups for tax-exempt status and plagued by a backlog tens of thousands of cases long, the Internal Revenue Service unveiled a strikingly stripped-down online application last year to speed the process.

title: In the Boston Marathon Bombing, a Verdict, but Few Answers
description: It took more than three months from start to verdict in the Boston Marathon bombing trial. It will most likely take another couple of months for the government and the defense to lay out, respectively, the aggravating and mitigating circumstances, and for the jury to determine whether Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, convicted of all 30 charges on Wednesday, gets the death penalty, or life without parole. The trial has been an astoundingly time-consuming and expensive undertaking, but it has not given the public what it needs and wants most: the fullest possible understanding of what happened.

title: Italian Artisans Revival After Economic Crisis Reflects Resilience of Small Industry
description: PADUA, Italy  High-end printing is an artisans job in Italy. For those books, the gluing and the binding of the pages is predominantly done by hand.

title: John E. Walsh, Who Distilled the Bible, Dies at 87
description: In the beginning, there were 850,000 words. Three years later, John E. Walsh and his team of editors had condensed the Bible by 40 percent, to 510,000.

title: Obama Calls for End to Conversion Therapies for Gay and Transgender Youth
description: WASHINGTON  A 17-year-old transgender youth, Leelah Alcorn, stunned her friends and a vast Internet audience in December when she threw herself in front of a tractor-trailer after writing in an online suicide note that religious therapists had tried to convert her back to being a boy.

title: 10-Year Treasury Notes
description: High yield in monthly refunding auction.

title: The Dow Minute by Minute
description: Position of the Dow Jones industrial average at 1-minute intervals.

title: Wisconsin Chief Justice Files a Lawsuit to Avoid Demotion
description: The liberal-leaning chief justice of the Wisconsin Supreme Court, Shirley S. Abrahamson, filed a federal lawsuit Wednesday seeking to keep her position, a day after voters approved a constitutional amendment likely to result in her demotion.

title: Kenya Struggles Over Best Response to University Attack
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Opposition leaders demanded Wednesday that Kenya pull its troops out of Somalia as soon as possible and accused the president of trying to emasculate the judiciary, one of Kenyas few public institutions that are not considered hopelessly corrupt, in the wake of a terrorist attack last week that killed 142 students.

title: Snapchat Video on the Apple Watch
description: Farhad Manjoo answers users questions about the smartwatch.

title: Council Vote in Ferguson Brings Promise and Pause
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  As he began his legal career as a public defender and then worked for about a decade in private practice, Wesley Bell said he grew frustrated by some of the shortcomings he saw in St. Louis Countys municipal court system. There were judges who would show little leniency when he felt it was deserved. There were defendants making decisions that did not seem to fit their best interests.

title: Anne-Claude Leflaive, Vintner in Burgundy, Dies at 59
description: Anne-Claude Leflaive, who presided over one of Burgundys most storied white wine estates and was a fervent, influential advocate for environmentally sensitive forms of farming, died on Monday at her home in Gilly-ls-Cteaux, France. She was 59.

title: In California, Cities Braced to Cut Water by 10 to 35%
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Among the California water officials who were left reeling on Wednesday by the magnitude of the drought-related cutbacks they will have to make was Tom Gray, the general manager of the Fair Oaks Water District, outside Sacramento. He had been prepared to meet a 25 percent reduction in water use in the district, but the 35 percent recommended by the state? That seemed punitive.

title: Toronto Orchestra Drops Pianist Over Tweets About Ukraine
description: The Toronto Symphony Orchestra abruptly canceled a performance of Rachmaninoffs Second Piano Concerto on Wednesday after parting ways with a Ukrainian soloist over concerns that her ribald Twitter commentary had crossed the line into intolerance.

title: Attention Turns to Adam Scott as Anchored Putting Begins a Farewell Tour
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  The Masters is viewed as the unofficial start to the consequential golf season, which makes this years opening round a first among lasts.
