title: Wall St. Is Told to Tighten Digital Security of Partners
description: Wall Streets oversight of cybersecurity measures at outside firms it does business with remains a work in progress, according to a review by New York States top financial regulator.

title: Fitting Hugs Into Chipping Practice, Tiger Woods Makes a Cheery Return
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  On the sixth hole of the par-3 contest at Augusta National Golf Club, Tiger Woods called his caddie over to confer on strategy. Woodss regular caddie, Joe LaCava, held back as the golfers son, Charlie Axel, wearing a white pint-size coverall, went over and listened. Woods pointed to where he wanted to land his tee shot.

title: Video of Walter Scott Shooting Reignites Debate on Police Tactics
description: WASHINGTON  Nothing has done more to fuel the national debate over police tactics than the dramatic, sometimes grisly videos: A man gasping I cant breathe through a police chokehold on Staten Island, a 12-year-old boy shot dead in a park in Cleveland. And now, perhaps the starkest video yet, showing a South Carolina police officer shooting a fleeing man in the back.

title: Pearl River Mart, a Community Lifeline
description: The Chinese department stores goods, and jobs, have been supporting Chinese immigrants in New York City for 44 years.

title: In a Surprise, a Top Kerry Adviser Visits Venezuela
description: MEDELLN, Colombia  A top adviser to Secretary of State John Kerry was in Venezuela on Wednesday for a surprise meeting as the United States appeared to be seeking to lower the volume in the rancorous relationship between the countries ahead of a regional meeting of heads of state.

title: At Pearl River, Four Decades of Helping New Arrivals From Asia
description: Every morning, Ming Yi Chen walks down to the basement of Pearl River Mart, the Chinese department store he opened in 1971, and burns incense. Then he walks back to the first floor to light more incense. He breathes in the sandalwood, to him a calming scent. And the day can begin.

title: Review: In Buzzer, a Relationship Strained on the Urban Frontier
description: The effects of urban gentrification have oft been noted. Bodegas transformed into latte dispensaries. Skyrocketing rents that force out longtime neighborhood dwellers. In the skillful play Buzzer, by Tracey Scott Wilson, which opened at the Public Theater on Wednesday, the issue is examined from a more intimate point of view, as the relationship between an interracial couple comes under unexpected strain when they move to the urban frontier.

title: When Service Isnt Perfect
Review: Vanessa Hudgens in a Squeaky Clean Gigi on Broadway
description: A shower of soap bubbles descends upon the audience at the finale of the pretty and pleasant revival of the musical Gigi that opened at the Neil Simon Theater on Wednesday. The gentle downpour is meant to evoke the fizz in a glass of Champagne, the delights of which have been celebrated in one of the bounciest songs from the score by Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe.

title: Veteran CBS Newscaster Bob Schieffer Announces Plan to Retire
description: Bob Schieffer, a television anchor who has worked at CBS for nearly half a century and interviewed every sitting president since Richard Nixon, announced Wednesday night that he was retiring this summer.

title: Mrs. Obamas Wing of White House Is Having Its Share of Transition at Key Time
description: WASHINGTON  The West Wing, where President Obama works, is used to the comings-and-goings of staff members  a never-ending churn that spawns speculation. Now it is the East Wings turn.

title: New York Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Parking Rules Suspended on Thursday
description: Because of Holy Thursday (Orthodox), alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Thursday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: 4th Brooklyn Man Indicted in Plot to Assist ISIS Pleads Not Guilty
description: A fourth Brooklyn man indicted in a plot to aid the Islamic State pleaded not guilty on Wednesday to charges of attempt and conspiracy to support the terrorist group.

title: Wall Street Fees Wipe Out $2.5 Billion in New York City Pension Gains
description: The Lenape tribe got a better deal on the sale of Manhattan island than New York Citys pension funds have been getting from Wall Street, according to a new analysis by the city comptrollers office.

title: Broadchurch Season 2, Episode 6 Recap: Deep Breaths
description: With the season finale looming and a third season on the way, its re-evaluation time for Broadchurch, a show that seemed destined to be a quiet one-off and then unexpectedly achieved tremendous success.

title: The Americans Recap: Paige the Interrogator
description: Season 3, Episode 11: One Day in the Life of Anton Baklanov

title: Stabbing ofChris Copeland Hangs Over Games in New York
description: Just two weeks ago, Wednesday nights schedule of basketball games in New York held little intrigue. The Nets were one of four teams separated by a half-game for the eighth playoff spot in the Eastern Conference but, at 30-40, had showed that they would probably be little more than an appetizer for the top-seeded Atlanta Hawks if they qualified for the postseason.

title: Eighth-Inning Rally Chases Chill Out of Yankees Second Game
description: The pomp and circumstance of opening day had disappeared  along with the capacity crowd and the warm, sunny skies. Yankee Stadium was a vastly different place Wednesday night from what it had been two days earlier, a mostly vacant ballpark that was occupied by the hearty few who braved temperatures that dipped into the 30s and the wind that accompanied them.

title: Before Loss, Mets Scoff at Talk of Tension
description: WASHINGTON  Mets Manager Terry Collins was surrounded by members of the news media Wednesday, answering a pregame question, when General Manager Sandy Alderson interrupted him from the back of the room.

title: Kik Interactive Says Its Weighing Options, Including Selling Itself
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The messaging app Kik Interactive said on Wednesday that it was exploring its strategic options, including a potential sale of itself, as messaging apps continue to grow in popularity.

title: Inside Raf Simonss House
description: The designer talks about a new film detailing the bumpy road to his first couture collection for Dior  and the intimate relationship with the women of his atelier.

title: A Revived New Orleans Market Champions the Local and Brightens Up the Neighborhood
description: Urban European-style food halls packed with grab-and-go artisanal goods and gourmet groceries from specialty purveyors and local vendors are quickly becoming commonplace across America. A majority of these stateside culinary wonderlands are located, of course, in Manhattan: This spring has already welcomed downtowns Le District, a vast 30,000-square-foot French market near the World Trade Center (commonly dubbed the French Eataly) and a new Times Square multi-vendor called City Kitchen. And modern markets of all sizes are set to open between now and early fall, from Seattle (Market Hall) to Portland (Pine Street Market), Denver (Avanti Food and Beverage) to Atlanta (Ponce City Market) and Charleston (The Cigar Factory). Today, New Orleans joins the trend with the reopening of St. Roch Market  in its original building, which was wrecked by Hurricane Katrina nearly a decade ago.

title: Kaleidoscopic Images of Jewelry, Flowers and Everyday Objects
description: In this weekly series, Ts photo editors share the most compelling visual projects theyve discovered.

title: Brooklyn Academy of Music Chooses New President
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music hasnt had to search for a new president in a very long time. Since the impresario Harvey Lichtenstein stepped down in 1999, Karen Brooks Hopkins has held the position, becoming a fund-raising powerhouse and building the institution into an anchor for a cultural renaissance in Downtown Brooklyn.

title: David Laventhol, Publisher on Both Coasts, Dies at 81
description: David A. Laventhol, a former publisher of The Los Angeles Times and Newsday who made a journalistically acclaimed but financially doomed attempt to break into the New York City newspaper market by starting New York Newsday in 1985, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 81.

title: Whats on TV Thursday
description: 10 P.M. (FX) THE COMEDIANS Billy Crystal is a comedy legend whose best work may be behind him and Josh Gad is a rising star in this new series, which ventures behind the scenes at The Billy & Josh Show, a semifictional late-night sketch series. Stephnie Weir plays the long-suffering producer caught between the men, who agree on almost nothing; Matt Oberg is the shows head writer; and Megan Ferguson is the no-nonsense production assistant. Semifake Billy and semifake Josh drop references to these real-life rsums constantly in The Comedians as they try to one-up each other while battling over the show theyre supposed to be creating together, Neil Genzlinger wrote in The New York Times. How meta is it? In Episode 4, Mel Brooks advises his friend Billy not to try to book a big-name guest on The Billy & Josh Show because it would distract the audience from the title characters. Mr. Brooks, of course, steals the episode. In the Season 5 opener of Louie, at 10:30, Louie (Louis C.K.) admits in therapy that hes not sure how to live a life anymore and encounters an angry lesbian at a school potluck. This time around, as Louis C.K. reinvents the classic sitcom in his own elliptical, cerebral style, he seems to be in his absurdist theater phase, or his surrealist short-story phase  Kafka on the Hudson, Mike Hale wrote in The Times. His moments of victory, and redemption, come when hes alone, onstage, working a funny voice and a dumb joke.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I knew this family would never get justice, and this guy just hands us justice. He handed us justice.

description: INTERNATIONAL

description: SNEAK PEEK: This week Lens is featuring a selection of photographers attending the New York Portfolio Review.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Rand Paul, Paul Rand Quiz
description: Rand Paul for president! Wow, were awash with first-term Republican senators who feel the nation needs their services as leader of the most powerful nation on the planet.

title: Israel and the Iran Deal
Enjoying the Low Life?
description: The United States is the most powerful colossus in the history of the world: Our nuclear warheads could wipe out the globe, our enemies tweet on iPhones, and kids worldwide bop to Beyonc.

title: Footing the College Bill
A Shortage of Funds for Food Safety
description: A farsighted food safety law enacted in 2011 has faced obstacles to meaningful enforcement ever since, including delays in issuing necessary rules and a shortage of money. Now, in what may become the latest shameful chapter, Congress seems unwilling to provide enough money to effectively carry out regulations that are about to be issued. The losers, of course, will continue to be consumers, who live with the hazards of an unsafe food supply.

title: Explaining Jeb Bushs Hispanic Error
description: EVANSTON, Ill.  AFTER the news broke this week that Jeb Bush erroneously listed himself as Hispanic on a 2009 voter registration application, a familiar cycle of accusations and recriminations set in. The Florida Democratic Party suggested that Mr. Bush might have committed a felony. Cynics contended that for Mr. Bush, a former governor and likely Republican presidential candidate who has long courted Hispanic voters, this was a ploy to further his appeal with that demographic.

title: Gov. Christies Bad Deal With Exxon
description: New Jersey has been fighting for years to get the Exxon Mobil Corporation to clean up and pay up after turning more than 1,500 acres of marshes and waterways into toxic wastelands. But, just as a State Superior Court judge was about to rule on the case earlier this year, Gov. Chris Christies administration suddenly and unexpectedly agreed to settle with Exxon for 3 cents on the dollar. The agreement, which became public on Monday, allows Exxon to escape with a payment of $225 million, far less than the estimated $8.9 billion the state had originally asked for a decade ago.

title: Marijuana Taxes Wont Save State Budgets
description: Colorados marijuana tax collections are not as high as expected.

title: Chinese Police Seeking Charges Against Detained Womens Activists, Lawyer Says
description: BEIJING  Police officers in Beijing have asked prosecutors to charge five womens rights activists who have been detained for more than a month with organizing a crowd to disturb public order, lawyers for two of them said on Thursday.

title: A Struggle to Secure Iraqs Shared Past, and Perhaps Its Future
description: BAGHDAD  Looted and shuttered after American troops seized Baghdad a dozen years ago, the National Museum of Iraq has officially reopened its doors  a response to Islamic State thugs taking jackhammers to ancient treasures in Mosul.

title: Mocking Mao Backfires for Chinese TV Host
description: Mao Zedong famously said a revolution is not a dinner party. Nor, it seems, is a dinner party in China an occasion to mock Maos revolution.

title: Why Writers Love to Hate the M.F.A.
description: It was peak reading season, and Lan Samantha Chang, director of the Iowa Writers Workshop, was gamely juggling a call from a reporter, interruptions from her 7-year-old as well as a 10 percent surge in applications to the University of Iowas Master of Fine Arts program in creative writing. Ms. Chang was in the thick of decisions about who would fill 50 spots evenly divided between the fall fiction and poetry workshops.

title: North Charleston Police Shooting Not Justified, Experts Say
description: Can a police officer legally shoot a fleeing suspect in the back?

title: Chile Joins Other Latin American Nations Shaken by Scandal
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  Scandals are shaking one government after another this year in Latin America: the mysterious death of a prosecutor in Argentina, the ouster of Perus prime minister over a domestic spying operation, the revelations of a vast bribery scheme at Brazils national oil company.

title: Obama Adviser During Recession Is Given New Challenge: Climate Change
description: Brian Deeses first job at the White House included churning out economic doomsday scenarios, like how many communities might see unemployment rates hit 25 percent in the event of cascading bankruptcies across the Midwest.

title: When a Plane Seat Next to a Woman Is Against Orthodox Faith
description: Francesca Hogi, 40, had settled into her aisle seat for the flight from New York to London when the man assigned to the adjoining window seat arrived and refused to sit down. He said his religion prevented him from sitting beside a woman who was not his wife. Irritated but eager to get underway, she eventually agreed to move.

title: The G.O.P. Presidential Field Looks Chaotic. Its Not.
description: The Republican primary battle has been called a wide-open contest  the deepest and strongest field in many cycles. It is full of the partys rising stars and hopefuls, like Scott Walker, Marco Rubio, Rand Paul, Chris Christie, Ben Carson, Ted Cruz and Bobby Jindal, alongside the most formidable name in Republican politics: Bush.

title: Lyft Hires Amazon Executive as Chief Operating Officer
description: Amazon has long focused on delivering packages to customers as efficiently as humanly possible. It makes sense, then, that Lyft, a ride-hailing start-up, would want to hire staff from the online retail giant.

title: Jon Ronson: By the Book
description: The author, most recently, of So Youve Been Publicly Shamed used to find stories about children in peril unbearable. But with his son reaching adulthood, he says, I nowadays find it impossible to read stories in which dogs are in peril.

title: Paul Beattys The Sellout
description: African-American satire has been alive at least since the first black slave made fun of her putative masters and their manners. In that moment of mockery, the cakewalk was born, but this parody had a catch: The slave owners loved it. They mistook the dance for a poor imitation rather than a dark mirror. One of the first homegrown national fads to go global, the cakewalk anticipated the paroxysms of twerking that would follow, whose late adopters like Miley Cyrus might be forgiven for missing the deep irony in the forms black origins.

title: Fighting Mental Illness on the Ball Field
description: Mental illness remains highly stigmatized, even after celebrities like Brooke Shields, Mel Gibson and Robin Williams went public with their stories. So it was really a big deal 60 years ago when the Boston Red Sox outfielder Jimmy Piersall wrote two articles in the Saturday Evening Post entitled They Called Me CrazyAnd I Was. Mr. Piersalls courageous description of his struggles with manic depression, now called bipolar disorder, helped bring the disease and its treatments out of the shadows.

title: U.S. Defense Chief Arrives in South Korea Amid News of Norths Missile Launches
description: OSAN AIR BASE, South Korea  Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carters welcome present was waiting for him when he touched down here on Thursday: confirmed reports that North Korea fired two short-range missiles off its western coast two days before his first visit to South Korea as President Obamas defense chief.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: New York Today: Spring Break Fever
description: Good morning on this damp Thursday.

title: Daily Report: Phone Cameras and Apps Capture Interactions With Police
description: The video of the fatal shooting of an unarmed black man by a white police officer in South Carolina is seen by some advocates of police reform as evidence of the rising power of technological weapons in their fight, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac report.

title: Why Was This Patient Breathing So Strangely?
description: Her doctors thought she was having panic attacks. But she insisted she wasnt anxious.

title: The Awkward Romance in Veep
description: The HBO comedy is a political satire, but its core is the nonromantic romance between Selina Meyer, the vice president played by Julia Louis-Dreyfus, and Gary, her body man, played by Tony Hale.

title: The Grandparent Scam
description: URBANA, ILL.  The crime is known as the grandparent scam. Its a type of identity theft that many people have been aware of for a while, but my grandfather had not heard about it before he fell prey to it.

title: Lee Surrendered, But His Lieutenants Kept Fighting
description: If the programme which our people saw set on foot at Appomattox Court-House had been carried out  we would have no disturbance in the South, testified the former Confederate general (and future senator) John Brown Gordon in 1871. Speaking before a congressional committee investigating the widespread anti-black violence in the former Confederacy, Gordon was accusing Radical Republicans of bad faith  specifically, of breaking the Appomattox Compact.

title: Today in Politics: A Knighted Bloomberg Decrees Bush and Clinton Worthy Candidates
Morning Agenda: The $100 Billion Deal Day
description: THE $100 BILLION DEAL DAY  | Two huge offers  one accepted, the other unsolicited  trumpet a potential new frenzy of activity in deal-making. First and foremost, Royal Dutch Shells $70 billion acquisition of BG Group of Britain signals that the kinds of behemoth energy mergers that reshaped the industry in the late 1990s may be due for a revival in the face of lower oil and gas prices. In energy, the Brontosaurus is back. Mylans $29 billion approach to Perrigo, meanwhile, underscores just how red-hot consolidation in health care continues to be. Both of the generic drug makers had done their own deals in just the last two years.

title: How Low Can the Philadelphia 76ers Go?
description: There has never been a professional sports team quite like the 2014-15 Philadelphia 76ers, a roster of basketball castoffs and drifters that could be the least capable assemblage of players ever to suit up for an N.B.A. game. The franchise  widely believed by those who follow pro basketball to be deliberately in tank mode, in order to lose games and get a top pick in this summers N.B.A. draft  has offended sensibilities, provoked curiosity, inspired bizarre mathematical theorems. How low could they go? After they lost 17 games to open the current season, the FiveThirtyEight website published a dark simulation that projected their losing streak could reach 54 games. Deadspin declared the Sixers a godless abomination, while Slam Magazine, the hip-hop basketball bible, described them as a flesh-eating bacteria of sorts on the N.B.A.s collective self-respect.

title: Do Police Use Deadly Force Too Often?
Raising Your Successful 35-Year-Old
description: What do we mean when we say we want to raise successful children? Too often, especially around this time of year, that conversation centers on college or the kinds of academics and activities that lead to college. Success is hard to measure, and those external markers make for comforting milestones along the way.

title: Julia Louis-Dreyfus and Tony Hales Demented Double Act on Veep
description: The show begins  the very first scene of the very first episode  with a man helping a woman put on her coat. The man is tall. The woman is small. The man is balding. The woman has the shimmering hair of an extremely convincing shampoo ad. The man wears a nondescript dark suit, a striped tie and some kind of ID badge  the uniform of the bureaucratic functionary. He has a five oclock shadow and the hint of a double chin. The woman wears a snug red dress with a deep neckline, an elegant gold necklace, understated makeup. She is the vice president of the United States. Getting her coat on is therefore an official matter of state, and the man is clearly treating it as such; he concentrates intently on maneuvering her right arm into the coats right sleeve. The woman, meanwhile, pays no attention to the man or to the coat, never even glances back; she stares forward, into the eyes of her chief of staff, with whom she is having a conversation.

title: Iris Apfel Doesnt Do Normcore
description: Youve been a mainstay of the New York fashion scene for years, and youre now the subject of a documentary, Iris, directed by Albert Maysles. Considering how long youve been around, are you surprised at all the recent interest in your life? It seems insane to me. Im doing nothing different than what Ive done for the last 70-odd years. Maybe I was ahead of the game, and people caught up with me. There arent too many 93-year-old cover girls around.

title: First Draft Focus: Obama at the Bob Marley Museum
Graphic South Carolina Video and Details From a Rap Sheet Distress Some Times Readers
description: The Times gave huge space online and in print Wednesday to the fatal shooting of a black South Carolina man by a white police officer. Given the events last summer in Ferguson, Mo., that decision needs no explanation.

title: The Indomitable Chita Rivera, Back on Broadway in The Visit
description: Two hours before any preview performance of The Visit, the Kander and Ebb musical that opens this month at the Lyceum Theater, you can find its star, Chita Rivera, in her dressing room. Upside down.

title: Review: Dior and I, a Documentary That Peers Into a Storied Fashion House
description: An elegant and captivating piece of corporate promotion in the guise of a documentary, Frdric Tchengs Dior and I unfolds like an episode of Project Runway with better clothes and bigger budgets, or perhaps a Christopher Guest movie without a sense of humor. There are some amusing moments, to be sure, and some touching ones as well, but the film is less interested in ideas or emotions than in illusions. It produces an aura of suspense without a sense of real risk, and offers devotees of fashion an appealing, shallow fantasy of inside knowledge.

title: Some Republicans Seek Status Quo on Iran
description: As Republicans criticize the nuclear deal President Obama and other world leaders struck with Iran last week, some of them say it would be better just to leave the current interim agreement in place instead.

title: When a Handbag Has a Starring Role
description: The Audience, Peter Morgans play about Queen Elizabeth II, which stars Helen Mirren on Broadway and which will reopen this month in the West End of London with Kristin Scott Thomas, has had many pleasant repercussions for its much-celebrated leading lady, the director Stephen Daldry and its author. But the name that potentially stands to benefit most from the plays success is probably less well known: Launer London.

title: The Gap Between Auto Dealers and Social Media
description: Matt Howell, the general manager of a Hyundai dealership in Huntsville, Tex., has been in the auto business for 18 years. In all that time, he said, I can think of one deal that originated on Facebook.

title: Kerry Says U.S. Knew of Irans Military Aid to Houthi Rebels
description: CAIRO  Secretary of State John Kerry has said that the United States knew Iran had been providing military support to the Houthi rebels in Yemen and that Washington is not going to stand by while the region is destabilized.

title: Review: In The Longest Ride, the Nicholas Sparks Brand Endures
description: On the Box Office Mojo website, The Longest Ride is described in three words: Brand: Nicholas Sparks. That may be all you need to know. The film, directed by George Tillman Jr. (Soul Food, The Inevitable Defeat of Mister & Pete), is the latest screen adaptation of work by an author whose stamp is unmistakable. To those familiar with his novels  and, more relevant to our purposes here, with the seacoast-and-sunlight, white-people-kissing-in-the-rain movies they have inspired  Mr. Sparkss name evokes a genre, an aesthetic, a swoony, saccharine, weirdly compelling gestalt.

title: Waiting for Chinese Food
description: Dear Diary:

title: Warner Bros. and Lego Enter Market Where Toys and Gaming Meet
description: BURBANK, Calif.  Warner Bros. and Lego are deploying Batman, Marty McFly, the Wicked Witch of the West and other movie characters in search of profits in the booming area of entertainment known as toys to life.

title: Dont Think Ive Forgotten, a Documentary, Revives Cambodias Silenced Sounds
description: For proof of the universality of rock n roll, look no further than Cambodia in the 1960s and 70s. Even there, young people picked up electric guitars and studied Mick Jaggers moves, melding Eastern melody with Western groove in ways that are still strikingly fresh.

title: A Penchant for the East Village
description: Before she moved to New York, Jen Dobrovolski lived at home in New Jersey, with an exhausting ferry commute. She caught the boat in Atlantic Highlands, disembarked near Wall Street and took two subway trains to her office in Midtown West. In the evening, it was the other way around.

title: Peltzs Attacks on DuPont Threaten Americas Research Edge
description: Since its founding in 1802, DuPont has been at the center of American scientific breakthroughs in chemistry. Among its research triumphs was the black powder that supplied 40 percent of the Allied needs in World War II.

title: Daily Show Successor Trevor Noah Finds Himself Catching Criticism, Not Dealing It Out
description: If an announcement of a presidential candidacy were as rocky as Comedy Centrals introduction of Trevor Noah, The Daily Show would have a field day with it.

title: U.S. Is Closer to Deciding Cubas Status on Terror List
description: PANAMA  President Obama is nearing a decision on removing Cubas three-decade-old designation as a state sponsor of terrorism, citing progress in his push to normalize relations with the island nation as he arrived here on Thursday night for a summit meeting of Latin American leaders.

title: How to Verify if That Port Is Indeed a USB 3.0
HSBC Facing Criminal Investigation in French Tax Case
description: LONDON  The British bank HSBC said on Thursday that it had been placed under formal criminal investigation by French magistrates examining whether its Swiss private bank assisted wealthy clients to avoid taxes.

title: French Broadcaster TV5 Monde Recovers After Hacking
description: PARIS  The French television broadcaster TV5 Monde was back on the air Thursday, a day after hackers claiming to support the Islamic State militant group carried out a wide-ranging cyberattack on the network.

title: Intel Said to End Talks to Buy Chip Designer Altera
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Intel has ended discussions to buy Altera, a designer of specialized computer chips, people briefed on the matter said on Thursday, putting to rest what would have been the companys biggest-ever takeover.

title: Malli Mastan Babu, Who Scaled the Worlds Tallest Mountains, Dies at 40
description: Malli Mastan Babu, an Indian mountaineer who won fame as the first South Asian to scale the highest peak on each of the seven continents, and who had been missing in the Andes since late March, was found dead on April 3. He was 40.

title: The Must-Attend Event for Education Technology Investors
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  To observe the major forces at play in the education technology sector, one needed only to stand near the marble fountain in the Phoenician Resort lobby this week.

title: China Says Construction in Contested Waters Is for Maritime Purposes
description: BEIJING  A Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman on Thursday defended Chinas island-building work in contested waters in the South China Sea, saying the infrastructure the nation was constructing around reefs, rocks and shoals was within Chinas sovereign rights and would help ships in the event of typhoons.

title: 1965: Hanoi Rejects Johnsons Offer
description: SAIGON  North Vietnam today assailed President Johnsons offer of a peaceful settlement for Vietnam as a crude hoax. It also widely distributed a statement by President Ho Chi Minh declaring that the United States must withdraw from South Vietnam before a settlement can be reached. North Vietnams response followed Communist Chinas rejection of Mr. Johnsons gesture as an inducement to the Vietnamese insurgents to disarm. Peking also called it a hoax.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 10, 1965

title: In Maastricht, a Taste of Joie de Vivre
description: By the time we were sitting at Caf Sjiek, sharing a pot of zoervleis  a Limburgian delicacy that translates to sour meat  my husband, Tim, and I were on our third ultra-indulgent restaurant meal of the day and feeling like failed Olympians. The waiter, a rather severe man with a shaved head and the arty eyeglasses of a museum curator, had seemed surprised that I ordered the dish.

title: Where to Shop in Vienna
description: Neubaugasse Street in Viennas seventh district, an enclave near the tourist-frequented Museumsquartier, where both longtime residents and young professionals live, has emerged as a go-to for innovative shopping. Boutiques, housed mostly in three- and four-story 19th-century buildings on this charming and quiet street, sell everything from trendy clothes and accessories to food, and stand out for their personable feel.

title: Spurs Prepare to Pass the Torch, and Kawhi Leonard Is Ready
description: SAN ANTONIO  With a little over two minutes remaining in the game here on Wednesday night, two fans were ushered onto the court for a contest. They would be racing to make a layup, the catch being that they first had to rest their foreheads on traffic cones and spin around 10 times.

title: New Hikes in Sonoma
description: A new hiking trail linked to Jack London State Historic Park in Sonoma County, Calif., gives the public access to parts of Sonoma Mountain for the first time.

title: Irans Supreme Leader Says Sanctions Must Lift When Nuclear Deal Is Signed
description: TEHRAN  Irans supreme leader on Thursday challenged two of the United States bedrock principles in the nuclear negotiations, declaring that all economic sanctions would have to be lifted on the day any final agreement was signed and that military sites would be strictly off limits to foreign inspectors.

title: Fine Foods Match Vancouver Islands Spectacular Setting
description: Tofino, an enclave on the western edge of Vancouver Island in Canada, has long been a draw for its spectacular setting between the Pacific Ocean, with its surfer-magnet waves, and the Pacific Rim National Park Reserve. Now, the growing number of restaurants is another reason to visit this British Columbia district, with a population of less than 1,900. The thriving culinary scene here is led by transplants who were attracted to the areas idyllic surroundings and easygoing way of life.

title: In Rand Paul Ads, an Appeal to Viewers Before the Skip This
description: It can be a saving grace. Queue up the latest music video, say, from Taylor Swift on YouTube, and instead of having to wait for an entire car commercial to pass, a Skip This Ad button occasionally appears after five seconds.

title: Keeping Adrian Gonzalezs Torrid Start in Perspective
description: Adrian Gonzalez of the Los Angeles Dodgers had a home run in each of his first two games this season, then added three on Wednesday night to become the first player in major league history with five home runs in his first three games, according to Elias Sports Bureau.

title: Anti-Bias Ordinance Falls in Springfield, Missouri, After Push by Christian Conservatives
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mo.  After a successful vote by the City Council here in October to add sexual orientation and gender identity to the list of categories protected from discrimination here, one supporter, David Trippe, thought this Bible Belt city might have turned a page.

title: Irans Supreme Leader on Nuclear Deal
description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei of Iran said on Thursday that he neither accepts nor rejects the framework nuclear deal reached between Iran and world powers last week.

title: Eddie Murphy to Receive Mark Twain Prize for American Humor
description: If the tribute that Eddie Murphy received at the Saturday Night Live 40th-anniversary special (or the tantalizingly short remarks he made at the end of it) wasnt enough for you, hell soon be the recipient of another prestigious comedy honor.

title: De Blasio Rides the Subway: A Flight of Whimsy With an Undertone of Purpose
description: Read the full story here.

title: Lincoln Chafee Explores Presidential Run as a Democrat
description: With no advance warning, the Democratic race for president got a surprise new contender on Thursday.

title: A Marital Spat Over Running Shoes
description: When you are trying to improve yourself through any kind of exercise program, its good storytelling to use phrases like I wanted to be a better version of myself, or I was ready to see what I was truly capable of. But I hired a running coach because I was tired of fighting with my husband about the cost of running shoes.

title: Founder of Satyam, Software Outsourcing Company in India, Found Guilty of Fraud
description: NEW DELHI  An Indian court on Thursday sentenced the former head of Satyam Computer Services, a software outsourcing company, and nine others to seven years in prison after a trial centered on one of the largest corporate accounting frauds in Indias history.

title: Vegetables  la Grecque Shows Its Versatility
description: Despite the name, vegetables  la grecque is French through and through. According to the food writer Roy Andries de Groot, the phrase  la Grecque is attached to many dishes that came to France with refugees (many of them Greek) from the Ottoman Empire in the 15th century and have been absorbed into French cuisine.

title: Beijings Olympic Bid Faces Drought
description: As Beijing makes its pitch to hold the 2022 Winter Olympic Games, environmentalists worry that the decades-long drought in and around the ski venues will further stress water sources.

title: LinkedIn to Buy Lynda.com, an Online Learning Company
description: SAN FRANCISCO  LinkedIn, the professional networking site, is branching out yet again.

title: Scientists Question Environmental Impact of Chinas Winter Olympics Bid
description: JIUZHANBAO, China  A few times a year, rains sprinkle the dry mountains north of Beijing, feeding streams that trickle down to catchments like the Yunzhou Reservoir. From its shores, the water shimmers and sparkles, a mirage that local farmers can see but not touch.

title: At the Masters, a Cheer for the Old-School Big Three
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Cancer did not prevent Carl Jackson from keeping his annual appointment with Ben Crenshaw on Thursday at the 79th Masters. That was the good news.

title: 1940: Nazis Enter Nordic States
description: A video report from British Path on the occupation of Scandinavian countries by Germany. britishpathe.com.

title: Toronto Museum Director to Succeed Malcolm Rogers as Leader of Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
description: Succeeding Malcolm Rogers, who served for 19 years, Matthew Teitelbaum will become the next director of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, the museum announced Thursday.

title: Witnesses Describe Milan Court Shooting
description: Two witnesses described the scene at a Milan courthouse on Thursday after a man on trial for bankruptcy opened fire, killing three people.

title: In Accepting Bitcoin, Rand Paul Raises Money and Questions
description: WASHINGTON  Presidential fund-raising, never known for its transparency, may have just become even more secretive.

title: No Netflix Crown for Helen Mirren
description: After having played Queen Elizabeth II on both stage and screen, Helen Mirren told BBC Radio 4 that she had not been asked to reprise the role in a coming Netflix series.

title: U.N. Rights Chief Criticizes Malaysian Antiterror Measure
description: GENEVA  The United Nations human rights chief on Thursday joined in criticism of the Malaysian governments planned legislation on sedition and the prevention of terrorism, warning that both bills threatened to severely curtail freedom of opinion and expression and breach the countrys international obligations.

title: Ahead of World War II Anniversary, Questions Linger Over Stance of Japans Premier
description: PELELIU ISLAND, Palau  Visiting the remote Western Pacific site of one of the fiercest battles of World War II, Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko of Japan offered flowers and prayers on Thursday to mark the coming 70th anniversary of the end of a conflict that continues to haunt Japan as it seeks a larger role in the world.

title: Imported Stars Give Red Sox a Chance at a Worst-to-First Repeat
description: PHILADELPHIA  The last time the Boston Red Sox played the Yankees in the regular season, Derek Jeter retired. On his way off the field for the last time, Jeter paused to shake hands with Clay Buchholz, the Boston pitcher who had been warming in the bullpen when Jeter shook the hands of the other Red Sox before the game.

title: 1976 | When Cutting-Edge Technology Involved a Rotary Dial
description: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

title: Investment Banks Are Within Reach of Adequate Returns
description: Investor redemption may be nearing for investment banks. Most lenders wholesale units have destroyed value for seven years. Some may have done so again in the first quarter of this year.

title: In Living on Love,Rene Fleming Takes a Humorous Broadway Turn
description: Rene Fleming has performed at Bayreuth, La Scala and the Super Bowl. She has lent her soprano to the contents of a David Letterman Top 10 list. She has inspired a character in a best-selling novel (Ann Patchetts Bel Canto) and a dessert by the chef Daniel Boulud.

title: 2016 Ambitions Turn Marco Rubio, Jeb Bush Protg, Into Rival
description: MIAMI  As Marco Rubio debated whether to run for the United States Senate in 2010, he made a pledge steeped in loyalty and deference: He would never challenge his political mentor, Jeb Bush, if the former Florida governor wanted the job himself.

title: Amid Political Confrontations in Bangladesh, a Search for a Missing Opposition Official
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  A jittery silence has fallen over the street where Salahuddin Ahmed, a top official of the opposition Bangladesh Nationalist Party, is believed to have been abducted a month ago.

title: Russian Consumers Reflect the Pinch of Economic Sanctions
description: MOSCOW  The brand-new Avia Park is a glittering testament to the power of the Russian consumer. A panorama of white tile flooring, under a soaring, six story-tall glass roof, it is the largest mall in Europe, with 377,000 square meters of enclosed space, a 17-screen multiplex, even a 70-foot tall aquarium of tropical fish.

title: Laurie Anderson to Receive Yaddo Artist Medal
description: Laurie Anderson will receive the second annual Artist Medal awarded by Yaddo, the artist colony in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. The ceremony will take place June 1 in New York and will be hosted by Steve Buscemi and Kate Valk.

title: Letters: How Does That Make You Feel?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ice Cream Sandwiches
description: Born on the Bowery, the ice cream sandwich has come a long way over the last century.

title: The Ice Cream Sandwich Comes of Age
description: The American ice cream sandwich was born in the Bowery district of Manhattan in the early 1900s, when a pushcart vendor slapped together skinny wafers and vanilla ice cream and handed them for a penny each to shoeshiners and stockbrokers alike.

title: Robert Durst Pleads Not Guilty to Weapons Charges
description: NEW ORLEANS  Robert A. Durst, the estranged member of a prominent Manhattan real estate family, pleaded not guilty on Thursday to two weapons charges.

title: Anatomy | Clouds of Sils Maria
description: In this Anatomy of a Scene, the writer and director Olivier Assayas narrates a sequence from Clouds of Sils Maria, featuring Juliette Binoche and Kristen Stewart.

title: The Right Wine to Drink With a Sandwich
description: Some people with narrow views of the possibilities ask, Why would you drink wine with a sandwich? I say, Why on earth wouldnt you?

title: Taliban Attack in Northern Afghanistan Leaves at Least 10 Dead
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Assailants armed with heavy weapons and suicide vests stormed the provincial prosecutors office on Thursday in one of the most peaceful cities in northern Afghanistan, battling security forces for more than six hours and leaving at least 10 people dead and dozens wounded.

title: Andrew Rashbass, Reuters Chief, Is Moving to Euromoney
description: Andrew Rashbass, the chief executive of Reuters, is leaving the organization this year to join Euromoney Institutional Investor, a British publisher of financial publications, as executive chairman, the companies said on Thursday.

title: Ana Khouris Newest Jewelry Forms to Accentuate a Womans Own
description: The Brazilian designer Ana Khouris fine jewelry isnt defined by carats, cut or color, nor by its high-profile fans, like Madonna and Jennifer Lawrence. Instead, she aims to distinguish her work by highlighting its natural synergy with the human anatomy. In her latest designs (she doesnt create collections), the former art scholar and sculptor is taking that notion, of connecting the accessory to its wearer, even further. Today at Dover Street Market New York, she debuts collar necklaces, earrings, rings and bracelets made from materials like yellow gold, pav diamonds and pearls. I was inspired by a dialogue with the human form, Khouri says. The shapes of these pieces follow the lines of the body. There are cuffs that appear to climb inside the ear and slink their way out of the lobe, and rings that better frame the curves of the fingers. Inspired by artists like Louise Bourgeois and Alberto Giacometti, Khouri explains that she aims to call attention to the lines of the thing  and not the person who is wearing it. To that effect, the DSMNY installation features live models, veiled and wearing the pieces over their fabric-draped skin  so that viewers only, as Khouri puts it, focus only on what is essential.

title: Latest Score in Cyprus Soccer: Blown-Up Cars 6, Referees 0
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus  In retrospect, the low point was probably the sixth car bombing.

title: Extracting Structured Data From Recipes Using Conditional Random Fields
description: MathJax.Hub.Config({showProcessingMessages: false,tex2jax: { inlineMath: [['$','$'],['\\(','\\)']] }});

title: Clouds of Sils Maria (With Movie Trailer): Olivier Assayas Narrates a Scene
description: The writer and director Olivier Assayas takes a trip to Switzerland, by way of Italy, with his latest film Clouds of Sils Maria. It features Juliette Binoche as Maria Enders, a seasoned actress, and Kristen Stewart as her assistant Valentine. Maria agrees to take a role in the revival of a play she performed in 20 years before. In the scene in this video, Maria takes her assistant Valentine to the Swiss Alps to rehearse. During an interview at the New York Film Festival last fall, Mr. Assayas discussed the scene and how Italy stood in for Switzerland. Below are excerpts from that conversation.

title: Readers Respond: On Can Rand Paul Win With His Principles?
description: A number of readers responded hopefully to an editorial about Senator Rand Pauls presidential candidacy, saying its time for the Republican Party to listen to a broader range of voices.

title: The Many Looks of Amal Clooney, New Yorks New Fashion Darling
description: Some of the human rights lawyers stylish looks, spotted around town.

title: Neil Youngs Human Highway Finally Hits Theaters Decades Later
description: Neil Youngs image, circa 1982, was that of a dark, brooding, introspective rock star who couldnt get along with Crosby, Stills or Nash, and seemed intent on alienating his fans and his record label with Kraftwerk-inspired electropop. He was certainly not perceived as someone inclined to do a 90-minute Jerry Lewis impersonation in a movie designed as a drug-addled Wizard of Oz  one that ends in nuclear conflagration, rather than Kansas.

title: G.E. Seen Close to Selling Its Real Estate Portfolio
description: General Electric is poised to sell its enormous real estate portfolio in a sale that could fetch about $30 billion, according to people with knowledge of the matter who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

title: Kansas Tries to Stamp Out Abortion
description: During the past four years, the state of Kansas has become ground zero in the war to criminalize all abortions, and in the process to remove a womans ability to control what happens in her own body.

title: If We Cant Prevent Wrongful Convictions, Can We at Least Pay for Them?
description: A few weeks ago, a former prosecutor in Caddo Parish, La., named A. M. Stroud III wrote a letter to the editor of The Shreveport Times that quickly caught fire on the Internet. Over more than 1,400 anguished words, Stroud apologized for his leading role in the 1984 trial of Glenn Ford, a Louisiana man who was convicted of murder and spent nearly 30 years on death row in Angola, the states maximum-security prison, until last year, when his conviction was overturned and he was released.

title: Heirs to French Art Dealer May Benefit from Sale of Monet Lost During World War II
description: Much of the art collection of Ren Gimpel, a French art dealer who associated with the intellectual elite of his day, was lost during World War II when the dealer was detained by the Vichy government and shipped off by the Nazis to a German concentration camp.

title: Weekend Entertainments From the Archives of The New York Times
description: 112 YEARS AGO

title: Ahead of Watch Release, Apple to Allow Customers to Try It On
description: The era of online shopping made buy before you try (and ship back if you dont like it) a typical consumer experience. The Apple Watch, which comes out April 24, is probably something you should actually try before buying.

title: Portraits of People and Paper
description: SNEAK PEEK: This week Lens is featuring a selection of photographers attending the New York Portfolio Review.

title: Rand Paul Tells Republican Critics: War Is Not a Game
description: MOUNT PLEASANT, S.C.  Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky was defiant on Thursday as he answered fellow Republicans who have attacked his foreign policy as nave and misguided, telling them war is not a game to be exploited by over-zealous politicians.

title: Review: Personal Correspondents: Photography and Letter Writing in Civil War Brooklyn
description: Symbolically, the Civil War ended when Robert E. Lee surrendered to Ulysses S. Grant in a Virginia parlor on April 9, 1865, a century and a half ago this week. Officially, it concluded a year later, when President Andrew Johnson issued a proclamation of peace. For many people who lived through it, the war never ended at all.

title: Christen Wilson on What to Do in Dallas During Art Week
description: Tonight, the Dallas Art Fair previews its seventh edition at the Fashion Industry Gallery in Downtowns Arts District, drawing close to 100 galleries to a city more commonly associated with 10-gallon hats than bohemian berets. Few Dallasites are busier this week than collector Christen Wilson. In addition to chairing Dallass Nasher Sculpture Centers program committee and sitting on similar councils for the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York and Londons Tate museum, she and her husband Derek regularly open their museum-like Highland Park home to visitors and local art lovers alike. Last night, they hosted a reception for the Dallas Museum of Art, amid collection highlights from Sterling Ruby to Donald Judd and Eddie Peake on view. Here, Wilson shares her favorite spots around town  for Art Week or anytime.

title: Viewfinder: Marko Metzinger
description: The photographer Marko Metzingers new series finds symmetry and movement in unexpected places.

title: 11, and Reviewing His Parents Credit Card Bills
description: By the time your kids are applying to college, they ought to know how much money you make.

title: Word of Oil Find Near Gatwick Excites Britain
description: LONDON  Oil fever gripped Britain on Thursday after a small company announced the discovery of what it described as a possible world-class potential resource in the Surrey countryside south of London near Gatwick Airport.

title: Biden Cites Progress in Iraqs War With ISIS
description: WASHINGTON  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. offered an upbeat assessment of the battle against Islamic extremists in Iraq on Thursday, saying the government in that country was making significant and growing progress with help from the United States and its allies in the region.

title: Matt Harvey Quashes Uncertainty and the Nationals
description: WASHINGTON  When Matt Harvey took the mound Thursday for his first professional baseball game in 593 days, he kicked at the dirt in front of the rubber, paced off four steps toward the plate and drew a straight line. Every time he threw a pitch, his left foot would land on, or somewhere near, the end of the line.

title: Greek Finance Minister Steers Debt Talk His Way
description: PARIS  You would never know from his demeanor that Yanis Varoufakis, the celebrity Greek finance minister, was carrying the weight of a nation on his shoulders. In fact, you could be forgiven for thinking that it was his countrys uncompromising creditors who were on the defensive.

title: Natural Selection May Help Account for Dutch Height Advantage
description: Gert Stulp stands 6 feet, 7 inches tall. His height makes him especially self-conscious at scientific conferences when he rises to describe his research as a demographer at the London School of Tropical Medicine. Its always quite embarrassing, he said.

title: Lincoln Chafee Hits Hillary Clinton on Foundation Donations
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton has faced little dissension from fellow Democrats as she moves closer to running for president, but fresh signs of restlessness are emerging.

title: A Boyfriend Too Good to Be True
description: Eight years ago, my mother received an unusual call from her mother.

title: In 2012 Tribute, Rubio Asked What Would Jeb Do?
description: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida may have written Jeb Bushs campaign bumper sticker.

title: Biden Speaks of Progress Against ISIS
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said on Thursday that Iraqis, with help from the United States, have been making progress in the fight against the Islamic State.

title: Tensions Between Iran and Saudi Arabia Deepen Over Conflict in Yemen
description: CAIRO  Tensions between Iran and Saudi Arabia deepened on Thursday as Iranian leaders lashed out with rare vehemence against the continuing Saudi air campaign in Yemen, even hurling personal insults at the young Saudi prince who is leading the fight.

title: Disorder and Stray Dogs Capture the Look of Cities Falling Apart
description: To live in a large city, the German sociologist Georg Simmel observed in 1903, was to experience an intensification of nervous stimulation. Made just over a century later, Disorder  a found-footage documentary assembled by the Chinese filmmaker Huang Weikai  takes Simmels point to the far side of the moon.

title: Park Avenue Armory to Restore Tiffany-Designed Veterans Room
description: The blue-blooded Park Avenue Armory has announced the next stage of its modernization. The architecture firm Herzog & de Meuron will restore the buildings opulent Veterans Room, which has one of the few surviving interiors designed by Louis C. Tiffany and Company, the firm identified with the American Aesthetic Movement, led by Louis Comfort Tiffany, working with Samuel Colman, Lockwood de Forest, Candace Wheeler and Stanford White.

title: Deutsche Bank Nears Plea Deal Over Libor Manipulation
description: A long-running investigation into Wall Streets manipulation of interest rates is heading into a stark final chapter as authorities around the globe push Deutsche Bank to pay a record penalty and accept a criminal guilty plea for the unit at the center of the case.

title: Review: One of Us, by Asne Seierstad, on Anders Breiviks Rampage in Norway
description: The nonfiction horror story told in One of Us: The Story of Anders Breivik and the Massacre in Norway moves slowly, inexorably and with tremendous authority. Its a sober book that smells like fresh construction, a house built from plain hard facts. Youre forced to bring your own emotion, and it pools beneath the steady sentences.

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, April 12 to 18, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: After Bitter Loss, a Bittersweet One: Seven Are Leaving Kentucky Early
description: In October, the Kentucky mens basketball team held a two-hour open practice expressly designed for N.B.A. scouts who wanted to see the Wildcats draft prospects up close.

title: Wine Study, by Barge, in Burgundy
description: For passengers who want to drink in more than the scenery, three Burgundy-based barges run by the luxury tour operator Belmond will offer a new Wine Academy focused on educating oenophiles.

title: A Honey Lozenge of a Cocktail for Cold Spring Days
description: The sharp lens of Bill Cunningham revealed that by the end of March, we still hadnt shaken our winter black-and-whites. And this week, meteorologists predicted rain every day for the Big Apple  and rain it has. With restaurants reluctant to open up their gardens and sidewalk seating, New Yorkers have yet to savor that first al fresco drink of the season. Indoors, the Bowerys Saxon & Parole is passing the time until warmer weather arrives with the bartender Maxime Belfands Laddie Punch, a surprisingly light drink that warms the bones (thanks to bergamot tea) but isnt too heavy for April attitudes. Wintertime, we tend to use heavier spices like cinnamon or even anise or nutmeg, says Belfand, adding that in the summer, we crave a drink that has light botanicals in it. The addition of lemon and vermouth puts his Scotch-based summer drink somewhere between a Rob Roy and a honey lozenge, perfect for the rain-soaked bon vivant.

title: Bill to End Civil Forfeiture in New Mexico Awaits Move by Governor Martinez
description: In March, New Mexicos divided Legislature voted unanimously to end the contentious practice of civil forfeiture, which lets law enforcement agencies take property suspected of ties to crime even if no charges are ever filed.

title: Nationals Play D.J. and Try to Make Mets Feel Like Dust in the Wind
description: WASHINGTON  When the Washington Nationals finished batting practice here on Wednesday at Nationals Park and the Mets took the field, the slow, soothing tones of Rainy Days and Mondays, by the Carpenters, came over the loudspeakers.

title: Obama on Cubas Terror List Review
description: President Obama, appearing with the Jamaican prime minister, said that the State Department had completed its review of whether to remove Cuba from the list of state sponsors of terrorism.

title: Review: The Living Wades Into Domestic Abuse and Revenge
description: The neo-noir The Living, while bearing an impressive sheen for its modest budget, sells short its own potential. The story of a working-class man in rural Pennsylvania who in a drunken fever physically abuses his wife one night  setting into motion events involving a hit man hired by the wifes brother to avenge her injuries  flirts with a loaded topic but settles for mere genre exercise.

title: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Kenya, South Africa, Syria and Japan

title: Things to Do on Long Island, April 12 to 18, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Review: In Lost River, by Ryan Gosling, Surreal Scenes of Urban Decline
description: Like It Follows and Buzzard, Lost River uses bleak Michigan scenery as the backdrop for a form of horror film. Although set in a made-up city, the movie  the feature directorial debut of Ryan Gosling, who also wrote the screenplay  was shot in moribund Detroit neighborhoods. Dilapidated houses, overgrown lawns and abandoned buildings give this demented fantasia a surreal charge.

title: April 9, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Kenya, South Africa, Syria and Japan.

title: Review: Coypels Don Quixote Tapestries Weaves a Classic Tale
description: Miguel de Cervantess Don Quixote, whose first volume was published in 1605, has inspired and challenged illustrators from Goya to Dal. Few have captured the paradoxical essence of a book in which fantasy and reality collide to farcical effect over and over. Its a hard problem: How would you picture simultaneously the narrators vividly realistic, warts-and-all description of his hapless protagonists adventures and Don Quixotes own delusional view of himself as a knight errant in a simplified world of heroes, villains, giants and damsels in distress? How would you make visible such a contradictory double vision?

title: Note to Commuter: Make Yourself Heard
description: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio joined more than 60 mayors across the country on Thursday morning for a nationwide rally on behalf of the American commuter. Mr. de Blasio, Senator Charles Schumer and other bigwigs actually took the city subway (the R train) to make their point. The well-dressed cluster startled veteran subway riderswho are usually interrupted by people begging for money, not beseeching them to contact their members of Congress about the highway trust fund.

title: Retailers to Stop Sales of Controversial Supplements
description: Some leading vitamin stores have announced that they were pulling from their shelves a group of supplements that may contain a dangerous stimulant.

title: Bucking Trend, Pereira & ODell to Break With Its Brazilian Parent
description: Pereira & ODell, an advertising agency known for the long-form digital video campaigns it has created for clients like Skype, is breaking away from its holding company, a move that goes against an industry trend toward consolidation.

title: Listeria in Sabra Hummus Prompts New Wave of Recalls
description: Two food manufacturers have issued nationwide recalls of products because of the discovery of the potentially lethal bacterium listeria, which federal authorities have now linked to three deaths and five illnesses in Texas and Kansas.

title: New York Detective Is Suspended Amid Inquiry on Theft at Deli
description: A New York police detective has been suspended after a surveillance video appeared to show him taking money from a Brooklyn deli during a sweep of the store for loose cigarettes.

title: Married, With Roommates
description: Living with roommates is practically a rite of passage in New York City. It often begins with far too many people sharing too little space and ends with a move into an apartment of ones own, or with that special someone.

title: Taking Steps to Bridge a Divide
description: I am traveling abroad and staying with relatives who welcomed me into their home. They are Israeli migrs and have strong opinions on the Middle East. My boyfriend, whom I am also visiting here, is Muslim, but from a country far from the Middle East. One of my relatives said she is uncomfortable having my boyfriend in her home because he is Muslim. I was aghast. My boyfriend is the kindest man in the world. But my parents told me not to address her hurtful comment because she has been so hospitable. Help!

title: Lena Hall Rocks Out at, Yes, the Reserved Caf Carlyle
description: Early in her Caf Carlyle show on Wednesday evening, Lena Hall produced a tambourine and remarked that she might be the first performer to shake such an instrument in this staid cabaret, which until recently had avoided booking rock performers. But appearances there by Debbie Harry and Buster Poindexter, who have done good business, have signaled that the walls are crumbling.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Swords, Sleight of Hand and a Speaking Mummy
description: THE Luxor Mummy returns. Last seen onstage in the 1930s, the bogus but brilliant artifact, reputed to be a contemporary of King Tut, takes an encore at the Morbid Anatomy Museum in Brooklyn in the exhibition Do the Spirits Return?: From Dark Arts to Sleight of Hand in Early 20th Century Stage Magic. It opens on Saturday.

title: Opera & Classical Music Listings for April 10-16
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Citigroups Top Risk Executive, Brian Leach, to Depart
description: A top executive who oversees many of Citigroups risk functions is stepping down.

description: FROM ELEPHANT TUSKS INTO MEDIEVAL HORNS

title: Things to Do in Westchester, April 12 to 18, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Review: The Critique of Reason Revisits What Romantic Art Means
description: NEW HAVEN  In the popular imagination, the Romantic artist is a dreamy, introverted type. Picture Turner lashing himself to a ships mast, Delacroix whipping up feverish harem scenes or Caspar David Friedrich planting his solitary wanderers in misty landscapes.

title: Movie Listings for April 10-16
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

description: Theater

title: On Location | Redding, Conn.
description: Michael Ian Black and Martha Hagen-Blacks house was designed to catered to their way of life and reflected their every preference.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for April 10-16
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Things to Do in New Jersey, April 12 to 18, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Comedy Listings for April 10-16
description: Comedy

title: Amazon to Sell Predictions in Cloud Race Against Google and Microsoft
description: Welcome to the era of low-cost predictions. Your products and services will never be the same, and a couple of big companies may wish wed never arrived.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for April 10-16
description: Pop

title: Jazz Listings for April 10-16
description: Jazz

title: Review: In Ex Machina, a Mogul Fashions the Droid of His Dreams
description: The perfect 21st-century female looks like a million bucks though costs a great deal more. In Ex Machina, Alex Garlands slyly spooky futuristic shocker about old and new desires, the female in question is a robot called Ava, a name suggestive of both Adam and Eve. Ava has a serene humanoid face and the expressive hands and feet of a dancer, but also the transparent figure of a visible woman anatomy model. Beautiful and smart, sleek and stacked, Ava is at once decidedly unsettling and safely under lock and key, which makes her an ideal posthuman female.

title: Spare Times for April 10-16
description: Museums and Sites

title: Bushwick Flea Market Is Open for Browsing
description: Anyone who wants to find a flea market in New York doesnt have to try very hard. Although pop-ups can be found in places like school playgrounds and parking lots, there are also plenty of familiar mainstays like the Brooklyn Flea in Williamsburg and Fort Greene.

title: Dance Listings for April 10-16
description: Dance

title: Perella Weinberg Poaches Top Telecom Banker From Lazard
description: As the boutique investment bank Perella Weinberg Partners aims to expand, it has poached one of the top telecommunications bankers around  one who helped put together one of last years biggest deals.

title: On Game of Thrones, a Change of Scene
description: Winter may always be approaching in Game of Thrones, but as Season 5 of this HBO fantasy hit begins on Sunday night, it feels like springtime in the known world.

title: Spare Times for Children for April 10-16
description: Spring Wings

title: An Awkward Exception to Cruzs Recipe for Winning the White House
description: Since coming to Washington in 2013, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas has frequently used his public appearances to make a case that Republicans win the presidency only when they nominate bold conservatives.

title: Mamma Mia! to Close in September
description: Mamma Mia!, the hit musical based on the songs of the Swedish pop group Abba, will end its 14-year run on Sept. 5. The show, which opened at the Winter Garden on Oct. 18, 2001, and moved to the Broadhurst Theater in 2013, will close after 5,765 performances, making it the eighth-longest-running show in Broadway history, seen by more than 7 million people.

title: New Video Shows Start ofSouth Carolina Police Conflict as Routine
description: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C.  South Carolina officials investigating the weekend shooting death of a black man by a police officer here released a video Thursday that for the first time showed the early moments of an encounter that would ultimately reignite anger about police misconduct.

title: Review: Rebels of the Neon God Gets a New York Screening
description: In addition to having one of the best titles ever, Rebels of the Neon God marks the start of one of modern cinemas great careers. This film, which in spite of a worldwide cult following has never received a proper United States release, was the first feature directed by Tsai Ming-liang, whose subsequent work would establish him, alongside slightly older contemporaries like Hou Hsiao-hsien and Edward Yang, as a leading figure in the Taiwanese New Wave of the 1990s. (A retrospective of his work starts Friday at the Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens.)

title: Dash Cam Footage of Walter Scott
description: Dashboard camera footage of Walter L. Scott before he was shot.

title: In New York, Everywhere a Writing Nook
description: WORK and leisure dont have to be enemies. The writing life is proof of it. New Yorks coffee shops would be deserted if it werent for people scribbling and typing the day away. But when every seat is taken, the Wi-Fi is down and the only muffin left is bran, there are alternatives to being cooped up in the home office, and the citys legion of playwrights know them well.

title: Exiled Children of Tibet
description: Eight years old when he was sent into exile from Tibet, Tsering Topgyal has followed the lives of others who made a similar journey.

title: Review: Black Souls Depicts Crime Families Bound by Blood in Bad Ways
description: Except for one family member, the Carbones, a clan of goat-herding gangsters in Francesco Munzis film Black Souls belong to the Ndrangheta, Calabrias mafia, based in the rocky climes of extreme southern Italy. In their secretive culture of simmering blood feuds, vendettas and territorial rivalries, which has flourished since the 19th century, not a grudge is forgotten nor an insult overlooked. The peace is fragile, and a pall of suspicion hangs over their hometown, Africo.

title: Rand Paul Demands TV Stations Pull Iran Ad
description: Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky has been a presidential candidate for only three days, but he is already the subject of a blistering ad attacking his position on Iran. In response, he sent television stations showing the commercial a cease-and-desist letter demanding they pull it.

title: Review: With Bach as a Catalyst, Thierry Escaichs Lavish Concerto
description: Not many concertos for violin and oboe have entered the standard repertory. The best-known, as Alan Gilbert remarked during a New York Philharmonic concert on Wednesday, is Bachs splendid Concerto in C Minor for Oboe, Violin and Strings.

title: Turning to Big, Big Data to See What Ails the World
description: Like many fields, public health is in the midst of a data revolution: randomized control trials, pay-for-performance and value calculations, all based on data, are changing our ideas about what works and how to finance it.

title: Review: Broken Horses, Vidhu Vinod Chopras Modern Western
description: In Vidhu Vinod Chopras Broken Horses, a brave simpleton named Buddy (Christopher Marquette) follows the murderous orders of his boss, Julius Hench (Vincent DOnofrio), somewhere on the border with Mexico. Years ago, Buddy promised to build a ranch for his little brother, Jakey (Anton Yelchin), whose life took a different turn: He moved to New York, became a professional violinist and acquired an Italian girlfriend. When Jakey comes home to visit, a deeply silly drama of corrupted innocence ensues.

title: The Wise Words of Maya Angelou. Or Someone, Anyway.
description: THIS week the United States Postal Service celebrated the life and work of Maya Angelou, unveiling a stamp with her portrait and a lyrical quotation. Unfortunately, the words on the stamp do not appear to have originally been uttered by the poet. Instead, they come from the childrens book author Joan Walsh Anglund.

title: Review: Desert Dancer Tells the Story of the Afshin Ghaffarian
description: The fictionalized biopic Desert Dancer explores fascinating aspects of present-day Iran but suffers mightily from simplistic and sentimental tendencies. The debut feature of Richard Raymond, the film depicts the life of Afshin Ghaffarian (Reece Ritchie), a dancer who, frustrated by cultural repression, left the country in 2009. We follow him from childhood, when his instinct to perform at school leads to cautionary messages from his mother about government morality police. Later he attends the Saba Art and Cultural Institute and then a university in Tehran, where friends (played by Tom Cullen, Marama Corlett and Bamshad Abedi-Amin, among others) and a love interest (Freida Pinto) join him in a kind of secret college dance club.

title: This Weeks Movies | April 10, 2015
description: The New York Times film critics review The Longest Ride, Ex Machina, and Black Souls.

title: Oscar Broadcast Set for Feb. 28
description: Who will produce the next Academy Awards broadcast is yet to be announced, but the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and ABC have set the show date: Sunday, Feb. 28. In an announcement on Thursday, the academy and ABC also scheduled the 2017 Oscars, for Feb. 26, and the 2018 show, for March 4. Voting for the 2016 Oscar nominations will begin on Dec. 30 and close on Jan. 8. Final voting will begin Feb. 12 and end at 5 p.m. Pacific time on Feb. 23. Earlier, Craig Zadan and Neil Meron, who produced the last three Oscar shows, said they would not return as producers of the next ceremony. Academy officials have been reviewing the awards process and presentation after a drop in ratings for this years ceremony, which was hosted by Neil Patrick Harris.

title: Review: In The Harvest, Love Is Wielded With a Chill
description: Pity little Andy (a wan Charlie Tahan), stuck in a narrow bed in a cramped room, an IV pole and a wheelchair silently standing guard. Pity lonely Maryann (Natasha Calis), recently orphaned and transplanted to the countryside to be cared for by her solicitous grandparents (Peter Fonda and Leslie Lyles). And pity the horror fans who expect The Harvest to deliver the extravagant slicing and dicing that the genre commonly promises. Quieter, stealthier  and downright slow in parts  this sly dig at extreme parenting has virtually no blood and no weapon scarier than a hypodermic needle. Unless you count a mothers love.

title: A Yankee Fan Admits (Painfully) That Boston Has the Better Team
description: Can you hear it? Its the sound of a rumble readying in the Bronx. At least it would have been in years past. The Yankees meet the Red Sox on Friday for their first series in the post-Jeter era. There was a time when the teams rivalry was considered by many to be the greatest in sports  and a ticket to a game one of the hottest in town. Things have changed. Two reporters for The New York Times, one a die-hard Yankees fan, below, and the other a die-hard Red Sox fan, weigh in on whether the flame can be rekindled. Its up to you.

title: For a Sox Fan, Intensity Is Not Yet in Midseason Form
description: Can you hear it? Its the sound of a rumble readying in the Bronx. At least it would have been in years past. The Yankees meet the Red Sox on Friday for their first series in the post-Jeter era. There was a time when the teams rivalry was considered by many to be the greatest in sports  and a ticket to a game one of the hottest in town. Things have changed. Two reporters for The New York Times, one a a die-hard Red Sox fan, below, and the other a die-hard Yankees fan, weigh in on whether the flame can be rekindled. Its up to you.

title: Review: In Country, Young Men Play at Fighting in Vietnam
description: In Country is a stingy documentary. It gives you just enough information about its subjects, some Vietnam War re-enactors in Oregon, for you to be irked by them, but not enough to leave you confident that youve formed a fair opinion.

title: Arca, Valued Facilitator, Steps Out Front
description: Crashes, whooshes, sampled screams. Mournful minor chords, dissolving into distortion or receding into single notes and silence. Deep throbs of bass under splintery percussion. Ghostly processionals. Zaps of static, metallic scrapes, hovering insectlike buzzes. Slowed-down, half-melted hip-hop beats. Floating falsetto melodies under siege from stop-and-start chords. A synthesized cumbia mixed as if its tune were being intermittently obscured by clouds. Breakneck drum programming under orchestral strings.

title: Jobless Claims
description: Weekly number of people who have filed for unemployment benefits for the first time.

title: Freddie Mac Yields
description: Average for some Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. securities.

title: All Back in the Skull Together
description: Maccarone

title: The Dow Minute by Minute
description: Position of the Dow Jones industrial average at 1-minute intervals yesterday.

title: Jack Davidson: love, mistake, promise, auto crackup, color, petal
description: Theodore:Art

title: Alison Rossiter: Paper Wait
description: ALISON ROSSITER

title: Sascha Braunig
description: Foxy Production

title: On a Day for Good Scores at the Masters, Jordan Spieth Has a Great One
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Standing over his drive in the middle of the fairway on the par-5 15th hole at Augusta National Golf Club on Thursday, Jordan Spieth was eight under par for the day. Spieth, who is 21 years old, said he had no idea that the record for the lowest 18-hole score in Masters tournament history was nine-under 63.

title: Cooper Union Inquiry Puts Nonprofits on Notice
description: In what should be a ringing alarm for nonprofit boards across the country long accustomed to minimal scrutiny or accountability, Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman of New York has signaled that the laissez-faire approach to nonprofit governance is over.

title: SendGrid Account Breach Was Used to Attack Coinbase, a Bitcoin Exchange
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Hackers targeted SendGrid, a mass email service used by 180,000 companies including Uber, Pinterest, Spotify and Foursquare, to infiltrate Coinbase, one of the most popular Bitcoin exchanges.

title: Booker, Mentored by Menendez, Assumes Role as His Defender During Legal Fight
description: In his days as mayor of Newark, Senator Cory A. Booker built a national image of himself as a model citizen, given to well-publicized acts of valor like helping his neighbors escape a house fire and saving a vulnerable dog from the bitter cold.

title: Mexican Official Quits Over Helicopter Ride
description: MEXICO CITY  When a helicopter landed on a grassy patch in an exclusive suburb here on a recent Sunday morning, Ignacio Vizcano, a mathematician and aircraft enthusiast, snapped a few photos from his window  and set off the latest scandal to rock Mexicos political class.

title: Bronx Womans 10 Marriages, Not All of Them Over, Lead to Fraud Charges
description: The year 2002 was very busy for a young woman named Liana Kristina Barrientos.

title: Georgia Says It Will Allow Hormones for Transgender Inmates
description: Less than a week after the Justice Department intervened in support of a transgender inmates lawsuit against Georgia, the state said Thursday that it had ended its blanket denial of new hormone therapy to transgender inmates and would provide them constitutionally appropriate medical and mental health treatment.

title: Brought by Wild Neighbors, Deadly Bird Flu Attacks Turkey Flocks
description: A virulent, deadly flu virus has hit the nations turkey flock, forcing culling and quarantines that are disrupting trade with various countries.
