description: Olivia Delauren Martinez, a daughter of Josephine Rodriguez and Wilfredo Martinez of Winter Park, Fla., was married Friday evening to Benjamin David Gallagher, the son of Dr. Amy E. Jaroslow and Richard Gallagher of Tenafly, N.J. Jonathan Lippman, the chief judge of the State of New York, officiated in his Manhattan chambers.

title: Sara Putcha, Amit Trehan
description: Sara Putcha and Amit Kumar Trehan were married Saturday at the Pierre in Manhattan. Pandit Subrahmanyam M.K. Bhamidipati, a Hindu priest, officiated.

title: Thomas Rosato, Jack Garrity
description: Thomas Scott Rosato and John Thomas Garrity were married Monday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Angel L. Lopez of the New York City Clerks office officiated.

title: Rachel Glickman, Joshua Rosen
description: Rachel Alanna Glickman, the daughter of Deborah A. Glickman and Jeffrey G. Glickman of Jericho, N.Y., was married Saturday to Joshua Stefan Rosen, a son of Rosalie A. Rosen and Dr. Lon J. Rosen of West Orange, N.J. Rabbi Arthur Schwartz performed the ceremony at Temple Avodah in Oceanside, N.Y.

title: Whitney Cunningham, Jordon Giancoli
description: Whitney Ann Cunningham and Jordon Samuel Giancoli were married Saturday at the Fort Worth Botanic Garden. The Rev. Dr. Michael Waschevski, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Amelia Ashton, Evan Thorn
description: Amelia Hubbard Ashton and Evan Ritter Thorn were married Saturday at the Duke University Chapel in Durham, N.C. The Rev. Dr. Victor M. Wilson, a Presbyterian minister, led the ceremony.

title: Sunny Jenkins, Walter Hasselbring IV
description: Stephanie Miranda Jenkins and Walter Henry Hasselbring IV were married Saturday. The Rev. J. P. Reynolds, a Universal Life minister, officiated at Malibu Rocky Oaks Estate Vineyards in Malibu, Calif.

title: Seema Rasheed and Faisal Charania
description: Dr. Seema Rasheed and Faisal Charania were married Saturday evening in Texas at the St. Regis Houston by R. K. Sandill, the judge of the 127th District Court in Harris County, Houston.

title: Nicole Magoon, Jonathan Moran
description: Nicole Sasha Magoon and Jonathan Luke Moran were married Saturday. The Rev. Stephen Arbogast, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Washington National Cathedral.

title: Annie Robinson, Andrew Ward
description: Annie Walsh Robinson and Andrew Dehner Ward were married Saturday evening at Mission San Francisco de Ass, a religious settlement in San Francisco. The Rev. Xavier Lavagetto, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Anna Orsini, Andrew Margius
description: Anna Marissa Orsini, the daughter of Gaye R. Orsini and Richard L. Orsini of Marietta, Ga., was married Saturday evening to Andrew Thomas Margius, the son of Susan A. Margius and Thomas A. Margius of Milford, Conn. John Hoffman, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony at the Duke University Chapel in Durham, N.C.

title: Olympia Lettry-VauBan, Brenton McDonald
description: Olympia Lettry-VauBan and Brenton Gregory McDonald were married Saturday evening by the Rev. William J. Bergen, a Roman Catholic priest, at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Jennifer Queliz, Sean Strathy
description: Jennifer Ann Queliz and Sean Stephen Strathy were married Friday. The Rev. Cresus Fernando, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Anthony in Nanuet, N.Y.

title: Their Connections Stretch Back to Africa
description: Fatiah Dicha Touray and Mohamed Kaba Diakite were married Saturday at the Mint Museum Uptown in Charlotte, N.C. The Rev. Jacquie Mace, a Unity minister, officiated, with Ibrahim J. Touray, a brother of the bride who recited blessings from the Quran.

title: Jennifer Eng, John San Filippo
description: Jennifer Elizabeth Eng, a daughter of Kathleen A. Eng and Sidney H. Eng of Garden City, N.Y., was married Saturday to John Eugene San Filippo, a son of Catherine S. San Filippo and Philip E. San Filippo of Shrewsbury, N.J. John J. McKenna, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Joseph in Garden City.

title: It Took Time but Was Worth It
description: Margaret Mary Brennan and Maj. Ali Iyad Yakub were married Saturday evening at the Decatur House in Washington. The Rev. Raymond Kemp, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Kayla Tausche, Jeffrey Izant
description: Kayla McCall Tausche and Jeffrey Jacob Izant were married Saturday at the Cathedral of Christ the King in Atlanta. Msgr. Francis G. McNamee, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Timothy Fischer and Robert Huber
description: Timothy David Fischer and Robert Warren Huber were married Saturday at the Cathedral of All Souls in Asheville, N.C. The Rev. Thomas Murphy, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Raina Wallace and Orlando Sol
description: Raina Whitney Wallace, a daughter of Dr. Nancy Williams-Wallace and Raymond K. Wallace of Tampa, Fla., was married Saturday to Orlando Ivan Sol, the son of Elizabeth Capifali and Dr. Orlando I. Sol-Gomez of Amherst, Mass. The Rev. John Reese, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Andrews Episcopal Church in Tampa.

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 9 P.M. (HBO) GAMES OF THRONES  A fifth season begins as Jaime Lannister (Nikolaj Coster-Waldau) takes the road to Dorne to retrieve Myrcella (Nell Tiger Free), his niece-daughter. Brienne of Tarth (Gwendoline Christie) and Podrick Payne (Daniel Portman) are chasing Sansa Stark (Sophie Turner), who is still under the protection of Petyr Baelish (Aidan Gillen, above, with Ms. Turner). And Arya (Maisie Williams) and Tyrion Lannister (Peter Dinklage) have crossed the Narrow Sea to Essos, perhaps bringing resolution for Daenerys (Emilia Clarke), who has been cut off from the main cast for 40 episodes. Quibbles aside, Game of Thrones is still remarkable for both the scrupulousness and the lavishness of its production, beautiful to look at and mostly engaging to follow, though there is something of the accountants method in Mr. Martins fantasy  progress through constant addition  that transfers into the television show, Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times, referring to George R. R. Martin, on whose books the series is based. And while the beginning of Season 5 is a building period, without the big jolts that came early in Season 4, we can trust that the blood will flow more copiously before long. In the new season of Silicon Valley, at 10, Richard (Thomas Middleditch) and the rest of the Pied Piper team find their future jeopardized by big changes at their competitors, Raviga and Nucleus. And in Veep, at 10:30, the staff of Selina (Julia Louis-Dreyfus) has just 24 hours to figure out how she can say opposing things in her first major speech as president.

title: Corrections: April 12, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Obama Denounces Attempts to Derail Nuclear Deal With Iran
description: PANAMA  President Obama fiercely defended the framework nuclear agreement with Iran on Saturday and criticized those Republicans he said were politicizing foreign policy and working to derail the deal.

title: U.S. Steps Up Bombing Raids in Anbar After Shiite Militias Withdraw
description: BAGHDAD  Under pressure from American officials here, Iraq has withdrawn Shiite militiamen from the Ramadi area in Anbar Province, and the American-led coalition immediately responded by stepping up bombing raids to support Iraqi forces battling extremists of the Islamic State there, according to Iraqi officials involved in the decision.

title: When My Daughter Called Me, Sick, From College, I Got on a Plane
description: I went out to Michigan in January, the day after my daughter  a college freshman  called to tell me her throat was closing up. I cant breathe, she said, sounding as if she wasnt just being dramatic but actually couldnt breathe. Then she started crying. Can you just come out here, Mommy?

title: What Hillary Clinton Would Need to Do to Win
description: Mrs. Clinton can expect little if any opposition in the Democratic primaries. But she was similarly well positioned when she declared her candidacy in 2007.

title: 2 Killed in Shooting at South Korean Embassy in Libya
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Unidentified gunmen fired 40 machine-gun rounds at a guard post for the South Korean Embassy in Tripoli, the capital of Libya, early Sunday, killing two local police officers and injuring another, the South Korean Foreign Ministry said.

title: Day of Mourning for Walter Scott in South Carolina Town
description: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C.  Most of the congregation had left the sanctuary at the Charity Missionary Baptist Church on Sunday afternoon when yet another man approached Mayor R. Keith Summey and embraced him. Keep praying for me, Mr. Summey said softly. Keep praying for me.

title: Hillary Clinton Announces 2016 Presidential Bid
description: Ending two years of speculation and coy denials, Hillary Rodham Clinton announced on Sunday that she would seek the presidency for a second time, immediately establishing herself as the likely 2016 Democratic nominee.

title: Revolutionary War-Era Document Discovered in Cincinnati
description: A rare document associated with the Declaration of Independence has been discovered in the Cincinnati History Library and Archives, which will put it on display May 15 in the exhibition Treasures of Our Military Past at the Cincinnati Museum Center.

title: Hillary Clinton on the Issues
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton, a former secretary of state, has been most outspoken in recent years on foreign policy matters. But she has also taken positions on domestic and economic issues, like immigration and income inequality, that have been at the center of policy discussions since she left government. Here is a look at where she stands on some major issues.

title: John Dickerson, Political Director at CBS, Named as New Face the Nation Host
description: John Dickerson will be the new host of the CBS Sunday morning program Face the Nation after Bob Schieffer retires this summer. Mr. Schieffer announced the news on Sunday morning on his show.

title: Nelly Arrested on Drug Charges After Bus Is Stopped
description: The rapper Nelly was arrested on felony drug charges this weekend in Tennessee, Reuters reported. A state trooper pulled over the bus he was in and found marijuana, methamphetamine, and drug paraphernalia, as well as several handguns, the authorities said.

title: 1915: Holland Expects Many Americans
description: The Hague  Holland will enter upon a new era of popularity the moment the war is ended is the prophecy made by M. Rey, the manager of the Hotel des Indes, who is interested in the question of American travel on the Continent, so strongly negative by Mr. Roosevelt in his recent letter to the Herald.

title: Furious 7 Still in the Box-Office Drivers Seat
description: LOS ANGELES  Furious 7 continued to dominate the North American box office over the weekend, while the 10th film adaptation of a Nicholas Sparks novel, The Longest Ride, arrived to relatively muted ticket sales.

title: Smoking Marijuana for 50 Years, and Turning Out Just Fine
description: As much as Catherine Hiller refuses to admit it, marijuana is a gateway drug. Seriously, after smoking more or less every day for the past 50 years, there had to be some consequences. Yet, she did not go to jail after a random police stop. She did not end up strung out on heroin, sprawled in an alley. She didnt even binge-munch herself into obesity.

title: Game of Thrones Episodes Leaked Online Before Season Premiere
description: Game of Thrones begins its fifth season Sunday night  on television, at least. On the Internet, 4 of the seasons 10 episodes have already leaked.

title: Emails Reveal Discord Over Blackwater Charges
description: WASHINGTON  As prosecutors put the finishing touches on the 2008 indictment of Blackwater security contractors for a deadly shooting in Iraq, the F.B.I. agents leading the investigation became convinced that political appointees in the Justice Department were intentionally undermining the case, internal emails show.

title: Pope Calls Killings of Armenians Genocide, Provoking Turkish Anger
description: ROME  Pope Francis on Sunday described the World War I-era slaughter of Armenians by the Ottoman Turks as the first genocide of the 20th century, igniting a diplomatic confrontation with Turkey, which quickly summoned the Vaticans ambassador to condemn the pontiffs remarks and recalled its own ambassador to the Holy See.

title: Republicans Release Their Anti-Clinton Messages
description: Though Republican presidential hopefuls have already expressed differences on a variety of issues, when it comes to their opposition to a Hillary Rodham Clinton presidency, they clearly stand united.

title: No Hillary Clinton Endorsement Just Yet From Bill de Blasio
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons first campaign manager is not ready to offer his support for her soon-to-be-announced campaign just yet.

title: 1965: 239 Are Killed by Tornadoes in Midwest
description: CHICAGO  Savage tornadoes spread death and destruction through a six-state area of the Middle Western states yesterday [Apr. 12] and last night, leaving more than 235 dead and thousands homeless.

title: 2 Alabama College Students Charged in Spring Break Sexual Assault on Florida Beach
description: Two Alabama college students have been arrested on a charge of sexually assaulting a 19-year-old woman over spring break on a crowded Florida beach, law enforcement officials said.

title: Huge Head Start for Hillary Clinton, but the Big Race Is Far From Won
description: In the modern era, every major-party nominee who was not a sitting president has faced a primary fight. All except Al Gore, a sitting vice president, lost at least one state  and Mr. Gore came within four percentage points of losing the crucial early state of New Hampshire.

title: Podesta Says Shes In
description: Its official.

title: Hillary Rodham Clintons Political Life
description: Mrs. Clinton through the years.

title: Clinton Takes Supporting Role in Video to Open Campaign
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons initial campaign advertisement tries to establish a central theme: this run will not be about her.

title: Email From John Podesta About Hillary Rodham Clintons Presidential Bid
description: A copy of an email sent by Mr. Podesta obtained by The New York Times.

title: Review: Gore Vidals Thieves Fall Out, Where Pulp Fiction and Hard Reality Met
description: Then, still without a word, he took her in his arms, and it was as if a sudden storm passed over them and into them, carrying them to the bed and gathering momentum till finally it exploded in a flash of lightning, leaving them shaken and content. And Pete knew that it had never been like this before.

title: Hillary Clintons Announcement Video
description: On Sunday, Hillary Rodham Clinton released a video featuring the stories of a diverse group of Americans to announce that she will seek the presidency for a second time.

title: A Winning Deal in Pairs Play
description: The most previous editor of the Bridge Bulletin of the American Contract Bridge League, Brent Manley, began his career in the newspaper industry. But bridge lured him to Memphis, where the league headquarters were until a few years ago.

title: Sothebys Offering a Rothko Once Owned by Bunny Mellon
description: A Mark Rothko painting that was once owned by Rachel Lambert Mellon  better known as Bunny  will soon be up for auction at Sothebys.

title: The Inspiration of Staten Island
description: Locations around Staten Island that made up Eddie Joyces childhood.

title: Staten Island Helps Define a Natives First Novel
description: On the last day of his legal career, Eddie Joyce packed up his desk and turned in his security badge. He said goodbye to the partners and associates, to his six-figure salary, to his Park Avenue office.

title: After Winning Olivier Award in London, King Charles III Will Aim to Conquer Broadway
description: LONDON  King Charles III, a set-in-the-future play in verse by Mike Bartlett about Prince Charless accession to the British throne, won the award for best new play at the ceremony for the Olivier Awards, Londons leading theater prizes, on Sunday.

title: Vaudeville Authenticity at the Metropolitan Opera
description: Every so often, buried among the mezzo-sopranos, conductors and set designers, an unusual credit line jumps out of a Metropolitan Opera program.

title: With Arm and Bat, Bartolo Colon Steadies the Ship as Mets Head Home
description: ATLANTA  When the final out was recorded Sunday, and the Mets had beaten the Atlanta Braves, 4-3, Jeurys Familia had earned his first save of the season. But he did not celebrate. He did not scream, or stomp his feet, or pound his chest. Maybe he felt it would have been disrespectful or inappropriate.

title: At the Helm of a Philanthropists New Los Angeles Museum
description: LOS ANGELES  Being the director of Eli Broads new museum might strike some people as a contradiction in terms.

title: Review: Cucumber, a Logo Series Starring Vincent Franklin
description: Henry Best, a 46-year-old insurance executive from Manchester, England, is a profound portrait of self-loathing in comic form. Googly-eyed at the sight of beautiful young men, he lacks the self-confidence to pursue them. In a loving, committed relationship for nine years, he dismisses the idea of marriage  for him, the sudden availability of same-sex marriage is just an irritation.

title: Review: The Driver, on Acorn TV, Stars David Morrissey
description: The British actor David Morrissey probably already knew from his experience playing the Governor on The Walking Dead that wickedness has a gravitational pull. But he learns the lesson all over again in The Driver, a three-part suspense series on Acorn TV starting Monday.

title: Formal Charges May Be Next in Europes Google Antitrust Inquiry
description: BRUSSELS  As Europes antitrust investigation of Google has dragged on without a settlement for nearly five years, the American technology giant has had some breathing room to continue its domination of Internet search on the Continent.

title: Review: Fazil Say, Soloist, Composer and Even Conductor With Orpheus
description: Orpheus advertises itself as a conductorless chamber orchestra, and for the most part it is one, and a fine one. But what is to stop a guest soloist from grabbing every opportunity to coordinate and shape the ensembles sound, as the Turkish pianist and composer Fazil Say did in Mozarts Piano Concerto 23 in A on Saturday evening at Carnegie Hall?

title: Review: Shwe Man Thabin at Asia Society
description: Zat pwe, an outdoor Burmese performance dating to the late 1800s, is a busy, all-night affair in which Buddhist offerings mingle with court and folk traditions, acting, opera scenes, a percussion-and-gong ensemble and dancers who melt onto the stage like marionettes. In Myanmar, formerly known as Burma, such events end at sunrise, which is ushered in by the hna pa thwa, an unbroken, improvised sequence of dance, singing, acting and clowning.

title: Review: Dance Theater of Harlems Return Has Warm Reception
description: One thing that Dance Theater of Harlem seems to understand is how to please its public. At City Center on Friday, as the troupe presented the second program of a four-show return to a theater that had long been its home, a receptive audience expressed its approval enthusiastically and with increasing intensity through each of the four works. This beloved company is still in recovery after a hiatus from 2004 to 2013, but by the sound of it, the show was a smash.

title: Times Reporters Analyze Hillary Clintons Presidential Announcement Video
description: With her release of a video on Sunday announcing her candidacy for president in 2016, Hillary Rodham Clinton sought to chart the way forward. But the script and images also evoked a wave of memories from her past campaigns. Over instant messages just after 3 p.m., two New York Times correspondents analyzed the announcement video: Patrick Healy, who covered Mrs. Clintons 2007-08 bid for the Democratic nomination, and Maggie Haberman, who began covering Mrs. Clinton during her campaign to be a United States senator of New York in 2000. Here, lightly edited, is their full chat.

title: Amazon, Google and More Are Drawn to Home Services Market
description: The installation of Deborah Davids new kitchen faucet was a $145 job. But it lies at the heart of an expanding $400 billion commercial war.

title: Empty Nesters Favorite Beatle Song
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  Beatles songs are a lovely way to start the week. Alex Silverman appears to be making his debut in The New York Times today with a theme that reconfigures songs by the FAB FOUR as the favorites of people for whom the songs would be appropriate.

title: Rodale Broadens Its Organic Vision in Rebranded Magazine
description: When James Oseland was editor in chief of Saveur, the food magazine, he had dinner one night with Maria Rodale, the chief executive of the publisher Rodale. There, at ABC Kitchen near Union Square, they ran into Alice Waters, the acclaimed chef and champion of sustainable food.

title: Clinton Campaign Kickoffs Over the Years
description: How Hillary Rodham Clinton began her campaign for the United States Senate seat and for the presidency (twice).

title: A Long Drought on a Long River
description: Drought around the nearly 2,000 mile long Rio Grande has dried reservoirs and forced the region to find new water sources.

title: Hillary Clinton Resigns From Board of Clinton Foundation
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton told staff members at the Clinton Foundation that she was stepping down from the board in order to run for president, according to an internal email.

title: In Record Fashion, Jordan Spieth Captures the Masters Green Jacket
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  The University of Texas mens golf team played in a competition in California over the weekend without Jordan Spieth, who helped the Longhorns win the national title three years ago as a freshman.

title: Morbid Anatomy Museums Taxidermy Classes Offer a Slice of Life (and Death)
description: Down in the basement, dead pigeons lay on their backs, wings splayed, their bodies sliced open at the breastbone. White powder, an abrasive, was sprinkled liberally over the carcasses. Then a hand carefully reached in behind each of the birds knees and tugged, patiently pulling the torsos free from the wings.

title: Tribute on Ice to Gritty Competitors Who Made Syracuse the King of the N.B.A.
description: SYRACUSE  Three players for the Syracuse Nationals basketball team huddle before another game, in a back room of the concrete coliseum known as the War Memorial. They hunch in a half-circle as an official scribbles the strategy on an erasable white board.

title: Clinton Fund-Raising, for Starters
description: In 2008, there were the Hill-raisers. In 2016, there are the Hill-starters.

title: Group Discounts Benefit Commuter Train Lines and Passengers
description: Brad Ashley, a teacher for a high school in Chelsea, chaperones a hiking club for students who want an occasional weekend escape from the concrete confines of New York City.

title: Blackstones Deal With G.E. Highlights Its Real Estate Holdings
description: As Blackstones top executives fan out across the globe, pitching their services at elite gatherings of investors, they invariably tell the crowd: Hope you guys like this hotel, because we own it.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of April 13
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Grizzlies at Warriors
description: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

title: Political Violence Threatens Bangladeshs Garment Industry
description: Exports could be down 25 to 30 percent from last year as buyers shift to manufacturers in other countries.

title: Turmoil Between Political Leaders Has Harmed Bangladeshs People
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  The quickest way to grasp the nastiness of Bangladeshs season of political turmoil is to visit the high dependency unit at Dhaka Medical College Hospital.

title: Review: Scenario Embeds Secrets in Its Prose and Pauses
description: In Gillian Walshs Scenario: Script to Perform, the dancers never look up. On Thursday at the Kitchen, Maggie Cloud, Nicole Daunic, Mickey Mahar and Ms. Walsh walked into the bright, silent space clasping sheets of paper, heads bowed and eyes fixed on those pages, to remain there for most of the next 80 minutes.

title: Brazilian Protests Return as Scandals Intensify
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  For the second time in a month, thousands of protesters marched in cities across Brazil on Sunday calling for the impeachment of President Dilma Rousseff, who is struggling with a sharp economic slowdown, simmering bribery scandals and dismal approval ratings.

title: JPMorgan and Wells Fargo Earnings; March Retail Sales
description: Here are some of the top business stories to pay attention to in the coming week.

title: In Etan Patz Trial, Closing Arguments Are Expected to Focus on Confession
description: Lawyers will sum up 10 weeks of testimony on Monday in the trial of the former store clerk accused of killing 6-year-old Etan Patz, with each side expected to marshal arguments designed to sway the jury on a simple question: Did the defendant, Pedro Hernandez, tell the truth when he confessed to strangling the boy?

title: Working, but Needing Public Assistance Anyway
description: A home health care worker in Durham, N.C.; a McDonalds cashier in Chicago; a bank teller in New York; an adjunct professor in Maywood, Ill. They are all evidence of an improving economy, because they are working and not among the steadily declining ranks of the unemployed.

title: Sinai Group Kills Officers in Bombings
description: CAIRO  At least 12 people were killed on Sunday when militants linked to the Islamic State carried out three separate attacks on Egyptian security forces in the northern Sinai Peninsula, including bombing a police station, according to officials from the ministries of Interior and Health.

title: Mayor de Blasio Holds Off on Endorsing Hillary Clinton for President
description: She plucked him from obscurity to run her 2000 campaign for United States Senate, sat onstage at his swearing-in as mayor of New York City and, just this month, visited Brooklyn for a high-profile photo opportunity with his wife.

title: Wall Street Banks Mutual Funds Can Lag on Returns
description: Facing challenges on all fronts, Wall Street banks are pinning some of their hopes on a relatively simple business opportunity: creating mutual funds for ordinary savers.

title: Pattern of Safety Lapses Where Group Worked to Battle Ebola Outbreak
description: Partners in Health, a Boston-based charity dedicated to improving health care for people in poor countries, signed on to the Ebola fight last fall with high ambitions.

title: Popular Demand
description: The Interview, with Diana Bang, Seth Rogen and James Franco, was offered primarily on demand, online and via streaming services.

title: Rangers Are Potent Mixture of New Faces and Old
description: Rangers forward J. T. Miller was not shy about eavesdropping as the resident sage Martin St. Louis was asked about the teams youth infusion this season.

title: Saudi Spurns Call by Iran to Draw Back From Yemen
description: CAIRO  Saudi Arabias foreign minister accused Iran on Sunday of meddling in Yemen and pointedly dismissed Iranian appeals for the Saudis to end their bombing campaign, in the latest sign of deepening tensions between the regional heavyweights.

title: Coachella Festival Fends Off Rivals With Fresh Acts and Eye on Style
description: INDIO, Calif.  As the gates to Coachella opened Friday and thousands of fans began to stream across the grass of the Empire Polo Club here, Paul Tollett, the impresario behind the music festival, was as calm as could be.

title: Breaching Sacred Walls to Purchase Souvenirs
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  The Masters tournament ended Sunday. So did another tradition unlike any other. The Masters merchandise tents, open annually for just seven days, closed for another year.

title: Talks With Cuba Earn U.S. Raves in Latin America
description: PANAMA  And the new star in Latin America is ... the United States?

title: Milton Delugg, 96, Dies; Accordionist, Composer, Tonight Show Bandleader
description: Milton Delugg, who accompanied Al Jolson on the accordion, co-wrote the Nat King Cole hit Orange Colored Sky, conducted the band for Johnny Carsons The Tonight Show and was musical director of the Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade for three decades, died on April 6 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 96.

title: Terrorism Case Renews Debate Over Drone Hits
description: WASHINGTON  A Texas-born man suspected of being an operative for Al Qaeda stood before a federal judge in Brooklyn this month. Two years earlier, his government debated whether he should be killed by a drone strike in Pakistan.

title: Richard L. Bare, Prolific TV Director for Decades, Dies at 101
description: Richard L. Bare, a director whose career began during World War II and who became a Hollywood mainstay in the early days of television, died on March 28 at his home in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 101.

title: At the Head of the Pack, HBO Shows the Way Forward
description: In 2007, just as Tony Soprano faded to black, HBO fell into a deep slump. Forgettable shows like John From Cincinnati and Tell Me You Love Me did poorly, each lasting only a season. Its content cupboard was bare, and rival TV executives openly referred to the cable network as HB-Over.

title: Farmers Seek Other Water Sources as Rio Grande is Reduced to a Trickle
description: In a region that has replumbed entire river systems to build cities and farms where they would not otherwise flourish, the drought is a historic challenge, and perhaps an enduring one.

title: Was That Hillary Clinton Pumping Gas?
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton said she was going to hit the road. And she did.

title: Tiger Woods Finds Cause for Hope Amid Bumps, Pain and Young Upstarts
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Tiger Woods ended his 20th Masters in a groove, but like the one in a broken record, not the one he was in 14 years ago when he held all four major trophies concurrently. His physical health and a hole in his game again dominated the conversation after he closed with a one-over-par 73 at Augusta National Golf Club to finish at five-under 283, 13 strokes behind the winner, Jordan Spieth.

title: Hillary Clinton Starts to Detail Rationale for Run as Campaign Begins
description: For months, the suspense surrounding Hillary Rodham Clintons plans to make a second attempt at the White House had little to do with whether, and everything to do with why: What would be her rationale for seeking the presidency?

title: Game of Thrones Season 5 Premiere Recap: Stannis Emerging, Tyrion Unboxed
description: Here be spoilers and golden shrouds.

title: Review: In Ludic Proxy, a Blur of Actual and Virtual Reality
description: Nina, a Russian woman now living with her sister in America, finds herself back in her childhood apartment. She sees her mailbox, her mothers kitchenware, her fathers vodka bottles, all the books we left behind. But Nina isnt really home; shes watching her nephew play a version of the video game Call of Duty, set in Pripyat, the Ukrainian town she was forced to evacuate after the Chernobyl disaster.

title: Review: In Richard Eyres Production of Ghosts, the Clean Parts Are the Most Disturbing
description: So this is what all the fuss was about. Richard Eyres full-strength production of Ibsens Ghosts, which opened over the weekend at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, allows you to feel the bruising force with which this drama assaulted unsuspecting audiences of the late 19th century.

title: Review: An American in Paris, a Romance of Song and Step
description: The city of light is ablaze with movement in the rhapsodic new stage adaptation of An American in Paris that opened at the Palace Theater on Sunday, directed and choreographed by Christopher Wheeldon, a gifted luminary of the ballet world. This gorgeously danced  and just plain gorgeous  production pays loving tribute to the 1951 movie, to the marriage of music and movement, and to cherished notions about romance that have been a defining element of the American musical theater practically since its inception. Just about everything in this happily dance-drunk show moves with a spring in its step, as if the newly liberated Paris after World War II were an enchanted place in which the laws of gravity no longer applied. Even the elegant buildings on the grand boulevards appear to take flight.

title: Spring and Sneakers on the High Line
description: Dear Diary:

title: Coachella 2015: Punk Without the Dyed Blond Hair and Tank Tops
description: INDIO, Calif.  The temptation with a messy colossus like Coachella is to figure out its essence. Theres a theory that Coachella evolved directly from the southern-California rave and dance culture in the 90s. (The KCRW D.J. Jason Bentley, for instance, explains it in an interview in the Coachella Valley Independent this month.) But it has a connection to punk, too: Goldenvoice, the promoter behind the festival, used to put on punk shows in Los Angeles in the early 80s.

title: Stars Fade at Augusta as One Is Born
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  The Masters was first contested in 1934, but it now comes off as a made-for-TV event. With a natural stage that remains reassuringly familiar, it is a setting that historically summons final-day dramatics.

title: In the Yankees Reality Show, Its Alex Rodriguez, Flaws and All
description: Yankees fans had the first glimpse last week of life without Derek Jeter and life with Alex Rodriguez.

title: Brooklyn Man, 81, Is Sought in Fatal Stabbing of Relatives Ex-Boyfriend
description: An argument between an estranged young couple in Brooklyn turned deadly early Sunday, when an 81-year-old man intervened and stabbed and killed the young man with a knife, the police said.

title: Group Spells Out  5-Year Plan to Build Liberal Infrastructure
description: While Hillary Rodham Clinton was kicking off her very long-awaited presidential bid on one side of the country on Sunday, dozens of deep-pocketed liberal donors were meeting on the other side to ponder a progressive resurgence.

description: Season 2, Episode 1: Sand Hill Shuffle

title: Marco Rubio Builds Political Career on Defying Establishment and Odds
description: MIAMI  At 26, when Marco Rubio was such an inexperienced candidate that his father knocked on doors for him, he still defeated a West Miami city commissioner twice his age.

Farmers Seek Other Water Sources as Rio Grande is Reduced to a Trickle
description: In a region that has replumbed entire river systems to build cities and farms where they would not otherwise flourish, the drought is a historic challenge, and perhaps an enduring one.

title: Mighty Rio Grande Now a Trickle Under Siege
description: FABENS, Tex.  On maps, the mighty Rio Grande meanders 1,900 miles, from southern Colorados San Juan Mountains to the Gulf of Mexico. But on the ground, farms and cities drink all but a trickle before it reaches the canal that irrigates Bobby Skovs farm outside El Paso, hundreds of miles from the gulf.

title: After 8 Shots in North Charleston, Michael Slager Becomes an Officer Scorned
description: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C.  Michael T. Slager played cops and robbers as a boy in the Virginia woods, volunteered as an emergency medical technician after high school and earned an associate degree in criminal justice while working full time as a patrolman.

title: Veep Season 4 Premiere Recap: Shes Bebop Speaking
description: Season 4, Episode 1: Joint Session

title: Watching and Waiting for Long-Anticipated Clinton Announcement
description: Sunshine forsaken. Brunches and bike rides interrupted. The Masters on mute as golf lovers checked Twitter for the long-anticipated political news.

title: Wolf Hall Recap: Cromwell Shows Us His Two Sides
description: Episode 2

title: Hooking a Slippery Prize Where the Klamath River Meets the Pacific
description: KLAMATH, Calif.  The pursuit of eels at the turbulent mouth of the Klamath River begins at winters end, when the frogs start croaking and the great blue herons return to the riverbanks.

title: Though Petition Seeks His Ouster, Ferguson Mayor Says He Is Best Leader for City
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  Like many people who dive into small-town politics, James W. Knowles III, the mayor of Ferguson, wanted to tend to lifes everyday concerns when he first ran for elected office years ago: repairing streets, building parks, organizing festivals.

title: Seeking Voice in Iran Deal, Lawmakers Are Set to Act
description: WASHINGTON  After months of delicate negotiations with the Iranian regime, President Obama this week will face a high-stakes confrontation with defiant lawmakers  including members of his own party  who are intent on influencing diplomacy over the future of Irans nuclear program.

title: From Start to Finish, Spieth Dominates Masters
description: Jordan Spieth, 21, became the first wire-to-wire winner of the Masters since 1976.

title: The Kentucky Derby Dartboard: Week 3
description: Top contenders for the 141st running of the Kentucky Derby are listed in order of preference, with comments provided by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. Churchill Downs recently adopted a point system to determine the Derby field, with points being earned by the top four finishers in designated prep races. The odds are from the Churchill Downs futures pool, and the records are starts-win-place-show.

title: Forgotten Designs From the Memphis Groups Founder, Posthumously Produced by Kartell
description: As the most recent Design Issue of T investigates, the exuberant postmodern style of the Memphis Group is lately having a moment. Now, just in time for Salone del Mobile, the Italian plastics manufacturer Kartell is paying tribute to the movements revival by releasing a collection of previously unseen pieces designed by the groups founding father, Ettore Sottsass, near the end of his life. The vases, stools and lamp in the assortment were originally created by Sottsass for Kartell in 2004 and 2005 but never went into production; theyll make their debut at Kartells Memphis-themed installation at its retail flagship in Milan during design week. (The vase and stools are scheduled to hit Kartell stores later this year.)

title: Word of the Day | abscond
description: abscond  \ab-sknd, b-\  verb

title: Yankees Bats Take Focus Off Velocity of Masahiro Tanaka
description: The radar gun, once a relatively mysterious device that a scout might haul around in a suitcase, first gained notoriety in baseball around 1980 because of the man holding it: Mike Brito, a mustachioed scout who wore a distinctive white Panama hat and was a fixture at Dodger Stadium.

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 8 P.M. (Smithsonian) LINCOLNS LAST DAY Commemorating the 150th anniversary of the assassination of President Abraham Lincoln by John Wilkes Booth, this documentary uses computer-generated maps of 1865 Washington and artifacts from the Smithsonians National Museum of American History and from Fords Theater  among them, Lincolns gold watch and hat, and Booths diary and derringer  to piece together the movements of key players in the plot to avenge the defeated South after the Civil War and throw the future of the Union into question. In Living With Lincoln, at 9 on HBO, Peter Kunhardt chronicles his familys efforts to assemble and care for one of the largest private collections of 19th-century American photography, most of it devoted to Lincoln, across five generations. The Meserve-Kunhardt Collection  more than 73,000 items, including 57,000 prints and thousands of books, among other things  was bought by the Beinecke Rare Book & Manuscript Library at Yale last month.

title: Retailers Scrutinized for Schedules and Staffing
description: The office of the New York attorney general, Eric Schneiderman, is investigating 13 large retailers over whether increasingly unpredictable and on-call work schedules adopted by some employers in the retail sector violate New York labor laws.

title: Corrections: April 13, 2015
description: NATIONAL

title: Quotation of the Day
description: It seems that humanity is incapable of putting a halt to the shedding of innocent blood. It seems that the human family has refused to learn from its mistakes caused by the law of terror, so that today, too, there are those who attempt to eliminate others with the help of a few, and with the complicit silence of others who simply stand by.

title: China Limits Neighbors Visits to Hong Kong After Smuggling Complaints
description: HONG KONG  The Chinese government announced on Monday that residents of Shenzhen would be limited to one visit to Hong Kong a week, in a move to defuse public anger here over surging numbers of mainland Chinese visitors who cross the border to buy goods.

title: Mad Men Recap: Misplaced Nostalgia
description: Season 7, Episode 9: New Business

title: All in the Family With Lincoln
description: The legacy entrusted to generations of the Kunhardt family is not mere treasure, although it is priceless. Its more than just photographs, although their main subject is instantly recognizable, 150 years after his death. That subject is part of the family, even though he is not related to them by blood. He belongs to us all: Abraham Lincoln.

title: Trade Groups Seek Chinas Written Assurance on Tech Policy
description: HONG KONG  Despite a glimmer of progress after talks in March between the United States and China over a potential technology trade war, little has changed, according to a letter sent by trade groups to Chinese leaders on Monday.

title: Detained Feminists Loved Ones Plead for No Charges in China
description: Zheng Churan, the jailed womens rights advocate, loved rabbits as a child, earning the nickname Little Rabbit from friends and family.

title: Hallucinogenic Tea Time in Brazil
The A.F.L.-C.I.O., on the Trans-Pacific Partnership
A College Education for Prisoners
On the Trail of Super PAC Money
description: Two developments caught the attention of the political fund-raising world last week. First is the eye-popping amount of presidential campaign money Senator Ted Cruzs supporters reported raising in just a week  $31 million in big checks from affluent conservatives. This bonanza offers further evidence that the 2016 election has already become a runaway race of super PACs allowed to raise unlimited funds from uber-rich donors out to reap political influence.

title: It Takes a Party
description: So Hillary Clinton is officially running, to nobodys surprise. And you know whats coming: endless attempts to psychoanalyze the candidate, endless attempts to read significance into what she says or doesnt say about President Obama, endless thumb-sucking about her positioning on this or that issue.

title: When Taxes Arent a Drag
description: ANNOYANCE and dread. Thats what tax season brings for many Americans. But there is a large section of people for whom the bureaucratic paperwork of April means something else entirely: joyful anticipation.

title: Housing for the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: Conflicts of Interest at the F.D.A.
description: The Food and Drug Administrations lethargic regulation of dietary supplements containing a dangerous stimulant described in recent reports  in The Times is a classic example of what happens when industry representatives infiltrate the agency that is supposed to regulate them. The worrisome ingredient is BMPEA, a chemical nearly identical to amphetamine that is added to weight-loss and workout products in an effort to enhance their effect. Whether it does so is unclear, since there have never been tests of its effectiveness and safety in humans.

title: 152 Innocents, Marked for Death
description: However much Americans may disagree about the morality of capital punishment, no one wants to see an innocent person executed.

title: Kansas Abortion Law
description: To the Editor:

title: How Not to Protect Pregnant Women
description: CHICAGO  IN the wake of a savage attack on a pregnant woman and the removal of her fetus, Colorado lawmakers are planning to introduce a bill that would criminalize fetal homicide. If the bill passes, the state would join nearly 40 others that make fetuses a distinct class of victims. (The federal Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 similarly makes it a crime to kill or injure a fetus in certain circumstances.)

title: Walter Scott Is Not on Trial
description: I not only watched television pundits discuss the shooting of Walter Scott in North Charleston, S.C., last week, I participated in some of those discussions.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Hillary Clinton Announces Her Presidential Campaign

title: Should Schools Strive for Racial Diversity Among Teachers?
description: Do you have an adult in your life who is your role model, a sounding board to whom you can turn when you are challenged or just in need of a little guidance? If so, is that person a teacher? Is he or she the same race as you?

title: Letter From Families of Detained Chinese Feminists Calls for Their Release
description: The following is a translation of a letter sent by families and partners of five detained Chinese feminists to state prosecutors asking for their release. It was delivered in Beijing last Friday.

title: Spinster, by Kate Bolick
description: How does a woman move through the world alone? Kate Bolick posed this question in her 2011 cover story for The Atlantic, All the Single Ladies, explaining that she broke up with her intelligent, good-looking, loyal, kind boyfriend because she wasnt ready to settle down. But, she confessed: I feared I would be alone forever. Had I made the biggest mistake of my life? The tone fit neatly into the magazines preoccupation at the time with the Woman Problem, its steady flow of pieces about the terrible paradoxes of female life, from Anne-Marie Slaughters smart essay on the impossibility of having it all to Lori Gottliebs impassioned treatise urging women to settle for Mr. Not Quite Right to Caitlin Flanagans anachronistic dispatches in praise of the domesticated life. But it was Bolicks question  Can I spend my life alone and still be happy?  paired with photos of the attractive 39-year-old author sipping champagne in a bridesmaids dress, that had book publishers in a swoon that resulted in a bidding war and a high six figure deal from Crown.

title: Toni Morrisons God Help the Child
description: As children we have gentle, wordless expectations that the big people in our lives will endeavor to keep us from harm, or, at the very least, not harm us. Its the sacrosanct social contract: that adults will feed, clothe and protect us, that they will keep our bodies alive long enough for us to devise adult survival strategies of our own.

title: Chinas Island-Building Is Ruining Coral Reefs, Philippines Says
description: MANILA  Chinas island-building activities have destroyed about 300 acres of coral reefs and are causing irreversible and widespread damage to the biodiversity and ecological balance of the South China Sea, a spokesman for the Philippine Department of Foreign Affairs said on Monday.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Good morning.

description: Attention, American women, especially young women: Have you got the heart to save yours?

title: Gnter Grass Dies at 87; Writer Pried Open Germanys Past but Hid His Own
description: Gnter Grass, the German novelist, social critic and Nobel Prize winner whom many called his countrys moral conscience but who stunned Europe when he revealed in 2006 that he had been a member of the Waffen-SS during World War II, died on Monday in the northern German city of Lbeck, which had been his home for decades. He was 87.

title: ScienceTake | Shape Shifting Bacteria
description: Researchers analyzed how groups of rod-shaped E. coli bacteria dissolve their own cell walls and then, after generations, rebuild them.

title: New York Today: Tips for Tax Day
Simple Signal Spurs Complex Process of Fixing Cell Walls
description: One of the most important structures in nature is the cell wall. Not every living thing has them. Mammals, fish, squid, and insects get along fine without them. But plants, fungi and bacteria depend on them for various reasons, like keeping the cells together.

title: What Marco Rubio Would Need to Do to Win
description: Mr. Rubio will try to position himself as a next-generation conservative who can unite the Republican Party.

title: Why Survival Rate Is Not the Best Way to Judge Cancer Spending
description: In 2012, a study published in Health Affairs argued that the big money we spend on health care in the United States is worth it, at least when it comes to cancer. The researchers found that the survival gains seen in the United States equated to more than $550 billion in additional value, more than the difference in spending.

title: The Power of Light
description: My brother, Scott, kept the magnifying glass in his top desk drawer, with his pencils. On sunny days, he would take it to the driveway, sprawl out on his stomach and scan the asphalt for ants. I knew that he was incinerating the bugs with the lens, lasering them dead until smoke rose up from their carcasses. At age 7, I was a budding conservationist, preferring to rescue insects and the like rather than maim them. Still, I was curious.

title: Here Junior, Play With This
Philosophy Returns to the Real World
description: When I was in graduate school at Johns Hopkins in the early 1980s, I played on the intramural softball team of the postmodern literary theorist Stanley Fish. I recall his umpiring at a practice once when the batter, my buddy Mike, now a distinguished professor at Yale, argued a call. Fish good-humoredly pointed out that whats a ball and whats a strike is not an objective, external, or natural fact, its an interpretive practice; and according to that practice, whatever the umpire calls is real: If he calls it a strike, its a strike. (So that was a strike, Mike.)

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | April 13, 2015

title: Today in Politics: An Expected Announcement With Some Unexpected Twists

In Miami, the budding election season prepares for another official player, Senator Marco Rubio, and in South Carolina, the Rev. Al Sharpton seeks to keep the focus on a high-profile police killing. If that happens, she will be lucky to avoid the fight. Most of the concerns about an unopposed Clinton candidacy are overstated, and there are big reasons she will benefit from running unopposed in the presidential primary.

title: 1940: U.S. Citizens Urged to Leave
description: COPENHAGEN  All American citizens residing in Denmark were warned by the United States Consulate General today [April 13] to arrange to leave the country as quickly as possible. None of the 3,371 registered American citizens living in Denmark, Norway and Sweden so far have taken advantage of the State Departments offer to evacuate them by way of Germany and Italy to Genoa, Department officials said today.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 14, 1940

Its also worth remembering where much of his inspiration came from  in particular how he deeply loved the theater, his teacher from the rugged prairie to raging, war-torn Washington. It is not without a little irony that he was assassinated, 150 years ago this week, while enjoying the stage.

title: Fairy Tale Works From New Yorks Freshest Crop of Artists
description: One night every April, six floors within Tribecas acclaimed New York Academy of Art transform from artist studio space to an art fairlike showcase known as the Tribeca Ball. Current MFA students present years worth of work, bolstered by alumni and staff contributions, over cocktails and in the midst of roughly 700 gala attendees. There are more than 100 simultaneous presentations, and the Tribeca Ball stands as a top destination to discover emerging artists, learn first-hand of their creative processes and even leave with a unique piece of art (proceeds support both scholarships and public programs). The institution was co-founded by Andy Warhol in 1982, and the ball has been around since 1994, with a different theme each year.

Caproni of Federal District Court in Manhattan on Friday questioned whether Mr. Bharara had gone too far in public statements that castigated Sheldon Silver, the former New York State Assembly speaker, after he was charged with corruption.

title: Without Financial Aid, a Preschool Is Out of Reach
description: I just found out that my daughter was accepted to my top-choice preschool, but I dont know whether she will be able to go. Why? Because the annual tuition is three times what I spent for college, and without financial aid, theres no way I can afford it. While I would likely qualify on my own, her fathers income may take us out of the running  but right now, Im solely responsible for her expenses. The aid application process is ill-equipped to deal with nontraditional families like ours.

title: 1965: Niger Leader Escapes Assassin
description: NIAMEY, Niger  President Hamani Diori narrowly escaped assassination today [April 13] in a hand-grenade attack which killed a seven-year-old child and injured five other people. Mr. Diori later named his would-be assassin as Eniste Amadou Diop, who allegedly participated in uprisings by clandestine commando groups last October. Reports said the grenade was thrown at a group of government officials attending ceremonies to mark the beginning of the Moslem feast of Aid el Kebir. Diop was arrested as he was about to throw another grenade, the reports said. The names of the casualties were not available, but they reportedly included a member of parliament and three members of the visiting Mali soccer team.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 14, 1965

title: Juvenile Sea Turtles Are No Slackers
description: Sea turtles six to 18 months old are active swimmers that work hard to find favorable ocean habitats, according to a new study in Current Biology. Scientists know little about the so-called lost years that young turtles spend at sea before returning to coastal areas to forage and reproduce. Juvenile sea turtles were thought to passively drift with ocean currents. Researchers discovered otherwise after using satellite telemetry to track 44 young turtles in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: J.J. Martin on Where to Eat, Drink and Shop in Milan During Salone del Mobile
description: As the international design set descends on Milan for another edition of the Salone del Mobile fair, which begins tomorrow, one American expat waits with open arms: J.J. Martin. The California native moved to the city 14 years ago to be with her Italian husband and has devoted herself to exploring its charms ever since, first as a journalist and Wallpaper magazine contributing editor and more recently as the founder of LaDoubleJ.com, an editorial and e-commerce site devoted to the best style and vintage shopping the city has to offer. I have gotten an incredible hands-on education in fashion and design in Milan just by doing my job, she says. I feel like its the biggest, most international small town in the world. Here, on the eve of the fair, Martin offers up suggestions for where to eat, drink, shop and explore in her adopted hometown.

description: Comic writing is generally undervalued by the American critical establishment, if not by readers. In the last 40 years, only two novels with significant comic ambitions have won the National Book Award: James McBrides The Good Lord Bird and Philip Roths Sabbaths Theater. John Kennedy Tooles A Confederacy of Dunces was arguably the last purely comic novel to win the Pulitzer, in 1981.

title: Headphones Perfect for Listening to Ts Favorite New Track  All Day Long
description: Its rare that you hear a track over and over, against your will, and still crave the beats and vocals after the audio assault is over. Working 12 hours on set for the music video of Rihannas Whats My Name?, featuring Drake, I thought Id heard enough playbacks to get my fill for a lifetime. Yet I still find myself humming ooh na na out of the blue every now and then, scrambling for my iPhone to pull the song up. And Kanyes All Day is the latest earworm to lodge itself into my brain.

title: General Electrics Days as Wall Streets Golden Goose May Be Numbered

The conglomerate has been the best corporate client for investment bankers over the last 15 years, spending some $5.1 billion for advice and assistance. description: BARCELONA, Spain  Lluis Miquel Venteo Fernandez is a longtime Barcelona fan, so he had a specific opponent in mind for his beloved soccer team when the matchups were announced for this weeks Champions League quarterfinals.

title: Walkabout: China Limits Travel to Hong Kong
description: Restricted Travel China is limiting visits by residents of Shenzhen to Hong Kong, according to Xinhua, the official Chinese news agency. The move comes as tensions increase over mainland Chinese residents who travel to Hong Kong, primarily to shop. (NPR)

title: Questions and Answers About the Armenian Genocide
description: Pope Francis description of the killing of Armenians 100 years ago as a genocide has caused a diplomatic uproar with Turkey and elevated resilient historical arguments about what really happened. The arguments are likely to intensify as Armenia prepares to officially commemorate the event in less than two weeks.

title: Easy Solution for Shrimpers and Smelt Alike
description: For the past four years, trawlers on the West Coast have been hauling in vast amounts of pink shrimp, much of it destined for dainty salads and shrimp cocktails across the country. But though these have been boom times for shrimpers, many are uneasy.

title: Rosario Dawsons Adventures in Ghana, Celebrating Women and Her First Clothing Collection
description: As dusk fell on a weekday last month, a four-wheel-drive barreled down a jungle path in the central region of Ghana, carrying Rosario Dawson, who, rubbed clean of makeup, less resembled a Hollywood actress than her latest role as a fashion entrepreneur studying agroforestry and sustainable cotton practices on a century-old plantation. During a break from promoting her new Netflix series, Marvels Daredevil (released last Friday), Dawson, 35, had escaped a New York snowstorm to spend six days in Ghana and oversee production of her first full collection for Studio One Eighty Nine, a line of recycled glass jewelry and batik cotton and indigo separates. The company was cofounded and soft launched with her best friend Abrima Erwiah in 2013. We wanted to do something we both valued and loved, she said, adding that they both grew up on Manhattans Lower East Side and realized the need to do something social-minded.

title: Review: Flip FabriQues Other-Worldly Catch Me!
description: The young members of Flip FabriQue claim to be French Canadian, but after watching them perform, you may suspect that they hail from a different planet. At the end of Catch Me! (Attrape-Moi), their circus show at the New Victory Theater, I half-expected Agents J and K from Men in Black to enter and blast the audience with ray guns to expunge our memories of an alien encounter.

title: The Trouble With .Sucks
description: How much should a website address that ends in .sucks cost? Should such web addresses even exist to begin with?

title: In Performance | Lesley Manville
description: Ms. Manville plays the aggrieved widow Helene Alving in Richard Eyres production of the Ibsen drama Ghosts, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music through May 3.

title: TV Review: Other Space Explores Familiar Territory
description: Outer space is crowded, and not just with asteroids and old weather satellites. Its full of filmmakers and TV creators, who have been joking about space travel gone awry at least since A Trip to the Moon in 1902. So anyone trying to boldly go there these days has to put more effort into the venture than went into Other Space.

description: Photos from Sudan, Syria, Ukraine and France.

description: What lurks behind the literary landmarks of Victorian London? Fear? Joy? Ambiguity?

description: Antonio Weiss, the former Wall Street banker who became a top adviser to the Treasury secretary this year, has made two trips to Puerto Rico in recent weeks.

description: Two concerts, two British mezzo-sopranos, two rising British accompanists  and two performances of Mahlers Rckert Lieder.

description: VILLAGERS

description: Countless words have been written about John Wilkes Booth since he shot Abraham Lincoln in Fords Theater 150 years ago on Tuesday. But the assassin, amazingly, has not yet received a full-dress biography.

title: Talent vs. Buzz: the Push-Pull of Coachella
description: INDIO, Calif.  I hope you all realize that music is sacred, Jack White said, near the end of his headlining set at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival on Saturday night. He repeated it: That music is sacred! That music is sacred!

title: Review: Misty Copeland in the Washington Ballets Swan Lake
description: WASHINGTON  The Washington Ballet, founded in 1976 just presented its first full-length Swan Lake. This notable fact, however, is not what has gained the production national attention. That would be the casting. At the Kennedy Center here on Thursday and Sunday, the leads of this archetypal classical work were both taken by African-American dancers, one of them an increasingly famous guest star from American Ballet Theater: Misty Copeland.

description: Catch up on the days top stories.

description: Its an inevitable reaction. A good performance of Purcells Dido and Aeneas leaves you thinking of what might have been had Purcell lived longer.

description: The Republic of Armenia has received what could be its biggest tourism boost to date: a visit from the Kardashians.

IBM Creates Watson Health to Analyze Medical Data
description: IBM is taking its Watson artificial-intelligence technology into health care in a big way with industry partners, a pair of acquisitions and an ambitious agenda.

title: American Flags Popping Up in Cuba on Everything but a Pole
description: HAVANA  The diplomatic thaw between the United States and Cuba has been accompanied by an unexpected outburst of flag-waving here  of the American flag.

title: New Plan to Shrink Rikers Island Population: Tackle Court Delays
description: There is rare consensus among inmate advocates and correction officials that the surest way to fix the Rikers Island jail complex is to empty it.

title: Fueling Up for a Long Campaign: Hillary Clinton Lunches at Chipotle
description: Driving to Iowa for her first campaign swing on Monday, Hillary Rodham Clinton stopped for lunch at a Chipotle in Maumee, Ohio, outside Toledo. Tipped that she had been there, I called the manager, Charles Wright, but he insisted I was wrong. He offered to check the security footage, though  and there it was. His employees, he said, were kicking themselves.

title: Gazprom Warns Europe Over Price of Natural Gas
description: BERLIN  The head of Gazprom, the Russian energy giant, warned European customers on Monday that if their countries angled for a single price for natural gas, it would most likely be at the higher end of the range they now pay.

description: Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential campaign is all about everyday Americans, she made clear in announcing it on Sunday.

description: Festival fashion statements at the first weekend of Coachella.

title: Witnesses to Indian Loggers Killing Dispute Police Claims of Self-Defense
description: NEW DELHI  The decades of cat-and-mouse between the police and red sandalwood smugglers have yielded some extraordinary stories: of precious, fragrant logs hidden among bags of flour or inside lengths of PVC pipe, of crime kingpins who, when not smuggling sandalwood, had sidelines in trafficking opium and humans.

title: Best-Selling Science Books
description: 1 Being Mortal by Atul Gawande. Metropolitan/Holt. The surgeon and New Yorker writer considers how doctors fail patients at the end of life, and how they can do better. (1)

description: Introduce a new advertising technology, and a political campaign will find a way to raise money with it.

description: This past winter, Nicholas Gottlieb, the father of a third grader and a sixth grader in Manhattan, helped organize a citywide forum against standardized testing during which more than 200 parents and teachers talked about ways to attack the issue from different angles.

description: In an age when viewers increasingly fast-forward past television commercials on their DVRs or bypass most advertisements altogether by streaming the programs, companies are constantly looking for new ways to reach consumers.

description: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C.  After Julius G. Wilson was stunned with a Taser in August, he and his lawyers considered filing a complaint against the officer who discharged it, Michael T. Slager. For months, though, they did not act.

description: Last year, Dani Rylan wanted to bring a New York expansion team into the Canadian Womens Hockey League, the home for womens pro hockey in North America since 2007.

title: New Report on Washington Post Writer Seen as Prelude to Espionage Trial
description: An Iranian news report that suggests that an imprisoned Washington Post correspondent is a spy who furnished economic and industrial data to the Central Intelligence Agency was viewed by friends on Monday as a sign that a trial might be held soon.

title: Long a Glass Half Empty, Citi Field Brims With Confidence
description: The Mets announced in the ninth inning Monday that the crowd at their home opener  43,947  had set a regular-season record for Citi Field. It sounded like a joke because the ballpark, now in its seventh season, has never hosted a postseason game. It was an All-Star Game, two years ago, that holds the record.

title: BlackRocks Chief, Laurence Fink, Urges Other C.E.O.s to Stop Being So Nice to Investors
description: On Tuesday morning, the chief executives of 500 of the nations largest companies will receive a letter in the mail that will most likely surprise them.

title: Sheila Kitzinger, Childbirth Revolutionary, Dies at 86
description: Sheila Kitzinger, a British anthropologist who encouraged women around the world to reclaim from doctors their natural prerogative over pregnancy and childbirth, died on Saturday at her home in Oxfordshire, England. She was 86.

title: One Companys New Minimum Wage: $70,000 a Year
description: The idea began percolating, said Dan Price, the founder of Gravity Payments, after he read an article on happiness. It showed that, for people who earn less than about $70,000, extra money makes a big difference in their lives.

title: Eduardo Galeano, Uruguayan Voice of Anti-Capitalism, Is Dead at 74
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Eduardo Galeano, the Uruguayan writer who blended literature, journalism and political satire in reflecting on the vagaries, injustices and small victories of history, died on Monday in Montevideo, Uruguay. He was 74.

title: Senate Leaders and White House Make Their Cases on Iran Deal Legislation
description: WASHINGTON  Leaders of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee negotiated into the night on Monday to soften language and possibly shorten a congressional review period in legislation that would give Congress influence over the shape of President Obamas nuclear accord with Iran.

title: Brooklyn Man, 81, Charged in Stabbing Death of Granddaughters Ex-Boyfriend
description: An 81-year-old Brooklyn man was charged with manslaughter on Monday, a day after the police said he fatally stabbed his granddaughters estranged boyfriend during an early morning fight.

title: Capitals, Seeking Scoring Balance, Tinker With a Dynamic Twosome
description: WASHINGTON  For all of Alex Ovechkins accomplishments with the Washington Capitals, it is hard to mention him without including Nicklas Backstrom in the same breath.

description: The grass-roots energy building around the minimum wage issue may upend Hillary Rodham Clintons plans to ease into proposing specific economic policies.

title: From Cybersecurity to Trade Deal, Bills Are Expected to Start Moving
description: WASHINGTON  After a lengthy stretch of legislative somnolence, interrupted occasionally by frenetic action to prevent the government from shutting down, Congress is now pivoting to policy.

title: Stressing Youth, Marco Rubio Joins 2016 Field
description: MIAMI  Senator Marco Rubio, the 43-year-old son of Cuban immigrants, on Monday declared that it was time for his generation to lead the country, portraying himself as the youthful future of a Republican Party that has struggled to connect with an increasingly diverse electorate.

title: Teenager Whose Stray Bullet Killed Man on Brooklyn Bus Goes on Trial
description: Sitting at the back of the B15 bus on a Thursday evening in March 2014, Kahton Anderson, then 14, pulled a gun from his backpack, shot once and killed a father of two who was heading home from his job as a fruit vendor.

title: Kelley Paul Has a Task: To Make Rand Paul More Approachable
description: Before Senator Rand Paul formally announced his campaign for president last week, he used to get one question all the time: What would stop you from running?

Man Gets 25 Years to Life for Hit-Run That Killed Brooklyn Couple and Son
description: A man was sentenced on Monday to 25 years to life in prison  an unusually harsh penalty  after being convicted of crashing into a livery cab in Brooklyn and killing a couple and their son, who was delivered shortly after the accident.

title: Review: 39 Steps, Frenetic Thriller Spoof, Rises Again
description: Silliness, it would appear, has been gravely undervalued as a survival strategy. How else to explain the unquenchable life  or rather lives, for there have been many  of Richard Hannay, the charmingly fatuous fop who keeps defying death all over the world and has now returned to fight bad guys with bad accents in New York at the Union Square Theater?

title: Review: Iowa Is a State of Absurdity at Playwrights Horizons
description: Aiming for the endearingly zany, the new musical Iowa overshoots the runway, landing somewhere in the vicinity of complete inanity. This oppressively antic show, about the uneasy relationship between an introverted teenage girl and her excessively  make that lunatically  outgoing mother, plays like a series of songs, scenes and sketches with little connecting tissue.

title: Bit of Mind Reading
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  Well, you cant say that Bruce Haight makes life easy for himself, at least not after todays puzzle.

title: Sierra Leone: Ebola Trial Begins
description: Researchers began vaccinating volunteers in Sierra Leone with an experimental Ebola vaccine in a study officially begun on Monday. The trial, the third to begin in the West African countries hardest hit by Ebola, is sponsored by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Sierra Leones Health Ministry and the University of Sierra Leones College of Medicine and Allied Health Sciences. Scientists aim to enroll 6,000 health workers. The vaccine, rVSV-EBOV, licensed by Merck and NewLink Genetics, has also undergone testing in Liberia, Guinea, the United States and other countries. Earlier research showed that the vaccine is protective in nonhuman primates, but it has not yet been proved to prevent Ebola in humans. The epidemic is declining in Sierra Leone, which on Monday reported two new cases.

title: Sex, Dementia and a Husband on Trial at Age 78
description: There is no question that Donna Lou Rayhons had severe Alzheimers.

title: Stung by Popes Remarks on Armenian Genocide, Turkish Minister Insults Argentina
description: Turkish officials continued to vent their fury at Pope Francis on Monday, one day after he called the mass killing of Armenians a century ago the first genocide of the 20th century, at a commemorative mass at the Vatican.

description: HarperCollins has signed a deal with Amazon to sell its books, much like the contracts the online bookseller has reached with other publishers.

title: Rare Jolt by Stephen Drew Lifts Yanks Over Orioles
description: BALTIMORE  Easygoing and soft-spoken, with a smooth Georgia drawl, Stephen Drew does not play with any more of an edge than he speaks with. His is not the sort of demeanor that can endear players to fans at Yankee Stadium when their performances do not.

title: Routed by Bulls, Nets Still Hope for Playoffs but Need Help
description: The Nets were encouraged by a late-season surge that gave them control of their playoff destiny.

title: Equal Pay Day Highlights a Likely Theme for Clinton
description: The partner organization of EMILYs List, the group dedicated to electing women, is trying to focus attention on policies that support women and their families ahead of Tuesdays Equal Pay Day.

title: Sweet and Savory Italian Desserts, the Jody Williams and Rita Sodi Way
description: Climbing plants, hanging vines and potted herbs set the scene for Edible Schoolyard NYCs annual spring benefit last night  and true to the programs mission of championing a healthy, just and sustainable food system, some of those greens are being replanted in the school gardens. The enchanting decor was not lost on the evenings patrons, who snuck Ball jars of basil and chives into their goodie bags after dinner  prepared by some of the areas best chefs, from David Chang (the events culinary chair) and Tom Colicchio to April Bloomfield and Camille Becerra  and dancing (in the company of the Momofuku team, starring alum Kevin Pemoulie, owner of Thirty Acres, and his wife Alex).

title: How to Cook Savory Spring Oatmeal, Brooklyn Style
description: Over the weekend, George Weld and Evan Hanczor, the duo behind Williamsburgs Egg restaurant, did what they do best: share the art of breakfast with perfect strangers in Brooklyn. They set up a very Southern hash bar at Smorgasburg flea market, and showcased recipes from their week-old cookbook, Breakfast: Recipes to Wake Up For ($35, Rizzoli), at the annual Food Book Fair. Its no secret the duo is passionate about pushing good, wholesome food in the wee hours of the day (and sources many of the kitchens seasonal ingredients from its own farm upstate).

title: Study Finds Broad Rise in Medication Use by Those Newly Joining Medicaid
description: People newly covered by Medicaid drove a significant increase in prescription drug use in 2014, even as those with private commercial coverage filled fewer prescriptions and, over all, patients did not visit the doctor as often, according to a new report by the IMS Institute for Healthcare Informatics, which tracks the health industry.

title: Christopher McDougall Wants You to Go Outside
description: The author Christopher McDougall helped make barefoot running mainstream with his best-selling book Born to Run, a tale about a tribe of endurance runners and an annual 50-mile footrace in the mountains of Mexico.

description: bereavement  \bi-rev-mnt, be-\  noun

title: Sheldon Silvers Son-in-Law Is Arrested and Charged With Securities Fraud
description: A son-in-law of the former State Assembly speaker was arrested on Monday and accused of defrauding investors out of $7 million, according to a criminal complaint unsealed in federal court.

title: Whats on TV Tuesday
description: 7:10 P.M. (Starz) THE IDES OF MARCH (2011) George Clooney, Grant Heslov and Beau Willimon received an Oscar nomination for best adapted screenplay for this political drama, which Mr. Clooney also directed and stars in as Mike Morris, a Pennsylvania governor turned dream candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination. Ryan Gosling plays Stephen Meyers, a strategist who becomes involved with an intern (Evan Rachel Wood) with a powerful father and a secret that could derail Stephens career and the Morris campaign. Philip Seymour Hoffman and Paul Giamatti are advisers battling for Stephens loyalty. And Marisa Tomei is a reporter trying to get at the truth. Mr. Clooney handles the plot complications with elegant dexterity, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this adaptation of Mr. Willimons play Farragut North, loosely based on Howard Deans 2004 presidential primary campaign. As an actor he works best in long, understated scenes that allow him to play with nuances of charm and menace, so it is not surprising that, as a director, he gives the rest of the cast room to work, Mr. Scott added. But the parts of The Ides of March  quiet scenes between Mr. Gosling and Ms. Wood; swirling, Sorkin-esque exchanges of banter; any time Ms. Tomei or Max Minghella (as a campaign worker grooming himself to be the next Stephen Meyers) are in the room  are greater than the whole.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: So much of aging and so much of being in a long-term care facility is about loss, loss of independence, loss of friends, loss of ability to use your body. Why would we want to diminish that?

title: Spotting Hope in Pakistan
description: Most photographs in Pakistan depict something awful or its immediate aftermath: suicide bombings, a horrible earthquake, even more horrible floods, unimaginable grief. The Spanish photographer Diego Ibarra Snchez, who made Pakistan his home for five years, saw something different amid all the tragedy: hope.
