title: Dont Keep the Trans-Pacific Partnership Talks Secret
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  WHEN WikiLeaks recently released a chapter of the Trans-Pacific Partnership Agreement, critics and proponents of the deal resumed wrestling over its complicated contents. But a cover page of the leaked document points to a different problem: It announces that the draft text is classified by the United States government. Even if current negotiations over the trade agreement end with no deal, the draft chapter will still remain classified for four years as national security information. The initial version of an agreement projected by the government to affect millions of Americans will remain a secret until long after meaningful public debate is possible.

title: Making Sense of Water
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  Almost every number used to analyze Californias drought can be debated, but this can be safely said: No level of restrictions on residential use can solve the problem. The solution lies with agriculture, which consumes more than its fair share.

title: The Lost Language of Privacy
description: Like a lot of people, Ive come to believe that it would be a good idea to put body-mounted cameras on police officers. I now believe this for several reasons.

title: Marijuana Economics
Women Still Earn a Lot Less Than Men
description: Tuesday is Equal Pay Day, the day selected each year by the National Committee on Pay Equity, a coalition of womens, civil rights and labor groups, to draw attention to how much longer women must work to earn what men earned in the previous year. In 1963, when President John F. Kennedy signed the Equal Pay Act, a woman working full time year-round typically made 59 cents for every dollar paid to her male counterpart. By 2013, the latest year of available census data, it was 78 cents on the dollar. Another measure of the wage gap, computed by the Institute for Womens Policy Research, shows that, in 2014, the ratio of female-to-male weekly earnings was 82.5 percent.

title: Iraqs Cycles of Revenge
description: The Iraqi government billed its recent operation to wrest control of the northern city of Tikrit from fighters for the Islamic State as a significant victory. The Pentagon is echoing that upbeat view about the war against the terrorist group, also known as ISIS or ISIL, which the United States is fighting with an aggressive air campaign and with the training of Iraqi troops.

title: What Lincoln Left Behind
description: John Wilkes Booth shot Abraham Lincoln at Fords Theater, in Washington, on the evening of April 14, 1865, and within hours, telegrams and newspapers began to deliver the news around the country. As horrible as Lincolns murder seems to us today, it is hard to fathom just how earth-shattering it was for many people at the time. It was shocking enough that this was the first presidential assassination in American history. But it also came at a moment  less than a week after Gen. Robert E. Lees surrender at Appomattox  when Americans were either celebrating victory or despairing at defeat.

title: Rival Factions in Ukraine Are Urged to Withdraw Heavy Weapons
description: BERLIN  Warring parties in Ukraine should withdraw heavy weapons  including tanks, armored vehicles, mortars and artillery  in order to comply with the shaky cease-fire that has held in eastern Ukraine since late February, the German foreign minister said early Tuesday.

title: Nokia in Advanced Merger Talks With Alcatel-Lucent
description: LONDON  It is a paradox of the digital age: Even as smartphones and high-speed Internet access become more crucial to everyday life and commerce, the makers of the equipment that underpins those networks can struggle to make money.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Coachella Festival Fends Off Rivals With Fresh Acts and Eye on Style
description: In Coachella Festival Fends Off Rivals With Fresh Acts and Eye on Style, Ben Sisario writes about Coachella, whose ticket sales far exceed any other music festival in the United States.

description: Here are several paragraphs from an April 11 article, House That Wouldnt Budge (or Float Away) Faces a Last Stand.

description: How does a true believer in Irans theocracy confront what even he admits is a losing battle against modernity and his governments nuclear deal with the Great Satan and world powers.

title: Obama Gives Visiting Iraqi Premier Aid and an Endorsement
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama gave Haider al-Abadi, the prime minister of Iraq, a full-throated endorsement and $200 million in humanitarian aid on Tuesday, but the visiting leader left the White House still in need of billions more dollars to cope with plunging oil prices and a yawning budget deficit.

title: Fighting Homelessness, One Smartphone at a Time
description: Holly Leonard has been homeless on and off for years. There was a stint in jail and, more recently, a period in a womens homeless shelter, while her husband slept in their car.

title: For Canadiens, Heightened Expectations Apply Not Just to Players
description: MONTREAL  At Bell Centre, there is a team that cannot wait for the N.H.L. playoffs to begin.

title: In Perception Primary, Its Folksy Hillary Clinton vs. Statesmen-Looking Jeb Bush and Marco Rubio
description: On one side is a crowd of Republicans trying to look presidential. On the other side is a lone Democrat trying to look normal.

title: Docker Raises Another $95 Million in Funding
description: Another day in tech, another company tops $100 million in money raised.

title: Should Toys Be More Gender-Neutral?
description: Walk into a toy store, and you are likely to see toys specifically designed and marketed for boys or girls  without very much overlap. With pink and blue color coding, and princess and action-hero designs, manufacturers seem to be using more and more gender messaging to sell their toys.

title: Bold Look for a Landmark
description: The 14-acre project to develop air rights over the tracks will feature 1,300 residential units, retail space, more than 500 hotel rooms, and parks and plazas.

title: Union Station in Washington Has a Grand Development Plan
description: WASHINGTON  This citys venerable Union Station, which opened with much fanfare in 1908, was never about the federal union but about the union of two railroads whose separate terminals had formerly occupied valuable space blocks apart, even encroaching on the National Mall.

title: The World Before Us, by Aislinn Hunter
description: Our dead are never dead to us, until we have forgotten them. This line from George Eliot, quoted before the opening of The World Before Us, will turn out to be the key to this strange and absorbing novel. Time and place are juggled between two narratives, two sets of characters: present-day Jane, a 34-year-old archivist at a London museum, and the inhabitants of a country house and neighboring lunatic asylum in late-19th-century Yorkshire. Jane has been haunted all her adult life by a terrible event that occurred when she was just 15: A 5-year-old girl, Lily, went missing while Jane was minding her and was never found. In that other, long-ago time, another girl disappeared, on the day two of those incarcerated in the asylum made a temporary breakout. In Janes mind, these stories become interwoven as she tries to pursue truth and broods about identity.

title: The Fishermen, by Chigozie Obioma
description: One of the most remarkable literary developments of the past decade has been the more or less simultaneous eruption onto the world stage, after a long fallow period, of nearly a dozen popular new novelists from Africa. Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, NoViolet Bulawayo, Teju Cole, Alain Mabanckou and Dinaw Mengestu are all young African writers who have worked in America. Many teach at or are graduates of creative writing schools, institutions that are sometimes scorned for being literary factories. Yet these writers voices, anything but undistinguished, are as distinct as the African countries they come from, whether Nigeria in the west, Zimbabwe in the south or Ethiopia in the east.

title: Between You & Me, by Mary Norris
description: Copy editors are a peculiar species (Ive been one myself, and at the very publication you are now reading). But those at The New Yorker are something else entirely, a species nova that mutated into existence in 1925 and would hurl itself off a cliff rather than forsake the dieresis in coperate.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: New York Today: A Campaign Whodunit
description: Good morning on this changeable Tuesday.

title: Despite Release, Feminists Case Shows Chinas Hostility Toward Civic Action
description: BEIJING  Though liberated from the confines of jail cells in western Beijing, the five young womens rights activists who have won broad international support, including from Hillary Rodham Clinton and other political leaders, remain criminal suspects in the eyes of the police and the Chinese judicial system.

title: The Last Reel
description: As cinemas across the United States transition to digital projectors, this short documentary celebrates the beauty of traditional 35-millimeter film.

title: The Last Reel
description: Theres something special about going to the movies: As viewers become immersed in the film, their faces relax, and their eyes widen a bit, in a moment of un-self-conscious wonder. Movies give us a capacity for awe.

title: Mets Hope Harvey Can Lift Attendance as Gooden Did
description: Back in 1985, Dwight Gooden was Matt Harvey, and more. In his second season in the major leagues, at 20, he went 24-4 with a 1.53 earned run average, threw 16 complete games (which would be unthinkable these days), had eight shutouts and struck out 268 batters in 2762/3 innings of work.

title: Instagrams TMZ
description: The first time I heard about The Shade Room, I thought it was a reality show, or maybe a nightclub. It turned out to be neither, although I was close in spirit; its a new celebrity-entertainment publication with hundreds of thousands of readers and a secretive owner, which lends it an air of mystery and intrigue. When I arranged to meet this person at a restaurant in Downtown Brooklyn, I wasnt quite sure who, or what, to expect. But I located her right away: a petite young woman absorbed in the glow of her supersize smartphone.

title: The Muddied Meaning of Mindfulness
description: Most newly stylish coinages carry with them some evidence of grammatical trauma. Consider affluencer, selfie, impactful. Notes of cynicism and cutesiness come through. But every now and then a bright exception to this dispiriting routine appears. A rookie word makes its big-league debut, a stadium of pedants prepares to peg it with tomatoes and  nothing. A halfhearted heckle. The new word looks only passably pathetic. Maddeningly, it has heft.

title: Her Majestys Jihadists
description: He was a dreamer, with Che Guevara looks  a jet-black beard and eyes  who built a new persona online, as a Muslim warrior riding into battle in the back of an open-bed truck, dressed in black, his long hair blowing in the breeze, with an AK-47 hanging from his shoulder, strapped to his back. He had just turned 22  the product of British private schools, a computer aficionado working in customer service at Sky News  when he decided to turn his dream into reality.

title: Today in Politics: Rubio Leaps In From Miami, and Clinton Hits the Road
description: Good Tuesday morning from Washington, where commemorations are beginning for the 150th anniversary of President Lincolns assassination. This week, the Capitol prepares for its first congressional yoga sessions, and former Senator Bob Graham is still scribbling in his notebooks. In Miami, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida joined a growing field of presidential contenders, and Hillary Rodham Clinton made her way to Iowa, with stops for lunch, in a van. Her campaign team there says it has big plans for small events to show her humble side.

title: The Worst Tax Breaks
Daily Report: In Silicon Valley, Helping the Homeless With Tech
description: Holly Leonard has been homeless on and off for years. There was a stint in jail and, more recently, a period in a womens homeless shelter, while her husband slept in their car, reports Claire Cain Miller.

title: U.S. Soldiers, Back in Iraq, Find Security Forces in Disrepair
description: CAMP TAJI, Iraq  Lt. Col. John Schwemmer is here for his sixth Iraq deployment. Maj. James Modlin is on his fourth. Sgt. Maj. Thomas Foos? Its so many, I would rather not say. Sir.

title: Weekly News Quiz | March 31-April 13, 2015
description: We were on spring break at the beginning of April, so the quiz below covers two very newsy weeks.

title: Network Security Start-Up Illumio Raises $100 Million
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In its quest to create a platform for networking security, the start-up Illumio has drawn a number of prominent backers.

title: Citigroup Names New Head of Consumer Bank inManagement Shuffle
description: Citigroup said on Monday that it had shuffled its executive ranks as Manuel Medina-Mora, its co-president and the head of its global consumer bank, prepares to retire.

title: Stephen Colbert, Trevor Noah and Julia Louis-Dreyfus to Join Seinfeld in Coffee-Centered Web Series
description: A familiar face from Jerry Seinfelds television past and a couple of newly ascendant late-night hosts are among the performers that will share road trips and caffeinated beverages with him in the newest episodes of his online show, Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee.

title: In Performance: Lesley Manville of Ghosts
description: This weeks video features the Olivier Award-winning actress Lesley Manville as Helene Alving, the aggrieved wife and mother at the center of Ibsens family drama Ghosts. In this scene Helene recalls the pain she and her son endured because of her husbands years of lies and affairs. In his review of the show, which opened on Sunday, Ben Brantley writes that Ms. Manville charts her characters varying repression and awareness with a scalpel-edged exactitude. Directed by Richard Eyre, the production continues through May 3 at the Brooklyn Academy of Musics Harvey Theater.

title: A Lineup of Missteps
description: This week, an extra-large grab bag of grammar, style and other lapses, compiled with help from colleagues and readers.

title: Taking the Torch From Sarah Brady: Why Doctors Need to Ask About Guns in the Home
description: Last week, while reading the obituary of the gun control activist Sarah Brady, I couldnt help but be struck by the poignant juxtaposition of her tireless crusade for gun safety with the Texas Legislatures consideration of a bill that would prevent physicians like me from inquiring about gun ownership in the home.

title: A Thumb Drive on the Sidewalk
description: Dear Diary:

title: JPMorgan Chase Profit Rises 12% on Strong Trading
description: JPMorgan Chase delivered stronger-than-expected first-quarter results on Tuesday, thanks to a rebound in some of the big businesses that had been lagging and fueling criticism of the company.

title: I.M.F. Warns of Uneven Economic Growth
description: WASHINGTON  The International Monetary Fund warned on Tuesday that continued weak growth in emerging economies would reduce global growth despite an improving outlook in the United States and Europe.

title: A Congressional Delegation of the Downward-Facing Dog
description: Congress has been long contorting itself in all kinds of uncomfortable positions as lawmakers struggle to bridge partisan divides.

title: Nuclear Reactors in Japan Remain Closed by Judges Order
description: TOKYO  Fukui Prefecture, with 13 commercial nuclear reactors clustered along a short, rugged coastline, has earned the area a reputation as a political stronghold for the atomic power industry. Nuclear-friendly politicians dominate most of Fukuis government offices, and the region is nicknamed Genpatsu Ginza, or Nuclear Alley.

title: Luxury Families in Court: Is All Publicity Good Publicity?
description: Gucci is not the only luxury name whose founding family has been tangled in a legal web, though it may have been the most dramatic, what with the former wife of the heir Maurizio Gucci convicted back in 1998 of ordering his murder. (Indeed, it was so dramatic, Ridley Scott tried to make a movie about it.)

title: Shooting Arrows at Hillary Clintons New Campaign Logo
description: Its just a blue letter H with a red arrow through it, but because it is Hillary Rodham Clintons new campaign logo it is the subject of much debate.

title: How a Hudson Highlands Mountain Shaped Tussles Over Energy and the Environment
description: On Sunday, I spent the afternoon accompanying my wife as she led a hike up Storm King Mountain, the imposing northern terminus of the ancient, history-rich and stunning Hudson Highlands.

title: Morning Agenda: Fink Tells Chiefs to Not Be So Nice
description: FINK TELLS CHIEFS TO NOT BE SO NICE | You could call Laurence Fink, chief of BlackRock, No More Mr. Nice Guy. On Tuesday, he plans to send a letter to the chief executives of 500 of the nations largest companies to say that too many of them are taking shareholder-friendly steps like paying dividends and buying back stock, which arent in their long-term interests,  Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column.

title: Hillary Clinton Is People
description: After a week off from writing, let me ease gently back into punditry by talking about a couple of the more interesting takes onHillary Clintons weekend announcement video, in which the candidate herself appeared at the end of a series of micro-portraits of Americans who are, like her, getting ready for a significant moment or pivot point in their lives. (Thats a snark-free summary, at least.) The first piece, from Peter Beinart at the Atlantic, argues that the videos cast of characters alone tells us something important about the kind of campaign Hillary thinks she can run this time  namely, a confidently liberal one:

title: Hillary Clintons Chipotle Order: Above Average
description: On Monday, Hillary Rodham Clinton ordered a burrito bowl at a Chipotle outside Toledo, Ohio.

title: Wells Fargo Posts Rare Decline in Quarterly Net Income
description: Wells Fargos profit machine showed signs of slowing in the first quarter as the bank reported a rare decline in net income from a year ago.

title: Whats New in Milan, Paris and Manchester, England
description: A dozen different European destinations, including Macedonia and the Faroe Islands, made our list of 52 Places to Go in 2015. And since the list was published in January, a few of them have enjoyed the opening of cultural centers and exhibitions. Milan, which topped our list, is gearing up for one large event beginning in May. Heres a rundown of highlights this spring.

title: Shabab Carry Out Deadly Attack on Ministry Building in Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Militants detonated a car bomb outside the Ministry of Higher Education building in Mogadishu, the capital of Somalia, and then stormed into the building on Tuesday, witnesses and officials said. The attack left at least 19 people dead, including seven attackers, and 15 more were wounded.

title: A Book Fair in Buenos Aires
description: The 41st Buenos Aires International Book Fair takes place April 21 to May 11 at La Rural, fairgrounds in the Argentine capital.

title: Marco Rubio: An Upshot Debate About His Chances
description: Marco Rubios chances of winning the Republican nomination have been the subject of a friendly debate around The Upshots offices in Washington. Here, David Leonhardt and Nate Cohn hash out that debate. They conducted the conversation via Google chat on Monday, and its been lightly edited.

title: Readers Turn: Sleep Deprivation
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: 10 Hotels in Europe That Make You Feel at Home
description: Taking up temporary residency on the quiet lanes and public squares of Europe offers the sort of civic intimacy that often eludes mere sightseers. Location and a connection to community distinguish each of the following 10 hotels, all of which offer a strong sense of place, both outside and in.

title: 1940: Italians Told War May Come
description: ROME  Italy must not allow itself to be awakened by the bugle calls of invaders, Signor Ansaldi, editor of Count Galeazzo Cianos newspaper, the Telegrafo, said in a broadcast to Italys armed forces today [April 14]. If bugles must sound, we shall be the ones to sound them, he declared.

title: Are Grand Historical Events Better Fodder for Fiction Than Everyday Life?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. A weekend is a much bigger character than Watergate, Wilfrid Sheed said. This week, Thomas Mallon and Francine Prose debate whether grand historical events are better fodder for fiction than everyday life.

title: Blue Jays, Bills, Timberwolves and Oilers Are Parched in the Postseason
description: Saturday, Oct. 23, 1993. SkyDome, Toronto. Bottom of the ninth, two men on, one out. Mitch Williams of the Philadelphia Phillies is on the mound, facing Joe Carter of the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Sonia Delaunays Fashionable Legacy, at the Tate Modern (and on the Runway)
description: Spring has sprung at Londons Tate Modern, where a new exhibition celebrates the work of Sonia Delaunay in living color. Its the first British retrospective of the Franco-Russian artist whose rich career spanned six decades  and as many media. Alongside paintings that summon the modernist spirit in bright, abstract brushstrokes, there are textiles and tapestries, which the artist used to cover everything from books to lampshades, furniture to fashion, including the embroidered coat that belonged to the 20s film star Gloria Swanson.

title: A Book Fair in Buenos Aires
description: The 41st Buenos Aires International Book Fair takes place April 21 to May 11 at La Rural, fairgrounds in the Argentine capital.

title: Aftermath of Attack in Somalias Capital
description: The Somali police and residents in Mogadishu combed through the debris on Tuesday after a suicide bombing outside the Ministry of Higher Education killed at least nine people.

title: Obama Yields, Allowing Congress Say on Iran Nuclear Deal
description: WASHINGTON  The White House relentedon Tuesdayand said President Obama would sign acompromisebill giving Congress a voice on the proposed nuclear accord with Iran as the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, in rare unanimous agreement, moved the legislation to the full Senate for a vote.

title: 1965: U.S. to Step Up Air Attacks
description: WASHINGTON  U.S. air attacks on North Vietnam will be stepped up in an effort to persuade the Hanoi regime to accept President Johnsons proposal for unconditional peace talks, U.S. officials said today [April 14]. They said the United States does not consider Hanois initial rejection of Mr. Johnsons suggestion as necessarily the final word. As for North Vietnams counter proposals for restoring peace in the area, they got a cold reception in Washington.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 15, 1965.

title: A Math Problem From Singapore Goes Viral: When Is Cheryls Birthday?
description: A couple of months ago, it was a color-changing dress that blew out the neural circuits of the Internet. Though it may not have quite the mass appeal, this week it is a math problem that is making bushels of brains hurt.

title: How to Figure Out Cheryls Birthday
description: If you have not already, read about the question first.

title: Draft Resolution on Yemen
description: The Security Council on Tuesday imposed an arms embargo on the Houthi fighters battling for control of Yemen.

title: Why Californias Approach to Tightening Vaccine Rules Has Potential to Backfire
description: In a number of states, parents are allowed to opt out of legal requirements to have their children vaccinated before entering school by claiming a personal belief or philosophical exemption. These provisions have raised a great deal of concern since the Disneyland measles outbreak, including in California, where it began. Unfortunately, the blundering approach state legislators there have taken shows how direct attacks on exemptions can rally the anti-vaccine cause.

title: Verbatim: Boehner Pushes Iran Deal Review
description: Speaker John A. Boehner, discussing an agreement over Irans nuclear program.

title: Drivers License Suspensions Create Cycle of Debt
description: LEBANON, Tenn.  The last time Kenneth Seay lost his job, at an industrial bakery that offered health insurance and Christmas bonuses, it was because he had been thrown in jail for legal issues stemming from a revoked drivers license. Same with the three jobs before that.

title: First Draft Focus: Hillary Clinton Rolls Into Iowa
Palestinian Doctors Can Drive Own Vehicles Into Israel, Agency Says
description: JERUSALEM  Dozens of Palestinian doctors who work in Israel will be allowed to drive their own vehicles into the country from the West Bank, the Israeli agency dealing with Palestinian civilian affairs said on Tuesday. The decision, exempting the doctors from a blanket ban in force for 15 years, is the latest in a series of recent steps to relax constraints on Palestinians entering Israel.

title: Conflict in the Air: Readers React
description: Marie Tae McDermott is a news assistant and comment moderator for The Times.

title: U.S. Plans Stiffer Rules Protecting Retiree Cash
description: Federal regulators on Tuesday proposed rules, more than four years in the making, to provide greater consumer protection for retirement savings, requiring a broader group of investment professionals to act in their customers best interests when handling their retirement money.

title: N.B.A. Playoff Standings and Lottery Possibilities: Updated Wednesday
description: With one night to go in the N.B.A. season, the playoff situation is still uncertain, especially in the West. But there is almost as much focus on the bottom of the standings, where the leagues weakest teams are jockeying for the best chance at a top draft pick.

title: Theres No Mayonnaise Like My Mayonnaise
description: MAULDIN, S.C.  The South has a penchant for odd loyalties, which goes a long way toward explaining why a man from North Carolina last year ordered a customized Dukes mayonnaise jar in which to store his remains.

title: Atlanta School Workers Sentenced in Test Score Cheating Case
description: ATLANTA  In an unexpectedly harsh sentence after a polarizing six-year ordeal, eight of the 10 educators convicted of racketeering in one of the nations largest public school cheating scandals were sentenced to prison terms of up to seven years Tuesday after they refused to take sentencing deals that were predicated on their acceptance of responsibility and a waiver of their right to appeal.

title: In the East Village and SoHo, Orleys Family Values
description: The art-stuffed homes of the knitwear brands three designers influence their eclectic workspace.

title: U.N. Security Council Bans Sales of Arms to Houthi Fighters in Yemen
description: UNITED NATIONS  After weeks of closed-door negotiations between diplomats from Persian Gulf states and Russia, the Security Council on Tuesday imposed an arms embargo on the Houthi fighters battling for control of Yemen and left it to Secretary General Ban Ki-moon to negotiate the delivery of humanitarian aid to Yemenis who have endured nearly three weeks of Saudi-led airstrikes.

title: THX Eclipse Trailer
description: A new trailer for the THX sound system.

title: THX Wings Trailer
description: The original trailer for the THX sound system from 1983.

title: Alcatel-Lucent Poses Challenge for Nokia
description: Alcatel-Lucent makes a bold but messy takeover target for Nokia.

title: AOL Unveils ONE by AOL, an Advertising Platform
description: AOL introduced an advertising platform Tuesday that it says will help brands more effectively spend their money to maximize the impact of ad campaigns. The platform, called ONE by AOL, is the companys latest push into ad tech as it seeks to compete with Facebook and Google.

title: The Retro Futurism of Marco Rubio
description: Marco Rubio announced his presidential campaign on Monday evening in Miami, in a speech that was supposed to be all about the future, about the 21st century, about the triumph of young energy over old ideas.

title: Review: James Merrill: Life and Art, a Literary Biography
description: When the poet James Merrill (1926-1995) was born on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, his mother, Hellen, thought him tiny and ugly, even by newborn baby standards.

title: A Campaign Whodunit, From New York Today
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons announcement on Sunday that she was again running for president was not unexpected.

title: Jake Gyllenhaal Will Star in Little Shop of Horrors at City Center
description: Suddenly, Seymour is a Hollywood heartthrob: Jake Gyllenhaal will make his musical theater debut as the nerdy florist in the Encores! Off-Center production of Little Shop of Horrors at City Center this summer, theater representatives announced on Tuesday.

title: In Race for Medicare Dollars, Nursing Home Care May Lag
description: Promises of decadent hot baths on demand, putting greens and gurgling waterfalls to calm the mind: These luxurious touches rarely conjure images of a stay in a nursing home.

title: Italian Investment Firm Unveils Competing Bid for Reinsurer PartnerRe
description: LONDON  The Italian investment company Exor said on Tuesday that it was making a competing bid for the reinsurer PartnerRe, which agreed to a merger with Axis Capital Holdings earlier this year.

title: Meat Hook Sandwich
description: Higher sandwich intelligence is at play at this satellite of the Brooklyn butcher shop.

title: Restaurant Review: Meat Hook Sandwich in Williamsburg, Brooklyn
description: A normal sandwich was what I had in mind one day in January. Normal is not what Meat Hook Sandwich does, though, so I ended up eating something that I would call the greatest cheeseburger Ive ever tasted if not for the inconvenient fact that it wasnt a cheeseburger. What I ate was a chopped cheese sandwich, also known  in the very small patch of the United States where it is known at all  as chop cheese.

title: Wonder Woman Loses Female Director
description: LOS ANGELES  Michelle MacLaren, known for her work on television series like Breaking Bad and Game of Thrones, may not after all be the first woman to direct a major studio superhero franchise: She has parted ways with Warner Brothers and its planned Wonder Woman film.

title: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch
description: Its another good week to find an excuse to be in front of a TV and not behind a desk on Tuesday and Wednesday. Andrew Das, soccer editor and shameless Ajax supporter, tells you what to watch.

title: Man Convicted in Murder Investigated by Scarcella Is Ordered Freed
description: More than two decades after Rosean S. Hargrave was convicted of murdering an off-duty correction officer in Brooklyn, a judge on Tuesday ordered him released from prison, saying Mr. Hargraves prosecution was based on deeply flawed detective work that undermines our judicial system.

title: Loosening a Partys Grip on Karachi, a Pakistani City Known for Violence
description: LONDON  Hours before he was scheduled to be executed last month, the Pakistani hit man made an incendiary accusation.

title: Game of Thrones Season 5 Premiere Draws 8 Million Viewers
description: Sundays premiere of the fifth season of HBOs Game of Thrones drew about 8 million viewers live and on the same day, according to Nielsen.

title: Percy Sledge, Smooth Wailer in When a Man Loves a Woman, Is Dead at 74
description: Percy Sledge, the R&B singer whose soulful ballad of eternal love and rejection, When a Man Loves a Woman, topped the charts in 1966, died on Tuesday in Baton Rouge, La. He was 74.

title: Justice for Blackwater Victims
description: For years, it seemed inconceivable to Iraqis that the American justice system would ever punish the private security contractors who wantonly opened fire in a busy Baghdad traffic circle in September 2007, killing 17 civilians.

title: 2016 Delegate Count and Primary Results
description: According to the Associated Press, Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton have each won enough delegates to claim their partys nomination for president.

title: A Writer Watches His Life Unspool on Film
description: In 2002, The New York Times ended its contract with the writer Michael Finkel after he fictionalized a story about slavery in Africa. Soon afterward, Mr. Finkel discovered his identity had been stolen by Christian Longo, a man who had just been arrested for the murders of his wife and three children in Oregon.

title: Lawyers Square Off in Tulsa as Reserve Deputy Surrenders in Unarmed Mans Death
description: The reserve sheriffs deputy in Tulsa, Okla., who killed an unarmed suspect, apparently after mistaking his pistol for a Taser, probably would not have held that post if not for his long friendship with the county sheriff, a lawyer for the dead mans family said Tuesday.

title: This Sandwich Is Worth the Space in Your Carry-On
description: Before I leave for a trip, I get into sandwich mode, taking stock of what I have in the refrigerator so I can use up odds and ends.

title: Sentences in Blackwater Killings Give Iraqis a Measure of Closure
description: BAGHDAD  Ali Khalaf, a traffic police officer, stood in busy Nisour Square on Tuesday, waving the cars by, and pointed.

title: Israeli Leader Expresses Dismay Over Russian Sale of Missiles to Iran
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu spoke with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Tuesday and expressed Israels grave concerns regarding Russias decision to deliver a sophisticated air-defense missile system to Iran, according to a statement from Mr. Netanyahus office.

title: Financial Prescriptions Shouldnt Be Taken Lightly
description: Imagine youre walking down the street. A woman approaches and hands you a small piece of paper. You glance down and realize its a prescription. Well, you think to yourself, she was wearing a white coat, so shes probably a doctor.

title: Hearing Voices: Reporters Notebook
description: A voices piece, as they call it in the trade, is one of those articles in which a dozen or so nonexperts, often sitting in a diner or a beauty salon, offer their views on some topic of the day. These kinds of articles tend to get a bad rap because they are not nearly as reliable as polls in measuring popular opinion, and because ambushing people on their lunch hour does not always yield the most thoughtful analysis. Still, an ideal voices piece can give a sense of how people think, rather than just what they think.

title: Cuba to Be Removed From U.S. List of Nations That Sponsor Terrorism
description: The White House announced on Tuesday that President Obama intends to remove Cuba from the American governments list of nations that sponsor terrorism, eliminating a major obstacle to the restoration of diplomatic relations after decades of hostilities.

title: How to | Cook Spring Oatmeal
description: At Egg restaurant in Brooklyn, the sweet breakfast staple gets a savory twist with the addition of farmers market finds and an egg.

title: Boko Haram Abducted Nigerian Girls One Year Ago
description: DAKAR, Senegal  A year to the day after they were kidnapped by Boko Haram in northern Nigeria, more than 200 schoolgirls from the town of Chibok remain missing, with no sign that the current government is any closer to finding them.

title: Make Savory Galettes Without a Recipe
description: Kristen Miglore and Erin McDowell of Food52 show you how to make a simple galette with greens and cheese.

title: In Closing, Prosecutor in Etan Patz Case Says Suspects Many Confessions Ring True
description: A former store clerk accused of murdering 6-year-old Etan Patz first confessed to the crime in 1979 to a prayer group and has admitted to the killing more than a half-dozen times  to his family, to the police, to a prosecutor and, finally, to several psychological experts, a prosecutor said in her closing argument on Tuesday.

title: Fight Over Wynn Resorts Overshadows Question of Management
description: This Wynn-Wynn situation could be a loss for shareholders if they are not careful.

title: A Call to Look Past Sustainable Development
description: The average citizen of Nepal consumes about 100 kilowatt-hours of electricity in a year. Cambodians make do with 160. Bangladeshis are better off, consuming, on average, 260.

title: Corker and Cardin on Compromise Bill
description: Senator Bob Corker, of of the Foreign Relations Committee, discussed a bill that would allow Congress to vote on the nuclear deal being negotiated with Iran.

title: Toasting Salone del Mobile in Milan, With Friends and Fruit
description: Last night in Milan, T toasted the launch of this years edition of Salone Internazionale del Mobile, the worlds preeminent furniture and design fair  and of our own spring Design issue  with a festive outdoor cocktail party at the Villa Necchi Campiglio. (The beautifully preserved mansion, designed in the 1930s by the architect Piero Portaluppi, provided much of the setting for Luca Guadagninos sumptuous 2010 film I Am Love.) On hand to help Ts editor in chief Deborah Needleman and design editor Tom Delavan celebrate were a bevy of luminaries from the worlds of design, art and fashion.

title: Obama on Relations Between Iran and Iraq
description: The president said that the two countries should have strong relations and that Iraqi sovereignty must be respected in the fight against the Islamic State.

title: U.N. Asks Kenya Not to Close Somali Refugee Camp in Wake of Garissa Killings
description: GENEVA  The United Nations refugee agency urged Kenya on Tuesday to reconsider plans for closing Dadaab, one of the worlds oldest and biggest complexes of refugee camps, and forcing its more than 350,000 Somali inhabitants back into Somalia.

title: A Field Guide to the American Sandwich
description: A celebration of the sandwich, and an attempt to create a taxonomy for its many diverse forms.

title: Bulls Offer Nets a Lesson in Team-Building
description: It was no small wonder that a healthy portion of the Barclays Center crowd showered the visiting team with hometown adoration Monday night, cheering Chicagos Bulls as if they were straight out of Brooklyn. With the exception of being an N.B.A. champion, Derrick Rose and company are precisely what the Nets promised (and failed) to become while assembling the leagues richest roster.

title: New York Botanical Garden Adds a Restaurant
description: Headliner

title: Intel Earnings Rise 3%, Despite Slow PC Market
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Intel, the worlds largest maker of semiconductors, on Tuesday reported first-quarter earnings that were slightly higher than the same period a year ago, reflecting aggressive cost management in a weak personal computer market.

title: Pictures of the Day: Somalia and Elsewhere
description: Somalia and More  Pictures of the Day

title: What Equal Pay Day Says About Working Men
description: An editorial published today in the Times points out that women are typically paid much less than men, no matter their occupation, career attainment or level of education.

title: Iraqis React to Blackwater Sentences
description: Iraqis reacted to the sentences given in the trial of four former Blackwater guards who opened fire in a crowded Baghdad square in 2007. Many believe the sentences are too lenient.

title: When Schools Turn to the Police for Discipline
description: Many schools, and teachers and administrators within those schools, struggle to find effective methods of disciplining students, from setting the rules to enforcing them to handling students who transgress. Even the language of discipline is tricky  is a student breaking the rules? Out of control? Violating the policy? Disrespecting the community? Does she need punishment, discipline, redirection or correction?

title: Google Expected to Face Antitrust Charges in Europe
description: LONDON  The European Commission is said to be planning to charge Google with using its dominant position in online search to favor the companys own services over others, in what would be one of the biggest antitrust cases here since regulators went after Microsoft.

title: April 14, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Somalia, Brazil, Syria and Ukraine.

title: The American Sandwich: An Introduction
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J.  The sloppy Joe sandwich served at the Town Hall Deli in this suburban township on the banks of the Rahway River looks nothing like the ground-meat slushburger of middle-school cafeteria life.

title: Review: Alexandra Colliers Underland Mines Rich Performances
description: Anyone who has ever lived in a deadly dull town will understand why two bawdy-mouthed Australian schoolgirls dig a hole to China in Alexandra Colliers Underland. Its the only way out, they decide, from stone-quarry country. But theyre bad at geography, so the nice man who crawls out of their tunnel one day is from Tokyo. Back at school, the girls physical education teacher turns into a crocodile.

title: Boehner Calls for Expanded Role for U.S. Troops in Fighting ISIS in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON  Speaker John A. Boehner said Tuesday that American troops in Iraq should move beyond training Iraqi forces to take a more direct role in fighting against the Islamic State.

title: What You Get for  $1,000,000
description: This weeks properties include a condo in Washington, D.C., a house in Vermont and a duplex in Denver.

title: Editing the Editors
description: Editing the Editors

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Global Online Music Sales Slightly Surpass CDs and LPs
description: The global market for recorded music fell slightly in 2014 to $14.97 billion, down 0.4 percent from the year before, as sales of online music matched those of CDs and other physical formats for the first time, according to an annual industry report released on Tuesday.

title: Review: Between Worlds, With English National Opera, Addresses 9/11
description: LONDON  Are there no-go areas for opera  stories too momentous or traumatic to be told in song? Perhaps not. But there are some narratives that stage composers tend to stay away from, including the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. An exception occurred last weekend when Tansy Daviess Between Worlds had its premiere at the Barbican in a production overseen by the English National Opera here.

title: TV Review: CWs The Messengers
description: If you cant wait for the reboot of Heroes that NBC is planning for later this year, CW has a series called The Messengers beginning on Friday that has some of the same elements. And the premiere certainly grabs your attention. The angel wings are a bit of a red flag, however.

title: Staging Mockingbird in Alabama
description: The Mockingbird Players perform a theatrical production by the playwright Christopher Sergel based on Harper Lees book To Kill a Mockingbird.

title: To Kill a Mockingbird Is a Stage Hit at Home in Monroeville, Ala.
description: MONROEVILLE, Ala.  Each April and May during play season, as locals call it, the hotels in this town of 6,300 routinely sell out on weekends. Lines form at the restaurants. The charter buses carrying ticketholders stream off the Interstate, passing tractors chugging along in the slow lane of U.S. Route 84.

title: Gnter Grasss Germany, and Mine
description: FOR years I was frustrated, and a bit embarrassed, to admit that I didnt much like the work of Gnter Grass, the Nobel Prize-winning author who died Monday. He was, after all, Germanys most acclaimed writer of the postwar era  not just our national poet, but for many Germans, our conscience. Yet he did not speak to me.

title: SpaceX Comes Close to Recovering Rocket
description: A cargo ship carrying food, experiments and supplies, including an Italian espresso maker, to the International Space Station, lifted off Tuesday afternoon from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station in Florida.

title: Review: In Flamenco Sin Ttulo, the Many Sides of Olga Pericet
description: Who is Olga Pericet? In Flamenco Sin Ttulo (Flamenco Untitled), at Repertorio Espaol, the answer keeps changing. Joined by three other performers  the guitarist Antonia Jimnez and the singers Jos ngel Carmona and Ismael Fernndez  on the Repertorios small stage, Ms. Pericet, a compact powerhouse of a dancer, passes through many moods and modes of performance.

title: Review: Nellie McKay Goes Retro to Days of Song and Psychedelia
description: A globular light show flickered behind the piano at 54 Below on Monday evening as Nellie McKay resurrected the cheerfully embattled spirit of the hippie counterculture in her new show, Nice Try, 60s. The performance celebrated the release of her wonderful album, My Weekly Reader, devoted to vintage psychedelia and period protest songs.

title: Review: Magma Plays Prog-Rock at Le Poisson Rouge
description: The progressive rock that arose in the late 1960s took pride in complexity, using large-scale structures, long-form narratives, jumpy melodies, dissonant harmonies, layers of polyphony, tricky meters, sudden transitions and the mixed vocabularies of rock, classical music and jazz  all tests of virtuosity and memorization. Magma, the band formed in France in 1969 by the drummer and songwriter Christian Vander, embraced all of those and added an extra convolution: Its lyrics are in an invented language, Kobaan, of a culture that had to set out from a dying Earth into space. The story has been told across Magmas albums.

title: New Minimum Wage: $70,000 a Year
description: Dan Price, C.E.O. of Gravity Payments, surprised his 120-person staff by announcing that he planned over the next three years to raise the salary of every employee to $70,000 a year.

title: At the Tribeca Film Festival, Movies for Every Taste
description: Show business ballyhoo and serious cinema: Every film festival offers some combination of the two. But the Tribeca Film Festival, which begins on Wednesday, is different from others because it has never staked its reputation on groveling for the respect of the cineastes who flock to Cannes, Toronto, Venice, Berlin, Sundance or the New York Film Festival. Tribeca is a community celebration in which art films, documentaries and indie pop movies coincide on a populist menu that aims to satisfy every taste.

title: Masa rpida para pizza
description: El amasado se hace casi en su totalidad con ayuda de un procesador de alimentos.

title: The Robotics Inventors Who Are Trying to Take the Hard Out of Hardware
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In a converted pipe organ factory in the citys Mission District, Saul Griffith works on products that are smarter, cheaper and, above all, squiggly.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Tribeca Film Festival: Documentaries Offer a Niche-Pleasing Lineup
description: This years Tribeca Film Festival serves as proof, if any were needed, of the ascendancy of the documentary on the international film circuit. Close to half the festivals roughly 100 features are documentaries, including the opening-night film on Wednesday, Live From New York!, Bao Nguyens history of Saturday Night Live.

title: Christie Blames Trusting Nature for Bridge Scandal
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey says the scandal over the closing of lanes on the George Washington Bridge arose because hes an overly trusting person who likes to delegate.

title: Clintons Day in Iowa
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton made stops at a coffee shop and a community college on Tuesday in her first events since declaring her candidacy for president.

title: Living in Long Beach, N.Y.
description: Two and a half years after Hurricane Sandy, Long Beach, N.Y. a city on a barrier island off the southwest corner of Nassau County, is making a comeback.

title: A Conversation With Paul M. Galvin, Chief Executive of SG Blocks
description: Mr. Galvin, 52, is the chairman, chief executive and a founder of SG Blocks, a publicly traded company that repurposes maritime-grade steel cargo shipping containers into green building blocks for use in commercial, industrial and residential building construction. The containers are provided by ConGlobal Industries, a partner.

title: Many Home Equity Loans Are Facing a Reset Point
description: A decade ago, when home values were soaring, many homeowners financed all sorts of spending using home equity lines of credit, often borrowed in addition to a mortgage.

title: A Four-Bedroom Oceanfront House on the Pacific Coast
description: In a gated development near Puerto Escondido, the home is on the market for $1,495,000

title: Report Questions Whether Health Apps Benefit Healthy People
description: Consumers looking to use their mobile devices to improve their health  or at least maintain their well-being  have tens of thousands of choices.

title: Jason Rezaian, Washington Post Reporter Imprisoned in Tehran, Is Subjected to Kafkaesque Restrictions, Editor Says
description: Jason Rezaian, The Washington Posts Tehran correspondent imprisoned for nearly nine months on unexplained charges, has been subjected to Kafkaesque restrictions that include only one hour of pretrial time with a defense lawyer  and that meeting has not yet happened, the newspapers executive editor said Tuesday.

title: New Stumbles by Prosecutors in Trial of Former Goldman Programmer
description: Prosecutors continue to make unforced errors in the trial of Sergey Aleynikov, the former Goldman Sachs programmer who is being tried for the second time on charges he stole some of the source code to Goldmans high-frequency trading program.

title: Searching for Peace and Justice in Guatemala
description: The civil war ended almost 20 years ago, but the country is struggling to bring justice to communities shattered by the conflict.

title: Centuries of Italian History Are Unearthed in Quest to Fix Toilet
description: LECCE, Italy  All Luciano Faggiano wanted when he purchased the seemingly unremarkable building at 56 Via Ascanio Grandi was to open a trattoria. The only problem was the toilet.

title: Anticorruption Activist in Russia Sentenced for Street Art Theft
description: A court in Russia convicted an opposition activist of theft on Tuesday for removing a grimy piece of street art from a wall in a provincial city and presenting it to his boss, the anticorruption blogger Aleksei Navalny.

title: Recent Commercial Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Yale Medical Schools Request to Expand Campus Program Online Is Denied
description: The Yale University School of Medicine and 2U, an education technology company, have been denied accreditors permission to offer a physician assistant masters degree online as an expansion of an existing campus degree program.

title: Looking Back at the Holocaust, Through a Childs Eyes
description: JERUSALEM  Jakov Goldstein survived the Holocaust as a child by hiding alone for two years in a narrow attic, sustained by the books delivered each day by the eldest daughter of the Polish family that shielded him. Eliyahu Rozdzial turned 13, hidden alone in the forest and farms around his hometown, Dzialoszyce, Poland, after his family had been killed. He observed his bar mitzvah by digging an imaginary synagogue from the earth and filling it with upright twigs to serve as a silent congregation.

title: Florence Welch Suffers Broken Foot at Coachella
description: One of the most energetic sets at Coachella last weekend was by the British band Florence and the Machine, led by Florence Welch. On Sunday, previewing songs from the bands next album, How Big, How Blue, How Beautiful, Ms. Welch strutted and skipped across the stage in a flowing white pantsuit, and leaped repeatedly off the stage to convene with the screaming crowd.

title: Chimps That Hunt Offer a New View on Evolution
description: Studies of hunters and gatherers  and of chimpanzees, which are often used as stand-ins for human ancestors  have cast bigger, faster and more powerful males in the hunter role.

title: U.N.s Syria Envoy Looks to Revive Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS  Staffan de Mistura, the beleaguered United Nations envoy for Syria, will seek to restart political negotiations intended to bring an end to a four-year conflict by holding one on one meetings with representatives of the warring parties and the countries that support them, a United Nations spokesman said Tuesday.

title: New Jersey Cheesecakes? Juniors Is Moving Bakery
description: The cheesecakes that made Juniors famous have been baked in New York City, and only in New York City, for more than 60 years  but not for long.

title: A Reckless Act in the Senate on Iran
description: Congress has formally muscled its way into President Obamas negotiations with Iran, creating new and potentially dangerous uncertainties for an agreement that offers the best chance of restraining that countrys nuclear program.

title: Clinton Holds First Campaign Event
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton, who announced her campaign for the 2016 Democratic presidential nomination on Sunday, held a round-table discussion on education on Tuesday in Iowa.

title: Results at Wells Fargo and JPMorgan Show Slower Consumer Banking
description: The recent ascendance of consumer banking over Wall Street appears to have reversed course, at least for one quarter.

title: New York City Plans to Transform Summons Process
description: When New York City announced in November that it would start issuing tickets instead of making arrests for possession of small quantities of marijuana, the states judges were alarmed. Already overburdened and mired in time-consuming bureaucracy, summons courts faced the prospect of having to process tens of thousands of additional tickets each year.

title: Ex-Freddie Mac Leaders Reach Deal With S.E.C.
description: At a news conference in Washington three years ago, federal regulators trumpeted their case against former executives at the mortgage giant Freddie Mac, proclaiming that all individuals, regardless of their rank or position, will be held accountable for perpetuating half-truths or misrepresentations.

title: Dozens Arrested DuringBrooklyn Bridge Protest Against Police Violence
description: Dozens of participants in a march intended to protest police violence were arrested on Tuesday as the demonstration crossed the Brooklyn Bridge and caused major delays there during the evening rush.

title: Hillary ClintonWas Asked About Email 2 Years Ago
description: WASHINGTON  Hillary Rodham Clinton was directly asked by congressional investigators in a December 2012 letter whether she had used a private email account while serving as secretary of state, according to letters obtained by The New York Times.

title: I Am Not A Generic Economist
description: Sorry about the radio silence  Im scrambling to (a) meet a deadline on a longish piece I foolishly agreed to write and (b) trying to get ready for a quick trip to Brussels and Athens. (No, dont mail or call me about arranging a meeting or interview  thats up to my hosts, and I already have negative free time.)

title: U.S. Drone Kills a Top Figure in Al Qaedas Yemen Branch
description: WASHINGTON  An American drone strike has killed a top ideologue and spokesman for Al Qaedas branch in Yemen, the terrorist group announced Tuesday. The spokesman, Ibrahim al-Rubeish, a 35-year-old Saudi citizen, had been held for five years in the United States military prison at Guantnamo Bay.

title: For Hillary Clinton, Small Events Still Draw a Frenzy of Attention
description: MONTICELLO, Iowa  For the start to a presidential campaign in which small-and-personal is the order of the day, I and me are out and it is supposed to be all about you, Hillary Rodham Clinton sat down for an intimate round table chat on Tuesday with a handful of community college students and employees.

title: List of Smuggled Antiquities Recovered
description: The Manhattan district attorneys office made public the largest antiquities seizure in American history and asked a judge to grant it custody of a startling 2,622 artifacts recovered from storage rooms affiliated with an imprisoned Madison Avenue art dealer.

title: New York Authorities Seek Custody of Stolen Artifacts Worth Over $100 Million
description: The Manhattan district attorneys office on Tuesday made public the largest antiquities seizure in American history and asked a judge to grant it custody of a startling 2,622 artifacts recovered from storage rooms affiliated with an imprisoned Madison Avenue art dealer.

title: Student Coalition at Stanford Confronts Allegations of Anti-Semitism
description: LOS ANGELES  The debate over what constitutes anti-Semitism has spilled into Stanford Universitys student government election, with a Jewish student claiming that she was asked how her Judaism affects her view of divestment from Israel, morphing what was a contest about campus issues into a fierce discussion on identity and loyalties.

title: Bill Arhos, Founder of Austin City Limits, Dies at 80
description: Bill Arhos, a frustrated guitarist whose long-running television show, Austin City Limits, introduced much of America to the sound of redneck rock and progressive country and prompted Austin, Tex., to proclaim itself the Live Music Capital of the World, died on April 11 in suburban Austin. He was 80.

title: Quality Goalies Outnumber Opportunities on U.S. Mens National Team
description: SAN ANTONIO  For nearly three decades, becoming the first-choice goalkeeper of the United States has been a bit like being appointed to the Supreme Court, so permanent is the tenure.

title: De Blasio Seeks Updated Vision From Clinton for 2016
description: For nearly 20 minutes on Tuesday, Mayor Bill de Blasio set off on a political tightrope of his own making, at turns heaping praise on his former boss, Hillary Rodham Clinton, and defending his decision not to bless her presidential candidacy just yet.

title: Senate Approves a Bill on Changes to Medicare
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Tuesday overwhelmingly approved sweeping changes in the way Medicare pays doctors, clearing the bill for President Obama and resolving an issue that has bedeviled Congress and the Medicare program for more than a decade.

title: Blackwaters Legacy Goes Beyond Public View
description: By the time four former Blackwater security guards were sentenced this week to long prison terms for the 2007 fatal shooting of 14 civilians in Iraq, the man who sent the contractors there had long since moved on from the country and the company he made notorious.

title: New York State Erases Fees Seen as Nuisances to Business
description: ALBANY  Its a good day to be a potato fan in New York. Ditto for supporters of antique and miniature boilers, animal rendering plants, and operators of ski lifts. And for anyone with a career in lasers or food salvage, put your hands together in applause.

title: Knicks Superfan Is Set to Be There to the Bitter End
description: ATLANTA  About 45 minutes before the Knicks faced the Hawks at Philips Arena on Monday night, Dennis Doyle was among the first patrons seated in Section 112.

title: Trapped in a Torn Country
description: While some families fled eastern Ukraine because of the military conflict, many of the elderly stayed behind and now face a desperate shortage of health care.

title: Corinthian Colleges Fined for Bogus Job-Placement Claims
description: The Education Department has fined Corinthian Colleges $30 million for misrepresenting the job placement rates at its Heald College. The department cited 947 false placement rates given to students and prospective students, and to accreditors. In some cases, Heald paid temporary agencies to hire graduates for on-campus temporary jobs and counted those students as placed; in others, it counted as placed students who got their jobs even before enrolling. The department also told Corinthian, one of the nations largest for-profit college companies, that Heald College could no longer enroll students. Over the last year, after a crackdown by the government, most of Corinthians campuses have been sold, but the Heald campuses have continued to operate.

title: Passing Concerns
description: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE  Dont let the revealer to Joel Faglianos puzzle confuse you. Its not the grid that has BILATERAL SYMMETRY. Its the things inside the grid that do.

title: Lincolns Unattainable Standard
description: John Wilkes Booth killed Abraham Lincoln 150 years ago, but the martyred presidents legacy is still felt at the White House.

title: Abraham Lincoln, the One President All of Them Want to Be More Like
description: WASHINGTON  In an exhibition just a few dozen feet from where Abraham Lincoln died 150 years ago hangs a picture of President Obama taking the oath of office. His left hand rests on Lincolns Bible, the culmination of a campaign that opened in Lincolns town, citing Lincolns words.

title: For Special-Needs Students, Custom Furniture Out of Schoolhouse Scraps
description: Whenever Michael Konstalid visits a school, he makes sure to pay a visit to the basement.

title: Anger Over Reports of D.E.A. Agents Parties, and Bewilderment at Mild Penalties
description: WASHINGTON  Lawmakers expressed outrage on Tuesday at the punishments imposed on Drug Enforcement Administration agents who were accused of participating in sex parties with prostitutes while stationed in Colombia.

title: Paul Almond, Who Directed First Seven Up!, Dies at 83
description: Paul Almond, a Canadian director whose television film Seven Up! examined the lives of a group of midcentury British children and became the basis of the documentary series that has followed them into middle age, died on Thursday in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 83.

title: Yankees Bullpen Is More Like a Turnstile
description: BALTIMORE  Kyle Davies was elated late Sunday afternoon when he arrived at Yankee Stadium. It had been four years since Davies, 31, had pitched in the major leagues, but getting called up made all the long bus rides and fast-food meals he endured in the minor leagues worth it. Davies then pitched two and a third shutout innings in the Yankees 14-4 win over the Boston Red Sox.

title: Joel Spira, Physicist Who Softened the Lights in Homes Everywhere, Dies at 88
description: Joel Spira, who changed the ambience of homes around the world and encouraged romantic seductions of all types when he invented the first lighting dimmer for domestic use, died on April 8 in Coopersburg, Pa. He was 88.

title: Jury Chosen in Rampage at Multiplex in Colorado
description: CENTENNIAL, Colo.  After months of delays, jury selection ended late Tuesday in the trial of James E. Holmes, who is accused of killing 12 people and injuring 70 during a shooting rampage at a Colorado movie theater. Twelve jurors and 12 alternates were selected from a pool of 93 finalists, winnowed from an initial field of 9,000. Opening arguments are scheduled for April 27.

title: Yankees Burst of Power Fades Away in Baltimore
description: BALTIMORE  The Yankees had suddenly been living up to their Bombers pedigree, driving balls out of the park or taking ambitious cuts that chased outfielders to the warning track.

title: Christies Predicts Giacometti Sculpture Will Draw High Price
description: Christies will auction a bronze sculpture by Alberto Giacometti at a sale next month, and has estimated its value as high as $130 million, which would be the highest price paid for a sculpture at auction, the company said Tuesday.

title: Matt Harvey Delivers in Home Debut, but Mets Victory Is Painful
description: The start was so sublime, with a swinging strikeout as the crowd stood and chanted for the return of a phenomenon. By the end, the events in the Mets 6-5 win over the Philadelphia Phillies on Tuesday were so scrambled that Matt Harvey best summed it up this way:

title: They Dug Coal Together: Timothy Olyphant and Walton Goggins Look Back on Justified
description: The gun thugs were plentiful. The body count might have exceeded the total population of Harlan County, Ky. But in the end, Justified went out on a surprisingly compassionate note.

title: Review: Justified Finale on FX Ends Shows 6-Year Run
description: There was never really any doubt that Raylan Givens, the deputy marshal whose body count was matched only by his grudging devotion to the law, would do the right thing in the end. But the makers of Justified, which closed out its six-season run on FX on Tuesday night, needed to keep us guessing as long as possible.

title: Justified Series Finale Recap: We Are Gonna End This
description: Season 6, Episode 13: The Promise

title: Staten Island Candidates Clash Over Garner Investigation
description: The candidates for a vacant congressional seat clashed on Tuesday night over the handling of a grand jury inquiry into the death of Eric Garner, whose treatment by police was investigated by the Staten Island district attorney, Daniel M. Donovan Jr., the Republican candidate.

title: Chinas G.D.P. Slows to 7 Percent, the Weakest Rate Since 2009
description: HONG KONG  Chinas economy grew in the first three months of 2015 at its slowest quarterly pace in six years, dragged down by an industrial slowdown and a weak housing market, the government announced Wednesday.

title: Review: It Shoulda Been You, a Wedding on Broadway
description: As the father of the bride might put it, Oy.

title: Can a Colleague Donate My Lost Money?
description: The Ethicists answer reader questions about an unintended contribution, a proposed negative hotel review and a religious tract.

title: Rangers or Islanders? Take Your Pick
description: Fans of the Yankees, the Mets, the Giants, the Jets, the Knicks and the Nets have not had much to celebrate the past few years. But there are winners in New York. You just have to look on the ice.

title: Flour Shops Installation for the Brooklyn Artists Ball Is a Gumball Homage to Murakami
description: The Murakami flowers have got to be one of my favorite things ever, says the baker, Flour Shop proprietor and candy aficionado Amirah Kassem, who has made fancy and fanciful confectionery for Vogue, the Wu-Tang Clan, Warby Parker and Olivia Wilde. Its really anything Flour Shop could dream of, with colors, flowers, rainbows and smiley faces, Kassem continues, with her trademark cheer, of Takashi Murakamis famous grinning flower paintings. So when the Brooklyn Museum tapped Kassem, for the second year, to create an installation for tonights annual Brooklyn Artists Ball, she knew what to do as soon as she saw that Murakami (along with Jean-Michel Basquiat and Kiki Smith) is one of the events honored artists. The way his finish is, it sort of gives me the illusion of being one giant gumball with flowers in it, Kassem says of Murakamis slick, vivid paintings. So whats something else we can do with it? Of course, 10,000 gumballs into flowers was the answer!

title: Crochet Chic
description: Breezy knit pieces are as comfortable as they are practical for the seasons rising temperatures, and like-minded accessories lend an off-duty feeling to more work-appropriate looks.

title: Americans in Paris Share a Ceviche Recipe From Their New Menu, Plus Wine Pairings
description: In Paris, like so many other major cities, finding a last-minute table at a top restaurant is pas possible. To avoid losing any hopeful walk-ins, however, savvy proprietors have found the perfect solution: Open up another venue, just a few doors down. The Frenchie star Grgory Marchand has his empire on the charming rue de Nil with his original neo-bistro; its sidekick, Frenchie wine bar; and the low-key, daytime hangout Frenchie to Go. Likewise in the 11th Arrondissement, the award-winning chef Bertrand Grbaut put the gritty rue de Charonne on the map, first with his famed restaurant Septime and wine bar Septime Cave. More recently he opened one of Pariss best seafood restaurants, Clamato, next door.

title: Word of the Day | discourse
description: discourse  \dis-kors, dis-\  noun and verb

title: Give My Regards to Brooklyn
description: Dan Minervini, a senior at John Jay College and a member of the New York Theater Organ Society, plays Give My Regards to Broadway on the four-manual, 26-rank Wurlitzer organ in the former (and future) Brooklyn Paramount.

title: Suspense Goes Down to Wire for New York Teams
description: Both the Nets and the Knicks will have plenty at stake when they play their final games of the regular season on Wednesday night. One team is hoping to squeeze into the eighth and final playoff spot in the Eastern Conference, while the other would benefit from finishing with a record almost unmatched in its misery.

title: Homaro Cantu, Science-Minded Chicago Chef, Dies at 38
description: Homaro Cantu, a Chicago chef who kept a Class IV laser as a cooking tool and dreamed of eradicating hunger with nutrient-soaked edible paper, was found dead on Tuesday on the citys North Side. He was 38.

title: E.C.B. Sees Early Progress From Its Bond-Buying Program
description: FRANKFURT  Just weeks ago, the European Central Bank began a bond-buying program intended to stimulate the economy and to last at least 18 months. On Wednesday, the banks president, Mario Draghi, indicated that the measure had already begun to bear fruit.

title: Whats on TV Wednesday
description: 3:30 P.M. (HBO2) THE CONSTANT GARDENER (2005) In this political thriller directed by Fernando Meirelles and adapted from the John le Carr novel, Ralph Fiennes portrays Justin Quayle, a British diplomat (and diligent caretaker of his plants), and Rachel Weisz is Tessa, his wife, whom he meets during a lecture on foreign policy when she angrily challenges Britains participation in the Iraq war. Throughout most of the movie Tessa is shown in flashbacks; she has been murdered in the Kenyan wilderness, where she traveled with a Belgian doctor of African ancestry (Hubert Kound) to help fight poverty and disease. Danny Huston plays Justins colleague, and Bill Nighy is a villain in this tale about the evils lurking in multinational corporations and the Western governments that enable them. It may be best to take the cloak-and-dagger elements of The Constant Gardener, and the vision of justice with which it concludes, as metaphors, symbolic crystallizations of a reality too complex and diffuse to be dramatized by more empirical means, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Justin Quayle, then, is an allegorical figure, an emblem of timid virtue roused to heroic action by the discovery of his own complicity with evil.

title: Corrections: April 15, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I felt like justice was somewhat served. I have no pity for what happened to them today because it is what it is. Im sorry.

title: Chinese Cab Drivers Take to Song to Call for Their Own Company
description: To protest their working conditions, a group of about 30 taxi drivers from northeastern China drank pesticide on a central Beijing shopping street on April 4. The men survived after being sent to local hospitals, the police said.

title: Nokia Agrees to $16.6 Billion Takeover of Alcatel-Lucent
description: LONDON  The Finnish telecommunications company Nokia said on Wednesday that it had agreed to an all-stock deal to acquire Alcatel-Lucent that valued its French rival at about $16.6 billion.

title: A Crash Course inArmenian History
description: The two days I spent in Yerevan, the Armenian capital, were Feb. 25 to 27, 2015. But it didnt feel that way.

title: Psst, Want to Make a Better Sandwich?
description: It is one of lifes nagging mysteries: Why is a sandwich you order at a restaurant so invariably and intensely better than a sandwich you make at home?

title: Searching for Peace and Justice in Guatemala
description: Guatemalas 36-year civil war may have ended in 1996, but peace  of mind or community  has been elusive. Impunity reigns, allowing organized crime and drug traffickers to operate their deadly enterprises without interference. Street gangs that started in Los Angeles can even be found in dusty villages that have few paved streets, making life unbearable for law-abiding residents. And the nations many indigenous groups  who were promised much under the ambitious accords that ended the war  find themselves under siege from forces that want their land.

title: New Enterprise Associates Raises Giant Venture Fund
description: SAN FRANCISCO  With investing opportunities on its mind, New Enterprise Associates has raised the biggest venture capital fund in the industry  and added a little extra on top.

title: After 15 Years, Legal Victory for Family of Pastor Believed Abducted by North Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  When Kim Dong-shik, a South Korean pastor with permanent resident status in the United States, was abducted 15 years ago in northeastern China, his friends and family suspected North Korean involvement. The Pyongyang government loathes clergymen like Mr. Kim, who worked and proselytized among North Koreans who had fled to China.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:
