description: To the Editor:

title: My Fathers Secret
description: ATLANTIC CITY  Dad had a twinkle in his eye.

title: Senator Sessions, Straight Up
description: There was something bracingly honest about an op-ed article in The Washington Post last week by Senator Jeff Sessions, an Alabama Republican. Under the headline America Needs to Curb Immigration Flows, Mr. Sessions, the chairman of the Senate Judiciarys immigration subcommittee, argued the case for letting in fewer foreigners.

title: Whats Up With You?
description: While U.S.-Iran relations are taking up all the oxygen in the room these days, and theyre vitally important for the future of the Middle East, U.S.-China relations are vitally important for the world  and theres more going on there than meets the eye. The concept of one country, two systems was invented to describe the relationship between Hong Kong and mainland China. But heres the truth: the American and Chinese economies and futures today are now totally intertwined, so much so that they are the real one country-two systems to watch. And after recently being in China to attend the big Boao Forum on Hainan Island, and hearing President Xi Jinping speak, what is striking is how much each side in this relationship currently seems to be asking the other, Whats up with you?

title: The F.D.A. and Industry
description: To the Editor:

title: What Drives the Bile Against Obama?
description: To the Editor:

title: Shaming Those Who Skip Out on Taxes
description: IN 2006, according to an estimate by the United States Treasury Department, Americans underpaid their taxes by about $450 billion. For that year, thats roughly equal to Pentagon spending, and more than the gross domestic products of Sweden and Switzerland.

title: Build a Better Sandwich
description: New York chefs offer secrets for creating midday marvels.

title: Test Yourself | A New Show of Pop Art
description: Here are several paragraphs from an April 8 article, When the World Went Pop.

title: Nestl in Talks to Sell Its Davigel Frozen Food Business
description: LONDON  The food giant Nestl said on Wednesday that it had entered exclusive negotiations to sell its Davigel frozen foods business to Brakes Group, the British food service provider owned by the private equity firm Bain Capital.

title: Clip: Kurt Cobain: Montage of Heck
description: A clip from the HBO documentary film Kurt Cobain: Montage of Heck, screening in the Tribeca Film Festival, in theaters April 24 and coming to HBO May 4.

title: Nirvana Concerts Could Be Beautiful Wrecks
description: In the unrelenting new documentary Kurt Cobain: Montage of Heck, Nirvanas frontman can be seen abusing his body in both public and private. While battling drugs and depression at home, Cobain was a tattered rag doll onstage, hurling himself into drum sets, flailing off speaker stacks and writhing in waves of guitar feedback as if possessed.

title: 6 Qs About the News | A Math Problem From Singapore Goes Viral
description: In A Math Problem From Singapore Goes Viral: When Is Cheryls Birthday?, Kenneth Chang writes about a logic problem that has baffled many.

title: Long Beach Comes Back After Hurricane Sandy
description: When Hurricane Sandy struck Long Beach, N.Y., in 2012, water flooded the first floor of David and Shoshana Katofs two-story home on the east side of the city, causing $100,000 worth of damage. During the six months the house was being repaired, the Katofs, who were insured and fared better than many of their neighbors, lived on their second floor. Then they decided to downsize and sell.

title: In Rebel Territory of Ukraine, Older Residents Fight to Live
description: PEREVALSK, Ukraine  In a cramped cardiologists office in southeast Ukraine, Tatyana Ivanovna, 76, begged for sedatives.

title: With Kurt Cobain: Montage of Heck, Brett Morgen Demythologizes a Legend
description: LOS ANGELES  Clad in a crimson dress, Courtney Love blew into the Beverly Hills Hotel in March 2007 with a lawyer in tow and Kurt Cobains legacy on her mind. For the first time, she wanted to provide a documentary filmmaker with unrestricted access to her dead husbands archives, including journals, artwork, home movies and more than 100 never-before-heard cassette tapes stashed in a mysterious storage locker.

title: Would You Let the I.R.S. Prepare Your Taxes?
description: Around this time every year, Joseph Bankman, a professor of tax law at Stanford Law School and a longtime advocate of using technology to simplify tax filing, gets on the phone with reporters to explain what is wrong with how we do our taxes in the United States. Every year he says pretty much the same thing: No other industrialized country asks its citizens to jump through as many hoops to calculate their taxes as ours.

title: For a Clinton, Its Not Hard to Be Humble in an Effort to Regain Power
description: WASHINGTON  When a 35-year-old Bill Clinton, famously the nations youngest former governor, set out in 1982 to reclaim the job he had lost two years earlier, he began with a remarkable televised confessional.

title: After 50 Years, Reviving the Opulence of a Faded Brooklyn Beauty
description: Just two months after the reopening of a sumptuous, gilded, Jazz Age movie palace on Flatbush Avenue comes word that another sumptuous, gilded, Jazz Age movie palace will reopen  on Flatbush Avenue Extension.

title: As Cuba Opens Up, Fashion Reacts
description: When people talk about the resumption of relations between the United States and Cuba, as they did over the weekend as President Obama and President Ral Castro sat down for the first meeting between leaders of their two countries in more than 50 years, they talk mostly about history and diplomacy and influence, and what it could mean for the future in terms of trade and travel, not to mention human rights.

title: A Survey: Chinas Ideological Spectrum
description: Survey questions extracted from M.I.T. Political Science Department, Research Paper No. 2015-6, by Jennifer Pan, Harvard University, Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, and Yiqing Xu, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Department of Political Science.

title: Celebrating Boston Marathon, While Honoring Victims Memory
description: BOSTON  This city, for so long huddled inward, is slowly breaking out of its winter shell.

title: Turmoil at Voice of America Is Seen as Hurting U.S. Ability to Counter Propaganda
description: WASHINGTON  When David Ensor announced last week that he was stepping down as the director of the Voice of America, critics saw the move as the latest sign of turmoil at the government agency that is charged with presenting Americas viewpoint to the world.

title: Michelle Obama: A Life, by Peter Slevin
description: Earlier this year, when President Obama announced from the East Room of the White House that he and his wife, Michelle, and their two daughters would travel to Selma, Ala., to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the civil rights marches there, he said they did so not just as a president or a first lady or as African-Americans, but as Americans.

title: The Shadow of the Crescent Moon, by Fatima Bhutto
description: Fatima Bhuttos first novel, about one tense morning in the life of three Pakistani brothers and two of the women they love, is set in the tribal region bordering Afghanistan. This land is also home to a three-dimensional chessboard of seemingly endless war  American drones killing the Taliban; Sunni Muslims bombing Shia Muslims; and an underground, generations-old fight for independence from the central government.

title: The Right Dose of Exercise for a Longer Life
description: Exercise has had a Goldilocks problem, with experts debating just how much exercise is too little, too much or just the right amount to improve health and longevity. Two new, impressively large-scale studies provide some clarity, suggesting that the ideal dose of exercise for a long life is a bit more than many of us currently believe we should get, but less than many of us might expect. The studies also found that prolonged or intense exercise is unlikely to be harmful and could add years to peoples lives.

title: Keeping Your Car Safe From Electronic Thieves
description: Last week, I started keeping my car keys in the freezer, and I may be at the forefront of a new digital safety trend.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Survey Offers Rare Window Into Chinese Political Culture
description: A Chinese conservative supports the teachings of the philosopher Confucius, backs a strong state and wants the government to have a strong role in running the economy. Chinese liberals yearn for more civil liberties, believe in free-market capitalism and want more sexual freedom.

title: New York Today: Fighting for $15
description: Good morning on this sparkling Wednesday.

title: Europe Challenges Google, Seeing Violations of Its Antitrust Law
description: BRUSSELS  The European Unions antitrust chief on Wednesday formally accused Google of abusing its dominance in web searches, bringing charges that could limit the giant American tech companys moneymaking prowess.

title: Segway Finds Some Respect and a Buyer in China
description: HONG KONG  The Segway scooter, the punch line of countless jokes about overhyped gadgets since its invention more than a decade ago, may get the last laugh: On Wednesday, a Chinese company that makes a similar vehicle said that it planned to buy the scooters maker.

title: Intuit Statement on Tax Policy
description: In this weeks State of the Art column, Farhad Manjoo writes about the software company opposition to return-free filing, a plan that would allow the government to pre-calculate peoples tax returns with financial information that is already collected from employers, banks and other financial institutions.

title: Bits Daily Report: E.U. Antitrust Chief Formally Accuses Google of Abuse
description: The European Unions antitrust chief on Wednesday formally accused Google of abusing its dominance in web searches to the detriment of competitors and began official proceedings into whether its Android smartphone software forces phone makers to favor the companys own services and applications, James Kanter and Mark Scott write.

title: Experimenting at Home With Air Quality Monitors
description: Two years ago, when Thomas Talhelm was a Fulbright scholar in Beijing, he built his own air purifier after growing concerned about the citys notorious pollution. To test his handiwork, he spent about $260 for a portable device that counts tiny particles in the air.

title: Manny Pacquiao Can Fight, Legislate and Even Sing Sometimes When We Touch
description: Manny Pacquiao, Renaissance man.

title: Customizing Your Own Blend at Wineries and Hotels
description: Wine or Champagne is no longer limited to imbibing; hotels and wineries around the world are giving their guests the chance to customize their own blends.

title: Breakfast Gets New Life at Jessica Koslows Sqirl
description: It all started with the jam. This being Los Angeles, it wasnt, of course, just any jam. It was  and is  organic, and local, and often made from varieties of fruit that usually dont make it out of California, like Blenheim apricots, or combinations that you dont see elsewhere, like strawberry and rose. The jam is fragrant and not overly sweet, and you want to eat it with a spoon.

title: Gourmands Transform a Granada Neighborhood
description: Most travelers descend on Granada, the ancient city in southern Spain, to nibble on tapas with their tinto de verano and wander, mouths agape, through the sprawling Alhambra complex. But its worth saving energy and an appetite for some time in the Realejo area, where, along Calle San Matas and its neighboring streets, gourmands are transforming the historical Jewish quarter.

title: Can a Colleague Donate My Lost Money?
description: I work in a public hospital, in a poor neighborhood. In between seeing patients, I placed $50 in my pocket and went to use the public bathroom. I then went to buy lunch, and realized I lost my money. I ran back to the bathroom, but the money was gone. I went to security, but it was not turned in. I later told the story at a staff dinner. The next day, a staff member told me I would be happy to hear the moneywent to a good cause: her down-and-out patient, a struggling 25-year-old woman, with a bad knee injury, who had lost her job. Apparently she came in to our department to declare how happy she was to find $50 the previous day, and felt her luck was finally turning around. The timing of her coming into the bathroom was exact. My colleague said she was about to tell her she might know the moneys owner, but felt she did not want to spoil the womans happiness. She also said, knowing me and how I care for my patients who are needy (I often help patients buy needed equipment), that I would want the woman to have the money. Did she do the right thing?NAME WITHHELD, TORONTO

title: The Man Who Makes the Worlds Funniest People Even Funnier
description: Melissa McCarthy, her hands tied behind her back, writhed on the dingy basement floor of an abandoned power plant in Budapest  grunting, shrieking and, despite her best efforts, laughing. Let me try that again, she said, attempting a straight face. McCarthy was shooting Scene 114 in Spy, an action comedy that was, in April 2014, partway through its first week of production. A few feet away was the director Paul Feig, who likes to feed actors new lines of dialogue from just outside the frame. Feig gave McCarthy a breakthrough ensemble role in Bridesmaids (2011) and later cast her opposite Sandra Bullock in The Heat (2013). In Spy, McCarthy is the star, playing an unlikely secret agent called Susan Cooper. In Scene 114, Susan has been apprehended and dumped in the basement alongside another captive, named Aldo  a disconcertingly libidinal ally who keeps hitting on Susan despite their dire circumstances. The scene builds toward some exquisitely clumsy physical comedy, as Susan commands Aldo to help untie her, even though he is also in knots, inaugurating a grabby ballet and creating numerous opportunities for Aldo to say sleazy things.

title: Balancing Faith and Science in the I.C.U.
description: There she was, lying in the hospital bed dying. This mother, wife, daughter, sister and friend had played so many roles in her life, but none more important than her role as a believer in God. Since the patient, whom Ill call Ms. Ellen, was a little girl, she had always had the hope that her Christian faith would pull her through. But now, at age 77, the faith that she held on to seemed to be slipping in the face of her pain, prognosis and impending demise. Faith that was held together by an unyielding thread of hope. This woman who had made so many decisions for others was now forced to embrace her new role of a dying patient, subject to the decisions of a hospital medical team.

title: Has Obamacare Turned Voters Against Sharing the Wealth?
description: With the advent of the Affordable Care Act, the share of Americans convinced that health care is a right shrank from a majority to a minority.

title: Reading With Imagination
description: Reading, Jean-Paul Sartre writes in his essay What Is Literature?, is a pact of generosity between author and reader. Each one trusts the other; each one counts on the other, demands of the other as much as he demands of himself. Literature, he maintains, is a shared experience, and a literary works reception and success is integral to it. What the writer requires of the reader is not the application of an abstract freedom but the gift of his whole person, with his passions, his prepossessions, his sympathies, his sexual temperament, and his scale of values.

title: Before Its Opening, the Whitney Museum Faces a Protest
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art has yet to open its doors in a new location in the meatpacking district, but on Tuesday night it unwittingly played host toits first radical art exhibition.

title: Today in Politics: Christie Goes to New Hampshire, but Which Christie Will Arrive?
description: Good Wednesday morning from Washington, where the attention, including that of Speaker John A. Boehner, is increasingly on the presidential campaign. Hillary Rodham Clinton prepares for her second day campaigningin Iowa, and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey is in New Hampshire for an event where his approach may very well clash with that of the crowd.

title: In Washington, a Solemn Anniversary of Lincolns Death
description: At just before 8 p.m. on Tuesday night, looking straight out from the Petersen House on 10th Street in Washington, it was briefly possible to filter out the peripheral sounds and sights of the city and imagine the scene 150 years ago almost to the minute, when President Abraham Lincolns carriage pulled up in front of Fords Theater and delivered him to his fate.

title: Are There Topics That Should Be Off Limits to Comedy?
description: Are there any topics that are just too offensive to be joked about?

title: 25 Injured as Asiana Jet Skids Off Runway in Japan
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea said Wednesday that it would review the qualifications of all the pilots of Airbus A320 passenger jets flown by carriers based in the country, one day after one of the airplanes skidded off a runway while landing at Hiroshima Airport in Japan.

title: Immersive Mamma Mia! to Be Staged in a Greek Restaurant
description: The Abba catalog has been mined for many purposes  a musical and a movie, for starters. And now, one of the Swedish pop groups founders has decided to try a new venture: a Mamma Mia!-inspired immersive theatrical show.

title: Menlo Ventures to Announce It Has Raised $400 Million for Latest Fund
description: SAN FRANCISCO  For Menlo Ventures, its latest investment fund means a significant sum of fresh capital to invest in start-ups. It also represents a changing of the guard at one of Silicon Valleys oldest venture capital firms.

title: Tax Day: Are You Receiving a Marriage Penalty or Bonus?
description: The United States tax system is unusual in the way it levies a marriage penalty, or a marriage bonus, for couples who are not allowed to file like single individuals. The penalty or bonus depends on how much the couple make in total, and how evenly their income is divided.

title: Britain Fines Bank of New York Mellon $185 Million for Compliance Failures
description: LONDON  British regulators on Wednesday fined Bank of New York Mellon 126 million pounds, or about $185 million, for failing to comply with rules intended to protect client assets if the bank were ever to become insolvent.

title: Morning Agenda: Telecom Deal Reached
description: TELECOM DEAL REACHED  | In the latest in a string of mergers in the telecom sector, the Finnish telecommunications company Nokia said on Wednesday that it had agreed to a takeover of Alcatel-Lucent that valued its French rival at about $16.6 billion,  Mark Scott reports.

title: Outlook for Oil Prices Only Getting Murkier, Energy Agency Says
description: LONDON  The outlook for oil prices is still uncertain after the sharp fall that began last summer, the International Energy Agency said on Wednesday.

title: How Tasharro Harris, a Child-Care Worker Who Cant Afford Her Own Child Care, Does It
description: Tasharro Harris works at a child-care center, where she is paid $8.10 an hour. She lives near Atlanta in a four-bedroom rental house with her husband, her four children, ages 7, 7, 10 and 20, and her adult niece. How I Do It is an occasional series dedicated to telling the stories of how parents get through the long days and the short years.

title: Nonlinearity, Multiple Equilibria, and the Problem of Too Much Fun (Wonkish)
description: Theres been another blogospheric debate on methodology, this time involving a currently fashionable critique of mainstream macroeconomics  namely, that its too reliant on linear models and fails to make allowance for multiple equilibria. Frances Coppola and Wolfgang Munchau are leading the charge, with Roger Farmer (I think) in support; Brad DeLong and Tony Yates beg to differ. So do I.

title: Help, Plus Fashion Advice
description: Dear Diary:

title: House Hunting in ... Mexico
description: A FOUR-BEDROOM OCEANFRONT HOUSE NEAR PUERTO ESCONDIDO

title: Sounding Off
description: You know what an oronym is, even if you dont recognize the word. I scream for ice cream is probably the most famous oronymic phrase  the word combinations I scream and ice cream serendipitously sound just alike, though of course they are completely different in meaning. Appropriately, thats the first of six oronyms  seven, if you count the wonderfully clever title  that anchor Frank Vivas new picture book, Outstanding in the Rain. With the playful visual and verbal economy that is a hallmark of Vivas work (hes also the author of Young Frank, Architect, Along a Long Road and A Long Way Away), its one of those books that pulls grown-ups into its puzzles as surely as it does children.

title: Trailer: Live From New York!
description: A preview of Live From New York!, the documentary about Saturday Night Live opening the Tribeca Film Festival.

title: Bank of America Swings to a Profit
description: The first quarter was supposed to give investors a clear picture of Bank of Americas present and future, now that the bank has put most of its mortgage problems behind it.

title: F.B.I. Cites Persons of Interest in 2008 Times Square Bomb Case
description: The bomb went off just after 3:30 a.m. in the heart of Times Square. It caused little damage and no injuries, but the 2008 explosion left an enduring mystery about who set it off, and why.

title: In China, Weak Growth Is Expected to Push Beijing Into Action
description: HONG KONG  Chinas leaders are widely expected to cut interest rates and encourage lending after data on Wednesday showed that an industrial slump and a weak housing market had dragged economic growth to its slowest pace in six years.

title: $1 Million Homes in Washington, D.C., Denver and Vermont
description: WASHINGTON, D.C.

title: A Look Through The Lively Morgue
description: A selection of photos that have been posted on The Lively Morgue blog on Tumblr, in celebration of the 500th post.

title: Protest at E.C.B. News Conference
description: A young woman tossed papers and confetti at Mario Draghi and shouted end E.C.B. dictatorship before she was subdued by security guards.

title: Politico to Expand Coverage of States, Starting With New Jersey
description: Politico, the political website that started in Washington, is expanding its coverage of states, beginning with New Jersey and Florida.

title: The Debate Over Californias Drought Crisis
Google Accused of Cheating Competitors
description: Margrethe Vestager, the European Unions competition commissioner, accused Google of distorting Internet search results and began an antitrust investigation into its Android mobile operating system.

title: Aaron Hernandez Found Guilty of First-Degree Murder
description: Aaron Hernandez, a former tight end with the New England Patriots, was convicted of first-degree murder and several weapons and ammunitions charges Wednesday, ending the stunning downfall of a player who was once one of the N.F.L.s most promising young stars.

title: Chinatowns in Brooklyn
description: Chinese immigrants, who make up the second largest foreign-born group in New York, are reshaping parts of the city far beyond their traditional neighborhoods.

title: With an Influx of Newcomers, Little Chinatowns Dot a Changing Brooklyn
description: Just before 5 p.m., wave after wave of smiling toddlers came bounding down the stairs, their grandparents from China breathlessly in tow.

title: Sandwiches Coast to Coast
description: A closer look at some of the many sandwiches the country has to offer.

title: Nokia and Alcatel-Lucent Chiefs on Deal
description: Rajeev Suri, the chief executive of Nokia, and Michel Combes, the chief executive of Alcatel-Lucent, discussed the deal to combine the Finnish and French telecom equipment companies on Wednesday.

title: Boston Marks Attacks Second Anniversary
description: Mayor Martin J. Walsh marked the second anniversary of the Boston Marathon attack with a low-key ceremony at the site where the bombs went off.

title: Classical Playlist: Tchaikovsky, Leonard Bernstein and More
description: Tchaikovsky Piano Concerto No 1; Prokofiev Piano Concerto No. 2Kirill Gerstein, piano; James Gaffigan, conductor; and Deutsches Symphonie-Orchester BerlinMyrios Classics MYRO16

title: Christopher Marleys Biophilia
description: Christopher Marley creates multispecies spheres, prisms and mosaics from around the globe.

title: Christie Is Served a Ribbing at New Hampshire Restaurant
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  It started with a Sopranos joke. And it went downhill from there.

title: Protester Attacks E.C.B. President
description: A protester disrupted the monthly European Central Bank news conference in Frankfurt by jumping on the desk and throwing confetti at Mario Draghi, the central bank president.

title: 1915: Zeppelin Attack a Huge Fiasco
description: LONDON  The Zeppelin raid on the north- east coast district of England last night [April 14] was the biggest fiasco yet recorded to the discredit of Germanys air fleet. No lives were lost, although two men and an old woman were slightly injured. It was about 8.20 when the airship, believed to be the Z 9, arrived over Blyth, heading from the sea at a great speed at a height of about 2,000 feet. Orders were immediately given for the extinguishing of all lights in Blyth and the surrounding town as far as Hull and Newcastle. As far as can be ascertained twelve bombs were dropped during the flight over Blyth, but most of them fell outside the town and very little damage was done.  The New York Herald, European Edition, April 16, 1915

title: Tribeca Film Festival Interview: Bao Nguyen on the Saturday Night Live Documentary Live From New York!
description: This is one in a series of interviews focusing on New York-centric movies having their premieres at the Tribeca Film Festival.

title: Iran Assails U.S. Plan for a Vote in Congress
description: TEHRAN  Irans president on Wednesday dismissed the compromise worked out between the Obama administration and Congress over an impending nuclear agreement as internal American politics, saying the Iranians were negotiating with six countries, not just with the United States.

title: White Parents, Becoming a Little Less White
description: Former Gov. Jeb Bush made news recently because he checked Hispanic on a voter registration form. This is obviously ridiculous from a scion of the Bush family (and Mr. Bush has said he made a mistake). Yet, I understand, because the family he raised is not unlike mine.

title: Killing of 10 Soldiers Deals a Setback to Colombian Peace Talks with FARC Rebels
description: BUENAVENTURA, Colombia  After more than two years of peace talks, the finish line seemed to be getting closer.

title: 1965: Blood Test for Cancer Is Cited
description: ATLANTIC CITY  Successful trials of a blood test to detect cancer were reported here yesterday [April 14] by a U.S. Public Health Service doctor. The test, which depends on labeling red blood cells with a radioactive isotope, was given to 79 subjects. It should cost less than $10 to administer, according to Dr. John M. Vogel, of San Francisco, who has been testing it. Dr. Vogel reported the results of the cancer test before a session of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 16, 1965.

title: First Draft Focus: A High-Five for Clinton in Iowa
The Art of Arranging Flowers, According to Charlotte Moss
description: T culls tips from the gardener, designer and T contributors new book, Garden Inspirations.

title: Scene in Courtroom at Hernandez Verdict
description: A jury in Fall River, Mass., found the former N.F.L. player Aaron Hernandez guilty of murder in the first degree and firearms charges.

title: The Art of Arranging Flowers, According to Charlotte Moss
description: In the introduction to her new book, Garden Inspirations ($50, Rizzoli), Charlotte Moss writes that creating a garden means giving consideration to the house, its aspect, the views from the windows, the places you will sit outside, the paths leading from one place to the next and what will greet you at the front door. Its a beautiful idea, but for those of us living in small apartments in concrete jungles, its just that: an idea, aspirational at best. Then you flip through the sunny tome and realize that the author, a designer and T contributor, gives as much consideration to bringing her East Hampton garden indoors, filling inspired vessels with clippings from fruit, flower and herb plants. Here, T scours the books pages for tips on arranging bouquets, baskets and buds at home (with, if youre like us city dwellers, stems from the bodega downstairs).

title: 36 Hours on the Left Bank, Paris
description: From the Latin Quarters alleys to the grand boulevards of St.-Germain-des-Prs, the Left Banks classic charms can be found in cafes, museums and shops.

title: 36 Hours on the Left Bank, Paris
description: Explore street view, find things to do in the Left Bank and sign in to your Google account to save your map.

title: 36 Hours on the Left Bank, Paris
description: While the Right Bank of Paris has seen internationalism and the irrepressible rise of bobos (the Parisian form of hipsters) change its landscape in recent years, the Left Bank has been able to preserve the soul of the French capital. Walk through the Latin Quarters crooked cobblestone corridors or down the grand plane-tree-lined boulevards of St.-Germain-des-Prs and, more than once, youll think youre inside a black-and-white Robert Doisneau photo. Cafe terraces, limestone buildings and nattily dressed locals create a timeless tableau. Thats not to say that Paris south of the dividing Seine is immune to change. But at least for now, the classic charms outweigh the contemporary influences.

title: Yael Farbers Nirbhaya at the Lynn Redgrave Theater
description: Sexual violence against women is a problem pretty much the world over, but in India in particular it has made headlines for a series of recent gruesome incidents. The documentary drama Nirbhaya recounts the story of Jyoti Singh Pandey, who boarded a bus with her boyfriend in New Delhi in 2012 and was subjected to a brutal gang rape that subsequently led to her death. The attack set off protests against the police and governments lax attitude toward protecting women, and it made Nirbhaya (Fearless One), as Pandey was called in the news media, a symbol of the horror of sexual violence.

title: William H. Donaldson Named Chairman ofFinancial Services Volunteer Corps
description: William H. Donaldson, the former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission and a longtime Wall Street grandee, will become chairman of the Financial Services Volunteer Corps, the organization is expected to announce on Wednesday.

title: Warren Buffett, Italian-Style
description: The Agnellis are paying up to do an impression of Warren E. Buffett.

title: Tensions Flare Between Iraq and Saudi Arabia in U.S. Coalition
description: WASHINGTON  A remarkable clash between two key American allies in the Middle East burst into the open here on Wednesday as the Iraqi prime minister publicly criticized the Saudi air campaign in Yemen and a top Saudi official retorted that there was no logic to those remarks.

title: The Danish Politician Who Accused Google of Antitrust Violations
description: Margrethe Vestager, the European Unions competition commissioner, announced on Wednesday that she was bringing formal antitrust charges against Google. A longtime Danish politician, she has brought an assertive approach to Europes competition ministry since taking over late last year. She also may be the only regulator in Brussels known for knitting elephants.

title: Foods Field Guide to Sandwiches: No Wraps and No Burritos
description: Emily Weinstein is a senior staff editor for the Food section.

title: Dictionary of American Regional English Faces Shutdown
description: The Dictionary of American Regional English reached a milestone three years ago when it released its fifth installment, bringing its 50-year effort to document the vagaries of American speech to a climax with a volume running through zydeco.

title: Jeb Bush to Give Liberty University Commencement Speech
description: Former Gov. Jeb Bush will pay a visit to the heart of the conservative movement next month when the likely presidential candidate gives a commencement address at Liberty University.

title: Royal Opera House Plans a Dozen New Productions
description: LONDON  The Royal Opera House in London will premiere 12 new productions in its 2015-16 season, it said Wednesday. The choreographer Hofesh Shechter, who brought a work, Untouchable, to the Royal Ballet for the first time last month, will return to Covent Garden as an opera director, collaborating with the operas associate director, John Fulljames, on a production of Glucks Orphe et Eurydice.

title: Now in His Eighties, Malcolm Morley is Still Finding New Ways of Looking
description: New works by the British painter, known for his photorealist portraits, are brighter, looser and touched with a playful surrealism.

title: Ts New Pinterest Board: Springtime Gardening Inspiration From the High Line
description: In New York City this time of year, an elevated railroad-trestle-turned-public-park known as the High Line is a popular place for a springtime stroll. As the weather warms up, the parks co-founder and executive director, Robert Hammond, shares on Pinterest, exclusively with T, whats inspiring him this season, from other urban landscapes to beloved gardening tools and sunny shots of the High Line in full bloom.

title: Outside Judge Is Named for Police Shooting Case
description: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C.  In a departure from the way most cases are handled, the chief justice of the Supreme Court of South Carolina on Tuesday appointed a judge from outside North Charleston to oversee the case against the former police officer, Michael T. Slager, who has been charged with murder in the shooting of Walter L. Scott, an unarmed man who fled after being pulled over for a traffic stop on April 4.

title: Politicos, Hollywood Stars and Models Gather at the Vanity Fair Party
description: The annual kickoff party for the Tribeca Film Festival.

title: Big Brands Take the Party to No-Chella
description: The people flocking to Coachella arent always there just for the music.

title: N.C.A.A. Proposes New Settlement in Lawsuit on Head Injuries
description: CHICAGO  The N.C.A.A. filed a new proposed settlement late Tuesday night in a class-action lawsuit brought against the association over its handling of concussions and head injuries. It is the second attempt by plaintiffs lawyers and the N.C.A.A. to settle the case after a federal judge asked for changes to the original proposal in December.

title: Vanity Fair Kicks Off Tribeca Film Festival
description: Youre not here to be seen, Charlie Rose said, standing beneath the towering Corinthian columns of the New York State Supreme Court on Tuesday night, during Vanity Fairs lavish kickoff to the Tribeca Film Festival. Youre here to see. At any other point during the festival, such an assertion might be interpreted as a reference to this years screenings. But on this night, the films could wait.

title: $52 Million Push to Help Arts Institutions Find New Audiences
description: Opera Theater of Saint Louis will experiment with reaching younger and more diverse audiences with a variety of programs, including one that will send singers into houses of worship to perform, to work with choirs and to connect with people who do not normally go to the opera.

title: Removing Cuba From the List of Terror Sponsors, Finally
description: There were a couple of questions American officials struggled to answer substantively when they announced on Tuesday that the White House has decided to remove Cuba from the list of nations that sponsor terrorism.

title: Ernst & Young in Settlement Over Lehman Brothers
description: Another loose end stemming from the collapse of Lehman Brothers was wrapped up on Wednesday as Ernst & Young agreed to pay $10 million to settle a four-year-old lawsuit brought by New York State authorities.

title: Shifting Position, Clinton Says Gay Marriage Should Be a Constitutional Right
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign said on Wednesday that she hopes that the Supreme Court will make same-sex marriage a constitutional right, reflecting a shift in her previous view that it is a decision that should be left to the states.

title: Preserving Auschwitz-Birkenau
description: The goal at the Auschwitz-Birkenau site is to keep the place intact, exactly as it was when the Nazis retreated.

title: Preserving the Ghastly Inventory of Auschwitz
description: OSWIECIM, Poland  To visit Auschwitz is to find an unfathomable but strangely familiar place. After so many photographs and movies, books and personal testimonies, it is tempting to think of it as a movie-set death camp, the product of a gruesome cinematic imagination, and not the real thing.

title: Google Joins Its U.S. Peers Under Europes Scrutiny
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Over the last few decades, Europes regulators have challenged the practices of some of the titans of American technology, including Microsoft, Intel and now Google.

title: Nudge + Coach App Connects Health Data to a Real-Life Coach
description: Wearable gadgets and data trackers are taking notes around the clock on how much we run, walk, sleep, drink and eat. But what do you do with all that data?

title: Obama Hosts West African Leaders
description: The president met with the leaders of the Ebola-affected nations of Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea on Wednesday to discuss how the United States could help them as they rebuild after the outbreak.

title: Outlander Costume Designer Terry Dresbach on 8 Memorable Outfits
description: Ms. Dresbach discusses some of her most memorable designs.

title: Republicans Debate Lincolns Place in Todays Party
description: On the anniversary of his death, Abraham Lincoln occupies a place in the hearts of Americans across party lines. But would the first Republican president be at home in todays Republican Party?

title: Case Against Google May Be Undercut by Rapid Changes in Technology
description: The antitrust case against Google filed by European Union regulators on Wednesday will inevitably draw comparisons to the long-running prosecution of Microsoft, in which regulators on both sides of the Atlantic pursued the software giant for anticompetitive behavior.

title: During G.E. Deal,Blackstones Schwarzman Focused on a Scholarship Fund
description: Many Blackstone executives worked grueling seven-day weeks for a month to put together last Fridays $23 billion acquisition of mortgages and office buildings from General Electric. But Blackstones chief executive says he has been spending twice as much of his time on an entirely different project: the scholarship fund he started at a top Beijing university.

title: No Clarity on Conflicting Laws as Judge Keeps Marijuana on List of Harmful Drugs
description: A federal judge declined on Wednesday to order the removal of marijuana from the Drug Enforcement Administrations list of the most harmful and addictive drugs, disappointing those who had hoped the courts might help settle growing conflicts between federal and state laws.

title: Performing Math and Mime, for Fun and Profit
description: Without saying a word, a man walks on stage carrying a case full of small plungers. Each time he reaches in the case to take some plungers out, he tries to array them in order on a table in front of him, but he always has one left over. Five, seven, 13: No matter what number, there is still that one left alone, and the man gets visibly, but silently, more exasperated at each turn.

title: Preserving Auschwitz-Birkenau
description: The goal at the Auschwitz-Birkenau site is to keep the place intact, exactly as it was when the Nazis retreated.

title: A Snapshot of the Campaign Finance Landscape
description: Today is the first major deadline for 2016 presidential campaigns to file their finance reports. Since most of the candidates hadnt declared before March 31, the end of the last reporting period, much of the focus is on who wont be filing a report. But thousands of other committees will be reporting donations and spending from the first three months of the year, and here are some of the key points from them:

title: Tam Mutu, on Broadway at Last, in Doctor Zhivago
description: For a few years there, Broadway must have seemed about as accessible as the icy battlefields of revolutionary Russia for Tam Mutu.

title: Planned Motorcycle Rally by the Night Wolves, a Putin Ally, Has Poland on Edge
description: BRANIEWO, Poland  Several hundred leather-clad motorcyclists from the Night Wolves, a club closely allied with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, plan to roar from Moscow to Berlin this month for the 70th anniversary of the Soviets victory over Nazi Germany.

title: Verbatim: When in Iowa
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton, on a visit to Capital City Fruit, a fresh produce delivery service, in Norwalk, Iowa.

title: Nick Clegg, a Star of Britains 2010 Election, Faces a Tough Fight
description: SHEFFIELD, England  With Britain approaching a tight general election on May 7, it remains difficult to forecast who will win  but picking the likely big loser is easy.

title: Flour Shops Installation for the Brooklyn Artists Ball Is a Gumball Homage to Murakami
description: The baker and candy aficionado Amirah Kassem used nearly 10,000 of the treats to recreate the artists famous smiling flowers.

title: Short Stories for E-Readers, 99 Cents Each
description: Short stories seem like the perfect snackable literary form for the digital age, when a growing number of readers are looking for content they can quickly scan through on their phones. But most of the time, publishers package stories in meal-sized portions, as a complete collection.

title: Now in His 80s, Malcolm Morley Is Still Finding New Ways of Looking
description: Malcolm Morley has gotten off the couch. A longtime champion of psychoanalysis, the 83-year-old British artist finally got thrown out by his therapist, he says. But that doesnt mean the self-described super-realist painter has been relieved of that foundational psychoanalytic catch: He is still fixated on his childhood. I have been able to, as one person put it, make friends with your unconscious life,' says Morley, who was quite famously a child of neglect with a disregard for the system. But a stint as a petty thief, and then one in prison, straightened him out  though naturally, it was painting that truly saved him.

title: Bomb Kills 3 Military Academy Students in Egypt
description: CAIRO  Three students at a military academy were killed by a roadside bomb in the Nile Delta town of Kafr el Sheikh on Wednesday, in what appeared to be the latest in a series of attacks by militant groups against members of Egypts security services.

title: Harry Reid Jabs His Adversary
description: Senator Harry Reid, the Democratic minority leader, was an amateur boxer in his youth, so he should know about haymakers. He directed one at Senator Mitch McConnell Wednesday when, criticizing the Kentucky Republicans fierce dedication to the coal industry, Mr. Reid concluded, I dont mean to be mean-spirited, but he is a lump of coal.

title: Fabio Mauri Works, Fueled by Trauma, Head to the Venice Biennale
description: After the defeat of Fascism in World War II, images filtered into Italy that portrayed, in horrifying detail, the concentration camp victims of Nazi Germany. At the home of Fabio Mauri in Rome, those pictures arrived with unusual frequency, because among his fathers varied businesses was the distributorship of 300 foreign newspapers.

title: Video Feature: Navigating London From Your Smartphone
description: LONDONS history, theaters, pubs and shops are great reasons to visit. And now, navigating the streets and attractions is much easier because of the bevy of apps devoted to the city.

title: App Smart | London Calling
description: Kit Eaton reviews several apps to make planning your trip to London easy and help you navigate around this popular tourist destination.

title: A.I.G. Invests in Krolls K2 Intelligence Firm
description: In 1993, the Kroll family, one of the most prominent practitioners of corporate intelligence, reached out to the American International Group, the insurance giant, about investing in its firm.

title: Writing for Change: Student Winners From Our Second Annual Editorial Contest
description: Neither freezing weather nor a record number of snow days in some places could deter nearly 4,500 of you from entering this winters Second Annual Student Editorial Contest. And, just like last year, we were bowled over by the breadth of topics you chose and the passion with which you wrote about them.

title: In Boston Turnabout, Celtics Play On but Bruins Go Home
description: The playing surface at TD Garden in Boston will be exclusively parquet for the 2015 playoff season. Very few people, if anyone, saw that coming.

title: Keep Patients Healthy, and Doctors Sane
description: BAINBRIDGE ISLAND, Wash.  I OPENED the curtain and found my patient stretched out flat on the recliner, one arm thrown across his eyes. Worried, I reached for his pulse, but then I heard a soft snore. He was sound asleep, before Id given him any anesthesia. I felt far less relaxed than he seemed to about his upcoming surgery.

title: Pilot of Gyrocopter Is Arrested After Landing on Lawn at Capitol
description: WASHINGTON  A 61-year-old postal worker from Florida delivering a protest message to Congress about campaign finance laws landed a lightweight gyrocopter on the West Lawn of the Capitol Wednesday afternoon, upending what was shaping up to be another day of legislative stalemate in the Senate.

title: Treating Sleep Apnea May Ward Off Memory Decline
description: Breathing problems during sleep may be linked to early mental decline and Alzheimers disease, a new study suggests. But treating apnea with a continuous positive airway pressure machine can significantly delay the onset of cognitive problems.

title: As Ebola Retreats, Obama Urges Vigilance and Preparation in West Africa
description: WASHINGTON  Now that the Ebola crisis in West Africa finally appears to be petering out, President Obama on Wednesday called for renewed international efforts to rebuild the shattered health systems in Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone, to shore up the response to future pandemics in the region.

title: Jailed Azerbaijani Journalist, Khadija Ismayilova, to Be Honored by PEN
description: MOSCOW  A jailed Azerbaijani journalist, Khadija Ismayilova, will receive a prestigious press freedom award next month from the PEN American Center, as the nonprofit literary organization joins a rising wave of international criticism directed at the government of President Ilham Aliyev over human rights abuses and the suppression of free speech.

title: How to | Plant a Simple Garden
description: Ts European editor Rita Konig shares her add-as-you-go strategy for building a backyard oasis.

title: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
description: South Korea and More  Pictures of the Day

title: How to Show a Little Skin at Any Age and More Shopping Tips
description: Cut-outs grow up; knitwear that has just the right fresh-off-the-beach look and a former Goldman Sachs analyst uses her engineering background to create geometric, functional designs.

title: A Look Back Through the Times Photo Archives
description: The Lively Morgue, The New York Timess photo blog on Tumblr, takes viewers on a journey through the massive collection of the Times Photo Archives. All of the images are pulled from the morgue, as it is called in the newsroom, where archived news clippings and photos are stored, two levels below ground in an office building next to the Times offices on West 41st Street.

title: April 15, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from South Korea, Germany, Syria and South Africa.

title: Devices and Apps for Heading Outdoors After the Thaw
description: Now that spring is finally here, its time to venture outside again. And there are a number of noteworthy devices to help you on your journey, whether its to your backyard or farther afield.

title: Delta Posts Record Net Income; Reduces International Service
description: Delta Air Lines said on Wednesday that it would cut some of its international flights in coming months as the rising value of the dollar eroded revenue abroad.

title: Furious 7 Is No. 1 on Music Chart, Too
description: The film Furious 7 has dominated the box office for the last two weeks, and now its screeching victory lap has extended to the music charts as well.

title: Total Failure on Speedy Trials in New York
description: The outrageous delays in New York Citys criminal justice system were given a human face last year, when Jennifer Gonnerman, writing in The New Yorker, introduced readers to Kalief Browder, who was 16 when he was arrested in 2010 for a robbery he says he did not commit.

title: Come for Coachella, but Party at #nochella
description: INDIO, Calif.  Last Friday night, as AC/DC took the stage at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, one of the 100 bands that did so last weekend, a party a mile from the concert kicked into full gear.

title: Pushing Back Against the Authorities in China According to the Law
description: After the Chinese government on Monday released on bail five feminists whose 37-day detention in Beijing had become an international cause clbre, their supporters in China posted a petition online welcoming their release  and making demands:

title: Europe Streets Issue
description: Streets in Europe

title: Signs of Slowdown in Oil Production Send the Price Up, for Now
description: HOUSTON  Oil prices jumped on Wednesday with the surprising news that domestic crude stockpiles rose by the smallest amount for any week this year.

title: In Lecture, the Conductor Alan Gilbert Gives Job Description, Lauds New Music
description: In delivering this years Royal Philharmonic Society Lecture in London on Wednesday, Alan Gilbert, the music director of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra, lamented the narrow ways in which the roles of orchestras and their leaders are sometimes viewed.

title: Training for Would-Be Stars on How to Be Famous
description: Australian Siri, otherwise known as Karen Jacobsen, was hoping for tips to expand her brand as the GPS Girl. Her mellifluous antipodean accent can also be heard in GPS systems around the world, and thats a hook the 46-year-old singer and voice-over artist has been using to promote herself as a motivational speaker. (Its never to late to recalculate, is her slogan.)

title: Theyre Not Afraid to Say It: Fat Yoga
description: The telemarketers and bottled-water vendors who call Anna Ipoxs yoga studio in Portland, Ore., often ask, Is this the yoga place?

title: These Guys Help Fashion Labels Get the Web
description: Mentorship can be a two-way street.

title: A Video Lesson in Backyard Gardening
description: In her own backyard in London, Ts European editor, Rita Konig, shares tips and tricks for designing a simple outdoor oasis. Her laid-back, add-as-you-go strategy ensures that you enjoy the process as much as the final result.

title: Clintons Enthusiasm for Questions Depends on Whos Asking
description: NORWALK, Iowa  Hillary Rodham Clinton loved the barrage of questions she got from a group of small-business owners here  but she was noticeably less enthused with the questions from reporters who covered her round-table discussion.

title: William Oesterle, Chief Executive of Angies List, to Step Down
description: Just a few weeks after leading business opposition against a controversial religious freedom law in Indiana, William S. Oesterle is stepping down as the chief executive of Angies List, in part to become more civically involved in the states issues, the Indianapolis-based company announced on Wednesday.

title: Review: The Childrens Crusade, by Ann Packer
description: Ann Packers meandering new book, The Childrens Crusade, begins with a man, a tree and a dream. The year is 1954. The man is Bill Blair, a newly discharged Naval officer. The tree is the most beautiful California live oak Bill has ever seen in an area that will someday come to be known as Silicon Valley. Bill loves the tree and decides to buy it and the surrounding homesite, for a minuscule fraction of what the place will someday be worth.

title: Review: Salvage Looks at What the Hazmat Dragged In
description: The Flux Theater Ensemble makes the most of a modest stage in its production of August Schulenburgs new play, Salvage, at the Loisaida Center in the East Village. The show, a somewhat meandering science-fiction character study with poetic leanings, capitalizes on a large room at the center, outfitting it (Will Lowry did the scene design) to suggest a bunker in a postapocalyptic Manhattan.

title: Review: Knock Knock, Its Tig Notaro
description: The amiable documentary Knock Knock, Its Tig Notaro, which has its premiere Friday on Showtime, is a you-had-to-be-there kind of experience. A twist on the usual tour movie, it features Ms. Notaro traveling the country and doing her stand-up in peoples homes. Clearly it would have been great to be sitting with your friends in that living room or that backyard a few feet away from the comedian (and her film crew). Watching others have that experience isnt quite the same thing.

title: Review: Anne-Sophie Mutter, in a New Trio, Offers Simple Pleasures
description: At 51, the violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter has never lacked for laurels, nor has she ever rested on them. Having mastered the standard repertory early on, she has made repeated forays into contemporary music, deepening her interpretive skills in old music as well as new. She has developed into a complete musician, as passionately committed to chamber music as to the great concertos. No shrinking violet, she has cultivated a glamorous image, but without compromising her artistry with cheesy crossover ventures and the like.

title: Review: Cedrics Barber Battle, a New CW Reality Show
description: More interesting than watching grass grow, less interesting than chain-saw sculpturing. Thats Cedrics Barber Battle, reality televisions latest Can we make a TV show out of that? experiment, which begins Friday on CW.

title: European Parliament Urges Turkey to Recognize Armenian Genocide
description: ISTANBUL  The European Parliament adopted a resolution Wednesday commemorating the centennial of the Armenian genocide and urged Turkey to recognize that event.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Ruling Shields G.M. From Ignition Suits
description: A federal bankruptcy judge on Wednesday blocked most lawsuits against General Motors over a defective ignition switch that is tied to at least 84 deaths, sparing the automaker billions in claims and handing it a momentous victory as it tries to move past its gravest safety crisis.

title: Susan Henshaw Jones to Leave Museum of the City of New York
description: When Susan Henshaw Jones became director of the Museum of the City of New York in 2003, the way forward was as complicated as a Greenwich Village street map.

title: Review: Rob Mazureks Black Cube SP Plays at ShapeShifter Lab
description: Near the midpoint of Black Cube SPs commanding show at ShapeShifter Lab in Brooklyn on Tuesday night, Rob Mazurek tucked his cornet between his knees and began punching buttons. He had turned his focus toward a tabletop console with the dimensions of a large briefcase, joining his bandmates in an analog electronic squall.

title: Review: Ariel Quartets Beethoven Cycle at SubCulture, With Energy to Spare
description: If the aristocratic salons of the late 18th and early 19th centuries have any equivalent today, it might be a place like SubCulture. At this little NoHo basement space, which has fast established itself as a major music presenter, theres a tangible, deserved sense of pride.

title: Reynold Levys New Book Names Names, Including the Met and Peter Gelb
description: The New York Philharmonic was, at crucial moments in recent years, an orchestra adrift. New York City Operas death, after years of missteps, was a suicide, not a homicide. And all who care about the Metropolitan Opera are entitled to ask how its desperate financial condition arose, and whether the steps taken to date are nearly enough to address it successfully.

title: New Treatments for Thinning Hair for Women
description: After 20 years of trying every drug, supplement, diet and procedure for hair loss  including driving four hours twice a week for laser therapy  Lina Telford, a graphic artist, gave up on her comb over (her description) and shaved her head. From then on, she alternated between a $1,500 wig and a $4,000 wig.

title: At Tiffany, Something New Inside the Blue Box
description: Back in February at the Academy Awards, the Australian actress Cate Blanchett made her usual regal turn on the red carpet, a vision of cool beauty in a silk velvet sheath. The dress, designed by John Galliano for Maison Margiela, was so conspicuous for its lack of frippery it might have easily been interpreted as an emblem of Mr. Gallianos continuing public chastening.

title: Review: At Met Opera, Pagliacci Goes Vaudeville as Cavalleria Turns
description: Someone at the Metropolitan Opera should persuade the director David McVicar to turn off the rotating platform that mars his new production of Mascagnis Cavalleria Rusticana. Over all, Mr. McVicars bleak, spare take on this enduring 1890 one-act , the breakthrough work of the Italian verismo movement, offers some insights into Mascagnis drama of love, betrayal and revenge in a small Sicilian village. And Mr. McVicars daring concept for its traditional companion piece, Leoncavallos Pagliacci, may prod those who think they know this 1892 tale about a hardscrabble troupe of roving commedia dellarte players to think again: Mr. McVicar zaps the setting from late-1860s Calabria to a grimy truck stop in the late 1940s in what could be any bustling Italian town; the players become a troupe of zany vaudevillians.

title: Review: Ballet Hispanico at the Joyce Theater
description: Finding new choreographers is a perennial challenge for artistic directors, and Eduardo Vilaro, who leads Ballet Hispanico, is no different. In 2010, he formed the Instituto Coreogrfico, a creative lab for Latino choreographers and filmmakers, and on Tuesday Ballet Hispanico opened its season at the Joyce Theater with three works, two of which were developed through that program: Miguel Mancillass Conquer and Rosie Herreras Show.Girl.

title: F.D.A. Approves Amgen Drug to Treat Heart Failure
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday approved a drug to treat chronic heart failure that may help keep patients out of the hospital.

title: Elvis Guesthouse, an East Village Bar by Way of Katmandu
description: For night life veterans, departed haunts like Plant Bar, APT and Guernica were influential incubators where avant-garde D.J.s set the tempo. Elvis Guesthouse, an East Village bar opened last month by the team behind Babys All Right, a music club in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, seeks a similar spiritual space.

title: Though Profits Fall, Netflix Shares Surge on Subscriber Growth
description: Netflix beat expectations for subscriber growth both in the United States and globally in the first quarter of this year, as the company accelerated its output of original programming and pushed ahead with its aggressive international expansion.

title: Mayor de Blasio, on Midwest Trip, Seeks to Lead a National Shift to the Left
description: OMAHA  Mayor Bill de Blasio, dismayed by a Democratic Party that he believes has moved too slowly to embrace a populist platform, arrived in the Midwest on Wednesday with an audacious mission: leading the nation leftward.

title: Shopping Events and Sales Happening This Week in New York
description: Get in the spirit for Earth Day by dropping into the H&M Conscious pop-up, a raw birch structure with sustainable metal inlays at H&M Times Square open through Sunday. You can shop for pieces like a dress embellished with recycled sequins and beads ($299) and an organic cotton sleeveless top ($99) made from sustainable materials. Customers who donate clothes to H&Ms garment recycling program will receive a 20 percent discount. At 4 Times Square.

title: Long Before Obama and Iran, Conservatives Compared Reagan to Neville Chamberlain
description: If the wrangling in Washington to give Congress a say on the terms of a final deal on Irans nuclear program caused some irritation in Tehran, the compromise bill approved by a Senate committee on Tuesday also drew catcalls from the far right of the American political spectrum.

title: U.N. Envoy in Yemen Conflict Says He Will Resign
description: The United Nations envoy who had tried to avert a conflict in Yemen said Wednesday that he wants to resign, following vocal criticism of his four years of fruitless diplomacy.

title: A Turning Point at the Yeh Brothers Cup
description: The Yeh Brothers Cup took place in Shanghai from April 8 to Sunday.

title: Barbara Strauch, 63, Science and Health Editor at The Times and Author, Dies
description: Barbara Strauch, a reporter and editor who wrote two books about the brain and directed health and science coverage for The New York Times for a decade, died on Wednesday at her home in Rye, N.Y. She was 63.

title: Freddie and Fannie to Lower Some Fees
description: The federal regulator of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac plans to lower the mortgage fees paid by some borrowers, but the move would amount to only modest help for risky buyers with checkered credit histories.

title: Letters: Eleanor Marx: A Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Rewarding Character and Reportage
description: Kevin Frayer wins the 2015 Getty Images and Chris Hondros Fund Award while Diana Markosian takes the funds emerging photojournalist award.

title: Microsoft, Once an Antitrust Target, Is Now Googles Regulatory Scold
description: BRUSSELS  Not long ago, Microsoft was the scourge of European antitrust regulators.

title: California: Another Guilty Plea in Navy Bribery Case
description: A lieutenant commander on Tuesday became the fifth Navy official and the eighth person over all to plead guilty to federal charges in a bribery scandal involving ship-supply contracts in the Pacific. The lieutenant commander, Todd Dale Malaki, 44, admitted in federal court in San Diego that he had accepted more than $15,000 in cash, hotel stays and the services of a prostitute to help Leonard Glenn Francis, a Malaysian contractor, win Navy business. Mr. Francis and two of his former employees have also pleaded guilty to federal charges. Prosecutors estimate that they overbilled the Navy by at least $35 million for ship supplies and dock services.

title: Colin Bailey Is Named the New Director of Morgan Library
description: The Morgan Library & Museum, which has been without a leader since late last summer, looked West to bring back a longtime New Yorker as its new director, choosing Colin B. Bailey, who has served since 2013 as director of the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco but was for many years before that the chief curator at the Frick Collection.

title: 3 Big I.P.O.s Could End Slow Start for 15 Debuts
description: Early 2015 has been a slow time for companies looking to go public. But a handful of new stock offerings may help jolt that market back to what has been one of the busiest on Wall Street in recent years.

title: Senator Menendezs Legal Fund Raised $431,000 in First Quarter of 2015
description: Senator Robert Menendez, who was indicted this month on federal bribery charges, raised nearly $431,000 for his legal defense fund in the first quarter of the year, according to a report prepared for the Senate Select Committee on Ethics.

title: Jury Begins Deliberations in Etan Patz Case After 10 Weeks
description: A Manhattan jury began deliberating on Wednesday afternoon in the trial of a former store clerk accused of murdering 6-year-old Etan Patz in 1979, one of the most infamous missing-child cases in New Yorks history.

title: Doctors See Benefits and Risks in Medicare Changes
description: Dr. Robert Wergin, president of the American Academy of Family Physicians, made little effort to contain his glee Wednesday over the news that Congress had voted to end a reviled payment system for doctors, simultaneously averting a 21 percent physician pay cut and overhauling the way Medicare will pay doctors in the future.

title: Chicago Pays $5 Million to Family of Black Teenager Killed by Officer
description: CHICAGO  The City Council here agreed on Wednesday to pay $5 million to the family of a black teenager who was fatally shot by a Chicago police officer last fall, as federal and state prosecutors acknowledged that they were conducting a criminal investigation into the shooting.

title: Aaron Hernandez Shed Tackles, but Not His Past
description: Aaron Hernandez grew up in the flagging factory city of Bristol, Conn., where during his youth a declining downtown was prowled by petty criminals who dreamed of making bigger scores in New Englands prosperous hubs.

title: A Year After Sewol Ferry Tragedy, Peace Is Elusive for South Korean City
description: ANSAN, South Korea  The classrooms where the dead students once studied sit empty, as they have since Danwon High School lost nearly three-quarters of its 11th graders to a ferry disaster a year ago. School cafeteria menus for April 2014 hang on the walls. Desks are piled high with offerings from grieving parents and friends: flowers, favorite snacks and notes.

title: Barriers Remain for American Business in Cuba
description: MEXICO CITY  It had become a political sticking point: As long as Cuba remained on the American governments list of states that sponsor terrorism, there would be no historic opening of Americas first full-fledged embassy in Havana in more than 50 years.

title: Wolverine at Newark Airport Is an Uneasy Rider
description: If there were a manual for transporting wolverines, Rule No. 1 would probably go something like this: Make sure the wolverine cannot get out of the cage.

title: A Fluid Barcelona Squad Sends Paris St.-Germain Closer to Elimination
description: PARIS  Most of the signs were recognizable: the incandescent hues of the rosebuds and the radiant splendor of parks and bridges and monuments. All of it arrived this week, as if on cue. So, too, did the tourists. Clichs become such for a reason, and springtime in Paris is, if nothing else, bathed in beauty.

title: Congresss Role in Iran Nuclear Deal Shows Limits of Obamas Power
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  In his assertions of executive power to advance his agenda in an era of gridlock, President Obama has been largely on offense. But his latest battle with Congress not only left him on defense, it actually broke the gridlock. Against him.

title: Dean Skelos, New York Senate Leader, and His Son Are Said to Be Focus of Corruption Inquiry
description: Federal prosecutors have begun presenting evidence to a grand jury considering a case against the leader of the New York State Senate, Dean G. Skelos of Long Island, and his son, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

title: As Season Shifts to Clay Courts, Madison Keys Finds Unexpected Success
description: DANIEL ISLAND, S.C.  After Madison Keyss breakout performance at the Australian Open, her disappointing losses on hardcourts in March seemed to indicate she needed the rest of the spring for recovery and recharging.

title: Iran Is Raising Sophistication and Frequency of Cyberattacks, Study Says
description: WASHINGTON  In February, a year after the Las Vegas Sands was hit by a devastating cyberattack that ruined many of the computers running its casino and hotel operations, the director of national intelligence, James R. Clapper Jr., publicly told Congress what seemed obvious: Iranian hackers were behind the attack.

title: In Test for Unions and Politicians, a Nationwide Protest on Pay
description: The protest by tens of thousands of low-wage workers, students and activists in more than 200 American cities on Wednesday is the most striking effort to date in a two-and-a-half-year-old labor-backed movement that is testing the ability of unions to succeed in an economy populated by easily replaceable service sector workers.

title: Even in New Hampshire, Bridgegate Dogs Christie
description: LONDONDERRY, N.H.  Chris Christies name has tumbled off the list of top-tier presidential candidates. He is sagging in the polls. And in the kind of indignity that creeps up on him with agonizing regularity, a stranger here wisecracked Wednesday morning that he and his wife had been stuck in the George Washington Bridge traffic jam engineered by the governors allies  on their wedding anniversary, no less.

title: The Best and the Worst: The Rangers and the Knicks Are a Study in Contrast
description: The Rangers and the Knicks share two buildings, an owner and not much else.

title: California Parents Opposing State-Mandated Vaccinations of Children Delay Vote
description: SACRAMENTO  Several hundred Californians swarmed the State Capitol on Wednesday to oppose a bill that would eliminate their right not to vaccinate their children against contagious diseases like measles. They were able to help stall a committee vote on the legislation by a week.

title: Raul H. Castro, Arizonas Only Hispanic Governor, Dies at 98
description: Raul H. Castro, Arizonas first and only Hispanic governor and an American ambassador to three Latin American countries, died Friday in San Diego. He was 98.

title: Clinton Foundation Revises Policy on Foreign Donations
description: The Clinton Foundation has adjusted its policy on foreign donations, permitting several countries like Germany and Britain to keep financing existing programs but eliminating contributions from all others.

title: Penguins, in Unfamiliar Spot as Underdog, Still Pose a Threat to the Rangers
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  They may have a roster that includes Sidney Crosby, Evgeni Malkin and Marc-Andre Fleury, but these Pittsburgh Penguins are different.

title: Art Powell, Star Receiver Who Protested Segregation, Dies at 78
description: Art Powell, a star receiver for the New York Titans and the Oakland Raiders of the American Football League in the 1960s and a persistent voice protesting the segregation encountered by the pro football players of his time, died on April 6 at his home in Aliso Viejo, Calif., between Los Angeles and San Diego. He was 78.

title: Russia: Siberian Fires Spread
description: At least 29 people have died in raging brush fires that emergency workers have been unable to quell for nearly a week, the authorities in a region of Siberia said Wednesday. The blazes started in the remote region of Khakassia when small fires set by farmers to burn off their fields spread into neighboring regions, driven by heavy winds. Several dozen towns have been evacuated, and the fires have left thousands homeless.

title: City Council Speaker Draws Ire of Allies on Police Hiring
description: The New York City Council is again calling for the hiring of 1,000 additional police officers, a request that Mayor Bill de Blasio rejected last year.

title: France: Radio Strike Is Ending
description: Most of the striking employees of the public broadcaster Radio France returned to work on Wednesday, four weeks after they walked off the job to protest a proposed reorganization that would have resulted in hundreds of layoffs and the closing of the countrys oldest orchestra. The broadcaster, which operates seven radio stations and two orchestras, is one of Frances most trusted voices in news and entertainment. The strike had left listeners with canned music playlists and abbreviated news broadcasts since March 19. The strike ended after the government appointed a labor mediator and the culture minister, Fleur Pellerin, promised on Monday to work for a satisfactory outcome. Four of the networks five unions voted Tuesday to end the strike, and the last holdout, the CGT union, was expected to return to work this week.

title: Review: Hamlet as an After-Party That Got Out of Hand
description: A lavish tiered wedding cake stands sentinel throughout the new production of Hamlet that opened Wednesday at the Classic Stage Company, with Peter Sarsgaard in the title role. As the presence of this big pile of pastry suggests, the concept behind this stylish-looking modern-dress production directed by Austin Pendleton essentially presents the action as a long dramatic hangover after the wedding celebrations for Claudius (Harris Yulin) and Gertrude (Penelope Allen).

title: Review: Finding Neverland, a Broadway Musical With Matthew Morrison
description: The first entrance applause occurs before even the overture begins. Riotous clapping is occasioned when a bright point of light travels over the ceiling and the curtain of the Lunt-Fontanne Theater in New York, where the push-button, button-pushing musical Finding Neverland opened on Wednesday night.

title: $20 Million Gift to Promote Tolerance on WNET
description: Before the dentist Simon B. Poyta, of Forest Hills, Queens, died in 2006, he expressed a wish that programming on WNET, New Yorks flagship public television station, could help combat the anti-Semitism he witnessed while serving in the army during World War II.

title: Toll Provider
description: THURSDAY PUZZLE  Wow, a tough one today from Joe Krozel and Peter A. Collins, at least for me. Thank goodness for kind crossings.

title: Egypt: Blast Kills Military Cadets
description: Three students at a military academy were killed by a roadside bomb in the Nile Delta town of Kafr el-Sheikh on Wednesday in what appeared to be the latest in a series of attacks by militant groups against members of Egypts security services. The students, who were from 20 to 23 years old, had been waiting for a bus to take them to their academy, which is in Cairo, said Gen. Abdel Rahman Sharah, a security official in Kafr el-Sheikh. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the bombing, which fit a pattern of attacks by militants who have killed hundreds of soldiers, police officers and members of the state security forces over the past 18 months.

title: NBC News Alters Account of Correspondents Kidnapping in Syria
description: NBC News on Wednesday revised its account of the 2012 kidnapping of its chief foreign correspondent, Richard Engel, saying it was likely that Mr. Engel and his reporting team had been abducted by a Sunni militant group, not forces affiliated with the government of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria.

title: Mother Settles for $2.25 Million in Lawsuit Claiming Abuse of Disabled Man at O. D. Heck
description: The mother of a developmentally disabled 22-year-old man who died soon after arriving at a state-run home near Schenectady, N.Y., will receive $2.25 million to settle a lawsuit charging that workers had beaten and humiliated him.

title: Once Again, David Wright Is Foiled by an Injury
description: In the eighth inning of Tuesdays game against the Phillies, David Wright stood near second base for five pitches, fidgeting and clenching his batting gloves with a strained look on his face. He was debating whether he should leave the game.

title: Yankees Sluggers Produce, but the Bullpen Comes Up Short
description: BALTIMORE  The game was unfolding just the way it must for the Yankees to be competitive this season. Two aging sluggers, Carlos Beltran and Alex Rodriguez, had delivered booming hits. Starter Nathan Eovaldi had pitched his way out of trouble, delivering crucial strikeouts. And Manager Joe Girardi could turn to his bullpen with a lead.

title: Tax Returns Show Cuomos Income Rose in 2014, Largely From Memoir Deal
description: ALBANY  According to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos memoir, all things are possible. Recouping his books advance, however, may not be.

title: Mets Complete 3-Game Sweep of Phillies
description: When Eric Campbell walked into the Mets clubhouse Wednesday afternoon, he looked exhausted, and for good reason. The night before, he had been pulled from a game and put on a plane from Sacramento to Las Vegas. From there, in the morning, he had flown to New York and went directly to Citi Field.

title: Whats on TV Thursday
description: 10:30 P.M. (13) JASCHA HEIFETZ: GODS FIDDLER By most accounts, Heifetz (1901-87)  considered the first modern violin virtuoso  was a contradiction: generous and playful when socializing; serious and intense while performing and teaching. And he was a genius whose commitment to his art resulted in two failed marriages, estrangement from his children and very few friends. In this American Masters presentation, Peter Rosen uses home movies and interviews with those Heifetz influenced, including the violinists Itzhak Perlman, Ivry Gitlis and Ida Haendel, to traverse his life from his childhood in Lithuania and studies in St. Petersburg with Leopold Auer to his immigration to New York and later years in Los Angeles. Danny Burstein narrates, reading from Heifetzs letters.

title: Corrections: April 16, 2015
description: NATIONAL

title: Quotation of the Day
description: We are doing something against the initial idea of the Nazis who built this camp. They didnt want it to last. Were making it last.

title: How Do You Keep Your Kids Healthy in Smog-Choked China?
description: On a recent morning in Arizona, my two young sons padded out into their grandparents garden to marvel at the flowers of a hedgehog cactus. The spectacular pink and yellow blossoms of this particular plant burst open once a year and last for only a day.

title: A New Day for the Minimum Wage?
description: Nationwide protests on Wednesday by tens of thousands of low-wage workers were planned long before Hillary Rodham Clinton announced her candidacy for president on Sunday. But the demonstrations  part of the Fight for $15 campaign that began with fast-food workers in 2012 and now includes retail employees, child-care workers, home-care aides, airport workers and adjunct professors, among others  have proved well timed.

title: Congressional Pressure on an Iran Deal
President Vladimir Putins Dangerous Moves
description: President Vladimir Putin of Russia has added new, chilling nuclear threats to his aggression in Ukraine, where 6,000 people have been killed in a war with Russian-backed separatists. Mr. Putin wants to expand his countrys influence and standing, but his alarming behavior has estranged Russia from most other major powers, damaged its economy and narrowed its future options.

title: Take Your Hillary Temperature
description: A simple quiz will show if youre ready for the candidate.
