description: In Aaron Hernandez, Guilty of Murder, Shed Tackles, but Not His Past, Bill Pennington writes about the elite tight ends background and trial.

title: Test Yourself | Finding Centuries of History While Fixing the Toilet
description: Here are several paragraphs from an April 15 article, Centuries of Italian History Are Unearthed in Quest to Fix Toilet.

title: A Landing Place on the Upper West Side
description: For several years, Hugo Nicholls and Adam Flagg, both flight attendants, had two homes. First came a Houston condominium, owned by Mr. Nicholls, who was originally based there. Then, in 2009, they bought an Upper East Side co-op. By then, both were based in Newark.

title: Support for Bostons Olympic Bid Is Still Lacking
description: BOSTON  Support for a Boston Olympics in 2024 may have edged up slightly since some dismal polls last month, but on the whole, more people still oppose having the Games here than support it. And they remain seriously concerned about the financing.

title: Gilberto Valle, Ex-New York Police Officer, Talks About His Cannibalism Fantasies in Film
description: Months before his arrest in late 2012, Gilberto Valle, then a New York police officer, sat at his computer, hiding behind fictional online identities and exchanging messages about abducting, torturing, killing and eating women.

title: Hydrogen Fuel Cell Cars Return for Another Run
description: FOR decades, hydrogen has been the Dracula of automotive fuels: Just when you think a stake has been driven through its zero-emissions heart, the technology rises from the grave.

title: Behind Outlander, on Starz, True Hearts in the Highlands
description: Sometimes its hard to tell where the real-life love story between Ronald D. Moore and Terry Dresbach begins and the fictional one they depict on Outlander ends.

title: Big Money From Super PACs Is Eroding the Power of Parties
description: Six months ago, I would have told you that April 15, the date when campaigns report their first-quarter fund-raising tallies, could be one of the most interesting early milestones of the Republican primary season.

title: Judges Skeptical of Challenge to Proposed E.P.A. Rule on Climate Change
description: WASHINGTON  A panel of federal judges appeared inclined on Thursday to dismiss the first legal challenge to President Obamas most far-reaching regulation to slow climate change.

title: A Century After Armenian Genocide, Turkeys Denial Only Deepens
description: CUNGUS, Turkey  The crumbling stone monastery, built into the hillside, stands as a forlorn monument to an awful past. So, too, does the decaying church on the other side of this mountain village. Farther out, a crevice is sliced into the earth, so deep that peering into it, one sees only blackness. Haunting for its history, it was there that a century ago, an untold number of Armenians were tossed to their deaths.

title: Who Lived Long Ago Where You Live Now?
description: The Faggiano family in Italy dug a hole to look for a sewage pipe. What they found instead were layers of history going back before the time of Jesus: a floor of medieval stone, an ancient Roman chamber used to store grain and the basement of a Franciscan convent where nuns had once prepared the bodies of the dead.

title: Another Clinton Promises to Fix Political Financing
description: More than 20 years ago, a newly elected President Bill Clinton decided that overhauling the countrys loophole-ridden campaign fund-raising rules would be a top goal of his first year in office. Months later, faced with battles over health care and the deficit as well as opposition from lawmakers in his own party who had prospered under the old political-money regime, Mr. Clinton dropped the issue.

title: Alexa von Tobel | Dreaming Big
description: Alexa von Tobel dropped out of Harvard Business School to start her financial planning service, LearnVest. Now with more than 150 employees, Ms. von Tobel says she often sees that people dont dream big enough.

title: At Marathon in North Korea, Curiosity Goes a Long Way
description: PYONGYANG, North Korea  By 8:30 a.m. Sunday, the 50,000 seats in Kim Il-sung Stadium were nearly filled with men in Mao suits and coats and ties, women in dresses and heels, and soldiers in olive-drab hats with crowns as wide as a discus.

title: Rewarding Character and Reportage
description: Kevin Frayer, a freelance photographer who works for Getty News in China, has won the 2015 Getty Images and Chris Hondros Fund Award. Diana Markosian, 25, was selected for the funds emerging photojournalist award.

title: South African Investment Firm to Pay $1 Billion for Stake in Virgin Active
description: LONDON  Brait, the South African investment firm, said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire an 80 percent stake in Virgin Active, the health club chain that is partly owned by the billionaire Richard Bransons Virgin Group.

title: Deutsche Wohnens Bid to Acquire Austrian Rival Fails
description: LONDON  The German real estate company Deutsche Wohnen said late on Wednesday that it had failed to acquire enough shares from investors of Conwert Immobilien Invest to proceed with a takeover bid for its Austrian rival.

title: Snub at Sewol Ferry Memorial Shows Rawness of Wounds in South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  In a sign of unabated anger with the government over last years Sewol ferry disaster, which killed more than 300 people, families of the victims refused to see President Park Geun-hye on Thursday when she visited a memorial on the anniversary of the sinking.

title: A Rocky Mountain Haven for Lovers of Books and the West
description: Plans are underway to convert a rural Colorado property into a research institution for reconnecting people with books and the West.

title: Envisioning a Colorado Haven for Readers, Nestled Amid Mountains of Books
description: SOUTH PARK, Colo.  The project is striking in its ambition: a sprawling research institution situated on a ranch at 10,000 feet above sea level, outfitted with 32,000 volumes, many of them about the Rocky Mountain region, plus artists studios, dormitories and a dining hall  a place for academics, birders, hikers and others to study and savor the West.

title: Operation Nemesis, by Eric Bogosian
description: On March 15, 1921, a 25-year-old Armenian in Berlin, Soghomon Tehlirian, shot and killed Mehmet Talat Pasha, who had been the Ottoman minister of the interior during World War I. After the Ottomans collapse, Talat had fled into secret exile and was now plotting a return to power with the other Young Turks (or, formally, the Committee for Union and Progress) who had led Turkey into its disastrous wartime alliance with Germany. To Tehlirian, however, Talat was something infinitely worse than simply one of the leaders of a defeated empire. He was a member of the central committee, with a key role in authorizing the Armenian genocide, the series of deportations and massacres in 1915-16 that under the fog of war had murdered much of Tehlirians family and some one and a half million other Armenians.

title: The Fall of the Ottomans, by Eugene Rogan
description: In November 1914, the worlds only great Muslim empire was drawn into a life-or-death struggle against three historically Christian powers  Britain, France and Russia. All parties made frantic calculations about the likely intertwining of religion and strategy. The playing out, and surprise overturning, of these calculations informs every page of Eugene Rogans intricately worked but very readable account of the Ottoman theocracys demise.

title: Divorce May Be Bad for the Heart, Especially for Women
description: Divorce may be linked to a higher risk for heart attack, especially in women.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Scribd Expands Audiobook Catalog in Deal With Penguin Random House
description: E-book subscription services are bulking up and expanding their libraries and services as the competition to become the Netflix of books escalates. On Thursday, the subscription reading service Scribd announced that it would add more than 9,000 audiobooks from Penguin Random House Audio to its platform, increasing its audiobook catalog to more than 45,000 titles.

title: New York Today: Little Engines That Wont
Throwback Thursday | The 150th Anniversary of the Assassination of Abraham Lincoln
description: A slide show from Abraham Lincoln, the One President All of Them Want to Be More Like.

title: Daily Report: Joining American Peers, Google Gets Caught in Europes Cross Hairs
description: Over the last few decades, Europes regulators have challenged the practices of some of the titans of American technology, including Microsoft, Intel and now Google, Vindu Goel, Quentin Hardy and Mark Scott report.

title: Woe of White Men, Again?
description: Hillary Clintons entry into the race for the presidency has goosed the egos of some conservative ganders.

title: Q. and A. With the Feds John Williams: Timing of Rate Rise Is Overrated
description: John Williams, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, says hes done talking about which month the Fed will start to raise its benchmark interest rate.

title: Alexa von Tobel of LearnVest: No, Really, Whats Your Weakness?
description: This interview with Alexa von Tobel, chief executive of LearnVest, the financial planning company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Reclaiming the Age-Old Art of Getting Lost
description: Lost in the Latin Quarter, I ended up, literally, at the foot of Michel de Montaigne.

title: Maria Loi on Greeces Quiet Islands
description: For the chef Maria Loi, 60, her native Greece is the ultimate vacation destination, but of course shes biased. Born in the village Thermo, about two hours west of Athens, she is something of a celebrity in the country because of her more than 34 cookbooks on local cuisine and her regular television appearances. Now, she lives both in Greece, where she runs a restaurant called Kouzina Maria Loi in the port town of Nafpaktos, and in New York, where she owns Loi Estiatorio in Manhattan. When she is not shuttling between her two hometowns, she unwinds with jaunts to one of Greeces lesser-known islands, or by visiting under-the-radar cities on the mainland. She advises other travelers to do the same. Theres much more to discover in my country than overly touristy Athens, Mykonos and Santorini, she said, and if you go off the typical path, youll find fewer crowds but more beauty. Following are edited excerpts from a conversation with Ms. Loi.

title: A Visual Remix
description: When he visited the Plumbe National Daguerrian Gallery in Manhattan in 1846, Walt Whitman was astonished. What a spectacle! he wrote. In whichever direction you turn your peering gaze, you see nought but human faces! There they stretch, from floor to ceiling  hundreds of them. In the seven years between the invention of the daguerreotype and Whitmans visit to Plumbes, the medium had become popular enough to generate an impressive, and even hectic, stream of images. Now, toward the end of photographys second century, that stream has become torrential.

title: The Disturbing Photography of Sally Mann
description: This cover story appeared in the magazine on Sept. 27, 1992, and is discussed in an article by Sally Mann in the April 19 issue.

title: Speaking Truth to the Supreme Court
description: Five years ago this month, Justice John Paul Stevens announced that after more than 36 years on the Supreme Court, he planned to retire. Next Monday, the retired Justice Stevens turns 95.

title: Why Should Cancer Make Me Want to Knit?
description: Two years ago, when I was in the midst of treatment for breast cancer, Susan, a dear friend, showed up on my doorstep with a bag of yarn and two wooden needles. I am going to teach you to knit, she announced. This is what got me through my own horrible year of treatment.

title: Sally Manns Exposure
description: In September 1992, I published my third book of photographs, Immediate Family. The book contained 60 photographs from a decade-long series of more than 200 pictures of my children, Emmett, Jessie and Virginia, who were about 6, 4 and 1 when I started the project. The photographs show them going about their lives, sometimes without clothing, on our farm tucked into the Virginia hills. For miles in all directions, there was not a breathing soul. When we were on the farm, we were isolated, not just by geography but by the primitive living conditions: no electricity, no running water and, of course, no computer, no phone. Out of a conviction that my lens should remain open to the full scope of their childhood, and with the willing, creative participation of everyone involved, I photographed their triumphs, confusion, harmony and isolation, as well as the hardships that tend to befall children  bruises, vomit, bloody noses, wet beds  all of it.

title: China Building Aircraft Runway in Disputed Spratly Islands
description: BEIJING  China is building a concrete runway on an island in the South China Seas contested waters that will be capable of handling military aircraft when finished, satellite images released Thursday show.

title: Kwame Anthony Appiah: The Complexities of Black Folk
description: This is the 10th in a series of interviews with philosophers on race that I am conducting for The Stone. This weeks conversation is with Kwame Anthony Appiah, who teaches in New York Universitys department of philosophy and its school of law. He has been the president of the American Philosophical Association, Eastern Division, and of the PEN American Center. He is the author of numerous books, including, most recently, Lines of Descent: W.E.B. Du Bois and the Emergence of Identity.  George Yancy

title: Today in Politics: Jeb Bush Has Big Plans for a State That Upset His Brother
description: Good Thursday morning from Washington, where the political battle between President Obama and Congress over an Iran nuclear deal continues even in the face of compromise. Hillary Rodham Clinton finishes up in Iowa, and in New Hampshire, Jeb Bush is just getting started, even if he has yet to declare his candidacy or had to campaign for several years.

title: European Car Sales Make Biggest Leap in a Year
description: PARIS  European automakers last month had their best showing in a year, an industry report showed on Thursday, as the economic recovery and incentive programs lifted sales across the region.

title: Doubling of Search Zone Planned if Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 Isnt Found Before June
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Officials from Malaysia, Australia and China said Thursday that they would double the search area for the Malaysia Airlines jet that disappeared more than a year ago if it is not found by the end of next month.

title: The Do-Gooder Corporation
Reviving Giacomettis Legacy
description: PARIS  For much of his life, the Swiss sculptor Alberto Giacometti (1901-1966) lived and worked out of a cramped and cluttered atelier in the 14th Arrondissement of Paris where paint-stained surfaces were covered with busts and figurines and walls were sketched and scrawled over. The artist toiled day and night in this spartan setting, pausing for meals with plaster still stuck in his hair.

title: 100 Years Later, a Genocide Haunts the Armenian Psyche
description: For surviving Armenians and their descendants, the genocide by Ottoman Turks became a central marker of their identity, the psychic wounds passed through generations.

title: Lindstrm Loses Umlauts on Road Signs, and the Town is Dotted With Displeasure
description: Some of the residents of Lindstrm, Minn., did not even realize that the umlauts were gone.

title: Morning Agenda: Bernanke, Citadels New Adviser
description: BERNANKE, CITADELS NEW ADVISER | In the latest and most prominent move by a Washington insider through the revolving door into the financial industry, the former Federal Reserve chairman Ben S. Bernanke will become a senior adviser to the Citadel Investment Group, the $25 billion hedge fund founded by the billionaire Kenneth C. Griffin,  Andrew Ross Sorkin and Alexandra Stevenson report.

title: 100 Years Later, a Genocide Haunts the Armenian Psyche
description: For surviving Armenians and their descendants, the genocide by Ottoman Turks became a central marker of their identity, the psychic wounds passed through generations.

title: Freeman Dyson: By the Book
description: The physicist, mathematician and author, most recently, of Dreams of Earth and Sky says the best books he knows about mathematics and physics are nearly a hundred years old.

title: Review: In Toni Morrisons God Help the Child, Adults Are Hobbled by the Pain of the Past
description: One of the great themes that threads its way through Toni Morrisons work like a haunting melody is the hold that time past exerts over time present. In larger historical terms, it is the horror of slavery and its echoing legacy that her characters struggle with. In personal terms, it is an emotional wound or loss  and the fear of suffering such pain again  that inhibits her women and men, making them wary of the very sort of love and intimacy that might heal and complete them.

title: In Something Rotten!, if Music Be the Food of Farce, Play On
description: Something Rotten!, which opens Wednesday, is about a pair of brothers, Nick and Nigel Bottom, Elizabethan-era playwrights who are more or less learning on the job. Unable to get anywhere in a theatrical world dominated by Shakespeare, they consult a soothsayer, who informs them that the next new thing will be the musical, and with mixed results they set about trying to write one. An early number they drop, for example, is a celebration of the Black Death.

title: Pakistani Justices Suspend Executions Ordered by Military Courts
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistans Supreme Court on Thursday suspended the death sentences issued by recently established military courts in a move that could incite tensions between the countrys powerful military and its judiciary.

title: A Practice Nook in the Subway
description: Dear Diary:

title: Will Carine Roitfeld & Uniqlo Be More or Less Than the Sum of Its Parts?
description: On Thursday, the Japanese clothing retailer Uniqlo announced that its next collaboration would be with Carine Roitfeld, the former French Vogue editor and former Tom Ford muse who is now the global fashion director at Harpers Bazaar International and editor of her own magazine, named after herself (CR Fashion Book). Consisting of 40 pieces from outer wear to inner wear, Ms. Roitfelds Uniqlo line will go on sale in October.

title: Celebrating the Fast-Moving, Bug-Eyed, Wily World of Hip-Hop Mixtape Covers
description: Mixtapes have been around almost since hip-hops beginning, but in the last decade, their ubiquity and efficacy have made them perhaps the prime way for new artists to be discovered and for older artists to re-establish their bona fides. At the same time, now that theyre everywhere, its tough to stand out and win attention.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs: Story Lines to Watch
description: It took all 82 games to decide many of the N.B.A. playoff seedings, but the field is set. A look at some matchups reveals several compelling story lines to follow when postseason play begins Saturday.

title: At Jin Youzhis Funeral, a Quiet Farewell to Chinas Imperial Past
description: The simple funeral was fitting for a man who was the last surviving sibling of Chinas final emperor, but who led a commoners life.

title: Goldman Sachs Reports Robust Earnings as Trading Revives
description: Goldman Sachs used a strong quarter to fire back against recent criticism of its business model and the opportunities on Wall Street.

title: Encouraging Teenagers to Read, by Choosing Books From the Non-Y.A. Shelves
description: My sons have always been voracious readers. One started early, the other started late, but once they got going, both were hooked. Then, one day this winter, I looked around my teenagers room and noticed something was missing. Where books once littered his room, I now find guitar picks, running spikes and dirty socks.

title: Cost-Cutting Helps Citigroup Beat Estimates
description: Citigroup was able to take a rare victory lap on Thursday, reporting first-quarter results that were devoid of the kind of scandal, losses and regulatory missteps that have come to plague the bank.

title: Favorite Streets in Europe
description: From Lisbon to Milan, 12 quintessential urban byways.

title: Cycling Start-Up Peloton Raises $30 Million
description: Investors appear enamored of Peloton and its advanced home-cycling stationary bicycles, so much so that the start-up has raised money again to continue its expansion.

title: Editorial Contest Winner | The N.H.L. Should Do Away With Fighting
description: For the next 10 days we will be honoring each of the Top 10 winners of our Second Annual Student Editorial Contest by publishing an essay a day, in the order of submission.

title: South Korean President on Raising Ferry
description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea spoke on the anniversary of the ferry sinking that killed more than 300 people, most of them high school students, promising that the sunken ship would be raised.

title: Anne Hathaway and Julie Taymor Bring Grounded to the Public Theater
description: Anne Hathaway vividly remembers the first time she went to Shakespeare in the Park, to see a production of The Seagull featuring Meryl Streep, Kevin Kline, Christopher Walken, Natalie Portman and Philip Seymour Hoffman, among others.

title: The Musical Amazing Grace to Open on Broadway This Summer
description: An inspirational musical about the British slave trader who composed Amazing Grace will open on Broadway this summer.

title: PEN Announces Finalists for 2015 Awards
description: The PEN American Center on Thursday announced the shortlists and judges for the 2015 PEN Literary Awards. Taken together, the awards, fellowships and grants from the literary and human rights organization will confer $150,000 on writers, editors and translators.

title: Cannes Competition Includes Films by Todd Haynes and Gus Van Sant
description: New films by Todd Haynes, Gus Van Sant and Denis Villeneuve are among the entries in the official competition of the 68th annual Cannes Film Festival, organizers announced Thursday. Projects from Yorgos Lanthimos of Greece and three leading Italian directors  Matteo Garrone, Nanni Moretti and Paolo Sorrentino  also made the cut.

title: Dita Von Teese Brings Burlesque to a Desert Getaway
description: For the past 36 years, Canyon Ranch in Arizona has had reputation as a desert getaway where guests enjoyed deep-tissue massages and seminars about the power of possibility.

title: China Halts New Policy on Tech for Banks
description: HONG KONG  China has suspended a policy that would have effectively pushed foreign technology companies out of the countrys banking sector, according to a note sent by Chinese regulators to banks.

title: Go Hammerheads! Winning With Autism
description: Children with disabilities often cant participate in team sports. A new documentary called Swim Team chronicles the Jersey Hammerheads, a swim team for kids with autism.

title: A Swim Team for Teens With Autism
description: Team sports are a rite of passage for many children, but kids with disabilities often cant participate. A new documentary called Swim Team chronicles the Jersey Hammerheads, a swim team for children with autism.

title: When Old Glory Returned to Fort Sumter
description: On the evening of April 13, 1865, the steamship Oceanus arrived in Charleston, S.C., after a three-day trip from New York City. Passing by Fort Sumter, the island fort where the Civil War had begun, the ships nearly 200 passengers, most of whom were members of minister Henry Ward Beechers Brooklyn congregation, broke out into song. Praise God, from whom all blessings flow! / Praise Him, all creatures here below! they bellowed.

title: Search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370
description: Officials from Malaysia and Australia said they would double the search area for the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 if its wreckage was not found in the current target area.

title: Clues to How an Electric Treatment for Parkinsons Works
description: In 1998, Dr. Philip A. Starr started putting electrodes in peoples brains.

title: Advanced N.H.L. Statistics Dont Like the Rangers
description: The Rangers finished the season with the best record in the N.H.L. and are widely touted as the Stanley Cup favorites.

title: Cristobal Balenciagas Lace Legacy
description: A new exhibition at the Museum of Lace and Fashion celebrates the life  the 120th anniversary of his birth  and legacy  particularly, innovative silk silhouettes  of Cristbal Balenciaga, who founded the Balenciaga fashion house in Spain in 1937. For the show, the curator Catherine Join-Diterle, with the help of the designers namesake foundation, first gathered creations from the museums own 18-piece Balenciaga collection in Calais, France. She then brought in vintage Balenciaga from the Cristbal Balenciaga Museum in Getaria, Spain (which will host the show in 2016), as well as loaned designs from Pariss Museum of Decorative Arts, Palais Galliera and Maison Lesage. On view will be a total of 75 items, some of which have never been seen before, and many of which feature lace from Calais, a small city known for its manufacturing of the delicate material. (The museum itself was once an old lace factory.)

title: Tribeca Film Festival Interview: Pamela Romanowsky on The Adderall Diaries
description: This is one in a series of interviews focusing on New York-centric movies having their premieres at the Tribeca Film Festival.

title: Colleagues Addicted to Tech
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: Contested Artifacts from Internment Camps Withdrawn from Auction
description: Hundreds of artifacts from Japanese-Americans held in internment camps during World War II were withdrawn from auction Wednesday night.

title: Vatican Ends Battle With U.S. Catholic Nuns Group
description: The Vatican has abruptly ended its takeover of the main leadership group of American nuns two years earlier than expected, allowing Pope Francis to put to rest a confrontation started by his predecessor that created an uproar among American Catholics who had rallied to the sisters defense.

title: Tune In to The Times
description: Mary Anne Weaver , a contributor to The New York Times Magazine, joined MSNBCs Morning Joe to discuss her in-depth cover story on why middle-class British Muslims are joining Islamist militant groups so rapidly.

title: 2 Brooklyn Landlords, Accused of Making Units Unlivable, Are Charged With Fraud
description: One morning in February 2014, Silveria Hormiga, who lived at 324 Central Avenue in Bushwick, a rapidly gentrifying area of Brooklyn, left for a doctors appointment.

title: 1915: Turkish Sultan May Resign
description: A council of the Imperial dynasty has been held at Constantinople, with the Sultan presiding. The council discussed the possibility of the capture of Constantinople by the Allies and the necessity of transferring the capital to the interior of Asia Minor. The Sultan, who was very depressed, said he owed his accession to the throne to the Young Turks and the revolution, but that he would rather never have reigned than see the misfortunes which their inexperienced and rash policy had brought on Turkey. He declared he was determined to abdicate if it became necessary to transfer the capital to Asia Minor.  The New York Herald, European Edition, April 17, 1915

title: Etsy I.P.O. Tests Pledge to Balance Social Mission and Profit
description: The online craft bazaar Etsy made its debut on the Nasdaq stock market Thursday, signaling the birth of an unusual public corporation  and not just because its employees carry around compost on bicycles, or because its regulatory filings are peppered with phrases like, We keep it real, always.

title: From Michigan to Alabama, a 690-Mile Yard Sale
description: The Worlds Longest Yard Sale runs 690 miles along U.S. Highway 127 from five miles north of Addison, Mich. to Gadsden, Ala.

title: Celebrating 50 Years of New Yorks Landmarks Law (at a Landmark, of Course)
description: At a party on Wednesday night that was all about landmarks, the where-were-you-then question simply had to be asked: Where were you on April 19, 1965, when Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr. signed New York Citys landmarks law?

title: Carly Fiorina Makes Case That She Could Offset Hillary Clinton
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons candidacy could make history by bringing the first female president to the White House, but one potential Republican opponent has an idea for neutralizing her powerto galvanize women: nominate a woman to run against her.

title: Viewfinder: Lexie Moreland
description: Lexie Morelands photos of Michael C. Hall preparing for his role in Hedwig and the Angry Inch document private moments in the actors nightly transformation.

title: Casa Del Chef
description: This restaurant, run by an alum of Blue Hill at Stone Barns, aims for more than just Ecuadorean comforts.

title: At Casa Del Chef in Woodside, Queens, the Goals Are Lofty
description: At the end of each day as head cook at Academy of the City Charter School in Woodside, Queens, Alfonso Zhicay hops onto his bike and makes his way a mile south to Casa Del Chef, the restaurant he opened last August near the No. 7 train tracks.

title: Jackpots for Local TV Stations in F.C.C. Auction of Airwaves
description: LAS VEGAS  The pitch to television broadcasters this week was not easy for them to swallow. It is a good time, they were told, to sell their most precious resource.

title: Pragues Cool New Crop of Collective Showrooms
description: Once limited to just a few scattered shops and showrooms, Pragues design scene is currently experiencing a boom with storefronts and studios opening at a striking pace. And a new crop of collective showrooms, inspired spaces that house multiple designers under one roof, increasingly double as studios and local hangouts.

title: A Generous (and Unwanted) Gift
1965: Mississippi Floods New Areas
description: CHICAGO  Raging waters of the flooding Mississippi and its tributaries spread over new areas today [April 16], causing stepped-up evacuation of lowland residents and creating new destruction. Along a 400-mile stretch of the rampaging river from Minneapolis-St. Paul, Minn., to south of Hannibal, Mo., thousands of volunteers labored to shore up dikes against the worst spring flooding on record. The number of persons already driven from their homes in North Dakota, Minnesota and Wisconsin was estimated at between 30,000 and 35,000.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 17, 1965.

title: BlackRock Says Assets Grew 8% in Quarter
description: WASHINGTON  As regulators in Washington warn of the risks that large asset management companies may pose to the markets, BlackRock, the largest of them all, continues to rake in heavy investment flows.

title: Palestinian Women Join Effort to Keep Jews From Contested Holy Site
description: JERUSALEM  The women, covered face-to-toe, surrounded the Jewish group walking through the contested holy site in Jerusalem. The army of Muhammad is coming! the women shouted.

title: Favorite Streets in 12 European Cities
description: Cobbled lanes, broad avenues, streets for gallery-hoppers, food-lovers, shoppers and flneurs: Contributors in 12 European cities describe the byways (including one river) they love.

title: Highlights From Putins Annual Call-In
description: In his televised call-in with the nation on Thursday, President Vladimir V. Putin discussed the economy and said, I tell you straight and clearly: There are no Russian troops in Ukraine.

title: Ryan Sullivan Scales Up
description: The young artists abstract drip paintings for a new show at Miamis Institute of Contemporary Art are the largest of his career.

title: Ferran Adri Serves Up a Bubbly Night in Barcelona
description: The chef celebrated El Bulli Foundations partnership with Dom Prignon with 29 different hors doeuvres, paired with a new champagne vintage.

title: Etsy, Virtu and Party City All Climb in Their Stock Market Debuts
description: Three prominent companies  Etsy, Virtu Financial and Party City  made promising stock debuts on Thursday, potentially providing a jolt to the market for initial public offerings that has been slow so far this year.

title: More Bills in G.O.P. Senate; Less Democratic Support
description: Eager to show it can function, the new Republican majority in the Senate has cracked open a window for legislation.

title: Next Round of Nuclear Talks With Iran Set for Next Week
description: TEHRAN  The next round of nuclear talks between world powers and Iran is scheduled for next week in Vienna, as the two sides begin to address the issues they left unresolved earlier this month in Lausanne, Switzerland, and try to conclude a comprehensive agreement by the end of June.

title: In Debate Around Sally Manns Photography, Too Much Is Exposed
description: What an artist captures, what a mother knows and what the public sees can be dangerously different things.

title: Wonder Woman Gets a New Female Director
description: LOS ANGELES  Just days after Warner Brothers said Michelle MacLaren had departed as the director of its planned Wonder Woman film, the studio replaced her with Patty Jenkins, who had previously been in and out of Marvel Entertainments Thor 2, Variety and others reported.

title: War in Yemen Is Allowing Qaeda Group to Expand
description: DOWAAN, Yemen  Al Qaedas branch in Yemen took control of a major airport and an oil export terminal in the southern part of the country on Thursday, expanding the resurgent militant groups reach just two weeks after it seized the  nearby city of Al Mukalla and emptied its bank and prison.

title: Without Bidding, Eugene, Ore., Is Abruptly Awarded World Track Championships
description: There was surprise in multiple time zones on Thursday when Eugene, Ore., became the first city in the United States to secure the world outdoor track and field championships. It will stage them in 2021 without the usual constraint of having had to win a formal bidding process.

title: Dealing With Being Dissed by a Disinvite
description: A month ago, I received an Evite to a colleagues birthday party. I didnt open it right away because I could see all the details in the message. I also had to ask mutual friends whether spouses were invited and find a babysitter. There was no R.S.V.P. date. Today, I tried responding (the party is still three weeks away), but when I clicked on the link, I got this message: Sorry, you are not on the guest list for this event. Was I disinvited? When I see the host, should I pretend this never happened?

title: Living With Cancer: In and Out of the Closet
description: In a memoir, The Summer of Her Baldness, the visual artist and theorist Catherine Lord finds the cancer closet . . . at least as complicated as the sexuality closet: You can never get entirely out and you can never get entirely back in.

title: Use of E-Cigarettes Rises Sharply Among Teenagers, Report Says
description: Kenny, a high school senior in Weston, Fla., likes to puff e-cigarettes during study sessions with friends after school. James, a senior in Fauquier County, Va., uses them outside at lunch with friends who do smoke tricks. Tom, a sophomore from Westchester County, uses them while hiking with friends.

title: Welcome to Your First Year as a Lawyer. Your Salary Is $160,000.
description: Salaries for lawyers starting out at firms have remained flat, with an annual pay of $160,000 continuing to be the top of the market, according to a new survey from the National Association for Law Placement.

title: Hillary Clinton Re-emerges, by Design (but Also by Surprise)
description: Did you hear the one about the presidential candidate who walks into a Chipotle restaurant in Ohio? She orders a burrito bowl and makes headlines worldwide.

title: Its N.B.A. Playoff Time. Pay No Attention to Those Losing Records.
description: The N.B.A. playoffs this year have an exciting cast. There is Stephen Curry and the supercharged Warriors; the veterans on the Spurs; the Pelicans and the playoff debutant Anthony Davis; and LeBron James in his return to Cleveland.

title: Deal Reached on Fast-Track Authority for Obama on Trade Accord
description: WASHINGTON  Key congressional leaders agreed on Thursday on legislation to give President Obama special authority to finish negotiating one of the worlds largest trade accords, opening a rare battle that aligns the president with Republicans against a broad coalition of Democrats.

title: Blackstone Reports Sharp Rise in Profit
description: Blackstone, fresh off its real estate deal with General Electric, continues to mint money in its two largest areas of focus: private equity and global real estate.

title: How Presidential Campaigns Became Two-Year Marathons
description: The comedian John Oliver doesnt think the length of the American presidential campaign is funny. I have no interest whatsoever in the 2016 election, at the start of 2015, he recently told reporters. Theres a time and a place for that, and its in 2016.

title: N.Y.U. Labor Guidelines Failed to Protect 10,000 Workers in Abu Dhabi, Report Says
description: About one-third of the migrant construction workers employed at New York Universitys campus in Abu Dhabi  or about 10,000 people  were excluded from the protections of the universitys labor guidelines ensuring fair wages, hours and living conditions, according to an investigative report issued on Thursday.

title: A Yale Graduate Leaves a Trail of Ventures and Debts
description: In many ways, Joshua Bryce Newman fits the part of the young, successful entrepreneur.

title: With Eye on Mobile, Yahoo Revises Its Search Partnership With Microsoft
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Marissa Mayer has finally gotten what shes wanted ever since she left Google three years ago to run Yahoo: a chance to build a new experience for searching the web and mobile phones.

title: Who Votes For Rubio?
description: When Ted Cruz entered the race a few weeks ago I did my best to conjure a scenarioin which he somehow emerged as the Republican nominee. With Marco Rubio, officially in earlier this week, the conjuring is easier: Ive always thought that the Florida Senator is well-positionedas a primary contender, because hes closer to the G.O.P.s center of gravity than any nominee since George W. Bush, because hes been ahead of his rivals in establishingan actual policy vision (its flaws notwithstanding), andbecause hes personally appealing (inspiring immigrant background, no Bush-family baggage, gives a great speech) in ways that distinguish himevenin a pretty deep field.

title: Shareholder Litigation That Works
description: Charles Korsmo is an assistant professor at Case Western Reserve School of Law, and Minor Myers is an associate professor at Brooklyn Law School. They provide compensated advice on stockholder appraisal.

title: Lawsuit Against Yale Graduate
description: The trail of litigation against Joshua Bryce Newman began with Cyan Pictures, an independent movie production company he founded in Manhattan in 2002.

title: Florida Governor to Sue Obama Administration Over Medicaid Expansion
description: A standoff over expanding Medicaid in Florida escalated on Thursday after Gov. Rick Scott, a Republican, said he planned to sue the Obama administration for using what he called coercion tactics to try to pressure the state into adopting the program, a centerpiece of the presidents contentious Affordable Care Act.

title: Book by Slain Charlie Hebdo Editor Argues Islam Is Not Exempt From Ridicule
description: PARIS  Stphane Charbonnier, the editorial director of the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo who was assassinated by Islamist gunmen in Paris in January, is proving as defiant in death as he was in life.

title: Star Wars Trailer Is Unveiled for Ecstatic Fans
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Most fan conventions are known for high hysterics, but the reaction to the debut of the second Star Wars: Episode VII  The Force Awakens teaser trailer here on Thursday was nothing less than bone rattling.

title: Goldmans Improved Returns Come at Higher Risk
description: Goldman Sachs is replacing one earnings problem with another.

title: A Balancing Act for Jeb Bush in 1989
description: A series of diplomatic cables tied to a business trip Jeb Bush made to Nigeria in March 1989 highlighted the tension between his own business interests and the privileges and scrutiny that came with being the son of a president.

title: For Jeb Bush the Businessman, Some Deals Brought Grief
description: Barely a month after his fathers inauguration as president in 1989, Jeb Bush and his new business partners landed in Nigeria.

title: Palestinian Driver Suspected of Deliberately Hitting Jerusalem Bus Stop
description: JERUSALEM  A preliminary investigation of a Palestinian driver who crashed into a bus stop in Jerusalem late Wednesday night, killing an Israeli man and injuring an Israeli woman, reinforced suspicions that he had rammed his car into the pedestrians intentionally, the Israeli police said Thursday.

title: Visiting Auschwitz: Reporters Notebook
description: The day I was scheduled to fly from Paris to Krakow, to visit Auschwitz, there was an air traffic control strike in France and hundreds of flights were canceled. Luckily, not mine.

title: Verbatim: I Believe I Can Fly (With Some Help)
description: Senator John Cornyn of Texas, the Republican whip, when asked about the gyrocopter that landed on the Capitol lawn on Wednesday.

title: N.F.L. to Reinstate Vikings Adrian Peterson
description: Minnesota Vikings running back Adrian Peterson will be reinstated on Friday, ending one of the N.F.L.s more complex and embarrassing suspensions.

title: Generic Version of Copaxone, Multiple Sclerosis Drug, Is Approved
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved the first generic substitute for Copaxone, a widely used drug for multiple sclerosis and the biggest-selling product for Teva Pharmaceutical Industries.

title: Ebola Researchers Take New Look at Risk of Sexual Transmission
description: Concerned about the potential for sexual transmission of Ebola, international health officials are investigating new reports of suspected cases and beginning studies to determine how often and how long the virus remains active in semen. And, for now, they are warning Ebola survivors to practice protected sex indefinitely.

title: Hillary Clinton Evolves on Gay Rights, While Others Lag Behind
description: Two bits of news today on the civil rights front seemed worthy of comment.

title: U.S. Investigates Possible Misconduct in Chicago Public Schools
description: CHICAGO  Federal investigators are speaking to public school officials here as part of an inquiry into possible misconduct, the president of the Chicago Board of Education acknowledged this week.

title: Clinton Is Said to Love de Blasio, Despite Lack of Endorsement
description: DES MOINES  Hillary Rodham Clinton has no hard feelings toward Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York for declining to endorse her presidential bid  at least according to Tom Harkin, the former Democratic senator from Iowa.

title: Teaching the Armenian Genocide With Primary Sources From The New York Times
description: In the spring of 1915, the Young Turk regime of the Ottoman Empire began an organized campaign of violence against its Armenian population under the cover of World War I. A consensus of historians (PDF) consider the massacres, forced deportations and mass starvation that killed more than one million Armenians a genocide.

title: The Look of Love Is in the Dogs Eyes
description: Those big brown eyes gaze at you, deeply. Your heart leaps. You caress, murmuring sweet nothings. And as those big browns remain fixed on you, the tail wags.

title: Putin Takes Questions: More Economy, Less Ukraine
description: MOSCOW  Sounding at times like a mayor promising to fix potholes and close noisy bars, President Vladimir V. Putin used his annual national call-in show on Thursday to try to reassure Russians that the countrys economic troubles were under control and that he shared their concerns on pocketbook issues.

title: Misty Copeland Makes the Cover of Time Magazine
description: For the first time in a generation a dancer has made the cover of Time magazine: Misty Copeland, the American Ballet Theater soloist, was chosen as one of the magazines 100 most influential people, and is featured on one of the five different covers for its upcoming issue.

title: Clinton May See Rubio Fund-Raiser From Her House
description: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida is taking his fight to Hillary Rodham Clinton  or at least, very close to her.

title: Exploring Californias Bold Pinot Noir
description: The most interesting California pinot noir producers today seem to continually push out toward the fringes. In that, they are following in the footsteps of Josh Jensen, the founder of the Calera Wine Company.

title: American Woman Wounded in Shooting in Karachi, Pakistan
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  An American citizen was critically wounded in what was apparently a militant attack on Thursday in the southern port city of Karachi.

title: Russia Bans Tom Hardy Thriller From  Theaters
description: In the latest salvo in a broader culture war, Russias culture minister, Vladimir Medinsky, has banned the release in Russia of Child 44, a Cold War thriller starring Tom Hardy as a policeman investigating a series of child murders in 1953, for distorting historical facts, Variety reported.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Lost River
description: Ryan Gosling narrates a sequence from his film Lost River.

title: Two Museums to Host Pollock Black Pourings
description: TWO MUSEUMS TO HOST

title: Lost River (With Movie Trailer): Ryan Gosling Narrates a Scene
description: For his directorial debut, the actor Ryan Gosling took to the streets of Detroit to tell the story of a family  Billy, played by Christina Hendricks, and her two sons, Bones and Frankie  in a deserted town, Lost River. The film is in theaters and available  on demand. During a recent interview in New York, he answered questions about his film. Below are excerpts from that conversation.

title: Ohio Man Trained in Syria Is Charged With Planning Terrorism in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  An Ohio man who trained with a terrorist group in Syria was accusedby federal prosecutors on Thursday of returning to the United States with the goal of mounting an attack at home, the first example of a pattern that counterterrorism officials have long feared.

title: Telephone: An International Arts Experiment by Nathan Langston
description: Sometime last winter, Terri St.Arnauld and Frank Yezer, photographers in Austin, Tex., and Maya Ciarrocchi, a video artist in New York, each received an email that contained a song. The tune was by Stelth Ulvang, a musician from Denver, whom they had never met. In a spare recording, on banjo and accordion, Mr. Ulvang sang of a forlorn man and a landscape of smoke and clouds.

title: N.B.A. to Test Players for H.G.H. Starting Next Season
description: The N.B.A. announced Thursday that it would expand its antidrug program next season to include blood tests for human growth hormone. The league said testing would begin this year in preseason training camp.

title: Apple Watch Availability Is Clarified
description: Apples method of releasing products like the iPhone is straightforward: On the day of release, you buy the phone at a retail store or it is delivered if you ordered online. The process is a lot less clear for the Apple Watch.

title: Hillary Clintons Changing Views on Gay Marriage
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons views on same-sex marriage have evolved in the almost 20 years since her husband, Bill Clinton, then the president, signed the 1996 Defense of Marriage Act, saying that he had long opposed governmental recognition of same-gender marriages. This week Mrs. Clinton, who is running for president, said she hoped that same-sex marriage became a constitutional right.

title: Ferran Adri Serves Up a Bubbly Night in Barcelona
description: Last night in Barcelona, Ferran Adri, the renowned Catalan chef, worked a dinner service for the first time since he closed El Bulli, the avant-garde, Michelin-three-star table that was repeatedly named best restaurant in the world. Co-hosted with Dom Prignons head oenologist, Richard Geoffroy, the event at the Palo Alto market was titled This Is Not a Dinner.

title: Dodd-Franks Hotel California May Have Exit After All
description: General Electric may be the first to find out if it is possible to escape the Hotel California.

title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on 3 Leaders of Gang Based in El Salvador
description: MEXICO CITY  The United States government imposed sanctions on three leaders of the Mara Salvatrucha street gang on Thursday as part of a broader effort to crack down on the transnational gang, which is based in El Salvador and runs human trafficking and drug operations into the United States.

title: Duchovny and Anderson: The Literary Files
description: There must be something about solving paranormal mysteries that sparks literary inspiration.

title: Review: Child 44, a Secret-Police Thriller in Soviet Russia
description: Child 44, directed by Daniel Espinosa from a screenplay by Richard Price, is an English-language movie set in Russia, which means that it is above all a festival of accents. Gary Oldman, Paddy Considine and Vincent Cassel measure their vowels and consonants carefully, but the most floridly enjoyable voices belong to Tom Hardy and Noomi Rapace, last seen together speaking Brooklynese in The Drop. In that film, Mr. Hardy dropped his rs like a champ. Here he lands heavily on the aitches and contracts the words it is into the letter Z. Zimpossible, he says. Zdifficult.

title: Review: Tangerines Is a Tale of War and Honor
description: Ivo, a taciturn grandfather with a straight back and a silver beard, makes wooden crates in his workshop. He hopes to make enough to contain the harvest from his neighbor Marguss tangerine grove. The two men are among the last Estonians remaining in the former Soviet Republic of Georgia during the 1992 war in the Abkhazia region.

title: House Votes to Repeal Estate Tax
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and the Republicans in Congress clashed over taxes and wealth on Thursday, a day after many Americans sent checks to the Internal Revenue Service, as the House voted to repeal the federal tax levied on multimillion-dollar estates.

title: Review: Salad Days Revisits Washingtons Punk Moment
description: Yes, Washington is a company town, its labor force often revolving in and out with each presidential administration. But a vigorous underground musical scene has long existed there, and Salad Days, an enlightening documentary by the rock journalist Scott Crawford, details its origins.

title: Review: True Story Stars Jonah Hill and James Franco
description: The Journalist and the Murderer is the title of a book by Janet Malcolm, but it could just as well be the name of a genre. A small library of searching and sensational stories attests to the strong, often uncomfortable affinity between reporters and killers. Truman Capotes In Cold Blood is perhaps the supreme example, and one that has inspired several movies over the years. Neither Michael Finkels book True Story nor Rupert Goolds film adaptation is anywhere near as accomplished as Capotes book or Bennett Millers movie Capote. The new film is of interest mainly because it demonstrates just how difficult it can be to map the queasy moral territory where crime and journalism intersect.

title: Clashes Intensify Over Stalled Nomination of Loretta Lynch
description: WASHINGTON  Senators on Thursday reopened negotiations on a stalled bill to combat human trafficking, while bickering intensified among Democrats and Republicans, and even the White House, over the stalemate that has ensnared the attorney general nomination of Loretta E. Lynch.

title: Review: In The Human Experiment, Were the Unwitting Guinea Pigs
description: Not long into The Human Experiment, a scary if scientifically lightweight documentary about our daily exposure to thousands of synthetic chemicals, you realize that its main targets are women. Proceeding through breast cancer statistics, cosmetics ingredients and the toxic horrors that lurk in our household cleaners, the movie focuses primarily on the ladies. Even its poster  an infant surrounded by cleaning products  seems designed to catch a womans eye.

title: Seaport Museum Picks Interim President to Lead as New Executive Director
description: Jonathan Boulware, who since November 2011 has served as the South Street Seaport Museums waterfront director and interim president, has been appointed executive director, the museum is to announce next week.

title: Some Fear Fallout From Preet Bhararas Tension With Judges
description: Preet Bharara, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York and one of the most acclaimed prosecutors of his generation, is locked in what seems to be an escalating war of words with the federal judiciary  one that some judges fear could influence important rulings.

title: Making the Magazine
description: A behind-the-scenes look a The New York Times Magazine in the 1980s.

title: Review: In Alex of Venice, a Career Workaholic Learns to Shoulder Family Burdens
description: An appealing portrait miniature of a woman who loses and finds her bearings, Alex of Venice takes place against that messy Los Angeles backdrop of beachside attractions and boardwalk crowds, millionaire mansions and homeless encampments known as Venice. Thats the neighborhood in which the heroine, Alex (Mary Elizabeth Winstead), grew up and that, with her family, she still calls home. She may not notice the carnival anymore, but the director, Chris Messina, takes time to gently point out some of the more picturesque sites, like the Venice sign that serves as a gateway to the Pacific and the arched walkways that Orson Welles immortalized in Touch of Evil.

title: Former JPMorgan Chase Broker Charged in $20 Million Fraud
description: A former JPMorgan Chase broker treated accounts maintained by his clients as his own personal piggy bank  using about $20 million in client money to make unprofitable options trades and even paying down the mortgage on his New Jersey home, according to a federal criminal complaint unsealed on Thursday.

title: Reading The Times With Andy Borowitz
description: Andy Borowitz is the creator of the news satire column The Borowitz Report and a memoir, An Unexpected Twist.

title: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
description: South Korea and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Review: Human Highway and Muddy Track, Whimsical 80s Artifacts From Neil Young
description: Throughout his protean music career, Neil Young has tried his hand at filmmaking. The movies of Neil Young, auteur, include the rarely seen Journey Through the Past (1974), which Paul Thomas Anderson (Inherent Vice) has cited as an influence, and Greendale (2004), an earnest and political rock opera.

title: April 16, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from South Korea, Poland, Greece and Brazil.

title: Something Old (Bridal Wear) Meets the New (3-D Printing)
description: It is only a coincidence that the opening of the 3-D Print Design Show on Thursday at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in New York should coincide with the start of New York International Bridal Week, whose runway shows will be held farther up the Hudson River at Piers 92 and 94 and elsewhere in the city.

title: Review: Monkey Kingdom Invests a Wild Chimp With Girl Power
description: Imposing human motives, emotions and story lines on wild animals is probably never a good idea for a nature documentary, but its done to especially annoying effect in Monkey Kingdom, a new feature from Disneynature aimed at younger children.

title: Review: Unfriended, in the Scariest Ways You Can Think Of
description: A skinflints dream, Unfriended either raises or lowers the bar for low-budget, big-studio synergy. More provocative sizzle than bloody-disgusting steak, it features a small cast of whozat young actors and was directed by another question mark, Leo Gabriadze. The most recognizable name is Timur Bekmambetov, the cult filmmaker (Night Watch) turned Hollywood name (Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter), who cooked up the idea of making a movie that unfolds almost entirely on computer windows. One of Mr. Bekmambetovs former employees, Nelson Greaves, wrote the script, and they both also helped produce.

title: Ryan Sullivan Scales Up
description: The young painter Ryan Sullivan makes the type of ethereal drip abstractions one might expect to require a three-page pamphlet for explanation; but in fact, most of his descriptions are simple. Thats not an insult  quite the contrary. Sullivan speaks of his practice with sharp, fine-tuned language. Im trying to deal with these parameters that Ive set in front of me and the event of making this thing, says the 32-year-old Rhode Island School of Design graduate. Theres something closely linked between the image that you see, the process of making it and the material. Theres nothing else. Theres no subject matter tacked on top of that, its much more about how closely those things can be bound together. This week, Sullivan opens his first solo and American institutional exhibition at Miamis Institute of Contemporary Art  the institution founded by former employees of the Museum of Contemporary Art, North Miami, thats lately been closely watched in the art world after its recent move to the Design District (on the second floor of the charming 1912 Moore building) and appointment of a not-yet-30-year-old deputy director and chief curator (Alex Gartenfeld, a former Art in America editor).

title: Review: Closer to the Moon Recounts a Bizarre Bit of Romanian History
description: Closer to the Moon, a fictionalized tale about a weird chapter in Romanian history, tries hard to slap a smiley face on a calamity. In 1959, a group of formerly true-believing Romanian Communists, all Jewish, did the unthinkable when they robbed a branch of the state (and only) bank. They were soon caught, but the story went from curious to crackpot when officials decided that the robbers would portray themselves in a state-produced film titled Reconstruction, recreating their gangsta roles with secret meetings, gats and getaway cars. Apparently believing that the state might go easier on them if they cooperated, the robbers played along, all the way through the show-trial end.

title: Roadblocks to Sharing Medical Records
description: The ability to transfer electronic medical records from one doctor or hospital to another is essential to the smooth functioning of the health care system and to providing the best possible care to patients. Yet all too often these transfers are being blocked by developers of health information technology or greedy medical centers that refuse to send records to rival providers.

title: Review: Felix and Meira, a Portrait of a Tempted Hasidic Wife
description: Unfolding on snowy sidewalks and beneath overcast skies, Felix and Meira watches ever so closely as a young Hasidic wife and mother is tempted by the quirky charms of a wayward older man.

title: The Economy Still Needs More Help Than Its Getting
description: For economy watchers, more angst than usual has surrounded the release of recent economic reports. The uneasiness began two weeks ago, when data showed an abrupt and unexpected slowdown in job growth in March. That decline upped the importance of subsequent reports. If they were strong, the slump in March could be dismissed as a fluke. If they were weak.

title: Staten Island Rising
description: This year could mark a turning point for the borough, with major projects starting construction and hundreds of new apartments coming to market.

title: Review: In The Dead Lands, the Maori Fight for Survival
description: The burdens of tribal responsibility weigh heavily on Toa Frasers The Dead Lands and its Maori warriors, but, inconveniently, so does some ponderous and cluttered filmmaking. Set deep in New Zealand forests long before colonization and performed in the Maori language, Mr. Frasers full-dress action drama follows a chieftains son surviving after his family is slaughtered by merciless enemies.

title: Going Interactive at Tribeca With Storyscapes
description: WITHIN a few minutes of entering Door Into the Dark, an interactive installation at the Tribeca Film Festival, you are, quite literally, at the end of your rope. The installation, which invites participants to take a visionless, disorienting journey in a big black box, is one of five projects in this years Storyscapes, a division of the festival that presents experiments in narrative and storytelling.

title: WikiLeaks Posts Sony Pictures Documents, Angering the Studio
description: LOS ANGELES  Sony Pictures Entertainment reacted harshly on Thursday to word that WikiLeaks, a web portal devoted to disclosing confidential information from governments, corporations and other large and powerful entities, had posted a searchable archive of emails and other documents stolen from the studio last year by hackers.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: On Holocaust Day in Israel, Strangers Answer the Call to a Funeral
description: JERUSALEM  Most of the mourners had never met Nate Remer, who survived the Holocaust hiding in a Ukrainian forest, built a successful wholesale hardware business in Southern California and had severe dementia for 15 years before dying Tuesday at 82. They did not know his son, Gary, a professor at Tulane University, or his grandson, Moshe Alexander, who moved to Israel five years ago and works in high tech.

title: Review: In Antarctic Edge, a Region of Retreating Ice
description: There arent many uncharted areas left on the globe, but Antarctic Edge: 70 South takes viewers to a spot where surveying is so scarce that the destinations may diverge from their locations on a map. Exploring that terrain could mean getting caught in ice for a month, as one scientist in the film recounts experiencing.

title: Carmelo Anthony Says Hes Much Clearer About Knicks Future
description: If there was a positive thing that Carmelo Anthony could take from the Knicks brutal 2014-15 season, he said, it might be clarity.

title: Lower East Side Galleries
description: Holland Cotters walk through the galleries of the Lower East Side.

title: Galleries in Brooklyn and Queens
description: Martha Schwendeners tour through the galleries of the boroughs.

title: Chelsea Galleries
description: Roberta Smiths walk through the galleries of Chelsea.

title: 10 Galleries to Visit in Brooklyn and Queens
description: The difference between Brooklyn and the citys other art districts is that a huge number of artists actually live here  ask anyone whos reviewed applications for grants or fellowships for artists.

title: 10 Galleries to Visit on the Lower East Side
description: THE Lower East Side was once frontier territory, where new immigrants settled alongside poets and artists, punk musicians and anarchists, everyone needing rock-bottom rent. In the 1980s, the neighborhood soaked up some of the limelight trained on the East Village art scene, and began the slow creep toward gentrification. A decade or so ago, when art dealers started to set up shop below East Houston Street, a vague hope beat in the hearts of some observers that the neighborhood might be an alternative, in art and attitude alike, to Chelsea. I doubt anyone harbors that hope today. Mostly, the Lower East Side gallery scene is Chelsea with more storefronts and cheaper retail. Still, it has a certain margin of flexibility, and sometimes it uses it. And thats good to see.

title: 10 Galleries to Visit in Chelsea
description: NO gallery scene is static, but lately Chelseas has been especially in flux.

title: Distinct Prisms in an Ever-Shifting Kaleidoscope
description: With female artists more visible than ever, here are five who have put their stamp on the current gallery moment. They work in studios from Sunnyside to Crown Heights to Paris, in paint, porcelain and pixels.

title: Review: Below Dreams, the Human Struggle in the City Below Sea Level
description: Garrett Bradleys Below Dreams hovers around three people in their 20s striving separately in New Orleans. With an impressionistic style and mostly nonprofessional actors, what emerges is a handful of adequate scenes that constitute an assortment of notes toward a film rather than a final draft.

description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

Movie Listings for April 17-23
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Ontario Will Loosen Rules to Allow Beer Sales in Largest Supermarkets
description: OTTAWA  Ontario, Canadas most populous province, said on Thursday that it would partly open its beer retailing system, which is dominated by three of the worlds largest breweries.

title: Galleries in SoHo and Tribeca
description: Martha Schwendener takes a tour through the galleries of SoHo and Tribeca.

title: 10 Galleries to Visit in SoHo and TriBeCa
description: IN SoHo, the real estate casualties just keep coming: Last year Pearl Paint, the venerable art supply store on Canal Street, closed. This month Pearl River Mart, the Chinese department store where you can buy everything from paper lanterns to cheap ceramics, announced its departure. Rent on its Broadway space is reported to exceed a heart-stopping $500,000 a month. Yet, amazingly, despite the growing glut of flagship stores, SoHo remains a great place to see art; its nonprofit spaces are thriving. And few things are as satisfying as braving the consumerist hordes, ducking into an art space that is hidden in plain sight, and having your consciousness altered without spending any money at all.

title: See Art Now: 50 New York Art Galleries to Visit This Weekend
description: THERE is no New York art world; there are only art worlds: a planetary system with no sun at its center.

title: Civil Lawsuit Against Jameis Winston
description: The former Florida State student Erica Kinsman filed a lawsuit in state court in Florida against Jameis Winston, the former Florida State quarterback, and accused him of forcible rape.

title: Upper East Side Galleries
description: Holland Cotters walk through the galleries of the Upper East Side.

title: 10 Galleries to Visit on the Upper East Side
description: IN terms of New York City gallery history, the Upper East Side, roughly from 57th Street northward, is the establishment, the old regime. Galleries that put the city on the international map in the 1950s started here. Several of our big museums call this turf home. So do several of the elite contemporary galleries that now serve as feeding tubes to those museums.

title: Gisele Bndchens Runway Walks Through the Years
description: A look back at Ms. Bndchens runway career.

title: Review: In Beyond the Reach, Michael Douglas as a Greedy Ogre in the Desert
description: How many times can a guy lose his marbles? If the guy is Michael Douglas, apparently as many times as he wants.

description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Gisele BndchenMay Not Be Off the Runway Just Yet
description: Why would she do this to us? wailed Anita Bitton, the fashion-industry casting director, when confronted with the news of Gisele Bndchens apparent retirement from the runway.

title: Is Slack Really Worth $2.8 Billion? A Conversation With Stewart Butterfield
description: When I recently wrote about Slack, a corporate messaging app that has aspirations to replace email, investors valued the company at $1 billion. That was a month ago. Today, the start-up announced that it has raised $160 million from a half dozen investors, and that it is now worth $2.8 billion.

description: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

description: The woman who accused the former Florida State quarterback Jameis Winston of sexually assaulting her in 2012 filed a lawsuit against him on Thursday, two weeks before the N.F.L. draft.

title: This Weeks Movies | April 17, 2015
description: The New York Times film critics review Child 44, Alex of Venice and Unfriended.

title: Allan McCollums One-of-a-Kind Shapes in For the Millions/Just for You
description: PEOPLE accuse me of making fun of the art world, of cynically satirizing it, the artist Allan McCollum once said. But I only feel Im trying to dramatize it, to reduce it to its most simple codes. During an era when the contemporary art world can feel like a planet for the 1 percent  soaring auction prices, private museums, new international art fairs by the week  the codes seem ever more exclusive and cryptic. Yet at the same time, entry to one of the largest contemporary-art collections anywhere in the world  the galleries of New York City  is free. To enjoy it, you dont need much more than a good pair of walking shoes, a list of addresses and an open mind.

title: For the Millions/Just for You (One Hundred and Eight Unique Shapes Out of Over Thirty-One Billion)
description: The New York Times asked the artist Allan McCollum, a pioneering Conceptual artist, to create a work specifically for a newspaper page.

title: Review: Beth Gills Portrait Study, Improvised Death at the Live Ideas Festival
description: It was an odd night at New York Live Arts on Wednesday. For one thing, exceptional dancers kept dying. Or that is was it looked like, as one by one they entered, moved around a bit and collapsed on the ground, lying there as more and more dancers succumbed to the same fate.

title: Pop, Rock & Cabaret Listings for April 17-23
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Review: Robert Ashleys Crash Opens at Roulette
description: Robert Ashley, the brilliant, innovative American composer who died in March last year at 83, created a distinctive operatic aesthetic, a surrealist, meditative style instantly recognizable as his own. Operas of all genres often have surrealist elements, whether the fantastical plot lines of Handel or the satirical quirks of Shostakovich. But Mr. Ashleys engrossing stage works feature ordinary people, taking on a surrealist hue through the imaginative use of voices: singsong patterns of multiple speakers that blend into scores both direct and elusive.

title: Dance Listings for April 17-23
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.
