description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Review: MATA Festivals Sounds of Play
description: A playground swing, a set of miniature panpipes and a chorus of table lamps were among the instruments in use at the Kitchen on Tuesday and Wednesday during the first two concerts presented by the MATA festival of new music. One trend that emerged early on was the playful experimentation with objects  found, invented and tinkered with  as a conduit for sound.

title: Spare Times for Children for April 17-23
description: Take the Stage With Broadway Stars

title: African-American Life, Double-Exposed
description: Through the African American Lens, culled from a Smithsonian collection, shows how photography  and black photographers  reshaped a peoples image.

title: Vanity Fair Updates Article by NBC Reporter Engel
description: Vanity Fair on Thursday updated the account it had published by the NBC News correspondent Richard Engel about his 2012 kidnapping in Syria, stating that he had misidentified his captors.

title: Spare Times for April 17-23
description: Around Town

title: No. 2 Lawyer for New York City, Set to Retire, Looks Back
description: When Jeffrey D. Friedlander went to work as a lawyer for New York City in 1970, he was hired by Norman Redlich, his former law professor at New York University, his salary was $13,300 and John V. Lindsay was mayor. When he retires in June as the Law Departments second in command, he will have worked for 13 corporation counsels and seven mayors.

title: David Makol, Known for Pursuit of Insider Trading Cases While at F.B.I., Joins S.E.C.
description: Before David Makol scared insider trading suspects into cooperating with the F.B.I., and long before he helped investigate the Boston Marathon bombing, he was a low-level examiner at the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Review: Ali Akbar Moradi in Concert at Elebash Recital Hall
description: Love, spirituality, intoxication with the divine and the power of music were all channeled through ancient, basic instruments at Ali Akbar Moradis concert on Wednesday night at Elebash Recital Hall at the City University of New York Graduate Center. Instead of bringing a clergyman to direct me toward God, he sang, bring me a musician. The concert was part of Live@365, a world-music series at the center.

title: Italy Accuses Muslim Migrants of Killing Christians at Sea
description: ROME  The Italian police on Thursday charged 15 Muslim men with homicide aggravated by religious hatred after survivors of a migrant boat rescued in the Mediterranean told investigators that the men had menaced Christians on board and thrown a dozen Christians overboard to their deaths.

title: Journalists at Gawker Medias Websites Are Planning to Unionize
description: Employees at Gawker Media, the parent company of websites like Gawker and Deadspin, are planning to unionize.

title: After $1 Billion Loss, Senior Citadel Manager Derek Kaufman Steps Down
description: A senior manager at the hedge fund Citadel has left after losing $1 billion of investors money last year.

title: Deesha Dyer, a Former Music Writer, Is Named Presidents Social Secretary
description: Deesha Dyer, a former music and hip-hop culture writer, has been selected as President Obamas new social secretary, overseeing the parties and public events held almost daily at the White House.

title: U.N. Security Council Sees Video Evidence of a Chemical Attack in Syria
description: UNITED NATIONS  A Monday night in March, at 8:30. The sound of helicopters, then a thud, then the smell of bleach, overpowering, followed by a surge of wounded to the local hospital. They were all short of breath. Some vomited. All reeked of bleach.

title: Iraqi Premier Softens Tone About Saudis
description: WASHINGTON  One day after he sharply criticized Saudi Arabias military intervention in Yemen, Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi of Iraq on Thursday said that he still wanted to maintain good ties with the Saudis and hoped that they would open an embassy in Baghdad soon.

title: A Police Shot to a Boys Back in Queens, Echoing Since 1973
description: It was 1973, long before anyone could imagine hashtag declarations of solidarity and protest, the kind of message to the world that today might read, #IamCliffordGloverInTheFourthGrade.

title: Rahul Gandhi, an Heir Apparent in India, Ends a Secretive Absence
description: NEW DELHI  Fifty-seven days after the Indian National Congress partys heir apparent, Rahul Gandhi, mysteriously absented himself from New Delhi, leaving word through his office that he needed a few weeks off to reflect on recent events, he returned with equally little explanation on Thursday, striding into his house as a scrum of television reporters said things like He has stepped out of the vehicle! and He was wearing dark glasses!

title: British Election Photo Ops With Children Go Awry
description: As campaigning intensifies before next months general election in Britain, candidates have been forced to respond to the U.K. Independence Partys calls to restrict immigration, by leaving the European Union.

title: Trial ofKarma al-Khayat, Lebanese Journalist, Begins in Hague Tribunal
description: PARIS  A Lebanese journalist went on trial Thursday before an international tribunal to face charges of obstruction of justice and contempt of court for publishing confidential information from the international investigation into the 2005 assassination of Rafik Hariri, a former Lebanese prime minister.

title: Amid Dean Skelos Inquiry, Contracting by Nassau County Faces Review
description: A corruption unit of the Nassau County district attorneys office will open a review of county contracting practices, in response to revelations that a federal investigation into the leader of the New York State Senate is focused in part on a county storm water contract.

title: Mayor de Blasio, in Iowa, Cites Rampant Inequality in U.S.
description: DES MOINES  The tall man from out of town came dressed in the colors of the flag, carrying a message of woe about the nation: Washington, he lamented, was out of touch; working-class people were hurting; and political parties had a lot of explaining to do.

title: In Canada, Its March Madness in April
description: OTTAWA  The swaggering confidence that fans of the Ottawa Senators displayed Wednesday night is a relatively new phenomenon. Last month, when it looked as if the Senators might defy the odds and make the playoffs, the anxious local conversation was about jinxes, hexes and curses.

title: Mix of Curiosity and Outrage on the Hill After Pilot Buzzes Capitol
description: WASHINGTON  Some prominent lawmakers raised questions on Thursday about how the pilot of a gyrocopter, eager to deliver a protest message to Congress over campaign finance laws, was able to fly the aircraft apparently undetected through protected airspace and land near the Capitol.

title: Levi Watkins, 70, Dies; Pioneering Heart Surgeon Pushed Civil Rights
description: Dr. Levi Watkins Jr., the first surgeon to successfully implant an automatic heart defibrillator in a human patient, and a civil rights pioneer who helped fling open medical school doors to hundreds of students who had been excluded  as he had once been  because they were black, died on Saturday in Baltimore. He was 70.

title: Ira Lewis, Actor and Playwright, Dies at 82
description: Ira Lewis, an actor turned playwright whose comedies, often with star-studded casts, skewered the neuroses and pretensions of writers and artists, died on April 4 in Edison, N.J. He was 82.

title: Thelma Coyne Long, Australian Tennis Champion, Dies at 96
description: Thelma Coyne Long, an Australian tennis star who won 19 Grand Slam titles at midcentury, died on Tuesday in Narrabeen, near Sydney. She was 96.

title: Matt McKenna, Bill Clintons Spokesman, Is Leaving for Uber
description: Former President Bill Clintons longtime spokesman, Matt McKenna, is leaving his current role for a communications job at Uber, the by-order car service that has swelled in size in the last two years.

title: A Time for Phil Jackson to Raise His Game
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  If Phil Jacksons first full-season performance as president of the Knicks has fallen woefully short of being commensurate with his $12 million annual salary, payback can begin in the playoffs. His 17-victory team has mercifully gone home. It is time for him to learn as much as he can about those clubs that remain.

title: New York City Council Votes to Restrict Credit Checks in Hiring
description: The City Council passed a bill on Thursday that will make New York the 12th jurisdiction in the country to prohibit employers from using credit checks to screen job applicants.

title: Review: The King and I, Back on Broadway
description: A big, scrupulously detailed 19th-century ship glides toward the audience in the opening moments of Bartlett Shers resplendent production of Rodgers and Hammersteins The King and I, which opened on Thursday night at the Vivian Beaumont Theater. Its an impressive sight, worthy of every oooh it elicits. But its presence wouldnt count for nearly as much if it werent carrying such precious cargo.

title: Charge Leader
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  To the average solver, who might not even notice bylines, this might not matter. But as a female constructor, I find a themeless crossword that a woman has constructed as a welcome thing to see.

title: For Sale: Aging Boat That Had an Unenviable Job
description: Kevin Byrnes stood on the bridge of the Newtown Creek, an aging, 300-foot-long tanker that has served New York City since 1967, and looked admiringly down its length.

title: Fee to Be Charged for Video of South Carolina Shooting, Publicist Says
description: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C.  The video of a North Charleston police officer shooting an unarmed man in the back will now cost news outlets that want to run it $10,000, according to a publicist representing the man who shot it.

title: Rangers Seize Quick Lead and Dont Let Go
description: The regular season ended, and for the Rangers the days passed by like ellipses, a cliffhanger, a tantalizing pause bridging all that has happened with all that they hope is still to come.

title: Mexicos President Rolls Out Plan to Save Endangered Porpoise
description: MEXICO CITY  President Enrique Pea Nieto and his top military commanders flew to a modest fishing village in Mexicos far northwest on Thursday and made a promise to protect a small porpoise called the vaquita that is on the edge of extinction.

title: Two Found Dead on Brooklyn Railroad Tracks
description: The bodies of two unidentified men were found on railroad tracks in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn on Thursday.

title: Ukraine: Gunmen Kill Pro-Russian Journalist in Kiev
description: A Ukrainian journalist with a vocal pro-Russian stance was killed in Kiev, the capital, by unidentified gunmen on Thursday, a day after a pro-Russian lawmaker was killed in a similar attack. The journalist, Oles Buzina, 45, publicly opposed the protests that led to the ouster of President Viktor F. Yanukovych in 2014. The current president, Petro O. Poroshenko, called for a swift investigation and declared that the recent killings were conscious provocations intended to destabilize domestic politics in Ukraine. President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said Ukraines government was allowing a campaign of political violence against supporters of the previous government.

title: At Politics and Pie Event, Jeb Bush Goes Against the Republican Grain
description: Jeb Bush indicated on Thursday night that President Obamas choice for attorney general, Loretta E. Lynch, ought to be confirmed  putting him at odds with a number of Senate Republicans whove said they would try to block the nomination.

title: Voting Ends in Sudan With a Small Turnout
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  Voting ended Thursday in Sudans elections, with a low turnout despite a one-day extension.

title: New York State Elections Board Retains a Corporate Donation Loophole
description: ALBANY  The State Board of Elections declined on Thursday to change a longstanding ruling that critics say has allowed millions of dollars to flow, virtually unchecked, into campaign coffers across New York.

title: Chinese Journalist Sentenced to 7 Years on Charges of Leaking State Secrets
description: HONG KONG  Gao Yu, a 71-year-old Chinese journalist who has repeatedly challenged the Communist Party during a decades-long career, was sentenced to seven years in prison on Friday after a court in Beijing found her guilty of leaking state secrets abroad. Ms. Gao said she would appeal, according to her lawyer and her brother, who were in the courtroom.

title: Jewell Loyd andAmanda Zahui B. Are Top Two Picks in W.N.B.A. Draft
description: UNCASVILLE, Conn.  The Seattle Storm of the W.N.B.A. selected Jewell Loyd first overall in the draft Thursday, the second early entrant to earn the honor after the Los Angeles Sparks took Tennessees Candace Parker No. 1 in 2008. Amanda Zahui B. was selected second overall by the Tulsa Shock.

title: Just Like Mets Imagined It: Clutch Offense, Fifth Straight Win, First Place
description: The Mets talked all winter about winning, about contending, and they dreamed about scenes such as the one at Citi Field on Thursday. Lucas Duda delivered the big hit, sending home the go-ahead run against the Miami Marlins. The crowd was on its feet, chanting Doo-da! Doo-da! The Mets won their fifth game in a row and jumped into first place in the National League East.

title: Under Deal, Living Wage for Workers at a Tower in Hudson Yards
description: New York City officials said on Thursday that all of the workers in a proposed office tower in the Hudson Yards project in Midtown Manhattan will be paid at least $13.30 an hour, the first broad application of Mayor Bill de Blasios executive order mandating a living wage.

title: Unlicensed Dental Work in the Bronx Leads to Arrest
description: The former manager of a dental office in the Riverdale section of the Bronx practiced dentistry without a license on five patients, performing risky and complicated procedures that harmed at least two people, according to the Bronx district attorneys office.

title: Word of the Day | epic
description: epic  \e-pik\  noun and adjective

title: Harnessing a Fan Base
description: Unlike most big studios, Lucasfilm has a full-time head of fan relations, and the heart of that operation is a biennial convention.

title: Whats On TV Friday
description: 8:10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) FOOTNOTE (2012) The tension-filled relationship between rival Talmudic scholars  Eliezer (Shlomo Bar Aba, above), who toils in obscurity under the belief that his career was blocked by a nemesis, and Uriel (Lior Ashkenazi), an academic star with a busy schedule of public lectures  becomes more complicated when Eliezer is mistakenly awarded a coveted prize meant for Uriel, who happens to be his son. But how to correct the error? Under the direction of Joseph Cedar, the American-born Israeli director, the fraught relations between father and son erupt into an intergenerational tsimmes worthy of Shakespeare, Freud or the more melodramatic portions of the Hebrew Bible, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this Oscar nominee for best foreign-language film. It plays as farce, but the chords of family tragedy resonate underneath the laughter. Resolution, he added, is unlikely, which may or may not be cause for optimism. Academic life and family life are both built on love  the love of learning, the love of other people  but they survive on contention, renewing and extending quarrels from one generation to the next.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Its about as close to an apology, I would think, as the Catholic Church is officially going to render.

title: Corrections: April 17, 2015
description: NEW YORK

title: At Helsinki Airport, a New Snooze Option
description: The Helsinki Airport hopes to help jet-lagged travelers catch up on their sleep with the introduction of new sleeping pods at two of its international gates.

title: African-American Life, Double-Exposed
description: The late 1930s image by Eliot Elisofon shows Zack Brown taking a picture of two dapper African-American men on a Harlem street. It challenged the then-dominant view of black urban life, focusing on dignity instead of suffering, self-possession instead of defeat, happiness instead of sorrow. Mr. Elisofons picture also reminds us of the powerful role of photography in African-American life, how the medium  and black photographers  helped reshape the image of a people.

title: Help for Victims of Crooked Schools
description: State attorneys general have long served on the front lines of the struggle to control and discipline predatory for-profit colleges that saddle students with crippling debt while granting them useless degrees, or no degrees at all. On April 9, nine of them who know firsthand how people can be deceived and bled dry sent a letter to the Department of Education, asking it to provide restitution  and help fix the problem  by forgiving the federal student loans of people harmed by crooked schools. The letter makes a strong case for prompt action.

title: California Groundwater
Racial Terror, Fast and Slow
description: WASHINGTON  IN the past two years, this country has held events commemorating 50 years since the triumphs and key struggles of the civil rights movement: the March on Washington, the Civil Rights Act and, most recently, the Bloody Sunday march in Selma, Ala.

title: That Old-Time Economics
description: BRUSSELS  America has yet to achieve a full recovery from the effects of the 2008 financial crisis. Still, it seems fair to say that weve made up much, though by no means all, of the lost ground.

title: A View From Thailands Ambassador
description: To the Editor:

title: When Cultures Shift
description: In January 1969, two quarterbacks played against each other in Super Bowl III. Johnny Unitas and Joe Namath were both superstars. They were both from Western Pennsylvania, but they came from different cultural universes. Unitas was reticent, workmanlike and deliberately unglamorous. Namath was flashy and a playboy. He turned himself into a marketing brand and wrote a memoir jokingly called, I Cant Wait Until Tomorrow Cause I Get Better Looking Every Day.

title: Alan Dershowitz Responds
description: To the Editor:

title: Republicans Today: What Would Lincoln Think?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Revolt Over Standardized Tests in New York Schools
Want Reform? Principals Matter, Too
description: POLITICIANS and education reformers are fixated on the performance of teachers, but they often overlook another key ingredient for improving student achievement: principals. The problem is that great principals often dont end up in the schools that need them most  those with poor and minority students. School districts, states and universities need to do much more to get outstanding principals into these schools.

title: Turkeys Willful Amnesia
description: Next Friday, April 24, Armenians the world over will commemorate the 100th anniversary of the start of the mass killings of Armenians in Ottoman Turkey, now widely recognized as the first genocide of the 20th century. Widely, that is, outside Turkey, where the government and the majority of Turks continue to furiously attack anyone who speaks of genocide.

description: Here are several paragraphs from an April 14 article, Knicks Superfan Is Set to Be There to the Bitter End.

description: In A Project to Turn Corpses Into Compost, Catrin Einhorn writes about a proposal to compost human bodies in place of using conventional burial methods.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: April 17
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images of a taxidermy class, Brooklyns expanding Chinese population and a protest over police brutality.

title: Staten Islands Turning Point?
description: A wide bay may separate Staten Island from the rest of the city. But in terms of real estate, differences between the borough and other enclaves seem to be lifting like a morning fog.

title: For Lucasfilm, the Way of Its Force Lies in Its Star Wars Fans
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Even in the social media age, some movie studios still see fans as zoo animals to be force-fed: We, the cool film people, will tell you, the easily manipulated consumers, what to like. Other Hollywood companies have developed a true appreciation for the geek masses, but they are still learning how to hone a strategy.

title: Appeals Panel Weighs Fate of Obamas Immigration Overhaul
description: NEW ORLEANS  The immediate fate of President Obamas sweeping immigration overhaul now rests with a three-judge appeals panel after an intense legal clash on Friday between lawyers for the federal government and for a 26-state coalition that has challenged the executive actions.

title: In Nod to Future and Past, Notre Dame Receives $5 Million to Endow Coachs Job
description: Nearly 20 years after they first met, Karen Keyes and Muffet McGraw shared a telephone conversation that neither could have imagined when they arrived at Notre Dame together, just trying to adapt to their unfamiliar surroundings.

title: First in Flight? Connecticut Stakes a Claim
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  Connecticut lawmakers are wrestling with difficult issues  a budget deficit, assisted suicide, judicial reform.

title: U.N. Calls on Western Nations to Shelter Syrian Refugees
description: UNITED NATIONS  With Syrias neighbors increasingly shutting their borders to refugees and thousands trying to cross the Mediterranean Sea in search of safety, the war in Syria is creating the worst global refugee crisis in decades, putting new pressure on the United States and other Western countries to open their doors  and in turn, prompting domestic political backlash.

title: Whats Your Favorite Sandwich?
description: Smoked turkey, hot pastrami or the classic P.B. & J.? Spicy mayo, a drizzle of olive oil or pickled peppers? Sharp Cheddar, pepper jack or Gruyere? Toasted rye, sliced focaccia or a sesame-seed bun?

title: Q. and A.: Willis Barnstone on Translating Mao and Touring Beijing With Allen Ginsberg
description: Willis Barnstone is a polymath author of more than 70 books  a poet, translator and scholar of Gnosticism and the New Testament. But the 87-year-old also has had a long and colorful relationship with China, translating Mao Zedongs poetry and befriending numerous Chinese artists and political leaders in the 1980s.

title: Republican Hopefuls Swarm New Hampshire for Its First Candidate Forum
description: With every major Republican presidential hopeful descending on New Hampshire this weekend for the states first candidate forum, attention will turn for the moment from Hillary Rodham Clintons entry into the campaign to the fluid Republican race.

description: Question:

description: Good morning.

title: Bloomberg Terminals Suffer Widespread Failures
description: The web that weaves together much of the global financial ecosystem went down for a few hours on Friday when the Bloomberg data and communication network unexpectedly crashed.

title: New York Today: Stuffed
description: Good morning on this moist Friday.

title: Daily Report: Etsys Market Debut Is a Test for a New Business Model
description: The online craft bazaar Etsy made its debut on the Nasdaq stock market Thursday, signaling the birth of an unusual public corporation  and not just because its employees carry around compost on bicycles, or because its regulatory filings are peppered with phrases like, We keep it real, always, Hiroko Tabuchi reports.

title: Editorial Contest Winner | Americans Should Defend Their Digital Privacy
description: We are honoring each of the Top 10 winners of our Second Annual Student Editorial Contest by publishing an essay a day, in the order of submission.

title: What to Know About Election 2016 Today
description: The latest news from the campaign trail.

title: Reining In Soldiers of Fortune
description: WASHINGTON  Ten years ago, I found myself in Burundi, sipping a Coke with the countrys president, the American ambassador and the presidents 8-year-old daughter. The presidents life was in danger, and the American government sent me in to keep him alive.

title: Overcoming Povertys Damage to Learning
description: In the weeks after 9/11, Pamela Cantor, a child psychiatrist specializing in trauma, was enlisted by the New York City Board of Education to lead a team studying the impact of the attacks on the citys public school children.

title: In Ireland, Chasing the Wandering Soul of Yeats
Sweet and Salty: Majorcas Traditional Cuisine
description: Dinner at Ca Nignasi was a parade of delicious oddities. An empanada that looked liked a tribal crown got its earthen color from cuttlefish ink in the dough. A coca, a type of flat bread normally topped with roasted vegetables, was capped by strands of briny whitebait.

title: Crossing to Safety
description: My father died when I was only a year old, and my mom had six children to care for. My husbands family always came around to help my mom out. When I was a toddler and my husband was 13, he used to carry me on his back to escape bombings during the Vietnam War. When I grew up, my family suggested I marry him. They said it would lighten the load and lift us from poverty. I was 19.

title: Letter of Recommendation: Kneipp Herbal Bath Oils
description: Not so long ago, I was given a bottle of jewel-toned Kneipp Herbal Bath Oil as a gift. It was packaged in a pretty glass bottle, like crme liqueur. Also like crme liqueur, it seemed pointless. I ignored it. For two decades, bath-taking was something I filed under the category of Things I Dont Do, for Reasons of No Moral Significance. Other items in this class include whistling (physically incapable of it), parallel parking (dont own a car) and twerking (hurts my back).

title: Nem
description: The colloquialism of the title, which means and them  as in Tell your mama nem I said hello  encompasses a host of people made familiar by the world of the poem. Most of us have known them: elders and distant ancestors whose way of being was rooted in the wisdom of folk knowledge, a generation now all but gone. Poem selected by Natasha Trethewey.

title: How to Negotiate a Ransom
description: Make sure theyre alive first, says Leslie Edwards, a top hostage negotiation specialist and former British Army officer. Demand to speak to the captive on the phone, or better still, on video chat. If that is not possible, ask the abductor to answer what Edwards calls a proof-of-life question, something only the kidnapped would know, like the name of a pet goldfish. Ransom amounts vary widely. At the high end, Edwards once settled at $10 million to secure the release of 26 crew members aboard an oil tanker held by Somali pirates, but he has also freed a detainee in Afghanistan for less than $10,000. A counteroffer to the first ransom demands should be a result of exhaustive research. You dont need to know their names, but you need to know their modus operandi and their track record, Edwards says. Whether the hostage-takers motives are purely mercenary or derive from a more dangerous mix of ideology, politics and greed, this is not the time to be a cheapskate. Make a decent opening offer that puts value on the life of the hostage, he says.

title: Re: Note to Self
description: It is what it is. When Colson Whitehead wrote in the April 5 issue about the use of tautological phrases like You do you and Haters gonna hate as evidence of an increasingly narcissistic culture, he hit a nerve with readers.

title: Mona Eltahawy Doesnt Need to Be Rescued
description: In your new book, Headscarves and Hymens: Why the Middle East Needs a Sexual Revolution, you write about your decision to start wearing the hijab as a teenager. What prompted it? My family moved to Saudi Arabia from the U.K. when I was 15. I was groped twice while on pilgrimage to Mecca. It made me feel like I just wanted to hide my body. I struck a deal with God. I said: They say a good Muslim woman should wear a head scarf. Ill do it if you save my mind.

title: The Man Who Carried Lincolns Torch
description: It seemed all of Washington had gone to the theater on April 14, 1865  Good Friday  to hail the imminent end of the war. Grovers New National Theater celebrated with a performance of Aladdin, or the Wonderful Lamp, along with the reading of an original patriotic poem, the singing of the popular new war song When Sherman Marched Down to the Sea, a massive panorama painting of Fort Sumter and a Magnificent Pyrotechnic Display. Although President and Mary Lincoln had declined Leonard Grovers invitation, the audience included Tad Lincoln and his tutor. Also in the packed house was a 21-year-old clerk in the War Department named Jim Tanner, who left a record of his evening in a long letter he wrote to a friend several days later.

title: Cam Talbot, One of the Most Valuable Rangers, Now Just Sits and Watches
description: About eight hours before Game 1 of their first-round playoff series Thursday against the Penguins, Rangers goaltender Henrik Lundqvist addressed a media scrum around his locker. He discussed an array of topics, describing his approach and the top-seeded teams position as the favorite in the series.

title: The Boat to Lift All Tides
description: Out on Lake Washington, you hear them in the predawn murk: coaches barking, rowers gasping, sounds as familiar to the morning as the Canada geese that clack above the boys and girls in the boats. In Seattles first light, you see the slender crafts cutting through the chop of the lake, oars dipping in strained union.

title: Whats On This Week Around The World
description: London

title: Today in Politics: The Republican Dance Card Fills Up in New Hampshire
description: Good Friday morning from Washington, where the relationship between Congress and the Obama administration continues its prickly course. But the primary focus moves from Iowa to New Hampshire, the state of derailed presidencies and second chances, which welcomes 19 Republican presidential hopefuls for a weekend of 30-minute pitches.

title: Arnaldur Indridasons Reykjavik Nights, and More
description: Arnaldur Indridason isnt like other authors of Nordic crime fiction. The crimes he writes about arent particularly gruesome. His villains arent excessively violent, nor are his victims especially remarkable. And his detective hero is so taciturn hes barely socialized. But the Icelandic authors latest novel, REYKJAVIK NIGHTS (Thomas Dunne/Minotaur, $25.99), nicely illustrates the qualities that make his books so deeply pleasurable.

title: Morning Agenda: Bhararas Tension With Judges
description: BHARARAS TENSION WITH JUDGES | Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, is locked in what seems to be an escalating war of words with the federal judiciary, James B. Stewart writes in the Common Sense column.

title: We Armenians Shouldnt Let Genocide Define Us
description: ON April 9, Armenias prime minister, Hovik Abrahamyan, welcomed an unusual visitor to his office. His guest might have blended in with the locals were it not for the film crew and bodyguards around her. But she was not just any Armenian, she was the worlds most famous person of Armenian origin: Kim Kardashian.

title: American Warlord, by Johnny Dwyer
description: What happens when you give a disturbed American teenager unlimited power and weaponry and put him in a zone where law and morality dont exist?

title: Education
description: THE TYRANNY OF THE MERITOCRACY

title: Katy Perry, Showing My Daughter That Breasts Can Be Fun
description: Yes, she has a lot of fun with her breasts.

title: General Electric Reports Strong Growth in Industrial Businesses
description: Last week, General Electric declared that it was substantially accelerating its retreat from finance to bet its future on its industrial business.

title: NYTLNReads | Some of Our Favorite Student Comments on Comedy and Its Limits
description: This week we asked students, Are There Topics That Should Be Off Limits to Comedy? Here is the way we framed it:

title: Crew Retook Italian Fishing Boat Seized Near Libya, Navy Says
description: ROME  The crew of an Italian fishing boat turned the tables on armed Libyans who tried to seize their vessel at sea on Friday, the Italian Navy said, describing a confused episode that ended with the navy taking control of the vessel and of one of the Libyans.

title: Jon Ronsons So Youve Been Publicly Shamed
description: The Welsh journalist and author Jon Ronson joined Twitter on Dec. 10, 2008. He has since published more than 44,000 tweets  almost 20 each day. He has seen some things.

title: Gritty Details Are Behind the Glitter at Fund-Raising Galas
description: HUNDREDS of New Yorks judges and lawyers will gather on Saturday in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf Astoria hotel to honor one of their own, John A. Barone, a New York Supreme Court justice in the Bronx, who will receive this years Rapallo Award.

title: Kris Bryant Will Bat Cleanup for Cubs in Major League Debut
description: The Chicago Cubs have started the season 5-3. Would the addition of a potential superstar slugger perhaps have turned one of those losses into a win? Cubs fans certainly have a right to wonder.

title: Galileos Middle Finger, by Alice Dreger
description: Soon enough, Alice Dreger writes at the beginning of her romp of a book, I will get to the death threats, the sex charges, the alleged genocides, the epidemics, the alien abductees, the anti-lesbian drug, the unethical ethicists, the fight with Martina Navratilova and, of course, Galileos middle finger. But first I have to tell you a little bit about how I got into this mess.

title: Umbrella Delivery in the Rain
description: Dear Diary:

title: A Ban on Beef in India Is Not the Answer
description: The sacredness of cows in India might be a clich, but it is deeply felt, rooted in the history of Hinduism. In Mumbai, one often encounters women selling grass to feed the cow they have in tow  for a few rupees, the donation affords not only a blessing, but also a chance to feel connected to the countrys farmland roots. The cow is divinely associated with Krishna, the cowherd, and considered a mother figure because of the milk it gives. One doesnt go into an Indian branch of McDonalds expecting to order a Big Mac.

title: Serving All Your Heroin Needs
description: FATAL heroin overdoses in America have almost tripled in three years. More than 8,250 people a year now die from heroin. At the same time, roughly double that number are dying from prescription opioid painkillers, which are molecularly similar. Heroin has become the fallback dope when an addict cant afford, or find, pills. Total overdose deaths, most often from pills and heroin, now surpass traffic fatalities.

title: Ferrari Interiors for a Miami Condo
description: MIAMI  The color of the walls, floors and ceilings is a dead giveaway.

title: Is Alexander Wang Really the Most Influential Designer in the World?
description: The Time magazine 100 Most Influential People list is out, and there are four fashion names on it (or two, and two kind-of-fashion names): Alexander Wang, under artists; Diane von Furstenberg, under icons; and Kim Kardashian and Kanye West, under titans.

title: Former Tullett Prebon Employee Pleads Not Guilty in Libor Case in Britain
description: A former employee of the British brokerage firm Tullett Prebon Group pleaded not guilty on Friday in a criminal inquiry into the manipulation of a global benchmark interest rate.

title: Rain: A Natural and Cultural History, by Cynthia Barnett
description: When I finish Cynthia Barnetts Rain, I toss the book into a more-or-less waterproof pouch and walk five miles in a steady drizzle.I carry the book through a forest of moss-blanketed Sitka spruce, along a soggy gravel beach and over the slippery mud of a coastal marsh. This is the least I can do in homage to Barnetts work.

title: Shame and the Captives and The Evening Chorus
description: The dislocations of wartime come in many forms. A major military conflict can destroy cities, ruin economies and inflict calamity and hardship on entire populations. But it can also cause subtler, more personal derangements, and its these that are the subject of two new novels, each tracing the complex arithmetic of war as it plays out for individuals living far from the wholesale chaos of the front lines. Shame and the Captives, by Thomas Keneally, and The Evening Chorus, by Helen Humphreys, both tell stories of far-flung P.O.W. camps during World War II, but in each case the principal focus is less on the prisoners themselves than on those living on the other side of the barbed wire.

title: Clip: The Wannabe
description: A scene from The Wannabe, directed by Nick Sandow.

title: Foot Fungus Is Better in America
description: Lets say you have a borderline embarrassing medical condition. Heres how it goes down in America: You go to Target, walk past the dollar bins (keep walking, your local landfill thanks you), stroll to the pharmacy located near the free restrooms, pick up your over-the-counter medication, amble toward the registers while deciding which one of the many available cashiers will have the pleasure of ringing up your purchase, and finally pick up a pack of gum or the latest Disney princess Band-Aids. A minute later, the cashier asks, Did you find everything you needed today?

title: New York Times Co. Elevates Meredith Kopit Levien to Chief Revenue Officer
description: Meredith Kopit Levien, executive vice president for advertising at The New York Times Company, has been promoted to chief revenue officer and will oversee the generation of all advertising and subscription revenue, the companys chief executive, Mark Thompson, said in a memorandum to employees on Friday.

title: Taking a Facebook Break, Temporarily or for Good
Infested, About Bedbugs, by Brooke Borel
description: A book about bedbugs is, by necessity, a book about nearly everything: about travel and adventure, about our relationship to nature, about how scientists solve problems, about trust and whether we view strangers as friends or foes. It is a book about what people will do under extreme circumstances, and about environmental politics, and art and mental illness. It is even a book about kinky sex.

title: Rust: The Longest War, by Jonathan Waldman
description: I am afraid of the can of haggis in my kitchen cupboard. It is not that I dont like haggis; I do. No, I am worried about what may have happened to it in the 14 years since I bought it. Now I have an idea, after reading Rust, which is one of those books that examine the fabric of our material world and pick at its scabs. It is a book about what is corroding away unseen and unnoticed by most of us. The heroes and antiheroes in this account of cans exploding, bridges collapsing and buildings falling apart are the engineers and corrosion experts who are either saving us all from oblivion or pushing paranoia. Jonathan Waldman, an environmental journalist, is an outsider coolly detached from this debate, although clearly fascinated by the people involved, and this is one of the main strengths of the book.

title: As THX Gets a New Trailer, an Interview With Its Composer
description: It starts with soft, low, swarming, otherworldly sounds, then steadily builds to high-pitched unified, synthesized bliss.

title: Verizon to Offer Slimmer TV Channel Packages to Battle Streaming Rivals
description: Verizon Communications is introducing a television offering through FiOS that gives customers more options to pay for the channels they watch and not for those they dont.

title: The Triumph of Seeds, by Thor Hanson
description: Oh, no! I thought as I gazed at Thor Hansons book with pictures of seeds all lined up on the jacket in boring, well-spaced symmetry. If The Triumph of Seeds had really been about how the little acorn makes the mighty oak, I might have screamed. But the genius of Hansons fascinating, inspiring and entertaining book stems from the fact that it is not about how all kinds of things grow from seeds; it is about the seeds themselves.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE BROTHERS: The Road to an American Tragedy, by Masha Gessen. (Riverhead, $27.95.) Gessen traces the roots of the two Chechen immigrants who became the Boston Marathon bombers, and examines the attacks aftermath.

title: Inside the List
description: Northern Lights: With a population of 5.1 million people, Norway has fewer residents than New York City  and, by the look of things these days, more writers than Brooklyn. This is their moment in the midnight sun: Our cover next week will feature new books by Karl Ove Knausgaard, Per Petterson and Asne Seierstad, while Jo Nesbo turns up at No.9 on the hardcover fiction list with his latest crime novel, Blood on Snow. Nesbo is of course a regular on the best-seller pages, thanks to his Harry Hole mystery series, but Blood on Snow  about a 1970s hit man who falls in love with his target  is a stand-alone. It was inspired, Nesbo has said, by his desire to do for Oslo what Jim Carroll did for New York in The Basketball Diaries: He makes Manhattan feel dangerous but also small, Nesbo told The Yorkshire Post earlier this month. Any big city will have its darker side, its inevitable, and Oslo is no different. ... On the other hand my Oslo is a little bit more twisted and darker, a bit like Gotham City is a darker version of New York. Nesbo is often grouped with the Swedish writers Stieg Larsson and Henning Mankell as exemplars of a recent wave of Nordic noir, but he told the newspaper hes at a loss to explain the phenomenon: People ask me, What is it with Scandinavian crime fiction? And Ive been trying to come up with a smart answer, but I really dont know.

title: Paperback Row
description: TO RISE AGAIN AT A DECENT HOUR, by Joshua Ferris. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $16.) Ferriss debut novel, the first-person-plural satire Then We Came to the End (2007), traced the decline of an ad agency. His second, The Unnamed (2010), concerned a mans debilitating compulsion to walk. To Rise Again follows the undoing of Paul ORourke, a misanthropic, Red Sox-loving dentist in midlife crisis, who watches in horror as an online impersonator promotes an obscure religion in his name.

title: Banking on Apple Watch Will Be Limited, for Now
Stuff We Liked
description: Heres what caught our eyes this week.

title: Germanwings Memorial Service Held at Cologne Cathedral
description: COLOGNE, Germany  The leaders of Germany on Friday joined hundreds of mourning relatives in one of the countrys most hallowed cathedrals to honor the passengers and crew members who died when a jet smashed into a French mountainside last month, a crash that horrified the world after investigators said the co-pilot had deliberately brought down the plane.

title: Orson Welless The Lady From Shanghai is Reissued on Blu-ray
description: Film noir was conceived in Weimar Germany, born in wartime Hollywood and named in postwar France  which is where these dark crime films, including two new releases, Orson Welless The Lady From Shanghai (1948) and Robert Montgomerys Ride the Pink Horse (1947), were most fully appreciated.

title: 1984 | Behind the Scenes at a Long-Ago Magazine
description: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

title: Vivendi Chairman Bollor Wins Battle Over Double Voting Rights
description: PARIS  The chairman and biggest shareholder of Vivendi, the French company that owns Universal Music, withstood a stockholder rebellion at the companys annual meeting on Friday, winning a battle in what could be an unusually contentious proxy season for corporate France.

title: 1915: Italo-Austrian Fight Reported
description: Grave incidents have occurred within the last few days on the Austro-Italian frontier, writes the Figaros Milan correspondent. The Austrians have attacked the Italian Bersaglieri of the 11th Regiment, who repulsed the attack, crossing into Austrian territory for about 200 mtres. It is stated that 100 men were killed on both sides.

title: How Many Fingers Does Hillary Clinton Have Up?  Five!
description: Saturday Night Live spoofs can bedevil politicians, burnishing their quirks in the publics consciousness for entire campaigns and beyond.

title: More Married Couples, Same-Sex and Straight, Are Sharing the Job of Pastor
description: HARTFORD  Cathy Rion Starr and Heather Rion Starr, the ministers of the Unitarian Society of Hartford since last summer, were reminiscing recently about a conversation early in their friendship, before they had become either romantic partners or co-workers.

title: Sarah Jessica Parker Will Return to HBO in Divorce
description: Sarah Jessica Parker is coming home to the cable network that helped make her one of TVs biggest stars. She will star in another HBO series set in New York, more than a decade after the series finale of Sex and the City, it was reported Thursday.

title: More Older Adults Are Becoming Inventors
description: LIKE many inventors, Bob Nepper, 82, is a compulsive improver. Mr. Nepper, an electrical engineer who lives in North St. Paul, Minn., has pet projects that have included a self-guided lawn mower and an outside faucet that can run hot and cold. His basement is stocked with tools like a lathe and a milling machine to craft his ideas.

title: Cast of Hamilton Pays Tribute to A Chorus Line With a Song
description: The hit Off Broadway musical Hamilton closed its Thursday night performance with an unusual number: What I Did For Love from A Chorus Line.

title: Top Saddam Hussein Aide Reported Killed in Northern Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  An Iraqi provincial governor said Friday that militiamen had killed Izzat Ibrahim al-Douri, the highest-ranking official from Saddam Husseins government who was still on the loose, in clashes in a mountainous region of northern Iraq.

title: Fred Segal Opens a Store, and a Food Truck, in Japan
description: Just as Japans cherry blossom season comes into bloom, the storied Southern California brand Fred Segal sets up shop  and a food truck  in Tokyo. The new store, situated on a recently converted urban railway site called Log Road Daikanyama, opens its doors in the Daikanyama neighborhood, among luxe boutiques (like Saturdays NYC), low-key cafes, residential homes and gleaming skyscrapers.

title: The Path to Today, I Announce ...
description: Highlights as the 2016 presidential hopefuls make their way down a familiar path, perhaps to yes. There are four loosely defined stages.

title: Mapo Tofu Goes Vegetarian
description: Mapo tofu, that aromatic dish of braised tofu with minced pork (sometimes beef) in a deeply savory sauce, is a wildly popular menu item in many Chinese restaurants. I gladly order it whenever possible. Just a spoonful or two with steamed rice makes a pleasant beginning to a multicourse meal.

title: Cooking Techniques: Making Caramel
description: Dissolve sugar in water over heat to make caramel.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Exercise, Women and the Love of Dogs
description: Take the Quiz

title: Video: Getting From Not Interested to Im Running
description: Back in mid-March, when he was merely an undeclared presidential hopeful, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas acknowledged that he was pretty much already running for the Republican nomination. I will point out, a week ago, I was in Iowa, he said to a cheering crowd. Yesterday, I was in South Carolina. And today, Im in New Hampshire.

title: Exclusive | The San Remo
description: A triplex penthouse owned by Demi Moore in the prized south tower the 1930 Emery Roth landmark is for sale at $75 million.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties include condos in Prospect Heights and Alphabet City and a co-op in the West Village.

title: Demi Moore Is Seeking $75 Million for Her Central Park West Penthouse
description: The triplex south tower penthouse widely considered the crown jewel of the San Remo, the twin-peaked Emery Roth masterwork and city landmark on Central Park West, is poised to enter the market for the first time in 25 years. The asking price for the residence, PH26C, along with a two-bedroom two-bath lobby level maisonette, No. 1H, included in the sale, is $75 million, an amount that, if met, would set a record for an Upper West Side co-op and shatter the in-house record of $26.4 million achieved at the San Remo last year.

title: Mike Huckabee Fuels Speculation With Announcement on Fox
description: Mike Huckabee, the former Republican governor of Arkansas and TV talk-show host, has been saying that he will make a decision on whether he will run for president by sometime in the spring.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Spinster and Public Shaming
description: This week, Kate Bolick discusses Spinster; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Jon Ronson talks about So Youve Been Publicly Shamed; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Spinster and Public Shaming
description: This week, Kate Bolick and Jon Ronson.

title: 1940: French Canadians Guard Buckingham Palace
description: French-Canadian service members guarded Buckingham Palace in April 1940.(britishpathe.com)

title: Letter: What Weve Learned
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: How Much Festival Is Too Much Festival?
description: Jon Caramanica, Jon Pareles and Ben Ratliff discuss the vicissitudes and artistic value of music festivals.

title: Humanitarian Crisis Grows as Iraqis Flee ISIS Threat
description: BAGHDAD  In an intensifying humanitarian crisis in Iraqs embattled Anbar Province, thousands of residents are fleeing a pitched battle between Islamic State militants and pro-government forces around the provincial capital.

title: Parents of Youngest Boston Marathon Victim Oppose Death Penalty for Tsarnaev
description: BOSTON  For the last few months, the government has used Bill and Denise Richard, and the death of their son Martin, to drive home the heinous and depraved nature of the bombings at the 2013 Boston Marathon.

title: An Unwanted Dog in China
description: Tibetan mastiffs were once trendy must-have dogs for wealthy Chinese, selling for more than $200,000. But waning interest has left many breeders with unwanted dogs.

title: No Comment Necessary: Ovary Clinton
description: Deanna Alexander, a member of the Milwaukee County Board of Supervisors, has apparently begun calling Hillary Clinton Ovary. On Wednesday, she tweeted:

title: Popcast: How Much Festival Is Too Much Festival?
description: Every summer, they rise: moist, many-tentacled, confused, chaotic, pervasive. They pop up in cities across the country  around the world!  and sprawl out largely unchecked, imposing their will upon tens of thousands of people, who find themselves helpless in their presence.

title: Once-Prized Tibetan Mastiffs Are Discarded as Fad Ends in China
description: BEIJING  There once was a time, during the frenzied heights of Chinas Tibetan mastiff craze, when a droopy-eyed slobbering giant like Nibble might have fetched $200,000 and ended up roaming the landscaped grounds of some coal tycoons suburban villa.

title: Springtime Sheet-Pan Chicken
description: Most sheet-pan chicken suppers are wintry things: long-roasted one-pan meals heavy on the starchy root vegetables. They are satisfying and kitchen-warming, but not a recipe to reach for when the sun finally shines.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties include a five-bedroom lake house in Islip, and a five-bedroom in Tarrytown.

title: Homes for Sale in Westchester and Suffolk Counties
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York City region:

title: Stories From Current and Former Success Academy Parents
description: New York City parents of current and former Success Academy students describe a learning environment that was a godsend for some children and a grind for others.

title: Review: Cantata Profanas Indefinable Dreams and Visions
description: When is a quartet a quintet? One answer to this stump-your-friends trivia question is Schoenbergs String Quartet No. 2 (1908), whose four players are joined by a singer in the final two movements, intense settings of poems by Stefan George.

title: Writer Retreats to a Kabul That Lives Only in His Memories and Books
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  FOUR large clocks tick out of sync, puncturing the silence of his Soviet-built apartment. A half-burned candle sits next to a stack of books. A small television is covered in soot.

title: Tribeca Film Festival Interview: Nick Sandow on The Wannabe
description: This is one in a series of interviews focusing on New York-centric movies having their premieres at the Tribeca Film Festival.

title: Why Americans Dont Want to Soak the Rich
description: With rising income inequality in the United States, you might expect more and more people to conclude that its time to soak the rich. Heres a puzzle, though: Over the last several decades, close to the opposite has happened.

title: South Africa Moves to Quell Anti-Immigrant Violence
description: JOHANNESBURG  Shops and vehicles owned by foreigners were attacked in downtown Johannesburg on Friday as the South African government tried to quell a wave of anti-immigrant violence that has claimed at least four lives in the country.

title: Vegetables and Cheese Meet Bread
description: This week Martha Rose Shulman joined Foods sandwich issue with a roasted pepper and goat cheese sandwich that is ideal for travel. Vegetables and cheese, hot or cold, always make a great sandwich combination. Here are more ideas from Recipes for Health.

title: What I Love | Sally Hershberger
description: Home is an apartment with a fireplace, sunsets out the window and friends nearby.

title: The Logistics Behind Mayweather and Pacquiaos 60-40 Split
description: LOS ANGELES  No matter who wins the richest boxing match in history on May 2, Manny Pacquiao will receive part of his pay the next business day from his promoter, Bob Arum.

title: Handling Images From Sources Who Arent Journalists
description: Some call it user-generated content. The authors of a new study prefer the term eyewitness media.

title: Carine Roitfeld + Uniqlo, NYFWs New Homes and Ryan Gothling
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: Everythings Coming Up Daisies
description: I remember a time when a daisy was just a daisy, with its familiar yellow circle at the center, surrounded by that soft ruff of velvety white petals: cheap and lovable. And then those Gerbera daisies seemed ubiquitous in the 1990s, flashy and colorful. Sure, theyre pretty, but they seemed to be trying a little too hard.

title: Justice Departments Criminal Chief Pledges More Clarity
description: The Justice Department often bemoans a lack of transparency from companies facing criminal investigations. Now the Justice Department will be providing some clarity of its own.

title: Colors Pop at Sally Hershbergers Chelsea Home
description: Bright colors pop in Sally Hershbergers one-bedroom rental at London Terrace Gardens. The neutrals are limited almost exclusively to the black, gray and white coats of her dogs, Cherry and Foxy.

title: Clintons Stance on Marriage Equality Is Promoted in Video
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons embrace of the gay community continued on Friday with a new advertisement featuring her in a diner being thanked for supporting same-sex marriage as a constitutional right.

title: Rodrigo Rato, Ex-I.M.F. Chief, Investigated in Spain Over Finances
description: LONDON  The financial affairs of the former International Monetary Fund chief Rodrigo Rato have come under increased scrutiny in Spain after law enforcement officials detained Mr. Rato as part of a tax and money-laundering investigation.

title: Verbatim: A Yankee Candidate in Red Sox Country
description: Former Gov. George Pataki of New York, addressing New Hampshire Republicans at a meeting of prospective 2016 presidential candidates on Friday, when asked about his best moment in public life. The roomful of Red Sox fans erupted in loud boos.

title: Fraud Fed the Mortgage Crisis
description: Expanded mortgage lending in low-income neighborhoods before the foreclosure crisis was helped along by fraud  namely, the overstating of borrower income on loan applications, according to new academic research.

title: N.B.A. Playoff Preview and Predictions: New Contenders Emerge
description: When the Cleveland Cavaliers announced that they had made a trade for the All-Star forward Kevin Love, pairing him with the returning LeBron James, one of the worst teams in basketball became a championship contender. Amid the Coming Home hoopla, someone forgot to tell the Golden State Warriors and the Atlanta Hawks that this was Clevelands year.

title: George Bushs Letter Cautions Family on Conflicts of Interest
description: In 1988, as George Bush ran for president, he addressed a letter to George W. Bush, urging family members to steer clear of perceived conflicts of interest.

title: U.S. Army Trainers Arrive in Ukraine
description: MOSCOW  The Kremlin on Friday warned that the arrival of several hundred American military trainers in Ukraine could destabilize the situation in the countrys southeast, where a cease-fire between government troops and Russian-backed separatists is barely holding.

title: Ted Cruzs Strange Gun Argument
description: Americans who believe the Second Amendment gives them an individual right to own guns (as opposed to a more general right to bear arms, as our editorial board argues) often make cogent arguments for their position. I believe that allowing people to own guns is not incompatible with imposing reasonable restrictions on their ownership, but I have heard sensible people strongly argue the opposite side.

title: The Power of Starting With Yes
description: I once served on a committee led by a powerful woman. She had strong views, but what I remember most is that whenever I spoke, she nodded her head vigorously and affirmatively. Over time, I learned that her nodding didnt mean she necessarily agreed with me. Even so, I always sensed that she was listening closely and carefully considering what I had to say.

title: The Eiffel Tower Reappears in The Timess Travel Section
description: Quick, name a structure in Paris besides the Eiffel Tower.

title: Blackstones Latest Results Suggest Its Model Is Finally Working
description: It makes sense for a firm that thinks in blocks of seven to 10 years to take about eight before hitting its stride. The listed units of Blackstone, the buyout shop led by Stephen Schwarzman, finally trade noticeably above their 2007 initial public offering price. Owners of the equity, however, may yet prove more fickle than investors in Blackstones funds.

title: A Drug Trials Frayed Promise
description: Last fall, an article in The American Journal of Psychiatry caught the attention of specialists who treat borderline personality disorder, an intractable condition for which no approved drug treatment exists.

title: Dan Farrell, Photographer Who Captured Kennedy Funeral Salute, Dies at 84
description: Dan Farrell, a photographer for The Daily News in New York known for his image of John F. Kennedy Jr. saluting his fathers coffin, died on Monday in Rockville Centre, N.Y. He was 84.

title: France Announces Stronger Fight Against Racism and Anti-Semitism
description: PARIS  Deadly attacks on Jews by Muslim extremists in January and a sharp spike in anti-Muslim acts since then have prompted the French government to elevate the fight against racism into a great national cause, leading government officials said on Friday.

title: Identity Theft Poses Extra Troubles for Children
description: The note that arrived in the mail, dated March 25 and addressed to my grade-school-age daughter, said what we had expected and feared: Like tens of millions of other Americans, including untold numbers of children, she may have fallen victim to thieves who gained access to Social Security numbers and other personal data from the health insurance giant Anthem.

title: Jeb Bush Proposes Requiring Medicare End-of-Life Directives
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Jeb Bush, defending his efforts to keep alive Terri Schiavo, a brain-damaged woman, when he was governor of Florida, suggested on Friday that patients on Medicare should be required to sign advance directives dictating their care if they become incapacitated.

title: Current and Former Success Academy Parents
description: New York City parents share their experiences with the charter school network.

title: Verbatim: Rubio Addresses Question of His Age
description: I know 44 is, which is what I turn in May,

title: Another Petrobras Subcontractor Files for Bankruptcy
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Another Brazilian company has fallen to the corruption scandal surrounding Brazils petroleum giant, Petrobras: Schahin Group requested on Friday a bankruptcy courts protection for 28 of its subsidiaries.

title: First in the Nation Forum: Rick Perry
description: Every major Republican presidential hopeful isinNew Hampshire this weekend for the states First in the Nation candidate forum. We bring you the highlights, starting with former Texas Gov. Rick Perry.

title: Carla Fernndez Brings T to Mexico to See the Making of Her Designs
description: Last year, the fashion designer and activist Carla Fernndez, who collaborates with artisans throughout Mexico to create avant-garde silhouettes rich in hand-worked detail, was the subject of a popular show at the Isabella Stewart Gardner museum in Boston. Now, just in time for Earth Day, the West Coast will have the chance to interact with Fernndezs work up close  and, for the first time in the U.S., to actually buy it. Starting tomorrow, the Boiler Room at Heath Ceramics in San Francisco is hosting Design Culture Mexico, a presentation that expands upon the Gardner show. Curated by Renee Zellweger of the San Francisco organization Summer School (no, not that Rene Zellweger), the exhibition also features work from select Mexican artists and functions as the official stateside launch of Fernndezs collection.

title: Letter on Settlements
description: A letter signed by 16 European foreign ministers urged the E.U.s foreign policy chief, Federica Mogherini, to clearly distinguish products that are made in Israel from those made in Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank.

title: Israeli Foreign Minister Denounces E.U. Proposal to Label Settlement Products
description: JERUSALEM  Israels foreign minister on Friday angrily denounced a letter signed by more than a dozen of his European counterparts asking that the European Union require products made in Israeli settlements be labeled differently from those made in Israel.

title: George Bush Letter in 1988 Warned Family of New Friends Asking Favors
description: As the 1988 presidential campaign of then Vice President George Bush began, he knew that the microscopic probing of his family was about to intensify.

title: At Global Economic Gathering, U.S. Primacy Is Seen as Ebbing
description: WASHINGTON  As world leaders converge here for their semiannual trek to the capital of what is still the worlds most powerful economy, concern is rising in many quarters that the United States is retreating from global economic leadership just when it is needed most.

title: Yemeni Army Tries to Safeguard Oil Fields as Qaeda Fighters Advance
description: DOWAAN, Yemen  A Yemeni Army unit handed over control of a group of oil fields to a coalition of armed tribes on Friday in an attempt to keep the fields from falling into the hands of Al Qaeda or other militant groups amid the chaos of a continuing bombing campaign led by Saudi Arabia.

title: Univisions Sbado Gigante Ends a 53-Year Run
description: The Spanish-language variety show Sbado Gigante is ending its run in September after more than 53 years on the air, Univision Networks announced Friday.

title: Obama Urges Creative Talks to Bridge Divide With Iran on Sanctions
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Friday directed his diplomats to use creative negotiations to bridge a sharp divide with Iran over the fate of sanctions if it agrees to curb its nuclear program, signaling flexibility in hopes of keeping a tentative agreement from unraveling.

title: Participatory Budgeting Opens Up Voting to the Disenfranchised and Denied
description: On Wednesday afternoon. Anthony Marx, the president of the New York Public Library, addressed a roomful of women in pastel boucl at an annual fund-raising lunch. He told them about a boy he had met on the stoop of a branch library in the Bronx who had a laptop that looked as though it was associated with a sales receipt time-stamped in the early 1990s. Mr. Marx asked him what he was doing, and the boy told him that he was there because his family couldnt afford Internet access at home.

title: Video Reviews of Child 44, Alex of Venice and Unfriended
description: In this video, Times critics share their thoughts on Child 44, Alex of Venice and Unfriended. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Movie Review: Child 44
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Child 44.

title: Book Review Podcast: Kate Bolicks Spinster
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Heather Havrilesky reviews Kate Bolicks Spinster: Making a Life of Ones Own. Ms. Havrilesky writes:

title: Making a Home, in Sickness and Health
description: Winston S. Fisher didnt have big plans for his 30th birthday in July 2013. I thought Id just go home and eat cake, alone, he said.

title: Second Wind for Michael Phelps, as a Swimmer and a Person
description: MESA, Ariz.  As his life unraveled, the athlete rued that all he knew how to do was swim. So I was just this little hole where a man should be, he said.

title: For Professor Rubio, Remedial Welding May Be Required
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  On his first day on the campaign trail as an official 2016 presidential hopeful, Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, on Friday embraced the retail tradition of New Hampshire, offering himself up as both teacher and student, eager to learn but comfortable and quippy.

title: Movie Review: Alex of Venice
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Alex of Venice.

title: New Life for the Dodgers Old Digs
description: Images from Dodgertown, now Historic Dodgertown, which hosts events like Canadian Football League minicamps, high school soccer games and junior college softball championships.

title: Movie Review: Unfriended
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Unfriended.

title: Turkish Premier Says European Stance on Armenian Genocide Reflects Racism
description: ISTANBUL  Turkeys prime minister on Friday accused Europe of showing signs of racism after the European Parliament passed a resolution calling on his government to recognize the mass killings of Armenians in the collapsing Ottoman Empire as genocide.

title: A Duplex at One57 for $91.5 Million
description: The Winter Garden duplex penthouse at One57, Extell Developments vitreous skyscraper, which has attracted a bevy of billionaire buyers since sales began in 2011, sold for $91,541,053 to a group led by the hedge fund mogul William A. Ackman. It was the second highest price ever paid for a single residence in New York City and the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: After Manhattan Explosion, Familys Real Estate Business Faces Scrutiny
description: The field of rubble on Second Avenue in Lower Manhattan where three buildings stood before they were destroyed by a gas explosion last month shares a neighborhood with restaurants serving borscht and varenyky, shops that post signs in Cyrillic and a store selling tubs of poppy seed spread. These are the vestiges of a pocket of the East Village neighborhood once so dense with Ukrainian immigrants fleeing Soviet control after World War II that it was known as Little Ukraine.

title: Promised a Supermarket Five Years Ago, a Housing Project Is Still Waiting
description: Residents of the Farragut Houses, a city housing project in northwest Brooklyn, suffer from at least two forms of isolation. There is the physical kind: the gated Brooklyn Navy Yard to the east, the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway to the south. And there is the economic kind: the luxury apartments of Dumbo to the west, the historic rowhouses of Vinegar Hill to the north.

title: Serbian Presidents Plane Takes Harrowing Plunge
description: WARSAW  An engine on an aging Serbian government plane carrying the president failed on Friday, sending the aircraft into a horrifying 60-second plunge over the Adriatic Sea, according to Serbian officials and news reports.

title: Obama Calls Senate Delay Embarrassing
description: President Obama criticized the Senates delay in approving the appointment of Loretta E. Lynch as attorney general on Friday, saying there was no reason for it besides political gamesmanship.

title: Pictures of the Day: South Africa and Elsewhere
description: South Africa and More  Pictures of the Day

title: April 17, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from South Africa, Greece, Turkey and Lebanon.

title: Review: In Tatau, a Pacific Idyll for Dodgy Londoners
description: Just to prove that all eight-episode cable drama series are not created equal, even in the golden age of television, BBC America is offering the British import Tatau beginning on Saturday night. From the production studio behind the original Being Human, Tatau is a spring-break thriller translated to TV about a pair of gullible boys from London set loose among the shamans, hallucinogens and maidens of the South Pacific. You get a sense of what youre in for early on when the grizzled surfer dude who runs the local bar walks into his first scene carrying a chain saw.

title: A Lively Comment Discussion About Dementia and Sex
description: Elder sex. Nursing home dalliances. The erotic lives of dementia patients.

title: Stopping Short of Rejection, Clinton Sets Conditions for a Trade Deal
description: After 24 hours of silence, Hillary Rodham Clinton has weighed in on perhaps the most divisive issue before the Democratic Party, setting her conditions for accepting a new trade deal making its way to Congress but not flat out rejecting it.

title: A New Spring for Old Dodgertown
description: VERO BEACH, Fla.  The Montreal Alouettes football players, dozens of them, jogged out of the Jackie Robinson meeting room to a practice field wearing shorts, cleats and Jackie Robinson T-shirts.

title: Things to Do on Long Island, April 19 to 25, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Martin Winterkorn to Stay as Volkswagen Chief, Even After Slight
description: PARIS  Just a week after it appeared that Ferdinand K. Pich, Volkswagens powerful chairman, was preparing to throw his hand-picked chief executive and presumed successor under the Microbus, the company announced Friday that the executive, Martin Winterkorn, would have his contract renewed.

title: Things to Do in New Jersey, April 19 to 25, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Rubio to New England: Cant Wait Til That Tom Brady Guy Retires
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Senator Marco Rubio on Friday offered a crowded house party in New Hampshire some hard truths  namely, he doesnt love New England sports teams.

title: Obama on His Concerns About Congress
description: The president, in an appearance with Prime Minister Matteo Renzi of Italy on Friday, spoke about his concerns that congressional action would derail the nuclear deal with Iran.

title: First in the Nation Forum: Chris Christie
description: Best Applause Line: Many to choose from, but I didnt run for governor of New Jersey to be elected prom king got the most love.

title: Nick Caves The Sick Bag Song, an Epic Poem Composed on Tour
description: If you ever find yourself sitting next to the rock star Nick Cave on a plane, dont be alarmed if he reaches for an airsick bag. Hes probably just going to jot down some song lyrics or other stray thoughts.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: On TV, Ecological Themes for a Small Planet
description: Earth Day, which this year falls on Wednesday, is an occasion for celebrators, castigators and celebratory castigators. And for television that does all three of those things.

title: Friday Night Music: Milk Carton Kids
description: Im in Athens, and should do something location-appropriate, but am just too tired. And I did get to see them in an invitation-only concert last Saturday, which was wonderful; new album coming out next month. Sometimes simple beauty is enough:

title: The Rapper Heems on Sticking to His Roots, Eschewing Stylists and His Signature Herms Scarf
description: Heems, n Himanshu Kumar Suri, looks equal parts regal and comfortable holding court in the back of Brooklyns Cafe El Beit. Dressed in tailored black separates, his shiny hair slicked up into a high bun, he could be dressed for any one of his many roles: art curator, clothing designer, loving uncle, political activist and, of course, rapper. His first solo album, Eat Pray Thug, was released last month to critical accolades. (His former project, the hip-hop group Das Racist, was likewise beloved for its incisive and playful lyrics.) But Suri barely allowed himself time to celebrate, instead diving right back into community politics  specifically, the desperate call for a taxi stand near Manhattans beloved Punjabi Deli.

title: Seller in Canceled Internment-Camp Auction Comes Forward
description: For years, the things sat in storage in John Ryans house in Connecticut and in his fathers house before that, a 60-year-old time capsule of a painful period in American history and a looming question mark for the Ryan family members, who did not know what to do with what they had.

title: Irans Foreign Minister Warns of Unlimited Atomic Fuel Enrichment if Talks on Final Agreement Fail
description: Irans foreign minister raised the prospect on Friday of unlimited Iranian atomic fuel enrichment if the final phase of talks with the United States and other big powers on Irans disputed nuclear program does not achieve an agreement by a June 30 deadline, with all sanctions dropped.

title: Can You Be a Waitress and a Feminist?
description: LAS VEGAS  THIS week I will be sexually harassed on the job, and like many women in the Las Vegas service industry, I will count my tips at the end of my shift and decide that it is worth it.

title: Review: Se Llama Cristina, a Search for Identity, at the Intar Theater
description: A magical realist fable with a side of fried chicken, Octavio Soliss Se Llama Cristina begins with a Latino man and woman (Gerardo Rodriguez and Carmen Zilles) asleep in a squalid room. On waking, they cant remember where they are or who they are. Eventually, they notice a crib, with a drumstick stuffed into the swaddling. Maybe, just maybe, were still trippin, the man suggests. You and me and the leg of chicken.

title: When a Gun Is Not a Gun
description: THE Justice Department recently analyzed eight years of shootings by Philadelphia police officers. Its report contained two sobering statistics: Fifteen percent of those shot were unarmed; and in half of these cases, an officer reportedly misidentified a nonthreatening object (e.g., a cellphone) or movement (e.g., tugging at the waistband) as a weapon.

title: Penn Station, Then and Now
description: Despite protests, the Midtown railroad mecca was demolished in the mid-1960s, and led to stronger efforts to save landmarks.

title: Before Coming Together, Separates
description: Two-piece wedding dresses are turning up in the fall 2015 lines of a number of designers.

title: Puzzling Death of Chicagos Whirlwind Chef, Homaro Cantu
description: CHICAGO  As people in the restaurant business here remember the chef Homaro Cantu, who took his own life this week, they describe a man who was always willing to take on one more thing.

title: Dances of India, Rich in Breadth and Addressing the Sublime
description: The dance forms of India  though I began to watch them over 30 years ago in London  became a regular and deepening source of fascination to me only once I began work as chief dance critic of The New York Times in 2007. Its been a boon, after decades of dancegoing, to investigate them: Theyve extended my idea of dance itself, what it can be and signify.

title: A Star Wars-Themed Plane Will Take to the Skies this Fall
description: The 2016 election campaign may have begun, but an even bigger marketing crusade is on the horizon  and the force is strong with this one. Yesterdays release of a trailer for Star Wars: The Force Awakens, the latest film in the famous franchise, has kicked off what will surely be an endless series of product placement partnerships, one of the first of which is with All Nippon Airways, Japans largest airline.

title: Biden to Attend Israeli Event, in Attempt to Cool Tensions
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. will attend an Israeli Independence Day event sponsored by the Israeli Embassy in Washington next week as the Obama administration tries to cool its public feud with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

title: Two-Piece Wedding Dresses Make Their Statement
description: With an intimate May 16 wedding set in Santa Fe, N.M., Tiffany Coletti Titolo began a quest last year for a gown that would fit her hourglass proportions but that also, she said, didnt feel off the rack.

title: Why Is Spring Being So Passive Aggressive?
description: The springlike weather that  finally!  has begun to arrive, nearly a month after its official start date, with temperatures reliably reaching into the 60s and budding flowers making a sudden appearance in public parks, has not appeared a moment too soon for Nick Guy, 28, of Buffalo.

title: Review: At Youth America Grand Prix Gala, Young and Older Stars Align
description: A dancer may be born with talent, but it takes more than that to get a body ready for the stage.
