At Stars of Today Meet the Stars of Tomorrow, a Youth America Grand Prix gala in which young dancers shared a program with professionals, Julie Kent, the host along with Jared Angle, spoke of gratitude for the teachers, parents and students who sacrifice much in the pursuit of bringing more beauty to the world.

title: Anna Clyne, a Composer Who Creates With Images
description: When Anna Clyne was working on her first big orchestral piece, she invited one of her composition teachers, Julia Wolfe, to look at her drafts. But when Ms. Wolfe arrived at Ms. Clynes studio in Chicago, where she had just begun a residency with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, Ms. Wolfe found no sketches written out on music manuscript paper or drafted with any of the software programs commonly used by composers. Instead, The wall had a painting across it, Ms. Wolfe remembers. It was done in a series of panels that went across her studio, and she said, This is my piece.

title: Review: In Third Rail Projects Genuine Plastic Reliquaries, All the Citys a Stage
description: Public displays of affection are hardly uncommon in Manhattan, where it can often seem as if all the worlds a make-out party. But few such demonstrations are as artfully awkward  or as thoroughly public  as that of a couple recently spotted on West 42nd Street.

title: The New York City Landmark Law Over the Years
description: Heres a look back at the laws impact and some of the thousands of buildings, interiors and entire neighborhoods it has protected.

title: New York Citys Landmarks Law at 50
description: New York Citys landmarks preservation law turns 50 on Sunday. Any who doubt its continuing significance should head to the West Side of Manhattan, to the building it came too late to save. Pennsylvania Station in 2015 is a monument to civic suffocation, a basement of low, dust-blackened ceilings, confusing corridors, beer-and-popcorn dealers, yowling buskers and trudging commuters.

title: Dont Confuse Jeremy Piven With Ari Gold
description: The fast-talking, obnoxiously brazen Hollywood agent played by Jeremy Piven on Entourage dogs him wherever he goes. l have an Apple Store appearance coming up, the compact 49-year-old Mr. Piven said last month, and the invitation says, Please join the actor Ari Gold.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Reviews: Jidenna, Chastity Belt, Sicko Mobb and Mickey Guyton
description: Jidenna

title: Bill Cunningham | Joy Blooms
description: Signs of spring and summer showed up last week.

title: Review: Heidi Latsky Dance at Montclair State University
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  For the choreographer Heidi Latsky, there are no unbeautiful bodies and no bodies incapable of dancing. In what some might call disability, she finds possibility. In Triptych, which opened at the Alexander Kasser Theater at Montclair State University on Thursday as part of the Peak Performances series, she unleashes some of those possibilities in three complementary dances, one for film and two for the stage.

title: In Shanghai, a Convincing Win in the Open Pairs
description: In Shanghai last week, there were subsidiary events for those players not continuing in the Yeh Brothers Cup.

title: Meatyard at Home in Kentuckys Cultural Scene
description: A new exhibit explores how Ralph Eugene Meatyard, a master of creating a strange and personal reality, was far from a solitary artist, but deeply involved with others in Kentuckys creative milieu.

title: Bill Cunningham |Joy Blooms
description: Signs of spring and summer showed up last week. For fashion, it was all about the colorful scarf and the gray flannel suit. Daffodils, tulips, pussy willows, flowering branches and balloons appeared in Union Square. In Central Park, it was almost summer, with flying kites and a new generation of flower children.

title: Things to Do in Westchester, April 19 to 25, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Tibetan Dies After Setting Himself on Fire in Protest
description: HONG KONG  A man set himself on fire in a heavily Tibetan region of southwest China this week, leaving behind a makeshift shrine that included a photo of the Dalai Lama, international groups reported on Friday. He was the second Tibetan to set himself on fire in a protest in the last two weeks and the 139th within China since the practice began among Tibetans in February 2009.

title: Hey, Kids, Look at Me When Were Talking
description: Consider this fair warning: If youre going to bring your children around me, Im going to teach them how to shake hands. The process, which I picked up from my dad, involves three simple steps: firm grip, squeeze, look me in the eye. When my father started doing this in the 1970s, the hardest step for many children was the first. This was the era when the demure four-finger handshake was still popular among women and girls. More recently, as gender equality has leveled the handshake, Ive noticed that young people have an almost universal aversion to the final step.

title: Evening Hours | Highlight of the Season
description: Creative dining at the Brooklyn Museum and other celebrations.

title: Review: Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2, Starring Kevin James, Heads to Las Vegas
description: You wont find much offensive in Kevin Jamess slick, innocuous vehicle Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2. You wont find much prompting an emotional reaction in general, so familiar are the jokes and situations. If Mr. Jamess character thinks of safety first, so does this movie, to its extreme detriment.

title: A New Face at 20 Percent Off? Sign Me Up.
description: I lost a lot of weight a while back, and a few weeks ago I realized my skin was too big for my face.

title: Anger Management: Why the Genius Founders Turned to Couples Therapy
description: Over breakfast at Cafe Mogador in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, Ilan Zechory couldnt stop talking about the complicated relationship with his best friend, Tom Lehman.

title: Under Bombardment in Yemen, Civilians Voice Terror and Despair Online
description: While Saudi Arabias ambassador in Washington offered an upbeat assessment this week of the air campaign in Yemen led by his nation, calling it very, very successful, civilians living under bombardment for more than three weeks expressed terror and despair in messages posted online.

title: Christopher Wheeldons An American in Paris Brings Ballet Values to Broadway
description: The conversion of famous movies into stage musicals is business as usual on Broadway these days. But the adaptation of the 1951 film An American in Paris that opened at the Palace Theater on Sunday has attracted unusual attention from the world of ballet because of who is involved.

title: Khalik Allahs Movie Captures Harlem Faces and Voices by Moonlight
description: Shot at night, the Harlem subjects of the photographer and filmmaker Khalik Allah have a soulful glow even when their circumstances are dire. In his film Field Niggas, Mr. Allah records the struggling denizens of the corner of 125th Street and Lexington Avenue. His rich use of color, chiaroscuro, slow motion and fades seems to suspend faces and bodies against the inky backdrops and twinkling city lights.

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, April 19 to 25, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Review: Revenge of the Popinjay at Dixon Place
description: The curtain speech at Revenge of the Popinjay, by Animal Parts at Dixon Place, sounds a bit different than usual. Theres little about cellphones or flash photography or exit routes. Instead, Anthony (Anthony Johnston), with his plaid shirt and ripped jeans and uniquely Canadian friendliness, shares the latest safety guidelines issued by the New York Police Department: Try to be off the streets by nightfall. Do not go out alone. If you must leave your homes after dark, always travel with a same-sex buddy.

title: Colbert and Lucas on Star Wars, Late-Night TV and Howard the Duck
description: Just like everyone else, George Lucas checked out the new teaser for Star Wars: Episode VII  The Force Awakens. That was one of several tidbits gleaned from a wide-ranging talk between the director and the television host Stephen Colbert at the Tribeca Film Festival on Friday.

title: Loyalty Extending Beyond the Barbers Chair
description: Frank Codispotis hair salon, Allegria, is in a fancy new hotel in Downtown Brooklyn, but his camaraderie has fostered generations of loyal customers.

title: A Little Off the Sides, Camaraderie on Top
description: You would have a hard time finding a better representative of Old Brooklyn than Frank Codispoti. A barber who immigrated to New York when he was 18 from the town of SantAndrea in the southern Italian region of Calabria, Mr. Codispoti has cut hair in Brooklyn for more than 40 years. So it might seem somewhat jarring to find him in such a fancy spot in the lower lobby of the New York Marriott at the Brooklyn Bridge. But the crossroads of new and old Brooklyn are everywhere, and Allegria Hair Salon is just such an intersection.

title: Review: Jordi Savall, Plunged in the Emotion of Performance and Life
description: If it is possible for a musician performing publicly at full tilt to be simultaneously lost in thought, the Catalan viola da gamba virtuoso Jordi Savall may have done it in the first half of his solo program at Weill Recital Hall on Monday. One of Mr. Savalls two appearances in Carnegie Halls Before Bach festival, the recital, The Spirit of the Viol, focused on music of Marin Marais and the Sainte-Colombes, father and son.

title: The Week in Political Pictures
description: On the road in Iowa and New Hampshire; a crashed gyrocopter; Booths pistol; and cycling for wounder warriors.

title: 59th Street Bridge Singer
description: For most of its users, the Queensboro Bridge is something to be traversed as quickly as possible, but for Sue Hassel, it is a place to linger.

title: New York Citys People, Famous and Everyday
description: Two photographers who shared a fascination with the city captured it with very different focuses.

title: Two Visual Tales of New York
description: The two photographers were born just two years apart and grew up poor in Brooklyn in the 1920s and 30s. The war awakened them creatively. Their subject was New York.

title: First in the Nation Forum: Jeb Bush
description: Best Applause Line: It drew both laughter and applause, but the tight-fisted New Hampshire Republicans really enjoyed Mr. Bushs recounting of how, as Florida governor, he earned the nickname Veto Corleone for his efforts to restrict spending.

title: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
Clinton Team to Hit the Road in Search of New Donors
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons finance team will go on a fund-raising road trip next week, holding a series of meetings with hundreds of small donors on the East Coast as a way to engage supporters ahead of larger planned events aimed at those who are expected to bundle donations and collect a larger number of checks.

title: Stock Markets Fall Around the World
description: Signs of complacency were evident before stock markets around the world tumbled on Friday.

title: A Challenge to Lumber Liquidators Tests
description: A few consumers have filed a lawsuit against Lumber Liquidators, accusing the company of hiring unaccredited laboratories to prove to customers that its flooring is safe and not contaminated with formaldehyde.

title: Chief Leaves Music Service Taken Over by Jay Z
description: Barely a month after Jay Z took over Tidal, a Swedish streaming music service, the top executive at its parent company has stepped down and about a dozen employees have been laid off.

title: Gun Maker Colts Curious Exchange Offer
description: Colt Defense, maker of the famous pistols used by outlaws and actors, has announced that it may undertake one of  the strangest prepackaged bankruptcy cases ever.

title: Safety Regulations Issued for Trains Carrying Oil
description: Responding to public pressure to act more quickly after a series of fiery train derailments involving oil shipments, the Transportation Department on Friday issued a series of emergency orders, including a 40-mile-an-hour speed limit for hazardous materials moving through urban areas.

title: At a Long Island Beach, Human Tempers Flare Over Claws and Feathers
description: JONES BEACH STATE PARK, N.Y.  On a brisk day in early spring, the scene at Jones Beach was quiet.

title: Free the President
description: LAST weeks news from Washington: A dysfunctional Congress managed to function just long enough to bludgeon President Obama into ceding his prerogative to enter into an executive agreement with Iran regarding its nuclear program.

title: Why We Let Prison Rape Go On
description: ORANGE, Conn.  ITS been called Americas most open secret: According to the Bureau of Justice Statistics, around 80,000 women and men a year are sexually abused in American correctional facilities. That number is almost certainly subject to underreporting, through shame or a victims fear of retaliation. Overall, only 35 percent of rapes and sexual assaults were reported to the police in 2010, and the rate of reporting in prisons is undoubtedly lower still.

title: For a Mother, Many Worries and Few Clues About Her Runaway Daughter
description: In January, a 16-year-old girl named Joannie opened her journal, decorated with glittery stars on the cover, and wrote, Dear God, Thank you for another day on earth and watching over me and my family. There was nothing, in hindsight, to remotely suggest she would run away from home again in three months.

title: Republicans in Quandary Over Vote on Loretta Lynch
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Republicans do not want to be held responsible for rejecting the historic nomination of Loretta E. Lynch, the first African-American woman picked to be attorney general. But they also are in no hurry to see her confirmed because of her defense of President Obamas immigration policies.

title: Key Moments in Pilots Mental Health History
description: The Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz received certifications allowing him to fly, even though he had exhibited suicidal tendencies and was treated by psychotherapists.

title: Keep Pilots in the Cockpit
description: To the Editor:

title: Putins Threats: How Should the U.S. React?
description: To the Editor:

title: Jury in Etan Patz Case Focuses on Confession and Video
description: A Manhattan jury deliberating in the trial of a man accused of murdering 6-year-old Etan Patz in 1979 asked on Friday to review the testimony of a prosecutor who made the decision not to record the daylong interview with the police that led to the mans confession.

title: Teenage Pressures and Suicide Risks
Equity and Birthrates
description: To the Editor:

title: Senator Jeff Sessions Argues for a Cut in Immigration
description: To the Editor:

title: The Pope and the Nuns
description: To the Editor:

title: Review of Comcast Deal Is Said to Raise Concerns
description: The staff lawyers at the Justice Department reviewing Comcasts proposed $45 billion takeover of Time Warner Cable have raised concerns about the merger and are leaning toward recommending that it be blocked, according to a person with knowledge of the deliberations.

title: Declassify the 9/11 Pages
description: To the Editor:

title: Marco Rubio Swings Through New Hampshire
description: NASHUA, N.H.  On his first day on the campaign trail as a declared 2016 presidential candidate, Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, embraced New Hampshires appetite for retail politics on Friday, offering himself up as both teacher and student, eager to learn but comfortable and full of quips.

title: Sunny Skies, but N.B.A. Has Eye to the Horizon
description: On the eve of the N.B.A. playoffs, Commissioner Adam Silver relayed the news that business was good in the wake of two days of meetings by the leagues Board of Governors at a Manhattan hotel.

title: First in the Nation Forum: Marco Rubio
description: Best Applause Line: This is about the future of America and its very identity.

title: Ichiro Suzukis Hitting Remains Constant Amid Changes
description: He gently places the silver case on the carpet of the Miami Marlins clubhouse, then clicks the fasteners and lifts the lid. You know what is inside, but this is Ichiro Suzuki, still a bit mysterious after all these years. You half expect the contents to glow, like the briefcase in Pulp Fiction, a movie released more than two decades ago, in a year Suzuki hit .385.

title: Referendum Reshapes Scottish Political Terrain
description: PAISLEY, Scotland  Mhairi Black is lively, self-confident and 20, with an exam in politics to take before she graduates from college. But as the Scottish National Partys candidate for Parliament from a constituency west of Glasgow, Ms. Black is poised to overturn a large Labour Party majority here and defeat one of Labours stars, its shadow foreign secretary and campaign manager, Douglas Alexander.

title: Robert P. Griffin Dies at 91; Michigan Senator Urged Nixon to Quit
description: Robert P. Griffin, a former Republican senator and congressman from Michigan who co-sponsored one of the nations most rigorous laws to fight corruption in unions and who delivered a critical blow to Richard M. Nixons presidency by withdrawing his support during the Watergate crisis, died on Thursday in Traverse City, Mich. He was 91.

title: British Prosecutors Drop Charges Against 9 Journalists in Tabloid Inquiry
description: LONDON  After a series of court reversals, prosecutors on Friday dropped charges against nine of the 12 journalists who still faced trial after police investigations into the behavior of Britains freewheeling tabloid press.

title: Hillary Clinton Hiring of C.F.O. Is Called Signal to Possible Donors
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons recruitment of Gary Gensler, a former top federal Wall Street regulator, as her campaigns chief financial officer was meant to show donors she is serious about avoiding the overspending that plagued her 2008 presidential campaign, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: Rules to Make Retirement Investing Safer
description: In a giant step forward for investor protection, the Department of Labor proposed new rules this week to ensure that financial advisers act solely in their clients best interests when giving advice and selling products for retirement accounts. The new standard of fiduciary duty would bar stockbrokers, insurance agents and other financial professionals from increasing their pay by steering clients into high-cost products and strategies when comparable lower-cost ones are available.

title: Pope Stops Investigating the Good Sisters
description: The Vaticans misguided investigation of American Catholic nuns seemed thoroughly steeped in chauvinism from its inception three years ago by the churchs male-dominated bureaucracy. Romes move against widely respected churchwomen was puzzling and provocative in an era of scandal by male priests committing child rape and being repeatedly shielded by their male superiors.

title: After Walter Scott Shooting, Scrutiny Turns to 2nd Officer
description: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C.  He did not fire a shot. He is black, not white.

title: Hope Still Bright for CubsKris Bryant After Shaky Debut
description: CHICAGO  A few hours before Kris Bryant made his major league debut at Wrigley Field on Friday afternoon, his father, Mike, a onetime minor league outfielder, stood near the Cubs dugout, watching his son rip line drives all over the field during batting practice. Gripped by nostalgia, he recalled how 5-year-old Kris had hit the ball with such power he thought his son could have been a big leaguer even then; how Kris had opted for college instead of turning professional after high school; how his son had never had an alcoholic drink; and how he wept a night earlier, after he had learned Kris was on his way to Wrigley.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: The Syrian crisis places the entire humanitarian system at a crossroads. It requires us to radically rethink how we protect and assist such large numbers of displaced people.

title: Civil Rights Groups in South Carolina Ask U.S. to Investigate Killings by Police
description: Civil rights groups in North Charleston, S.C., asked the United States Department of Justice on Friday to investigate all fatal shootings by police officers in Charleston County in the last 21 years.

title: Cardinal Francis E. George, 78, Dies; Urged Zero Tolerance in Abuse Scandal
description: Cardinal Francis E. George, who was the Roman Catholic archbishop of Chicago for 17 years and helped shape the American Catholic bishops response to the child sexual abuse scandal and their resistance to the Obama health plans contraception coverage, died on Friday at his residence in Chicago. He was 78.

title: Military Deaths in Afghan and ISIS Operations
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,343 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations and three service members who have died supporting the operation to eliminate the Islamic State militant group. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Peering Through the Haze
description: They sure know how to bury the lead at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Replica of Lafayettes Frigate to Set Sail From France for a U.S. Visit
description: PARIS  A finely wrought full-size replica of the Hermione, the ship that carried the Marquis de Lafayette to America in 1780 to help the American revolutionaries fight the British, will set sail on Saturday for the United States in a formal launching ceremony in France.

title: Its Your Fiction That Interests Me
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  As Damon Gulczynski says in his notes below, it helps to have a knowledge of current pop culture  well use The Simpsons as an example in the next paragraph  to gain a toehold in a Saturday puzzle. It also helps to know history, sports, horticulture, older pop culture, music, the capitals of Indian states and intriguing yet seemingly out-of-context quotes from books written in 1950.

title: Sony Studio Renews Warning After WikiLeaks Posts Stolen Data
description: LOS ANGELES  David Boies, a lawyer for Sony Pictures Entertainment, began warning news media outlets on Friday that WikiLeakss posting of emails and documents stolen from Sony does not, in the media giants view, make them fair game.

title: Arrest by F.B.I. Is Tied to $500 Million Art Theft From Boston Museum, Lawyer Says
description: BOSTON  Federal agents trying to solve the biggest art theft in the nations history arrested a 79-year-old Hartford man on Friday after conducting their second sting against him in three years to force him to disclose the whereabouts of $500 million in stolen art, the mans lawyer said.

title: Review: The Mineralogy of Objects, With a Most Flexible Guest Star
description: The star of Laurie Bergs The Mineralogy of Objects is an inflatable sex doll named Tanya. She appears midway through the 55-minute dance, which made its debut on Thursday at Danspace Project, in line with Ms. Berg and the three other female dancers who make up the cast. They toss Tanya around and try to keep her aloft like a beach ball. They engage her in an absurdly acrobatic ballroom duet. They roll with her on the ground as she deflates.

title: Stanislav Gross, Czech Leader Who Erred on Iraq Link to 9/11, Dies at 45
description: Stanislav Gross, who in 2004, at age 34, became the Czech Republics youngest prime minister and who played a small role in the buildup to the Iraq war, died on Thursday in Prague. He was 45.

title: Bartolo Colons Arm and Bat Help Push Mets to 6th Straight Win
description: Michael Cuddyer walked around the Mets clubhouse before Friday nights game against the Miami Marlins wearing a faded orange T-shirt adorned with a Mets logo and the slogan The Magic is back. But Harry Houdini would have had difficulty conjuring some of the plays that led to the 4-1 win against the Marlins a few hours later, the Mets sixth straight victory.

title: Vivian Nicholson, 79, Dies; A Rags-to-Riches Story Left in Tatters
description: She went to London to collect her prize wearing borrowed stockings and cardboard in the soles of her shoes. There, as flashbulbs exploded, she became an international celebrity  the factory worker who had come into a fortune.

title: Alex Rodriguez, a Maligned Source of Power, Lifts the Anemic Yankees
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Too often in the young season, the Yankees have floundered in the field, flailed at the plate and watched their starting pitchers last as briefly as a June bug.

title: One Teenager Is Killed and Another Is Injured in Shooting Outside Brooklyn Housing Project
description: One teenage boy was killed and a second was injured in gunfire in the courtyard of a Brooklyn housing project on Friday night, the police said.

title: Whats on TV Saturday
description: 9 P.M. (CUNY) THE CLAY BIRD (2003) City Cinematheques tribute to Milestone Films continues with Tareque Masuds drama, set in Bangladesh in the 1960s, about Anu (Nurul Islam Bablu), a shy young boy from rural East Pakistan who is sent to an Islamic school by his father (Jayanto Chattopadhyay), who doesnt want his son tainted by the outside world. Anu struggles to conform to the schools monastic ways, and to be accepted by the cliquish boys. But soon he gravitates to the enthusiastic oddball Roko (Russell Farazi), the one student who refuses to go along with the program. Mr. Masuds expansive fluidity is rapturous, inspired equally by the floating equanimity of Satyajit Ray and the work of the Iranian director Abbas Kiarostami, who deftly uses ritual behavior to provide social commentary, Elvis Mitchell wrote in The New York Times. Its also evident that Mr. Masud loves all his characters, even the small-minded ones  the sign of a real director. Its no small achievement to make a picture that extols the necessity for clear, free thought while dramatizing the barriers that challenge such a capacity.

title: Corrections: April 18, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Afghan President Blames ISIS for a Bombing
description: JALALABAD, Afghanistan  The Afghan president, Ashraf Ghani, blamed the Islamic State extremist group for a suicide bombing here on Saturday that killed 35 civilians. If responsibility is confirmed, it will suggest a major escalation of the groups activities in Afghanistan.

title: Australian Police Arrest 5 Men They Say Were Planning Terror Attacks
description: SYDNEY, Australia  The Australian police arrested five men on Saturday who they said had been planning terrorist attacks to be carried out next weekend, during a national holiday. Prime Minister Tony Abbott said the men had been inspired by the Islamic State extremist group.

title: At Afghan Weddings, His Side, Her Side and 600 Strangers
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  When Shafiqullah walked into his wedding celebration, he was surprised to find 600 extra people in the room, none of whom he recognized.

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took viewers from a Louisiana plantation to a Star Wars celebration.

title: 1947: dith Piafs New York Debut
description: dith Piaf singing Non, Je Ne Regrette Rien in December 1960. It was her comeback show after a year off the stage because of health issues. INAThis year marks the centenary of the birth of the French singer dith Piaf. In 1947, the New York Herald Tribune reported on her first show in the United States:

title: Catherine Deneuve Celebrated at IFC Center
description: Imperious, perverse, remote and radiant, Catherine Deneuve is a monument to French poise and pulchritude. Franois Truffaut, Luis Buuel and Roman Polanski are among the Continental auteurs who have been captivated by her. Now, the IFC Center honors her with Deneuve x 8, a program of her best-known films, playing through June 7 as part of its Weekend Classics series.

title: Deciding the Fate of a Beloved Tree
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Germanwings Crash Exposes History of Denial on Risk of Pilot Suicide
description: DSSELDORF, Germany  When Andreas Lubitz sent an email in 2009 seeking reinstatement to Lufthansas flight-training program after a monthslong absence, he appended what in retrospect was a clear warning signal about his fitness to fly passenger jetliners: an acknowledgment that he had suffered from severe depression.

title: Second Stage Buys Helen Hayes Theater, Ending Dispute
description: A nonprofit theater company on Friday purchased one of the last independently owned Broadway houses, promising to bring more plays by living American playwrights to an industry dominated by musicals, movie adaptations and British imports.

title: At Republican Gathering, All Talk Is of Hillary Clinton (None of It Is Good)
description: NASHUA, N.H.  They attacked her judgment on resetting American relations with Russia and protecting American diplomats in Libya. They slammed her as secretive for using a personal email account at the State Department and deleting messages in the face of scrutiny. They mocked her recent campaign events in Iowa as inauthentic and her unannounced lunch at Chipotle as antisocial. They even reached back to her husbands infidelity to disparage her.

title: Surveying How Their Gardens Grow
description: Deborah Marton spends her workdays toiling over places where others spend their days of rest. Ms. Marton, 52, is the executive director of the New York Restoration Project, a nonprofit group that Bette Midler started in 1995 to reclaim decaying green spaces in the citys low-income neighborhoods. This means that Ms. Marton sometimes spends her weekends hearing from Ms. Midler. Right now shes in L.A., preparing for a tour, Ms. Marton said. But she does think about work on the weekends. After the past winter, and with Earth Day approaching on April 22, the staff, which tends to two parks and 52 community gardens, has had a lot of planting and spiffing up to do. When not overseeing the spiffing, Ms. Marton decamps to her loft in the Flatiron district, which she shares on alternating weeks with her son, Henry, 16, and full time with Lex, a small rescue mutt.

title: Regulatory Relief for Banks That Rarely Fail
description: Rolling back regulations created after the 2008 crisis has been Job 1 for leaders of many of the nations large and powerful banking institutions. So its no surprise that recent proposals for regulatory reform in the financial industry have overwhelmingly been the work of big banks or their supporters. The bankers want to return to the days when they could roll the dice, pocket their winnings and rely on the taxpayer if something went wrong.

title: Variety: A Mind-Boggling Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  And you thought April Fools Day had passed.

title: Moleskine Notebooks Adapt to the Digital World
description: During his travels, the author Bruce Chatwin famously scribbled in small black notebooks with covers made of oilcloth, a tightly woven cotton coated in linseed oil; each was wrapped in an elastic band. He stocked up on them at a Parisian paper store and took them on trips to Brazil, Afghanistan and Australia and to a dinner meeting in New York with Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis.

title: The Trout Lilys Brief Spring
description: Despite the warm weather and recent rains, spring was barely evident on a recent walk I took through Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. Not even the tips of the bloodroot were showing, and trout lily leaves were resigned to south-facing slopes. The calls of an Eastern phoebe resonated through the sober woods; it was still winter in most ways.

title: First in the Nation Forum: Rand Paul
description: Best Applause Line:Holding up former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clintons actions before the attack on American diplomats in Benghazi, Libya, as a dereliction of duty that should forever preclude her from holding high office.

title: An Inspirational Interior for a Digital Designer
description: Geoff Dowd is the director of experience design at Adobe Systems in San Francisco.

title: One Killed in Kashmir Valley Protest
description: NEW DELHI  A young man was killed in the western part of the Kashmir Valley on Saturday when police and security forces fired on stone-throwing protesters, the police said.

title: Israel and Palestinians Reach Tax Deal
description: JERUSALEM  Israel and the Palestinian Authority have reached an agreement to resolve a monthslong dispute over the transfer of tax revenue Israel collects on behalf of the Palestinians, officials said on Saturday.

title: Books on a Photographer, the Underground Railroad and Ancestry
description: Back in the 1940s, a boyfriend gave Eve Arnold a $40 Rolleicord camera, and she wandered to New York after work and on weekends, she recalled, capturing in black and white drunken bums sleeping in the Bowery, sun glinting off rope, texture of paint peeling off walls.

title: Drawing a Trout
description: The writer and artist James Prosek makes drawings of the fish he catches in order to enhance his powers of observation.

title: Beyond Horse-Whispering
description: Sheryl Jordan, 56, is the equestrian director at Salamander Resort and Spa in Middleburg, Va.

title: The First Film Shot in New York City
description: Q.What was the first movie shot on location in New York City?

title: Technology That Prods You to Take Action, Not Just Collect Data
description: The bookshelves in Natasha Dow Schlls office at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology are punctuated here and there with kitchen timers: a windup orange plastic device, an egg-shaped stainless steel mechanical timer, a digital hourglass with falling pixels in lieu of sand.

title: Out of Africa, Kuba Fabrics That Dazzle and Teach
description: An intriguing back story enlivens the dazzling designs and astute scholarship on display in Kuba Textiles: Geometry in Form, Space, and Time, an exhibition of 19th- and early 20th-century African textiles now at the Neuberger Museum of Art.

title: The Mine-Sniffing Rats of Africa
description: Nicholas Kristof follows a large rodent as it searches a minefield in northern Angola.

title: Googles Steely Foe in Europe
description: Margrethe Vestager, the European Unions commissioner for competition, who last week took on the colossus that is Google, has a reputation for toughness.

title: Whooshing Trains and Sweeping Views at Hudson Social in Dobbs Ferry
description: We knew that we were in for a good time at Hudson Social when minutes after we were seated. another patron (a CNN producer, we were told) bought everyone in the restaurant a round of drinks. When we politely refused, our waitress deadpanned: He insists. And so, like the other two dozen folks sipping Westchesters own Captain Lawrence brews and vodka-strong blood-orange martinis, we settled into the good vibes  and great views  at this new Dobbs Ferry eatery.

title: Faith vs. Facts
description: JERUSALEM  MOST of us find it mind-boggling that some people seem willing to ignore the facts  on climate change, on vaccines, on health care  if the facts conflict with their sense of what someone like them believes. But those are the facts, you want to say. It seems weird to deny them.

title: The Machines Are Coming
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  THE machine hums along, quietly scanning the slides, generating Pap smear diagnostics, just the way a college-educated, well-compensated lab technician might.

title: Trout Fishing, a Taut Line to Our Past
Responses to David Brooks: The Road to Inner Virtue
description: Readers discuss a column by David Brooks about how deeply good people got that way.

title: The Giant Rats That Save Lives
description: MALANJE, Angola  IM walking in a minefield here in rural Angola, tailing a monster rat.

title: Granny Get Your Gun
description: WASHINGTON  THE most famous woman on the planet has a confounding problem. She cant figure out how to campaign as a woman.

title: Hillarys Shelved Crown
description: THE 2016 presidential campaign is only now gathering steam and already Im confused.

title: Checking Charlie Hebdos Privilege
description: A LIVING cartoonist lecturing his murdered peers makes for a curious spectacle, but thats what transpired at journalisms George Polk Awards a week ago. The lecturer was Garry Trudeau, of Doonesbury fame; his subject was the cartoonists for Charlie Hebdo, the Parisian satire rag, who were gunned down by fanatics because of their mockery of Muhammad and Islam.

title: Vance Joy
description: Vance Joy is an Australian singer-songwriter known for the recent breakout hits Riptide and Mess Is Mine.

title: I Was an Animal Experimenter
description: How did it happen? How did I go from being a high school student who played in a rock band to a mad scientist conducting cruel animal experiments?

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: The Other Side of Boredom
description: MY years as a kayak guide coincided exactly with the Great Recession. By 2009, tourists were canceling their trips in droves. I received their cancellation emails in a quiet shop on the water in San Diego, behind a desk stuffed with waivers for the two-hour trips I rarely led, topped with a display rack of sunglasses that were never purchased. Many days went by without any customers. I had nothing, really nothing, to do. The only indicator of time passing was the sun moving across the wall and the click of the mouse as I, alone with my boredom, discovered the Internet.

title: Voting Rights, by the Numbers
description: When the Supreme Court struck down the heart of the Voting Rights Act in 2013, its main argument was that the law was outdated.

title: Would You Want to Smell BBQ All the Time?
description: CITY COUNCIL meetings in Austin, Tex., tend to be droning, low-drama affairs, but that wasnt the case earlier this month when barbecue was on the agenda: specifically, the smell of barbecue and a proposal to control it, in response to some citizen complaints.

title: Anti-Semitism in the Soccer Stands
description: An ugly vein of soccer fan excess  the chanting of anti-Semitic slurs  recently disgraced a Dutch soccer game, prompting officials of the home team, Utrecht, to apologize for shocking outcries from the stands like Hamas, Hamas, Jews to the gas and Jews burn the best!

title: Europes Tough Case Against Google
description: The charge in the European Commissions antitrust complaint against Google may be relatively easy to explain  the company tried to steer people to its own comparison-shopping service. But it wont be easy to show that Googles tactic actually hurt its rivals  or hurt consumers by limiting their choices.

title: First in the Nation Forum: Carly Fiorina
description: Best Applause Line: Ms. Fiorina has organized her campaign around tough attacks on Hillary Rodham Clinton, and has emphasized how much more business experience she has. Ms. Fiorinas comment that Hillary Clinton must not be president of the United States, was met with an enthusiastic ovation.

title: Hey, Google! Check Out This Column on Headlines
description: THE headline was perfect: Chinas Tensions with the Dalai Lama Spill Into the Afterlife. Engaging, informative and clever, it sat atop a story about reincarnation and the succession plan for the Tibetan Buddhist leader, accompanied by a photo of the golden-robed monk.

title: First in the Nation Forum: Bobby Jindal
description: Best Applause Line: Mr. Jindals denunciations of the Common Core education standards, with particular hoots and claps for his flat insistence that We have got to get rid of Common Core.

title: Lawsuit in Spain Seeks Recognition of Another Dal Creation: A Daughter
description: GIRONA, Spain  Salvador Dal led the kind of eccentric and sensational lifestyle that might have been expected of one of the greatest Surrealist painters.

title: As Detroit Tigers Evolve, Success Is a Constant
description: The Detroit Tigers have pulled off a trick that only the best teams can do. Their position in the standings never changes, but their roster continues to evolve.

title: The Art of Music and Conversation
description: Louis K. Meisel, a Manhattan art dealer and music lover, has been presenting concerts by young musicians in his SoHo loft for some 18 years.

title: At Organico, Where Organic Isnt Simply Healthy
description: Signs that Long Islanders are interested in healthier eating seem to be everywhere. My favorite supermarket recently doubled the space for organic and whole food; a peek into my son and daughter-in-laws refrigerator revealed an all-organic lineup of milk, eggs and poultry, and then theres Organico, an organic Italian restaurant that opened last August in Port Washington.

title: Nearly 20 Years Later, Another Yankees Replacement Is Struggling
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  For a generation, Don Mattingly embodied the Yankees ideal. He was the teams best player, its captain and a revered figure for the way he carried himself.

title: Review: In Tammy Ryans Play Tar Beach, a Summer Night of Partying, Boys and Regrets
description: Tammy Ryan is a playwright known to New Jersey audiences for her Lost Boy Found in Whole Foods and Soldiers Heart, both of which were produced in recent seasons by Premiere Stages in Union. Her latest work, Tar Beach, can now be seen in its world premiere at Luna Stage in West Orange.

title: First in the Nation Forum: Lindsey Graham
description: Best Applause Line: Mr. Graham, a noted quipster, won more laughs than applause, but they were chuckles of approval. One of Mr. Grahams most resonant one-liners was his criticism of the Obama administrations negotiations with Iran over that countrys nuclear capacity. I wouldnt let John Kerry buy me a car, he cracked.

title: Ever-Changing Flavors, With a Hint of Daring at Pairings Palate+Plate
description: As a new father, I rarely find myself in a white-tablecloth, formal restaurant, so Im almost surprised when I enter such a place. The casual elegance of Pairings Palate+Plate in Cranford, N.J., made me wonder if I was underdressed in my jeans and sweater.

title: Nets Hopes Rest on Deron Williams, if Hes Up to Carrying Them
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Deron Williams was surrounded by a group of reporters Friday as he answered questions about the Nets new lease on life.

title: First in the Nation Forum: John Kasich
description: Best Applause Line: After calling for stronger border security and federal budget changes, especially changes to entitlement programs, Mr. Kasich said, We need a strong America to send a message to our enemies  that America is back, and this can be done.

title: Oh, Baby, What a Playoff Game! Right, Mom and Dad?
description: My parents dont remember anything about the first hockey game I went to, but theyve been talking about the second ever since. Probably because it could also count as the third game and part of the fourth one, too.

title: An American Dreamland, From the Beginning
description: Somehow, she missed Coney Island Baby, the 1962 doo-wop hit by the Excellents. But Robin Jaffee Frank, who organized Coney Island: Visions of an American Dreamland, 1861-2008, has not missed much. A sprawling evocation of Brooklyns most famous  and sometimes infamous  locale installed at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art, this clamorous multimedia exhibition mixes fine art, pop culture and history, juxtaposing shimmering beachscapes and gaudy carousel horses, Sunday comics and classic photographs, surreal paintings and vintage posters.

title: First in the Nation Forum: Mike Huckabee
description: Best Applause Line: It was not for a lack of trying, but Mr. Huckabee only received modest applause from a crowd that may have been a bit fatigued as the afternoon wore on and the candidates kept coming. His best response may have been when, in criticizing the countrys tax system, he referenced the emails lost by Lois Lerner, the former Internal Revenue Service official. They cant even keep their emails for seven days much less seven years, Mr. Huckabee said of the I.R.S., complaining that the agency requires Americans to retain their income tax records.

title: An Architect of Hawks Success, in Purgatory as Playoffs Begin
description: ATLANTA  Jonathan Walton, a professor of religion and society at Harvard University, received a phone call in September from Danny Ferry, who had recently started a leave of absence as the general manager of the Atlanta Hawks.

title: La Foresta in Killingworth is a Farmhouse With Big Visions and Big Portions
description: The hulking olive-brown barn set along a barren reach of Route 81 in Killingworth had sat unused for years. Once home to a struggling Christmas-themed gift shop, it had long stood vacant  a looming carapace marooned beside a sparsely traveled rural road. But then, in late 2013, Francesco Lulaj, a local restaurateur, noticed it.

title: First in the Nation Forum: Ted Cruz
description: Best Applause Line: Take your pick. We need to abolish the I.R.S. We need to repeal every word of Obamacare. Or, Twenty months from now, imagine a commander-in-chief who stands up and says with utter clarity, we will destroy radical Islamic terrorism. And finally, If only the terrorists attacked a golf course, that might actually get the White Houses attention: Holy cow, this is serious. Most of the Republicans ate up all of it and more.

title: After Collapsing in Game 2, the Islanders Relish the Comforts of Home
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  The Islanders almost unfathomable ability to squander two-goal leads rose to the forefront yet again Friday night in Game 2 of their first-round playoff series against Washington.

title: A Marathoner Outruns a Childhood of Poverty
description: Fernando Cabada  a poor Latino from one of the rougher neighborhoods in Fresno, Calif.  is the first to acknowledge that he will be an unusual front-runner for Mondays Boston Marathon.

title: A Free Spirit Prepares to Make an N.F.L. Splash
description: It surely was a sight to behold last year when Leonard Williams, a 6-foot-5, 302-pound defensive end at Southern California, would coast to team workouts across campus on a longboard as his wild hair flapped in the wind.

title: California Releases Revised Water Consumption Rules
description: LOS ANGELES  In case there was ever any doubt, forcing a 25 percent cut in urban water use by Californians in the fourth year of a searing drought is not going to be easy.

title: China Cracks Down on Golf, the Sport for Millionaires
description: HONG KONG  President Xi Jinpings crackdown on vice and corruption in China has gone after drugs, gambling, prostitution, ill-gotten wealth and overflowing banquet tables. Now it has turned to a less obvious target: golf.

title: Police Unions, Facing Public Anger, Rethink How to Address Shootings
description: Amid nationwide outrage over a police officers shooting eight bullets at the back of an unarmed, fleeing suspect in South Carolina, the statement by the local police union had a half-sentence of regret and contrition: Yes, it said, the fatal shooting was beyond comprehension.

title: Cornells Chocolate Milk Fills Refueling Gap
description: ITHACA, N.Y.  Throughout the school year, Cornells strength and conditioning center is filled with a chorus of clanging weights and thumping rock music.

title: Irwin Schatz, 83, Rare Critic of Tuskegee Syphilis Study, Is Dead
description: Nobody knows how many people read the December 1964 issue of the journal Archives of Internal Medicine, but apparently only one, Dr. Irwin Schatz, was so appalled by one of its articles, about a syphilis experiment using uneducated black men in Tuskegee, Ala., that he wrote the studys author to protest.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: A Positive Perspective

title: Double Down
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  Well, I got myself into a fine mess with this one. I got out of it, eventually, but a fine mess is to be expected when I am faced with a rebus puzzle.

title: A. Alfred Taubman, 91, Dies; Developer, Sothebys Owner and Focus of Scandal
description: A. Alfred Taubman, an art collector and shopping-mall tycoon who sold Renoirs and root beer with equal panache and turned a sleepy Sothebys auction house into a global power of art sales, but went to prison in a commission-fixing scandal involving its archrival Christies, died on Friday at his home in Bloomfield Hills, Mich. He was 91.

title: Sale of U.S. Arms Fuels the Wars of Arab States
description: WASHINGTON  To wage war in Yemen, Saudi Arabia is using F-15 fighter jets bought from Boeing. Pilots from the United Arab Emirates are flying Lockheed Martins F-16 to bomb both Yemen and Syria. Soon, the Emirates are expected to complete a deal with General Atomics for a fleet of Predator drones to run spying missions in their neighborhood.

title: Utility vs. Homeowners Over Solar Power
description: In Hawaii, where 12 percent of the homes have solar panels, handling the surplus power is putting pressure on the states biggest utility, which is fighting to reduce what it pays for the energy.

title: Conflict Over Soil and Water Quality Puts Iowa Nice to a Test
description: MANSON, Iowa  The flat, endless acres of black dirt here in northern Iowa will soon be filled with corn and soybean seeds. But as farmers tuned up their tractors and waited for the perfect moment to plant, another topic weighed on their minds: a lawsuit filed in federal court by the states largest water utility.

title: Solar Power Battle Puts Hawaii at Forefront of Worldwide Changes
description: HONOLULU  Allan Akamine has looked all around the winding, palm tree-lined cul-de-sacs of his suburban neighborhood in Mililani here on Oahu and, with an equal mix of frustration and bemusement, seen roof after roof bearing solar panels.

title: Workers Seeking Productivity in a Pill Are Abusing A.D.H.D. Drugs
description: Fading fast at 11 p.m., Elizabeth texted her dealer and waited just 30 minutes for him to reach her third-floor New York apartment. She handed him a wad of twenties and fifties, received a tattered envelope of pills, and returned to her computer.

title: On This Day, Five Pitches and Youre Done
description: CENTRAL ISLIP, N.Y.  Sean Burroughs of the Bridgeport Bluefish fouled off an 0-2 pitch in the first inning of Saturdays exhibition game against the host Long Island Ducks. The ball landed beyond first baseman Jon Griffins reach, and Burroughs lingered near home plate until the umpire Tony Senia explained to Burroughs that he had struck out.

title: Outlander Recap: The Power of Choice
description: Season 1, Episode 11: The Devils Mark

title: Derrick Rose Puts Injuries, and Doubts, Behind Him as Bulls Defeat Bucks
description: CHICAGO  The lights dimmed, and the pump-up songs filled United Center. Fans stood, and spotlights circled the arena. The word playoffs, in red lighting, flashed on the floor. The Bulls starting lineup for Game 1 of their Eastern Conference series against Milwaukee was introduced, and the public-address announcer had a long-awaited treat for the home crowd.

title: At Candidate Forum, Scott Walker Discusses Same-Sex Marriage of a Relative
description: NASHUA, N.H.  Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, a likely Republican presidential candidate, addressed an issue on Saturday night that has been roiling his party in recent years: gay marriage. Asked by a reporter if he would attend a gay wedding, Mr. Walker, a conservative and a son of a preacher who prays regularly for guidance, said he had attended a reception for a gay relative who had been married.

title: First in the Nation Forum: Scott Walker
description: Best Applause Line: If you want to vote in the state of Wisconsin, you have to carry a photo I.D. to prove who you are, Mr. Walker said about one of several conservative laws he said he enacted as governor.

title: Jonathan Crombie, Romantic Lead in Anne of Green Gables, Dies at 48
description: Jonathan Crombie, a Canadian actor who was known to a generation of fans as Gilbert Blythe in the mini-series Anne of Green Gables, died on Wednesday in New York City. He was 48.

title: Mets, Hottest Theyve Been Since 2010, Extend Their Streak to 7 Wins
description: Sitting atop the National League East, the Mets, winners of six straight, carried a noticeably calm vibe into Saturdays game against the Miami Marlins.

title: Masahiro Tanaka Is Stellar as Yankees Blank Rays
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  It took three starts, a cautious protocol and two months of ceaseless questions about the health of his right elbow, but the Masahiro Tanaka the Yankees have anxiously been hoping for was unveiled here Saturday night.

title: A New Whitney
description: No longer a fortress in an uneasy city, the Whitney Museum of American Art opens itself up to a changed New York, a glittery emblem of new urban capital signaling a definitive shift in the citys social geography.

title: Smriti Rajan, Ravi Bhatia
description: Smriti Rajan and Dr. Ravi Bhatia were married Saturday at the Marriott Silicon Valley in Fremont, Calif. Pandit Bhushanji, a Hindu priest, officiated.

title: Kiara Pesante and  Malik Haughton
description: Kiara Chavon Pesante, the daughter of Aundrea Wearing-Pesante and Wilfredo Pesante Jr., both of Fairburn, Ga., is to be married Sunday to Malik Jelani Haughton, the son of Tina L. Haughton of Orlando, Fla., and the late David H. R. Haughton. The Rev. Dr. Michael E. Dyson, a Baptist minister, is to officiate at the Mayflower hotel in Washington.

title: Summer Jackson and  Luke Tarbi
description: Summer Rachel Maria Jackson and Luke Davis Tarbi were married Saturday at the Sedona Heritage Museum in Sedona, Ariz. Roland J. Jackson, a brother of the bride and a minister of the American Marriage Ministries, officiated, with their great uncle, the Rev. Joseph S. Simmons, a Baptist minister, taking part.

title: Daphne Stavropoulos, Robert Papp
description: Daphne Zoe Stavropoulos and Robert Joseph Papp were married Saturday at the Archangels Greek Orthodox Church in Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Harry Pappas, a Greek Orthodox priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Bianca Caban, Justin Gerrard
description: Bianca Marie Caban, a daughter of Donna Acevedo Caban and Osvaldo Caban Jr. of the Bronx, was married Saturday to Justin Robert Gerrard, a son of Melinda R. Gerrard and Robert J. Gerrard, Jr. of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. Peter M. Colapietro, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of Saint Monica in Manhattan.

title: James Fielding and Edison Briones
description: James David Fielding and Edison Briones were married Saturday in Palm Springs, Calif. The Rev. J. Edwin Bacon Jr., an Episcopal priest, officiated at the ODonnell House, an event space.

title: Madeleine Fawcett, Adam Atenasio
description: Madeleine Johnston Fawcett and Adam Anthony Atenasio were married Saturday at the Bath and Tennis Club in Palm Beach, Fla. The brides half brother, Courtney D. Fawcett, who became a Universal Life Church minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Melissa Paniccioli,  Daniel Linehan
description: Melissa Dawn Paniccioli and Daniel Connor Linehan are to be married Sunday evening at the Liberty House restaurant in Jersey City. The Right Rev. Kenneth J. Reihl, a Lutheran minister, is to officiate.

title: Danielle Stahl and David Kirsch
description: Danielle Heather Stahl and David Jay Kirsch were married Saturday at the Park Hyatt in New York. Rabbi David Posner officiated.

title: Ilona Palamarchuk,  David Johansson
description: Ilona Joy Palamarchuk, a daughter of Emiliya S. Palamarchuk and Petr A. Palamarchuk of Everett, Wash., was married Thursday in Seattle to David Douglas Johansson, the son of Barbara Corrigan Johansson and Douglas K. Johansson of Sammamish, Wash. Ed McKenna, a judge at the Seattle Municipal Court, officiated.

title: Rebecca Savoie,  Christian Patry
description: Rebecca Ann Savoie and Christian Michel Patry were married Saturday by the Rev. George M. Rossi, a Baptist minister, at the River Course at Kiawah Island Club on Kiawah Island, S.C.

title: Caroline Scheinfeld, Jeremy Leventhal
description: Caroline Patricia Scheinfeld and Jeremy Nathaniel Leventhal were married Saturday night by Rabbi Steven C. Reuben at the Hotel Bel-Air in Los Angeles.

title: Jessica Schisano, Kyle Reidy
description: Jessica Martha Schisano, the daughter of Marianna T. Schisano and Richard Schisano of Newburgh, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Kyle Louis Reidy, a son of Valerie J. Reidy and James M. Reidy of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph G. Marina, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of Saint Francis Xavier in Manhattan.

title: Amanda Niu, Patrick Swieskowski
description: Amanda Pei-Shiang Niu and Patrick David Swieskowski were married Saturday at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Their friend Dr. Joseph Dottino, who became a minister of the American Marriage Ministries for the occasion, officiated.

title: Kristin Meliambro, James Crismale II
description: Dr. Kristin Ann Meliambro and Dr. James Francis Crismale II were married Saturday at the Church of St. Paul the Apostle in Brookville, N.Y. Raymond P. DAlessio, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony.

title: Natalie McCormack,  Jonathan Richards
description: Natalie Genecia McCormack and Jonathan Elliot Richards were married Thursday at Ebenezer Wesleyan Methodist Church in Brooklyn. The churchs pastor, the Rev. Edward L. Jenkins Sr., performed the ceremony.

title: Katherine Lamm,  Nicholas Morales
description: Katherine Elmlinger Lamm and Nicholas James Morales were married Saturday evening at Manhattan Penthouse, an event space in New York. The Rev. Galen Guengerich, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated.

title: Julie de Neufville, Nick Monier
description: Julie Lyons de Neufville, the daughter of Virginia Lyons de Neufville and Richard de Neufville of Cambridge, Mass., was married Saturday to John Nicholas Monier, a son of Amy Williams Monier and Dr. Jules C. Monier of Dallas. William S. Lyons, the brides maternal uncle, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at Stella Plantation, a working plantation and event space in Braithwaite, La.

title: Antonia Pryor and William Leavitt
description: Antonia Reese Pryor, a daughter of Lindsey Stansfield Pryor and Samuel F. Pryor IV of New York, was married Saturday evening to William Cowles Leavitt, the son of Elizabeth Ballantine and Paul Leavitt of McLean, Va. The Rev. Ted Pardoe, an Episcopal priest and the brides godfather, performed the ceremony at Christ Memorial Chapel in Hobe Sound, Fla., with the Rev. David C. L. Prior, an Anglican priest, taking part.

title: Leah Keim, Bates Parsons
description: Leah Ann Keim, a daughter of Sarah L. Keim and Dr. Michael L. Keim of Fargo, N.D., was married Saturday evening to Charles Bateman Parsons, the son of Kathryn M. Parsons and J. Geddes Parsons of Hobe Sound, Fla. The Rev. Jered Weber-Johnson, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. John the Evangelist Episcopal Church in St Paul.

title: Patricia Peter and Henry Park
description: Dr. Patricia Rose Peter, the daughter of Dr. T. Rose and T. P. Peter of Freehold, N.J., is to be married Sunday to Dr. Henry Soo-Min Park, a son of Hye Kyong Park and Dr. Robert I. Park of Warren, N.J. The Rev. Ian B. Oliver, a minister of the United Church of Christ, will perform the ceremony at Battell Chapel at Yale, where he is a pastor at the University Church.

title: Booyah at the End of This First Date
description: Lisa Cadette Detwiler and Jim Cramer were married Saturday evening at the Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn. Aran Yardeni, an archeologist and friend of the couple who became a Universal Life Minister for the event, officiated.

title: Crosby Scores Twice as Penguins Tie Series With Rangers
description: Pittsburghs Sidney Crosby hunched at center ice for the opening face-off against his Rangers counterpart, Derick Brassard, on Saturday night, and on cue came the boos that greet Crosby every time he touches the puck at Madison Square Garden.

title: BuzzFeed Says Posts Were Deleted Because of Advertising Pressure
description: An internal review by BuzzFeed last week found three instances when editors deleted posts after an advertiser or employees from the companys business side complained about their content, according to a memo sent to staff members on Saturday by the news and entertainment websites editor in chief.

title: Corrections: April 19, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Finding Fame In the Frame
description: In 1980, the groundbreaking conceptualist photographer Tseng Kwong Chi (1950-1990) infiltrated a $300-a-ticket reception for an exhibition of Ching dynasty costumes at the Metropolitan Museum of Art wearing his own signature outfit, a drab uniform similar to what Chairman Mao regularly wore. Pictures taken by a collaborator show him posing with Paloma Picasso, Henry Kissinger and others who may have taken him for a visiting dignitary rather than an interloper from the downtown art scene.

title: Party-Rap Tunes, Served Up Light
description: As radio stations that were once straight-ahead hip-hop begin to lower their walls to pop influence, hip-hop wont necessarily change, but it will morph. That creates room for a whole new class of rappers who have never considered life outside of the club. Take Kid Ink: Hes from Los Angeles, but where he really lives is on the radio, in saccharine party anthems full of dubious gender politics and toothless rapping.

title: Finally, An Interview
description: Ive been waiting all my life for this moment, Bruce Jenner says in a recent trailer for his hotly anticipated tell-all with Diane Sawyer. (Havent we all?) But what this moment is, exactly, remained a mystery when the network released a second excruciatingly brief teaser on Thursday for Bruce Jenner  The Interview, a two-hour 20/20 special on Friday at 9 p.m. Eastern time.

title: A Merger of Art and Life
description: For the final section of a trilogy delving into issues including identity, memory and ancestry, the choreographer Emily Johnson has aimed high in her multiday performance installation Shore in Lenapehoking (New York City). Each section  four equal parts  relates to her quest to find connections between live performance and life. An Alaska native of Yupik descent now based in Minneapolis, Ms. Johnson looks at those places where, as she puts it, we meet and merge.

title: BuzzFeed Report on Deleted Stories
description: A memo from Ben Smith, the editor in chief of BuzzFeed, that was sent to staff members about the sites review of deleted posts.

title: BuzzFeed Editors Emails Concerning Ads
description: An email from Ben Smith, the editor in chief of BuzzFeed, about a deleted post.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: The privacy of the pilot cannot be traded for aviation safety.

title: Whats On Sunday
description: 5:30 P.M. (FXM) RUBY SPARKS (2012) Zoe Kazan, above, wrote and stars in this variation on the Pygmalion myth as Ruby, a smart, saucy, redheaded young woman from Dayton, Ohio, who magically appears in Los Angeles, seemingly without much control over her emotions. Paul Dano, Ms. Kazans real-life partner, is Calvin, a literary whiz kid turned blocked writer who breathes life into this figment of his imagination, and then directs her every move. Ruby Sparks, directed by Jonathan Dayton and Valerie Faris, the team behind Little Miss Sunshine, has the same zany and sweet tone laced with just enough hardheaded wisdom to keep it grounded in psychological truth, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. The screenplay, by Ms. Kazan, is so polished and witty that it immediately puts her in the same league as Diablo Cody. And Ms. Kazans lovely, tart performance is the equal of Ellen Pages portrayal of the title character in Juno. Both are impetuous screwball heroines who could have been created only by women.

title: Notes on Greece
description: OK, that was intense. Ill write more about my visit, but right now (from Frankfurt, where Im laying over for a couple of hours) I want to make a data point. about just how much adjustment Greece has done.

title: Crowding In and the Paradox of Thrift
description: As Francesco Saraceno notes, the IMFs research department, which was always excellent, has become an extraordinary source of information and ideas in this Age of Blanchard. In particular, these days you can pretty much count on the semiannual World Economic Outlook to offer some dramatic new insight into how the world works. And the latest edition is no exception.

title: Editorial Contest Winner | Chemical Horses and the Racing Industry
description: We are honoring each of the Top 10 winners of our Second Annual Student Editorial Contest by publishing an essay a day, in the order of submission.

title: Hundreds of Migrants Are Feared Dead as Ship Capsizes Off Libyan Coast
description: ROME  Hundreds of people were feared dead on Sunday after a ship crowded with migrants capsized and sank in the Mediterranean, as the authorities described a grisly scene of bodies floating and submerging in the warm waters, with the majority of the dead apparently trapped in the ship at the bottom of the sea.

title: A Mothers Fight Against Gun Violence
description: It was a phone call that Jean Corbett-Parker had been dreading since the birth of her son. After leaving a nightclub in Harlem in 2001, her son, LaTraun Parker, was fatally shot in the head. When Ms. Corbett-Parker was called to Harlem Hospital to identify his body, she said she almost refused.

title: ISIS Video Appears to Show Executions of Ethiopian Christians in Libya
description: CAIRO  The Islamic State released a video on Sunday that appears to show fighters from its branches in southern and eastern Libya executing dozens of Ethiopian Christians, some by beheading and others by shooting.

title: 1915: After Wifes Death, Baron de Reuter Commits Suicide
description: LONDON  Baron de Reuter, the death of whose wife on Friday [April 16] at Margery House, Lower Kingswood, Reigate, has already been announced in the HERALD, committed suicide last night by shooting himself with a revolver. Since his wifes death, to whom he had been married for thirty-nine years, the baron had been deeply depressed, and he passed several hours daily beside the body.

title: At Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Ceremony, a Generational Push and Pull
description: CLEVELAND  Although the show went on for five hours, a few things managed to go unmentioned at the 30th annual Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony on Saturday night here. Among the relevant topics not discussed: the solo catalog of Ringo Starr, who became the fourth and final Beatle to gain entry to the Hall twice over, this time as an individual; disco, rap and dance music, some of the rock-adjacent genres not represented in this years class; and the conspicuous decades-long absence of Bill Withers, one of the shows honorees, from the music industry.

title: Kenneth Branagh Starting London Theater Company
description: LONDON  Bibbidi-bobbidi-boo. Kenneth Branagh, whose movie Cinderella opened last month, has formed his own theater company, and will put on a season of plays at the Garrick Theater in the West End here, starting in October.

title: Los Angeles County Museum of Art Reveals New Acquisitions
description: Before starting an ambitious capital campaign to finance the creation of a bold new building by Swiss architect Peter Zumthor, the Los Angeles County Museum of Art has been engaged in a 50th-anniversary acquisitions campaign designed to boost a collection that has long been considered uneven.

title: A Response to Alec Baldwins Complaints That a Living Wage Rally Snarled Traffic
description: Dear Alec Baldwin,

title: 1965: Swiss Try to Curb French Consumption of Snails
description: PARIS  After the lobster war, the chicken war and the artichoke war, France has become embroiled in a snail war. The Swiss canton of Neuchtel, it was disclosed today [April 19], has issued a decree barring the capture, transport and sale of snails. Since most Swiss have a pronounced aversion to snails  on the dinner table, anyway the new law is interpreted here as a riposte against the neighboring French department of the Doubs. Snail, smothered in garlic butter and baked, are a favorite dish of the French, and the people of the Doubs are accused of crossing the border to hunt for the escargots that the Swiss dont use. Police have been authorized to search cars, suitcases and gamebags for contraband snails. Smugglers run the risk of having not only their booty but also their cars seized.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 20, 1965

title: Furious 7 Muscles Out Newcomers
description: LOS ANGELES  Box office analysts have run out of bad car puns  raced laps, zoomed past, revved up, burned rubber, put pedal to the metal  to describe the performance of Furious 7, which took in an additional $29.1 million over the weekend in North America, for a three-week global total of $1.15 billion.

title: Womens Rights in China
description: Does the shoe fit?

title: Gone With the Wind Dress Sells for Six Figures
description: A dress worn by Vivien Leigh in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 this weekend. The dress, which was worn in four scenes by Leighs Scarlett OHara, was sold by Heritage Auctions along with other memorabilia from the film.

title: Europe's Duty on Migrants
description: The high season of migration from Africa to Europe has begun, bringing with it a new wave of tragic drownings in the Mediterranean. Last year, more than 3,200 people died crossing the Mediterranean. This year, 900 people have already drowned, and on Saturday a boat carrying hundreds more capsized in the Mediterranean north of Libya. Unless Europe acts to reform its policy on migration, 2015 could be the deadliest year yet for the thousands of people who fled to Libya from conflict-torn regions across the Middle East and Africa, only to find Libya equally dangerous.

title: Library of Congress Begins Posting Its Recorded Poetry Archive
description: To celebrate National Poetry Month, the Library of Congress has posted online some 50 recordings from its Archive of Recorded Poetry and Literature, including readings and lectures by Robert Frost, Elizabeth Bishop, Gwendolyn Brooks, Czeslaw Milosz and Paul Muldoon.

title: New Blood Test Shows Promise in Cancer Fight
description: In the usual cancer biopsy, a surgeon cuts out a piece of the patients tumor, but researchers in labs across the country are now testing a potentially transformative innovation. They call it the liquid biopsy, and it is a blood test that has only recently become feasible with the latest exquisitely sensitive techniques. It is showing promise in finding tiny snippets of cancer DNA in a patients blood.

title: Praise and Skepticism as One Executive Sets Minimum Wage to $70,000 a Year
description: When Dan Price announced last week that he would cut his own pay and profits to make it possible to raise the minimum wage at Gravity Payments, his credit card processing company in Seattle, to a hefty $70,000 a year, he had little idea of the whirlwind it would stir.

title: With Mad Men Shoot, Unwittingly Adding to Ateliers Colorful Past
description: Adam Van Doren  who has an eye for detail, what with his training as an architect and his career as a painter and art historian  marveled at the attention to detail. To give his atelier more of a 1960s look, the crew that rented it for the pilot of a television series not only took down the track lighting, but also replaced the not-exactly-new faceplates on the electrical outlets with even older-looking ones.

title: As a Cable Network Dispute Plays Out, Dodgers Fans Scramble to Pull Up a Chair
description: Through the last 66 seasons, Vin Scullys melodic voice has brought Dodgers baseball to the teams fans on radio and television.

title: IBM Venture With China Stirs Concerns
description: HONG KONG  Shen Changxiang, who once supervised the cybersecurity of Chinas strategic missile arsenal and spearheaded computer security research for the navy, has warned of the perils of his countrys reliance on American technology.

title: Bill Clinton Leads Tribute on 20th Anniversary of Oklahoma City Bombing
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  Twenty years to the hour after a homemade bomb gutted this citys federal office building, killing 168 people and a nations complacency about terrorism, a delegation led by former President Bill Clinton gathered here on Sunday to honor the dead and to celebrate the citys resilience.

title: China Frees Up $200 Billion for Lending to Stimulate Economy
description: HONG KONG  Chinese policy makers are dealing with a financial conundrum. Overall economic growth is slipping, which argues for looser monetary policy. But the risk is that any new money is diverted to the countrys frothy stock markets.

title: Greece Flashes Warning Signals About Its Debt
description: WASHINGTON  By the standards of his frenzied schedule here last week, the meeting on Friday between Yanis Varoufakis, the Greek finance minister, and Lee C. Buchheit, the dean of international debt lawyers, was a quiet one.

title: Tavaress Overtime Goal Lifts Islanders Over Capitals
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  The chants of Lets go, Islanders that reverberated through the 43-year-old Nassau Coliseum on Sunday before the Islanders took the ice to warm up were merely a preview of the jubilation ahead.

title: Sunday Talk Show Roundup: The Surrogates Are Loosed
description: The Sunday shows were filled with prospective and declared Republican candidates for president and with surrogates for Hillary Rodham Clinton, who announced her candidacy a week ago.

title: T.H. Tsien, 105, Dies; Scholar of Chinese Books Rescued 30,000 of Them
description: T. H. Tsien, a scholar of Chinese books and printing who in 1941 risked his life to smuggle tens of thousands of rare volumes to safety amid the Japanese occupation of Shanghai, died on April 9 at his home in Chicago. He was 105.

title: Mets Win Again, but With 2 Injuries, Its Not a Good Day
description: The crowd at Citi Field was doing the wave in the seventh inning. The Mets had scored seven runs in the fourth and eventually defeated the Miami Marlins, 7-6, to win their eighth straight game and complete a four-game sweep on a Sunday afternoon when Matt Harvey pitched.

title: Trevor Noah, Next Daily Show Host, Aggressively Sunny in Performance
description: By the way, Trevor Noah can also be pretty funny.

title: Review: The Mineralogy of Objects, With a Most Flexible Guest Star
description: The star of Laurie Bergs The Mineralogy of Objects is an inflatable sex doll named Tanya. She appears midway through the 55-minute dance, which made its debut on Thursday at Danspace Project, in line with Ms. Berg and the three other female dancers who make up the cast. They toss Tanya around and try to keep her aloft like a beach ball. They engage her in an absurdly acrobatic ballroom duet. They roll with her on the ground as she deflates.

title: Review: David Hallberg Presents: Legacy at the Koch Theater
description: David Hallberg is an extraordinary dancer. How did he get there? On Friday at the David H. Koch Theater, he took us through parts of that journey in David Hallberg Presents: Legacy, a showcase of companies with which he has danced, supplemented by his own commentary. (Because of an injury, hes on hiatus from performing.) These included the troupes for which he is a principal dancer  American Ballet Theater, represented by its Studio Company, and the Bolshoi Ballet  as well as the Mariinsky Ballet, Australian Ballet and Tokyo Ballet, in its American debut.

title: Efforts for Land Mine Removal in Colombia Have Doubters
description: Colombia has one of the highest numbers of land mine victims in the world.

title: Senator Joe Manchin of West Virginia to Seek Re-election
description: Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia, a Democrat known as a bridge between the parties, said on Sunday that he would run for re-election, quieting speculation that he would abandon his seat to run for governor.

title: The agreement between FARC and Colombias military to work together on land mine removal has its doubters.
description: Colombia has one of the highest numbers of land mine victims in the world.

title: In Colombia, Land Mines Are Cleared, Inch by Inch
description: COCORN, Colombia  Luvin Meja kneels on the ground, wearing a heavy Kevlar vest and pants, a thick clear plastic shield over his face.

title: Reviews: Ian Bostridge, Tenet and Tallis Scholars in Performance
description: SONGS OF WORLD WAR I

title: Venice Cup Womens Qualifying Unfolds
description: This years Bermuda Bowl, Venice Cup and dOrsi Senior Bowl world championships will take place in Chennai, India, from Sept. 26 to Oct. 10.

title: Yankees Sweep at Tampa Bay Is Their First Since 2005
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  There have been no puffs of white smoke emanating from the office of Yankees Manager Joe Girardi, nor has Girardi issued any proclamations.

title: Chivalrous Rule
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  When you find out the back story behind this one, you will likely give Tom McCoy a huge Awww Hes dedicated todays smooth Monday puzzle to his parents. His puzzle is also an excellent example of how to get started solving The New York Times crossword, if youre a beginner (and I know youre out there).

title: Second Stage Buys Helen Hayes Theater and Settles Suit
description: A nonprofit theater company on Friday purchased one of the last independently owned Broadway houses, promising to bring more plays by living American playwrights to an industry dominated by musicals, movie adaptations and British imports.

title: Review: Andris Nelsons Makes New York Debut as Boston Symphony Leader
description: One would think that by now the Boston Symphony Orchestra, which has been around since 1881, would have nothing to prove. Still, Andris Nelsons, the ensembles dynamic new music director, and the players, who are clearly excited over his arrival, seemed eager to show off last week at Carnegie Hall.

title: Review: Jon Krakauers Missoula Looks at Date Rape in a College Town
description: Pants on fire are a frequent motif in Jon Krakauers Missoula, a book about date rapes on a college campus. Mr. Krakauer, who admits to having known or cared virtually nothing about this subject before a personal experience prompted him to explore it, has a lot to say about lying.

title: Shift of Christies Auction Crowds Art Collectors Calendars
description: At first glance, it seems a simple thing: This year, Christies has decided to hold its Impressionist and Modern art evening auction in the second week of May, not the first, as it usually does.

title: Sky Pods Show Rise of New York Skyline
