description: The elevators to the observatory atop 1 World Trade Center show an animated time lapse that recreates the development of New York Citys skyline, from the 1500s to today.

title: On Time-Lapse Rocket Ride to Trade Centers Top, Glimpse of Doomed Tower
description: An imposingly realistic vision of the old 1 World Trade Center, the ultimately doomed north tower, will begin appearing next month in a most unlikely place: the five special elevators servicing the observatory atop the new 1 World Trade Center.

title: Billboards in Iran Say Death to America, but Officials Say Lets Make a Deal
description: TEHRAN  Wearing business suits set off with sneakers, the American executives trailed a young guide along the narrow sidewalks of the capital of Iran, once branded by the United States as part of the Axis of Evil.

title: Rangers Lose Ground as Power Play Falters
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins had 1,123 penalty minutes in the regular season  the most in the N.H.L.  and were short-handed 277 times, the fifth-highest total. In Game 1 of their first-round playoff series against the Rangers on Thursday, the Penguins sent a cavalcade to the penalty box, taking four first-period penalties, which led to Ryan McDonaghs decisive power-play goal in a 2-1 Rangers victory.

title: Vienna Convention Is Part of Criminal Court Routine in Immigrant-Rich Queens
description: In a windowless fluorescent haze, in the depths of Criminal Court in Queens, a defendant making his first appearance before a judge hears a long, numbing list of forms changing hands.

title: Xi Jinping Heads to Pakistan, Bearing Billions in Infrastructure Aid
description: BEIJING  Chinas president, Xi Jinping, travels to Pakistan on Monday laden with tens of billions of dollars in infrastructure and energy assistance on a scale the United States has never offered in the past decade of a close relationship, a gesture likely to confirm the decline of American influence in that nation.

title: Meb Keflezighi Is Back at the Boston Marathon as a Superstar
description: BOSTON  One year after capturing the Boston Marathon, when he ran alone for nearly the entire race to become the first American to win since 1983, Meb Keflezighi has come to attract the kind of vocabulary less commonly applied to runners than to gods.

title: Anatomy of an Interrogation
description: The story of the first and only CIA contractor to be convicted in a torture-related case after an interrogation.

title: A Singular Conviction Amid the Debate on Torture and Terrorism
description: Agonizing over torture as an antiterrorism tactic  how to define it and how to punish abusers, if at all  has been central to national security debates since the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. The issue has received renewed attention in recent months with the release of a Senate committee report describing techniques used by the Central Intelligence Agency against terrorism suspects, practices found by senators to have been high in brutality and low in effectiveness.

title: Skip Child Support. Go to Jail. Lose Job. Repeat.

title: Yemen Houthi Leader Is Defiant in Face of Saudi Airstrikes
description: SANA, Yemen  More than three weeks after Saudi Arabia began a bombing campaign aimed at crippling his movement, the leader of Yemens Houthi rebels responded with defiance on Sunday in a televised speech, saying that Saudi attempts to humiliate his country were doomed.

title: Netflix Is Betting Its Future on Exclusive Programming
description: LOS GATOS, Calif. title: Service Members Are Left in Dark on Health Errors

He was watching at the quarter-mile track nine days later when Mr. Moore, on an easy mile-and-a-half test run, collapsed at the finish line and was rushed to a hospital.

title: Interpublic to Buy Minority Stake in Samba TV, a Start-Up for TV Analytics

description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  This is the story of how Robert A. Iger, chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, solved a technology problem  how to bring the new Star Wars droid BB-8 to toy shelves and Disney parks  by playing with a ball on his office carpet.

title: Signs and Sounds of Spring

title: Review: The Tailor of Inverness, a Father-Son Tale at Brits Off Broadway
description: The writer and performer Matthew Zajac has a ghost story for you. And an adventure story and a detective story. Its all the same story, which is apparently a true story and conveniently his own story  well, his and that of his father, Mateusz Zajac, who eventually settled in Inverness, Scotland, supporting his family with his sewing machine. What happens before that and also long after, as Matthew returns to Poland to spool back the lost threads of his fathers life, are the subjects of his impassioned but unfocused solo show, The Tailor of Inverness, the first entry in this seasons Brits Off Broadway festival.

title: New Book, Clinton Cash, Questions Foreign Donations to Foundation
description: The book does not hit shelves until May 5, but already the Republican Rand Paul has called its findings big news that will shock people and make voters question the candidacy of Hillary Rodham Clinton.

description: The Americas Cup appeared to have regained momentum in San Francisco Bay in September 2013, but 19 months later, it looks in need of a gust of wind.

title: Mexican Police Capture Leader of Jurez Cartel

title: Seeking Business, Cuomo Heads to Cuba With aNew York Trade Delegation

Working out of a tiny trade-show booth, he signed a contract to do business with the Cubans, and even caught a glimpse of Fidel Castro.

title: In Arkansas, Gay Rights Ordinance Highlights Clash Between Two Faces of Tourism

description: Travis dArnaud, the stoic and rapidly improving Mets catcher, lost his cool late Sunday. No one could blame him. The Mets are the hottest team in baseball, and dArnaud cannot play for them for a while. He learned that his right hand was broken.

The building practically shook when Jamess name was announced before the tip.

title: Sunrise Over Marfa
description: Its the typical New York predicament: Artists need space. Donald Judd, apparently, needed a lot of it. In 1971, he moved from New York City to Marfa, Tex., over 2,000 miles away. Later that decade, with the help of the Dia Art Foundation, he repurposed 34 buildings across 340 acres of the former military base Fort Russell to host his many large-scale installations  and to exhibit a few of his favorite artists, including John Chamberlain and Dan Flavin. (The permanent collection also includes works by Roni Horn, Claes Oldenburg and Coosje van Bruggen.)

title: The Top 10 Moments from Salone del Mobile 2015
description: Unlike the fashion world, the furniture world pretty much only has one season, and it begins, for most brands, every April  when the Salone del Mobile trade fair takes place in Milan, bringing with it hundreds of satellite exhibitions and tens of thousands of professionals hoping to be excited by whats new and next in design. Furniture companies set up incredibly elaborate booths at the fairgrounds to showcase their newest products, international designers band together to install their contemporary wares in centuries-old palazzos and villas, and local gallerists like Rossana Orlandi and Nina Yashar become curatorial tours de force, putting on their best and biggest shows of the year. After youve spent nearly a week pinballing around Milan, around the clock, attempting to absorb all the objects and ideas on offer, its always hard to begin to make sense of what youve seen  but here is a quick look at the 10 people, things and exhibitions that stood out most this year.

title: Whats on TV Monday
description: 10:15 A.M. (Starz Cinema) MASTER AND COMMANDER: THE FAR SIDE OF THE WORLD (2003) In the first of three Russell Crowe movies, Mr. Crowe stars as Capt. Jack Aubrey, commander of a British frigate whose crew must battle a faster, larger French vessel off the South American coast during the Napoleonic wars. Paul Bettany is the ships surgeon  so deft he operates on his own abdomen  and the sensitive foil to Aubreys ferocity. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that Peter Weirs vigorous adaptation of the Patrick OBrien series, with land-based scenes filmed on the Galpagos Islands, hums with humor, passion and life. He added, It makes you wish Napoleon were still around, so we  that is, I mean, the British Empire  could beat him all over again. In Winters Tale (2014), at 12:45 p.m. on HBO Signature, Mr. Crowe plays a gangster in early- 20th-century New York intent on putting asunder the love between a consumptive rich girl (Jessica Brown Findlay) and a thief (Colin Farrell). A thin line separates the magical from the preposterous, and by insisting so strenuously on its own magic, Winters Tale pitches helplessly into earnest ridiculousness, Mr. Scott wrote about this adaptation by Akiva Goldsman of Mark Helprins best seller. And in A Good Year (2006), at 2:45 on HBO Signature, Mr. Crowe portrays Max Skinner, an aggressive London bond trader who inherits a small vineyard from his Uncle Henry (Albert Finney). Soon enough, Max, soothed by the memories of summers spent amid the grapevines, has morphed into a bon vivant and fallen for a beautiful bistro owner (Marion Cotillard). Then a young Californian (Abbie Cornish) shows up and announces that she is his uncles previously unknown daughter  which would make her Henrys true heir. In his review of this Ridley Scott adaptation of the Peter Mayle novel, Stephen Holden advised viewers to make a reservation at an upscale French restaurant immediately after seeing the film or risk going home feeling deprived.

title: Corrections: April 20, 2015
description: NEW YORK

title: Meatyard at Home in Kentuckys Cultural Scene
description: Ralph Eugene Meatyard, a master of photographing the strange and abstract, created his own reality, often casting his family into a hazy, two-dimensional world, where masked boys and specters of motion played against buildings and underbrush. Looking at that work  portraits of a minimal or absurd social landscape, it would be easy to see him as a solitary artist. Meatyards pictures are somewhat exclusionary, as if he found a surreal haven somewhere in the hills of Kentucky. Meanwhile, his local contemporaries tackled ambitious themes: Thomas Merton offered passionate counsel against the dangers of a self-centered, soulless society; while Wendell Berry ardently defended the environment.

title: Trial Postponed for Greek Neo-Fascist Golden Dawn Party Members
description: KORYDALLOS, Greece  In the highest-profile political trial in Greece in decades, members of the neo-fascist Golden Dawn party appeared in court on Monday for a brief hearing as their trial was scheduled to open on charges including membership in a criminal organization and murder.

title: Regulate the Internet?

title: Look to the States on Broadband
description: State and local governments are starting to play an important role in getting broadband Internet access to the American public. And thats highly commendable considering that many people still do not have access to high-speed connections at affordable prices.

title: Shinzo Abe and Japans History
description: The visit by Japans prime minister, Shinzo Abe, to the United States next week is important on several levels. He will be the first Japanese leader to address a joint meeting of Congress. He and President Obama are expected to announce progress on a key issue, increased defense cooperation, and possibly on a second, trade. They will also discuss a third challenge, Chinas growing influence in Asia.

title: Greece on the Brink
description: Dont you think they want us to fail? Thats the question I kept hearing during a brief but intense visit to Athens. My answer was that there is no they  that Greece does not, in fact, face a solid bloc of implacable creditors who would rather see default and exit from the euro than let a leftist government succeed, that theres more good will on the other side of the table than many Greeks suppose.

title: Mohammad Javad Zarif: A Message From Iran
description: TEHRAN  WE made important progress in Switzerland earlier this month. With the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council plus Germany, we agreed on parameters to remove any doubt about the exclusively peaceful nature of Irans nuclear program and to lift international sanctions against Iran.

title: The American Response to Ebola
Farming Sunshine by the Megawatt
description: CALVERTON, N.Y.  Across decades, the great agricultural belt of eastern Long Island has cycled through all manner of crops, from the postwar cornucopia of potato farms to the crazy-quilt of sun-dappled vineyards that blankets the modern farmland. Now the region is farming sunshine itself.

title: Saving a Plane That Saves Lives
description: WASHINGTON  WHEN American troops find themselves fighting for their lives, there is no better sound than an A-10, a plane officially nicknamed the Thunderbolt II but known affectionately by the troops as the Warthog, firing its enormous 30-millimeter gun at the enemy. It might not be pretty, but the A-10 is our most capable close air-support aircraft, and its arrival on the battlefield signals survival for our troops and annihilation for our enemies.

title: New Cards for Medicare Recipients Will Omit Social Security Numbers
description: WASHINGTON  Concerned about the rising prevalence and sophistication of identity theft, most private health insurance companies have abandoned the use of Social Security numbers to identify individuals. The federal government even forbids private insurers to use the numbers on insurance cards when they provide medical or drug benefits under contract with Medicare.

title: 2 Manhattan Aeries With Hearsts Imprint Are on the Market
description: Walking through Riverside Park in Manhattan on a sunny day in the 1980s, Jayne Bentzens friend stopped her and pointed skyward. A giant copper mansard, three stories high and half a football field long, loomed over the corner of 86th Street and the park. That used to be Marion Daviess skating rink, Ms. Bentzen was told.

title: How Do You Deal With Boredom?
description: When was the last time you felt bored: last summer, a week ago, ten minutes ago, or are you feeling boredom right now?

title: The Road to Character, by David Brooks
description: David Brookss gift  as he might put it in his swift, engaging way  is for making obscure but potent social studies research accessible and even startling, for seeing consistency as the hobgoblin of little minds and for ranging as widely across the private domain as the public. There arent many writers on politics who will study emotional intelligence as closely as they do polls, and fewer still extol failure as enthusiastically as they do success. Brookss flaws, as he tells us with typical cheerfulness and ease at the beginning of his new book, are that I was born with a natural disposition toward shallowness and Im paid to be a narcissistic blowhard (the admission itself, of course, taking some of the edge off that narcissistic). He is, in short, a near-ideal public commentator (for this paper and for many other media outlets) because he is happy to sacrifice complexity and nuance in order to spin a hyper-readable, lucid, often richly detailed human story that sounds far less shrill and ad hominem than most of the polarizing rants of the day.

title: Asne Seierstads One of Us, About Rampage in Norway
description: After the Second World War, Scandinavia seemed to create model societies, free of corruption and intolerance, moral, compassionate and fair. The Danish people had bravely defied their Nazi occupiers throughout the war and saved almost all of the nations Jews. In 1944, the Swedish economist Gunnar Myrdal published a groundbreaking critique of the racism faced by African-Americans in the United States. Myrdals study, An American Dilemma, greatly influenced President Trumans executive order to integrate the United States military, the Supreme Courts ruling on behalf of school desegregation, and the creation of the modern civil rights movement. In 1964, Gunnar Jahn, a former leader of the Norwegian resistance to the Nazis, handed Martin Luther King Jr. the Nobel Peace Prize at a ceremony in Oslo. Jahn expressed the hope that conflicts between races, nations and political systems can be solved, not by fire and sword, but in a spirit of true brotherly love.

title: Roadside Bomb in Somalia Kills 4 Unicef Workers
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  At least four Unicef staff members were killed and four others were severely wounded in northeastern Somalia on Monday when a roadside bomb exploded near their minibus, a United Nations statement said.

title: Your Monday Briefing

title: Mystery and Danger of Type 1 Diabetes
description: With mounting concern over the explosive rise in Type 2 diabetes, mostly among overweight and obese Americans, it is easy to forget that Type 1 diabetes, which is far less common, can be a much more serious disease that often seems to arise out of nowhere for no apparent reason.

description: Good morning on this puddle-wonderful Monday.

title: What, Exactly, Do You Want?
description: Suppose that you value freedom of choice. Are you committed to the mere opportunity to choose, or will you also insist that people actually exercise that opportunity? Is it enough if the government, or a private institution, gives people the option of going their own way? Or is it particularly important to get people to say precisely what they want? In coming decades, these seemingly abstract questions will grow in importance, because they will decide central features of our lives.

title: Presidents Acting Unilaterally
Simple Rules for Healthy Eating
description: Over the past few months, Ive written a number of times on how nutrition recommendations are seldom supported by science. Ive argued that what many people are telling you may be inaccurate. In response, many of you have asked me what nutrition recommendations should say.

title: 1940: Canadians Honor War Dead
description: Twenty-three years to the month from the day in April when gallant Canadian troops, in the face of withering German fire, began the battle of Vimy Ridge, destined to become one of the most famous pages in the history of the World War, Canadian veterans in Paris and modern Canadian soldiers at Vimy yesterday [April 20] refreshed the memory held by the world of the 11,000 who died at the ridge and the 60,000 Canadians who lost their lives in the war. In Paris the Canadian Legion gathered at the Arc de Triomphe yesterday morning as Colonel Vanier, Minister to France, laid a wreath upon the Unknown Soldiers grave.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 21, 1940

New Hampshire, however, remains the center of the presidential race, as it says so long to the crowded Republican field and welcomes Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Morning Agenda: Comcast in Push to Save Deal
description: COMCAST IN PUSH TO SAVE DEAL | The $45 billion merger of Comcast and Time Warner Cable was announced in February 2014. Now this week starts the process that will make or break the deal. On Wednesday, officials from Comcast and Time Warner Cable and their lawyers will meet with antitrust officials from the Justice Department, The Wall Street Journal reports.  The meeting will be the first where potential concessions will be discussed, The Journal says, citing people familiar with the matter.

At least 25 people were killed, according to witnesses and medical officials.

title: Tylenol May Blunt Emotions, and Not Just Pain

description: A combination of wind, rain and runway work is causing long inbound delays at New Yorks airports this morning.

title: Sleek Spring Sandals to Complement, and Elevate, Any Look
description: Since its inception four years ago, the L.A.-based brand Building Block has created It bags for the sort of women who dont do It bags. The lines Modernist, structured carryalls, accented with cylindrical rubber straps and pared-back tassels, have a pleasing heft and luxe gloss that resonate with the ladies who covet them  many of them from the art world, who prefer that their accessories whisper, not shout. Now, the labels designers, the sisters Kimberly and Nancy Wu, have turned their talents to footwear with the debut of their first shoe style, a simple but striking summer sandal. Hand-made in Italy of vegetable-tanned leather and encircled by a single strap of the same rubber tubing used in the lines bags, theyll gracefully ground even the most far-out spring looks. Nancy says of the design: Inspiration always stems from the beauty and challenge of editing out excess details to reach a quiet balance of form and function.

title: Chelsea Millers Most Treasured Cooking Tool
description: The knife that Chelsea Miller holds is heavy, primeval, with a flank of teeth, squadrons of sharp triangles like a Polynesian tattoo. The six-inch blade was once a farriers rasp for trimming horses hooves, rusted and dulled from use. Ms. Miller carved it with an oxyacetylene torch, ground it down and blasted it smooth in her smithy, down the street from her apartment in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

title: Look Inward to Determine Your Financial Values
description: Ive been surprised by a lot of things as a financial adviser. One of the biggest surprises has ended up playing a critical role in my development: the process of self-examination.

description: This is one in a series of interviews focusing on New York-centric movies having their premieres at the Tribeca Film Festival.

title: Hong Kong University Official Backtracks on Mandatory China Visits
description: A senior official of the University of Hong Kong apologized on Monday and retracted remarks suggesting that the university would make visits to mainland China mandatory for all undergraduate students.

title: The Politics of Awkwardness on Silicon Valley
description: As it enters its second season, its clear that the HBO comedy Silicon Valley concerns itself not just with the foibles of the American tech industry, but also with the many gradations of human social awkwardness.

title: Europe Is Expected to Bring Antitrust Charges Against Gazprom
description: BRUSSELS  European antitrust regulators are expected on Wednesday to charge the Russian energy giant Gazprom with abusing its dominance in natural gas markets, a move that could escalate Western tensions with Moscow.

title: Cheryls Birthday, the Afterparty
description: The Cheryls Birthday problem blazed brightly last week, putting a math puzzle, of all things, on top of the online world  even for The New York Times. More people clicked on Kenneth Changs How to Figure Out Cheryls Birthday than any other Times article in the past week. What caused this puzzle to go viral? I asked Kenneth and he sent this reply:

title: Twitter Expands Direct Messaging
description: Twitter announced Monday that its users will be able to change a setting on their accounts to allow anyone to send them a private message. In addition, if a person follows a big account  for example, from a company like United Airlines  the Twitter user can respond to messages sent by that account even if the account, United in this case, does not follow that individual.

description: The term African-American may seem to be a product of recent decades, exploding into common usage in the 1990s after a push from advocates like Jesse Jackson, and only enshrined in the Oxford English Dictionary in 2001.

title: The Methodology: 1.5 Million Missing Black Men
description: Our analysis of the number of missing African-American men relies on the 2010 census, the governments most recent attempt to count all residents. The census also contains counts of people in prison and in other institutions such as homeless shelters, hospitals, nursing homes and domestic military barracks.

title: This Time, Lelisa Desisa Wins Boston Marathon for Himself
description: BOSTON  Two hours after Lelisa Desisa won the Boston Marathon in 2013, two bombs ripped through the finish area, killing three spectators and wounding 264 others.

title: Carl Heastie, New York Assembly Speaker, Benefited From His Mothers Embezzling
description: When Carl E. Heastie leapt from obscurity to the top of New York States political power structure this year, he brought with him the potential of a new beginning in Albany. He vowed to bring accountability and integrity back to a statehouse that was reeling from the latest arrest of a lawmaker  the man he was succeeding as the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver.

title: 2nd Person Is Attacked by a Coyote in New Jersey
description: A coyote attacked a man in Bergen County, N.J., while he was walking his dog on Sunday night, the police said.

description: On a recent Tuesday night, about 30 men gathered at the Wall Street Humidor, a cigar shop in the financial district. They puffed on stogies and drank single-malt Scotch, but they had come to shine their shoes.

description: WARSAW  Polish political leaders have been taking turns angrily denouncing James B. Comey, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, over comments he made last week that suggested to them that he blamed Poles for being Nazi accomplices during the Holocaust.

description: Its never been easier to eat a healthy meal at a chain restaurant  so long as you know what youre doing,

title: Charges Against Jason Rezaian, Washington Post Reporter Held in Iran, Include Espionage
description: Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post correspondent incarcerated in Iran for nine months, has been charged with four serious crimes including espionage, his Iranian lawyer said on Monday. The newspaper and the White House denounced the charges, calling them absurd.

An Unexpected  and Surprisingly Useful  Gift for Grads

description: In a radio interview Thursday, Mike Huckabee argued that the military under President Obama punishes Christians and Orthodox Jews for their religious faith, and said that parents should consider waiting until a new president is in office before encouraging their children to enlist.

description: [Photo: View on Instagram.]

description: Andrew M. Luger, the United States attorney for Minnesota, said that six Minnesotans of Somali descent who were planning to join the Islamic State were arrested on Sunday.

title: Baltimore Suspends 6 Police Officers in Inquiry in Death of Freddie Gray
description: BALTIMORE  Six police officers have been suspended and officials said Monday that they were changing police procedures as they investigated the death of Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old black man who was rushed to the hospital with a severed spinal cord after being chased and tackled by officers.

title: Tulsa Sheriff Defends Volunteer Deputy in Shooting
description: An Oklahoma sheriff expressed condolences Monday to the family of an unarmed man who was shot and killed by a volunteer reserve deputy, but continued to defend the reserve program and his department generally.

title: Pollen-Deprived Bees Dont Make Good Dancers
description: Worker bees without access to adequate pollen early in life turn out to be poor foragers, and dancers, as adults.

description: HBO will produce six new episodes of the buzzy and popular web series High Maintenance.

title: How a Cracking Knuckle Makes a Noise
Marijuana and the Body
description: Q. Leaving aside questions of addiction and brain effects, what is known about the effects of marijuana on things like the lungs and digestive tract?

title: 1965: U.K. Scolds France on SEATO
description: LONDON  Britain publicly deplored today [April 20] Frances decision to slight the foreign ministers meeting here of the South East Asia Treaty Organization. This followed Pariss confirmation that it is planning to send only an observer to the meeting May 3 to 5. French officials said it was pointless to send Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville to be the lone dissenter against U.S. policy in Vietnam. French spokesmen, however, denied reports that this was just the first step toward complete withdrawal from SEATO.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 21, 1965

title: Financial Crisis Cases Sputter to an End
description: Yogi Berra once said that it aint over til its over. Unlike the final out or winning run in a baseball game, determining when cases arising from the 2008 financial crisis will end is a bit harder to discern. But the resolution of two cases last week clearly indicates that enforcement actions for conduct leading up to the crisis are pretty much done, with no real finding of liability for violations.

title: Bridal Trends
description: Here, a selection from the latest shows last week, sorted by the trends that promise to define the year ahead.

title: At Bridal Fashion Week,Sultry and Provocative
description: In the workrooms of bridal designers, who project their fairy-tale vision well into the future, its spring. Spring 2016, that is, a season adrift in acres of tulle, lingerie lace, crystalline beading and strategically placed panels of transparency intended to show off plenty of skin.

title: Digging Up the Root of Carbon Dating
description: The discovery of the principle behind carbon dating was reported in The New York Times two years before its remarkable implications were widely understood.

title: Petrofac of Britain Takes Another Write-Down on Gas Project
description: LONDON  Britain is not usually considered the wild frontier of the oil industry, but it is proving to be a tough environment for what had been a fast-growing engineering and construction company called Petrofac.

title: Burberry Invades Los Angeles for a Night
description: Naomi Campbell, Elton John, Anna Wintour and Cara Delevingne attend Burberrys London in Los Angeles show.

title: Burberry Invades Los Angeles for a Night
description: The British invaded Los Angeles on Thursday night, with Burberry taking over the Griffith Observatory for a runway show and cocktails. The 700 guests included celebrities and fashion insiders like the photographer Mario Testino. Here are more photos.

title: Pandora to Replace 2 Board Members With Music-Industry Figures
description: Pandora Media is replacing two board members, both longtime investors, with music-industry veterans, the company announced Monday.

title: Vampire Squid Outlast Their Shallower Peers
description: The mysterious vampire squid live in the deep sea at depths of about 3,000 feet. While squid in shallower waters reproduce only once, vampire squid reproduce throughout their life span, according to a new study in the journal Current Biology. After examining 40 specimens from the Santa Barbara Natural History Museum, the study authors noted that one fertile female appeared to have laid 3,800 eggs over her lifetime, but still retained 6,500 oocytes. The finding suggests vampire squid may live longer than shallow-water squid species.

title: Inside the Sunrise Tour at the Chinati Foundation
description: How Donald Judds untitled, 100-aluminum-box installation in Marfa, Texas looks in the early morning hours.

title: At Colette, an Art Exhibition and Beyonc-Approved Headpieces
description: I definitely didnt take a normal art path, says the Brooklyn-based multidisciplinary artist Amit Greenberg. Yes, his works have been displayed at institutions like the Whitney Museum of American Art and SFMOMA Artists Gallery but his debut solo show, This is a happy thought, featuring a character called BLU, fills the floors of the Paris shop Colette. Greenberg and a series of collaborators cooked up backpacks, T-shirts and tomato sauce; he asked Laura Wass of WXYZ Jewelry to customize the brands caps and headbands, made from metal tubes coated with car paint and hand-woven on rubberized elastic cording. The dream helmets, as Greenberg dubbed them, are meant to transform the viewer into a real-life BLU, and include a dose of Beyonc freshness  the musician wore an upside-down WXYZ visor as a crown in her 7/11 music video, released late last year.

title: Vivid Accounts of Wars Horror Stream From Yemens Capital
description: Residents of Yemens capital, Sana, shared vivid accounts of life during wartime on social networks on Monday, as a huge blast shattered windows and shook buildings miles from the site of an attack in the Faj Attan district of the city.

title: Cooking Techniques: Roasting Chestnuts
description: Roast chestnuts until fragrant and beginning to split.

title: Post-Disptachs Ferguson Coverage Wins Breaking News Photography Pulitzer
description: The St. Louis Post-Dispatchs coverage of the aftermath of the Michael Brow shooting earned the paper the Pulitzer Prize for Breaking News photography.

title: Batteries and Renewable Energy Set to Grow Together
description: POMONA, Calif.  The future of American energy, according to one widely held view, will include solar panels and wind turbines continuing to proliferate, churning out ever more electricity and eventually eclipsing fossil fuels to help offset the forces of climate change.

title: W.H.O. Promises Reform After Criticism Over Ebola Response
description: After criticism that it was slow and ineffective in the crucial early months of the Ebola crisis, the World Health Organization said Monday that it would overhaul the way it deals with epidemics.

title: Scenes from the Ebola Crisis Earn Photography Pulitzer
description: Daniel Berehulaks coverage for the New York Times of West Africas Ebola crisis has earned him the Pulitzer Prize for Feature Photography.

title: Morgan Stanley Takes Different Path to Rival Goldman
description: Morgan Stanleys divergence from Goldman Sachs strategy is starting to pay off. James P. Gormans firm had its best quarter in years in the three months to March. Its Wall Street arch rival still has the edge on earnings performance. By one important metric, however, investors value Morgan Stanley more highly.

title: Vaccine Phobia in California
description: California is in the midst of a dispute between parents who want to exempt their children from some or all of the vaccinations required for admission to public and private schools and a medical establishment that believes, with good reason, that vaccines can protect the students from the harm caused by infectious diseases and reduce the risk of transmitting the diseases from schools to the broader community.

title: Scenes From the Ebola Crisis Earn Photography Pulitzer
description: Daniel Berehulak was awarded the Pulitzer Prize for feature photography on Monday for his coverage of the Ebola outbreak in West Africa for The New York Times. The staff of the St Louis Post-Dispatch won the prize for Breaking News Photography for their coverage of the aftermath of the police shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Missouri.

title: Times Coverage of Ebola: Pulitzer-Winning Articles and More
description: The Times produced more than 400 articles, including about 50 front-page stories from inside the Ebola-afflicted countries themselves. Here is a sample of work.

title: 88,000 Applicants and Counting for 55 Units in Poor Door Building
description: A glassy new tower in New York City attracted an outcry for featuring one entrance for condominium owners and another for low-income tenants.

title: 2015 Pulitzer Winners:South Carolina Paper Wins Public Service Prize; New York Times Wins 3
description: The Post and Courier of Charleston, S.C., with a staff of about 80 and a daily circulation of 85,000, won the most prestigious of the Pulitzer Prizes for journalism awarded on Monday, for a series on the high number of deaths resulting from domestic abuse in the state.

description: The photography staff of The St. Louis Post-Dispatch won the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography on Monday for its coverage of the aftermath of the police shooting of an unarmed black teenager, Michael Brown, in Ferguson, Mo., last summer.

title: New York Times Coverage of Ukraine Conflict
description: Photographs of the Ukraine by Mauricio Lima, Sergey Ponomarev and Uriel Sinai were finalists for the breaking news category of the Pulitzer Prizes.

description: Photographs by Sergey Ponomarev, Tyler Hicks and Wissam Nassar of the Gaza conflict were finalists for this years breaking news category of the Pulitzer Prizes.

title: John Kasich of Ohio Takes Step Toward Presidential Run
description: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio unveiled New Day for America on Monday, a tax-exempt nonprofit committee that will allow him to raise money to travel the country as he explores a bid for the White House.

title: Finding Zero: A Long Journey for Naught
description: Most tourists who venture to the tiny town of Khajuraho in northern India are drawn there by the thousand-year-old Jain and Hindu temples, especially the scandalously explicit sex depicted in the statues adorning the walls.

description: There were about 17 times as many refugee deaths from January to April this year as there were during the same period last year.

description: Donald Judds 100 untitled works in mill aluminum, created from 1982-6, was filmed in stop-motion this weekend during a sunrise tour of the Chinati Foundation in Marfa.

description: Charles G. and David H. Koch, the influential and big-spending conservative donors, appear to have a favorite in the race for the Republican presidential nomination: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin.

title: Cuomo Stays Optimistic After Seeing the Challenges of Doing Business in Cuba
description: HAVANA  Those along for the ride on Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos whirlwind trade mission to Cuba got a quick lesson on the challenges of doing business here: They saw abject poverty and a poorly developed infrastructure  and even experienced spotty air-conditioning at a hotel as temperatures soared well above 90 degrees.

title: Leader of Militant Group in Russia Is Killed, Reports Say
description: MOSCOW  The leader of the Caucasus Emirate, the most active militant group in Russia, has been killed in a counterterrorism operation, the Russian authorities and Islamic militant websites reported Monday.

description: Advice to visit Seattles Pike Place Market may border on clich  but for a good reason.

description: A growing body of scientific clues  some ambiguous, others substantive  suggests that the Ebola virus may have lurked in the West African rain forest for years, perhaps decades, before igniting the deadly epidemic that swept the region in the past year, taking more than 10,000 lives.

title: Review: In I Understand Everything Better, Ruthless Elemental Forces
description: Hurricane Sandy is a marker for the choreographer David Neumann, whose life around that time underwent serious turbulence. His mother died the summer before the hurricane, his father a few weeks after the storm. (Both were esteemed actors in the experimental theater company Mabou Mines.) Somewhere along the way, Mr. Neumann turned to a quote from Albert Einstein: Look deep into nature and you will understand everything better.

title: Review: Ben Williams Steps Up on Coming of Age
description: BEN WILLIAMS

title: Silicon Valleys Water Conservation Conundrum
description: Menlo Park, Calif.  Silicon Valley has a richly deserved reputation as the worlds engine of technology innovation, with a track record that includes developing integrated circuits, microprocessors, personal computers and smartphones. This is a culture of confidence and bravado. Ask a bunch of tech leaders about their goals, and its a good bet that many of them will utter the words, To change the world.

title: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Greece, South Africa, Yemen and Iraq.

title: Dark Matters Deep Reach
description: Earlier this year, Dr. Sabine Hossenfelder, a theoretical physicist in Stockholm, made the jarring suggestion that dark matter might cause cancer. She was not talking about the dark matter of the genome (another term for junk DNA) but about the hypothetical, lightless particles that cosmologists believe pervade the universe and hold the galaxies together.

title: Our Ever Green World
description: By all evidence, Neros favorite color was green. The Roman emperor dressed in green, collected emeralds, cheered at the chariot races for the green stable team, and was particularly fond of eating green leeks.

description: Rabies kills 59,000 people a year, or about 160 a day  more than had previously been assumed  according to a study published last week.

description: If you have heard Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo speak and immediately thought operatic hero, then Jacob Ter Veldhuiss The News is the music drama for you.

title: On The Americans, Holly Taylor Plays a 15-Year-Old Whose Whole Life Is a Lie

description: IBM reported earnings on Monday that surpassed Wall Streets estimates, helped by solid sales of its new mainframe computers, even as its revenue fell.

description: Photos from Greece, South Africa, Yemen and Iraq.

title: TV Review: Inside Amy Schumer Season 3
description: Comedy Central recently released a teaser for the third season of Inside Amy Schumer: a music video parody sending up male obsession with a certain aspect of female anatomy, to the refrain, Milk, milk, lemonade, round the corner fudge is made. A few days later Inside Amy Schumer won a Peabody Award, televisions seal of middlebrow cultural respectability, alongside dramas like The Americans and The Honorable Woman. It was all the proof needed that no one has read the current cultural, intellectual and comedic moment better than Ms. Schumer.

title: Readers Respond: On Serving All Your Heroin Needs
description: Physicians, counselors, chronic pain patients and family members of people addicted to opiates shared personal stories about Americas growing opiate addiction problem in response to a Sunday Review article, Serving All Your Heroin Needs.

description: Position the pin, or enter an address below, to show us where your story takes place.

title: Walkabout: The Mystery of Kim Jong-uns Mountain Climb
description: Kim Jong-un, Explorer? Did the leader of North Korea actually climb the countrys highest peak, at more than 9,000 feet, in leather shoes and a medium-weight coat? (BuzzFeed)

title: Review: Marilyn Mayes Tribute to Frank Sinatra
description: It took a while for Her Way, Marilyn Mayes tribute to Frank Sinatra at 54 Below in New York on Friday evening, to achieve liftoff. But once it did, this 42-song anthology became a phenomenal demonstration of one womans stamina and musical intelligence.

title: Review: In Squence 8 Acrobats Defy Gravity and Constrictive Words
description: Among the abundant talents possessed by Les 7 Doigts de la Main  the philosophizing acrobats whose delightful new show Squence 8 runs through Sunday at City Center  is a gift for subverting metaphors. Many poetic comparisons will probably spring into your mind as you watch this sexy, witty Montreal-based team distort, upend and mock the laws of physics that keep us earthbound.

title: Letters to the Editor and Online Comments
description: Human Composting

title: Review: In Emily Climbs (Machine Mchant), a Botched Rebirth
description: Put down those probiotics, step away from the treadmill and leave that Lipitor prescription unfilled. You can stop worrying about extending your life via diet and nutrition, because in just a few decades, scientists will perfect the art of regeneration. Well, almost. The titular heroine of Emily Climbs (Machine Mchant), at the Brick, undergoes a rebirthing procedure in the year 2090. But she comes back in triplicate.

title: Heres Your Pulitzer. Bad News to Come.
description: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

title: Audiences Flying to Neverland and Paris
description: Finding Neverland, despite opening to a barrage of negative reviews, grossed more than $1 million on Broadway last week for the fifth week in a row, and on Monday producers announced a national tour to begin next year.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: In Performance | Kelli Barrett
description: Ms. Barrett, with Ron Melrose on piano, sings Hes There from the new Broadway musical Doctor Zhivago, an adaptation of Boris Pasternaks 1957 novel. The show is at the Broadway Theater.

title: Teachers Unions Fight Standardized Testing, and Find Diverse Allies
description: In Florida, the teachers union has lobbied to limit the use of standardized tests, and the governor last week signed a bill that limits the number of hours students can spend taking them.

title: Europes Migrant Crisis
description: Humanitarian experts predict the number of migrants who die crossing the Mediterranean Sea in 2015 could reach record levels.

title: Pulitzer Winner for Music Found Inspiration in Pennsylvania Coal Mines
description: The composer Julia Wolfes oratorio Anthracite Fields, which won the Pulitzer Prize for music on Monday, had its origins in curiosity about the road not taken.

title: Online Art Buying Rises in New Market Report
description: Sales of art online rose to $2.64 billion in 2014, from $1.57 billion the previous year, according to a report to be issued on Tuesday by the British insurance company Hiscox. Online art buying, the report found, accounted for 4.8 percent of the value of the global art market, which it estimated at $55.2 billion.

title: Bird Flu Spreads to a Farm in Iowa With 5.3 Million Chickens
description: WASHINGTON  The Agriculture Department announced Monday that an outbreak of avian flu had been confirmed in what could potentially be millions of chickens at an Iowa egg producer, the largest outbreak yet in an epidemic that has also hit turkey farmers in Minnesota.

title: Empty Nest? In Slovakia, It May Begin When the Child Is 35
description: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia  Jozef Izso, sitting on a small platform bed beside his desk while his mother busily puttered around in an adjoining room, said that there were definitely pluses and minuses to living with your parents when you are 29 years old.

title: 2015 Pulitzer Prize Winners in Journalism, Letters, Drama and Music
description: The prizes, which are administered at Columbia University, were announced on Monday.

title: Marathon Winners Jubilation in Boston
description: Lelisa Desisa and Caroline Rotich won the 2015 Boston Marathon, two years after bombs were detonated at the event.

title: Justices Hear Second Round of Arguments on Case Hinging on Phrases Meaning
description: WASHINGTON  For the fifth time since 2007, the Supreme Court on Monday struggled to make sense of a phrase in a federal law that requires longer sentences for some gun crimes based on earlier convictions.

title: H.I.V. Cases Lead Indiana to Extend Needle Exchanges
description: WASHINGTON  Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana extended a needle exchange program for another 30 days on Monday as the number of H.I.V. cases linked to intravenous drug use in a rural county continued to grow, with new cases being reported almost daily.

title: Zulu King Tries to Calm Anti-Foreigner Violence in South Africa
description: The influential king of the Zulus, South Africas largest ethnic group, sought to distance himself on Monday from anti-foreigner comments he made three weeks ago, which the authorities there have called the catalyst for a wave of deadly xenophobic violence.

title: Anxiety in Missoula Over Book About Campus Assaults
description: MISSOULA, Mont.  This town is bracing for a book. The local prosecutor wrote an urgent letter to its publishers trying to delay its release. Book sellers are taking orders for copies that wait in sealed boxes, ready to be opened on Tuesday. Some people are dreading its revelations about rape in their football-loving college town. Others are glad: Tell the story, they say, the louder the better.

title: A Ballet Dancer, Offstage, With a Camera
description: Daniil Simkin, a principal dancer at American Ballet Theater, captures candid moments offstage, revealing the hard work behind the natural, masterly ease shown onstage.

title: A Mets Newcomer Is Thrown Into the Fire
description: The first time John Flaherty crouched behind the plate in a major league game, the home plate umpire, Rich Garcia, asked how he was feeling.

title: Dr. Oz to Respond on Show to Criticism by Physicians
description: The celebrity talk show host Dr. Mehmet Oz plans to respond aggressively on Thursday to doctors who have criticized his medical advice and questioned his faculty position at Columbia University, a spokesman for the show said on Monday.

title: Clinton Calls Republican Criticism Just Partisan Distraction
description: KEENE, N.H.  Questions about her personal use of email at the State Department? Controversy about foreign donors to the Clinton Foundation? Accusations that her campaign events are overly staged?

title: Google Adds Mobile Friendliness to Its Search Criteria
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Many businesses around the world could wake up on Tuesday to discover their search ranking has been downgraded. After a monthslong warning period, Google will add mobile friendliness to the 200 or so factors it uses to list websites on its search engine.

title: Bill Would Give F.D.A. More Muscle on Cosmetics
description: For decades, the Food and Drug Administration has had fewer than a dozen pages of instructions for how to regulate the millions of lipsticks, moisturizers and other cosmetics sold each year.

title: Judge Denies Transgender Inmates Request for Transfer
description: MACON, Ga.  Ashley Diamond, the Georgia inmate whose lawsuit is making her a protagonist in transgender rights history, said in her first federal court appearance on Monday that she had come to blame herself for being a victim of multiple prison rapes, internalizing the guilt placed on her by corrections officials.

title: Federal Prosecutor Drops Kirchner Conspiracy Case
description: BUENOS AIRES  A criminal case against President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner seemed to dissolve Monday when a federal prosecutor dropped accusations that she and her foreign minister had conspired to shield Iranians suspected of planning the 1994 bombing of a Jewish community center here.

title: Uber Adds a Low-Tech Twist to Its Modern Business Model in India
description: NEW DELHI  Auto rickshaws are the mangy donkeys of Delhi transport, glorified golf carts that are a cheaper open-air alternative to taxis, and whose drivers enthusiastically embrace Delhis perpetual, honking traffic chaos.

title: Teva to Pay $512 Million to Settle Suit Over Delay of Sleep Disorder Drug
description: The drug maker Teva Pharmaceutical Industries said on Monday that it had agreed to pay $512 million to settle claims that a subsidiary, Cephalon, paid generic manufacturers to keep their own cheaper versions of a drug off the market, a practice that the Supreme Court ruled in 2013 could be illegal in some cases.

title: New York Subway Use Rose in 2014, Especially in Growing Neighborhoods
description: The number of people riding New York Citys subway system continued to rise last year, with some of the biggest jumps in ridership occurring in Brooklyn and Queens.

title: Warning Iran, U.S. Sends Two More Ships to Yemen
description: WASHINGTON  The aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt and a guided missile cruiser were headed to the waters off Yemen on Monday to join 10 other American warships as a warning to Iran about its shipments of weapons to rebels there, American officials said.

title: Ruling Clears Way for Jury Verdict on Former Goldman Sachs Programmer
description: The criminal case against Sergey Aleynikov  the former Goldman Sachs programmer who was convicted in federal court, then acquitted, only to be charged again in state court  will soon head to a jury after Mr. Aleynikovs last-ditch effort to toss out the case came up short.

title: A Grizzlies Fan Finds Fame as the Bongo Lady
description: MEMPHIS  The fans who pack FedEx Forum for Grizzlies games never know when it will happen. It could be a timeout late in the second quarter, or a break in the action early in the fourth. It does not even occur every game.

title: A Veteran of the Financial Crisis Tells China to Be Wary
description: About 340 pages into Henry M. Paulsons new book on China, a sentence comes almost out of nowhere that stops readers in their tracks.

title: California Court Rules Water Pricing Plan Violates Law
description: LOS ANGELES  A California appeals court dealt a setback Monday to one of the main tools drought regulators want to use to force reductions in urban water use, saying a tiered pricing plan in the Orange County city of San Juan Capistrano that charged higher rates for big water consumers violated a voter-passed amendment to the State Constitution.

title: Washington, Though Still Divided, Comes Together on Trade and Other Issues
description: WASHINGTON  Partisan peevishness is alive and well on Capitol Hill. But increasingly, Congress, under Republican control, is pressing forward on broad aspects of President Obamas end-of-term agenda.

title: Timing and Publicity Are Right as Pete Rose Looks to Shake Stigma
description: Since Fox Sports announced its hiring of Pete Rose as a studio analyst on Saturday, Ive wondered, What took so long?

title: N.J. Transit Proposes Fare Increase and Service Cuts
description: Fares for most riders would increase about 9 percent under a New Jersey Transit proposal announced on Monday in an effort to close a large budget gap at the agency.

title: Joseph Phelps Dies at 87; Brought Innovation to California Wines
description: Joseph Phelps, a former builder whose passion for wine led him to become an innovative Napa Valley producer and the first to bottle an expensive Bordeaux blend with a fanciful proprietary name, died on April 15 at his home in St. Helena, Calif. He was 87.

title: Elio Toaff, Spiritual Leader of Italian Jews, Dies at 99
description: Elio Toaff, the chief rabbi of Rome for half a century, who as a leader of Italian Jewry during its revival after World War II helped forge more amicable relations between Jews and the Vatican, died on Sunday in Rome. He was 99.

title: On One Point Voters Agree: Barcelona Election Has Intrigue
description: BARCELONA, Spain  It is election season in Catalonia, and the most anticipated race will have all of the expected ingredients: charges of corruption, fringe challengers, improbable campaign promises and blatant pandering to voters (free haircuts, anyone?).

title: Review: Rene Fleming Plays Against Type in Living on Love
description: Making her Broadway debut in Living on Love, the lumpy little comedy that opened on Monday night at the Longacre Theater, Rene Fleming seems like far too nice a woman to be playing a diva. That sounds irrational, I know, since Ms. Fleming, the great soprano, is one of the most celebrated opera stars in the world.

title: Well Have Manhattan
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE   So smart. Super sophisticated. We have an alliterative theme in this Tuesday puzzle, created by Gerry Wildenberg, and it includes several stumpers. So lets start slowly.

title: Israel: Leaders Decline to Meet Carter
description: Israels president and prime minister have declined requests for meetings with former President Jimmy Carter, who has long been a harsh critic of Israels policy toward the Palestinians. Mr. Carter has been persona non grata in Israel at least since his 2006 book, Palestine: Peace Not Apartheid, and he prompted further ire during last summers war between Israel and Hamas, the militant Palestinian group that dominates the Gaza Strip. Mr. Carter, 90, called for an international investigation into Israels prosecution of the war and renewed his plea to remove Hamas from Washingtons list of terrorist groups. Jason Pearlman, a spokesman for President Reuven Rivlin of Israel, said Mr. Rivlin had declined Mr. Carters request to meet based on the Foreign Ministrys counsel. When Mr. Carter visited Jerusalem in 2012 with a group of former leaders called The Elders, he met with Shimon Peres, then president, but said he had been denied meetings with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his cabinet.

title: New York Investigates Whether Boy Scouts Employment Practices Discriminated Against Gays
description: The New York State attorney generals office has opened an inquiry into the Boy Scouts of Americas hiring practices to determine whether the group has discriminated as an employer against gays.

title: Daily Breeze Celebrates Its Surprise Pulitzer
description: Rebecca Kimitch was on her couch, poring over a new story, when word of the Pulitzer Prize arrived.

title: South Korean Premier Offers His Resignation
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Prime Minister Lee Wan-koo of South Korea said Tuesday that he had offered to resign over a snowballing bribery scandal, dealing a blow to President Park Geun-hye, whose government has already been rocked by a ferry disaster.

title: Rangers Stifle Penguins for 40 Minutes, Then Withstand a Flurry
description: PITTSBURGH  The Rangers put an eye-opening 20-minute hiccup from Saturday behind them and regained their defensive consciousness Monday.

title: C. C. Sabathia Flashes Old Form for Yankees; Result Evokes More Recent Past
description: DETROIT  As C. C. Sabathia stood on the mound, the wind whipping his oversize uniform as if it were a Christo installation, he nevertheless displayed the unflappable countenance of his earlier years as a Yankee, before his knee began to disintegrate and his fastball began to desert him.

title: Amiable but Intense Defenseman Adds Punch to Islanders
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Lubomir Visnovsky, a quietly intense defenseman, played a vital role in the Islanders overtime victory on Sunday over the Washington Capitals.

title: Giants Eli Manning Says Contract Will Not Be His Focus
description: Eli Manning said Monday that he was comfortable playing the 2015 season in the final year of his current Giants contract.

title: New Genetic Tests for Breast Cancer Hold Promise
description: A Silicon Valley start-up with some big-name backers is threatening to upend genetic screening for breast and ovarian cancer by offering a test on a sample of saliva that is so inexpensive that most women could get it.

title: Word of the Day | disengage
description: disengage  \dis-n-gaj\  verb

title: Shinzo Abe, Japanese Premier, Sends Gift to Contentious Yasukuni Shrine
description: TOKYO  Prime Minister Shinzo Abe sent a ritual gift to a Tokyo war shrine on Tuesday, a gesture that could anger Japans neighbors ahead of a visit by Mr. Abe to Washington that will put his views of history under intense scrutiny.

title: Whats on TV Tuesday
description: 8:30 P.M. (TCM) MARRIAGE ITALIAN STYLE (1964) Sophia Loren, the subject of this Turner Classic Movies tribute, stars as an ex-prostitute who tricks her longtime lover (Marcello Mastroianni) into marrying her instead of a younger woman by claiming to be dying. But soon enough it becomes evident that she isnt. Whenever the director Vittorio De Sica joins forces with Ms. Loren, something wonderful happens, Bosley Crowther wrote in The New York Times about this flamboyant Oscar nominee for best foreign-language film. The something wonderful thats happened is the conception and projection of a film so frank and free and understanding of a certain kind of vital woman  and man, too  that it sends you forth from the theater feeling youve known her  and him  all your life. A short film directed by Ms. Lorens son Edoardo Ponti, Human Voice (2014), based on the Jean Cocteau play about a womans final telephone conversation with her lover, leads in at 8 p.m.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Its very comfortable here, especially now that my sister has moved out. But they do treat you like a child.

title: Editors Note: April 21, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Block by Block | Carroll Gardens
description: Verdant streetscapes and Italian-American flavor come together in the Brooklyn neighborhood of Carroll Gardens.

title: Block by Block: Carroll Gardens (Video Series)
description: Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, is the focus of the next video in our new monthly series, Block by Block. Watch for future installments from neighborhoods around the city.

title: Acquittal of U.S. Nuns
description: To the Editor:

title: Congresss Voice on Iran
description: To the Editor:

title: A Saudi Link to 9/11?
description: To the Editor:

title: Art Made in Internment
description: To the Editor:

title: Rand Paul, Lukewarm Libertarian
description: LOS ANGELES  LIBERTARIANS, to the extent we can ever hope for real political success, should be excited about Rand Paul. But Mr. Paul, the Kentucky senator who is running for president, has treated his libertarian inheritance as more burden than boon. Hes even called libertarianism an albatross, though a growing, and young, share of the Republican Party is rallying around libertarian ideals.

title: The Talented Mr. Rubio
description: Political audiences always like patriotic rhetoric, but as several reporters have noticed, this years Republican audiences have a special hunger for it. The phrase American exceptionalism has become a rallying cry. There is a common feeling on the right that the American idea is losing force and focus, that the American dream is slipping out of reach, that America is stepping back from its traditional role in the world and that President Obama doesnt forthrightly champion the American gospel.

title: Prosecutors Misconduct
description: To the Editor:

title: Lessons From #RaceTogether
description: Howard Schultz has a way of making a believer out of you.

title: Fix the Flaws in Forensic Science
description: THE F.B.I. stunned the legal community on Monday with its acknowledgment that testimony by its forensic scientists about hair identification was scientifically indefensible in nearly every one of more than 250 cases reviewed. But the conclusion should come as no surprise to scientists. It is the culmination of a collision between law and science that began in 1989 in a Bronx courtroom with the murder trial of a janitor.

title: In Trade Talks, Secrecy or Openness?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Violent Legacy of Chicagos Police
description: Rahm Emanuel inherited a Police Department with a history of serious misconduct when he became mayor of Chicago four years ago. Mr. Emanuel tried to break with the past on Wednesday when he co-sponsored a proposal in City Council that would provide reparations to scores of people who were systematically tortured by the police during the 1970s and 80s under the infamous police commander Jon Burge.

title: Credit Suisse Profit Rises 23 Percent in First Quarter
description: LONDON  Credit Suisse said on Tuesday that its profit rose 23 percent in the first quarter as the bank benefited from an uptick in market activity and measures it took to offset a sharp rise in the value of the Swiss franc.

title: Blue Bell Recalls All Products After Listeria Outbreak
description: Blue Bell Creameries, which distributes frozen desserts to about half of the United States, said that it was voluntarily recalling all of its products after the bacteria listeria was found in two cartons of ice cream last month.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Europe Considers Response as Hundreds of Migrants Die in Mediterranean Sinkings
description: In Europe Considers Response as Hundreds of Migrants Die in Mediterranean Sinkings, Jim Yardley reports on a full-blown humanitarian crisis in the Mediterranean Sea.

title: Migrant Boat Captain Steered Toward Tragedy in Mediterranean, Authorities Say
description: MINEO, Sicily  When the Italian Coast Guard first got a call Saturday night from a fishing boat alerting it to a large vessel carrying migrants in the Mediterranean between the Libyan coast and the Italian island of Lampedusa, it radioed the nearest commercial ship, a Portuguese freighter called the King Jacob, to go help.

title: What a Difference a Decade Makes: Xinjiang Film Emerges From the Past
description: One camera, one two-man crew, 16 poems, about 16 prostitutes and roughly 40 days in Xinjiang were all it took to make the road movie Poet on a Business Trip. That, and about 12 years of leaving the footage on a shelf, an incubation period that transformed the film into an inadvertent documentary of a seemingly more tranquil time in the ethnically divided region in western China.

title: An Eye for an Eye
description: After Ameneh Bahrami was blinded and disfigured by a scorned suitor who poured acid on her face, she fought for her right to punish her attacker in kind.

title: What Is Your Favorite Street?
description: Some of us love the glitz of a fancy shopping thoroughfare, like Fifth Avenue or Rodeo Drive, while others prefer leafy residential streets with stately homes. Or maybe you like quirky neighborhoods with hip cafes and cool restaurants.

title: A Ballet Dancer, Offstage, With a Camera
description: Who is to stop Daniil Simkin, a principal dancer at American Ballet Theater, from photographing his friends inside the bubble of one of the worlds leading classical ballet companies?

title: Steven A. Ballmer Speaks Loudly and Carries a Big Wallet
description: LOS ANGELES  Speaking last month to a few hundred M.B.A. students at the University of Southern California, Steven A. Ballmer, the owner of the Los Angeles Clippers, broke into verse. He recited a snippet of a song from the Broadway musical Pippin: Rivers belong where they can ramble. Eagles belong where they can fly. Ive got to be where my spirit can run free. Got to find my corner of the sky.

title: An Eye for an Eye
description: Ameneh Bahrami, whom Thomas Erdbrink first wrote about in 2008 when she won the right to exact revenge on a spurned suitor who doused her with a bucket of sulfuric acid, answered readers questions.

title: At Supreme Court, Eric Holders Justice Dept. Routinely Backs Officers Use of Force
description: WASHINGTON  Teresa Sheehan was alone in her apartment at a mental health center, clutching what her lawyers said was a small bread knife and demanding to be left alone. San Francisco police officers, responding to a call from a social worker, forced open the door, blinded her with pepper spray and shot her.

title: Penalty Phase Opens With Image of Boston Marathon Bomber Making Obscene Gesture
description: BOSTON  Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the man at the center of the Boston Marathon bombing trial, has been something of a mystery in the two years since his incarceration and throughout his trial. He has made no statements, and as he has sat in court, he has seemed disengaged, his blank expression revealing nothing.

title: Negotiated at The Hague, a Child Support Treaty Falters in Boise
description: POST FALLS, Idaho  It took five years for negotiators to work out the details of a multinational treaty on child support that would make it easier to track delinquent parents around the world. It took only a couple of minutes for a committee of the Idaho Legislature to endanger Americas participation.

title: Campaign Casts Hillary Clinton as the Populist It Insists She Has Always Been
description: CLAREMONT, N.H.  In her first week as a 2016 presidential candidate, Hillary Rodham Clinton seemed to channel another high-profile Democrat. The deck is stacked in their favor, Mrs. Clinton said of the wealthy and powerful. My job is to reshuffle the cards.

title: Targets Hasty Exit From Canada Leaves Anger Behind
description: TORONTO  Targets exodus from Canada has left gaping holes at some of the most prominent shopping centers across the country, the biggest symbol of an exceptional period of retailing turmoil.

title: Former SS Member, on Trial in Germany, Says He Was Morally Complicit at Auschwitz
description: LNEBURG, Germany  Seven decades after the liberation of Auschwitz, a 93-year-old former SS member at the Nazi death camp shuffled into a German court on Tuesday to answer charges of complicity in the murders of 300,000 mostly Hungarian Jews in two months during the summer of 1944.

title: Test Yourself | A Dogs Gaze
description: Here are several paragraphs from an April 16 article, The Look of Love Is in the Dogs Eyes.

title: The Light of the World, by Elizabeth Alexander
description: In the spring of 2012, four days after his 50th-birthday party, Ficre Ghebreyesus had a heart attack while exercising on a treadmill in the home he shared with his wife, the distinguished poet Elizabeth Alexander. He was probably dead before he hit the ground, but when Alexander and her sons found his warm body, she felt sure his soul was still in it. Its not easy to die, Ficre used to say to her. But in Ficres case it seemed improbably easy. One minute he was full of life, gathering provisions for Easter dinner, buying lottery tickets, sending his wife to a kabbalah poetry reading. (You are an artist, and you need it  I will take the children to the orthodontist!) The next, he was lying on the ground, a small pool of yellowish fluid (plasma?) beside his head.

title: Infamy and The Train to Crystal City
description: In the days after the Japanese sneak attack on Pearl Harbor in December 1941, America was roiled with fears about spies and saboteurs. The anxiety was greatest on the West Coast, but it quickly spread across the country. The editorial cartoonist of PM, New York Citys most liberal newspaper, drew a cartoon showing multitudes of bucktoothed, squinteyed Japanese lined up across the entire West Coast to be given packs of dynamite at a stand called Honorable Fifth Column, Richard Reeves says in Infamy. The caption was Waiting for the signal from home. The artists name was Theodor Seuss Geisel, later to become famous writing childrens books under the name Dr. Seuss.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: A Lesson From Sally Mann: Just Take the Picture
description: My assignment, from The Times Magazine, was to show what life is like on Sally Manns farm. My decision to drive to Virginia was somewhat strategic; the seven hours on the road would allow more time for planning and visualizing shots than would a 90-minute plane ride. The short video vignettes would run online, alongside an excerpt from her soon-to-be-published memoir.

title: New York Today: Finding Cuba in New York
description: Good morning on this clammy Tuesday.

title: The Stability Two-Step
description: Yes, Im wide awake at a ridiculous hour thanks to jet lag. Why do you ask?

title: Editorial Contest Winner | Have We Lost Our Cents?
description: We are honoring each of the Top 10 winners of our Second Annual Student Editorial Contest by publishing an essay a day, in the order of submission.

title: Daily Report: IBM Profit Slips as Company Enters Transition Year
description: IBM reported earnings that surpassed Wall Street estimates, helped by solid sales of its new mainframe computers, even as its revenue fell, writes Steve Lohr.

title: India Says It Seized Heroin Believed to Be Worth Nearly $100 Million From Boat
description: NEW DELHI  India said on Tuesday that it had intercepted a Pakistani boat in waters off its west coast with what appeared to be nearly $100 million worth of heroin aboard.

title: 7 Thoughts From a Chronically Unhappy Person
Today in Politics: Hillary Clinton Will Always Have New Hampshire
description: Good Tuesday morning from Washington, where a Supreme Court justice is urging his colleagues to seek wisdom from abroad and Republicans with an eye on the White House are juggling the campaign trail with the fund-raising circuit. Social Security is resurfacing as a hot topic for conservatives, and Hillary Rodham Clinton is waxing nostalgic about the good old days in New Hampshire  and hoping for more good ones ahead.

title: Mediterranean Graveyard
description: Europe searches for a response as the refugee toll soars.

title: Lawyers Group Seeks Overhaul of a Postal Service Surveillance Program
description: WASHINGTON  A Postal Service surveillance program that records the information on the outside of letters and packages delivered to people suspected of criminal activity should be overhauled because of a lack of oversight, according to a report by a national defense lawyers group.

title: Freddie Freeman Is Another Mets Tormentor, on a Far Different Braves Team
description: Even late in his career, whenever Chipper Jones came to bat and Mets fans chanted Lar-ry! Lar-ry!  his given name  he got a look in his eyes. The newspapers still called him a Met Killer, a name he had earned from years of clutch hits at Shea Stadium. Jones even named his son Shea, then denied that he had done so just to rile the Mets.

title: For Travelers to Russia, its Deals and More Deals
description: Be careful.

title: Seeking the Elusive Fee-Free Exchange Rate
description: Traveling on a budget can mean counting every penny, but thats a lot harder to do if you are converting from centimes or centavos. Most of us do a lot of rounding: that yak wool blanket for 100,000 Mongolian tugrik, at 1,924 tugrik to the dollar? Divide by 2,000  its about $50.

title: Beyond the Boundary Principle
description: It was a murky winter morning; I could tell that much from my hospital window. I carefully shifted my neck, trying to keep my head straight so that my newly bald scalp wouldnt burn as it brushed against the pillowcase. A small sea rock rested in my right palm.

title: Morning Agenda: Financial Crisis Veteran Cautions China
description: FINANCIAL CRISIS VETERAN CAUTIONS CHINA | In a new book, Henry M. Paulson, the Treasury secretary and chief firefighter during the 2008 financial crisis, warns that Chinas financial system will undoubtedly have to face a reckoning and have to contend with a wave of credit losses and debt restructurings. It is a remarkably cautionary message from the former chief executive of Goldman Sachs, writes Andrew Ross Sorkin in the DealBook column, given Mr. Paulsons deep and long-established ties with the senior leadership of China.

title: Pulitzer for International Reporting
description: The New York Timess coverage of the Ebola epidemic in Africa won the Pulitzer Prize.

title: Eric Lipton Accepts Pulitzer
description: Eric Lipton accepts the Pulitzer Prize for investigative journalism.

title: Daniel Berehulak Accepts Pulitzer Prize
description: Daniel Berehulak accepts the Pulitzer Prize for feature photography on the Ebola epidemic in West Africa.

title: Jon Stewart Announces August Date for Final Show
description: After more than 16 years at the helm of The Daily Show, Jon Stewart said that his final episode as host of the Comedy Central news satire would be on Aug. 6.

title: Adderall in the Office
Hundreds of Chinese Cities Dont Meet Air Standards, Report Finds
description: BEIJING  Air pollution data from the Chinese government shows that more than 90 percent of 360 Chinese cities failed to meet national air quality standards in the first three months of this year, according to a report released on Tuesday by Greenpeace East Asia.

title: Hillary Clinton to Hold Five Fund-Raisers at End of April
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton will hold five fund-raisers in two days this month, low-key events in private homes hosted by a number of longtime supporters of hers  and one prominent 2008 backer of Barack Obama.

title: In Performance: Kelli Barrett of Doctor Zhivago
description: This weeks video features the actress Kelli Barrett singing the number Hes There from the new Broadway musical Doctor Zhivago, a stage adaptation of Boris Pasternaks 1957 novel about lovers in Russia during World War I. Ms. Barrett stars as Lara, the paramour of the shows title character, played by Tam Mutu. Doctor Zhivago, directed by Des McAnuff, opens tonight at the Broadway Theater.

title: An Unprecedented Tsunami of Hyperbole
description: We all want our stories to be engaging, even exciting. Deep reporting, clear writing and sharp detail are the best tools. But sometimes we cant resist the impulse to pump up the prose with hyperbolic language.

title: Robert Finn, Missouri Bishop Convicted of Shielding Pedophile Priest, Resigns
description: Pope Francis accepted the resignation on Tuesday of Bishop Robert W. Finn as head of the Diocese of Kansas City-St. Joseph in Missouri, heeding pleas from parishioners and priests that the bishop had lost the credibility to lead after being convicted three years ago of failing to report a priest who took pornographic pictures of girls.

title: Weekly News Quiz | April 14-20, 2015
description: Have you been following the news?

title: Information-Hungry Millennial Parents, Making It Hard on Themselves
description: My mother gave me a gift when my first baby was born. When my newborn daughter was released from the hospital, my husband and I brought her home to my parents house, where (in true Millennial form) we were living at the time. Walking back into the house after a hellish, messy labor was a balm  the kitchen was immaculate and lemon-scented, and there was chicken salad in the refrigerator.

title: Even Locals Get Confused
description: Dear Diary:

title: As Cash Dwindles, Greece Negotiates With Gazprom on Energy Cooperation
description: ATHENS  With their country running desperately low on cash, Greek officials met on Tuesday with the head of the Russian energy giant Gazprom, spurring speculation about a possible multibillion-dollar pipeline deal between Athens and Moscow.

title: How a Color Becomes a Trend: Introducing Minion Yellow
description: This week, for the first time in three years, Pantone, the company whose shades are ground zero for pretty much all home, apparel or design work (in case you were wondering why you cared), has released a new color into the world: Minion Yellow.

title: Study Tracks Accelerated Pace and Growing Pains of Chinas Urbanization
description: China is in the midst of a sweeping government-led effort to transform the country from a once-predominantly rural economy to a land of modern city dwellers, with a goal of integrating 70 percent of the population, or about 900 million people, into urban areas within the coming decade.

title: A Danger on Rails
description: In recent years, small towns across the United States have begun hosting an increasingly common phenomenon: long trains, made up of 100-plus black cylindrical cars, rolling slowly past our hospitals, schools and homes.

title: A Danger on the Rails
description: This short documentary warns about the dangers posed by trains that transport explosive oil across North America.

title: What Do You Read While You Write?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Zo Heller and Anna Holmes discuss their reading habits when theyre working.

title: An Unexpected, and Surprisingly Useful, Gift for Grads
description: This spring, opt out of buying yet another copy of Oh, The Places Youll Go for the recently minted college grad in your life  shes sure to receive at least three. Instead, give the new book from Jessica C. White and Kseniya Thomas, the founders of the international trade organization Ladies of Letterpress (its design community comprises some 2,000 members, and despite the moniker, boys are allowed). You may get a befuddled Thanks? in response, until you explain that the oversize book contains 86 detachable poster pages, with plenty of prints ideal for decorating the walls of those brand-new, grown-up starterapartments.

title: Egyptian Court Sentences Mohamed Morsi to 20 Years in Prison
