description: CAIRO  Mohamed Morsi, the deposed president of Egypt, was sentenced to 20 years in prison by an Egyptian court on Tuesday, in the first verdict handed down in any of the four significant criminal cases brought against him since the military ousted him in 2013.

title: Teva, Maker of Generic Drugs, Bids $40 Billion to Acquire Its Rival Mylan
description: Eat or be eaten. That is the philosophy among drug makers that is underpinning a frenzied burst of consolidation and rapidly reshaping the global pharmaceutical industry.

title: Shyp, an On-Demand Mailing Service, Raises $50 Million
description: From private rides to hamburgers to marijuana, there is perhaps no better time in history to get anything delivered with little more than a tap of a smartphone button.

title: Chinese State-Owned Company, in a First, Defaults on Its Domestic Bonds
description: HONG KONG  For decades, regardless of weaknesses or inefficiencies, an overriding certainty of state-backed capitalism in China has been that the government looks after its own.

title: Eritrea and North Korea Are Worlds Most Censored Countries, Advocacy Group Says
description: The impoverished African nation of Eritrea has the lowest rate of cellphone ownership in the world, less than 1 percent of its people can go online, and its journalists are so terrified of offending the president that even reporters for the state-run news media live in perpetual fear of arrest.

title: Slovakia Seeks to Raise Up to $1.1 Billion in Slovak Telecom I.P.O.
description: The government of Slovakia is seeking to raise as much as $1.1 billion in an initial public offering of its 49 percent stake in Slovak Telekom, the company said Tuesday.

title: 1915: German Base Bombed
description: Further excellent work by French and Belgian aviators was reported yesterday [April 21] by the French Press Bureau. A communiqu issued last night says: Our aeroplanes have bombarded the headquarters of General von Strantz and German convoys in the Voivre, and a power station at Lorrach in the Grand Duchy of Baden. An earlier official announcement says: Belgian aviators have bombarded the arsenal at Bruges and the Lissevegh aviation ground. News received in Amsterdam from a German source confirms that Lorrach was bombarded by French aviators on Tuesday morning.  The New York Herald, European Edition, April 22, 1915

title: Readers Turn: How to Help Black Men
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: Senate Reaches Deal on Sex Trafficking Bill
description: Senator Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican and majority leader, announced Tuesday that a deal had been reached to resolve a dispute with Democrats over a bill to halt sex trafficking.

title: Blue Bell C.E.O. Apologizes for Recall
description: In a video message on Monday, Paul Kruse, Blue Bells chief executive and president, apologized for recalling products on the market after two samples of ice cream tested positive for listeria.

title: N.F.L. Draft Watchers Favor Jameis Winston Over Marcus Mariota
description: At the N.F.L. draft each year, a parade of tackles, safeties and linebackers streams to the podium to try on hats with logos and hold up jerseys. But for all the pundits talk about how teams desperately need a center or a cornerback, the choices that create the most excitement will always be the quarterbacks. And this year there are two big names.

title: Australian Director Barrie Kosky Carries on Innovative Operatic Tradition in Berlin
description: BERLIN  In this city of three major opera houses, a feted star of recent seasons has been off stage: Barrie Kosky, a self-described gay Jewish kangaroo from Australia who has staged everything from Rameau and Mozart to forgotten 1930s operettas and West Side Story.

title: Russian Premier Says Annexation of Crimea Was Worth Sanctions Fallout
description: MOSCOW  Prime Minister Dmitri A. Medvedev said on Tuesday that sanctions imposed on Russia over its annexation of the Crimean Peninsula had done meaningful harm to the economy, but that it was a price worth paying.

title: Twitter Broadens Ban on Violent Threats
description: When it comes to violent posts on its social network, Twitter has long held that it would only seek to ban direct, specific threats made against others on its microblogging service. Now, the company has decided that simply promoting violence against others is enough to get a user suspended.

title: Jeb Bush, Not Yet a Candidate, Leads Fund-Raiser Rankings
description: Allies of Jeb Bush have joked that if he runs for president, he will use a strategy of shock and awe to overwhelm his Republican rivals, and when it comes to making his way around the fund-raising circuit, he is proving them right.

title: A New Way to Look at Endive
description: Americans view endive differently than the French do: We associate it with salads, mostly served as a first course. But the French cook it all the time. They cut endive heads in half and sear them just enough to brown beautifully on the cut side, and serve them hot from the pan. The endive remains crisp, but the quick sear also renders it sort of juicy.

title: Senate, Clearing Hurdle, Sets a Thursday Vote on Loretta Lynch
description: WASHINGTON  After weeks of difficult negotiations, the Senate on Tuesday reached an agreement to clear the way for the long-delayed confirmation of Loretta E. Lynch to replace Eric H. Holder Jr. as the attorney general.

title: Defending the Family Routine
description: I remember my childhood as a time of routine, with days chugging along in much the same form for entire school years at a time. Is that just how I remember it, or how it really was? I dont know, but what I do know is that I struggle to find a similar routine for my own family. It seems like its all sudden changes and just-this-once meetings and rescheduled car pool pickups.

title: Daily Report: New Genetic Tests for Breast Cancer Hold Promise
description: A Silicon Valley start-up with some big-name backers is threatening to upend genetic screening for breast and ovarian cancer by offering a test on a sample of saliva that is so inexpensive that most women could get it, Andrew Pollack writes.

title: Charlie Parker to Return to the Apollo Theater in Gotham Chamber Opera Season
description: The real Charlie Parker played the Apollo Theater. And next year the tenor Lawrence Brownlee will portray Charlie Parker there when a new opera exploring his life and work is given its New York premiere at the Apollo as part of Gotham Chamber Operas 15th-anniversary season.

title: Jurassic World Trailer Offers a Closer Look at a Killer Dinosaur
description: They gotta eat, they gotta hunt, you gotta watch. On Monday, Universal Pictures released its most robust trailer for the newest addition to the Jurassic Park franchise, with a more detailed look at the many dinos in action (raptors in training, raptors on the run), along with a good deal more menace. In its earlier trailer, released in November, the studio gave only a hint of the potential havoc a new genetically modified dinosaur might wreak on the park.

title: Unpaid Russian Workers Unite in Protest Against Putin
description: MOSCOW  In the far east, the teachers went on strike. In central Russia, it was the employees of a metallurgical plant. In St. Petersburg, autoworkers laid down their tools. And at a remote construction site in Siberia, laborers painted their complaints in gigantic white letters on the roofs of their dormitories.

title: The Next Era of Campaign-Finance Craziness Is Already Underway
description: There may be no political adviser closer to Rand Paul than Jesse Benton. Benton was integral to Pauls Senate run in 2010 and was a top strategist for both of Ron Pauls Republican presidential campaigns. When a fellow Kentuckian, Senator Mitch McConnell, needed help with his re-election campaign last year, Rand Paul lent him Benton. Benton also happens to be married to Pauls niece. So it would have been natural to expect Benton to move into Pauls campaign headquarters as soon as he declared his candidacy for president.

title: New York Public Libraries Warn of a Staggering Crisis With Infrastructure
description: The Hunts Point Library in the South Bronx uses only two of the three floors in its Italian Renaissance building, which was built in 1929 with money from the industrialist and philanthropist Andrew Carnegie. The quarters are so cramped that adult classes in English and computer skills spill over into the childrens area.

title: Full House Sequel Coming to Netflix
description: Netflix has bet its future on original programming but its latest announcement stretches the notion of original. On Tuesday, it officially confirmed that the long rumored reboot of the family sitcom Full House would debut on the streaming service in 2016.

title: Survivors on Former Nazis Trial
description: Hedy Bohm and Eva Fahidi, Auschwitz survivors and co-plaintiffs in the trial of a former SS member who worked at the Nazi death camp, spoke on Tuesday at a press conference in Lneburg, Germany.

title: Finding the Right Credit Card, No Matter How Much You Travel
description: To rack up frequent-flier miles and loyalty points quickly and easily, you need the right credit cards. And now is a terrific time to sign up for one (or more), thanks to increased competition among issuers, resulting in some of the best offers in years.

title: Co-Pilots Coffee Spill Blamed in Plunge of Serbian Presidents Plane
description: WARSAW  The nearly disastrous plunge of the Serbian presidents plane Friday was the fault of the co-pilot, who spilled coffee in the cockpit and accidentally activated an emergency switch, the Serbian Civil Aviation Directorate said in a report published Tuesday.

title: Areas With Large Black Populations Have the Smallest Shares of Black Men
description: Why do some places have so many more missing African-American men than others?

title: Artisans and Crafts in London
description: London has long had a design week and a fashion festival, and now its turning the spotlight on potters, glass blowers, textile artists, metalsmiths and other artisans during London Craft Week, which runs from May 6 to 10.

title: Chinas Economy Puts New Pressure on Its Lopsided Job Market
description: HONG KONG  Wang Junping worked as a farmer in his native Hebei Province and as a coal miner in Inner Mongolia. But on a recent afternoon, Mr. Wang, 49, smartly dressed in a suit jacket, was awaiting lessons at an employment agency on the proper way to use a broom and mop to clean Beijings sprawling subway system.

title: A Christies Auction Brings Together the Art, and History, of Jeff Koons and Martin Kippenberger
description: People in the art world are fond of saying that their business is all about personal relationships. Some others look at recent prices for art  $250 million for a single Cezanne, $142.4 million for a Francis Bacon  and believe its only about money. Both sides of that coin will be in plain view on May 13, when Christies auctions an untitled self-portrait from 1988 by the late Martin Kippenberger and a gleaming, stainless steel bust of Louis XIV made in 1986 by Jeff Koons, currently the most expensive artist alive.

title: Former Met Director Becomes Chairman of Hispanic Society Museum
description: Philippe de Montebello, the longtime former director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is becoming chairman of the Hispanic Society of America to raise the profile of the organization, The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday.

title: Baryshnikov to Perform in a Show Based on Brodskys Poetry
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov will perform in a new solo work based on the poems of Joseph Brodsky, created for him by Alvis Hermanis, the director of the New Riga Theater in Riga, Latvia, where Mr. Baryshnikov was born. Called Brodsky/Baryshnikov, the piece will have its premiere in Riga on Oct. 15. A tour to the United States, as part of an international tour, is planned for 2016.

title: Utah Gymnastics Coach Greg Marsden to Retire
description: With more victories than any other college gymnastics coach and a program that averaged 14,950 spectators per home meet last season, Greg Marsden announced his retirement on Tuesday after leading the University of Utah program he started 40 years ago to 10 national championships and a second-place finish at last weekends N.C.A.A. championships.

title: South African Army Deployed in Areas Hit by Anti-Immigrant Violence
description: South Africa deployed troops on Tuesday to areas recently hit by a surge in anti-immigrant attacks that has claimed seven lives and exposed the governments inability to stop the violence.

title: Phil Rudd, AC/DC Drummer, Pleads Guilty to Threatening Murder and Having Drugs
description: Phil Rudd, the drummer for the still-kicking Australian rock band AC/DC, pleaded guilty to charges of threatening murder and drug possession on Tuesday in New Zealand, the BBC reported. Mr. Rudd, 60, was arrested in November and charged with trying to hire a hit man  apparently because of frustrations with the release of his solo album, Head Job, last year  although that more serious charge was promptly dropped because of a lack of evidence.

title: A Third-Grade Rap Portraitists First Visit To New York, for His Tribeca Film Festival Debut
description: Yung Lenox, at just eight years old, walked the red carpet on Friday  which paled in comparison, in his opinion, to eating doughnuts during the films two-day shoot last year.

title: Baltimore Officers Suspended Over Death of Freddie Gray Are Identified
description: The Baltimore Police Department on Tuesday identified the six officers who have been suspended in the death of Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old black man who was taken to a hospital with a severed spinal cord after being chased and arrested.

title: Santina
description: Its always summer at this new restaurant from Mario Carbone, Rich Torrisi and Jeff Zalaznick.

title: Restaurant Review: Santina in the Meatpacking District
description: The calendar said January when Santina opened early this year. The temperature outside hovered just above freezing. That said January, too.

title: Morsi Sentenced to 20 Years in Prison
description: A court in Egypt on Tuesday sentenced Mohamed Morsi, the former president, to 20 years in prison for inciting violence and directing illegal detentions and torture.

title: Trader Arrested in Manipulation That Contributed to 2010 Flash Crash
description: Five years ago, the global financial system was rocked by the flash crash, 15 minutes of chaos that shook the worlds biggest markets and prompted investors both big and small to question how such a vital part of the economy could be brought to its knees.

title: Justices Rule That Police Cant Extend Traffic Stops
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday ruled that the police may not prolong traffic stops to wait for drug-sniffing dogs to inspect vehicles.

title: Smart City Technology May Be Vulnerable to Hackers
description: So-called smart cities, with wireless sensors controlling everything from traffic lights to water management, may be vulnerable to cyberattacks, according to a computer security expert.

title: Israel to Remove Name of Slain Palestinian Teenager From Memorial
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli authorities said late Tuesday that the name of Muhammad Abu Khdeir, the Palestinian teenager from East Jerusalem who was abducted, beaten and burned to death by three Israelis last summer, would be removed from the states memorial to victims of hostile acts at the request of his father.

title: Why American Workers Without Much Education Are Being Hammered
description: The last couple of decades have been terrible for American workers without much education. New research calculates just how bad, and offers some evidence as to why that is.

title: Judge Orders Stony Brook University to Defend Its Custody of 2 Chimps
description: They may not know it, and they most certainly will not be in attendance, but Hercules and Leo will have their day in court.

title: Super PACs Are Gobbling Up Even More Power, Jeb Bush Edition
description: The super PAC, which transformed the 2012 presidential election as a new conduit of influence for wealthy donors, is gaining even more power and flexibility for the 2016 elections.

title: At the Intersection
description: Making the city safe for pedestrians begins by acknowledging that New Yorkers will walk wherever they damn well please.

title: The Term African-American Appears Earlier Than Thought: Reporters Notebook
description: As a reporter on the academic beat, I get lots of emails tipping me off to seemingly arcane items discovered in archives and libraries. Im temperamentally inclined to find such things extremely interesting. But my ears prick up a bit more than usual when the item relates to the history of language, and the tip comes from Fred Shapiro as did the one that formed the article I wrote on Monday about the discovery that the term African-American originated much earlier than previously thought.

title: Deal on Trade Pact Gives Obama Authority but Builds In a Delay
description: WASHINGTON  Republican lawmakers and the White House have agreed to subject any trade deal negotiated by President Obama to a monthslong review by Congress and the public, a concession aimed at winning the support of Democrats who view trade agreements as a threat to American workers.

title: Saudis Announce Halt to Yemen Bombing Campaign
description: OBOCK, Djibouti  Saudi Arabia said Tuesday that it was halting a nearly month-old bombing campaign against a rebel group in neighboring Yemen that has touched off a devastating humanitarian crisis and threatened to ignite a broader regional conflict.

title: Facts & Figures: Loretta Lynchs Long Wait
description: Loretta Lynch has spent 164 dayswaiting to be confirmed as United States attorney general  longer than the framers spent writing the Constitution, according to The Huffington Post. Amanda Terkel and Jennifer Bendery offer a few other points of comparison:

title: A Cooking Club Thats 124 Years Old and Counting
description: WICHITA, Kan.  Texas cattle, Turkey Red wheat and Pizza Hut all helped build this city on the Plains. And in its own quiet way, so has the Thursday Afternoon Cooking Club.

title: A Third-Grade Rap Portraitists First Visit to New York, for His Tribeca Film Festival Debut
description: When 8-year-old Lenox Buringrud, known by the name Yung Lenox, was asked about his first impressions of New York City, during a visit to town last weekend, he responded with appropriate candor: Its kinda smelly, he said. Despite it being the hometown of several of his favorite rap artists  Action Bronson and A$AP Ferg, for example  the citys trademark characteristics, such as the steady noise and unidentifiable odors, were clearly less impressive for the Seattle-based third grader who had arrived for the premiere of Live Fast, Draw Yung, a lighthearted, 16-minute documentary which debuted at the Tribeca Film Festival last Friday.

title: The Whitneys Inaugural Dinner and First Look
description: Artists and patrons attended the Whitney Museum of American Arts inaugural dinner at its new home.

title: Whitney Inaugurates New Museum with Dinner
description: Getting invited to the Whitney Museum of American Arts inaugural dinner on Monday took more than a quick text to a well-connected friend.

title: George Mendess Lupulo Is a Homage to His Heritage
description: Headliner

title: Midsummer Night Swing at Lincoln Center to Kick Off June 23
description: Lincoln Centers Midsummer Night Swing, the annual dance party marathon at the outdoor ballroom in Damrosch Park, will run this year for 15 evenings from June 23 to July 11, featuring a buffet of acts in various styles. They include Jonathan Stouts All Star Orchestra for the jazzy Lindy Hop, Cachaos Mambo All Stars for Cuban dance, Nikki Hill for rock n roll, Conjunto Sabrosura for salsa, and many more.

title: In a New Music Video, All Eyes Are on Speedy Ortiz
Cecily Strongs Trial by Fire at the White House Correspondents Dinner
description: Sitting in her tiny dressing room at Saturday Night Live on a Friday afternoon, Cecily Strong was trying to keep her mind off a big looming commitment.

title: Colm Toibin on Elizabeth Bishop: A Different Kind of Literary Tango
description: Captivating books are often born when one writer is obsessed with another. Nicholson Bakers U and I (about John Updike) and Geoff Dyers Out of Sheer Rage (about D. H. Lawrence, sort of) spring to mind, but those are wild, hilarious books, almost like antic pranks. On Elizabeth Bishop, the novelist and critic Colm Toibins  compact new study of the poets work, has little in common with them, but it succeeds as a different kind of literary tango. It hums instead of crows. Its pull on the reader is almost tidal.

title: Fear and Loathing in American Politics
description: New York Magazines Jonathan Chait and the Washington Posts Dan Balz both have interesting pieces up this week discussingnew research on polarization in America, though the basic findings they cite will not necessarily surprise anyone following our politics: The parties supporters are more ideologically distinct than in the past, split-ticket voting is disappearing, the electoral college map favors Democrats in presidential elections but population density creates a district map that favors House Republicans, etc. But the papers authors (Alan Abramowitz and Steven Webster) deploya very usefulterm, negative polarization, to describe what theyre seeing in the data. As Balz puts it, people dont like their own party any more or less than they used to, but they dislike the other party much more. Or to quote Chait: Todays voters form strong loyalties based more on loathing for the opposing party than on the old kind of tribal loyalty (My daddy was a Democrat, his daddy was a Democrat ) that used to prevail. The party system has split along racial, cultural, and religious lines, creating a kind of tribal system where each partys supports regard the other side with incomprehension and loathing.

title: First Draft Focus: Congratulations to a Nascar Champion
Decatur, a Commuter Town Near Atlanta, Turns Trendsetter
description: Equal parts molasses-drawled Southern and au courant, Decatur, Ga., has in the last 20 years recast itself from the sleepy DeKalb County seat catering to commuting government nine-to-fivers to one of the Souths trendsetters. Residents say the township, six miles from Atlanta proper, is where Mayberry meets Berkeley. Bordered by Emory University and Agnes Scott College, Decatur is anchored by a late 19th-century courthouse (now the DeKalb History Center) and a leafy square dense with some of the states best restaurants, pubs and shops. The walkable downtown hosts more than three dozen festivals a year.

title: Michele Leonhart, Head of D.E.A., to Retire Over Handling of Sex Scandal
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administrations top drug enforcement official will step down next month, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. announced on Tuesday, after her agency was tarnished by a scandal over sex parties with prostitutes and she broke with President Obama on drug policy.

title: Celebrating the Lost Art of Flyers Through the Lens of the Louisville Punk Music Scene
description: Gone are the days when all a person needed to disseminate information were some paper, markers, a glue stick and a stapler  along with the required telephone poles on which to attach the resultant flyers. This is how bands publicized their shows, creating announcements with just the vitals  who, what, when, where and how much  using only the most basic materials. White Glove Test: Louisville Punk Flyers 1978-1994 (Drag City, $40) showcases a collection of these DIY works of art that came out of one of the most storied independent music scenes in the country, responsible for such seminal bands as No Fun, Slint and Bonnie Prince Billy.

title: The Republican Recipe for Widening Inequality
description: This week, House and Senate Republicans will be working on a final budget plan. They are operating from templates that call for cuts of about 40 percent on average by 2025 in programs for low and moderate income households  things like food assistance, college aid and tax credits for the working poor.

title: Reassembling Woeful Knicks Tops Phil Jacksons To-Do List
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The primary newsbreak out of Phil Jacksons farewell address after the worst season of his long pro basketball career was that he had not lost his sense of humor.

title: Yahoo Shows Growth in Mobile Advertising, but Results Miss Estimates
description: SAN FRANCISCO  At Yahoo, the turnaround that investors are hoping for remains elusive.

title: Chipotle Posts Another Quarter of Billion-Dollar Sales
description: Earnings reports on Tuesday from three prominent restaurant operators, including Chipotle Mexican Grill, illustrated the impact of the changing preferences of American consumers.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Pictures of the Day: Italy and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Italy, Sri Lanka, India and South Africa.

title: April 21, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Italy, Sri Lanka, India and South Africa.

title: Migrants Face Fortress Europes Deadly Moat
description: LONDON  UP to 1,200 people are believed to have died this past week when, in several incidents, their flimsy boats foundered in the Mediterranean. These migrants from Syria, Mali, Eritrea, Somalia and beyond had set out from North Africa hoping to reach Europes southern shores. Fleeing war and poverty, most had paid large sums to traffickers.

title: European Central Bank Squeezes Greek Banks, Tightening Access to Loans
description: As Greece scrambles to secure a financing deal with Europe before running out of cash, the European Central Bank is tightening the vise on the countrys ailing banks by curtailing access to desperately needed emergency loans.

title: Sweet Parisian Confection Collaborations in Paris for Spring
description: TK

title: The Cover Stars
description: French artist JR pasted an enormous photograph onto the Flatiron plaza in the making of the magazines cover image.

title: Review: For The Prancing Elites Project, the March Goes On
description: In December 2013, the Prancing Elites  a black, gay, male dance troupe based in Mobile, Ala.  marched in the Christmas parade in the city of Semmes, Ala. The Prancing Elites specialize in J-setting, a fluid style with roots in cheerleading and traditionally performed by women. The group had applied through the formal channels, was accepted and showed up in Santa-themed costumes ready to dance.

title: N.E.A. Jazz Masters Hail From Inside and Outside the Club
description: The annual National Endowment for the Arts Jazz Masters awards ceremony and concert is not a referendum on the current state of jazz; it celebrates older heroes, as it is meant to. But there have been a lot of subplots in the long story of the music, and the emphasis of the event changes according to whos being inducted, through their performances and their speeches.

title: In Don Carlo Productions, Singers Tease Out a Kings Humanity
description: Even if everyone loves a bad boy, the appeal of Philip II in Verdis Don Carlo is hard to explain. He has none of Don Giovannis erotic allure or Mphistophlss sardonic wit. In Verdis adaptation of Schillers searing play, this Hapsburg king is a tyrant, a bigot and a hypocrite.

title: A New Home for the Prada Foundation
description: A look at the sprawling arts complex in Milan designed by Rem Koolhaas.

title: Review: Emptying the Skies Follows the Rescue of Songbirds at Most Any Cost
description: Two types of people will be tempted to ignore Emptying the Skies, a documentary about bird poaching based on a Jonathan Franzen article: people who dont care about birding, and people who care passionately about birding. Both groups would be missing out on a thoughtful bit of filmmaking, one that at heart is not really about birds at all.

title: Review: In 8 Stops, Finding Humor Amid Hardships
description: Talk about refreshingly low-key. When Deb Margolin walked up the aisle of the Cherry Lane Theater and bounded up the steps to the edge of the stage, I thought she was the house manager, there to make the opening announcements. She was wearing a blue dress, footless black tights and ballet flats and carrying some papers.

title: Big Mac Test Shows Job Market Is Not Working to Distribute Wealth
description: Some 15 years ago, searching for a consistent way to compare wages of equivalent workers across the world, Orley Ashenfelter, an economics professor at Princeton University, came upon McDonalds.

title: Review: 1915, a Ghostly Evocation of Bygone Slaughter
description: There might be an engaging film buried beneath the severe dialogue, portentous music and ominous shadows of 1915. But a relentless and heavy-handed script makes the effort to find it seem futile.

title: Oklahoma Recognizes Role of Drilling in Earthquakes
description: Abandoning years of official skepticism, Oklahomas government on Tuesday embraced a scientific consensus that earthquakes rocking the state are largely caused by the underground disposal of billions of barrels of wastewater from oil and gas wells.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Eli Reeds Long Walk Home
description: A major retrospective of Eli Reeds work shows how the Magnum photographer has sought beauty and understanding of the human condition.

title: Review: In Dont Think Ive Forgotten, Cambodias Lost Generation of Pop Stars
description: Dont Think Ive Forgotten, a moving and informative documentary by John Pirozzi, takes its name from a hit song of the 1960s. The title may not ring a bell among Western audiences, though the tune itself might carry a sonic reminder of that era. Like almost all the music heard in the film, it was a product of the vibrant pop music scene that flourished in Cambodia during the ill-fated reign of Prince Norodom Sihanouk.

title: StatcastArrives, Offering Way to Quantify Nearly Every Move in Game
description: Which outfielders take the most efficient routes to a fly ball? Which pitchers curveball has the highest spin rate? Which batter has the fastest speed to first base?

title: Living in Chatham, N.J.
description: A highly regarded school system, a walkable downtown and a train to Manhattan are among the attractions for house hunters.

title: What You Get for . . . $1,350,000
description: This weeks properties include a log house in Montana, a contemporary in Houston and a waterfront modern in Virginia Beach.

title: Jeb Bushs Likely Campaign Starts to Take Shape
description: Jeb Bush has not officially announced a 2016 presidential bid yet, but he is already building an elaborate political operation, complete with a strong super PAC that would rival the size of his campaigns core, according to people familiar with the plan.

title: Recent Commercial Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: A Three-Bedroom Traditional-Style Home in Ubud
description: Comprising two refurbished Javanese structures known as joglos, the house is on the market for $435,000.

title: A Conversation With R. Byron Carlock Jr., Partner at PricewaterhouseCoopers
description: Mr. Carlock, 52, is a partner and the national real estate practice leader, based in Dallas, for PricewaterhouseCoopers or PwC. The PwC division provides audit, tax and advisory services to managers of real estate assets, including real estate investment trusts or REITs, private equity funds, governments and other institutions.

title: One Israeli Soldier, 23 Namesakes and a Day of Remembrance
description: JERUSALEM  She had but one son, and he died childless at 21. Yet that boy spawned a generation.

title: Insurers Take On More Risk in Search of Returns, Study Says
description: Insurance companies just get cant enough for their money these days. Interest rates are at all-time lows and even the United States stock markets havent mustered much steam.

title: Walk the Line
description: Lee Friendlander photographs the tangles, the mess, the disorder of the citys streets.

title: The Boardroom Strikes Back
description: This years proxy season is turning out to be more hostile than ever, as companies fight back against hedge fund activists.

title: Congress Passes Bipartisan Bill to Improve Energy Efficiency
description: Congress on Tuesday passed a bill focused on improving energy efficiency in buildings and water heaters, a move celebrated by both parties for breaking longstanding partisan gridlock.

title: India, Seeking a Boost, Plans to Put Its Idle Gold to Work
description: MUMBAI, India  Just after 10:15 every night, the three stone goddesses of Mahalakshmi Temple are stripped of their finery  the gleaming masks, said to contain 17 pounds of gold; ropy gold necklaces; pendants shuddering with jewels.

title: Meredith, Publisher of Magazines, Lays Off 100 as It Reorganizes
description: The Meredith Corporation, the publisher of magazines like Family Circle and Better Homes and Gardens, laid off about 100 employees on Tuesday as part of a broader revamping.

title: The Best-Selling Sports Books
description: The best-selling sports books in March 2015, according to the New York Times best-seller list.

title: Study Finds Low Cost in Reducing Methane Emissions
description: Reducing methane leaks from oil and gas operations around the world could provide a relatively inexpensive way to fight climate change, according to a new report commissioned by the Environmental Defense Fund.

title: Comcasts Track Record in Past Deals May Be Hitch for Merger With Time Warner Cable
description: In July 2013, executives from the three companies that co-owned Hulu  Comcast, 21st Century Fox and Walt Disney  had a conversation about their joint venture. Hulu, the video streaming service, had been on the auction block, and lucrative bids had come in from two Comcast rivals, AT&T and the satellite operator DirecTV, among other potential buyers.

title: Kenya Envisions a Border Wall That Keeps Shabab Violence Out
description: MANDERA, Kenya  As the border gate opened early in the morning, minibuses dropped off passengers, donkey-led carts trotted through and pedestrians began to cross freely on foot, heading in both directions.

title: A New Home for the Prada Foundation
description: A look at the new complex designed by Rem Koolhaas.

title: M.T.A. Must Run Bus Ad From Pro-Israel Group, Judge Says
description: A federal judge in Manhattan on Tuesday ordered the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to display an ad from a pro-Israel group on buses after the agency declined to run it last year.

title: Bob St. Clair, Towering 49ers Tackle in the Hall of Fame, Dies at 84
description: Bob St. Clair, the towering tackle who overpowered defensive linemen while springing holes for his fellow Hall of Famers in the San Francisco 49ers million-dollar backfield of the 1950s, died on Monday in Santa Rosa, Calif. He was 84.

title: Sighs of Relief From Yemen, Mixed With Fears of More Conflict
description: Writing on social networks late Tuesday, Yemeni bloggers and activists in the capital, Sana, expressed relief that the Saudi-led air campaign, Operation Decisive Storm, officially ended after nearly a month at midnight local time.

title: New York Is Sometimes a Faithful Place
description: The cabdriver showed up at the 76th Precinct station house on April 5 and turned in a bag that had been left in the trunk. The police property clerks voucher is a fastidiously detailed document, so even a pen and a novel found in the bag had to be listed according to its rigorous format.

title: Promises Are Made Amid Obstacles During Cuomos Trade Mission to Cuba
description: HAVANA  On Monday morning, Kevin Ellis boarded a charter flight to Cuba, one of about 20 businesspeople accompanying Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York on a shared mission to take advantage of the recent decision by the United States and Cuba to ease diplomatic relations.

title: The Legal Odds Are Shifting in the A.I.G. Case
description: WASHINGTON  When David Boies delivers his closing arguments on Wednesday in a case that pits Maurice Greenberg against the federal government over the 2008 bailout of American International Group, he will have already achieved something that few had thought possible: a chance to win.

title: Answer Found to Mystery of Missing Bourbon, Kentucky Officials Say
description: The Kentucky authorities said on Tuesday that they had mostly solved the peculiar mystery of who had been pilfering  and illicitly profiting from  some of the states most celebrated bourbons.

title: White House Acknowledges Armenian Genocide, but Avoids the Term
description: WASHINGTON  The White House urged on Tuesday a full, frank and just acknowledgment of the Armenian genocide a century after the deaths of as many as 1.5 million people, but once again refused to use the word genocide.

title: Xi Jinping Plans to Fund Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  President Xi Jinping of China on Tuesday concluded an upbeat two-day visit to Pakistan during which he pledged $46 billion worth of energy and infrastructure projects.

title: New York Citys Environment Program Will Focus on Income Inequality
description: In his most sweeping bid yet to apply a focus on income inequality across the municipal spectrum, Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York on Wednesday will introduce a reimagined take on the citys ambitious environmental program, PlaNYC.

title: Atomic Labs Across the U.S. Race to Stop Iran
description: WASHINGTON  When diplomats at the Iran talks in Switzerland pummeled Department of Energy scientists with difficult technical questions  like how to keep Irans nuclear plants open but ensure that the country was still a year away from building a bomb  the scientists at times turned to a secret replica of Irans nuclear facilities built deep in the forests of Tennessee.

title: Persistence of a Steroid Bedevils Baseball
description: On opening day, Commissioner Rob Manfred said that alarm bells rang at Major League Baseballs offices when, just before the season began, three pitchers on major league rosters tested positive for the powerful, old-school steroid stanozolol.

title: Frederic Morton, Author Who Chronicled the Rothschilds, Dies at 90
description: Frederic Morton, who left Austria as a boy as his family fled from the Nazis and made a celebrated literary career in the United States, much of which involved observing his homeland and its history from a distance, has died in Vienna. He was 90.

title: For Blue Bell, a Drastic Move to Recall Ice Cream as Listeria Findings Rose
description: The alert hit HEB Grocery in San Antonio late Monday: Blue Bell Creameries, a Southwestern favorite and the countrys third-largest ice cream brand, was recalling all its frozen desserts over concerns of contamination by the potentially deadly bacteria listeria.

title: A Sublime Champions League Matchup, if Soccer Gods Cooperate
description: BARCELONA, Spain  As nights of soccer watching go, it was an excellent one for shampooing your hair. Or organizing your T-shirt collection. Or maybe even polishing off that last chunk of War and Peace that youd been putting off.

title: Freddie Gray in Baltimore: Another City, Another Death in the Public Eye
description: BALTIMORE  In life, friends say, Freddie Gray was an easygoing, slender young man who liked girls and partying here in Sandtown, a section of west Baltimore pocked by boarded-up rowhouses and known to the police for drug dealing and crime.

title: American Marine Veteran Held in Iran Assails Serial Hostage-Taking
description: Relatives of a Marine veteran incarcerated in Iran for more than three and a half years sent a letter to congressional leaders on Tuesday, dictated by him over the phone from prison, denouncing what he called Irans serial hostage-taking and mistreatment and demanding tougher pressure on the Iranian authorities to release him and two other American prisoners as part of the nuclear negotiations.

title: Parks Commissioner Pledges to Speed Pace of New York City Projects
description: New York may be one of the few places where a skyscraper can be built in less time than a playground, a fact bemoaned by park advocates and city lawmakers who help pay for park projects.

title: Review: Doctor Zhivago, the Broadway Musical
description: Doctor Zhivago, the endless Boris Pasternak novel familiar to most of us from the endless David Lean movie, has been resurrected for dramatic purposes once again, as a musical that opened at the Broadway Theater on Tuesday night.

title: A Full Deck
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  If you have memorized the Greek alphabet, youre pretty much guaranteed to know the answer to about five filler crossword clues each week. So my advice is to learn to navigate your way from alpha to omega  I promise, it will pay huge dividends in all of your future crossword solving endeavors.

title: Heidi Chronicles to Close on May 3
description: A well-reviewed Broadway revival of The Heidi Chronicles, the Pulitzer Prize-winning play by Wendy Wasserstein, will close on May 3, after a lackluster showing at the box office.

title: Man, 20, Faces Hate Crime Charges in Brooklyn Robberies
description: A 20-year-old man has been charged with robbery as a hate crime for six attacks on women of Chinese descent in Brooklyn, prosecutors said on Tuesday.

title: Running Between Rainstorms
description: A jogger, undeterred, near the Manhattan Bridge on Tuesday. Thunderstorms are predicted for the New York area on Wednesday.

title: Encouraged by dArnaud, a Mets Rookie Has a Strong Debut
description: Hours after tests confirmed that Mets catcher Travis dArnaud had a broken bone in his right hand and would have to wear a splint for the next three weeks, he took his replacement, Kevin Plawecki, out to dinner Monday night.

title: James Venture, 93, Dies; Resistance Fighter Survived Nazi Death Train
description: James Venture, one of the last survivors of the infamous Train de Loos, which carried French resistance fighters, Communists and Jews from a prison in the northern French village of Loos to concentration camps in Germany in September 1944, died on April 1 at his home in Mons-en-Baroeul, France, near Lille. He was 93.

title: Two Resurgent Yankees Fuel Road Victory Over Tigers
description: DETROIT  The rainbow that appeared Tuesday evening beyond left field at Comerica Park seemed to be a reminder of the parabolic nature of baseball, in which, over the course of time, outcomes generally even out.

title: AlexOvechkin Helps Capitals Even Series With Islanders
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Alex Ovechkin skated out for warm-ups, snared the first puck he could find and fired it toward the Islander net. He missed.

title: Word of the Day | gambit
description: gambit  \gam-bt\  noun

title: New $200,000 Carnegie Fellowships to Aid Researchers in Humanities and Social Science
description: Scholars studying dying languages, nuclear weapons, the effects of dark money on politics and the history of immigration reform are among the first recipients of the Andrew Carnegie Fellowship, a new award intended to support research in the beleaguered humanities and social sciences.

title: The Upshot Is One Year Old. Here Are the Stories You Clicked the Most.
description: The Upshot began publication April 22, 2014, and we published more than 1,500 articles in our first year. To celebrate our first birthday, weve put together a list of our 250 most-read pieces.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Nonhuman animals do not have legal rights any more than they have legal responsibilities. For a court to hold otherwise would have tremendous adverse legal and moral implications for mankind.

title: Editors Note: April 22, 2015
description: FOOD

title: The Champion Revisits New York
description: The heavyweight champion Wladimir Klitschko of Ukraine is preparing to defend his title against the American Bryant Jennings on April 25 at Madison Square Garden, where he last fought in 2008.

title: Hong Kong Presents Plan for Elections, Offering Little to Democrats
description: HONG KONG  Hong Kong entered a new bout of struggle over its political future on Wednesday, as the local government offered only minor changes to an election overhaul plan that set off months of pro-democracy demonstrations last year. Opposition lawmakers denounced the latest proposals, signaling the start of a political contest that will make or break the governments plans.

title: Eli Reeds Long Walk Home
description: A few years ago, Eli Reed decided to show a bunch of his photographs to David Hamrick of University of Texas Press. It was early evening as he made his way to Mr. Hamricks office with a box of prints, a MacBook with color work and some other things from his office at the university, where he has taught photography since 2005. The images included scenes from his childhood home in Perth Amboy, N.J., battlefields in Lebanon, Hollywood sets and American poverty.

title: Voice of Americas Mission
description: To the Editor:

title: Deal or No Deal?
description: The Obama teams effort to negotiate a deal with Iran that could prevent the Iranians from developing a nuclear bomb for at least a decade is now entering its critical final stage. I hope that a good, verifiable deal can be finalized, but it will not be easy. If it were, wed have it by now. Here are the major challenges:

title: Homaro Cantu: A Chicago Chefs Suicide
description: To the Editor:

title: Newt Gingrich: Double the N.I.H. Budget
description: MCLEAN, Va.  NO one who lived through the 1990s would have suspected that one day people would look back on the period as a golden age of bipartisan cooperation. But in some important ways, it was. Amid the policy fights that followed the Republican victories of 1994, President Bill Clinton and the new majorities in Congress reached one particularly good deal: doubling the budget for the National Institutes of Health.

title: Hollywood Trumps Harvard
description: Call me an idealist, but Id like to think that the halls of higher education are less vulnerable to the siren calls of fame and fortune than other byways of American life are. Id like to believe in a bold dividing line between academic virtues and celebrity values, between intellectual and commercial concerns.

title: Health and E-Cigarettes
description: To the Editor:

title: Faith and Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Whats on TV Wednesday
description: 7:30 P.M. (HBO) SAVING MY TOMORROW You are the future generation, says Grace, 10, a member of Plant-to-Planet in Seattle, which plants trees to help counter carbon dioxide emissions, the most prominent factor in climate change. You are the ones who are going to have to deal with this mess that everybody else behind us has gotten us into. Grace is one in a chorus of children speaking up for the planet in this kaleidoscopic family Earth Day special, the third of six episodes created with the American Museum of Natural History that melds science, animation, readings by Alan Cumming, Laura Dern, Tina Fey and Neil deGrasse Tyson, and music by Pharrell Williams, They Might Be Giants and Pete Seeger (in a previously unreleased performance) to address the perils of pollution, oil and gas drilling and climate change. The adults clearly arent doing enough to stop this, says Zoe, 12, so we have to take it into our own hands.

title: The Iranian Foreign Ministers Call for a Nuclear Deal
Fresh Outlooks From a Summer Getaway
description: Every child deserves a summer vacation or at least some relief from the heat. For Ricky Cruz, who was raised by his grandmother in the Bronx, the Fresh Air Fund provided an opportunity to escape. Spending a few weeks out of town as a young boy gave Mr. Cruz, now 22, a new outlook and a chance to see different things that I would not normally see in my neighborhood, he said.

title: Who Flew First? Gustave Whitehead or the Wright Brothers?
Profiting From His Mothers Crime
description: The speaker of the New York State Assembly, Carl Heastie, one of the three most powerful politicians in the state, has promised real reform in scandal-tainted Albany. Yet, as Russ Buettner and David Chen reported in The Times, Mr. Heastie himself is under a cloud for benefiting from his mothers crimes nearly 20 years ago.

title: The Gulf, Still at Risk
description: In the run-up to the fifth anniversary on Monday of one of the worst environmental disasters in American history, the 2010 BP oil blowout in the Gulf of Mexico, the country has heard happy talk from the company most responsible for it. Using phrases like returning to pre-spill or baseline conditions, and by emphasizing a rebound in fishing and tourism, BP has been suggesting in its reports and advertising that recovery of the entire ecosystem is just around the corner.

title: A Pawn in the Iran Nuclear Deal
description: Plenty of irresponsible detractors have sought to derail negotiations between world powers and Iran over its nuclear program. The Iranian judiciary stands to further poison the atmosphere surrounding the talks by its continued detention of Jason Rezaian, an American-born correspondent for The Washington Post.

title: A Year After Sinking, South Korea Will Try to Salvage Sewol Ferry
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea formally announced on Wednesday that it would try to raise the 6,825-ton ferry that sank more than a year ago, killing more than 300 people, most of them high school students.

title: A Guide to the Proposed Changes to Hong Kongs Election Rules
description: On Wednesday, Hong Kongs government presented its proposal for how the citys top official, the chief executive, could be chosen in future elections, starting in 2017. The governments initial proposal was vehemently opposed by tens of thousands of protesters who occupied streets in the former British colony for nearly three months late last year. They demanded a far more open and democratic process. The new proposal now leaves opposition lawmakers with the choice of endorsing it and allowing universal suffrage for the first time but restricting the list of candidates, or rejecting it and risking the forfeiting any changes to the electoral system.

title: 6 Qs About the News | 1.5 Million Missing Black Men
description: In 1.5 Million Missing Black Men, The Upshot investigates why, across the country, hundreds of thousands of black men are missing from everyday life.

title: Test Yourself | High-Fives Between Free Throws
description: Here are several paragraphs from an April 11 article, He Missed a Shot? Give That Man a Hand.

title: In Chatham, N.J., a Strollable Downtown and Good Schools
description: Julie and Thomas Blackstock moved to Chatham Borough from Union City, N.J., in 2013 for a reason Ms. Blackstock, a freelance photographer, called really unoriginal.

title: On the Night Willie Mays Hit No. 660, It Was Just Another Number
description: As New Yorkers filed into Shea Stadium that night in 1973, there was much more for fans to think about than an aging baseball stars home run total.

title: Wladimir Klitschko Seeks Recognition of Himself and Ukraine
description: Wladimir Klitschko, the heavyweight champion of the world, was trying to rescue a news conference that was supposed to be promoting a title bout at Madison Square Garden.

title: House Passes Cybersecurity Bill After Companies Fall Victim to Data Breaches
description: WASHINGTON  Responding to a series of computer security breaches in government and the private sector, the House passed an expansive measure Wednesday that would push companies to share access to their computer networks and records with federal investigators.

title: Ted Cruz Showed Eloquence, and Limits, as Debater at Princeton
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  By the time he was a senior at Princeton University in 1992, Ted Cruz had developed an arsenal of rhetorical skills and theatrical gestures that made him one of the most polished performers on the college debate circuit. So when he reached the quarterfinals of the national championships at M.I.T., with the title that had eluded him so far now in sight, he decided to try to knock his Harvard opponents off balance with one of his favorite tricks.

title: Brooklyn Movie Palace Throws Regal Arms Around Restored Lobby Suite
description: Dorothy Solomon Panzica always knew what to do.

title: The Prada Foundations New Arts Complex in Milan
description: MILAN  For more than 20 years, the Prada Foundation has been staging contemporary art exhibitions in abandoned warehouses and disused churches here, bringing contemporary artists like Anish Kapoor and Michael Heizer to Italian audiences, often for the first time. The foundation has masterminded projects elsewhere, too, like the time the Belgian artist Carsten Holler created the Double Club, a restaurant and club in a Victorian warehouse in London, drawing patrons like Mick Jagger and Penlope Cruz.

title: Taliban Are Said to Target Hazaras to Try to Match ISIS Brutality
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A wave of kidnappings followed by numerous beheadings of members of Afghanistans Hazara ethnic group have spread alarm and anger among a people who historically have been this countrys most persecuted.

title: How Emotionally Intelligent Are You?
description: This most-emailed article about emotional intelligence published in The Timess Education Life section suggests skills we all need to be real leaders.

title: New Orleans Bars Issue Last Call for Smoking
description: NEW ORLEANS  No one goes to a bar here, particularly one that advertises its hours as 2 p.m. till, and expects precision about the time of day. But it was right on the stroke of midnight that Frankie Mazzanti, 56, one of the owners of the low-ceilinged neighborhood joint called 45 Tchoup, went along the bar picking up ashtrays and tossing them in a plastic bag.

title: The Do-Over, by Kathleen Ossip
description: Oh, wow, mausoleums: Thats the title Kathleen Ossip gives to the final poem in The Do-Over, her third book, and that disarming phrase sums up her goals. Ossip writes to remember the dead, especially Andrea Ossip (1944-2008), her husbands stepmother; to face her own death without panic, if she can; to help us face ours; and to show how an aggressively up-to-date vocabulary  one that would make a lesser writer sound jaded, or bored, or distracted by pings from her iPhone  can fit the most serious of poetic concerns.

title: Wislawa Szymborskas Map: Collected and Last Poems
description: The mass of men may lead lives of quiet desperation, as Thoreau wrote, but the Polish poet Wislawa Szymborska (1923-2012) did just the opposite: She lived a life of quiet amazement, reflected in poems that are both plain-spoken and luminous. Many of them are gathered now in Map: Collected and Last Poems.

title: Mr. West, Sarah Blakes Poems About Kanye West
description: The cynic (or is it the realist?) may look at Sarah Blakes first volume of poetry, Mr. West, with a skeptical eye toward its interest in pop culture: The book is about Kanye West. It is also about contemporary media, motherhood, appropriation, infatuation and race. But it is mainly about Kanye West. Yet neither the cynic nor the realist need worry that Blake is merely using that mercurial genius as an attention-grabbing gimmick. No, Mr. West is a book that is in utterly good faith. That doesnt quite make it a good book, however.

title: The Worlds Fastest Recreational Runners
description: Who are the worlds fastest slower runners?

title: New Zealands Premier Apologizes for Pulling Waitresss Hair
description: New Zealands prime minister, John Key, has apologized to a cafe worker who accused him of a form of torment usually associated with playground bullies: hair-pulling.

title: Speculation to Condolences: Tales From the Comments Section
description: Bassey Etim leads The Timess community team, which is responsible for comment moderation.

title: This Earth Day, Green Is the New Denim
description: Earth Day, April 22, means different things to different people: a chance to plant some seedlings; a call to activism; the time to actually make that New Years resolution compost heap.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: New York Today: In Praise of Earth
description: Good morning on this unpredictable Wednesday.

title: Obama Uses a Visit to the Everglades to Press His Climate Agenda
description: EVERGLADES NATIONAL PARK, Fla.  President Obama on Wednesday made his first visit while in office to the Florida Everglades, choosing the backyard of a former Republican governor of the state, Jeb Bush, and its Republican senator, Marco Rubio, to demand action on climate change in a critical battleground in the 2016 presidential election.

title: Calixto Bieito Coming to Met Opera with a New Forza
description: Calixto Bieito, the daring Catalan theater and opera director, will make his Metropolitan Opera debut in the 2017-18 season with a new production of Verdis La Forza del Destino that is to be conducted by James Levine, company officials announced Wednesday.

title: In Accusing Russian Energy Giant Gazprom, E.U. Begins a Test of Wills
description: BRUSSELS  European antitrust regulators on Wednesday charged the Russian energy giant Gazprom with abusing its dominance in natural gas markets, a move amounting to a direct challenge to the authorities in Moscow.

title: Student Arrested on Suspicion of Planning Attack in France
description: PARIS  A 24-year-old Algerian computer science student suspected of planning an imminent terror attack was taken into custody in Paris over the weekend, the French authorities said on Wednesday.

title: Tesco Posts $9.5 Billion Loss in Latest Hurdle
description: LONDON  Tesco, Britains largest grocery store chain, capped a year marred by an accounting scandal, management turmoil and shrinking market share with a whopping loss of 6.4 billion pounds, or about $9.5 billion, it announced on Wednesday.

title: Saudi Resolve on Yemen Reflects Limits of U.S. Strategy
description: WASHINGTON  Saudi Arabias resumption of airstrikes against Houthi rebels in Yemen on Wednesday, only hours after it abruptly declared a halt to most military operations, reflected the difficulty of finding a political solution to the crisis. It also showed the challenges facing the Obama administration as it increasingly relies on allies in the Middle East.

title: British Regulator Fines Merrill Lynch $19.8 Million for Reporting Failures
description: LONDON  A British regulator on Wednesday fined an arm of Bank of America Merrill Lynch 13.3 million pounds, or about $19.8 million, for failing to properly report tens of millions of client transactions over a seven-year period.

title: Daily Report: Flash Crash Arrest Raises New Worries About High-Frequency Trading
description: Five years ago, the global financial system was rocked by the flash crash, 15 minutes of chaos that shook the worlds biggest markets and prompted investors both big and small to question how such a vital part of the economy could be brought to its knees.

title: An Earth Day Message in a Bottle
description: On our early morning dog walk in the Hudson Highlands woods near our new old home yesterday, my wife and I spotted this odd bit of Anthropocene ecology  the first ferns of spring growing in a bit of dirt inside a bottle discarded along the trail.

title: Obama and Republicans Agree on the Trans-Pacific Partnership  Unfortunately
description: Theres an important issue out there you may never have heard of, which is just what its proponents would like. Thats the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), currently being pushed by the Obama administration and its corporate (and mostly Republican!) allies. Its a blatant attack on labor, farmers, food safety, public health and even national sovereignty.

title: Thatcher Wine on Creating a Travel Book Library
description: Regularly hitting the road is an obvious way to express a love of traveling; collecting books on travel is another. At least according to Thatcher Wine, 42, who, through his Boulder, Colo., company Juniper Books, creates custom libraries for avid readers.

title: Obamacare, Hands Off My Medicare
description: A number of factors underpin the anti-redistributionist shift in public opinion that I wrote about last week.

title: For Visitors to the Florida Keys, More Hotel Choices
description: The Florida Keys have long attracted fans of its no-shirt-no-shoes-no-problem culture. Now the 125-mile island chain may see more of them as hoteliers expand capacity, with nine new or substantially renovated hotels.

title: Editorial Contest Winner | Journalistic Objectivity Was Yesterdays Saving Grace
description: We are honoring each of the Top 10 winners of our Second Annual Student Editorial Contest by publishing an essay a day, in the order of submission.

title: Guest Post | Climate Change Questions for Young Citizen Scientists
Can People With Dementia Have a Sex Life?
Today in Politics: Labor Looks to Push Hillary Clinton to the Left
description: Good Wednesday morning from Washington, where political fund-raising pitches are getting increasingly personal and free-flowing amendments are stalling bills in Congress. President Obama is talking about climate change in the Everglades, while Gov. Chris Christie will look to lighten things up on Jimmy Fallons show. We look back at how Senator Ted Cruz handled humor in his college years, and we look ahead at how labor unions are gearing up to pressure a likely Democratic presidential nominee.

title: Morning Agenda: Flash Crash Arrest Raises New Concerns
description: FLASH CRASH ARREST RAISES NEW CONCERNS | One of the most baffling financial mysteries of recent years  who caused the flash crash of May 6, 2010, when the stock market went into a free fall for 15 harrowing minutes  has now been solved. Well, up to a point. A major instigator of the crash, although not the sole cause, authorities say, was a single man, now 36 years old, who has been arrested in London.

title: Italys Premier Calls for Action Before European Meeting on Migrants
description: LONDON  On the eve of an emergency summit meeting to address Europes spiraling migration crisis, Prime Minister Matteo Renzi of Italy on Wednesday issued a plea for collective action, and he alluded to a call for the creation of centers in Africa that would process asylum applications in a bid to spare many the perilous sea crossing to Europe.

title: U.S. and South Korea Reach Revised Nuclear Deal
description: SEOUL, South Korea  After four and a half years of low-key yet highly sensitive negotiations, the United States and South Korea announced a revised treaty on Wednesday that continues to deny  but not permanently rule out  South Korea the right to enrich uranium or reprocess spent nuclear fuel, even for peaceful purposes.

title: Rites of Spring
description: New picture books welcome spring weather  even the downpours.

title: James Spader Prepares for Avengers: Age of Ultron
description: One overcast spring afternoon, James Spader was lurking in plain sight, standing on the stoop of the Greenwich Village townhouse where he lives, wearing a sport coat, a fedora and a bright purple scarf, smoking a cigarette and talking on a cellphone with the producers of his NBC series, The Blacklist.

title: Airbrushing Austerity
description: Ken Rogoff weighs in on the secular stagnation debate, arguing basically that its Minsky, not Hansen  that were suffering from a painful but temporary era of deleveraging, and that normal policy will resume in a few years.

title: Feel It in the Air
description: Dear Diary:

title: A Coyote Eludes the Police on the Upper West Side
description: After a three-hour chase involving tranquilizer guns, trucks, patrol cars and helicopters, the police surrendered Riverside Park back to a coyote who, on Wednesday morning, had started its day atop a big rock near 87th Street in the park, then journeyed north toward Grants Tomb. In addition to eluding pursuers, the coyote threw into question the citys recently stated policy that it would leave the predators alone in city parks.

title: Trader Charged in Flash Crash Case to Fight Extradition to U.S.
description: LONDON  A 36-year-old futures trader who operated from his London-area home indicated Wednesday that he would oppose extradition to the United States on criminal fraud charges, including claims that he had helped set off a huge crash in the United States stock market, known as the flash crash, in 2010.

title: $1.35 Million Homes in Montana, Houston and Virginia Beach
description: ENNIS, MONT.

title: In Permission, Robert Askins Pairs Romance and Spanking
description: Robert Askinss current Broadway horror-comedy is Hand to God, but his new play is about hand to something else entirely. In Permission, which begins performances April 29 at the Lucille Lortel Theater, Mr. Askins, who is having something of a moment right now, has written a work about romance with spanking. Like the critically acclaimed Hand to God, a scathingly funny, occasionally obscene play about a demonic force in church puppetry, Permission, directed by Alex Timbers, covers another Christian subculture. And this one may well appeal to fans of Fifty Shades of Grey.

title: Xi Jinping of China and Shinzo Abe of Japan Meet Amid Slight Thaw in Ties
description: BEIJING  Chinas president, Xi Jinping, and Japans prime minister, Shinzo Abe, met in Indonesia on Wednesday, a signal of a continued slight warming in relations that still remain frosty between Asias two biggest economies.

title: House Hunting in ... Bali
description: A THREE-BEDROOM TRADITIONAL-STYLE HOME IN UBUD

title: 1965: Disarmament Group Meets
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.  The 114-member UN Disarmament Commission met today [April 21] for the first time since 1960. Addressing the opening session, Secretary- General U Thant warned that there is evidence that we may be approaching yet another crucial point in the nuclear arms race. Mr. Thant urged the commission to give close attention to proposals to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons, to expand the 1963 partial test ban treaty to include all experimental weapons explosion and to plans for denuclearized zones such as Africa and Latin America.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 22, 1965

title: McDonalds Earnings Stumble on Sluggish Sales
description: McDonalds reported gloomy earnings on Wednesday, warning of fewer customers around the world and striking a stark contrast to the booming fortunes of fast-casual restaurants like Chipotle that are sapping the Golden Arches.

title: An Online Tune-Up for the Used-Car Marketplace
description: Linda Lo tried shopping for a car in the usual way, and like everyone else, she hated it.

title: 1915: Save Hungary, Kaiser Says
description: LONDON  Latest advices received as to the situation in the Karpathians show that the Russians are solidly fortifying and extending the positions wrested from the enemy in preparation for their next big forward drive. The official communiqu issued in Petrograd to-day [April 22] says: In the Karpathians the Austrians during the day and night of April 20 endeavored to attack our position on the Telepotche-Rumina front. The enemys offensive was repulsed by our counter-attacks carried out with the bayonet. The Kaiser, reviewing his troops at Czernowitz, told them they must prevent the Russians entering Hungary. Such an event, he said, would be the end of Austria.  The New York Herald, European Edition, April 23, 1915

title: E.U. on Antitrust Case Against Gazprom
description: Margrethe Vestager, the European Unions commissioner for competition, said in Brussels on Wednesday that Gazprom was abusing its market dominance in central and eastern European member states.

title: 2015 N.F.L. Schedule Matchups to Circle on the Calendar
description: In case you missed the three-hour (!) television special that revealed next seasons N.F.L. schedule, here is a look at five games that are particularly intriguing. (Yes, two involve the Buffalo Bills.)

title: Parkour for Beginners
description: Last week, we invited 10 readers from the Well Book Club to learn parkour in New Yorks Central Park with Chris McDougall, author of the new book Natural Born Heroes.

title: Why I Love Full House and Why We Need a Sequel Done Right
description: Full House reruns have eclipsed the Disney/Nickelodeon line-up that once dominated our screen on weekends. Jessie has been replaced by Uncle Jessie, and Austin & Ally by D.J., Stephanie and Michelle.

title: The Hole Left by Tamir Rices Death
description: Five months after a Cleveland police officer shot and killed Tamir Rice, 12, his family and friends are still struggling to make sense of their loss. This video captures an intimate portrait of the lives upended by Tamirs death.

title: After Death of Tamir Rice, Pain Lingers
description: Family and friends of Tamir Rice, 12, struggle with their loss five months after a Cleveland police officer fatally shot the boy as he played with a toy gun in a park.

title: Ted Cruz, the Great Debater  Sort Of
description: A Times article about Ted Cruz on the college debate circuit touched on his preference for prepared cases, where he could examine allangles and prepare for possible attacks.

title: U.S. and South Korea on Nuclear Accord
description: The American ambassador to South Korea and the chief South Korean negotiator discussed a deal reached between the two countries that included supplying fuel for nuclear power generation.

title: Former Microsoft Executive Nancy Tellem to Join Interlude Start-Up
description: LOS ANGELES  Nancy Tellem, a longtime entertainment executive recently caught in the crosscurrents of a leadership change at Microsoft, is joining senior management at Interlude, a start-up focused on interactive music videos.

title: 1965: A Bloody Battle in Vietnam
description: SAIGON  Viet Cong guerrillas, entrenched 30 miles south of the key Da Nang air base, today [April 22] hurled back six battalions of South Vietnamese troops in a bloody battle. A U.S. military spokesman said the government forces retreated and were operating in another direction. The Communists are dug in near Viet An, a hilly area 350 miles northeast of Saigon. Only a few weeks ago South Vietnamese troops suffered heavy losses in trying to drive them out.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 23, 1965

title: Sweet Spring Confections, Courtesy of Chic French Collaborations
description: It isnt spring in Paris until the citys leading high-minded ptisseries and chocolatiers unveil their new, seasonal collections  which, more than ever, involve collaborations with top-shelf names in fashion, beauty and bubbles. Here, some of the seasons best, illustrated for T by Jessie Kanelos Weiner, an American artist in Paris.

title: In This Corner, a Dominant Heavyweight Who Creates Much Less Buzz
description: The Dempsey-Tunney fight in September 1926 got plenty of attention. A crowd reported at the time as 135,000 fans  including Charlie Chaplin, the cowboy movie star Tom Mix and the English Channel swimmer Gertrude Ederle  packed Sesquicentennial Stadium in Philadelphia for the bout.

title: James Earl Jones and Cicely Tyson Will Star in Gin Game on Broadway
description: Shes 90. Hes 84. Between them they have three Tony Awards and five nominations. But you have to go all the way back to 1966 for the last time Cicely Tyson and James Earl Jones shared a Broadway stage.

title: Helping Women and Girls. Period. Part Two.
description: Earlier this year,On the Groundpostedmy articlehighlightinghow lack of ability to afford feminine hygiene products can compromise the health, productivity and dignity of low-income women and girls in the United States. While the challenges of managing menstruation for those living in developing countries has received significant publicity,less attention has been paid to how Americas poor fare.

title: High School Students, Doing Their Teachers Taxes
description: As a teacher in the Portland, Ore., public schools a decade ago, Kary Aloveah set out to give her students lessons in some of the things that she had not learned herself. Her family didnt have much money when she was growing up, and she didnt learn much about the topic either.

title: What Were Reading Now
description: Tens of thousands of low-wage workers and activists hit the streets last week in an ongoing nationwide campaign for $15 an hour. While opponents of higher wages say a raise would cost jobs, proponents point to a new study by the Berkeley Center for Labor Research and Education that shows low wages cost taxpayers nearly $153 billion a year in government support for the working poor.

title: Pope Francis Plans to Visit Cuba This Year
description: ROME  Pope Francis will visit Cuba later this year, stopping there on his way to the United States, the Vatican said on Wednesday.

title: French Official on Foiled Church Attack
description: Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve of France said on Wednesday that over the weekend the police had arrested a 24-year-old student suspected of planning an imminent attack on at least one church.

title: Opponents of Gay Marriage Ponder Strategy as Issue Reaches Supreme Court
description: EDEN, N.C.  John G. Kallam Jr., 67, carries a worn black Bible and another copy on his iPad, and believes Scripture is unequivocal.

title: Driven | 2015 Volkswagen Jetta Hybrid
description: For fuel efficiency, Toyota is known for hybrids, while Volkswagen is known for diesel. This 2015 Jetta Hybrid, however, might surprise a few car buyers.

title: Video Review: The VW Jetta Hybrid Offers Fuel-Efficient Fun
description: WHEN it comes to hybrids, Toyota owns the market with the Prius, but drivers looking for performance find overcooked pasta more appealing. The Priuss acceleration can be measured with the Mayan calendar. Cabin quality is on par with Rubbermaid bins.

title: New York Philharmonics Challenges Go Beyond the Music
description: The New York Philharmonic, the nations oldest symphony orchestra and the former home of Leonard Bernstein and Gustav Mahler, is preparing for its greatest upheaval in decades.

title: Struggling After a Dramatic Weight Loss
description: At one time, Paul Mason was known as the worlds fattest man. Since losing two thirds of his body weight, he has struggled with the burden of excess skin, and hopes for surgery soon.

title: Losing 650 Pounds, and Preparing to Shed a Reminder of That Weight
description: ORANGE, Mass.  Once weighing 980 pounds and a contender for the dismaying title of worlds fattest man, Paul Mason lost an astonishing 650 pounds after gastric bypass surgery five years ago. But he was left with a cruel, perpetual reminder of the person he had once been: 100 or so pounds of loose skin that enveloped him like a living shroud.

title: 36 Hours in Honolulu
description: The name Honolulu can conjure up frenzied activity: exploring the sea with electric scooters, high-altitude extreme parasailing, close encounters with sharks, 40-miles-per-hour motorboat rides that guarantee youll get wet. But Honolulu can also mean mellow: the fragrance of a custom-made orchid lei, the taste and texture of a perfect tuna sashimi slice, the elegance of a hula dancer, the deepening of the blues and greens of the sea as the sun sets. Even the steel-mesh netting to prevent falling rocks is partly hidden so as to blend with the landscape. Then there is the pace, the feeling that no one is ever too rushed to give you directions, take your dinner order or explain the history of a 100-year-old banyan tree.

title: Flash Crash Case Suggests Small Problems Can Cause Systemic Issues
description: The flash crash of 2010 resurfaced with an arrest on Tuesday. Prosecutors at the Department of Justice along with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission have accused one self-employed trader in Britain of manipulating futures markets so much that he played a significant role in the events that led to the five-minute, 1,000-point plunge in the Dow Jones industrial average on May 6, 2010.

title: 36 Hours in Honolulu
description: The fragrance of an orchid lei; the taste of perfect sushi; grand island residences and the blue-green sea: This is Honolulu.

title: 36 Hours in Honolulu
description: Explore street view, find things to do in Honolulu and sign in to your Google account to save your map.

title: Elizabeth Warren Knocks Obama Over Trade Deal Transparency
description: Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts criticized the Obama administration for failing to be transparent over the trade deal it is pursuing, arguing that the White House should not keep the American people in the dark.

title: How a Kansas Cooking Club Made Its Way Into The Times
description: Newspaper editors of a certain generation still refer to a certain kind of story as one that came in over the transom. Thats because people actually used to slip documents and other tips to reporters that way.

title: The New Flygirl Blog Focuses on Women and Travel
description: Since 2007, Jezebel, part of the Gawker Media group, has been covering womens issues, and more, with a tone thats smart and a touch snarky. Thanks to Jessica Coen, the sites editor at large (and former editor in chief), it is also now home to Flygirl, a blog-within-a-blog covering travel from a female perspective.

title: Fact-Checking Can Help You Learn About Politics (True!)
description: Fact-checks of politicians statements have become increasingly prominent in media coverage of American politics. With dedicated fact-checkers like PolitiFact and recurring features in newspapers like The New York Times and news agencies like The Associated Press, more journalists are trying to assess the accuracy of claims made by public figures than ever before.

title: Ebola Drug Works Against West African Strain in Study of Monkeys
description: A study in monkeys offers the first evidence that a leading drug developed to fight Ebola works against the strain causing the current outbreak in West Africa.

title: A New Exhibition Examines Alexander Calder in Miniature, With an Assist from Santiago Calatrava
description: At a moment when art  and the social and commercial rumpus around it  seems to be getting bigger and bigger, a new Alexander Calder exhibition in Manhattan attests to the power of small details. Opening today at Dominique Lvy in Manhattan, Alexander Calder: Multum in Parvo displays more than 40 of the late sculptors miniature works, many of which have never before been exhibited. Taking its name from a Latin phrase meaning much in little, the show includes standing sculptures and mobiles that span several decades of Calders career, ranging from postage-stamp height to 30 inches tall.

title: Start-Up Blends Old-Fashioned Matchmaking and Algorithms
