description: Lauren Kay and Emma Tessler are not stereotypical start-up founders. Theyre women, for one, and neither has a technology background. In fact, Ms. Tessler is a college dropout who taught sex education in Newark, then built a teenage pregnancy prevention program in Harlem.

title: Maxim Gorki Theater Leads an Immigrant Vanguard in Berlin
description: BERLIN  Standing in her office at the Maxim Gorki Theater here, a pack of Gauloises cigarettes in hand, Shermin Langhoff gestured at an image of one of Jeff Koonss gleaming balloon sculptures hanging on her wall.

title: Milan Pins Hopes on World Expo After Graft Scandal
description: MILAN  On a recent morning, with the inauguration of Expo Milano 2015, the next worlds fair, less than two weeks away, the dominant soundtrack at the site on the far outskirts of the city was the deep rumble of heavy machinery.

title: Alex Rodriguezs Quest Is Going, Going ... Unobserved
description: DETROIT  The Yankees seem to have never met a moment they could not monetize. They scooped up the infield dirt from the game in which Derek Jeter recorded his 3,000th hit  and put it in capsules that dangled from key chains. They offered a bullpen rubber from one of Mariano Riveras last games for $15,000. When the old Yankee Stadium closed, it was sold off brick by Monument Park brick.

title: Italian Leader Urges Action for Migrants
description: Prime Minister Matteo Renzi of Italy addressed the lower house of Parliament on Wednesday in Rome and said the European Union must change its path to tackle the migrant crisis in the Mediterranean.

title: Kanye West Shakes Up Time 100 Gala
description: Time magazine celebrates its annual list of The 100 Most Influential People.

title: What Bangladeshi Garment Workers Need From the West
description: Despite corporate and government efforts to improve the safety of Bangladeshsgarment factories since the collapse of a building killed more than 1,100 workers two years ago, there is still a lot of work to be done.

title: Jeremiah Tower Leaves Tavern on the Green
description: Jeremiah Tower, the veteran chef who stepped up last fall to help rescue the faltering Tavern on the Green, has left as executive chef, the owners said Wednesday. In his place, they have hired John Stevenson, who was most recently the chef at Russ & Daughters Cafe, on the Lower East Side.

title: Drone, Possibly Radioactive, Is Found at Office of Japans Prime Minister
description: TOKYO  A small propeller-driven drone possibly tainted with radioactive cesium was discovered Wednesday on the roof of the prime ministers office, unsettling officials, who said they were reviewing antiterrorism measures in response.

title: A Sustainable Chef
description: This short documentary explains why one world-class chef overhauled his menu to emphasize sustainable ingredients.

title: Verbatim: On Not Being Ted Cruz
description: Ted Niblock, a Johns Hopkins University debater who was recruited as a protest candidate in a 1991 emergency meeting to run against Mr. Cruz, then at Princeton, for the presidency of the American Parliamentary Debate Association. Mr. Niblock won.

title: Thunderstorm in Eastern India Leaves at Least 40 Dead
description: NEW DELHI  A huge, fast-moving thunderstorm killed at least 40 people in the eastern Indian state of Bihar on Tuesday night, most of them trapped under fallen roofs or struck by falling trees and tree limbs.

title: Bruce LaBruce on Virginia Woolf and Other Influences
description: Over the course of his career, the Canadian filmmaker Bruce LaBruce has made often subversive, sometimes playful and always queer work for the big screen. And he has mined mainstream Hollywood films for inspiration along the way. Hes become known for drawing out the gay subtext in movies from Robert Altman and Billy Wilder, and bringing it to the forefront in his features Super 8 1/2 (1994), No Skin Off My Ass (1991) and Hustler White (1996). That could mean using the same dialogue, creating scenes that mimicked the originals or taking footage directly from them.

title: A Sustainable Chef
description: When it comes to sustainability, the world of fine dining has never been better. As the chefs behind the most innovative restaurants discover their increasing societal influence, were witnessing the rise of a new kind of cook  one devoted to his or her craft, wielding masterly knife skills and a deft palate, as well as a social conscience.

title: Study of Sundance Filmmakers Finds Men Get Stronger Deals at Festival Than Women Do
description: The Sundance Film Festival, a proving ground for filmmakers, helps the careers of male and female directors at a nearly equal rate, a new study found. But after that, their professional fortunes split along gender lines, with male narrative filmmakers getting stronger distribution deals early on and having an easier time ascending through the Hollywood ranks, according to data and interviews compiled over three years of research.

title: Senate Approves Stalled Human Trafficking Bill, Clearing Way for Lynch Vote
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Wednesday overwhelmingly approved a stalled bill to fight human trafficking, freeing members to consider the nomination of Loretta E. Lynch to be the next attorney general.

title: Working With Old Office Files on a New Mac OS
description: Q. Im running Mac OS 10.6.8 and want to upgrade to the new OS X 10.10 (Yosemite). When installing, I got a warning that Yosemite wont support Microsoft Office, so I stopped. Is there any way to use Yosemite and still have access to Word and Excel files?

title: We Need a Role Reversal in the Conversation on Dying
description: In most doctor-patient conversations, the doctor leads the way.

title: Euronext C.E.O. to Leave in July for French Consulting Firm
description: The stock market operator Euronext said on Wednesday that its chief executive, Dominique Cerutti, will leave in July and take the top job at Altran, a French engineering consultancy.

title: Deutsche Bank Expects $1.6 Billion in Legal Costs
description: FRANKFURT  Deutsche Bank said on Wednesday that it would incur 1.5 billion euros, or $1.6 billion, in costs from legal proceedings as reports surfaced that the bank was set to accept a record penalty for its involvement in a plan to rig the benchmark rates used to set trillions of dollars in interest rates.

title: Kanye West, Amy Schumer Shake Up Time 100 Gala
description: Time magazine celebrated its annual list of The 100 Most Influential People with a Tuesday night gala that featured a rousing performance by one of its cover subjects, Kanye West.

title: Germanys Small Towns Feel the Cost of Europes Migrant Crisis
description: VORRA, Germany  Even as European officials struggle with an unrelenting tide of migrants trying to enter the Continent, tranquil villages like this one in a picture-book valley in northern Bavaria are coping with the legions who have already arrived.

title: Bulls Jimmy Butler Knows the Drill: Work Hard, Get Paid
description: CHICAGO  The home locker room at United Center was beginning to clear out late Monday night, but Joakim Noah was waiting around.

title: At RSA Conference, Computer Security Done Right and Wrong
description: SAN FRANCISCO The annual RSA security conference here is one of the largest gatherings of computer security professionals and companies in the world. It is also an opportunity for complaining and perhaps just a bit of navel gazing.

title: Judge Approves Deal in N.F.L. Concussion Suit
description: A federal district court judge on Wednesday gave her final approval to the settlement of a lawsuit brought by more than 5,000 former players who accused the N.F.L. of hiding from them the dangers of concussions, a major step toward ending one of the most contentious legal battles in league history.

title: Backers Say USB-C Is the Cable of the Future
description: BUYING a shiny new laptop, whether its a Mac or Windows PC, often evokes both joy and dread.

title: Bill Requiring Vaccination of Children Advances in California, but Hurdles Remain
description: LOS ANGELES  A bill that would require nearly all children in California to be vaccinated by eliminating personal belief exemptions advanced through the State Legislature on Wednesday, though it still has several hurdles to clear. If approved, California would become one of only three states that require all parents to vaccinate their children as a condition of going to school, unless there is a medical reason not to do so.

title: A Trove of Pop Art and Other Works Goes to Art Institute of Chicago
description: A Robert Rauschenberg combine painting from 1955 that once belonged to his collaborator and lover Jasper Johns is among the 42 artworks that the husband and wife collectors Stefan Edlis and Gael Neeson have donated to the Art Institute of Chicago  a gift valued at nearly $500 million. The gift also features important early paintings by Mr. Johns, including a Target image from 1961 and an Alphabet painting from 1959; nine paintings by Andy Warhol; four by Gerhard Richter; and six photographs by Richard Prince and six by Cindy Sherman.

title: Shawn Mendes Is No. 1
description: Two years ago, Shawn Mendes, a high school student in Pickering, Ontario, began covering popular songs on Vine, the mobile app that specializes in six-second videos. As the videos spread online he came to be seen as the next Justin Bieber  a baby-faced crooner with a mastery of social media  and today Mr. Mendes, 16, has taken a big step in that direction with a No. 1 album.

title: New Christo Work to Temporarily Bridge Italys Lake Iseo
description: ROME  One of Italys lesser-known lakes (without American movie stars to stalk) is likely to become considerably more famous after the wrap artist Christo has his way with it. For just over two weeks, in June 2016, floating walkways lined with bright yellow fabric will create a walkway around Lake Iseo, in the Lombardy region, joining the mainland to the lake islands. The fabric will continue on pedestrian streets in two mainland towns.

title: Gazprom Faces Effects of Politics on Its Bottom Line
description: MOSCOW  European antitrust regulators are striking at Gazproms core, going after the Russian energy giants pricing policies and its politically hued control over natural gas pipelines.

title: N.F.L. Concussion Settlement Ruling
description: A federal district court judge on Wednesday gave her final approval to the settlement brought by more than 5,000 former players who accused the N.F.L. of hiding from them the dangers of concussions.

title: Indian Farmer Commits Suicide at Rally Against Narendra Modis Land Policies
description: NEW DELHI  The public suicide of a farmer at a political rally on Wednesday appeared to add momentum to the opposition to Prime Minister Narendra Modis land policies.

title: Black Men Rally for Confirmation of Loretta Lynch as Attorney General
description: At least two dozen black men showed up at the Capitol on Wednesday to demand a long-awaited confirmation vote of Loretta E. Lynch as attorney general.

title: Audi to Test Plan to Deliver Amazon Packages to Drivers Trunks
description: FRANKFURT  Almost since the invention of the automobile, people have been using cars for more than just getting from place to place. The car is also a place to eat, to sleep and soon, it appears, to receive packages.

title: First Draft Focus: Clinton Awards Presented for Advancing Women
Google Introduces Wireless Service Called Project Fi
description: Now you can Google a phone call.

title: Some Los Angeles Theaters Told by Actors Union to Pay Minimum Wage
description: The national union representing stage actors has decided to require some small theaters in Los Angeles to pay the minimum wage, despite considerable opposition from supporters of that citys thriving theater scene.

title: Whats That on Beyoncs Wrist? Let Me Guess ... an Apple Watch
description: Two weeks ago, Pharrell Williams posted an Instagram video of his Apple Watch. The clip has more than 119,000 likes.

title: Supreme Court Hears Appeal in Raisin Case
description: WASHINGTON  With scorn bordering on anger, some of the Supreme Courts more conservative members on Wednesday gave a hostile reception to a government program dating to the Great Depression meant to increase raisin prices by keeping some raisins off the market.

title: Emma Watsons Perfect 10 Ensemble at Last Nights Time 100 Gala
description: The Star: Emma Watson

title: Biking the Great Allegheny Passage
description: The 335-mile-long ride is almost entirely car-free and weaves through terrain that forms a tour of American history.

title: Biking a Trail of History from Pittsburgh to Washington
description: As we zoomed up the gentle hills of the Interstate between Washington and Pittsburgh, we passed forests, farms and urban sprawl, the kinds of vistas that usually lull you to sleep. But I was wide awake, overcome by a feeling that you usually dont have at the start of a vacation: fear.

title: Airmail via Drones Is Vexing for Prisons
description: BISHOPVILLE, S.C.  During the graveyard shift at 1:44 a.m., security cameras at the prison here picked up the blinking lights of an unidentified flying object approaching the facilitys fence.

title: Pope Francis Weighs the Bishops Role in the Sex Abuse Scandal
description: More than 700 Catholic priests had to be dismissed in a three-year period when the United States bishops finally reacted to the Churchs child abuse scandal. But noticeably absent in their accounting was any mention of disciplining themselves  the bishops and other church superiors who systematically covered up the crimes of wayward priests typically rotated on to threaten other parishes. This has remained a scandal postscript, despite the warning eleven years ago from the bishops own review panel of laity that there must be consequences for ranking prelates who engineered cover-ups.

title: Intimate Archival Images from 30 Years of the Hyres Fashion Festival
description: For its anniversary, the annual event shares photos that even include a snapshot of the elusive Martin Margiela.

title: Scott Walker vs. the World
description: On the same day that my colleague Nick Confessore reported that he might be the Koch brothers first choice for president, Scott Walker went on Glenn Becks radio show and delivered some definitely not-Koch-approved remarks on immigration. Given the reaction, theyre worth quoting in full:

title: Former Sri Lankan Minister Is Charged With Misuse of Public Funds
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka  The Sri Lankan police on Wednesday arrested Basil Rajapaksa, the countrys former economic development minister and a brother of former President Mahinda Rajapaksa, on charges of misappropriating thousands of dollars in public funds from a development program for the poor run by his ministry.

title: True Story, The Jinx and Serving Up Truth With the Imagination
description: A few months ago, at the height of Oscar season, journalists indulged in what has become an annual orgy of fact checking. Feature films like the best-picture nominees Selma and American Sniper were subjected to special scrutiny because they were based on true stories. Departures from the record were parsed and debated, then everybody moved on.

title: Globe Trotters
description: As recent immigrants find their way on New Yorks streets, their lives are often hidden to the people walking past.

title: Working Through the Past
description: In a few weeks it will be 70 years since World War II on the European continent came to an end, yet the complex questions of culpability, victimhood, shame and guilt associated with the enormous crimes of Nazi Germany continue to rise painfully and regularly to the surface.

title: Star-Studded Book Tour Planned for Judy Blumes Latest
description: Judy Blumes hotly anticipated new novel, In the Unlikely Event, is becoming quite an event of its own.

title: Review: John Pizzarelli Sings Love Songs and Sinatra at Caf Carlyle
description: The musical equivalent of Viagra: That was John Pizzarellis description of Amoroso, the Brazilian guitarist and singer Joo Gilbertos lush mid-1970s album of bossa nova love songs to which he paid tribute on Tuesday evening at Caf Carlyle. Flanked by Daniel Jobim, the grandson of the genres pioneer, Antonio Carlos Jobim, he recreated the mood of that album, minus its soaring strings, arranged by Claus Ogerman. Around me, couples were holding hands and fervently gazing into each others eyes. Some cynics might relegate Amoroso to the category of make-out music, but even within that category it has singularly cosmic dimension.

title: Home Depot Says It Will Phase Out Chemical Used in Vinyl Flooring
description: Facing pressure from consumer groups, Home Depot said it would discontinue use of a potentially harmful chemical in its vinyl flooring by the end of the year.

title: The Apple Watch Arrives in Stores (Just Not Its Own)
description: Rumors of the Apple Watchs unavailability have, it turns out, been slightly, if not greatly, exaggerated.

title: Rebuilding Lives After a Factory Collapse in Bangladesh
description: Abir Abdullah has been following the mostly young, female survivors of the Rana Plaza factory collapse as they rebuild their lives.

title: Review: Now en Espaol Uncovers a Slice of Latino Life in Hollywood
description: With the competition growing fierce to find new subjects for a seemingly limitless procession of documentaries, Andrea Mellers Now en Espaol offers a window onto an offbeat and intriguing scene. Ms. Meller, following five actresses who did Spanish-language dubbing for the ABC series Desperate Housewives, reveals a demimonde of mostly immigrant artists, some stars in their home countries, living subsistence-suburban lives around Los Angeles and doing whatever they can to keep a Hollywood dream alive. Within a profession defined by hardship, they struggle even more tenaciously than most.

title: Iowa Man Found Not Guilty of Sexually Abusing Wife With Alzheimers
description: An Iowa jury on Wednesday found Henry Rayhons not guilty of charges that he sexually abused his wife, an Alzheimers patient, by having sex with her in a nursing home after staff members told him she was cognitively unable to give consent.

title: Facebooks Growth Slows Slightly, but Mobile Shift Intensifies
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Facebook is now so thoroughly a mobile service that its original website may soon become a footnote in the companys financial statements.

title: PayPal Unit Helps Lift eBay Revenue
description: EBay is speeding toward a split of its online marketplace and payments businesses. For some analysts and investors, it cannot come soon enough.

title: Final Grateful Dead Shows to Be Offered via Pay-Per-View
description: Now Deadheads have no excuse for missing the end.

title: A Challenge From Climate Change Regulations
description: WASHINGTON  As President Obama prepares to unveil his climate change regulations on coal-fired power plants, the nations electric utilities are preparing to transform the system that keeps the lights on in America. But some companies fear that in the process, the lights may go out.

title: Troubling Interdependency of Water and Power
description: In Modesto, Calif., utility records chart an 18 percent rise in farmers energy use in 2014 compared with 2013. No evidence shows exactly why this happened, but Californias drought, now in its fourth year, sent many farmers to their wells to pump from hidden aquifers water that normally would be found at ground level.

title: New Balance of Power
description: HOUSTON  For the better part of the last century, crude oil prices have swung like a pendulum, pushing and pulling the fortunes of nations. More often than not, global supplies of the volatile commodity were controlled by the rulers of desert domains who would otherwise have been powerless had it not been for the oil that bubbled beneath their thrones.

title: Homes Try to Reach Smart Switch
description: Dustin Bond of Cottonwood Heights, Utah, trimmed his electricity bill last summer by about 40 percent thanks to the sensors and clever software of a digital thermostat.

title: A Mayors Green-Power Moonshot
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  It is no secret that Mayor Bill Finch idolizes President John F. Kennedy. He has converted a room off his office into a shrine filled with campaign buttons, banners and busts of the former president.

title: Recycling Peanuts and Cracker Jack
description: For years, sports fans have been told to put their glass bottles and aluminum cans in recycling bins at arenas and stadiums.

title: Liquid Batteries for Solar and Wind Power
description: In an industrial park on the outskirts of Pullman, Wash., 10 white storage trailers sit side by side, neatly arranged in two rows.

title: Cowboys Greg Hardy Suspended for 10 Games
description: The N.F.L. on Wednesday suspended Greg Hardy of the Dallas Cowboys for 10 games for his role in a domestic-violence case, the stiffest penalty handed out under the leagues new and stronger personal-conduct policy.

title: Storming the Barriers Around Chinas Judiciary
description: Eager to get a ruling in a long-running case where she was the plaintiff, the lawyer Cui Hui jammed her foot against a security door in a courthouse near Beijing to stop it from closing and Judge Lai Xiulin from escaping.

title: Hillary Clintons Lawyer Says No Need for Private Interview in House Benghazi Inquiry
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons lawyer told Representative Trey Gowdy, chairman of the House committee investigating the 2012 Benghazi attacks, that she saw no need for a private interview over her use of a private email account while secretary of state and asked that he not delay her next appearance before the committee.

title: Europe Looks Offshore for Wind Power
description: On the outskirts of Groningen, a medieval Dutch town near the German border, a major construction project is underway.

title: As Mad Men Ends, the Woman Behind the Costumes Is Just Getting Started
description: Janie Bryant, the costume designer of Mad Men, was standing in a cordoned-off area in the second-floor shoe department of Nordstrom at the Westfield Garden State Plaza mall in Paramus, N.J., on a recent Thursday evening, wearing a red blouse and a pencil skirt and clutching a microphone. Hello, everybody! she said over the general din of piped-in Ariana Grande and Cinnabon.

title: Julian Ungano Brings a Cinematic Eye to Fashion Photography
description: AGE 32

title: Pictures of the Day: Hong Kong and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Hong Kong, Israel, India and Hungary.

title: Jonathan Groffs Life Imitates His Art
description: Decorating is not really Jonathan Groffs thing. In the spartan living room of the actors one-bedroom apartment in Chelsea is a sofa from Room & Board, and the only reason he bought it there is because he loves The Comeback, the HBO show in which Lisa Kudrow plays a desperate actress named Valerie Cherish, who lands a role on a sitcom called Room and Bored.

title: April 22, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Hong Kong, Israel, India and Hungary.

title: Research Suggests Pesticide Is Alluring and Harmful to Bees
description: Research by European scientists raised fresh questions on Wednesday about the impact on bees of neonicotinoids, a ubiquitous and controversial class of pesticides whose future use was restricted this month by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Lilly Pulitzer for Target: They Came, They Waited, They Went Home Mad
description: Never underestimate the hunger of a barely thawed populace for a warm breeze of Palm Beach.

title: Alex Garland of Ex Machina Talks About Artificial Intelligence
description: In the last few years, Ive become increasingly fascinated by artificial intelligence, and in particular our escalating fear of it. It seemed to me that our increasingly holistic relationship with technology and abstract clouds of information was compounding this fear and perhaps edging it into paranoia.

title: Striking Archival Images from 30 Years of the Hyres Fashion Festival
description: Jean-Pierre Blanc dreamed up the Festival International de Mode in 1986, as part of a school project and case study for his business degree. He was 20 years old, and he wanted, he says, to invent a moment for creative encounters that wasnt too complicated. He ended up getting backing from his native city of Hyres, a French hillside town flanking the Mediterranean; and over several decades, the festival went from being an endeavor powered by 50,000 francs to a nearly million-euro affair. Today, the festival, which has expanded to include photography in addition to fashion, is celebrating its 30th year  more than half of my life, Blanc notes  and it still drums up enthusiasm. And having Chanel on the roster  Karl Lagerfeld is this years artistic director, and two of his colleagues at the inimitable fashion house will oversee fashion and photography  puts the festival in another orbit, Blanc says.

title: Catching Waves and Turning Them Into Electricity
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Off the coast of Western Australia, three big buoys floating beneath the oceans surface look like giant jellyfish tethered to the seafloor. The steel machines, 36 feet wide, are buffeted by the powerful waves of the Indian Ocean. By harnessing the constant motion of the waves, the buoys generate about 5 percent of the electricity used at a nearby military base on Garden Island.

title: Oil Makes a Comeback in Pennsylvania
description: It wasnt quite a Jed Clampett moment: Instead of shootin for some food, Samuel Kier was drillin for some salt in his salt wells in the appropriately named Saltsburg in Indiana County, Pa., close to Pittsburgh.

title: Balancing Costs and Competition
description: Renewable energy was never a bargain compared with fossil fuels like natural gas and coal. Steep price declines in those commodities, especially lately, make it even tougher for alternatives like solar, wind and hydroelectric power to compete.

title: Families Ditch Cars for Cargo Bikes
description: When Dave Hoverman, 38, a business strategy consultant in Berkeley, Calif., goes to Costco on the weekends, he ditches his Audi Q7 and instead loads his four children into a Cetma cargo bike with a trailer hitched to the rear.

title: The Kooples Is for Couples (Usually European)
description: The world is awash in basics. A shopper can find silk shirts, cigarette pants, cashmere sweaters and pencil skirts for a range of prices starting at $12.90 (for a little black dress at Forever 21) to $3,495 (for a little black dress by Rosie Assoulin). Stocking up on wardrobe basics is no longer a problem of availability, but one of selection.

title: Box Opens Tools for Developers, Suggesting the Future of Business Software
description: Box announced changes on Wednesday that it hopes will take it into a new phase of growth, and potentially dominance of a critical part of the new way businesses use computers.

title: Sultans of Deccan India
description: A look at a new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Review: Tim Bernes Snakeoil at the Jazz Standard
description: Theres a coolheaded but decisive tension between moment-to-moment details and the arc of a larger design in the recent music by the alto saxophonist Tim Berne. That conceptual push and pull has been a hallmark of his working band, Snakeoil, since its auspicious debut album several years ago. Still, it probably hasnt had a more potent distillation than Embraceable Me, the composition that closed the bands first set at the Jazz Standard on Tuesday night.

title: How to Get a Fresh Face for the New Season
description: Forget beauty balms. Blur products, which impart velvety finishes that diffuse the look of pores and imperfections, are the seasons new obsession.

title: Shopping Events and Sales Happening This Week in New York
description: On Thursday from 6 to 8 p.m., Viktor & Rolf will celebrate the first birthday of its haute confectionary scent, Bonbon, at Saks Fifth Avenue. With any two-piece purchase from the fragrance collection, including the new satin body powder ($80) and limited-edition eau de parfum shimmer bottle ($120), customers will receive a free sketch from the illustrator Brooke Hagel, inspired by runway looks from the fashion house.

title: A Deal From the Trials for the Venice Cup
description: The trial to select the two United States womens teams for this years Venice Cup world championship took place last week in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The 120-board second final was between Connie Goldberg, JoAnn Sprung, Linda Lewis and Disa Eythorsdottir, and Sylvia Moss, Joann Glasson, Lynn Deas, Beth Palmer, Janice Seamon-Molson and Tobi Sokolow.

title: Review: Orson Welless Last Movie, by Josh Karp
description: Orson Welles stayed away from Hollywood in the 1960s, having a laundry list of reasons to feel like a pariah. But when he returned in 1970, he found a film business newly receptive to rogue talent. It didnt get more roguish than a 350-pound former boy genius seeking to make a barely describable film-within-a-film about a great man who has lost his creative powers.

title: The Heidi Chronicles Is Trailed by Questions of Feminism and Legacy
description: Twenty-five years after The Heidi Chronicles closed on Broadway, believers in the work of Wendy Wasserstein seized an opening. In the era of Lean In and Girls, and a paucity of female voices on Broadway, they would revive Ms. Wassersteins most acclaimed play, The Heidi Chronicles, with a beloved television star, Elisabeth Moss, in the title role.

title: Review: The Unexpected Guest, From Agatha Christie, Dispenses With a Bully
description: The actors werent even onstage yet when a man behind me tried to guess the culprit in Agatha Christies The Unexpected Guest. Clues were scarce, but he deduced what he could from the set: a wainscoted room with French windows, a cane-back wheelchair parked in front of them.

title: Gregory Pardlo, Pulitzer Winner for Poetry, on His Sudden Fame
description: On an unabashedly glorious afternoon this week, the poet and essayist Phillip Lopate stood in front of a small group of graduate students in Columbia Universitys creative writing program. He took attendance, noting a few absences, before turning to a discussion about the German filmmaker Harun Farocki.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Americas Ballroom Challenge, a Dance Series on PBS
description: Dance forms evolve. Because of the phenomenal popularity that ballroom-based competitions have achieved on television, there are many thousands of people out there  including members of my family and close friends  who feel they have a good grasp of the rudiments of the rumba and the Viennese waltz, without themselves having danced much or any of them. But because I watch little television and because I briefly studied ballroom, my first reaction to what I occasionally see being done on screen (and, even more rarely, onstage) to the fox trot, the rumba and other styles tends to be one of reactionary horror.

title: Susie Caves Seaside Short List for Shopping, Antiquing and Feasting Around Brighton
description: Ever since I was a child, Ive been designing entire collections of dresses in my head. Now seems like the right time to create them, says Susie Cave (formerly Susie Bick, before she married the musician Nick Cave), the darkly drawn English beauty who modeled for Steven Meisel, Helmut Newton and Sarah Moon during the 80s and 90s. This spring, Cave brings her fashion fantasies to life with a sample collection of skirts and dresses that she calls casually opulent, in rich hues inspired by trips to the Russian ballet. Sergei Diaghilev used unusual color combinations to evoke certain emotional responses. Thats what set me off on the color trail, she explains of The Vampires Wife line, which takes its gothic moniker from an unwritten novel by her husband. Im so happy he let me have that name, says Cave, who hopes to launch a complete spring/summer 2016 collection in the fall. I love that it sounds quite serious and dark, and yet the collection is bursting with color.

title: Tsarnaev Seen Making Obscene Gesture
description: In surveillance video captured from his holding cell, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the man at the center of the Boston Marathon bombing trial, is seen making a hand gesture to the camera.

title: After Jury Sees Gesture by Boston Marathon Bomber, Defense Tries to Blunt Its Meaning
description: BOSTON  The defense team for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev on Wednesday tried to blunt the shock value of an incendiary photo that the prosecution showed the jury of him thrusting his middle finger at a security camera three months after the bombing.

title: Obama Talks of Climate Change in Florida
description: President Obama spent Earth Day in Everglades National Park, where he spoke about the threat of climate change in Florida.

title: Pitorro, Anyone? Craft Distilleries and Breweries Take Hold in South Bronx
description: On family trips to Puerto Rico, Rafael Barbosa got a taste for his uncles pitorro: a potent concoction made from sugar cane in a crude backyard still.

title: Their Futures So Bright
description: This is the tale of a bipartisan fist bump between senators in shades.

title: Promising Full College Credit, Arizona State University Offers Online Freshman Program
description: Arizona State University, one of the nations largest universities, is joining with edX, a nonprofit online venture founded by M.I.T. and Harvard, to offer an online freshman year that will be available worldwide with no admissions process and full university credit.

title: Funding Circle Raises Another $150 Million
description: LONDON  Funding Circle, the British peer-to-peer lender, announced on Wednesday that it had raised $150 million in financing that valued the company at roughly $1 billion.

title: Appeals Court Overturns Barry Bondss Only Conviction
description: After years of investigations and court proceedings in the performance-enhancing drug case involving Barry Bonds, baseballs home run king, federal prosecutors were able to pin only one obstruction of justice conviction on him.

title: Grief Mixes With Anger Over Christian Ethiopian Deaths
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia  In a downtrodden neighborhood called Cherkos, not far from the headquarters of the African Union, an olive-green tent stands as a tangible symbol of this nations grief.

title: Ships Captains Call for Uniform Policies on Migrants at Sea
description: LONDON  As a growing number of migrants and refugees travel to Europe by land, air or, most tragically recently, by sea, southern countries of the European Union like Greece and Italy face the largest burdens, and Bulgaria, a newer member, has rebuilt walls to keep out illegal migrants.

title: Traders Arrest in Flash Crash Raises Concerns About Market Rigging
description: The arrest of a little-known futures trader this week drew back the curtain on one of the pernicious-sounding practices that have been linked to the distortion of global financial markets.

title: White House Seeks to Publicly Mend Fences With Netanyahu, but Issues Remain
description: WASHINGTON  As President Obama sat with Jewish leaders at the White House last week, trying to reassure them of his deep commitment to Israel, some wanted to know whether he would soon invite Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu for an in-person visit.

title: Turning Over a New Leaf, New York Assembly Pushes Paper Out and Adopts Tablets
description: ALBANY  Charging headfirst into the modern world  sort of  the New York State Legislature went partly digital on Wednesday, as the Assembly established itself as an electronic chamber, complete with tablet computers, touch screens and exceptionally limited web-surfing options.

title: Boeing Droops as Dreamliner Jet Fails to Deliver
description: Boeings stock fell by 1.4 percent on Wednesday after the company reported that it had generated less cash in the first quarter than most analysts had expected.

title: A.I.G. Bailout Lawsuit Trial Ends as It Began, With Most Issues in Dispute
description: WASHINGTON  The unusual trial of Maurice R. Greenbergs $40 billion lawsuit against the government ended on Wednesday in much the same way it started, with both sides presenting starkly different narratives about the 2008 taxpayer bailout of the American International Group.

title: New York Citys Environmental Goals Draw Praise, and Questions on How to Fulfill Them
description: As Mayor Bill de Blasio on Wednesday released a long-term blueprint for the city  calling on New Yorkers to send no waste to landfills by 2030, and aiming to lift 800,000 people from poverty or near-poverty in a decade, among other far-reaching goals  attention turned quickly to a follow-up question.

title: Disney Joins in Criticism of Verizons Cable Plan
description: The dispute between Verizon and some of the most popular and prominent TV networks escalated on Wednesday when Disney said that the new, slimmer FiOS cable offering violated agreements with all of its cable networks.

title: Richard C. Holbrookes Diary of Disagreement With Obama Administration
description: WASHINGTON  In the summer of 2010, Richard C. Holbrooke, the Obama administrations special representative for Afghanistan and Pakistan, began recording a secret audio diary, detailing his frustrations with a White House that he believed was too willing to listen to the military and too often mistook domestic political calculations for strategic thinking.

title: As War Grinds On, Yemenis Share Their Anguish Online
description: As a Saudi-led coalition continued to launch airstrikes against Houthi rebels in Yemen, one day after the operations name was changed from Decisive Storm to Renewal of Hope, online dispatches from Yemeni bloggers and activists were filled with anguish over the growing toll of the conflict.

title: Guardrail Maker Is Said to Be Focus of U.S. Case
description: The Justice Department has begun a criminal investigation of the guardrail maker Trinity Industries and is examining the companys relationship with the Federal Highway Administration, according to people with knowledge of the effort.

title: Opening Salvos in a Condiment War, and the Hot Dog Is the Battlefield
description: Like the Gingham Dog and Calico Cat, Heinz ketchup and Frenchs mustard have side by side in the condiments aisle sat for more than a century.

title: Comcast Critics Cast Doubt on Its Intentions
description: CHICAGO  David L. Cohen stood between the rappers Ludacris and Chance on stage in the gymnasium of Alcott College Prep high school here one afternoon last month, holding up one of the dozen laptops they were giving away to the roaring crowd. The scene was like a pep rally for the Internet: Students waved posters emblazoned with Comcasts logo and the hashtag #InternetEssentials.

title: Few People Lost Jobs With V.A. in Scandal
description: The nationwide scandal last spring over manipulated wait times at Department of Veterans Affairs hospitals led to the ouster of the secretary of veterans affairs and vows from the new leadership that people would be held accountable.

title: M.H. Abrams, 102, Dies; Shaped Romantic Criticism and Literary Bible
description: M. H. Abrams, who transformed the study of Romanticism with the critical histories The Mirror and the Lamp and Natural Supernaturalism, and who edited the first seven editions of The Norton Anthology of English Literature, a virtual Bible in literature survey courses, died on Tuesday in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 102.

title: Putin Bolsters His Forces Near Ukraine, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON  In a sign that the tense crisis in Ukraine could soon escalate, Russia has continued to deploy air defense systems in eastern Ukraine and has built up its forces near the border, American officials said on Wednesday.

title: Video Feature: Apps to Kindle the Imagination
description: Nearly everything in our daily lives is driven by rules, habits and social norms, which can stymie creative habits at work or elsewhere. Dont panic: There are apps to help ignite that spark.

title: App Smart | Spark Creative Thinking
description: A host of new apps are available to jump-start creative thinking or spark new ideas.

title: Swimmer Braves Brooklyns Gowanus Canal, a Superfund Site
description: Like most people who have heard anything about the Gowanus Canal  of its murky sludge, oil slicks, raw sewage, carcinogenic chemicals and dying dolphins  Christopher Swain strongly advises against swimming in it.

title: Betty Willis, Whose Fabulous Sign Defined Las Vegas, Dies at 91
description: Betty Willis, a commercial artist whose 25-foot-high neon sign blazingly and irrevocably linked Las Vegas with fabulousness, died on Sunday at her home in Overton, Nev. She was 91.

title: Cameras on Calbuco: In Chile, Volcanos Eruption Caught in Extraordinary Time-Lapse Videos
description: The endless, but spasmodic, dynamism of Earths crust produced extraordinary scenes in Chile, and across the Web, this week as the Calbuco volcano, quiescent for 42 years, powerfully erupted.

title: Review: Something Rotten!, an Over-the-Top Take on Shakespeare
description: Unchecked enthusiasm is not always an asset in musical comedy, despite the genres reputation for wholesale peppiness. Something Rotten!, the rambunctious new show that opened on Wednesday night at the St. James Theater, dances dangerously on the line between tireless and tedious, and winds up collapsing into the second camp.

title: More Than a Joke
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE Nothing brings people together like a good one-liner.

title: Sony Pictures Announces Plan for Animated Spider-Man Movie
description: Sony Pictures Entertainment has a new idea  or maybe a very old one  for its sticky superhero, Spider-Man: Hes going graphic, with an animated feature.

title: Jury Reviews the Testimony of Etan Patzs Childhood Friend
description: A Manhattan jury deciding the fate of a man charged with murdering Etan Patz in 1979 asked on Wednesday to review the testimony of Etans childhood friend, who saved a seat for him on the school bus the day he disappeared.

title: Walking New York
description: Sonny Rollinss favorite corner of the Williamsburg Bridge. The best can-collecting route in Bushwick. See New Yorkers most memorable walks in the city, and contribute your own.

title: Dog Bites Police Horse in Brooklyn
description: A pit bull attacked a police stallion in Brooklyn on Wednesday, biting him on the chest and the leg, the police said.

title: Harlem Man Is Found Guilty of Assault for Stabbing Officer in the Head
description: A Harlem man with a history of schizophrenia who stabbed a police officer in the temple was found guilty of assaulton Wednesdayat State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Nets Cant Sink Shot to Stay Out of Hole
description: ATLANTA  With just over 10 seconds remaining on the game clock, Deron Williams had an opportunity to salvage yet another untidy individual performance, to silence for just a moment all the talk that his game has become too passive.

title: Mets Rally Past Braves to Extend Their Streak to 10 Games
description: When Curtis Granderson drew a walk to lead off the eighth inning at Citi Field on Wednesday, the reaction from his teammates demonstrated the confidence that this team, the one with the best record in baseball, is starting to exude.

title: Season 3 Finale of The Americans: More Secrets, Lies and Torture
description: The jig is not up, not yet. But the third season of FXs The Americans ended on Wednesday night with the disclosure that the series superspies, Philip (Matthew Rhys) and Elizabeth (Keri Russell), have been dreading  and dodging  since the very first episode.

title: Review: British and American Ballets Showcase Youthful Blend of Style and Skill
description: A heady amalgam of youthful beauty, charm and skill flooded the Ailey Citigroup Theater on Tuesday during a 90-minute program shared by the Royal Ballet School and American Ballet Theater Studio Company: a showcase of the pre-professional skills of young dancers at a very high level.

title: Broadchurch Season 2 Finale Recap: Alec and Ellie Forever
description: In the penultimate episode of this season of Broadchurch, Claire Ripley asks Ellie Miller why shes so insistent on finding the Sandbrook killer. It brings peace to the families involved, Ellie answers.

title: The Americans Season 3 Finale Recap: Enter Evil Empire
description: Season 3, Episode 13: March 8, 1983

title: Once Again, Rangers Edge the Penguins
description: PITTSBURGH  Looking for his first career playoff goal, the rookie Kevin Hayes missed the net on an excellent scoring chance that would have tied the game midway through the second period. Given another opportunity, Hayes came through  sending the Rangers to the brink of the Eastern Conference semifinals.

title: Mayor de Blasio Revives Plan for a Utica Avenue Subway Line
description: Among the far-reaching ambitions of Mayor Bill de Blasios OneNYC plan, one proposal stood out in the transportation world on Wednesday: the study of a new subway line along Utica Avenue in Brooklyn.

title: Democrats Are Rallying Around $12 Minimum Wage
description: WASHINGTON  Democrats in Congress are uniting around a proposal to raise the federal minimum wage to $12 an hour.

title: A Snowy Trudge Yields a Big Win for the Yankees
description: DETROIT  Wednesday was a miserable night for baseball  38 degrees and snow flurries. Most players wore balaclavas under their caps and bundled up in the dugout. Pitchers warming up in the bullpen may have been a loose interpretation.

title: Things Are Looking Up for Mets Fans
description: Supporters of the team are energized as the Mets approach a three-game series this weekend with the Yankees, the crosstown rivals who usually overshadow them.

title: Donations to the Clinton Foundation, and a Russian Uranium Takeover
description: Uranium investors gave millions to the Clinton Foundation while Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clintons office was involved in approving a Russian bid for mining assets in Kazakhstan and the United States.

title: Never-Before-Seen Portraits of Marilyn Monroe, Lee Radziwill and More, From a Photographic Legend
description: In this weekly series, Ts photo editors share the most compelling visual projects theyve discovered.

title: Word of the Day | discount
description: discount  \dis-kaunt\  noun and verb

title: Cash Flowed to Clinton Foundation Amid Russian Uranium Deal
description: The headline on the website Pravda trumpeted President Vladimir V. Putins latest coup, its nationalistic fervor recalling an era when its precursor served as the official mouthpiece of the Kremlin: Russian Nuclear Energy Conquers the World.

title: Mercedes-Benz to Pay Fine in China to Settle Price-Fixing Claims
description: HONG KONG  Chinese antitrust regulators on Thursday fined Mercedes-Benz 350 million renminbi, accusing the company of fixing prices on luxury cars and some spare parts. The penalty is just the latest for a foreign carmaker in China, the worlds largest auto market.

title: Police Fatally Shoot Man Said to Fire at Officers in Queens
description: A man was shot and killed by police officers in Queens on Wednesday night after he fired a gun inside a bar and at officers who pursued him, the police said.

title: Freddie Gray Was Injured in Police Van, Baltimore Officers Lawyer Says
description: A Baltimore man who died after sustaining a spinal injury in police custody was hurt while riding inside a police van, the lawyer representing the officers in the case said Wednesday.

title: A Collision Crosses the Line for the Islanders
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  When John Tavares, the Islanders usually mild-mannered captain, is seething, playoff hockey must be in full bloom.

title: Whats on TV Thursday
description: 1:30 A.M. (Flix) THE MAGDALENE SISTERS (2002) Four Roman Catholic Irish teenagers (Anne-Marie Duff; Dorothy Duffy; Nora-Jane Noone; and Eileen Walsh) are sentenced in the late 1960s to toil in convent laundries run by the Sisters of the Magdalene as punishment for sexual misconduct in this semifictional story. (The existence of these religious labor camps, which 30,000 women are thought to have endured, came to light in the 70s with the discovery of the unmarked graves of some who lived there; the last laundry was closed in 1996.) Geraldine McEwan plays Sister Bridget, the twisted head nun  with a soft spot for The Bells of St. Marys and John F. Kennedy  who turns into a demon if her rules are flouted. The Magdalene Sisters would be too painful to watch if it didnt have a silver lining, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times about this drama, which was written and directed by Peter Mullan and won the top prize at the Venice Film Festival. Suffice it to say that it is possible to fly over this religious cuckoos nest and remain free. All it takes is courage and the timely kindness of strangers.

title: Foot Soldiers
description: Finding unexpected beauty in the hands of shoe shiners.

title: Corrections: April 23, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Quotation of the Day
description: He was an extreme fan of the Les Misrables soundtrack.

title: Rebuilding Lives After a Factory Collapse in Bangladesh
description: An hour after the Rana Plaza garment factory collapsed in Dhaka, Bangladesh, Abir Abdullah got to the scene unsure where to begin taking pictures. More than a thousand people had died and hundreds more were trapped alive in the rubble. Injured workers were screaming and crying all around him as rescue workers pulled bodies from the debris.

title: Armenians and Genocide
description: To the Editor:

title: Its Time to Regulate E-Cigarettes
description: WHEN the federal government announced last week that youth e-cigarette use tripled in just one year, surpassing the use of traditional cigarettes, the reaction was appropriately strong. A wake-up call, said one commentator, echoing others.

title: Bill de Blasio and Hillary Clinton
description: To the Editor:

title: The Missing Black Men
description: To the Editor:

title: Wind Energys Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Disputing Anti-Semitism Claims at Stanford
description: To the Editor:

title: Beyond Education Wars
description: For the last dozen years, waves of idealistic Americans have campaigned to reform and improve K-12 education.

title: The Perils of Smokeless Tobacco
description: The makers of smokeless tobacco products like to claim that their products are safer than cigarettes because users dont inhale the tars and toxic chemicals from burning tobacco. Of course, they play down other harms and risks, which are also potentially dangerous. For federal regulators, protecting public health will require looking beyond the smoke to other hazards.

title: Chinas Big Plunge in Pakistan
description: President Xi Jinping of China showed up in Pakistan this week with one of his governments most powerful weapons  money, and lots of it. He signed agreements worth more than $28 billion as part of a total promised investment of some $46 billion in a new Silk Road, an ambitious land-and-sea-based economic corridor connecting China to Europe and the Middle East through Pakistan, Central Asia and Russia.

title: Bobby Jindal: Im Holding Firm Against Gay Marriage
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  THE debate over religious liberty in America presents conservatives and business leaders with a crucial choice.

title: Eat Up. Youll Be Happier.
description: PARIS  MY father-in-law, an anthropologist, likes to talk about the time he ate dog penis. He was visiting a remote town in South Korea, and the mayor invited him to lunch. Once theyd finished the dog soup (not a big deal), a waitress carried out the boiled penis on a silver plate. The mayor cut it lengthwise with scissors, then served half to each of them.

title: The Importance of Good Principals
The Independent Women of Sweet Briar
description: Anna Chao Pai is the granddaughter of a Chinese warlord whose family inverted the usual immigrant trajectory when they arrived in this country in the 1940s.

title: 6 Qs About the News | The Giant Rats That Save Lives
description: In The Giant Rats That Save Lives, Nicholas Kristof writes about an innovative program using trained animals to address human problems.

title: A Fixer-Upper in Riverdale
description: Nearly three years ago, Renee Nelson, a high school math teacher at a charter school in the Bronx, moved back to Ossining, N.Y., where she had grown up.

title: Finding Easier Ways to Charge Electric Vehicles
description: Jeremy McCool is convinced there is a better way to charge electric vehicles in a crowded city than using a wired plug.

title: Senate Confirms Loretta Lynch as Attorney General After Long Delay
description: WASHINGTON  After one of the nations most protracted cabinet-level confirmation delays, the Senate Thursday approved Loretta E. Lynch to be attorney general. She is the first African-American woman to hold the position.

title: Why You Cant Put Faith in Reports of First-Quarter Economic Slumps
description: We have heard this story before: The recovery gathers momentum, but then as the new year gets underway, the reported pace of growth in gross domestic product stalls.

title: Do Machines Represent a Threat to Humans?
description: Last year Stephen Hawking, one of the worlds pre-eminent scientists, suggested: Artificial intelligence could be a real danger in the not-too-distant future. It could design improvements to itself and outsmart us all. Maybe villainous sentient computers like those depicted in The Matrix and 2001: A Space Odyssey arent so far-fetched after all. Or, if you are skeptical of killer robots, its hard to ignore the real possibility that machines might be replacing humans in the work force at a growing rate.

title: Ukrainian Refugees, Lost and in Limbo
description: Over a million people have been forced to flee their homes because of the war in Ukraine. Many of these internally displaced people have struggled to find a new life.

title: The Stanwicks, One of the First Families of Lacrosse, Find the Ties That Bind
description: The Stanwicks are considered one of the first families of lacrosse. All eight of Wells Sr. and Dori Stanwicks children, including Shack, the Johns Hopkins freshman attackman who was the No. 1 recruit in the country, have played or are playing in Division I. Yet throughout their careers, the Stanwicks have been in the minority, woven together by a common thread: a leather-strung stick.

title: A Population Uprooted by Ukraines War Struggles to Get By
description: DNIPROPETROVSK, Ukraine  Valeria Huseva fled her home in Luhansk last July during heavy fighting between pro-Russian separatists and Ukrainian military forces.

title: Black Mayor Is Voted In and a Small Towns Staff Empties Out
description: PARMA, Mo.  It was about a week after Tyus Byrd made history by being elected the first black mayor of this rural hamlet that things started getting weird.

title: An Unfamiliar Feeling for Mets Fans: Optimism
description: Ask a group of Mets fans to name the worst moment of the teams 53-year history and brace for a lengthy exercise in one-downmanship, as they argue the relative horrors of bad trades, blown leads and terrible performances on the field and at the plate.

title: Hidden Armenians of Turkey Seek to Reclaim Their Erased Identities
description: DIYARBAKIR, Turkey  For the first 25 years of his life, Armen Demirjian thought he was Kurdish. Then the elders in his village told him his familys secret: His grandfather was Armenian, a survivor of the genocide carried out by the Ottoman Turks a century ago.

title: Review: Sultans of Deccan India, Unearthly Treasures of a Golden Age, at the Met
description: Human beings may excel at making things, but destroying them is equally a specialty. The second skill has given the history of art many tantalizing mysteries, remnants of cultures whose achievement is unmistakable yet fragmentary, limited by extensive losses resulting from accident, neglect or war.

title: Test Yourself | Kids and Social Skills
description: Here are several paragraphs from an April 17 article, Hey, Kids, Look at Me When Were Talking.

title: Eurozone Economy Grows for 22nd Straight Month, Report Shows
description: PARIS  The eurozone economy expanded for a 22nd consecutive month in April, a private sector report showed on Thursday, but the modest pace of growth disappointed some analysts looking for more vigor resulting from the European Central Banks bond-buying program.

title: Inducing Labor at Full Term May Have Benefits
description: Inducing labor in normal full-term pregnancies has generally been frowned upon, but a new study suggests that induction causes no apparent harm, and may have advantages.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: New York Today: Ask for a Poem
description: Good morning on this dappled Thursday.

title: Daily Report: Facebooks Earnings Underline a Shift to Mobile
description: Facebook is now so thoroughly a mobile service that its original website may soon become a footnote in the companys financial statements, Vindu Goel reports.

title: Behind the Making of Our Walking New York Cover
description: What you see on the cover of this weeks New York Times Magazine is real. The image is by the French artist JR, who is known for pasting giant photographs on urban surfaces all over the world. About six weeks ago, we met with JR to discuss a project for our Walking New York issue. Lately, JRs work has been preoccupied with the theme of immigration. An installation at Ellis Island features large archival photographs of immigrants displayed throughout the islands abandoned hospital.

title: JR Brings New Yorks Immigrants Out of the Shadows
description: For more than a decade, the French artist JR has been pasting outsize portraits onto urban surfaces in Parisian banlieues, Nairobi slums, So Paulo favelas. His subjects: the locals, the not-famous, the threatened and the threatening, figures in the margins. Their monumental, expressive faces glued to buildings suggest  in ways that a buildings simple face cannot  that a citys people are its infrastructure too, or are at least inseparable from it.

title: Timelapse: A Walker in the City
description: A behind-the-scenes look at how the French artist JR created a large-scale pasting in the triangle below the Flatiron Building for the Walking New York issue of The New York Times Magazine.

title: The Rat Paths of New York
description: Most New York animals stay close to home. Yes, itinerant coyotes will traverse the parks by night, and raccoons might travel half a mile in search of better trash, skunks a little less. But feral cats wont stray three blocks beyond where they were born, and few mice will venture more than a hundred feet from their burrows in a lifetime. Rats seldom stray far from home, either. But they get where theyre going more easily than other New York animals, because they are more like us. The city suits them.

title: The Secret Slang of the Diamond District
description: The public face of New Yorks diamond district is Diamond and Jewelry Way, a block of 47th Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues lined with dazzlingly lit shops and exchanges and cluttered by hawkers, hustlers, cops and couriers. But beyond these street-level operations, in back rooms, upper floors and looming towers, toils an army of cutters, blockers, polishers, sorters, appraisers, graders, designers and dealers  most of whom the diamond-buying public never sees.

title: Whats Wrong With Inequality?
description: This interview, the third in a series on political topics, discusses philosophical ideas that underlie recent debates about inequality. My interviewee is Elizabeth Anderson, a professor of philosophy and womens studies at the University of Michigan. She is the author of The Imperative of Integration.  Gary Gutting

title: Lee Friedlander Captures the Citys Hustle and Flow
description: If youre walking around New York with the intention of taking photographs, you notice how different the city looks every few steps. Your progress is not a line, direct or winding, from one point to another, but a flickering series of scenes. A street is not only its tarred surface, the buildings alongside it, the cars fast or slow, the people around you. It is also the way those things relate to one another, the way they combine and recombine. As some elements slip out of view, new ones become visible: You are moving, the cars are moving, other people are moving, even the sun is moving, slowly, and in the middle of this movable feast you must decide when to press the shutter, decide which of these rapidly refreshing instants is more interesting than the others around it. A second before, it has not yet arrived. A second later, it is already gone. Henri Cartier-Bresson called it a joint operation of the brain, the eye and the heart.

title: How Do We Protect New York Citys Pedestrians?
description: When a car hit John Longo as he crossed Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn in December 2013, he was tossed skyward, high and far enough that he had time to contemplate his flight. I remember thinking, Ive been in the air too long, says Longo, whose 230-pound, 47-year-old body landed 20 feet from where it started. He does not remember hitting the asphalt (he landed on his head), but he recalls stumbling to a slender median dividing Atlantic and saying out loud, to no one in particular, Please let me live, please let me live. He was bleeding from the back of his head, but he felt little pain, only a numbness in his arm, which was the first clue, paramedics eventually told him, that he probably had spinal damage.

title: Escape to the L Train
description: I was 14 when I found out about the Canarsie L, the subway line whose lone gray train would take you from Brooklyn to Manhattan. In Manhattan, you didnt have to be Orthodox if you didnt want to be, no matter what your mother said; you could date boys without intending to marry them, you could wear lipstick and eyeliner, even both at the same time. But I wasnt allowed to ride the train. It took a half-hour to walk to the subway stop, and youd have to walk through Canarsie  ungentrifiable, unimprovable Canarsie  past a lot of questionable landmarks. There was the convenience store where my mother sent me to buy Kents, and whose clerk would ask if Id like a lighter, then offer me one with a photo of a naked lady on it. And the pharmacy, which was also maybe a methadone clinic, where I picked up my mothers still-prescription-only nicotine patches for use during the Sabbath, when she wasnt allowed to smoke. And the public high school, rife, my mother told me, with sex-crazed boys and drugs.

title: The History of a City Underfoot
description: What is a great walking city? For most of human history, every city was a walking city, in the sense that walking was the only way to get around  unless you were a pasha accustomed to being carried about on a palanquin. Now that we have mechanized palanquins  cars  New Yorks prideful pedestrianism might be its last old-fashioned virtue.

title: The Reunion
description: The longest walk I ever took in New York City was on a winters afternoon in December, five miles along Ocean Parkway with my father. This was 30 years ago, and we were, I suppose, trying to jump-start something, namely, a relationship. We were also trying to avoid any mention of what had been, until then, my fathers almost complete absence from my life, beginning when I was 9 months old. Now I was 18, and my father, newly arrived in Brooklyn, by way of Iran, was living in an apartment in Kensington with his bride, who was 20 years his junior, which is to say 20 years my mothers junior.

title: Street Romance
description: In the late 1970s, I was newly married, living in a fifth-floor walk-up on 107th Street and Riverside Drive. In those early days, my wife, Eileen, and I discovered that despite all there was to do in the city on Saturday nights, the thing we liked most was to stay home and cook for each other. We owned two cookbooks; the one we favored was Northern Italian Cooking, by Francesco Ghedini (an intensely serious cookbook whose heartsick, newly widowed author committed suicide before completing it). Our favorite Ghedini recipes were heavy on pork sausages. If you were going to buy pork, that meant you went to Espositos pork shop on Ninth Avenue and 38th. You went nowhere else. So on Saturday afternoons, I would start at our apartment and walk south, entering Riverside Park on 107th, crossing over on 96th and then continuing in the park all the way down to 72nd. In my memory of those walks, it is always late afternoon in autumn, the sun is just visible through a mesh of thick, darkening clouds: that time of day and weather that evokes young, headstrong New York to me.

title: Can King
description: I didnt just start doing this in one day, you know. It takes time to work it out: finding out which route produces, when to go. Thats whats going to turn you a profit. I live on Graham, near Montrose, so I usually start my morning there. I love to see the sun early in the morning. I usually get up at 4, 3:30, 2:30, and I exercise, I work out. I sit at the piano, do scales and all that. Take a shower, and, fwoosh, Im gone.

title: Special Delivery
description: I get to the New Dorp station around 8 every morning, and I sort my mail. Then around 10, I start my route on Mill Road. It takes maybe six and a half hours to cover the whole loop, and then, depending on overtime, Ill pick up pieces of another route. Sometimes Ill cover six or seven miles, depending. I know everything about where Im working. You know where all the cracks are. You dont have to look down. Its your route.

title: The Old Haunts
description: During the summer of 2001, I regularly drove from where I lived upstate, in Putnam County, to Lower Manhattan. Armed with historical maps, I would walk the streets, occasionally bumping into people. In a sense, I was not really there but rather in the same place 350 years earlier. As part of my research for a book about New Yorks origins, I was trying to locate the Dutch city of New Amsterdam on the grid of the financial district.

title: The Walking Cure
description: My father was a great walker. It was his only sport and his only pastime, if you dont count reading or going to synagogue. He recalled walks the way some people recount epic ballgames, marathon strolls he accomplished as a young man when he and his friend Fred, a refugee like him, would wander from Washington Heights to Greenwich Village and back again.

title: Speed Date
description: In my third New York apartment, which represented an achieved dream  an affordable prewar two-bedroom on 100th and West End, with wood floors and views outside every window  an inexplicable terror set in me. I dont know, even now, what caused those periods of short circuit, when I trembled on my bed, staring for hours at the gargoyles on the neighboring rooftop, but I have an idea of what made them eventually diminish and then subside.

title: Among the Rockets
description: My mother and father lead the way, holding my little sisters in their arms. I run ahead, excited. Its summer, and the streets of Corona swell with Muslims  men and young boys in new salwar kameez, sent special from family in Pakistan; women and girls, too, in reds, aquas and silvers, the kind usually found in the tails of mermaids and peacocks. We are headed early in the morning to Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, to celebrate Eid al-Fitr. For the month of Ramadan, we fasted from sunrise to sunset, spending our days in spiritual remembrance. Now we rejoice  eat sweets, give gifts and offer a communal prayer.

title: A Boys Dream
description: We lived on Sheridan Avenue, one block east of the Grand Concourse, a middle-class Mecca of apartment houses that had scalloped cornices and lintels with a nautical flavor, as if the buildings themselves sat in a solitary sea of gold. We didnt have doormen on Sheridan Avenue, hardly even an elevator.

title: The Power Walker
description: Robert Caro sometimes thinks about Robert Moses on his walk to work. For nearly 40 years, Caro has been working on his magisterial biography of Lyndon Johnson (four volumes and counting). But the stamp of Moses, the subject of Caros 1974 biography, The Power Broker, still in print, is inescapable in the city where Caro has lived  and walked  for most of his life. Moses displaced at least 250,000 people to build expressways, Caro likes to point out, and another 250,000 for slum clearance and urban renewal. Half a million New Yorkers. If you were talking about a European dictator, youd call it one of the greatest forced migrations in modern history.

title: One for the Road
description: This was my journey for four years. About 12 of us traveled from Queens to Rice, a Catholic school in Harlem. Wed get off the train at 125th and Lexington. Up here was way different from Queens. In Queens, we had houses. Up here, you aint got no houses and no backyards. Queens was a lower-middle-class suburb. So Harlem was a big culture shock.

title: First Time Out
description: It never occurred to me that my 8-year-old son could walk to school alone until the morning I spotted his friend Hal blithely strolling down the block in our Cobble Hill neighborhood in Brooklyn. I turned my head to look for the hovering parent. Nobody. Thats odd, I thought, imagining an unusually chaotic morning in which the parents threw up their hands and said, O.K., just this once.

title: Editorial Contest Winner | Redefining Ladylike
description: We are honoring each of the Top 10 winners of our Second Annual Student Editorial Contest by publishing an essay a day, in the order of submission.

title: Restaurant Report: Athlete Eats in St. Louis
description: The foods we Americans eat while watching sports are rarely the ones eaten by those playing it. But for Simon Lusky, team chef for the St. Louis Cardinals, theres no reason they couldnt be.

title: Hotel Review: Noon Hotel Apartments in Dubai
description: One-bedroom suites from 450 dirhams ($122 at 3.67 dirhams to the dollar) in low season, up to 1,000 dirhams in high.

title: Without Her
description: I had walked the 15 or so blocks between the Newkirk Avenue subway station and my parents house in East Flatbush for 25 years, but never with such a sense of dread. My mother had recently died of ovarian cancer, and I wanted to revisit that stretch of Avenue D that she and I had sauntered, strolled and marched along together throughout much of my life. I wanted to see if she would still be walking these same streets  alone, invisibly, without me.

title: In Amsterdam, Loving Rembrandt Again
description: Although Rembrandt lived and worked in Amsterdam starting in late 1631 and died there in 1669, its fair to say that he has never proved to be the same kind of tourist draw as another Dutch painter, Vincent van Gogh, or the diarist Anne Frank, even though all three of them have dedicated museums in the city. But in recent months the 17th-century Dutch masters life and work, particularly his final years, have been getting a reappraisal.

title: How a Gambling Addict Became a Bookie
description: BERKELEY, CALIF.  During a recent trip to Los Angeles, a traffic jam forced me to reroute through Culver City. How could I not take a few minutes to see what had become of 10136 Venice Boulevard?

title: Sax and Sky
description: In the late 1950s, I moved into a loft on Grand Street between Clinton and Suffolk. I used to go to Ratners to pick up pastries for my wife, Lucille. On her way home from work, she used to visit a man named Izzy and his wife, who ran a pickle store on Suffolk near Grand. We bought our chickens at a kosher butcher next door. We were welcomed on the Lower East Side, as an interracial couple. The rest of the world isnt like that. Thats a special place.

title: How to Walk in New York
description: A walk in New York is different from a stroll in most other cities. The pace and purpose on these streets are signs of the citys true self.

title: Home, Cooked
description: For my parents, who immigrated from Hong Kong in the 1970s, leaving Chinatown was how you knew you had made it in America. They worked there for 20 years in the garment industry  so that I would never have to, they insisted  but every night they made their proud exit to the New Jersey suburbs. Meanwhile, at school, I was hiding my stinky lunches from my American friends and hoping they wouldnt hear our alien language.

title: Alone After Dark
description: Nothing felt right when I opened the door to our apartment that evening. The lights had been turned down, and the steady current of contentment that ran daily through the place seemed muted by some invisible dimmer. I could see my boyfriend, the man Id been living with for six months, lying gravely on the couch, his body splayed out, hands folded over his stomach in a funereal pose. Candles flickered everywhere, wicking away at some truth in the air. Ever since, I havent trusted candles. Theyre always masking something.

title: City of 10,000 Steps
description: To walk is to take one step after another; to put out a special issue called Walking New York is to want to start counting all those steps being taken. So the magazine rounded up a random cross-section of New Yorkers and asked them to spend a single workweek wearing a Fitbit wristband, which tracks steps taken and miles traveled. Heres how the subjects measured up against the 10,000 daily steps recommended by health officials.

title: Today in Politics: The Lynch Drama Nears Its Final Act
description: Good Thursday morning from Washington. President Obama gave a climate change speech in Florida on Wednesday for Earth Day, but Speaker John A. Boehner had something else on his mind. Martin OMalley, the former Maryland governor, uses trade against Hillary Rodham Clinton, but most eyes in Washington are on the Senate, where a long-delayed vote is at last on the to-do list.

title: The Geographically Impossible West Village
description: I love to explore cities by walking. My hometown was planned from scratch in the 18th century. Every street is perfectly perpendicular.

title: Collecting Child Support Without Making Matters Worse
Throwback Thursday | Yankee Stadium, the Loch Ness Monster, Coney Island, Postal Cats and More
description: PDF of original 1923 article

title: Chinese Company Says It Never Planned a Thugs for Hire App
description: At first, it seemed like a brilliant marketing plan. Perhaps it still is.

title: Morning Agenda: Comcast Deal Could Be Waylaid by Hearing
description: COMCAST DEAL COULD BE WAYLAID BY HEARING | The staff of the Federal Communications Commission has recommended that the agency put the Comcast-Time Warner Cable merger before an administrative law judge, a procedure that could be a deal-killer, The Wall Street Journal reports, citing people familiar with the matter.

title: Jane Fonda and Lily Tomlin, Together Again, in Grace and Frankie
description: LOS ANGELES  Were not spring chickens, Jane Fonda said on a recent spring morning.

title: Deutsche Bank to Pay $2.5 Billion Fine to Settle Rate-Rigging Case
description: They called each other dude, mate and amigo, suggesting a certain innocence to their friendship. And yet at the center of their dispatches, United States and British authorities say, was actually a collusive effort to manipulate worldwide interest rates.

title: Greeks vs. Independents: My Daughters Battle, Not Mine
description: Of all of the useful and useless, fretful and hopeful, entirely unsolicited pieces of advice I tossed at my daughter as she was preparing to start her freshman year in college, I was most serious and adamant about this one:

title: K.K.R. Posts Weaker First-Quarter Profit
description: The private equity giant Kohlberg Kravis Roberts on Thursday posted slightly weaker first-quarter profit as it deals with more modest growth.

title: The Ice God Hears You
description: Dear Diary:

title: Why Athletic Brands May Be the Greenest Fashion Sector
description: Spending the last few weeks poking around sustainability and supply-chain issues in the fashion world for my column, I was struck by one thing in particular: Athletic brands seemed to lead other fashion sectors when it came to the various sustainable companies indexes. (I know, I know, sounds like a fun way to spend the weekend.)

title: G.M. Reports Strong Sales and Higher Profit
description: DETROIT  General Motors, the nations biggest automaker, said on Thursday that its net income climbed to $945 million in the first quarter on the strength of vehicle sales in its core North American market.

title: Olen Steinhauer: By the Book
description: The author, most recently, of All the Old Knives says the best espionage stories not only ask questions about how spying is performed, but they also question the value of the job itself.

title: Europes Promised Action on Migration Crisis Is Criticized as Inadequate
description: BRUSSELS  Struggling to cope with a growing migrant crisis in the Mediterranean, European leaders promised on Thursday to triple their spending on border protection and approved plans to intensify efforts to root out smugglers boats before they could set sail, among other measures.

title: Obama Apologizes After Drone Kills American and Italian Held by Al Qaeda
description: WASHINGTON  An American aid worker and another man held hostage by Al Qaeda were killed in an American drone strike in Pakistan in January, government officials disclosed on Thursday, underscoring the perils of a largely invisible, long-distance war waged through video screens, joysticks and sometimes incomplete intelligence.

title: Karl Ove Knausgaards My Struggle: Book 4
description: The last time I was in New York, Karl Ove Knausgaard wrote recently in The New York Times Magazine, in his account of traveling through the United States, a well-known American writer invited me for lunch. ... I tried desperately to think of something to say. We had to have something in common, we were about the same age, did the same thing for a living, wrote novels, though his were of considerably higher quality than mine. But no, I couldnt come up with a single topic of conversation. ... When we got back to Sweden, I received an email from him. He apologized for having invited me to lunch, he had realized he never should have done it and asked me not to reply to his email. At first I didnt understand what he meant. ... Then I realized he must have taken my silence personally. He must have thought I didnt find it worth my time talking to him.

title: Unforgettable Hubble Space Telescope Photos
description: On the eve of the 25th anniversary of the launch of the Hubble Space Telescope, we asked astronomers and others involved in the telescopes groundbreaking story to tell us about their favorite images.

title: An Exclusive Arrangement on a Clinton Book, and Many Questions
description: A sentence in an article this week about a new book critical of the Clinton Foundation stopped a lot of Times readers cold.

title: David Petraeus Is Sentenced to Probation in Leak Investigation
