But music and poetry mingle with equal force in The Night Dances, an hourlong collaboration between the renowned English actress Charlotte Rampling, who gives transfixing recitations of poems by Sylvia Plath, and the adventurous French-American cellist Sonia Wieder-Atherton, playing selected movements from the Suites No. 2 and 3 for solo cello by Benjamin Britten.

title: Chinas President to Meet With Head of Taiwans Governing Party Next Month
description: HONG KONG  President Xi Jinping of China, who is also general secretary of the Chinese Communist Party, will meet next month with the chairman of Taiwans governing party in Beijing, both sides said on Friday, in what would be the first meeting of the two parties leaders since 2009.

title: Its Barcelona vs. Bayern Munich and Juventus vs. Real Madrid in the Champions League
description: Barcelona was drawn against Bayern Munich on Friday for the Champions League semifinals, matching Bayern Coach Pep Guardiola against the club he led to two European titles. Real Madrid, the defending champion, will play the two-time winner Juventus in the other semifinal.

title: Lurid & Cute, by Adam Thirlwell
description: Hate may be too strong a word, but the unnamed narrator of Adam Thirlwells clever new novel, Lurid & Cute, is definitely easy to dislike. The dauphin, as he refers to himself, doesnt possess the gentrified ickiness of Humbert Humbert or the acidic anger of Nora Eldridge, the central character in Claire Messuds recent novel, The Woman Upstairs, yet hes equally  and wonderfully  detestable. Decadent and arrogant, he displays his own cringe-inducing brand of entitled and pathetic obnoxiousness.

title: I Refuse, by Per Petterson
description: The Norwegian novelist Per Pettersons new book, I Refuse, opens with a startling event, a rare spike of adrenaline in this meditative and melancholy story. Jim is driving through the pre-dawn, heading to the Ulvoya suspension bridge (fishing off the bridge is the one thing that gives his life any shape), when a figure plunges into the road. Jim, braking, is certain the man has been injured, but no: He steadies himself against the hood. For a moment I thought it was my father. But it wasnt my father. I had never seen my father. The man lurches off without a word; Jim, a little shaken, drives on to his usual fishing spot, where a short time later, he is recognized  though the two have not met for 35 years  by Tommy, commuting to work in his new Mercedes.

title: Its a Bird! Wait.
description: Dear Diary:

title: Hubble Reflects the Cosmos
description: After 25 years, the Hubble Space Telescope is still surprising us. Hubble has been called the most important advance in astronomy since Galileo, and its greatest discoveries might still be ahead.

title: 25 Years Later, Hubble Sees Beyond Troubled Start
description: Against all odds, its 25 years in space and counting for the Hubble Space Telescope this month.

title: Under Regulators Scrutiny, Comcast and Time Warner Cable End Deal
description: When Comcast announced its $45 billion takeover of Time Warner Cable in February 2014, the notion that television viewers would have the freedom to pay for exactly what they wanted to watch and how they wanted to watch it seemed like something that might be possible in the distant future.

title: Romanticizing the Reader
description: The best thing about a book tour is meeting your imagined readers, staring into their lamplit faces, hearing a little about their lives and, for a slender moment anyway, feeling the reciprocity of your trade.

title: Terrorist Cell May Have Sought to Attack the Vatican, Italian Officials Say
description: ROME  The Italian authorities arrested nine people on Friday and said they were part of a Qaeda-linked terrorist cell based on the island of Sardinia that the police have been watching for years.

title: China, in Suspending Womans Death Sentence, Acknowledges Domestic Abuse
description: BEIJING  In an acknowledgment of the problem of domestic abuse in China, a court on Friday suspended the death sentence of a battered woman who had killed her husband, a case that drew international attention and a petition from hundreds of Chinese lawyers and feminists urging the court to reconsider.

title: Tate Modern Director, Chris Dercon, to Step Down
description: LONDON  The director of Tate Modern, Chris Dercon, will step down in 2017 to lead the Volksbhne, one of Berlins five major theaters.

title: Lives of the Scientists
description: WE COULD NOT FAIL

title: After Frank Gehry and Louis Vuitton Comes Renzo Piano and MaxMara
description: Hire the architect, make the handbag? Such was the case, anyway, when Frank Gehry designed the Fondation Louis Vuitton in Paris and then became part of the brands special The Icon and the Iconoclasts: Celebrating Monogram collaboration last fall. (He made a structured curvy triangular not-quite-picnic-basket-like bag in the classic LV leather.) And such is the case this month as the new Whitney Museum by Renzo Piano is unveiled in New York  along with a new Whitney bag by MaxMara, a presenting opening sponsor.

title: The Mad Boy, Lord Berners, My Grandmother and Me, by Sofka Zinovieff
description: It isnt every host who would rejoice over a guest who signed herself into his visitors book as a procureuse de luxe. But Lord Berners of Faringdon House was not any old host and his guest  the bewitching Lady Castlerosse, famed for the Cleopatra grip with which she could bring even a resolutely homosexual Cecil Beaton to ecstatic climax  was not any old visitor.

title: The Longest August, About India and Pakistan, by Dilip Hiro
description: In the summer of 2009, as the clouds of Taliban violence thickened over Pakistan, I bumped into a senior army general at a polo game. We were in Shandur, a spectacular grassy arena in the Hindu Kush mountains, watching local horsemen play a rambunctious version of the genteel sport.

title: Sing, O Muse
description: This month is the 20th anniversary of National Poetry Month. If the celebration is partly intended to encourage poetrys engagement with contemporary culture, two young poets reviewed in this issue are doing their part.

title: Shawn Mendes and the 6-Second Path to Stardom
description: Shawn Mendes has a retort for those who knock Vine  the popular mobile app for six-second videos  as a creative medium.

title: Remembering the Armenian Genocide
description: Descendants of survivors - Turks and Armenians - share their families' stories.

title: Whats On This Week Around the World
description: Buenos Aires

title: Review: DorotheaRschmann and Mitsuko Uchida in Recital
description: In 1847, the German Romantic poet Joseph von Eichendorff told Clara Schumann that the lieder settings by her husband, Robert Schumann, had given life to his poems for the first time. Clara replied that, on the contrary, Eichendorffs poems gave life to the music.

title: An Arranged Marriage With a Back Story
description: Garima Pant and Manas Pant got married after her father showed her a profile of Manas that he found on a marriage website.

title: Transforming Indias Concept of Marriage
description: In India, urbanization, education and the rise of matrimonial websites are challenging centuries-old traditions of arranged marriage.

title: Websites in India Put a Bit of Choice Into Arranged Marriages
description: NEW DELHI  For thousands of years, fathers in India have arranged the marriages of their children, and Garima Pant  like an estimated 95 percent of her millennial peers  was intent on following this most Indian of traditions.

title: Editors Choice
description: GOD HELP THE CHILD, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $24.95.) Child abuse cuts a jagged scar through Morrisons novel, a brisk modern-day fairy tale with shades of the Brothers Grimm, and a blunt moral: What you do to children matters.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE TASTEMAKER: Carl Van Vechten and the Birth of Modern America, by Edward White. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $17.) A sexually complicated man from a well-to-do Iowa family, Van Vechten (1880-1964) was a patron of the Harlem Renaissance, a photographer who captured the eras most iconic figures, and a novelist who created some of the Jazz Ages most salacious stories. White deftly balances the many lives of this cultural impresario.

title: Eurozone Ministers Admonish Greece for Slow Progress on Overhauls
description: RIGA, Latvia  Eurozone officials sharply criticized the Greek government on Friday for moving too slowly on steps to overhaul the countrys economy that they say would be necessary to get debt relief and to avoid a default.

title: College for the Masses
description: Growing up in Miami in the 1990s, Carlos Escanilla was a lot more interested in hanging out with friends and playing music than in school. The son of immigrants from Chile, he slogged through high school with a C+ average and scored about 900 out of 1,600 on the SAT. I was convinced I was going to be a famous rock star, Mr. Escanilla, now 36, said.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Runners, Rabies and Dampened Emotions
description: Take the Quiz

title: Push, Dont Crush, the Students
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  PALO ALTO HIGH SCHOOL, one of the nations most prestigious public secondary schools, is sandwiched between two stark and illusory paths. Across the street to the west, Stanford University beckons as the platonic ideal, a symbol of the road to Google, the White House, the mansion on the hill. To the east, across a bike trail, are the railroad tracks where three boys from the school district have killed themselves this year.

title: Noninvasive Cosmetic Surgery Can Deliver Confidence, at a Cost
description: PHILIP FEAR, a radiologist, has helped build a physicians group in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., to over 20 doctors. And his successful practice means that he is often asked to give lectures to medical groups.

title: Warriors 20-Point Comeback Fueled by Offensive Rebounding
description: The Golden State Warriors had a superb season. But one area in which they did not particularly shine was offensive rebounding percentage, ranking a rather pedestrian 21st.

title: Inside the List
description: The Power Brokers: As a longtime political journalist for ABC News and a contributor to NPRs Morning Edition, Cokie Roberts regularly dissects the power dynamics of modern-day Washington. As an author, though, shes demonstrated a special regard for the farther reaches of American history and its behind-the-scenes players  especially, in best sellers like Founding Mothers and Ladies of Liberty, the political wives of the early Republic. Now she looks back to the Civil War era in Capital Dames, new on the hardcover nonfiction list at No.10. These women were lobbied by favor-seekers or bill-passer-seekers or just individuals, she said recently on NPR. They would be the person who had the ear of the powerful man more than anyone else. ... Its really remarkable how much we do the same things century in, century out. You recognize their concern about their children; you recognize their interest in fashion; you recognize the jewelry that theyre wearing. Mary Lincolns pearls were on display at the Library of Congress the other night; I would have loved to take them out of the case and put them on. But you also recognize their intelligence and their political sensibility. All of this inevitably calls to mind a terrific play that ran at Lincoln Center last year, The City of Conversation, by the underappreciated novelist and playwright Anthony Giardina, tracking several decades in the life of a fictional capital dame. Were an arm of the government, you might say, Giardinas stalwart heroine declares of Washingtons hostess class. Or we were. And will be again.

title: Schedule Wonder
description: Im pretty obsessive about our family calendar.

title: Ted Cruz Event in New York Prompts Boycott Threats
description: The two gay hoteliers whose duplex on Central Park was the site of a small dinner this week with Senator Ted Cruz are facing boycott threats to their properties.

title: Drone Strikes on Al Qaeda Are Said to Take Toll on Leadership in Pakistan
description: LONDON  Revelations of new high-level losses among Al Qaedas top leadership in Pakistans tribal belt have underscored how years of American drone strikes have diminished and dispersed the militant groups upper ranks and forced them to cede prominence and influence to more aggressive offshoots in Yemen and Somalia.

title: Clinton Rules
description: So theres a lot of buzz about alleged scandals involving the Clinton Foundation. Maybe theres something to it. But you have to wonder: is this just the return of Clinton rules?

title: Video Reviews of The Water Diviner, The Age of Adaline and Dont Think Ive Forgotten
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on The Water Diviner, The Age of Adaline, and Dont Think Ive Forgotten. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: 1915: Fighting With Poisonous Gas
description: Fighting the Allies with poisonous, asphyxiating gases, in violation of The Hague conventions, the Germans forced back the French lines to the north of Ypres on Thursday [April 22], but in a brilliant counter-attack on Friday, the French, supported by British and Belgian troops, recovered part of the ground lost and continued to advance. The big battle raged all Friday night and at dawn yesterday.

title: David Alvarez on Billy Elliot, the Army, and On the Town
description: Are you O.K.? the choreographer Joshua Bergasse asked his newest dancer during a recent rehearsal for On the Town at the Lyric Theater. Do you want to breathe for a minute? Take a minute. Get some water.

title: Blurry Fiscal Hindsight
description: Simon Wren-Lewis continues his voice in the wilderness campaign against British economic myths, focusing on claims that Labour was fiscally profligate. Needless to say, I agree, and would like to enlarge on his points.

title: Navigating the Thickets of Student Loan Counseling
description: As a former student loan borrower himself, President Obama has more than a passing familiarity with the complexities of higher education finance. But in a little-noticed bit of comment last year in an interview with David Karp, the founder of Tumblr, he issued some pointed criticism of the advice that students get on the way into college.

title: Stuff We Liked
description: Were confining what we liked on the web this week to two topics: inequality, for you serious folks, and emoji, for those who are less so.

title: Salt Cod With an Iberian Point of View
description: Salt cod is comfort food on the Iberian Peninsula, where it is called bacalao in Spain or bacalhau in Portugal. Whatever its name, I have always been a fan.

title: As Cognition Slips, Financial Skills Are Often the First to Go
description: WHEN Helen Clark brought her father-in-law, then 83, to the doctor last year, she knew his mind was slowing, but a mental status exam confirmed it. He knew the year, where he lived and the name of the president. But when the doctor asked him to count backward from 100, subtracting seven from each number  100, 93, 86, 79  a look of confusion washed over his face.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: In Defense of the Listicle
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Mass Murder in Norway
description: This week, Eric Schlosser discusses Asne Seierstads One of Us; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Meghan ORourke talks about Elizabeth Alexanders The Light of the World; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Niche Trade in Lamb Pelts Offers Afghans Economic Lifeline
description: Last year, Finland imported nearly a half-million Afghan lamb pelts, auctioning them off to be turned into luxurious womens coats, among other items.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Mass Murder in Norway
description: This week, Eric Schlosser and Meghan ORourke.

title: Digging Into Ted Cruzs Debating History: Reporters Notebook
description: The lives of presidential candidates are long  especially the older ones!  and full of details of uncertain interest to readers. The trick to a successful bio story is finding a part of their lives that is inherently interesting, relevant to their current pursuit and reportable. I thought an article about Ted Cruz and his debating career at Princeton might be just this kind of story.

title: Mylan Raises Its Offer for Perrigo, Which Rejects It
description: The drug maker Mylan on Friday raised its unsolicited offer for Perrigo, the Irish maker of store brand drugs, as it seeks to fend off its own unwanted suitor in Teva, the Israeli pharmaceutical company. But Perrigo quickly rejected the revised bid.

title: Streaky Mets Can Set a Modern Record With a Sweep in Next Home Series
description: Long-suffering Mets fans are feeling pretty good about taking the 7 train to Citi Field this year; in 10 home games, the team has not yet tasted defeat.

title: A Brooklyn Storefront Hid an Artists Decades of Work
description: For as long as people in the neighborhood could remember, the storefront at the corner of Seventh Avenue and 11th Street in Park Slope, Brooklyn, had been empty.

title: 1940: Discussion Over Greenland
description: LONDON  The position of Greenland as affected by the German occupation of Denmark is now under consideration by the British government in consultation with that of Canada, Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs Richard Butler told the House of Commons this afternoon [April 24]. The announcement followed a statement by Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain on the British attitude toward the foreign possessions of neutral states which might be invaded by Germany. The Prime Minister obviously had Denmark and Holland in mind.

title: Oklahomas Options Now That State and Federal Scientists Confirm Big Earthquake Impact from Water Disposal
description: Earlier this week,Oklahomas state geologist and state seismologistissued a statement that should largely end debates about the causes of a recent burst of seismic activity in that state. They said it was very likely that several thousand weak tomoderate earthquakes in recent years were triggered by deep-earth injection of water extracted from the ground as thousands of wells have beendrilled into shale oil and gas deposits.

title: Tell Us What You Think
description: Thanks for using The Timess app on the Apple Watch. Please tell us what you like about it, and what you want to see.

title: Cinnamon Raisin Swirl Bread
description: There is sweetness coiled in every bite of this moist white bread.

title: Suddenly, a Police Presence Comes to Brooklyn Bridge Park
description: On Tuesday evening in a sparsely occupied church basement near Downtown Brooklyn, a young police officer named Lauren Jones received an award, Cop of the Month, at a community affairs meeting of the 84th Precinct. If you suddenly lost track of where you were, you might have concluded that you were somewhere in Vermont or northern Minnesota, in a town populated by aging eccentrics and distinguished largely by amusing nuisances. The citation was presented to Ms. Jones by Leslie Lewis, the president of the precinct community council, who is in his late 80s, for the officers work retrieving a wallet that had been stolen from an open locker at a nearby Y.M.C.A. and making the appropriate arrests.

title: Economists Actually Agree on This: The Wisdom of Free Trade
description: If Congress were to take an exam in Economics 101, would it pass? We are about to find out.

title: Jonathan Franzen Ruffles Feathers Again
description: The music is creating a mood, the author Jonathan Franzen said, and Im not sure I like it.

title: White Bread Thats Beyond the Ordinary
description: If you want a loaf of truly excellent white bread, youre probably going to have to bake it yourself.

title: Cheaper Robots, Fewer Workers
description: This is the first episode in a Bits video series, called Robotica, examining how robots are poised to change the way we do business and conduct our daily lives.

title: Faster, Stronger and Cheaper
description: China faces rising labor costs and a shortage of workers. But a government project called replacing humans with robots is trying to change the face of the work force in Guangdong Province.

title: After He Beat Floyd Mayweather Jr., They Said, O.K., Now Do It Again
description: LAS VEGAS  In the industrial area behind Circus Circus, where tourists do not venture intentionally, is a squat concrete-block building that houses Barrys Boxing Center. Inside, high on a wall crowded with framed photographs of boxers, familiar and not, is the defeated face of Floyd Mayweather Jr.

title: Judge Robert Sweet, 92, Finds Balance on the Ice and the Bench
description: Dont think youre going to see an Olympic performance, warned Robert W. Sweet, 92, as he sat on a rink-side bench lacing up a pair of black figure skates at Chelsea Piers Sky Rink on Tuesday morning.

title: Boxings Broadcast Firsts
description: From Thomas Edison to Showtime, some of the key dates in boxings broadcasting history.

title: At Londons V&A, Defining Luxury  and Predicting Its Future
description: A new exhibition at the museum brings together more than 100 gorgeous objects (and contextualizes them).

title: Pelicans Anthony Davis Considers Adding a 3 to His Arsenal
description: NEW ORLEANS  Anthony Davis punctuated his activity at the Pelicans shootaround on Thursday morning by spotting up from the corner, where he took pass after pass from an assistant coach. Davis sank six of his final eight attempts, all from beyond the 3-point line. His release was effortless, the ball traveling in a pleasant parabola.

title: Victim of Extremists Comes to Understand the Siren Song of ISIS
description: AARHUS, Denmark  FROM his earliest years, Ahmad Walid Rashidi says he harbored a seething hatred against the Taliban, the extremist Sunni group that dominated Afghanistan before 2001 and the United States invasion.

title: Movie Review: The Age of Adaline
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews The Age of Adaline.

title: Review: Dont Think Ive Forgotten
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Dont Think Ive Forgotten.

title: Putting an End to a Bad Comcast Merger
description: Comcasts decision to walk away from its $45 billion deal to acquire Time Warner Cable is good news for consumers. A merger of the nations two largest cable companies would have created a telecom giant with tremendous power as a gatekeeper to entertainment and the Internet.

title: Christies Wife Leaves Job, Making His 2016 Run More Likely
description: Chris Christies wife, Mary Pat, has stepped down from her high-paying job at an investment firm as her husband prepares for a likely presidential run, the New Jersey governors aide said on Friday.

title: Worker Killed at Manhattan Hotel Construction Site
description: A 40-year-old worker was killed in a construction accident in Midtown Manhattan on Friday, the authorities said.

title: Movie Review: The Water Diviner
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews The Water Diviner.

title: Regret Over a Drones Deadly Damage
description: For years, the Obama administration has kept its drone strikes shrouded in great secrecy, knowing that what have been described as precision attacks on terrorist targets have also killed innocent civilians. So it was important to see candor and remorse from President Obama in his apology for the killing of two hostages held by Al Qaeda, an American and an Italian, in a drone strike near the Afghanistan-Pakistan border in January.

title: At Londons V&A, Defining Luxury  and Predicting Its Future
description: Design stirs debate in a new exhibition opening tomorrow at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London. What is Luxury? draws together more than 100 objects, both historical and contemporary, in a tightly edited show with broad ambitions: setting out to define the meaning of luxury while predicting its possible futures. At a time when the symbiosis of major museums with fashion and commerce has never been stronger (the V&A is concurrently showing the blockbuster exhibition Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty), it is apt  if a little surprising  that this temple of decorative art treasures should interrogate the very aesthetic on which it was founded back in 1852.

title: Poland Bars Russias Night Wolves Motorcycle Club
description: WARSAW  The Polish Foreign Ministry said Friday that it would deny entry to several dozen members of a Russian motorcycle club closely tied to the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, who had planned to pass through Poland on their way to commemorate the end of World War II in Berlin on May 9.

title: Turkeys Focus Is Elsewhere on Anniversary of Armenian Genocide
description: ISTANBUL  On the day that Armenians from around the world came here to commemorate the killing and forced expulsion of their ancestors by the Ottoman Turks a century ago, Turkish officials chose to focus on a different centennial, that of their countrys most important military victory.

title: Homes for Sale in Connecticut and Long Island
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City region:

title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Brooklyn
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: The Continuing Debate on Ted Cruz, a Competitive Friend
description: On the college debate circuit, Ted Cruz was the debater many opponents loved to hate. But among some of his teammates at Princeton, he came to be seen as a leader and a friend.

title: In Israel, Migrants Find a Home, Through Running
description: A team of young runners includes migrants from Eritrea, Sudan, Nigeria, Russia and Ukraine. Hebrew is their shared language.

title: Lindsey Graham Warns G.O.P. Not to Sell Hillary Clinton Short
description: A number of Republican presidential hopefuls insist that Hillary Rodham Clinton has been badly damaged over the last few weeks in her second quest for the White House.

title: Landmark Status for Corcoran Gallery of Art Interior
description: Much of the interior of the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington was designated a historical landmark on Thursday over the objections of George Washington University, the buildings owner.

title: How to Appeal College Financial Aid Offers
description: By now, most prospective college students have received their letters of acceptance and are weighing their financial aid packages. But what if the financial aid offer at your preferred school isnt what you had hoped?

title: Apple Watch Has Landed  Heres What You Need to Know
description: Apple released its much-anticipated Apple Watch on Friday, but the gadget isnt for sale inside Apple Stores just yet. Instead, Apple let people order the watch online, for deliveries that began Friday, so customers will be spending more time tinkering with their new watches this weekend instead of standing in line.

title: Ragtime Team and Gentlemans Guide Director Join For New Musical
description: The Tony Award-winning director of A Gentlemans Guide to Love & Murder is teaming up with the writers of Ragtime fora new musical which will open at the regional theater where he is the artistic director.

title: The Week in Political Pictures
description: President Obama travels to Florida for Earth Day, congressional leaders make nice, and sons and daughters go to work.

title: Flights Suspended After Chile Volcanos Ash Moves Into Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES  International flights into Argentina were halted on Friday as winds swept a sprawling volcanic ash cloud toward Buenos Aires, the capital. American Airlines and Delta Air Lines were among the carriers affected by the cloud, and they suspended their flights from the United States into the main airport in Buenos Aires. The Calbuco volcano in southern Chile, which borders Argentina, violently erupted this week for the first time in half a century, spewing ash miles up into the sky and setting off lightning bolts. After Chilean officials evacuated thousands of people from the surrounding area, the ash cloud wrought havoc as it drifted across the Andes, causing airport, road and school closings in Argentinas provinces, and jeopardizing a gubernatorial election scheduled for Sunday. Calbuco is expected to continue erupting, the head of Chiles state geology service said Friday.

title: Praise Be to Amy Schumer, Ray-Bans vs. Rand Paul and Christian Louboutins Nudes
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: Nursing Homes Are Starting to Supplant Hospitals as Focus of Basic Health Care
description: Israel Sapoznick doesnt do well in hospitals.

title: Police Killing of Unarmed Man Agitated New York ... in the 1850s
description: Officer Robert Cairnes was on patrol in the old First Ward when he was summoned to a ship at the foot of Wall Street to search for a one-eyed longshoreman known as Sailor Jack, accused of threatening to murder the captain.

title: Verbatim: No Looking Back for This Cabinet Member
description: Eric H. Holder Jr., on his last day as attorney general, taking off two black Free Eric Holder wristbands during his farewell speech. The bands became a joke within the Justice Department because of the delayed confirmation of his successor, Loretta E. Lynch.

title: Googles Eric Schmidt Plays the Adult in D.E. Shaw Investment
description: Eric E. Schmidt, the executive chairman of Googloe, is reprising the adult supervisory role he played with Googles founders.

title: A Snowy Service Brimming With Warmth
description: Carolyn Ethridge and Gregg Anderson were married on April 5 on the top of Aspen Mountain.

title: Video of Italian Terrorism Suspects
description: The Italian police released a video on Friday showing the arrest of several suspects in Sardinia officials said were thought to belong to a terrorist network.

title: The Daily Grind
description: Skateboarding New York

title: Migration Crisis Puts Europes Policy Missteps Into Focus, Experts Say
description: CATANIA, Sicily  To human rights advocates, one of Europes biggest mistakes in the Mediterranean migration crisis came last November with the shutdown of the Italian patrol and rescue program known as Mare Nostrum. Led by the Italian Navy, the program saved thousands of migrants at sea.

title: Foot Soldiers
description: Finding unexpected beauty in the hands of shoe shiners.

title: The Cost of Buying Someones Soul. Or Tweets.
description: YOU never forget your first time. Mine was 13 years ago, just after my first book came out in paperback. My literary agent called and said Id been asked to be a campus ambassador for a brand of feminine-protection products. Naturally, I had questions.

title: The Airline Industry Posts a Giddy First Quarter
description: There was an unmistakable shift in tone in the airline industry this week as the nations top carriers all reported record earnings because of lower fuel prices and strong demand for domestic air travel.

title: Wynn Resorts Shareholders Back Move to Remove Elaine Wynn From Board
description: LAS VEGAS  Shareholders of Wynn Resorts on Friday rejected the bid by Elaine P. Wynn, co-founder and former wife of the chief executive, Stephen A. Wynn, to remain on the companys board, ending the most public and awkward proxy battle in the companys 13-year history.

title: The Top 25 Draft Picks in 1990
description: Photos to fill Listy showcasing where the top 25 picks from the 1990 N.F.L. draft are now.

title: Tequila Is Getting Company: Sotol, Bacanora and Raicilla
description: The cocktail menu at Cosme, Enrique Olveras acclaimed Mexican restaurant in the Flatiron district, has a curious category: other agaves. At Tijuana Picnic, a restaurant on the Lower East Side, Jim Kearns, the bar manager, lists a flight of extended family spirits made from agave.

title: Saudi Arabia Says ISIS Helped a Militant Who Killed Police Officers
description: GAZIANTEP, Turkey  A militant who is accused of killing two police officers in Riyadh, the capital of Saudi Arabia, in a drive-by shooting on April 8 acted with support from the Islamic State militant group in Syria and had served time in a United States jail, Saudi officials said Friday.

title: Alabama Town Loses Rights to Produce Play of To Kill a Mockingbird
description: In a plot twist fitting of the stage, a Monroeville, Ala., museum that produces a theater adaptation of Harper Lees novel To Kill a Mockingbird, announced that it has lost licensing rights to the play indefinitely after this year.

title: A Glimpse Inside Public Housing
description: Most New Yorkers know what public housing looks like from the outside, but Project Lives goes into the interiors of the buildings.

title: Endive, Served Hot
description: Belgian endive is a vegetable often served as is, uncooked and delicious. But this week Martha Rose Shulman brings the heat with a new recipe of seared endive that can be enjoyed as a main course.

title: Residents Photographs Depict Life in New York City Projects
description: The first picture Znya Mourning took was of her dining room table at the Bailey Houses in the Bronx. She snapped it with an orange-and-red disposable camera she had received through Developing Lives, a participatory photographic project run in consultation with the New York City Housing Authority. She liked the way the chandelier was reflected in the serving bowl. She was 10.

title: The 10 Most Cost-Effective Renovations
description: High-end, major remodeling projects dont always offer the most favorable return on investment when you sell your home. Lower-cost but highly visible changes can often do more to increase profits in a sale, as Tim McKeough writes in this weeks cover story in the Real Estate section. Here are some simple improvements that may offer the most bang for the buck.

title: Bill Cunningham | Mercurial
description: The city parks and lawns exploded with magnolias, and the long-lost spring coat reappeared for the capricious weather.

title: Kamasi Washington and the West Coast Get Down
description: Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss the tenor saxophonist and his roots in the thriving Los Angeles jazz scene.

title: Orthodox-Friendly Asana
description: A yoga studio and gym in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, offer Hasidic women and their children places where they can exercise and remain within the bounds of their religious practice.

title: Water Restrictions for Californias Farms: Just the Beginning?
description: Californias water board sent curtailment notices to over a thousand water-rights holders on Thursday, ordering them to stop diverting water from the San Joaquin River and Scott River watersheds. The curtailments are a necessary step to limit agricultural water use in the state, but Californias farms may have to give up far more before this drought is over.

title: Gym and Yoga Studio in Brooklyn Cater to Hasidim
description: On the top floor of a brownstone, a dozen women were getting ready for a yoga class at the Space, a fitness studio in Crown Heights. Each woman removed her wig and replaced it with a bright scarf in one swift, fluid movement.

title: Gifts in Green for Spring
description: Items for couples who arent afraid to get their hands dirty.

title: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
How Maxwell Ryan of Apartment Therapy Spends His Sunday
description: Maxwell Ryan is the founder of Apartment Therapy Media, which owns apartmenttherapy.com and thekitchn.com, design and lifestyle websites that claim a combined monthly viewership of about 38 million. Mr. Ryan, 49, grew up on East 78th Street and now lives in a two-bedroom rental on Lafayette Street in SoHo with his 8-year-old daughter, Ursula Gillingham-Ryan.

title: Los Angeles Jazz With Kamasi Washington and Others
description: A few weeks ago, the jazz tenor saxophonist Kamasi Washington stood onstage at a club in Hermosa Beach, Calif., with his band, the Next Step, ending a version of the ballad standard My One and Only Love with an improvised closing tag, like a group cadenza.

title: Bill Cunningham | Mercurial
description: The city parks and lawns exploded with magnolias, and the long-lost spring coat reappeared for the capricious weather. Outstanding examples included a reptile-skin trench, an embroidered coat and one with a lace-scalloped hem. Women in colorful attire ran a half-marathon.

title: Bedazzled Sandles
description: The humble shower slide has ascended to high fashion, with crystal beading, golden grommets and a metallic sheen.

title: Popcast: Kamasi Washington and the West Coast Get Down
description: The tenor saxophonist Kamasi Washington, whose first album The Epic comes out on May 5th from Brainfeeder, is part of a collective of Los Angeles jazz musicians in their early 30s who are accomplishing a couple of difficult things extremely well.

title: An App That Builds Wonder
description: Like so many Brooklyn parents, Raul Gutierrez was fed up with the way his children behaved after being exposed to screens for too long. They would engage in mindless digital tasks and then be restless. But Mr. Gutierrezs solution was unusual. He didnt place a limit on screen time. Instead, he started a company called Tinybop, hoping to encourage more creativity and imagination in childrens interactions with digital devices.

title: An Elevated Sense of Togetherness
description: Good morning, Aspen! the Rev. Gregg Anderson shouted into the microphone at the start of this years Easter service on the summit of Aspen Mountain. Are you warm enough? If not, hug somebody.

title: In Israel, Migrants Find a Home, Through Running
description: In front of her teammates and Israeli peers, Rahel Gebretsadik, a 15-year-old Eritrean immigrant with a petite frame, a shaggy ponytail and an infectious laugh, stood alone on a white wooden box emblazoned with the blue number one. A medal, minted with the menorah from the Arch of Titus, the emblem of the State of Israel, hung around her neck.

title: Book Review Podcast: One of Us
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Eric Schlosser reviews One of Us, the Norwegian journalist Asne Seierstads account of the life and crimes of Anders Behring Breivik, a mass murderer who killed 77 people, most of them teenagers. Mr. Schlosser writes:

title: Streetbird Rotisserie in Harlem Offers Chicken in a Throwback Setting
description: If youre wondering what happened to your old skateboard or that boom box you used to carry, chances are its hanging from the walls or the ceiling of Streetbird Rotisserie, the newest Harlem restaurant from Marcus Samuelsson, a jangling arcade game of a space stuffed to the rafters with what aficionados call cool stuff. A drum set doubles as a chandelier, sneakers fill wall crannies, new graffiti and an ancient subway door evoke the funk of Harlem past. Its a lot to take in. Fortunately, since the restaurant opened on April 2, the wait for tables has given patient diners plenty of time to explore all the bric-a-brac. Even on a rainy Tuesday night, the wait was given as 25 minutes, which is restaurant-speak for who knows? Like the room, the menu is more casual than the one at Mr. Samuelssons flagship, Red Rooster Harlem. The location, at 116th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard, puts Streetbird in the heart of a newish restaurant row.

title: Evening Hours | Stacks of Invitations
description: A week crowded with parties for the arts, fashion, charity and more.

title: Tonys Panel Rules on Wolf Hall, Fun Home
description: The best-selling writer Hilary Mantel could add a Tony Award to the pair of Man Booker Prizes she earned for the novels Wolf Hall and Bring Up the Bodies.

title: The Economics of Suspense
description: IMAGINE the following situation. After a grueling day at work, you plop down in front of your TV, ready to relax. Your TiVo has recorded all of the days March Madness games. Youve sequestered yourself away from any news about who won or lost. Which game to watch?

title: Rays From Exploding Stars May Help Measure Strength of Thunderstorms
description: Scientists measure electric fields in thunderclouds with instruments aboard airplanes and weather balloons, but during violent conditions these methods can be difficult, even dangerous.

title: The History of Roller Skates
description: Q. Its time to get out my old two-by-two roller skates. When were they invented?

title: The Cost of Daydreaming
description: THAT spring I was teaching in Arizona and walking daily along a road at the edge of the town, taking new pleasure in the physical beauty that surrounded me (the mountains, the desert, the clarity of light) but, as usual, running a movie in my head. One afternoon in April, right in the middle of the film, a kind of visual static  something like the static on a television screen  cut across my inner field of vision; the story began literally to break up before my eyes and then it actually terminated itself. At the same time an acrid taste began to fill my mouth and, deep within, I felt myself shrinking from: I knew not what.

title: Review: Boomtowners Visits a North American Fracking Zone
description: You expect a certain tone from a workplace reality show, whether its about long-haul truckers or tuna fishermen or microbrewers. The underlying sensibility is that the job, however quirky or unheralded, is important and interesting and that the people doing it deserve respect.

title: Our Vietnam War Never Ended
description: LOS ANGELES  THURSDAY, the last day of April, is the 40th anniversary of the end of my war. Americans call it the Vietnam War, and the victorious Vietnamese call it the American War. In fact, both of these names are misnomers, since the war was also fought, to great devastation, in Laos and Cambodia, a fact that Americans and Vietnamese would both rather forget.

title: Pictures of the Day: Italy and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Italy, Armenia, Chile and Egypt.

title: Review: Chefs Table Profiles Top Culinary Talents
description: It has been years since a cooking show could get by with merely demonstrating how to prepare a particular dish, but these days a lot of entries in the genre are tarted up absurdly. Which of three competing chefs can cook the best five-course meal in 10 minutes using nothing but seaweed, paprika and a live chicken?

title: Unconditional Love: The Easiest, and the Hardest Part
description: Parents, as a group, arent perfect.

title: Baltimore Police Admit Delay in Calling Ambulance for Freddie Gray
description: BALTIMORE  The police commissioner in Baltimore said Friday that Freddie Gray, the unarmed black man who died Sunday after suffering a spinal cord injury while in police custody, should have received medical attention much sooner than he did.

title: Spanx Tries to Loosen Up Its Image
description: Spanx, the flab-obscuring, body-sculpting line of bras and bodysuits, helped a generation of women squeeze into ever-tinier dresses.

title: April 26, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Chile, Italy, Pakistan and Bangladesh.

title: Bomb Threat Causes Evacuation of Statue of Liberty and Liberty Island
description: The National Park Service evacuated hundreds of tourists from the Statue of Liberty and Liberty Island on Friday after reports of a bomb threat. Federal authorities and the New York Police Department conducted security sweeps before giving the island an all clear several hours later.

title: Eric Holders Farewell to Justice Department
description: Eric H. Holder Jr. said goodbye to the Justice Department on Friday, his last day as attorney general.

title: Pass the Pork Belly, and the Joint
description: SAN FRANCISCO  On a dark corner here in the Mission District on March 31, the doors opened at 7 p.m. for an under-the-radar pop-up dinner. Stationed at the entrance was a man who meticulously carded each of the 60 guests, even two with white hair.

title: Review: John Mellencamp, Still Defiant, at the Apollo Theater
description: John Mellencamp opened a can of worms at the top of his show at the Apollo Theater on Thursday night. Leading his six-piece backing band through a roadhouse shuffle called Lawless Times, he rattled off a partial list of modern ills: police brutality, banking malfeasance, government corruption, online music piracy. (Some of these worse than others.)

title: G.M. Paid Mary Barra $16.2 Million in 2014, Despite Recalls
description: DETROIT  General Motors said on Friday that it paid its chief executive, Mary T. Barra, a total of $16.2 million in compensation last year, in spite of the companys record number of safety recalls in 2014.

title: Rock Never Gets Old for New York Roots Music Association
description: Steven Prisco has been playing guitar since he first heard the Beatles in 1964.

title: Review of Outside Mullingar in Armonk
description: Sometimes, when a thing is beautiful, you should just sit back and say thanks.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: A Place in Los Angeles for Vegans and Their Non-Vegan Friends
description: LOS ANGELES  Let me explain why were special, our waitress said brightly as we sat down to dinner at the Springs, a six-month-old urban oasis in this citys quickly gentrifying downtown. You can eat dinner  everything is raw, vegan, organic, soy free and gluten free  and then have your colon cleansed right through that door!

title: A Review of Rapture, Blister, Burn at the Dreamcatcher Repertory Theater in Summit
description: Want answers? Look elsewhere.

title: Review: Civil War Songs of Memory and Loss, at Cooper Union
description: War anniversaries have kept musicians busy lately. The centenary of the outbreak of World War I was commemorated last summer with a gala concert by the Vienna Philharmonic in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, followed by a flurry of performances of Brittens War Requiem across Europe. Elgar, Beethoven and Shostakovich will figure prominently on programs commemorating the 70th anniversary of V-E Day next month.

title: Review: Gilberto Gil Brings Energy to Town Hall
description: About halfway through Gilberto Gils astonishing concert at Town Hall on Thursday night, he played Desafinado (Off Key) by Antnio Carlos Jobim and Newton Mendona, made famous in 1959 by Joo Gilberto. It is an intimate and self-righteous little song  essentially, a man telling a woman that his music and his emotions are true and real and perhaps on the right side of history, even if she doesnt think so.

title: The Critique of Reason Redefines the Meaning of Romantic Art
description: In James Wards Man Struggling With a Boa Constrictor, Study for Liboya Serpent Seizing Its Prey, a black man fights off an enormous snake. He grips the creature in each hand, pushing with all his might. His muscles are taut, his ribs outlined beneath the skin of his naked torso, his face contorted with rage, terror and grit.

title: Jake Tapper Is Named Host of CNNs State of the Union
description: CNN announced on Friday that Jake Tapper would take over the hosting duties for its Sunday morning show, State of the Union. He will start in June and continue to host the weekday daytime show The Lead.

title: Carly and Lucy Simon on Music, Fame, Sibling Rivalry and, Yes, James Taylor
description: When Carly Simon walked into the music room of her home on Marthas Vineyard, shyly trailing her sister Lucy and carrying a guitar like a shield, it was easy to see her as the author of the lyrics: She rides in the front seat; shes my older sister. Even rock stars have them. And for the next few hours, the Simon Sisters, as they were billed when they sang as a folk duo in the 60s, spoke warmly but candidly about the powerful devotion and jealousy of siblings.

title: Pressed by Young Republicans, Scott Walker Sticks to Tough Immigration Stance
description: After giving a version of his stump speech to a mostly gray-haired crowd in Iowa, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin was pressed on Friday by two twenty-something Republicans about a percolating issue he did not mention: immigration.

title: Jana Partners Barry Rosenstein Has Different Take on BlackRock C.E.O.s Missive
description: Laurence D. Fink, the chief executive of BlackRock, appeared to have been criticizing activist shareholders when he recently urged corporate chieftains not to be bullied by investors with short-term interests.

title: The Unintended Twist of Tax Inversions
description: Tevas unsolicited $40 billion bid for the drug maker Mylan and Mylans own unsolicited offer for the rival Perrigo are sweet revenge for the United States taxpayer.

title: Dennis Hoppers Drugstore Camera Photos
description: Dennis Hopper is most recognized for his film career, but he wanted to be remembered for his camera work.

title: Skateboarding New York
description: Three years ago, when Carlos Jaramillo moved to New York from Gainesville, Fla., he began to dread his 30-pound camera bag. Jaramillo had become the dude in his crew of skateboarders who shot photos. He even placed some in regional skate magazines before moving to New York to study photography at the School of Visual Arts. Back in Florida, going out skateboarding meant piling into a friends car. In New York, not so much. His bags heft presented a problem. I got burned out pretty quick on it, Jaramillo said.

title: U.N. Refugee Official Calls Situation in Syria and Iraq Unsustainable
description: The war that has engulfed Syria and spread into Iraq has displaced 14 million people, including four million Syrian refugees scattered to neighboring countries, and it has created host fatigue, which has further aggravated the crisis, United Nations officials said Friday.

title: From the Archives: Tafts Diet
Review: James Levine Conducts a Noirish Verdi at the Metropolitan Opera
description: In more than four decades at the Metropolitan Opera, James Levine has made Verdi a particular specialty. Yet, until Thursday nights performance of Un Ballo in Maschera, Mr. Levine had not conducted this touchstone Verdi work since 1997. The occasion was the revival of David Aldens film-noirish production, introduced in 2012.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Reputed Mobster May Be Last Link to Gardner Museum Art Heist
description: He may have a snappy nickname  the Cook  but Robert V. Gentile is no Hollywood directors vision of a master art thief.

title: Deutsche Bank to Shed Postbank Branch Network
description: FRANKFURT  Deutsche Bank said late Friday that it would spin off its Postbank network of bank branches in Germany and reduce risk in investment banking as it responds to increased pressure from regulators.

title: New Member for American Contract Bridge Leagues Hall of Fame
description: One player has been voted into the American Contract Bridge Leagues Hall of Fame this year: Michael Rosenberg of Cupertino, Calif. It is his first year of eligibility.

title: Former Guantnamo Inmate Is Granted Bail in Canada
description: OTTAWA  A Canadian court ordered on Friday that Omar Khadr, the only Canadian to have been held at the Guantnamo Bay detention center in Cuba, be released on bail pending an appeal of his conviction by an American military tribunal.

title: Man Is Arrested for Flying Drone Onto Japanese Leaders Office Roof, Reports Say
description: TOKYO  The police have arrested a man who said he flew a small drone carrying trace amounts of radioactive material onto the roof of the prime ministers office in Tokyo to protest Japans nuclear policy, Japanese news reports said early Saturday.

title: Ari Millen of Orphan Black on Being a Clone and a Dad
description: A maniacal leer, a zipper scar slicing his cheek, a body pumped to kill: You wouldnt want to run into Rudy, the new guy on the cellblock in BBC Americas Orphan Black, in a dark hallway.

title: Review: Mark Morris Dance Group at Brooklyn Academy of Music
description: If you try to analyze the way the choreographer Mark Morris fits dance to music, you quickly become aware of something akin to a scientific operation of intense intricacy: The connection of movement phrases and motifs to each score is extraordinarily complex in both structure and detail  and, often, brilliantly satisfying. But when you stand back and simply watch the sheer imagination with which Mr. Morris decides what kind of drama hes marrying to music that, in most cases, was written long ago with very different ideas in mind, then he starts to look eccentric, a peculiar and daring oddball, an engaging but naughty maverick.

title: Review: The Belle of Belfast, a Pressure Cooker of Moral Quandaries
description: Just before Nate Rufus Edelmans winning drama The Belle of Belfast begins, the buzz saw intensity of Stiff Little Fingers republican anthem Alternative Ulster and John McDermotts set  an imposing exposed-brick wall covered with graffiti and topped with barbed wire  signal that youre in the caldron of Belfast, Northern Ireland, in 1985. Add Jeff Larsons black-and-white projections from the bloodstained history of the Troubles, and throw in the hormones and caustic temperament of a 17-year-old live wire, and youre in a pressure cooker at steam heat.

title: A William Forsythe Dancer Moves From Toe-Tapping to Handshaking
description: FRANKFURT  In a chic 60s suit, spiky heeled boots and pillbox hat, Dana Caspersen strode to the center of the stage of the Bockenheimer Depot here, followed by a camerawoman. Ladies and gentlemen, Ms. Caspersen declared. Id like you to notice my extraordinary resemblance to ... (assuming a French accent)  ... Catherine Deneuve! The audience cheered, and the dancers onstage buzzed excitedly around her. By the end of the performance, the perky self-assuredness of that opening was shredded, Ms. Caspersens naked vulnerability on display as she sat quietly in a chair, speaking the final words of the piece.

title: The Chauvet Caves Hyperreal Wonders, Replicated
description: CHAUVET CAVE, France  After the retreat of Neanderthals across the European continent, modern humans made their way to this cave and began to create the first known works of pictorial art: buffalos surging across the rock background, rhinoceroses doing battle, lions searching for mates and dark-maned horses cantering.

title: Peter Eotvos Prepares the Opera Senza Sangue
description: During a recent morning rehearsal at Avery Fisher Hall, the New York Philharmonics music director, Alan Gilbert, led the orchestra in its first reading of a new one-act opera, Senza Sangue. In the auditorium, the ensembles assistant conductor, Courtney Lewis, followed along with the score spread out on his lap. In an aisle seat nearby, a third conductor was at work, accompanying the music with liquid hand gestures so small and instinctively expressive as to appear like extensions of an inner thought process.

title: New Music From Kathryn Calder, Buxton, Nadine Shah, East India Youth and Tal National
description: Kathryn Calder

title: Review: Lisa Fischer Joyfully Flaunts Her Range at Birdland
description: Not the least of the blessings bestowed by Twenty Feet From Stardom, the 2013 documentary about backup singers, many of whom have more vocal clout than the stars they accompany, was the attention brought to Lisa Fischer, a phenomenal powerhouse. She enjoyed a moment of glory when she won a Grammy in 1992 for best R&B vocal performance but then curtailed her solo career, saying she preferred the role of backup singer to soloist.

title: Review: Le Jardin des Voixs Sweet Italian Menu
description: Zabaglione, that irresistibly sweet and creamy Italian confection, usually crowns a dessert course. But Le Jardin des Voix served it right up front in a feast of mostly Italian music at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday evening, starting with a comic madrigal by Adriano Banchieri from his 1604 collection Il Zabaione Musicale. And from there, things grew only more delicious and delightful.

title: Review: Orchestras Large and Small and a Composer Portrait
description: Voices of Ascension

title: Review: Michelle Bouls White Explores the Unknown, Unheard, Unfelt
description: Just before presenting the debut of her new trio, White, at Danspace Project on Thursday, the choreographer Michelle Boul, dressed elegantly in that color, with her hair frizzed out like a fashion models, explained in a French accent that the work addresses things she doesnt understand, like quantum physics and BioGeometry. The soundtrack, she said, would involve frequencies outside the range of human hearing but nevertheless in ze room.

title: Syria Remains Silent on Intelligence Officials Death
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Brig. Gen. Rustom Ghazali, long a powerful figure in Syrias intelligence apparatus, has died in Damascus, the capital, a Lebanese television channel reported Friday. Reports simmered for weeks that he had been severely beaten in an internal government dispute.

title: The Clinton Foundation and the Foreign Donors
description: To the Editor:

title: Iran Oppositions View
description: To the Editor:

title: Brian Williams Inquiry Is Said to Expand
description: An NBC News internal investigation into Brian Williams has examined a half-dozen instances in which he is thought to have fabricated, misrepresented or embellished his accounts, two people with inside knowledge of the investigation said.

title: American Naval Force Off Yemen Gets Credit After Iranian Convoy Turns Away
description: WASHINGTON  Pentagon officials on Friday credited the deployment of an American aircraft carrier group in waters off the coast of Yemen for a decision by Iran to turn back a naval convoy suspected of carrying weapons bound for Shiite rebels.

title: Grass That Never Needs Watering
description: In California, interest in artificial turf for residential yards surged after Gov. Jerry Brown imposed statewide water restrictions this month.

title: Some Bright Green Lawns in California Require No Water
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Sitting in the sun on a patch of green grass behind his home, Paul OValle does not feel bad about having an urban oasis despite the states drought.

title: Robert Patterson Jr., Lawyer and Judge Who Fought for the Accused, Dies at 91
description: Robert P. Patterson Jr., a former federal judge who championed legal rights for the accused and the convicted and fought to hold guards and state troopers accountable for the casualties among inmates after the Attica prison rebellion in 1971, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 91.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Accidental Killings of Innocents by American Drones
description: To the Editor:

title: The Waitress Chronicles: Sexism on the Job
description: To the Editor:

title: For a Migrant Airlift to U.S.
Councilman Wants New York Citys Pools and Beaches Open Past Labor Day
description: The highest temperature recorded in New York City last year was on the day after Labor Day. The mercury climbed to 92 degrees, and New Yorkers turned on their fans, cranked up their air-conditioners and chased ice cream trucks.

title: Parents Role in the New York Test Protest
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Charities Review Tax Returns Amid Scrutiny of Foreign Grants
description: The Clinton familys namesake foundation and signature health initiative are reviewing several years of tax returns after questions were raised about the charities reporting of tens of millions of dollars in grants from foreign governments, foundation officials said Friday.

title: Training of Deputy in Tulsa Was Faulted in a Report
description: In an internal investigation six years ago into the volunteer reserve deputy who shot an unarmed man this month, sheriffs officers in Tulsa County, Okla., said that he did not have the training or skills required for his post, but that commanders told them to ignore such concerns.

title: To Lure Back Young Shoppers, Abercrombie Puts On a Shirt
description: Smooth, shirtless torsos have long greeted shoppers at Abercrombie & Fitch  in its ads, and sometimes in the flesh.

title: New Yorks Subway Madness
description: Anyone who has squeezed into a subway car recently in New York City knows in a very up-close and uncomfortable way that the citys mass transit system is overloaded. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority confirmed this week that ridership has indeed soared. The system handled 1.75 billion rides last year  a number not seen since the late 1940s, when many fewer people drove. That compares with just over a billion rides in 1980 and 1.3 billion in 2000.

title: Bill Clinton Ends Role With Chain of For-Profit Colleges
description: Bill Clinton ended his role with a for-profit college system on Friday, nearly two weeks after his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, began her second presidential campaign and singled out that industry for criticism.

title: Gunmen Kill Arts Advocate in Pakistan After Human Rights Event
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  Gunmen killed the director of a popular arts center in Pakistans largest city on Friday, shortly after she had hosted a contentious event on human rights abuses in western Baluchistan Province.

title: Should a Court Approve All Drone Strikes?
Comcast Withdraws Purchase Bid, but It Isnt Going Anywhere
description: As a boy, Brian L. Roberts watched his father, Ralph, build Comcast into a cable empire.

title: Big Mistake When Posing as an Officer: Pulling Up Behind the Real Thing
description: A driver waited at a red light on Bath Avenue and 21st Avenue in Bath Beach, Brooklyn, last Friday morning. He heard the familiar sound of a short blast from a police siren behind him  whoop-whoop  and realized the traffic light had turned green.

title: Intense Lobbying Failed to Assure Comcasts Deal
description: WASHINGTON  David L. Cohen, the master salesman who runs the Comcast Corporations lobbying efforts, stood before a room full of Latino House lawmakers one morning in early December trying to convince them that they should embrace his $45 billion deal to acquire Time Warner Cable.

title: 15 Bison Escape From New York Farm, Cross Thruway, and Are Shot
description: ALBANY  It was, in hindsight, an ill-fated escape, a seemingly aimless ramble that took a small herd of runaway bison from a farm to a river, through lawns and lots, and onto the New York State Thruway.

title: Minor League Hockey Goes West
description: With the formation of the American Hockey Leagues Pacific Division, three Northeast teams are pulling out for California.

title: Mary Keefe, Model for Rockwells Rosie the Riveter, Dies at 92
description: Mary Keefe, a 19-year-old Vermont telephone operator whom her neighbor Norman Rockwell immortalized as his model for the heroine of Rosie the Riveter, the World War II feminist anthem that empowered women to leave home and pinch-hit in military plants, died on Tuesday at her home in Simsbury, Conn. She was 92.

title: Whats So Great About Young Writers?
description: PHILADELPHIA  MY Facebook feed clogged this week with news that Meryl Streep was funding a screenwriting lab for women 40 and older. I am not a screenwriter, but as the author of two books of fiction, published when I was 48 and 52, I couldnt help but cheer.

title: Amid Errors, Obama Publicly Wrestles With Drones Limits
description: WASHINGTON  He looked down at his text, but seemed to drift away from it. He had planned to say something about the drone strike that killed two hostages by mistake, about how the tragedy would be reviewed.

title: Activists Say Both North Korea and South Korea Approve Womens Peace Walk
description: Organizers of a womens international peace walk across the Korean Peninsulas heavily mined Demilitarized Zone next month said Friday that the governments of both North and South Korea had given their conditional approval for the event, which is meant to create new pressure for a formal end to the Korean War. But the organizers acknowledged that they did not yet have the final written confirmations or visa approvals.

title: Richard Corliss, 71, Longtime Film Critic for Time, Dies
description: Richard Corliss, whose well-informed and spirited movie reviews appeared in Time magazine for 35 years, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 71.

title: A Better Way to Rein In Lobbying
description: WASHINGTON  CORPORATE influence is an old problem in American democracy. But in the last decade or so, corporate spending to influence Congress and federal agencies has reached a new, and probably unsustainable, level.

title: Outpouring of Grief and Anger as Pakistani Activist Is Gunned Down
description: A leading proponent of civil society in Pakistan was shot and killed in the port city of Karachi on Friday night, officials said, shortly after hosting a discussion with dissidents from Baluchistan, the countrys largest province, at the cultural center she founded.

title: Fans Suffer as Hockey Teams Leave Their Hotbeds for Warmer Climes
description: WORCESTER, Mass.  Before one of the Worcester Sharks final home games this season, fans gathered for a party at a popular pregame hangout near DCU Center, the teams home rink for the past nine years.

title: Baltimores Broken Relationship With Police
description: BALTIMORE  For nearly two years, ever since her brother Tyrone West died after a struggle with the police, a 35-year-old preschool teacher named Tawanda Jones has been in the streets here on Wednesday nights, protesting. Her message: We need killer cops in cellblocks.

title: Bruce Jenner Says Hes Transitioning to a Woman
description: Bruce Jenner, the Olympic gold medalist and member of the Kardashian family, ended months of speculation Friday night when he announced during an ABC television special that he identified as a woman and was making the transition from male to female.

title: Will the Vietnam War Ever Go Away?
description: Its not much fun returning to Vietnam.

title: System Crash for Starbucks Leads to Free Coffee for Some
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The in-store payment systems at Starbucks went down Friday at 8,000 company-operated stores in the United States and Canada, leading to an unexpected giveaway of coffee drinks at some stores.

title: With Bernie Williamss Retirement, a Storied Yankees Era Ends
description: It was a long, overdue formality that became a feel-good photo opportunity. But with a dotting of the is in Bernie Williams and the crossing of the ts in a nearly decade-old retirement, a beloved era of iconic Yankees was officially laid to rest.

title: A Big Machine Gets to Work
description: The I Lift New York Super Crane, painted red, white and blue, was brought in to help build the replacement Tappan Zee Bridge. On Friday, it made its inaugural lift: a pile cap.

title: Presidential Primary Book Club
description: Concerned citizens bear many great burdens, one of which is trying to follow a presidential race in which virtually every candidate has written one or more books about their lives, hopes, dreams, theories  and, in the case of Mike Huckabee, diets.

title: Books and Board Games
description: SATURDAYS POST  This puzzle has got all the trappings for a quiet Saturday night in. Books and board games, anyone?

title: On the Export-Import Bank, the Numbers Come First
description: In June, for the third time since 2012, the Export-Import Bank of the United States, an export credit agency that backs loans to foreign entities that help cement deals with American exporters  and thus helps create American jobs  must be reauthorized by Congress. Otherwise it will go out of business.

title: A Contest in the Bronx Helps Young Scientists Explore
description: Lawrence Abu-Hammour always knew he wanted to do scientific research, but he did not get into the Bronx High School of Science or any of New York Citys other elite schools with robust science programs and activities.

title: Cuomo Says He Wants M.T.A. Chairman to Stay On
description: The announcement came as a surprise on Friday to Thomas F. Prendergast, the leader of the New York City regions vast transit system: You can keep your job.

title: Jets Want Quantity From Draft, but Also a Potentially Costly Prospect in Marcus Mariota
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Mike Maccagnan graduated from Trinity College expecting to become not a football scout but a financial analyst. He applied for positions on Wall Street but then chose to pursue a career working in the N.F.L., where he has still managed to put his degree in economics to good use.

title: Government Releases Once-Secret Report on Post-9/11 Surveillance
description: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit by The New York Times, the government has declassified a 2009 report by five agencies inspectors general about the Stellarwind program, the group of N.S.A. warrantless wiretapping and bulk phone and e-mail records collection activities initiated by President George W. Bush after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Islanders Aim to Avoid Last Hurrah at Home
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Facing playoff elimination against the Washington Capitals on Saturday, the Islanders are hoping their crowd can lift them one more time.

title: Rangers Oust Penguins by a Familiar Margin
description: The Rangers and the Pittsburgh Penguins were destined to play a one-goal gameFridaynight at Madison Square Garden.

title: Declassified Report Shows Doubts About Value of N.S.A.s Warrantless Spying
description: WASHINGTON  The secrecy surrounding the National Security Agencys post-9/11 warrantless surveillance and bulk data collection program hampered its effectiveness, and many members of the intelligence community later struggled to identify any specific terrorist attacks it thwarted, a newly declassified document shows.

title: Mets Ride Ends at Yankees House
description: Jacob deGrom, the Mets promising young starter, turned, looked, then craned his neck higher, as if he were trying to spot a bird. He had floated a belt-high fastball over the plate, and Mark Teixeira had crushed it into the early evening sky down the right-field line at Yankee Stadium.

title: Whats on TV Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (Showtime) BOYHOOD (2014) Starting in 2002, Richard Linklater began to film four characters  a boy (Ellar Coltrane), then 6; his sister (Lorelei Linklater, Mr. Linklaters daughter); and their parents (the Oscar-winning Patricia Arquette and Ethan Hawke, in a nominated role)  over 12 consecutive years, composing the script as the movie progressed. What emerged from those dozen years is a series of meticulously textured and structured scenes set to the rhythm of life, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Siblings argue. A mother struggles with men, paying the bills and earning several college degrees. An estranged father roars into his childrens lives in a 1968 GTO. The story in Boyhood is blissfully simple: A child grows up, Ms. Dargis added about this film, which also earned Oscar nominations for best picture, directing, original screenplay and editing. This, along with the modesty of its physical production  its humble rooms, quiet moments, ordinary lives  can obscure Mr. Linklaters ambitions and the greatness of his achievement. But in his masterpiece, she said, he both captures moments in time and relinquishes them as he moves from year to year. He isnt fighting time but embracing it in all its glorious and agonizingly fleeting beauty.

title: Corrections: April 25, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I am always hungry.

title: Mapping the Clashes Between Baltimore Police and Protesters
description: Gov. Larry Hogan of Maryland declared a state of emergency and activated the National Guard when riots broke out after the funeral of Freddie Gray.

title: Earthquake Devastates Nepal, Killing More Than 1,900
description: NEW DELHI  A powerful earthquake shook Nepal on Saturday near its capital, Katmandu, killing more than 1,900 people, flattening sections of the citys historic center, and trapping dozens of sightseers in a 200-foot watchtower that came crashing down into a pile of bricks.

title: Lawsuit Over Banned Memoir Asks China to Explain Censorship
description: BEIJING  When Li Nanyang flew here from Hong Kong two years ago, she brought something eagerly anticipated by many Chinese historians and thinkers: several dozen copies of her fathers memoir. In it, Li Rui, a 98-year-old retired Communist Party official, offered an unvarnished, insiders account of his experiences in the leadership.

title: Earthquake Strikes Near Nepals Capital
description: People described scenes of panic and collapsed buildings after the quake, with an estimated magnitude of 7.8, struck on Saturday.

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took viewers from a one-woman show in Manhattan to the skies over Poland.

title: Wingnut Welfare and Work Incentives
description: Wingnut welfare is an important, underrated feature of the modern U.S. political scene. I dont know who came up with the term, but anyone who follows right-wing careers knows whereof I speak: the lavishly-funded ecosystem of billionaire-financed think tanks, media outlets, and so on provides a comfortable cushion for politicians and pundits who tell such people what they want to hear. Lose an election, make economic forecasts that turn out laughably wrong, whatever  no matter, theres always a fallback job available.

title: A Horse With the Right Name to Tie the Kentucky Derby to a Prizefight
description: After his final major workout ahead of next Saturdays Kentucky Derby, the colt Itsaknockout retreated to Barn 40 on Friday for a bath. He was swaddled in a black blanket with the words Mayweather, in orange, and Pacquiao, in yellow, printed on the side.

title: Long-Predicted Death Toll in Nepal Earthquake Reflects Wider Himalayan Seismic Risk
description: The Himalayas are one of the worlds most worrisome hot zones for earthquake risk, which is a function of tectonic activity, human population size and the quality (or lack thereof) of construction.

title: Firsthand Accounts of Nepal Earthquake
description: As a devastating earthquake hit about 50 miles from Katmandu, killing hundreds, residents took to social media to share information on the destruction and injured, post photographs of collapsed buildings and let their friends and family know they were safe.

title: 1915: Armenian Genocide in Turkey
description: The roots of the Armenian genocide lie in the collapse of the Ottoman Empire, and date as far back as the Armenian uprising of 1895. By the beginning of 1915, the empire was fully embroiled in World War I, facing direct attacks by the Allies on the Dardanelles and a threat from the Russian Army on its eastern border.

title: Bruce Jenner, Embracing Transgender Identity, Says Its Just Who I Am
description: This was shocking: Bruce Jenner is a Republican.

title: When a Co-op Neighbor Breaks the Law
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Earthquake in Nepal Kills Hundreds
description: An earthquake with an estimated magnitude of 7.8 shook Nepal on Saturday near its capital, Katmandu, flattening sections of the citys historic center.

title: Anonymous Donors Keep The Fantasticks Open
description: About that closing of The Fantasticks: Never mind.

title: Variety: Opposable Sums
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Solving a variety puzzle is a bit like cross-training  it works out a different set of muscles. For a standard crossword were just focused on filling in the blanks, but for an Opposable Sums puzzle, all the letters are right in front of you  you just have to rearrange them.

title: Bruce Jenners Transgender Announcement Draws 16.8 Million on ABC News
description: More than 16.8 million people tuned in Friday night to watch the ABC News television special in which Bruce Jenner said that he identified as a woman, according to preliminary ratings data provided by the network.

title: Scott Walker, a Pastors Son, Runs on Faith as Iowa Beckons
description: DES MOINES  Scott Walker, the son of a Baptist preacher, learned a lot about being a politician by going to church.

title: Push for Buses on Sabbath Sets Off Debate in Israel
description: JERUSALEM  It started as a bit of sarcastic whimsy: Israelis frustrated with the lack of public buses on the Jewish Sabbath and holidays hijacked the Facebook page of the transportation minister during Passover and turned it into a shared-ride board.

title: Thomas Staggs: Disneys Heir, Apparently
description: Robert A. Iger was grasping for words. Standing before shareholders in San Francisco last month, the normally quick-witted Mr. Iger, chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, had been caught off guard by Brooke Ledwith, an inquisitive 6-year-old. Who was the first Disney princess to walk on a Disney cruise ship? she asked, standing on tiptoe to reach a microphone.

title: Sue Desmond-Hellmann: Helping People Find Their Sweet Spot
description: This interview with Sue Desmond-Hellmann, chief executive of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: In Footgolf, Argentina Establishes Itself as the Dominant Force
description: GENERAL RODRGUEZ, Argentina  With dusk falling, Nico Garca squatted down to read the perilous 20-foot par putt. Needing only a bogey to win Argentinas national championship, he sent the ball snaking downhill across the green, where it stopped just short of the hole. He tapped in for victory  not with a putter, but with the instep of his soccer cleat.

title: Tempur Sealy Shareholder Clamors to Shake Up an Entrenched Board
description: Should they stay or should they go?

title: What About Those Three Kingman Homers? Oops
description: The soothing, authoritative voice that greets fans at Yankee Stadium is the same one that sparked the first widely broadcast managers rant. Yes, Paul Olden, the Yankees public-address announcer, was the reporter whose simple question inspired Tommy Lasordas famous Dave Kingman tirade at Dodger Stadium in 1978.

title: With Drybar, a Curly-Haired Girl Wages a Global War on Frizz
description: About 18 people gathered in a semicircle inside Drybars new location in the meatpacking district of Manhattan. It was mid-December, and in the previous weeks they had been trained in the fine art of giving the greatest possible blow-dry. They knew how to create the beachy rumpled look of the Mai Tai blowout and the sharp, pointy, uptightness of the Straight Up; they knew how to make you look like an extra from Steel Magnolias with the Southern Comfort. They could twist your hair into an Uptini, if that was your need on a particular day.
