They knew how to turn around the salon chair with a flourish so that the customer, who up to this point had been too mesmerized by watching The Devil Wears Prada on a big-screen TV to notice what was being done, could see her hair, shiny and smooth, in the mirror on the wall behind her. As Drybars founder, Alli Webb, sitting atop the bar to greet these new employees, likes to say: Were not selling blowouts. Were selling happiness and confidence.

title: Unbeaten Red Bulls Score on Another Front
description: HANOVER, N.J.  The shouting is as loud as ever around the Red Bulls, but then that is nothing new. Fortunately for the team, the reasons for it are entirely different these days.

title: A Case of Too Many Viennas
description: THE drone strike that accidentally killed two hostages held by Al Qaeda, one of them American, in Pakistans northwest frontier was a rare moment of media attention for a seemingly endless military campaign. Its six years old if you date it to President Obamas escalation of drone warfare, 11 if you date it to the first American drone strike inside Pakistan, and 14 if you date it to when United States Special Forces first slipped into Afghanistan after 9/11. By any estimate, our AfPak intervention has lasted longer than most major wars in American history. By the third estimate, its lasted longer than several of the biggest ones combined.

title: Dr. Oz Is No Wizard, but No Quack, Either
description: ONE afternoon last December, my book publicist called with the best possible news: Youre booked on The Dr. Oz Show! she crowed. This was a huge coup, and I tried to sound as thrilled as she was.

description: Frances Hannon is a British makeup, hair and prosthetic designer who has worked on a range of film and television projects, including The Grand Budapest Hotel, for which she won an Oscar this year.

title: Its Not Gay Marriage vs. the Church Anymore
description: NEW HAVEN  THIS week, committed gay couples seeking the right to marry will take their case to the Supreme Court. The plaintiffs in Obergefell v. Hodges are supported by amicus briefs submitted by a variety of institutions and people, from the former N.F.L. player Chris Kluwe to Ken Mehlman, a past chairman of the Republican National Committee.

title: What Role Do You Want to Play?
description: A CHARACTER in a book by Flaubert, or perhaps someone even smarter, like La Rochefoucauld, said that most people would never fall in love if they had not first read about it in a book. Like many tasty ideas, its an emulsion of true and not-so-true but points us toward an illuminating insight: We cant be the people we are without drawing on sources outside ourselves.

title: Forcing Black Men Out of Society
description: An analysis in The Times  1.5 Million Missing Black Men  showed that more than one in every six black men in the 24-to-54 age group has disappeared from civic life, mainly because they died young or are locked away in prison. This means that there are only 83 black men living outside of jail for every 100 black women  in striking contrast to the white population, where men and women are about equal in numbers.

title: The Justices and a Botched Execution
description: On Wednesday, the Supreme Court will hear a constitutional challenge to Oklahomas lethal-injection drug protocol, which last April left a man writhing in agony on the killing table for 43 minutes.

title: Fixes for Third-World Airports
description: Travelers have many complaints about air travel in the United States these days: crowded airports, slow security lines, subpar and expensive food. When added to rising ticket prices and fees, the problems on the ground become even more of an annoyance. Congress now has a chance to help fix some of them by raising the cap on a fee used to pay for airport improvements.

title: Finding Liberation in Two Deaths
description: The last time I wished my mother dead, I meant it. I was on the plane home to New York City after visiting her in Beaumont, Tex., where she was in what I now know were the final stages of Lewy body dementia.

title: Israeli Police Officers Kill Two Palestinian Men
description: JENIN, West Bank  Two Palestinian men were fatally shot by the Israeli police after attacking officers with knives, one at a contested shrine in the West Bank and the other at a checkpoint near East Jerusalem, a police spokeswoman said Saturday.

title: Scenes of Chaos in Baltimore as Thousands Protest Freddie Grays Death
description: BALTIMORE  A largely peaceful protest over the death of Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old black man who suffered a spinal cord injury in police custody, gave way to scattered scenes of chaos here on Saturday night, as demonstrators smashed a downtown storefront window, threw rocks and bottles and damaged police cruisers, while officers in riot gear broke up skirmishes and made 12 arrests near Camden Yards.

description: BOSTON  When almost unimaginable adversity struck Zach Hodges while he was still in high school, his response was always the same: He pressed on.

description: The calls started coming in before sunrise on Saturday: Coyote spotted in Battery Park City.

title: Spurned by an Insurer After Filing Small Claims
description: It has been the Hagglers new policy to name the heads of companies written about in this space, mostly because these people often hire publicists and lawyers to speak on their behalf and  this is just a guess  to deflect attention.

title: Volkswagens Chairman,Ferdinand Pich, Is Ousted in Power Struggle
description: FRANKFURT  Ferdinand Pich, the Porsche family scion who has dominated Volkswagen for more than two decades, will resign as chairman of the automakers supervisory board, the company said on Saturday, in what appeared to be a stunning defeat for a manager used to getting his way.

title: Everest Climbers Are Killed as Nepal Quake Sets Off Avalanche
description: NEW DELHI  A year after a deadly avalanche on Mount Everest ended the climbing season, multiple avalanches caused by the earthquake on Saturday rumbled down a treacherous icefall and slammed into the mountaineering base camp, killing at least 17 climbers and injuring at least 37 others, Nepalese officials said.

title: Celtics Coach Finds Solid Footing After a Perilous Leap
description: WALTHAM, Mass.  After a recent Boston Celtics practice at the teams training site here, I asked guard Marcus Smart why he felt that so many great college coaches had failed to make a successful leap to the N.B.A.

title: Dirty Talk and Dostoyevsky on the Night Shift
description: In 2004 I was fresh to London and green enough to think I would establish myself as a professional writer within a year. Not quite the wannabe actress arriving in Hollywood and waitressing, but not far off. I came to love London once Id conquered its back streets and understood its secrets, but my first year living there was bleak and harrowing.

title: Portraits of an Execution in Indonesia
description: Indonesia was to have executed 10 drug convicts in April in its largest mass execution in decades. A firing squad executed eight of them on April 29, but two were granted temporary reprieves.

title: Despite Protests, Indonesia Moves Forward to Execute Drug Convicts

title: Rising Star Kawhi Leonard Means the Spurs Wont Miss a Beat
description: SAN ANTONIO  Kawhi Leonard, at age 23, broke from routine before Friday nights game against the Los Angeles Clippers. He was led to midcourt by Tim Duncan, who presented Leonard with the N.B.A. Defensive Player of the Year Award. Leonard, who typically shows about as much emotion as a lamppost, even managed to crack a smile.

title: Michael Botticelli Is a Drug Czar Who Knows Addiction Firsthand
description: BALTIMORE  Six recovering substance abusers sat in an inner-city treatment center, sharing their stories. When Michaels turn came around, he spoke of his former drug of choice, alcohol, and mentioned the night years ago when he drove drunk on the Massachusetts Turnpike, caused an accident and was arrested before passing out.

title: Russian Hackers Read Obamas Unclassified Emails, Officials Say

description: Apples market value is now roughly twice the size of the next biggest companys in the Standard & Poors 500-stock index.

title: Electronic Africa at Red Bull Music Academy Festival
description: Electronic Africa, this Friday at Villain in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is the first night of the monthlong Red Bull Music Academy New York festival. This festivals programming tends to expose secret histories of old music or uncover thriving, noncommercialized scenes of new music; true to form, this is not the organic, lilting African music of Putumayo stores and the college-theater circuit. DJ Spoko and Nozinja, both from South Africa, have created fast-paced versions of Kwaito house; Islam Chipsy, from Egypt, plays blistering, distorted electro chaabi, using his fists to make tone clusters on his electronic keyboard over rhythm tracks; Titica, a popular transgender Angolan singer and dancer, performs the rap-techno style called kuduro. Youll get an education. (Villain, 50 North Third Street, Brooklyn; Friday, 9 p.m.; tickets $20; redbullmusicacademy.com)

title: Milka Djordjevich Puts Dancers on a Pedestal in MASS
description: When choreographers talk of putting dancers on pedestals, theyre often speaking metaphorically about attempts to idealize bodies. But Milka Djordjevich is putting three dancers onto an actual pedestal in MASS, her new collaboration with the composer Chris Peck. The constantly changing bodily shapes will be seen as moving sculptures in a surrounding sea of darkness.

title: From Chaplin to Avatar, a Film Tasting Menu
description: This week, filmgoers can taste the fruit of Hollywoods earliest technology, then sample a modern big-money audience-grabber. In its Essential Cinema series, Anthology Film Archives culminates a focus on Charlie Chaplin on Sunday with City Lights (1931), a seamless blend of physical comedy and genuine pathos. Chaplin released this silent masterwork more than three years into the sound era at great personal risk  and to resounding acclaim. (32 Second Avenue, at Second Street, East Village; anthologyfilmarchives.org.) On Friday, BAMcinmatek begins 3D in the 21st Century, demonstrating that what was once a gimmick is now a sophisticated tool. Avatar, James Camerons sci-fi epic that mandated every blockbuster have 3-D, is on Saturday. One of the best uses, though, is by a documentary next Sunday: Cave of Forgotten Dreams, Werner Herzogs transcendent tour of Chauvet Cave, home, fittingly, to the worlds earliest-known man-made images. (Friday through May 17 at 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, 718-636-4100; bam.org.)

title: John Eliot Gardiner Returns to Monteverdis Vespers
description: In 1964, when John Eliot Gardiner was a 20-year-old undergraduate at the University of Cambridge, he presented Monteverdis scintillating multi-choir Vespers of 1610 at the chapel of Kings College. He fashioned his own performance audition, rounded up the few cornetto players active in England, auditioned singers from London, including the tenor Robert Tear, and borrowed Trevor Pinnocks harpsichord. The show caused a stir and put Mr. Gardiner on the map as a conductor of immense persuasive gifts.

title: New Portraits by Chantal Joffe at the Jewish Museum
description: Susan Sontag wrote that the painter constructs, the photographer discloses. But the work of photography-based painters like Chantal Joffe (her early interest in nudes led her to paint mostly from pictures in pornographic magazines) has always existed somewhere in between, a fictive nonfiction. Starting Friday, the Jewish Museum will present 34 new portraits by Ms. Joffe of Jewish women of the 20th century whose contributions to art, literature and politics have interested her. The redoubtable group includes Sontag, as well as Diane Arbus, Gertrude Stein and Claude Cahun, the Surrealist shape-shifter whose photographic self-portraits as a man, amid many other guises, prefigured Cindy Sherman by decades. Ms. Joffe made the portraits after immersing herself not only in pictures of the women but also in what they wrote and made, striving for depictions charged with her own imagining of what her heroes would have looked like at various stages of their lives. (Through Oct. 18, 1109 Fifth Avenue, 212-423-3200, thejewishmuseum.org.)

title: Tales of the Grim Sleeper, on HBO, Explores a Murder Case
description: We all know how to make a documentary about a serial-murder case: Structure it around interviews with prosecutors and police investigators, who reconstruct the crimes and the pursuit of the suspect. Well, someone forgot to explain that formula to Nick Broomfield.

title: William Price Fox, Admired Southern Novelist and Humorist, Dies at 89
description: William Price Fox, a novelist and humorist who plumbed his South Carolina roots for the colorful characters in his work, earning fans in the upper echelons of American literary life if not necessarily over a wide range of the nations readers, died on April 19 at his home in Washington. He was 89.

title: Ellen Turner Dies at 87; Opened Kitchen to Feed the Needy of Knoxville
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.  Ellen Turner, who with her twin sister founded the Love Kitchen, which feeds several hundred people a week and drew national attention, died here on Wednesday. She was 87.

title: Gilbert Haroche, Builder of an Economy Travel Empire, Dies at 87
description: Gilbert Haroche, a co-founder of Liberty Travel, which began by busing vacationers to the Catskills and grew to become a national enterprise that delivered millions of thrifty tourists to more distant locales, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 87.

title: Speeding in Finland Can Cost a Fortune, if You Already Have One

title: Nepalese in Queens Anxiously Waiting to Hear From Relatives After Quake

title: Matt Harveys Pinstriped Dream Leads to Dominant Show in Mets Blue
description: The scene that unfolded Saturday at Yankee Stadium was, in a strange way, perhaps close to what Matt Harvey, the Mets ace, had imagined as a child, as a Yankees fan, playing catch with his father.

title: Ancient Collision Made Nepal Earthquake Inevitable
description: More than 25 million years ago, India, once a separate island on a quickly sliding piece of the Earths crust, crashed into Asia. The two land masses are still colliding, pushed together at a speed of 1.5 to 2 inches a year. The forces have pushed up the highest mountains in the world, in the Himalayas, and have set off devastating earthquakes.

title: Thousands Take to Baltimore Streets to Protest Freddie Grays Death

title: Gay Marriage Case Caps Cincinnatis Shift From Conservative Past

description: The earthquake that struck Nepal on April 25 flattened sections of Katmandus historic center, where many structures were made with bricks.

title: How Patrina Felts, Foster Parent, Adoptive Parent and Pageant Mom Does It

This post came about in an unusual way; Ali Smith, photographer and author of Momma Love ; How the Mother Half Lives, offered to catch up with some of the mothers she photographed for her (wonderful) book and give us a glimpse into how their lives have evolved.

description: Carmen Elinor James, the daughter of Regina Cortina and Thomas James of Manhattan, was married Saturday evening to Matthew Ryan Schrimpf, the son of Kathleen M. Schrimpf and Ronald D. description: WASHINGTON  President Obama might have that cool, professorial exterior. But what would happen if he ever got really mad?

title: Whats on TV Sunday
description: 9:30 P.M. (Showtime) HAPPYISH Steve Coogan stars as Thom Payne, a 44-year-old burned-out advertising executive living in Woodstock, N.Y., with his painter wife, Lee (Kathryn Hahn, above, with Mr. Coogan). He finds his world spiraling into disarray when his agency hires some young Swedes to bring the company into the new millennium. Bradley Whitford plays Jonathan, Thoms office mentor, who advises him to rebrand himself. Ellen Barkin is Dani, the headhunter who thinks that Thom has hit his joy ceiling. Writing in The New York Times, Alessandra Stanley called this new series, created by the novelist Shalom Auslander (Hope: A Tragedy, Foreskins Lament), funnyish. But mostly, she said, its annoyingesque.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: It was like being on a boat in heavy seas.

title: Corrections: April 26, 2015
description: NATIONAL

title: Nepal Searches for Survivors After Earthquake
description: Officials in Nepal said that most of the deaths occurred in and around the capital, but the quake touched a vast expanse of the subcontinent.

title: Perseverance and Grace as Nepal Is Turned Upside Down
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  There has not been a day in the two years I have lived in Nepal that I havent thought about earthquakes. They were, in many ways, my obsession.

title: George W. Bush Opens Up About 2016 Race
description: LAS VEGAS  Former President George W. Bush offered rare, and broad-ranging, remarks Saturday night about current national security threats and the 2016 presidential campaign to a large audience of Jewish donors, suggesting that sanctions on Iran should not be lifted, that his last name was a burden to his brother, the likely presidential candidate Jeb Bush, and that Hillary Rodham Clinton, while formidable, was beatable.

title: Nepal Terrorized by Aftershocks, Hampering Relief Efforts
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  A growing sense of despair spread through Katmandu on Sunday as the devastated Nepali capital was convulsed by aftershocks that sent residents screaming into the streets, where they were pelted by heavy rain.

title: For Jeb Bush Donors, Yoga Mats and Tesla Brochures
description: MIAMI BEACH  This is not your grandfathers Republican Party donor retreat.

title: The Sensor-Rich, Data-Scooping Future
description: The technology world is looking at ways to make everything more efficient.

title: A View of Katmandu After the Earthquake
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  It had been an unseasonably cold and rainy Saturday morning. Twelve of us from the staff of The Nepali Times were on a hiking retreat on a hill overlooking the city. The sky was overcast, and we were disappointed not to have a view of the Himalayas to the north. Some of us looked down at the capital spreading out in the bowl-shaped valley below and talked about its rapid, haphazard growth.

title: 1915: French and British Join Allied Fleet in Dardanelles Campaign
description: LONDON  The Franco-British Expeditionary Corps which has left Egypt under command of General Sir Ian Hamilton, is now co-operating with the Allied fleet in the attack on the Dardanelles. Statements issued by the Admiralty and the War Office announce that the general attack on the Dardanelles was resumed yesterday [April 26] by the fleet.

title: Deutsche Bank Profit Falls on Legal Costs
description: FRANKFURT  Deutsche Bank, Germanys largest bank, said on Sunday that its net profit fell by half in the first quarter as it absorbed the legal costs of past wrongdoing by bank employees.

title: 1965: Indian Armed Forces on High Alert
description: NEW DELHI  India put its armed forces on an emergency alert today as Pakistani troops were reported to have launched another attack on an Indian position in the Rann of Kutch wasteland. Indian Defense Minister Y.B. Chavan told parliament that a Pakistani brigade with 3,000 frontline soldiers and the support of a sizable force of armor attacked the post of Biarbet, said to be six miles within Indian territory. An Indian spokesman tonight said fighting was continuing around Biarbet.

title: Furious 7 Tops Box Office For Fourth Week
description: LOS ANGELES  Big-budget, visual effects-driven summer movies will be packed cheek by jowl for four months starting Friday, with the release of Avengers: Age of Ultron. So it was the box office calm before the storm over the weekend, with no major movies arriving to challenge Furious 7, which was the No. 1 movie in North America for the fourth week in a row.

title: This Is Not A Trade Agreement
description: OK, Greg Mankiw has me puzzled. Has he really read nothing about TPP? Is he completely unaware of the nature of the argument?

title: A Journalists Night Off
description: Politicians and their critics graced the red carpet at the White House Correspondents Dinner, often referred to as a nerd prom.

title: A Dozen Whitney Works to Be Displayed in Lights on the Empire State Building
description: King Kong was so 20th century. All that climbing and heavy breathing  so low-tech. This is the 21st century. Marc Brickman can have his way with the Empire State Building from wherever he happens to be, which, on Friday, will probably be his usual hangout, somewhere in a hotel with an unobstructed view.

title: Tax Break Used by Investors in Flipping Art Faces Scrutiny
description: Introduced in the 1920s to ease the tax burden of farmers who wanted to swap property, it soon became a tool for real estate investors flipping, say, office buildings for shopping malls.

title: World Nomads Festival Will Put Focus on Tunisia
description: The culture of Tunisia will be on display once again at the French Institute Alliance Franaises World Nomads festival, coming to New York from May 8 to 10. The biennial festival, which in 2011 presented artists inspired by the Arab Spring, will feature the singer Sonia MBarek, the musician Bassam Saba, and the filmmaker Nejib Belkadhi.

title: Earthquake Aftershocks Jolt Nepal as Death Toll Rises Above 3,400
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  Each time this city shuddered with aftershocks from the earthquake that convulsed Nepal, Samaj Gautam felt an urge to join the millions of residents who fled to safety outdoors. But working in a hospital emergency ward inundated with the wounded, and their broken limbs, fractured skulls and other physical traumas, Dr. Gautam said Sunday night, he and his colleagues had to suppress their fears and stick to treating patients.

title: Turning a Childrens Rating System Into an Advocacy Army
description: WASHINGTON  James P. Steyer came here from San Francisco last week on a whirlwind tour to try to engage the countrys power brokers in his new crusade to put children and education at the top of the nations political agenda.

title: Justices to Hear Challenge That ArguesLethal-Injection Drug Causes Agony
description: The use of a lethal-injection drug involved in prolonged, apparently agonizing executions last year will come under scrutiny in the Supreme Court on Wednesday as the justices hear a case brought by three condemned prisoners from Oklahoma.

title: Rescue Efforts Continue in Nepal Quake
description: The Indian government and rescue workers discussed the search and relief efforts in Nepal on Sunday, following the magnitude 7.8 earthquake that struck the country a day earlier.

title: Searching for Survivors at Mount Everest
description: An avalanche, set off by the Nepal earthquake, rumbled down a treacherous icefall into a Mount Everest base camp, killing at least 17 climbers and injuring many others, officials said.

title: New Group to Host Stage Adaptation of To Kill a Mockingbird in Harper Lees Hometown
description: Harper Lees hometown of Monroeville will continue to be able to host a stage adaptation of her novel To Kill a Mockingbird next year but the production will be run by a new not-for-profit organization being created, not the local museum.

title: 2 Dead After Storm Strikes Alabama Sailing Regatta
description: By the time the Dauphin Island Race began in South Alabama on Saturday morning, the worst of the days weather seemed to have passed. Another shower, the sailors thought, might drop from the skies, but perhaps the rains would stay to the north, or over the shore.

title: Jeb Bush Says Spending $1 Billion on a Campaign Is Unnecessary
description: MIAMI BEACH  Jeb Bush said he thought it was unnecessary to spend $1 billion on a presidential campaign, a figure reached by both Mitt Romney and President Obama in 2012, saying a smart team could run a leaner operation.

title: As Boardroom Struggle Ends, Volkswagen Looks to the Future
description: FRANKFURT  Ferdinand Pich inspired many stories, and one comes from many years ago, when he noticed that cars on display at the Volkswagen dealership in Salzburg, Austria, were covered in snow.

title: We Werent Soldiers (Personal and Trivial)
description: Im going belatedly through files my father left, and discovered a folder of stuff about myself  report cards and all that. Plus this:

title: Nepal Earthquake Poses Challenge to International Aid Agencies
description: LONDON  International aid agencies and governments mobilized on Sunday to respond to the earthquake in Nepal, saying they faced challenges in getting assistance to the country and distributing it amid the widespread devastation there.

title: A Life on the Gridiron
description: Patrick Risha was born into a football family in a football-first community, and he became a star running back. After he graduated from college, though, there were signs that something was off.

title: Tennessee Williams Plays Coming to 59E59 Theaters Next Season
description: 59E59 Theaters announced its next seasons lineup, which includes six new short plays adapted from Tennessee Williams short stories. Pulitzer Prize-winner Beth Henley, PEN/Laura Pels Award-winner Marcus Gardley, and other playwrights have signed on to adapt Williamss works for productions starting in August.

title: Julian Fellowes to Adopt Trollope Novel for TV
description: The Julian Fellowes era continues.

title: Packed Field Stokes Competition for Digital Ad Dollars
description: Over the next two weeks, some of the biggest Internet companies and publishers will showcase their original programming in an annual attempt to attract advertising dollars. The events, taking place in New York under the banner of the Digital Content NewFronts, are equal parts sales pitch and festival. This year, they are also something else: crowded.

title: Jailed Venezuelan Mayor Is Moved to Hospital for Surgery
description: The mayor of Caracas, Venezuela, who has been jailed on charges of conspiring against the government of President Nicols Maduro, was moved to a private hospital over the weekend for a hernia operation on Sunday. He will be transferred to house arrest later while he recuperates, according to his wife and a spokesman.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of April 27
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Burdened With Debt, Law School Graduates Struggle in Job Market
description: Jonathan Wang has not practiced law since he graduated from Columbia Law School in 2010, but he did not plan it that way.

title: Cavaliers Finish Sweep of Celtics but Lose Kevin Love to Injury
description: BOSTON  The Celtics were undeniably a feel-good story over the last two months of the N.B.A.s regular season. But in the playoffs, the cold, hard reality is that warm and wonderful stories of plucky underdogs and spunky overachievers invariably end when they collide head-on with showstopping talent.

title: A Son of Football Calls His Mother
description: DOYLESTOWN, Pa.  A mother sat at the edge of her bed. Angel figurines gazed down from a shelf, and a wooden sign on the wall offered inspirational words about life and love. They provided no comfort. She was on the edge, cellphone pressed to her ear.

title: Concerns on Jeep Safety Remain, Despite Recall
description: DETROIT  Since its bankruptcy and government bailout in 2009, the American automaker Chrysler has made a stirring comeback primarily by expanding sales of its popular Jeep sport utility vehicles.

title: Review: A Young Mans Voyage, Awash in Taboo Desires, in Blackbird
description: Theres impressive, palpable conviction in Patrik-Ian Polks drama Blackbird, an adaptation  written by Mr. Polk and Rikki Beadle Blair  of Larry Duplechans 1986 novel about a young black mans coming out. But despite its sense of mission, the film suffers from soapy excesses and narrative disjunctures.

title: Review: In Look Whos Back, Hitler Returns and Hes Amusing
description: A time traveler in military uniform wakes up on a sunny Berlin afternoon in 2011, looking up at a blue sky without enemy aircraft overhead. He hears no shelling, explosions or sirens. That the city still stands despite his orders that it be destroyed, right down to the screws and door handles, is something that puzzles him. On the other hand, I am here too, he thinks, and I cannot understand that either.

title: U.S. - Japan Alliance
description: Shinzo Abe, Prime Minister of Japan, will visit the U.S. this week to highlight close ties between the two countries.

title: Kazakhstan President Set to Win Fifth Term, Even as Economy Falters
description: MOSCOW  Voters in Kazakhstan were set to re-elect an incumbent on Sunday who has ruled the country since the Soviet Union collapsed, in an election that could have only one outcome.

title: Bill Hicks, Revived on Video to Jar Viewers Out of Apathy
description: Years ago, the comedian Bill Hicks began one of his stand-up specials with a video of himself riding a white horse and wearing a cowboy hat while talking about fighting corruption and evil. In another, he walked onstage in a black turtleneck sweater, arms extended like a guru welcoming his acolytes. He called himself a dark poet and an artist trying to illuminate the collective unconscious and help humanity.

title: A Night of Philosophy, 12 Hours of a Mental Marathon
description: The mental marathon billed as A Night of Philosophy began in an analytic frenzy at 7 p.m. on Friday as three speakers held forth simultaneously in separate lecture rooms: Monique Canto-Sperber, of the National Center for Scientific Research in Paris, dissected the notion of free speech in a liberal society. Chiara Bottici, of the New School for Social Research, discussed Machiavellis ideas about fortune. And Pascal Engel, of the University of Geneva, issued a ringing call for deep thought in a talk titled Must Intellectual Life Be Boring?

title: Review: Yokohama Rosa, With Michiko Godai, at Japan Society
description: Twenty-four years ago, the Japanese actress Michiko Godai caught sight of a homeless woman in Yokohama. A frail, stooped figure, the woman wandered the city in a white dress and ghostly white makeup. Fascinated, Ms. Godai began to interview anyone who knew her, gathering the scattered details of her life. Joining a few unconfirmed facts with considerable invention, she and the playwright Giho Sugiyama created Yokohama Rosa, which played briefly at the Japan Society in Manhattan as part of its Stories From the War series commemorating the end of World War II.

title: Review: Tales of the Grim Sleeper Investigates Los Angeles Murders
description: After its success with Andrew Jareckis The Jinx: The Life and Deaths of Robert Durst, HBO on Monday night offers another documentary about a man accused of murders that have gone unsolved for decades. Nick Broomfields Tales of the Grim Sleeper couldnt be more different from The Jinx, however.

title: Vietnam Is Focus of TV Programs During Fall of Saigon Anniversary
description: The PBS programmers get a little carried away this week with the 40th anniversary of the fall of Saigon, but the occasion at least gives Rory Kennedys excellent Last Days in Vietnam an opportunity to reach a broader audience. And if the other PBS offerings arent as compelling, you can wander over to the Smithsonian Channel for an absorbing special called The Spy in the Hanoi Hilton.

title: Reflecting as a Run Comes to an End
description: It was with much sadness that I learned The New York Times has decided to eliminate its bridge column. I wish to end our coverage of the worlds greatest card game over the next week by mentioning the papers bridge columnists.

title: Review: I Fagiolini, Richard Goode and the Juilliard Opera in Concert
description: I FAGIOLINI

title: Losing Speech
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  HECK YES, its time to start the week off fresh with a breezy Monday puzzle.

title: Survivors Rescued From Mount Everest
description: Rescue crews airlifted survivors from the Mount Everest base camp on Sunday after Nepals worst earthquake in 81 years triggered a series of avalanches.

title: Dewey & LeBoeuf Trial Is Expected to Be Lengthy
description: For the legal profession, the trial of three lawyers charged with concealing Dewey & LeBoeufs failing financial situation from investors in the once mighty New York law firm may well be the most closely watched trial in years.

title: Sharon Levin to Leave U.S. Attorneys Office for WilmerHale, Joining Other Ex-Prosecutors
description: Over the last 24 years, Sharon Cohen Levin built a multibillion-dollar operation  not as a trader or banker, but as a prosecutor.

title: Saudi-Led Air Campaign Resumes in Yemeni Capital
description: AL MUKALLA, Yemen  Warplanes of the Saudi-led military coalition bombed targets in the Yemeni capital on Sunday for the first time since Saudi officials said they were shifting the focus of their campaign against a Yemeni rebel group toward political negotiations and humanitarian relief.

title: Brazils Power Dynamics Shifting Amid Political Scandals
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The head of Brazils Senate, Renan Calheiros, has been accused of tax evasion, using a government jet to visit a surgeon who alleviated his baldness with hair implants and allowing a construction companys lobbyist to pay child support for his daughter from an extramarital affair with a television journalist.

title: The Stoop and the Universe
description: Dear Diary:

title: Remember Llama Drama? These Folks Do
description: A retirement community in Sun City, Ariz., was a focus of Internet attention in February, when two llamas escaped after a visit. Residents fondly remember their brush with fame.

title: Jay Z Counters Reports of Struggles at Tidal Music Streaming Service
description: Jay Z took to Twitter on Sunday to defend his new streaming music service Tidal, after news reports suggested that the app was slipping into early oblivion.

title: Clippers Absorb Their Coachs Tongue-Lashing, Then Make a Statement
description: SAN ANTONIO  When Doc Rivers, the coach of the Los Angeles Clippers, gathered to review film with his players on Saturday, the experience was not enjoyable.

title: After Great Escape, Llamas (and Owners) Adjust to Fame
description: PHOENIX  Their brush with freedom was over, and now the most notorious llamas in Arizona, if not the nation, were back in their dusty backyard, peeking out of their pen with their long necks and big eyes. They were home, though their lives were anything but the same.

title: Gay Businessman Who Hosted Ted Cruz Event Apologizes
description: Ian Reisner, one of the two gay hoteliers facing boycott calls for hosting an event for Senator Ted Cruz, who is adamantly opposed to same-sex marriage, apologized to the gay community for showing poor judgment.

title: Fashion Is Trending, in Google Searches
description: Whats in or out: an analysis of six billion Google searches shows how clothing styles spread from state to state.

title: The Latest Fashion, Trending on Google
description: Normcore? So last year. String bikinis? Most definitely over.

title: Deron Williamss Injury Lingers After Nets Reviving Win
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Deron Williamss mercurial postseason took another hairpin turn Sunday when his Nets teammate Joe Johnson let slip that Williams might be playing with severe tendinitis.

title: White House Takes Cybersecurity Pitch to Silicon Valley
description: SAN FRANCISCO  President Obamas newly installed defense secretary, Ashton B. Carter, toured Silicon Valley last week to announce a new military strategy for computer conflict, starting the latest Pentagon effort to invest in promising start-ups and to meet with engineers whose talent he declared the Pentagon desperately needed in fending off the nations adversaries.

title: Effort by Japan to Stifle News Media Is Working
description: TOKYO  It was an unexpected act of protest that shook Japans carefully managed media world: Shigeaki Koga, a regular television commentator and fierce critic of the political establishment, abruptly departed from the scripted conversation during a live TV news program to announce that this would be his last day on the show because, as he put it, network executives had succumbed to political pressure for his removal.

title: Israeli Military Says It Killed Armed Men in Strike on Golan Heights Frontier
description: JERUSALEM  An Israeli airstrike killed members of an armed squad that was preparing to bomb Israeli forces on Sunday along the Israeli-Syrian frontier in the Golan Heights, the Israeli military said.

title: Suspect Fatally Shot by Detective in East Village Had Mental Illness and a Troubled Past
description: Harold Carter and Vicente Matias, two veteran detectives from a Harlem police precinct, arrived at a six-story building on East Sixth Street in Manhattan on Saturday afternoon in search of a robbery suspect.

title: Comcast-Time Warner Cable Deals Collapse Leaves Frustrated Customers Out in the Cold
description: In the vast realm of unhappy cable customers, Time Warner Cable subscribers stand out as an especially miserable bunch.

title: G.O.P. Struggling With Shifts on Gay Marriage
description: Rick Santorum said he would never attend a same-sex wedding. Marco Rubio said he might attend one. Scott Walker actually went to a same-sex wedding reception, not to be confused with an actual same-sex wedding ceremony. Ted Cruz said he is firmly opposed to gay marriage, but would be comfortable if his daughter were gay.

title: In Rare Remarks, George W. Bush Argues Against the Lifting of Iran Sanctions
description: LAS VEGAS  Former President George W. Bush said the United States must show that it can follow through on its promises, and argued against the lifting of sanctions against Iran during rare remarks about foreign policy in a meeting with hundreds of Jewish donors here Saturday night.

title: Chipotle to Stop Using Genetically Altered Ingredients
description: In a first for a major restaurant chain, Chipotle Mexican Grill on Monday will begin preparing only food that is free of genetically engineered ingredients.

title: Republican Contenders Reach Out to Sheldon Adelson, Palms Up
description: LAS VEGAS  In a country wary of dynasties, former President George W. Bush said he could be a liability for his younger brother Jeb, a likely presidential candidate.

title: Jeb Bush Adopts a Surprising Style in Eco-Friendly Miami Beach
description: MIAMI BEACH  On his way to an ecologically friendly hotel here on Sunday, Jeb Bush ate a Paleo-diet-approved bison burger wrapped in lettuce and served by a Democrat-loving drag queen turned waiter.

title: New Amendments Imperil Measure on Iran in Congress
description: WASHINGTON  A bill to give Congress a voice in the nuclear deal with Iran is now endangered by Republican amendments that would peel away bipartisan support for a measure begrudgingly accepted by the White House this month.

title: Apple Earnings, Automaker Results and New Products From Tesla
description: Here are some of the top business stories to pay attention to in the coming week.

title: Six PEN Members Decline Gala After Award for Charlie Hebdo
description: The decision by PEN American Center to give its annual Freedom of Expression Courage award to the French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo has prompted six writers to withdraw as literary hosts at the groups annual gala on May 5, adding a new twist to the continuing debate over the publications status as a martyr for free speech.

title: Ellis Island Museum to Update the Story of Immigration in America
description: Everywhere in America, immigration is an unending story. Everywhere, that is, except at the Ellis Island Immigration Museum, where the story ends in 1954, when the immigrant processing and detention station there was closed.

title: Nepal Earthquake: Where to Donate
description: Here is a list of some of the groups soliciting donations for relief efforts in Nepal:

title: Opposition Grows as Home for Troubled Youths Comes to Quiet Queens Block
description: Michael Duvalle squared up in front of a two-story brick building on a quiet residential block in southern Queens and brought a megaphone to his lips. A retired security executive and local resident, Mr. Duvalle had a message for the commissioner of the citys Administration for Childrens Services, Gladys Carrin.

title: Downside of Police Body Cameras: Your Arrest Hits YouTube
description: Police departments around the country have been moving with unusual speed to equip officers with body cameras to film their often edgy encounters with the public. But the adoption of these cameras has created a new conflict over who has the right to view the recordings.

title: In an Already Troubled Nepal, a Picture of Despair Emerges
description: NEW DELHI  Her home and village near the earthquakes epicenter were destroyed, her grandfather was killed, and no one from outside the village  not a soldier, police officer or rescue worker  had arrived to help.

title: More Meh Than Meaning in Early Subway Series
description: So many people, it seemed, wanted to make this series between the Mets and the Yankees into something significant. The teams each owned a share of first place  the first time that has happened when they met each other. Matt Harvey would face Alex Rodriguez, a showdown that might have had historic  and theatrical  implications if Rodriguez were to tie Willie Mays on the career home run list. Were the Mets, who had won 11 in a row, really for real? Were the Yankees, who had won six of seven, tiptoeing back toward relevance?

title: Popular Demand
description: Its no surprise that the largest Internet properties, which offer multiple services like email, social media applications, entertainment and search, reached the most users in March.

title: Character Building at Japanese Festival
description: The annual Sakura Matsuri Festival, which showcases traditional and modern Japanese culture, was held over the weekend at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Odd Goal Against Galaxy Leads to Draw, and Red Bulls Stay Unbeaten
description: HARRISON, N.J.  The early wins were one thing. But when the Red Bulls started scoring goals accidentally  shots that went in off a teammates face, say, instead of out after clipping the post  it became easier to believe that their unbeaten start in Major League Soccer might not be a fluke.

title: Review: Anne Hathaway as a Fighter Pilot in Grounded at the Public Theater

title: At TPG, a Low-Profile Funds Diversity Thrives
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Since its inception, TPG has been best known for the leveraged buyouts of prominent companies including Continental Airlines, Neiman Marcus and a now-bankrupt Texas utility that was a big player in the energy sector.

description: Here be spoilers and more High Septon than you wanted to see.

title: Not Your Dads Pinewood Derby (at Least in Theory)
description: BROOKFIELD, Wis.  It starts with a block of wood, four wheels and four nails. It fills boys with hope and creativity; it fills parents with obsession or dread.

title: In Full Bloom at Japanese Festival in Brooklyn
description: The annual Sakura Matsuri Festival, which showcases traditional and modern Japanese culture, was held over the weekend at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. The festival, in its 34th year, has expanded to include a fashion show of cosplay, short for costume play, in which people dress as characters from anime, video games, film and elsewhere in popular culture.

title: Drought Frames Economic Divide of Californians
description: COMPTON, Calif.  Alysia Thomas, a stay-at-home mother in this working-class city, tells her children to skip a bath on days when they do not play outside; that holds down the water bill. Lillian Barrera, a housekeeper who travels 25 miles to clean homes in Beverly Hills, serves dinner to her family on paper plates for much the same reason. In the fourth year of a severe drought, conservation is a fine thing, but in this Southern California community, saving water means saving money.

title: Jeb Bushs Record Fund-Raising Total
description: MIAMI BEACH  Jeb Bush told donors here that he believed his political action committee had raised more money in 100 days than any other modern Republican political operation, according to those who heard him.

description: The police have arrested a man in the death last month of a 70-year-old Queens woman who was shot when she answered her front door.

title: Program Aims to Reduce Energy Costs and Keep Rents Affordable in Bronx
description: Long before it finally died last month, the old, rusted boiler in the basement of the five-story apartment building in the Bronx needed to go. It routinely broke down, leaving tenants without heat or hot water. It burned through copious amounts of heating oil and ran up thousands of extra dollars in bills.

title: Islanders Enter Finale on Road Buoyed by a Win at Home
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  John Tavares always exudes calmness, so it is no surprise to hear that he views his first postseason Game 7 as he would any road game.

title: Alex Rodriguez Revives Familiar Pattern With Approach to Matching Willie Mays
description: For a designated hitter who is soon to be 40, going more than a week without a home run is nothing to be alarmed about. But for Alex Rodriguez, who, entering Sundays game, was two shy of tying Willie Mays at 660 homers for fourth on the career list, it followed a familiar pattern.

title: Officers Indictment Is Protested
description: Marchers on the Brooklyn Bridge Sunday condemned the February indictment of Peter Liang, 28, in the fatal shooting of an unarmed man in a Brooklyn housing project in November.

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) WILD AT HEART (1990) Lula Pace Fortune (Laura Dern, above), a 20-year-old peach who describes herself as hotter than Georgia asphalt, and Sailor Ripley (Nicolas Cage), her gentle ex-con beau, take off from Cape Fear, N.C., for Big Tuna, Tex., on what they see as a trip down their own Yellow Brick Road in search of the Wizard of Oz. But the private detective Johnnie Farragut (Harry Dean Stanton) is fast on their trail with Lulas beauty queen mother, Marietta (Diane Ladd, in an Oscar-nominated performance), who wants Sailor dead. Willem Dafoe, wearing brown, wired-together teeth, plays the no-good gangster Bobby Peru; Isabella Rossellini is his unnaturally blond Mexican mistress; and Crispin Glover is Lulas cousin, who puts cockroaches in his underwear for pleasure. The director David Lynch believes that more is more but, after a while, the films odd inventions begin to exhaust, Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times about this adaptation of Barry Giffords road novel, which won the Palme dOr at the Cannes Film Festival. But though Miss Dern and Mr. Cage are constantly upstaged by the rest of the movie, they triumph.

title: Alex Rodriguez Closes In on Willie Mays as Yankees Beat Mets

title: Think of Undocumented Immigrants as Parents, Not Problems
description: LOS ANGELES  SOMETHING happened while the immigration system in the United States got broken, something that should change the way we talk about fixing it. Years went by, and nature took its course. More than 11 million unauthorized immigrants settled into our communities; many formed families and had children. Now at least one of every 15 children living in the United States has an unauthorized parent, and nearly all of those children are native-born United States citizens.

title: A Spotlight on Japans Wartime Past
Nobody Said That
description: Imagine yourself as a regular commentator on public affairs  maybe a paid pundit, maybe a supposed expert in some area, maybe just an opinionated billionaire. You weigh in on a major policy initiative thats about to happen, making strong predictions of disaster. The Obama stimulus, you declare, will cause soaring interest rates; the Feds bond purchases will debase the dollar and cause high inflation; the Affordable Care Act will collapse in a vicious circle of declining enrollment and surging costs.

title: Junk Science at the F.B.I.

Based largely on this compelling statistic, drawn from the testimony of an analyst with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Mr. Tribble, 17 at the time, was convicted of the crime and sentenced to 20 years to life.

title: The Plays the Thing. And the Pay, Too?
How Super PACs Can Run Campaigns
description: The 2016 presidential campaign has barely begun, but it is already clear this will be the super contest of the super PACs  the fast evolving political money machines that are irresistible to candidates because they can legally raise unlimited money from donors seeking favor and influence.

title: Deutsche Bank Shakes Up Its Business, and Maybe Its Identity

title: R.B.S. Agrees to Sell Another Batch of Company Loans to Mizuho

title: Tsarnaevs Lawyers Focus on Chaotic Upbringing in Case Against Death Penalty
description: BOSTON  His lawyers offered no moral objection to the death penalty. In fact, they said, being put to death would not be punishment enough  it could never be commensurate with the horrific crimes he committed, so there is no point even bothering. The scales could never be balanced.

title: Colorado Shooting Trial of James E. Holmes Pits a Calculated Killer Against an Erratic Mind
description: CENTENNIAL, Colo.  Pointing at the gunman, who sat in a button-down shirt and was tethered to the courtroom floor by a security cable, District Attorney George Brauchler described him in an opening argument Monday as a brilliant neuroscience student who had failed at his graduate studies, been dumped by his first girlfriend, and lost his purpose.

title: Doctors to Divas, Stagehands and Opera Lovers at the Met

title: How to Read the Ups and Downs of Polling in the G.O.P. Race
description: The polling roller coaster, as FiveThirtyEights Harry Enten put it, has begun. One week the headline is Ted Cruz Surging in Polls. Three weeks later, its Marco Rubio Surges to Front of G.O.P. Pack.

title: Why Might an Artist Choose to Turn Away From the Public Eye?
description: What do you think drives creativity: a passion for the art form, a quest for fame or maybe some combination of both? Or is it something else entirely?

title: Atlas Mara in Talks for Stake in Second Rwandan Bank
description: LONDON  The investment company Atlas Mara Limited, backed by Robert E. Diamond Jr., the former Barclays chief executive, said on Monday that it was in talks for another banking deal in Africa.

title: The Life of Saul Bellow: To Fame and Fortune, 1915-1964, by Zachary Leader
description: The very long first volume of Zachary Leaders biography of Saul Bellow  a second book will cover the later years  ends in 1964, with the publication of Herzog, the novel that secured Bellows position, at age 49, as the more or less undisputed champ of midcentury American fiction. The country was becoming steadily citified, and Bellow  born outside Montreal, raised in Chicago, at home in Manhattan  was the laureate of the new urban cosmos. Mr. Bellow has something like a genius for place, V.S. Pritchett marveled in The New York Review of Books. There is not a descriptive insinuator of what a city like New York is like from minute to minute who comes anywhere near him. Some novelists stage it, others document it; he is breathing in it. The big ideas and Great Books blurtings of Moses Herzog, a cuckolded professor and poor soldier of culture who goes on a half-crazed letter-writing spree (Dear Doktor Professor Heidegger), bounce like molecules off the shifting surfaces and bristling planes of Manhattan: the crowded sidewalks and pinched apartments, the humps of brown rock speckled with mica in Central Park, glimpsed between the blinds of an Upper West Side doctors office whose dark walls seemed swollen with the disease of old buildings in New York. Dropping his subway fare in the slot, Herzog sees a whole series of tokens lighted from within and magnified by the glass and notes that innumerable millions of passengers had polished the wood of the turnstile with their hips. In Bellows urban pastoral, mass human activity both exhilarates and terrifies, duplicating natures impersonal patterned randomness  as megatons of water shape organisms on the ocean floor. As tides polish stones. As winds hollow cliffs.

title: There Is Simply Too Much to Think About, Saul Bellows Nonfiction
description: The flies wait hungrily in the air, writes Saul Bellow (in a description of Shawneetown in southern Illinois), sheets of flies that make a noise like the tearing of tissue paper. Go and tear some tissue paper in two, slowly: It sounds just like the sullen purr of bristling vermin. But how, you wonder, did Bellow know what torn tissue paper sounded like in the first place? And then you wonder what this minutely vigilant detail is doing in Holiday magazine (in 1957), rather than in the work in progress, Henderson the Rain King (1959). It or something even better probably is in Henderson. For Bellows fictional and nonfictional voices intertwine and cross-pollinate. This is from a film review of 1962: There she is, stout and old, a sinking, squarish frame of bones. Two decades later the image would effloresce in the story/novella Cousins:

title: Katmandu: Before the Quake
description: Katmandus ancient sites were woven into the vibrant social and religious fabric of the city. Made of brick and timber, many of these iconic buildings were lost in the earthquake that rocked Nepal.

title: New York Today: The Artist Was Present
description: Good morning on this graying Monday.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Keep Moving to Stay a Step Ahead of Arthritis
description: I was a fanatical tennis player for decades until my increasingly painful arthritic knees forced me to stop playing. The knees were replaced two years later, but by then, I had filled in my life with other activities, including a daily three-mile walk and aerobic swim, and cycling for exercise and errands.

title: The Dandy Fellows at Fellow Barber
description: A Brooklyn barbershop caters to clients who may need a little trim but who are all set fashionwise.

title: Applied Materials and Tokyo Electron Call Off $10 Billion Merger
description: TOKYO  Two of the worlds largest manufacturers of the machinery used to produce semiconductors, Applied Materials of the United States and Tokyo Electron of Japan, on Monday dropped plans to merge after the Department of Justice said that combining their businesses would restrict competition.

title: A Boy, a Dog, a Decision
description: My three-year-old son, Archer, wants to go buy a gun. Right. Now.

title: ScienceTake | Leaping Moths
description: In order to take off, many moths launch themselves into the air with a powerful jump.

title: Kazakhstans President Is Re-elected by Almost Every Voter
description: MOSCOW  Election officials in Kazakhstan announced on Monday that voters had re-elected an incumbent who has governed the country since the Soviet Union collapsed, in an election that only ever had one likely winner.

title: Legs Give Moths a Flying Start
description: Moths often have relatively large wings, which can pose a problem as they take off. The wings might thrash against a leaf or the ground.

title: The Sinking of the Sultana
description: As John Wilkes Booth stepped into President Lincolns booth at Fords Theater on the evening of April 14, 1865, Union prisoners of war were heading home on foot and by rail, free from Andersonville, Cahaba and other prisons. Several thousand men had been brought to a transit camp at Vicksburg, Miss., where they awaited transport along the Mississippi River.

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | April 27, 2015
description: Updated: April 28, 2015

title: Today in Politics: Rand Paul Goes to New York to Coax a Wary Bloc
description: Good Monday morning from Washington, where the gardens are showing their colors, and the Senate is shifting its focus from attorneys general to Irans nuclear program. Jeb Bush broke some Republican stereotypes at an event in Miami, while he and Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky continue to seek to ease some conservatives concerns over their positions on Israel.

title: Reclaiming the Power of Play
description: Play is the highest form of human activity. At least thats what Friedrich Nietzsche suggested in Thus Spoke Zarathustra, when he described a three-step development of the human spirit. First, the human psyche has the form of a camel because it takes on the heavy burden of cultural duties  ethical obligations, social rank, and the weight of tradition. Next, the camel transforms into a lion, which represents the rebellion of the psyche  the holy nay that frees a rule-governed person from slavish obedience to authority. Finally, this negative insurgent phase evolves into the highest level of humanity, symbolized as the playing child  innocent and creative, the holy yea. Cue the Richard Strauss music.

title: Sobi, Swedish Maker of Drugs for Rare Diseases, Receives Takeover Bid
description: LONDON  The biopharmaceutical maker Swedish Orphan Biovitrum said on Monday that it had received a preliminary takeover offer from an unnamed suitor.

title: Discrimination Without Clear Intent
The Deadliest Earthquakes Since 2000
description: Five deadly earthquakes.

title: Daily Report: The Latest Fashion, Trending on Google
description: Normcore? So last year. String bikinis? Most definitely over, writes Hiroko Tabuchi.

title: Keeping Count: Corrupt Chinese Officials and Their Mistresses
description: Chinese news organizations caused a stir when they published stories last month saying that a senior security and intelligence official ensnared in an anticorruption investigation had six mistresses and two sons with them.

title: Details Emerge of China-Financed Dam Project in Pakistan
description: In all the bravura of the recent $45 billion offer by President Xi Jinping of China to build roads, rails and dams in Pakistan, it was hard to decipher when construction would begin, and what in a long list of infrastructure projects would be tackled first.

title: Baltimore Enlists National Guard and a Curfew to Fight Riots and Looting
description: BALTIMORE  Marylands governor activated the National Guard on Monday and the city of Baltimore announced a curfew for all residents as a turbulent day that began with the funeral of 25-year-old Freddie Gray, the nations latest symbol of police brutality, ended with rioting by rock-throwing youths, arson, looting and at least 15 police officers injured.

title: Morning Agenda: Comcasts Ambitions Likely to Remain Intact
description: COMCASTS AMBITIONS LIKELY TO REMAIN INTACT  | Though Comcast has suffered an ignominious and humbling defeat in withdrawing its $45 billion bid for Time Warner Cable, Brian L. Roberts, Comcasts chief executive, isnt likely to let the setback quell his ambitions,  David Gelles writes in DealBook. For a company like Comcast, taking big and risky bets is part of its business plan, says James McQuivey, an analyst at Forrester Research. You only get to be the biggest cable company and largest broadband provider in the country by swinging for the fences, Mr. McQuivey says.

title: Was Styles the Right Place for a Look at Sweet Briars Legacy?
description: At Sweet Briar College, the traditions are proud but the days are numbered.

title: Chinese Officers Harshly Interrogated Womens Rights Activist, Husband Says
description: BEIJING  A womens rights activist, who was among five female advocates whose detention for over a month led to a global outcry, was harshly interrogated for eight hours by police officers in her hometown, Hangzhou, on Friday, her husband said on Monday.

title: Getting In to College Doesnt Mean Students Are Ready to Go
description: Last October I held a hastily scheduled psychotherapy session with a teenager facing a disastrous start to her college career. When we met, she somberly shared that she was on her universitys radar for her uncontrolled drinking and had a coming court date for a disorderly conduct charge. Her parents wanted her to withdraw right away, but she had just started to make some solid friendships at college and was reluctant to go home. I saw her point, but understood where her parents were coming from: Given that she was clearly struggling, it was hard to imagine how she would handle the additional strain of trying to recover from her faltering start.

title: Nepal Villages Cut Off by Earthquake Wait for Aid as Death Toll Passes 4,000
description: SAURPANI, Nepal  Five hours by car from Katmandu, then by foot for several miles past the spot where the road is blocked by boulders and mud, people from the villages near the epicenter of Nepals powerful earthquake are burying their dead, despairing of help arriving anytime soon.

title: Lawyers Seek Sea Change on Gay Rights at Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON  In the months leading to Tuesdays Supreme Court arguments on same-sex marriage, teams of gay rights lawyers and their allies have held countless strategy sessions, drafted scores of briefs and participated in intense moot courts.

description: The beefcake has left the building. As have the ad campaigns, the catalogs, the gift cards, the website  all the marketing images you might see.

title: Addiction Research and Care Collide With Federal Privacy Rules
description: Researchers who want to study Medicare or Medicaid patients with substance-use disorders  and illnesses disproportionately affecting them like H.I.V. and hepatitis C  are, at best, working with biased data. At worst, theyre flying blind.

title: Nepal Searches for Survivors After Earthquake
description: Officials in Nepal said most of the deaths were in and around the capital, but the quake touched a vast expanse of the subcontinent.

title: Where the Islamic State Gets Its Weapons
description: Early one morning in late February, a European investigator working in Kobani, the northern Syrian city that for months had been a battleground between Kurdish fighters and militants from the Islamic State, stepped outside the building where he was staying and saw something unusual. A Kurd on the street was carrying a long black assault rifle that the investigator thought was an American-made M-16.

title: South Korean Premier on His Resignation
description: At a departing ceremony on Monday, Prime Minister Lee Wan-koo of South Korea apologized over a scandal that led to his resignation, saying he hoped the truth will eventually reveal itself.

title: 1940: Fighting in Three Directions
description: STOCKHOLM  Fighting raged today [April 27] along the three main communication lines spreading fan-shape out of Oslo with Norwegian and Allied forces halting the German advance at Voss, between Bergen and Oslo, and at Kvam, between Dombaas and Lillehammer, while the Germans continued their advance toward Roros, in the Oesterdal. In addition, there were sharp engagements in the Trondhjem sector, where the Allies north and south of the port continued to hold up German attempts to link their forces coming from Namsos and Andalsnes.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 28, 1940

title: Greece Says It Is Changing Team That Negotiates With Creditors
description: ATHENS  Ever since the leftist-led Greek government came to power in late January, the avatar of the countrys austerity-weary public has been its outspoken, motorcycle-riding renegade finance minister, Yanis Varoufakis.

title: A Scene of Destruction After Ice Thunders Into Everest Base Camp
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  Even for Lakpa Rita, a revered Nepalese mountaineer who has reached the summit of Mount Everest 17 times, the roaring wall of boulders, rocks, ice and debris that pulverized much of the mountains base camp over the weekend signified a malign new twist in the peaks destructive powers.

title: Mylan Rejects Tevas $40 Billion Takeover Offer

Sounds from a ballgame  a cheering crowd, announcers banter, fastballs popping into a catchers mitt  filled his living room.

Pacing, circling, brushing up against one another in the opening sequences of Yael Farbers Nirbhaya  the harrowing documentary drama that opened on Sunday night at the Lynn Redgrave Theater  a mere half-dozen performers evoke the explosive contingency of life in an overpopulated city.

description: Theres a short story collection by Cathy Day called The Circus in Winter that I thought about a lot on the long drives in Iowa and New Hampshire over the past couple weeks while covering Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign.

title: Why Is the Rising Death Toll in the Nepal Earthquake Still Lower Than Predictions?
description: Amid the horror and devastation around Nepals Katmandu Valley after Saturdays 7.8-magnitude earthquake, seismologists and earthquake-focused engineers are remarking on how low the death counts are  particularly in the capital  compared to many predictions for the densely populated, deeply impoverished and ill-prepared region.

description: Loretta E. Lynch, a career federal prosecutor, was sworn in Monday as the nations 83rd attorney general, as Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. told a room full of Justice Department officials: She is one of you.

title: Head Start for Jeb Bush Campaign Is Part of Scott Walkers Plan
description: It is a gamble at once audacious and born of necessity: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, a likely Republican candidate for president, has put campaign plans in motion that cede early momentum to his chief rival, Jeb Bush, in favor of beating Mr. Bush and other opponents with a long-game strategy designed to achieve financial and political success next winter.

title: President of Sudan Is Re-elected With 94 Percent of Vote
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan, the countrys longtime leader, was declared re-elected on Monday, winning 94 percent of the vote in balloting that was boycotted by opposition groups and marred by low turnout and public apathy.

title: 1965: Forces Storm Santo Domingo
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic  Military forces opposed to the return of former President Juan D. Bosch stormed into Santo Domingo today [April 27] with tanks and infantry. The anti-Bosch forces, under Army Gen. Elias Wessin y Wessin, fought their way into the capital across two bridges after the Navy joined anti-Bosch air-force planes in bombarding the city from sea and air. The forces under Gen. Wessin y Wessin approved last weekends military coup ousting the civilian junta of Donald Reid Cabral, but opposed the return of Mr. Bosch from his 19-month exile in Puerto Rico.  New York Herald Tribune, European edition, April 28, 1965

title: Congregants Challenge Sale of Bulwark of Judaism on Lower East Side
description: Each day, about a dozen Orthodox Jewish men in black hats and skullcaps file into the Home of the Sages, a Manhattan nursing home in the shadow of the Williamsburg Bridge.

title: The Fine Line Between Smart and Illegal
description: Prosecuting fraud begins with identifying a lie that leads the victim to lose something of value. The criminal charges announced  last week against Navinder Singh Sarao for spoofing orders for futures contracts raises the question whether they are enough to constitute fraud, the key to the governments effort to extradite him from Britain.

title: New Study Links Weather Extremes to Global Warming
description: The moderate global warming that has already occurred as a result of human emissions has quadrupled the frequency of certain heat extremes since the Industrial Revolution, scientists reported Monday, and they warned that a failure to bring greenhouse gases under control could eventually lead to a 62-fold increase in such heat blasts.

title: British Conservatives Suspend Candidate for Anti-Semitic Facebook Slur
description: The British Conservative Party suspended a candidate for a seat in local government on Monday after she posted an anti-Semitic slur on Facebook over the weekend.

title: A Starling Picnic, With Gusto
description: Q. A huge flock of starlings arrives in our neighborhood a couple of times a day. They poke around frantically in the lawns for a few minutes, then leave all together. What could they be eating?

title: Only Three Wolves Left on an Island Full of Prey
description: Only three wolves  a male, a female and a 9-month-old pup  remain in Isle Royale National Park in Michigan, where wolves have been studied for nearly 60 years. Researchers first noticed their numbers declining in 2009, possibly because of inbreeding. The population will probably not recover naturally, biologists have concluded. The pup appears to be sickly, with a constricted waistline, hunched posture and a deformed tail. The wolves prey on moose, whose population is on the rise. More than 1,000 have been spotted on the island.

title: Kentucky Derby 2015: Dortmund Leads Field of Contenders
description: The field for the Kentucky Derby on Saturday looks unusually strong. The winners of all the major prep races are expected to start, and few top contenders have dropped out with an injury. The draw is Wednesday, but here is an early look at the major players, ranked in approximate order from contender to pretender.

title: Fear Keeps Traders on Sidelines of Drug Mega-Deals
description: Fear is keeping traders on the sidelines of the latest mega-deals in the pharmaceutical industry.

description: ESPN filed a lawsuit against Verizon in New York Supreme Court on Monday, asserting that the telecommunications company breached its contract with the network when it unveiled a new cable package last week.

title: Harvey R. Miller, Renowned Bankruptcy Lawyer, Dies at 82
description: Harvey R. Miller, one of the countrys pre-eminent corporate bankruptcy lawyers, who shepherded clients as diverse as Continental Airlines, Lehman Brothers and General Motors through Chapter 11, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82.

title: NASAs Messenger Mission Is Set to Crash Into Mercury
description: NASAs Messenger spacecraft, in orbit around Mercury the past four years, will come to an abrupt end on Thursday.

title: Want to Talk With Your Children About Bruce Jenner? Consider Letting Them Talk to You
description: Here is the conversation I had with my 13-year-old this morning: Me, in a chair in the waiting room at the orthodontist: Do you know who Bruce Jenner is? An issue of Popular Science in hands, 13-year-old: No.
