description: Sophisticated software has enabled a market for organ donation, without any money changing hands.

title: Taliban Gains Pull U.S. Units Back Into Fight in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Months after President Obama formally declared that the United States long war against the Taliban was over in Afghanistan, the American military is regularly conducting airstrikes against low-level insurgent forces and sending Special Operations troops directly into harms way under the guise of training and advising.

title: Police Describe Ex-Residents Calculated Plan to Attack Bronx Homeless Shelters Director
description: In a desolate corner of the Bronx, Ana Charle ran a shelter for homeless men with mental illness. Many of them came to see her as an anchor in their otherwise turbulent lives.

title: M.T.A. Board Votes to Ban Political Ads on Subways and Buses
description: The board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted on Wednesday to ban political advertising on New York City subways and buses to avoid the legal challenges it had faced after rejecting some ads with political messages.

title: New Shingles Vaccine May Offer Improved Protection
description: In a large randomized trial, researchers have found that a newly developed shingles vaccine is about twice as effective as the one currently in use.

title: 1965: Marines at Embassy Open Fire
description: SANTO DOMINGO  U.S. Marines guarding the U.S. embassy here today [April 29] were attacked by rebel snipers firing on them from concealed positions. The Marines returned the fire from behind cars on the embassys lawn, killing four of their attackers. The firing, which lasted less than 15 minutes, was the first action for the Marines since they landed here yesterday on President Johnsons orders. None of them was injured in the engagement.  New York Herald Tribune, European edition, April 30, 1965

title: Gaza Protesters Beaten and Detained by Hamas Security Officials, Witnesses Say
description: GAZA CITY  A rare show of defiance against Hamas, the militant Palestinian group that controls Gaza, was quelled on Wednesday as men who appeared to be Hamas security officials beat some protesters and detained others, witnesses said.

title: Dante de Blasio Is Off to Yale, Mom Shares on Twitter
description: Boola Boola de Blasio!

title: 36 Hours in Key West, Fla.
description: Ernest Hemingways favorite pastimes  catching big fish, eating well and drinking hard  still define the islands appeal, with the added attractions of countless water sports and gorgeous sunsets.

title: 36 Hours in Key West, Fla.
description: Its the best place Ive ever been any time, anywhere, Ernest Hemingway wrote of Key West. Flowers, tamarind trees, guava trees, coconut palms.  Got tight last night on absinthe and did knife tricks. Now as then, Floridas southernmost key offers the delights of a tropical paradise matched by spectacular night life. The writers favorite pastimes in the 1930s  catching big fish, eating well and drinking hard  still define the islands appeal today. This historic allure persists in the decades of memorabilia on saloon walls, conch-style homes inhabited by famous writers and the never-ending diversion of the omnipresent pale-blue sea. Dip beneath the surface in the Conch Republic, and youll find something for everyone in the family. You may also find that, in Key West, everyone feels like a kid.

title: Instacarts Bet on Online Grocery Shopping
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Lets take a trip to crazy town, shall we, and pretend for a moment that we are in a precarious tech industry bubble. Imagine, for the sake of argument and not because this could possibly be true, that the rising valuations of the largest start-ups are unsustainable. O.K., now consider the following: If we are in a bubble, which of todays start-ups is the modern-day Webvan or Pets.com? A decade from now, which company will we look back on and wonder, what on earth were we thinking?

title: In Mexico City, a Kahlo-Rivera Tour
description: The Mexican artists Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo star on the museum circuit, as evidenced by the show now at the Detroit Institute of Arts and a future exhibition of Ms. Kahlos work at the New York Botanical Garden.

title: Hillary Clinton to Jump Start Fund-Raising Efforts
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton had once planned to wait until May to hold her first fund-raising events. But in the last two weeks, she has moved up her schedule, primarily out of concern about Jeb Bushs extensive super PAC fundraising, according to donors and people in contact with the campaign.

title: Lodging Tips for Summer Travel
description: Anyone booking lodging for summer travel faces endless options: hostels, Airbnb, homestays, budget hotels, bidding on Priceline.com, and more.

title: The M.&.A. Predators at Michael Milkens Ball
description: Michael R. Milkens latest ball was notable for its lack of predators.

title: Folk Meets Rock
description: The romantic spirit of early Joni Mitchell  peasant dresses, poet blouses and textured coats  is toughened up when paired with a simple Chelsea boot.

title: Letterman on Letterman: 11 Key Quotes
description: On May 20, David Letterman will host his last Late Show, bringing an end to his 33-year tenure in late-night. In a wide-ranging interview with The New York Timess Dave Itzkoff, Mr. Letterman discussed his early talk show innovations, his rivalry with Jay Leno, his sex scandal and the changing late-night landscape, among other subjects.

title: First Draft Focus: Obama Takes a Tea Break
A Saudi Royal Shake-Up With a Goal of Stability
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  In a series of predawn appointments on Wednesday, King Salman of Saudi Arabia eased the potentially treacherous issue of royal succession by placing a new generation of security-focused leaders first in the line of succession. The far-reaching changes carry the potential to reshape not only the kingdom and its place in the region, but also its relations with its most important ally, the United States.

title: Small Jurassic Dinosaur May Have Flown Without Feathers
description: Over the last two decades, scientists in China have paraded one surprising dinosaur discovery after another, enough to rewrite textbooks and even impress dinophile first graders. Some of the smaller newfound creatures, it turns out, had feathers, which shifted expert thinking to the dinosaurian origin of birds.

title: Republican Presidential Hopefuls Miss the Point on Baltimore
description: The need for a national conversation on race, policing and the crisisthat exists in so many of our cities becomes greater with each event like the tragedy that is now gripping Baltimore. Those who would lead our nation should be at the forefront of this discussion, as President Obama has sometimes been.

title: Jeffrey Deitch Will Bring Street-Art Show to Coney Island
description: When the art dealer and curator Jeffrey Deitch mounted his sprawling Art in the Streets exhibition in 2011 at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, his plan from the beginning was to take the show to New York, one of the cradles of the graffiti movement. But the Brooklyn Museum, which had agreed to organize the New York exhibition, dropped out, citing a lack of funding, and Mr. Deitch, then the director of the contemporary museum in Los Angeles, was unable to find another venue.

title: Legislators Introduce Student Digital Privacy Bill
description: Months after President Obama proposed to strengthen digital privacy protection for students, two legislators on Wednesday introduced a comprehensive bill in Congress intended to accomplish that goal.

title: Jury in Etan Patz TrialSays It Cant Reach Verdict; Judge Tells Panel to Keep Trying
description: A Manhattan jury deciding the fate of a man accused of murdering Etan Patz informed a judge in a note on Wednesday  its 11th day of deliberations  that it was unable to reach a verdict, raising the possibility that the trial would not resolve a child-abduction case that has haunted New York City for decades.

title: A Sneak Peek at Sally Manns New Collection of Family Photographs
description: American photographer Sally Mann has spent her career  and, as evidenced by her new memoir, much of her life  exploring the ideas of family, place, love, death and the fragility of memory. Her photos offer up glimpses of the commonplace turned extraordinary: 1992s iconic Immediate Family, for example, traced the day-to-day lives of her children, growing up on a farm tucked inside Virginias Shenandoah Valley. Manns intimate photos depicted both the innocence and complexity of childhood at the same time that they alluded to larger themes like sexuality and death (and elicited criticism about what kind of mother Mann is, as her children were often depicted without clothes). For Deep South (2005), she photographed the Southern landscape so dear to her, exposing its extravagant beauty and its haunting past. And with 2009s Proud Flesh, Mann turned her eye towards her husband of over four decades, in a candid portrait series revealing his once-powerful body, now marked by signs of age and muscular dystrophy; at once a love letter and a testament to times merciless passage. And so on.

title: Germanwings Crash Looms Large at Lufthansa Shareholders Meeting
description: HAMBURG, Germany  It was a shareholders meeting in which business, inevitably, was only part of the agenda.

title: Family-Friendly Music Festivals This Summer
description: If on the scale of child friendliness, the bacchanalian Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival is a 1 and the Kids Corner Music Festival in Philadelphia scores a 10, what is a 5? Where can parents hear the bands they love without exposing their children to, say, the desert sun and people on amphetamines?

title: Shinzo Abe of Japan Avoids Specifics in Speech on Trade Accord
description: WASHINGTON  Shinzo Abe, in the first address by a Japanese prime minister to a joint meeting of Congress, praised his nations quantum leap in economic reforms but offered no specific concessions as he appealed to skeptical lawmakers to back a far-reaching Pacific trade accord.

title: Reading The Times With Wes Anderson
description: Wes Anderson is an American film director and screenwriter. His most recent movie is The Grand Budapest Hotel.

title: John Turturro Stars in Zorba at City Center
description: Pick up a bouzouki and start strumming, you over-civilized New Yorkers, and dance as if its your last night on earth, preferably barefoot. Everybodys favorite, day-seizing Greek peasant is back in town. Zorba  the 1968 musical adaptation of Nikos Kazantzakiss novel Zorba the Greek  is the final offering of this seasons Encores! series of musicals in concert at City Center. Featuring a score by John Kander and Fred Ebb (whose The Visit recently made its Broadway debut), with a book by Joseph Stein, Zorba has had two major New York productions, including a 1983 revival that starred Anthony Quinn, who indelibly played the title character in Michael Cacoyanniss 1964 film. Stepping into his shoes (or lack thereof) is John Turturro; the supporting cast includes Santino Fontana and Zoe Wanamaker, portraying folks who learn to live, live, live under Zorbas tutelage. Walter Bobbie directs. (May 6-10, City Center, 131 West 55th Street, 212-582-1212, nycitycenter.org.)

title: Russian League to Cut Back on Foreign Soccer Players
description: MOSCOW  Russias government has said it will impose tough limits on the number of foreign players in the countrys top soccer league, hoping that the measure can revive Russias languishing domestic talent before the country hosts the World Cup in 2018.

title: Dire Prospects Seen When the Full Nepal Earthquake Death Toll is Tallied
description: I discussed the earthquake and global seismic risk with Charlie Rose, Laurent Lamothe of Haiti and Sanjeev Sherchen of the Asia Society.

title: Teaching About the Nepal Earthquake With The New York Times
description: Overview | A 7.8 earthquake on April 25 battered the mountainous nation of Nepal, killing and injuring thousands, destroying entire villages, shattering treasured historic landmarks and upending life for millions of people.

title: Behind closed doors
description: soccer violence

title: Shrugging Off Slow Growth, Fed Predicts a Rebound
description: WASHINGTON  Repeating an all-too-familiar pattern, the American economy barely grew during the first three months of the year, but the Federal Reserve said Wednesday that it expected growth to rebound, suggesting that it still intends to start raising its benchmark interest rate this year.

title: Athol Fugard Tells of a Great Outsider Artist
description: Five years ago, Athol Fugard, the great chronicler of South Africas apartheid past and its post-apartheid present, heard a surprising tale. It was about a farm laborer named Nukain Mabuza, who had spent about 15 years, in the late 1960s and 70s, painting vivid, highly patterned designs on the boulders and stones in arid terrain of the eastern province of Mpumalanga.

title: Damion Hardy Found Guilty of Drug and Murder Charges After Lengthy Legal Battle
description: More than a decade after Damion Hardy was arrested and charged with leading a Brooklyn drug crew and ordering six murders, a jury on Wednesday found him guilty on all of the 24 counts he faced.

title: Japanese Premier Addresses Congress
description: Shinzo Abe, the first Japanese prime minister to address a joint meeting of Congress, offered condolences for American lives lost in World War II and spoke of Japans remorse.

title: Protecting Service Members From Predatory Loans (Updated)
description: House Republicans and their masters in the banking industry are pushing to delay a proposed Defense Department rule aimed at shielding service members from predatory loans that trap them in debt and that, under some conditions, can end their military careers. The offending legislation, now before the House Armed Services Committee, deserves to die a swift death.

title: Microsoft Takes Steps to Close Its App Gap on Mobile Devices
description: Microsoft has steadily lost influence in the technology industry as software developers gravitated to mobile technologies like Googles Android and Apples iOS.

title: Rubella Has Been Eliminated From the Americas, Health Officials Say
description: Rubella, a disease with terrible consequences for unborn children, has finally been eliminated from the Americas, a scientific panel set up by global health authorities announced Wednesday.

title: Orioles Play in Eerily Empty Stadium, Sirens in Distance
description: BALTIMORE  On what might have been a perfect spring afternoon to sit with a beer and a hot dog and watch baseball, an eerie emptiness greeted the Baltimore Orioles and the Chicago White Sox on Wednesday in what was believed to be the first major league game played without spectators.

title: Cyndi Lauper Pushes Congress to Protect Homeless Teens, Especially L.G.B.T Youth
description: Cyndi Lauper visited Capitol Hill Wednesday to answer questions before a Senate subcommittee about youth homelessness, a problem she once faced herself that led her to co-found the True Colors Fund addressing homeless issues. But once she left the witness table, Ms. Lauper, an award-winning singer and songwriter, was the one pressing for answers.

title: Last Chance to Sign Up Under Affordable Care Act Is Thursday
description: Consumers still have one more last chance to sign up for health insurance this year under the Affordable Care Act and avoid paying penalties for failing to have coverage.

title: Letter From Nepal: An Earthquake Survivors Plea
description: To the Editor:

title: F.A.A. Raised Questions About Andreas Lubitzs Depression Before Germanwings Crash
description: The Federal Aviation Administration raised questions in 2010 about whether it should grant a pilots license in the United States to Andreas Lubitz, who in March flew a Germanwings jetliner into a French mountainside, but was assured by his doctors in Germany that he had fully recovered from an episode of depression the year before, according to newly released documents.

title: Review: All Involved by Ryan Gattis Is Set in the Days After the Rodney King Verdict
description: On April 29, 1992, four Los Angeles police officers were acquitted of assault in the beating of Rodney King  a beating, with kicks and 56 baton swings, captured on videotape. Riots soon broke out in the city: Stores were looted, motorists assaulted, and shops and cars set on fire. Some shopkeepers armed themselves to protect against looters and firebombs, and thousands of National Guard reservists and federal soldiers were called in to restore law and order. During the six days of rioting, The Los Angeles Times estimated, more than 60 people died and more than 2,000 were injured.

title: French School Deems Teenagers Skirt an Illegal Display of Religion
description: PARIS  A secondary school in northeastern France has sent a 15-year-old student home twice in the last two weeks for wearing a long skirt that the principal judged was an ostentatious sign of the girls Muslim faith.

title: Baltimore Mayors Response to Crisis
description: A sampling of public statements by Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake of Baltimore as the crisis in her city unfolded.

title: North Korea Executed 15 Top Officials in 2015, South Korean Agency Says
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea has executed 15 high-ranking government officials this year, as its leader, Kim Jong-un, continues to struggle to establish his monolithic authority more than three years after assuming power, the South Korean intelligence agency told lawmakers on Wednesday.

title: At Zen Center in California, Guests Invited
description: Tassajara, established by the San Francisco Zen Center and one of the largest Buddhist orders outside of Asia, opens its doors to visitors from April 30 to Sept. 13, with a full roster of weekend and weeklong workshops. The California center is also known for its natural hot springs, vegetarian cuisine and artisan bread baking book, The Tassajara Bread Book, by Edward Espe Brown.

title: Alabama Shakes Hits No. 1
description: For the last two weeks, the music charts have been led by albums that rose with up-to-the-minute technology: Shawn Mendes went to No. 1 after emerging on Vine, the six-second-video app, and the week before that the Furious 7 soundtrack reached the top with help from Spotify and Shazam.

title: Peter Schlesinger Reflects on Four Sculptures From His Over-25-Year Career
description: The artist discusses pivotal pieces featured in a new monograph of his ceramics, created in collaboration with Acne Studios.

title: South Koreas Governing Party Skates Through Elections Despite Scandal
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Despite a bribery scandal that led to the resignation of South Koreas prime minister, President Park Geun-hyes governing Saenuri Party won three of four parliamentary seats filled on Wednesday in by-elections billed as a referendum on her leadership.

title: Beer-Can Chicken and Other Mysteries of the Kitchen, Explained
description: Men in the kitchen, and those who deal with men in the kitchen, occasionally have questions about recipes, cooking and food. They send them to FoodEditor@nytimes.com. I answer their queries herewith.

title: An Ex-Air Force Flier Finds His Passion Behind the Bar at Campbell Apartment
description: Paris DuRante, a native New Yorker, has been a fixture at Grand Central Terminals semi-hidden cocktail oasis, the Campbell Apartment, since shortly after it opened its doors to the public in 1999. He began his bartending career almost 30 years ago, and can still recall with clarity what motivated him to get into the business: The free drinks and the women, he said with a laugh. Which are probably the worst two reasons to get into bartending.

title: Michelle Obamas State Dinner Fashion
description: During her time as first lady, she has made a point, particularly at state dinners, of wearing gowns by designers whose backgrounds and cultures reflect the countries being honored.

title: Michelle Obamas Diplomatic Wardrobe
description: At Tuesday evenings Japanese state dinner, held in the East Room of the White House, every detail was carefully planned to indicate cross-border cooperation and sensitivity. Toro tartare and Caesar sashimi salad were prepared by the chef Masaharu Morimoto, there was a sake toast and the decor was influenced by cherry blossoms. And Michelle Obama wore a purple gown by Tadashi Shoji, a Japanese-American designer.

title: With Patent Litigation Surging, Creators Turn to Washington for Help
description: Patent law  famously arcane and technical  is becoming a mainstream, even bipartisan issue in Congress.

title: Franois Michelin, Head of Tire Company, Dies at 88
description: Franois Michelin, who led the company that bears his family name and helped make the radial tire the worldwide standard, has died. He was 88.

title: Earthquake Reveals Hubris and Imbalance on Mount Everest
description: LONDON  From afar it almost seems as if two discrete tragedies are unfolding in Nepal, bound by natures fury.

title: Canadian Partnership Shielded Identities of Donors to Clinton Foundation
description: Aides to former President Bill Clinton helped start a Canadian charity that effectively shielded the identities of donors who gave more than $33 million that went to his foundation, despite a pledge of transparency when Hillary Rodham Clinton became secretary of state.

title: Stefan Knapp Mural in New Jersey Is a Mammoth in Mothballs
description: CARLSTADT, N.J.  Its been more than 20 years since Alexanders department store in nearby Paramus shut down, but many who grew up in the area while it still stood at the intersection of Routes 4 and 17 remember the giant mural that adorned its facade.

title: Seen Hamilton?No? You Poor Thing.
description: At 2:30 p.m. last Saturday, the lobby of the Public Theater was bustling. From the crowd of well-dressed people checking their smartphones, a familiar face emerged. It was Frances McDormand, the Oscar-winning actress, in navy slacks and a navy sweater, racing across the room.

title: Pictures of the Day: Nepal and More
description: Nepal and Elsewhere  Pictures of the Day

title: The Economy Stalled in the First Quarter: Now What?
description: The government reported today that economic activity increasedat an annualized rate of 0.2 percent in the first quarter of 2015. At that pace, increased is not really the right word. Effectively, the economy stalled. And by the important measure of final sales (growth minus volatile inventories), it contracted.

title: Doctors Worry Verdict in A.L.S. Murder Case Could Stigmatize the Disease
description: In what experts say is likely the first legal decision of its kind, a jury in Wisconsin has found a former sheriffs deputy not legally responsible in the shooting deaths of his wife and her sister because he has amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrigs disease.

title: Hospitals Provide a Pulse in Struggling Rural Towns
description: BEATRICE, Neb.  This real estate to be auctioned, reads a banner stretched across the abandoned warehouse of a store-shelving manufacturer that once employed generations living in and around this town of about 12,000.

title: Ford Recalls Nearly 600,000 Vehicles Over Steering and Stalling Problems
description: Ford Motor  is recalling almost 593,000 cars and trucks in North America, including 520,000 because the power-assist to the steering could be lost, making the vehicle harder to turn, the automaker announced on Wednesday. About 554,000 of the vehicles are in the United States.

title: CBSs Mom Handles Issues Beyond Kissing Boo-Boos
description: Fifty-five years ago this week, Theodore Cleaver had a big problem. His teacher had assigned him to write a 50-word essay about his mother, June, but after interviewing her he found that her life had been numbingly unexciting.

title: Where Can Men Buy Higher-End Vintage Mens Wear?
description: Where do a bros clothes go when a bro wants to move on? Yes, men are interested in fashion in ways that largely havent been the norm, and precisely because of that, theyll be buying more, and more often, and eventually these men are going to go on a Kondo purge and want to liquidate. Over the last few weeks, Ive tried to figure out where they may go to offload.

title: New York City Underreported School Violence to State, Audit Shows
description: A review of violent episodes at 10 public schools in New York City found that the Education Department failed to report nearly a third of the cases to the state, as required, according to an audit the state comptroller released on Wednesday.

title: Electronic Bidet Toilet Seat Is the Luxury You Wont Want to Live Without
description: IT may sound as if Im exaggerating when I say that a high-tech, heated, warm-water-spraying bidet toilet seat ruined me for regular toilets, but Im not. I dont know how you guys do it. I look at your normal toilets, the ones with seats that are as cold as ice, the ones that dont spray and buff your nethers with a soothing shower of cleansing H2O, and I shake my head. I look at your dry-wiping ways, and I wonder how your mom raised you. Dont you want to be clean? Dont you ever feel ... not so fresh?

title: Review: Tyler Farr Flaunts Arena-Size Ambitions at Irving Plaza
description: Even given the ever-shifting and unpredictable borders of contemporary country music, Tyler Farr is a man more or less without a state. Hes not a cool bro flirting with hip-hop references and not a faithful preservationist. And, despite his first huge hit, Redneck Crazy, hes not trying to pass for a true backwoods kingpin. At his Tuesday night concert at Irving Plaza, he didnt wear a cowboy hat (too traditional), and he didnt wear a baseball cap (too bro). He was just a hatless guy working the stage with an athletic, mildly menacing prowl, singing scratched-up country songs that werent coy about their arena-rock ambition.

title: Charlie Hebdo Cartoonist to Stop Drawing Muhammad
description: The cartoonist who drew the Prophet Muhammad for the first issue of the French satirical weekly Charlie Hebdo after the killings at the publications offices in January has said that he will no longer turn his pencil to that subject.

title: Orioles Aren't First Team to Play to Empty Seats
description: A look at some sporting events that people were kept out of  and some where they probably should have been.

title: Beginning Again: The Love Story of Leonard Lauder and Judy Glickman
description: This is a love story.

title: Review: New World Symphony at Carnegie Hall With Anne-Sophie Mutter
description: It was an inspiring statement, as well as a smart artistic choice. On Tuesday night, the extraordinary German violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter chose to conclude her series of six programs this season as a Perspectives artist at Carnegie Hall by playing two challenging 20th-century concertos with the youthful New World Symphony and its conductor Michael Tilson Thomas.

title: Miliband Takes His British Election Pitch to Russell Brands Audience
description: LONDON  In one of the more bizarre moments of a tight British election campaign, the Labour leader, Ed Miliband, went in the dead of night Monday to the apartment of Russell Brand, a bawdy comedian, to give him an interview, which was posted Wednesday on YouTube.

title: Gay Marriage and the Supreme Court
A (Quiet) Day at the Ballpark
description: Because of unrest in Baltimore in relation to the death of Freddie Gray while in police custody, the Orioles played Wednesday in a stadium closed to the public.

title: Steve Coleman, a Jazz Outlier, Rides a Wave of Acclaim
description: PHILADELPHIA  More than any other living jazz musician, the alto saxophonist and composer Steve Coleman seeks inspiration in unlikely places. So it wasnt all that odd to find him here on a recent Saturday, scouting locations at Bartrams Garden, the nations oldest botanical garden, near the southernmost bend of the Schuylkill.

title: When Baltimore Burned
description: Conservatives have sometimes been too quick to excuse police violence. And liberals have sometimes been too quick to excuse rioter violence.

title: 76 Semesters (Personal)
description: Blogging has been limited lately, because its the end of term and I have a lot of things to do (plus get ready for an extended visit to Oxford starting soon.) But today was a bit of a personal landmark. Regular readers may know that Im taking early retirement from Princeton  which has been a wonderful place for me, but Im just overextended  and taking up an appointment at CUNY Graduate Center, one with limited teaching.

title: Peter Schlesinger Reflects on Some of His Favorite Sculptures
description: Peter Schlesinger has been molding clay into a range of coveted ceramics for over 25 years  some sturdy and earthenware in appearance, passable as ancient utilitarian artifacts; others simply nice to look at; all obviously crafted at the hands of a sculptor with a painterly eyebut only just collaborated on his first set of pajamas. Would he call it a departure? No. Rather, the collection, created alongside Acne Studios and printed with patterns from Schlesingers own organic designs, tells the story of my evolving work, and how they go from one thing to another, but stay the same, he says. To that end, Acnes creative director Jonny Johansson also worked with Schlesinger to create a book (essentially, a portfolio) of the artists ceramics. Available today, the monograph features photographs of more than 150 sculptures, all shot by Schlesingers partner of 40 years, Eric Boman. Some were taken as each piece was completed, to document them, Schlesinger explains. Then they began to be more beautiful as photographs.

title: Sofa Vergaras Ex-Fianc: Our Frozen Embryos Have a Right to Live
description: DELRAY BEACH, Fla.  LAST August, I filed a complaint in Santa Monica, Calif., using pseudonyms, to protect two frozen embryos I created with my former fiance. I wanted to keep this private, but recently the story broke to the world. It has gotten attention not only because of the people involved  my ex is Sofa Vergara, who stars in the ABC series Modern Family  but also because embryonic custody disputes raise important questions about life, religion and parenthood.

title: Concerto Barocco
description: Sara Mearns, Teresa Reichlen and company performing George Balanchines Concerto Barocco, with music by Johann Sebastian Bach. Choreography by George Balanchine The George Balanchine Trust

title: A Bach Portrait, Heading to Germany, Gets Musical Send-Off
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  Most portraits dont receive a serenade when theyre about to travel, but this isnt most portraits.

title: Review: City Ballets Balanchine Dances Open Spring Season
description: In 1972, the great music critic Andrew Porter, who died on April 3, opened a New Yorker essay with these words: Why, they ask me, do you so much enjoy living in New York? There was the light, he wrote, which makes each day a visual adventure, and moreover the New York City Ballet. Imagine a world in which Mozarts music was played regularly in only one town, by an ensemble directed by its composer ... There are other composers than Mozart, other ballet-makers than George Balanchine. But each is central to his art.

title: At the Met, Andrew Bolton Is the Storyteller in Chief
description: When the Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum of Art debuts its latest exhibition, China: Through the Looking Glass, at its annual wingding on May 4, the event will be covered in orgiastic fashion by the global news media and treated by locals with the excitement country bumpkins once evinced when an elephant sauntered down Main Street with a sign announcing that the circus had come to town.

title: Review: New York Festival of Songs Letters From Spain, Some by Russians and Germans
description: Cheeriness, when conveyed via Shostakovich, invariably takes on a darker hue. As the pianist Steven Blier said while introducing selections from the composers Six Spanish Songs at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday evening, they might look like sweet little songs on paper, but Shostakovich turned them into songs of the steppes.

title: April 29, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Nepal, Burundi, Indonesia and Yemen.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Goldman Sachs Programmers Trial Resumes After Jury Disruption
description: Jury deliberations in the criminal trial of Sergey Aleynikov, a former Goldman Sachs programmer, resumed on Wednesday after a judge removed two feuding jurors from the panel.

title: American Pharoah and Dortmund Avoid Trouble in Kentucky Derby Draw
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  No one here was surprisedon Wednesdaywhen two colts trained by Bob Baffert were made themorning-line favorites forSaturdays141st running of theKentucky Derby. The colts, American Pharoah (5-2) and Dortmund (3-1), have been the most-talked-about horses on the Triple Crowntrail.

title: A Tireless Champion of the Game
description: Alan Truscott was born in England, one of the 1925 bridge babies. (Other leading players born that year included Dorothy Hayden Truscott, Edgar Kaplan, Robert Nail and Tim Seres.) Truscott was on the British team that won the 1961 European Open Team Championship. He came to New York City in February 1962 to compete in the Bermuda Bowl. While in New York, he was spotted by Richard Frey writing newspaper reports. Impressed by his work ethic, Frey asked Truscott if he would like to move to the city and work for the American Contract Bridge League (then based in New York), in particular to help Frey produce the first Official Encyclopedia of Bridge. As Truscott had instantly liked the bustling metropolis, he agreed.

title: Hillary Clinton Says Obamas Policing Proposals a Good Start for a Wider Overhaul
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton said Wednesday that a presidential task force that examined police practices in minority communities had provided a good start for a wider overhaul of the criminal justice system.

title: Verbatim: One Womans View of Women in Combat
Viewfinder: Lucas Samaras
description: A new exhibition of Lucas Samarass work comprises more than 720 images.

title: Trailer: Inside Out
description: A preview of the film.

title: Clinton on Effects of Mass Incarceration
description: On Wednesday, Hillary Rodham Clinton, a 2016 Democratic presidential candidate, called for an end to mass incarceration, saying it does little to reduce crime.

title: Rodriguez and Yankees Are Left Flailing in Loss to Rays
description: Alex Rodriguez, who wears No. 13 on the back of his Yankees jersey, played in his 1,313th game as a Yankee on Wednesday afternoon, a contest that lasted 13 innings and required a total of 13 pitchers. It may have been a signal that he would play a decisive role in the game, and he did  but not in the way he might have hoped.

title: Einsteins Dice and Schrdingers Cat, by Paul Halpern
description: On a cold January day in 1947, Erwin Schrdinger took the podium at the Royal Irish Academy in Dublin and triumphantly announced that he had succeeded where Albert Einstein had failed for the past 30 years. Schrdinger said hed devised a unified theory of everything that reconciled the general theory of relativity with quantum mechanics. His announcement caused a sensation in the international press, which shamelessly played up the David and Goliath angle, much to Schrdingers discomfort and Einsteins irritation. It nearly destroyed their longstanding friendship. Matters became so acrimonious at one point, with rumors of potential lawsuits, that another colleague, Wolfgang Pauli, stepped in to mediate. A full three years would pass before the estranged friends gingerly began exchanging letters again.

title: John Varvatos Goes Home to Detroit
description: John Varvatos is in the back seat of a chauffeured sedan, being driven around downtown Detroit in a 2014 Chrysler 300C limited edition that bears his name.

title: Trailer: Dope
description: A preview of the film.

title: Irans Foreign Minister Says U.S. Risks Ostracism if Signed Nuclear Deal Is Scrapped
description: Demonstrating suave fluency in English and a familiarity with American history and law, Irans foreign minister said Wednesday that the United States would risk global ostracism if it were to scrap a signed international pact that resolves the Iranian nuclear dispute.

title: Marcus Bleasdale: When Photography Campaigns for Change
description: Marcus Bleasedale, winner of the Robert Capa Gold Medal from the Overseas Press Club, has worked with NGOs that have used his images to get the attention of policy-makers and power brokers.

title: As U.S. Presses for Extradition of Ukrainian Magnate, His Lawyers Cry Foul
description: VIENNA  Far from the mortar fire in Donetsk and Luhansk, a different battle for Ukraines future has been playing out in a courthouse in Vienna and at the Justice Department in Washington, where American officials have spent the last year pressing for the extradition of Dmitry V. Firtash, one of Ukraines wealthiest and most powerful businessmen, and one-time patron of the ousted president, Viktor F. Yanukovych.

title: Clip: The Wolfpack
description: A scene from the documentary directed by Crystal Moselle.

title: Turkish Mayor Berates State Departments Marie Harf for Silence on Baltimore Unrest
description: ISTANBUL  The mayor of Ankara, the Turkish capital, fired out a slew of sexist, anti-American remarks on Twitter on Wednesday and promoted a photograph that referred to Marie Harf, the State Department spokeswoman, as a stupid blonde.

title: Violence in Baltimore
description: This week, Baltimore was engulfed in violent revolt as citizens took to the street in the wake of the mysterious and disturbing death of Freddie Gray after hed been taken into police custody.

title: Earthquake Prompts Accusations of Lax Building Standards
description: Nepal, like other developing nations experiencing rapid urban expansion, has not developed the regulatory muscle to cope as its urban population has multiplied.

title: Several American Airlines Flights Are Delayed by an App Malfunction
description: The list of reasons that a plane can be delayed grew a little bit longer this week.

title: Beware the I.R.S.s Speeded-Up Audit
description: TO those of us who fear the I.R.S. and the possibility of a tax audit, it sounded like good news. In March, the I.R.S. commissioner, John A. Koskinen, told his employees that because of budget cuts, the agency had to do less with less  reduce taxpayer services, delay refunds and do fewer audits. But alas, the outcome is not what it seems. Those who do get caught in the I.R.S.s net may be in for a terrible time and lose some of the rights set out in last years new taxpayer bill of rights.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: A Founder of Secret, the Anonymous Social App, Is Shutting It Down
description: Last summer, employees at the start-up Secret gathered in their new offices in downtown San Francisco, waiting for the founders to address the company. Secret had recently raised $25 million to work on its smartphone app, which lets users anonymously share information with groups of friends and connections.

title: When a Medical Proxy Saves a Life
description: Im begging you, pleaded my 93-year-old grandmother. I want to quit while Im ahead. Im too tired. Its been a good, solid run and Im done.

title: French Army Investigates an Allegation of Sex Abuse in Central African Republic
description: UNITED NATIONS  Amid an uproar over a leaked United Nations inquiry into allegations of child sexual abuse by French troops posted in the Central African Republic, France confirmed on Wednesday that it was looking into whether some of its soldiers had abused children in its former colony, but said nothing about whether or when they might face prosecution.

title: Gene Fullmer, a Brawling Middleweight Champion, Dies at 83
description: Gene Fullmer, the middleweight boxing champion known for a brawling style and an ability to shake off punches and remembered for his title fights with Sugar Ray Robinson and Carmen Basilio, died on Monday in Taylorsville, Utah. He was 83.

title: Crazy Patterned Pants Make a Statement (Yes, Amal) and More Shopping
description: Plus: Mules are this seasons streamlined, youthful alternative to the standard summer sandal and a bandanna thats for adults only.

title: Bob Corker Ends Blockade of Budget Deal
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Bob Corker, Republican of Tennessee, lifted his blockade of a House-Senate budget deal Wednesday, clearing the way for a blueprint that would cut $5 trillion in spending in the next decade to balance the federal budget.

title: Bernie Sanders, Long-Serving Independent, Enters Presidential Race as a Democrat
description: Senator Bernie Sanders, the Vermont independent, announced Thursday that he was running for president as a Democrat, injecting a progressive voice into the contest and providing Hillary Rodham Clinton with her first official rival for the partys nomination.

title: Lessons, 40 Years After the Fall of Saigon
At the Milan Furniture Fair, a Mash-Up of Historical References
description: The mood at the annual design fair was giddy, and the standout pieces combined high-tech precision with a respect for bygone eras.

title: New York Plan to Save Energy May Mean a Dimmer Skyline
description: The Manhattan skyline  glimmering, grand but not always environmentally efficient  may need to go darker to go green.

title: Shopping Events and Sales Happening This Week in New York
description: On Friday, in its second partnership with the Art Production Fund, Barneys will unveil a pop-up for its Art Production Fund x Alex Katz x Barneys New York collection of home goods and accessories. It includes a decorative pillow ($335) and black leather tote ($225) featuring Mr. Katzs drawings of black and white flowers and portraits of female figures. Twenty-five percent of sales will go to the Art Production Fund, a nonprofit dedicated to producing public art projects. At Barneys, ninth floor.

title: On Same-Sex Marriage, Its Too Late to Wait-and-See at the Supreme Court
description: During the often meandering and repetitious same-sex marriage argument at the Supreme Court on Tuesday, there was one galvanizing, clarifying moment that hasnt received much attention but that, at least for me, put everything in perspective. It was the response that Solicitor General Donald B. Verrilli Jr. gave to a suggestion by Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. that the court should simply stay its hand and permit the truly extraordinary pace of social change to continue on its own.

title: A Judicial Campaign Rule Survives at the Supreme Court
description: Judges are different: That was the basis of the Supreme Courts surprising 5-to-4 decision upholding a Florida rule that bans judicial candidates from personally asking donors for campaign cash.

title: M.T.A. Chief Rejects Higher Fares for Capital Plan
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said on Wednesday that the agency would not raise fares to pay for its $32 billion capital plan.

title: Highlights From the Collection
description: John Mayers abiding passion is his watch collection. Here are some pieces.

title: U2s Flight to Now (Turbulence Included)
description: VANCOUVER, BRITISH COLUMBIA  It was definitive arena rock, loud and clear, filling Pacific Coliseum here with surging sound. The Edge blared a distorted two-chord guitar riff, Larry Mullen Jr.s tom-toms and cymbals landed hard on the backbeat, Adam Claytons bass throbbed down below, and Bono was unleashing woo-oohs in exultant falsetto. U2 has taken over the coliseum for a month of full-scale rehearsal to assemble its Innocence and Experience tour, which starts at Rogers Arena here on May 14, and the band was charging through Elevation. The stage was an austere geometry of fluorescent tubes; the song was triumphant. Wow, thats four years since we played that? Bono said as the last chord faded. Not bad!

title: When Good News Is No News
description: There are times, in our national political conversation, when the good news is so pathetically puny that it actually makes you feel worse.

title: Marco Rubios Push to Amend Iran Measure Threatens a Fragile Balance in Congress
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, is demanding a vote on an amendment that would press Iran to recognize the state of Israel, threatening a fragile bipartisan coalition that had already fashioned a compromise bill giving Congress a voice in the Iran nuclear talks.

title: Healthier Time Warner Cable Emerges From Quashed Deal With Far More Options
description: What a difference 14 months make.

title: Insurers Flout Rule Covering Birth Control, Studies Find
description: WASHINGTON  Health insurance companies often flout a federal requirement that they cover all approved methods of birth control for women without co-payments or other charges, a major benefit of the Affordable Care Act, two new studies have found.

title: Puerto Rico on the Brink
description: Puerto Rico is in trouble, after years of bad policies, mismanagement, excessive debt and bad luck.

title: Saddling Homeowners With Risky Loans
description: House Republicans, with the help of several Democrats, recently passed two bills to weaken new rules against predatory mortgage lending. Senate Republicans are now trying to win support for the same measures, arguing that the rules would impose regulatory burdens that unduly restrict credit.

title: Betsy von Furstenberg, Baroness and Versatile Actress, Dies at 83
description: Betsy von Furstenberg, a glamorous German-born baroness who made her debut in the movies and on the Broadway stage in the early 1950s as a teenager and later reinvented herself as a television actress, writer and philanthropist, died on April 21 at her home in Manhattan. She was 83.

title: Jack Ely, Who Sang the Kingsmens Louie Louie, Dies at 71
description: Jack Ely would later insist that as a 19-year-old singing Louie Louie in one take in a Portland, Ore., studio in 1963, he had followed the original lyrics faithfully. But, he admitted, the braces on his teeth had just been tightened, and he was howling to be heard over the band, with his head tilted awkwardly at a 45-degree angle at a single microphone dangling from the ceiling to simulate a live concert.

title: Twitter Troubles Lie in Marketers Reluctance to Buy New Kind of Ad
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As a company, Twitter is an adolescent  gangly, starry-eyed, growing like a weed and unpredictable.

title: JPMorgan Sues to Prevent Transfer of $19.4 Million Condo at Time Warner Center
description: JPMorgan Chase has gone to court to prevent an Indian real estate developer from transferring ownership of a $19.4 million condominium at the Time Warner Center in Manhattan, the first step in an effort to seize the apartment as partial payment for a $90 million award.

title: Empty Streets New Threat to Businesses in Baltimore
description: BALTIMORE  Baltimores nighttime economy has gone dark.

title: Sid Tepper Dies at 96; Delivered Red Roses for a Blue Lady and Other Songs
description: Sid Tepper, half of a songwriting team whose ballads, pop tunes and novelty numbers were recorded by the musical stars of the 1940s and 1950s and live on in Elvis Presley movies and elevators around the world, died on April 24 at his home in Aventura, Fla. He was 96.

title: Alex Rodriguez 0 for 6? Its That Kind of Day
description: If one game can symbolize the state of modern baseball, consider Wednesdays matinee in the Bronx between the Yankees and the Tampa Bay Rays. Eleven relief pitchers combined for 141/3 innings, allowing only four hits and striking out 14. The winning run scored when a second baseman slid on the grass in right field to gobble up a ground-ball single.

title: Coalition Debates Expanding ISIS Fight
description: WASHINGTON  The Islamic States efforts to expand its reach beyond Iraq and Syria have spurred a debate within the coalition that the United States has assembled to confront the group about whether it needs to broaden its campaign.

title: Economic Boom Poses a New Threat, Among Many, to a Vietnamese Heritage
description: HUE, Vietnam  This is a city of edifices and their ghosts.

title: Health Problems Take Root in a West Baltimore Neighborhood That Is Sick of Neglect
description: BALTIMORE  At 49, Annette Booth already feels old.

title: Obama Administration Steps Back From Effort to End Federal Death Penalty
description: WASHINGTON  For a moment last year, it looked as if the Obama administration was moving toward a history-making end to the federal death penalty.

title: Slightly Higher Percentage of Law School Graduates Landed Legal Jobs, Report Says
description: The job market seems to have become a little better for law school graduates, but it could just be a numerical blip.

title: Trying to Locate the Living, Nepal Rescuers Find Only Frustration
description: BHAKTAPUR, Nepal  A team of the United States most renowned search-and-rescue workers drove into the shattered city of Bhaktapur on Wednesday, having traveled to Nepal from Fairfax County, Va.

title: Calvin Peete, 71, a Racial Pioneer on the PGA Tour, Is Dead
description: Calvin Peete, whose life traced one of sports most triumphant arcs  a school dropout with a crooked left arm who did not pick up a golf club until his 20s, did not join the pro tour until his 30s, and still became one of the leading players of his era and the most successful black professional golfer before Tiger Woods  has died. He was 71.

title: Taking to theBaltimore Streets, but for Peace and Progress
description: BALTIMORE  For the past few days, as a rare national media spotlight has shined on this citys troubles, the Rev. Warren Savage has taken the opportunity to meet with self-described members of the gangs that many residents blame for some of those woes: the Crips, the Bloods and the Black Guerrilla Family.

title: Iran: Ships Seizure Tied to Court Case
description: Iranian officials on Wednesday sought to play down the significance of Irans seizure of a cargo ship a day earlier in the Strait of Hormuz, a vital international waterway. The officials said the vessel was owned by a corporate defendant in a civil case in Iran. They denied that the impoundment had been meant to send a belligerent message to other nations over freedom of navigation in the strait. Thats a legal case, said Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif. This is not a security issue or political issue. A Foreign Ministry spokeswoman was quoted by Agence France-Presse as saying the action had been taken in conformity with international regulations. Some analysts in the United States said the seizure reflected what they called Irans desire to show it would not be bullied. Last week, the United States deployed warships near Yemens coast, in what was seen as a message to Iranian vessels in the area.

title: Baltimore Mayor Treads Fine Line in Divided City
description: BALTIMORE  With buildings ablaze and looters rampaging through city streets, Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake faced television cameras Monday night and sternly denounced the rioters as thugs. The next day, with some black residents in an uproar over a word they call racially charged, she walked it back.

title: Ukraine: Russia Seizes Leaders Assets
description: Roshen, the confectionary company owned by President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine, says that assets of the company worth $39 million in Lipetsk, Russia, where it owns two candy factories, have been seized this week by the Russian authorities, according to a statement by the company. The company, which has its headquarters in Ukraine, has had legal trouble in Russia since the upheaval last year that toppled President Viktor F. Yanukovych and led to Mr. Poroshenkos election. The company said Tuesday that the action by the Russian authorities was illegal and that it would fight the seizure in court. Analyzing the events that are occurring around the Russian assets of the corporation, it is safe to say that the Russian side is deliberately using all possible methods to deny the company the opportunity to sell its assets in the Russian Federation, it said.

title: Review: Belarus Free Theaters Trash Cuisine Serves Politics With Teeth
description: If you judge a show by its title, youd expect Trash Cuisine, the latest offering from the intrepid Belarus Free Theater, to be a friendly, jokey hoot. Its a name that puts you in mind of those breezy adventure shows for armchair chefs  Have Fork, Will Travel or Bizarre Foods  with an extra nip of camp added for seasoning.

title: Review: Ziegfelds Midnight Frolic Explores the Murky Death of the Actress Olive Thomas
description: Olive Thomas, the Ziegfeld Follies beauty whose teary ghost is said to haunt the New Amsterdam Theater, has taken up residence down the block. Her stage is the Liberty Theater, a long-ago Broadway house now tucked incongruously at the back of the Liberty Diner, on West 42nd Street. When she died scandalously in Paris in 1920, a Jerome Kern musical was running there.

title: What May Follow Anything
description: THURSDAY PUZZLE  Everyones brains work differently. I think we can all agree with that, right?

title: Latinos, in Class-Action Case, Accuse Suffolk County Police of Bias and Harassment
description: Latinos in Suffolk County filed a class-action lawsuit on Wednesday in federal court, accusing the Police Department of engaging in a widespread pattern of racial discrimination, harassment and cover-ups that occurred even while the Justice Department was investigating it for bias, the complaint said.

title: Searching for Survivors Outside Katmandu
description: Days after Nepals devastating earthquake, rescue teams continued to fly missions from Katmandu to the countryside to find and evacuate the injured.

title: Caretaker Is Accused of Killing Queens Toddler in a Scalding Bath
description: A nurse was charged on Wednesday with killing a developmentally disabled toddler she was taking care of by submerging the child up to her waist in scalding bath water.

title: Cuomo Announces Plan to Cut New AIDS Cases in New York
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Wednesday what he called a blueprint to virtually eliminate AIDS in New York, a package of new laws and more aggressive use of antiretroviral drugs that brought cheers from some activists, if no guarantee it will come to fruition.

title: Massachusetts: Witnesses Recall a Young Dzhokhar Tsarnaev
description: Defense lawyers at the penalty phase in the trial of the man convicted in the Boston Marathon bombing called as witnesses Wednesday a series of his teachers and friends, some of whom offered glowing accounts about his young life. They described the bomber, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, as a hardworking, coachable child who became a genial, if less than academically successful, high school and college student. The testimony stood in contrast to the excerpts from an F.B.I. report read earlier in the day that focused on the radical religious beliefs of Mr. Tsarnaevs older brother, Tamerlan, who died after a shootout with the police. Dzhokhar Tsarnaev was convicted this month of participating in the bombings and could face the death penalty. Defense lawyers are trying to convince a jury to spare his life by showing that it was Tamerlan, not Dzhokhar, who masterminded the bombings.

title: At Cortlandt Street Subway Station, Art Woven From Words
description: The Cortlandt Street station on the No. 1 line, which was wiped off the subway map on Sept. 11, 2001, will be much more than a local stop in Lower Manhattan when it reopens in 2018.

title: Rent-Stabilized Tenants in New York City Renew Call for a Freeze
description: Possible rent increases this year for New York Citys rent-stabilized apartments will run up to 3.5 percent on two-year leases, with a possibility of a rent freeze also on the horizon for one-year leases, according to a vote by members of the Rent Guidelines Board.

title: Tepid Start, and Hawks, Are Too Much for the Nets
description: A ferocious late comeback could not undo a tepid beginning for the Nets, who were debilitatingly unassertive for three quarters against the Hawks and paid the price with a 107-97 loss Wednesday night at Philips Arena in Atlanta.

title: U.S. Subpoenas Trinity Industries for Records on Guardrails
description: Trinity Industries has received a Justice Department subpoena seeking more than a decades worth of records on its guardrail products, the company disclosed late Wednesday.

title: Drivers Dreary Last Day at a D.M.V. in Yonkers
description: YONKERS  The robotic cadence of the numerical waiting system at the Department of Motor Vehicles building pulled about 75 sleepy, dead-eyed automotive aspirants to the edge of their wooden benches.

title: Mets Bullpen, Once a Strength, Falters Against the Marlins
description: MIAMI  Jack Leathersich landed here Wednesday morning on a redeye flight from Las Vegas, slept for maybe an hour or two at the team hotel, then went to Marlins Park for his first day as a major league reliever. His new manager, Terry Collins, and pitching coach, Dan Warthen, stopped by his locker.

title: Manipulated Self-Portraits From a Master of the Form
description: In this weekly series, Ts photo editors share the most compelling visual projects theyve discovered.

title: Goldman and IDG Put $50 Million to Work in a Bitcoin Company
description: GoldmanSachs is becoming the first major bank to make a significant investment in a Bitcoin-focused company, giving a vote of confidence to the embattled virtual currency.

title: Miles Davis at Newport: A Four-Disc Set Coming in July
description: Columbia/Legacy Recordings is to announce Thursday that it plans to release Miles Davis at Newport 1955-75: The Bootleg Series Vol. 4 on July 17. A four-disc set of live recordings, it traces the history of Daviss concerts at the various Newport Festivals  in Newport, R.I., as well as in Berlin; Dietikon, Switzerland; and New York City. (About three-quarters of the tracks have not been commercially released.)

title: Marcus Bleasdale: When Photography Campaigns for Change
description: Marcus Bleasdale has won the Robert Capa Gold Medal from the Overseas Press Club, which recognizes exceptional courage in published photojournalism. It will be presented Thursday night at the Mandarin Oriental hotel in New York. Jerome Sessini of Magnum Photos will receive the Olivier Rebbot Award, and Bulent Kilic of Agence France-Presse will be presented with the John Faber Award. Rodrigo Abd of The Associated Press will receive the Feature photography award for his photos of illegal gold mining in Brazil.

title: Word of the Day | causal
description: causal  \ko-zl\  adjective

title: Messengers Collision Course With Mercury
description: NASAs Messenger spacecraft crashed into Mercury on Thursday.

title: In Mayweather-Pacquiao Buildup, Surprisingly Little Fight in the Fighters
description: LAS VEGAS  If it is possible to see, or hear, through boxings predictable bombast  the bluster of promoters and entourages, the cacophony of marching bands and D.J.s  there is an introspective, measured side of the buildup to Saturdays fight between Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Manny Pacquiao.

title: Over 140 Arrested as New Yorkers Protest the Death of Freddie Gray
description: In an aggressive response designed to tamp down early signs of unrest, the police arrested 143 people in Manhattan on Wednesday night as protesters marched in a show of solidarity with demonstrators in Baltimore angered by the death of Freddie Gray, an unarmed 25-year-old black man who died after being injured while in police custody this month.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs: Familiar Foes in the Second Round
description: Familiarity will be the theme of the second round: Three of the N.H.L.s four second-round matchups are rematches from the last two postseasons.

title: Whats on TV Thursday
description: 8 P.M. (Fox) BONES The series celebrates its 206th episode  making it 20th Century Fox Televisions longest-running hourlong drama  by mentioning each of the 206 bones in the human body as Brennan (Emily Deschanel) and Booth (David Boreanaz) investigate the death of a celebrity chef who was reviewing their favorite restaurant. In the season finale of Backstrom, at 9, a death on an American Indian reservation leads to the local meth czar (Gregory Cruz). Backstrom (Rainn Wilson) believes his father (Robert Forster), a county sheriff, knew about the drug dealings.

title: Corrections: April 30, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Bernie Sanders on the Issues
description: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, a registered independent and self-described socialist who is seeking the Democratic nomination for president, has made a name for himself in Congress attacking the financial industry and the billionaire class. Though he is considered unlikely to mount a serious challenge to Hillary Rodham Clinton, his positions on major issues could help push her to address the concerns of more left-leaning voters. Here is a look at some of those positions.

title: What Bernie Sanders Would Need to Do to Win
description: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont is entering the race for the Democratic nomination for president.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: This isnt the way you want to make history.

title: BNP Paribas Profit Rose 18% in First Quarter
description: PARIS  BNP Paribas, Frances largest bank, said on Thursday that its first-quarter profit rose on the back of a strong performance at its corporate and investment banking business and a decline in the euro that increased its dollar-based returns.

title: Test Yourself | David Lettermans Late Night Legacy
description: Below, several paragraphs from the April 29 article David Letterman Reflects on 33 Years in Late-Night Television.

title: Q. and A.: Vanessa Hope on Documenting U.S.-China Relations in All Eyes and Ears
description: In her debut feature-length documentary, Vanessa Hope has taken on one of the most widely discussed topics of our time: United States-China relations.

title: Royal Dutch Shell Earnings Fell 56% in First Quarter
description: ABERDEEN, Scotland  Royal Dutch Shell said on Thursday that its earnings for the first quarter fell by 56 percent compared with a year earlier, as improved performance in marketing and refining failed to offset the effects of the plunge in oil prices.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Websites in India Put a Bit of Choice Into Arranged Marriages
description: In Websites in India Put a Bit of Choice Into Arranged Marriages, Gardiner Harris writes about how urbanization, education and the rise of matrimonial websites are challenging centuries-old traditions of arranged marriage.

title: More Space in Brooklyns Clinton Hill
description: For nearly six years, Josu Asselin-Bienvenue and Michael Robinson II shared a tiny studio on the fourth floor of a walk-up building on far East 14th Street.

title: R.B.S. Posts First-Quarter Loss on Restructuring and Litigation Costs
description: LONDON  The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Thursday that it fell to a loss in the first quarter as the British bank was again weighed down by restructuring and litigation costs.

title: Movies Seek Laughs With All Manner of Sex Scenes
description: New films are using sex to push boundaries, embarrass audiences and set up jokes.

title: Jewish Boxers and Wrestlers, and Yiddish Fighting Words, at Yivo Institute Exhibition
description: It was as if Samson had been reincarnated.

title: Should Single-Use Plastic Shopping Bags Be Banned?
description: How many plastic bags do we briefly use and then throw away every week? We get our takeout food, drugstore purchases and clothing bagged, and our groceries double-bagged. All those single-use plastic bags may be cheap for consumers, but their costs add up. Plastic bags end up stuffing landfills, clogging sewers, polluting animal habitats and even fluttering in trees for years. California became the first state to ban plastic bags in 2014, although that law has been temporarily put on hold, and dozens of cities or counties have either banned the use of plastic bags or imposed a fee for their use.

title: Martin OMalley Embraces Baltimore, for Better or Worse, in Long-Shot Presidential Bid
description: BALTIMORE  One day last fall, on the 200th anniversary of the Battle of Baltimore, Martin OMalley stood atop Fort McHenry and swept his hand over the landscape below. That was the battlefield, he said. It all happened here.

title: American Psychological Association Bolstered C.I.A. Torture Program, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  The American Psychological Association secretly collaborated with the administration of President George W. Bush to bolster a legal and ethical justification for the torture of prisoners swept up in the post-Sept. 11 war on terror, according to a new report by a group of dissident health professionals and human rights activists.

title: Capitals Plan A in Net: Braden Holtby. Plan B: Holtby.
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  When the Washington Capitals faced off against the Rangers in the first game of their playoff series on Thursday night, their fate rested on Braden Holtby, an idiosyncratic goaltender who played in more than 70 games this season and is known for his elaborate pregame visualizations.

title: This Ring Is Anything but Ornate, Yet All Eyes Will Be on It Anyway
description: LAS VEGAS  It is called a ring, even though it is square, and on Saturday night, it will be a center of attention when Floyd Mayweather Jr. fights Manny Pacquiao.

title: Diane von Furstenberg | Know Thyself
description: A clear goal is key to effective leadership, says fashion mogul Diane von Furstenberg. If you can explain the goal to yourself first, then to your team, you will be on the path to meeting that goal.

title: Report on American Psychological Associations Role in Bush-Era Interrogation Program
description: The organizations involvement undermines the fundamental ethical standards of the profession, argues a group of dissident health professionals and activists.

title: Diane von Furstenberg: The Key to Success Is Trusting Yourself
description: This interview with Diane von Furstenberg, the fashion designer, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Eurozone Consumer Prices Stopped Falling in April
description: PARIS  Eurozone consumer prices reached a standstill in April after four months in negative territory, official data showed on Thursday, easing concerns that Europe was headed for a broad and debilitating decline in prices known as deflation.

title: Beyond: Our Future in Space, by Chris Impey
description: Worlds may freeze and suns may perish, but there stirs something within us now that can never die again. ... A day will come, one day in the unending succession of days, when beings, beings who are now latent in our thoughts and hidden in our loins, shall stand upon this earth as one stands upon a footstool, and shall laugh and reach out their hands amid the stars.

title: China Rethinks Safety Net for Its Banking System
description: HONG KONG  When the United States started insuring customer deposits, the government wanted to instill faith in the countrys financial system, which had been broken by a string of bank runs and failures during the Great Depression.

title: Doctors and Nurses, Not Learning Together
description: There are few group projects in medical school  which is strange when you consider that there are few solo practitioners in the real world.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: N.F.L. First Round Picks, 25 Years Later and Hiding in Plain Sight
description: At first, a story about the 25 players chosen in the first round of the N.F.L. draft in 1990 seemed straightforward. Read some old news clips about them, search for their phone numbers and chat with them. Voil, a feature on where they are now.

title: New York Today: Our Coyote Neighbors
description: Good morning on this shimmering Thursday.

title: Daily Report: Secret to Shut Down
description: Last summer, employees at the start-up Secret gathered in their new offices in downtown San Francisco, waiting for the founders to address the company. Secret had recently raised $25 million to work on its smartphone app, which lets users anonymously share information with groups of friends and connections, Mike Isaac reports.

title: Kim Jong-un Wont Attend World War II Celebration in Moscow
description: MOSCOW  Kim Jong-un, the leader of North Korea, will not attend a celebration in Moscow in May of the 70th anniversary of the Soviet Unions defeat of Nazi Germany, a top Russian official said on Thursday.

title: Hong Kong Kidnapping Revives Memories of Other High-Profile Crimes
description: The police have spent days scouring Hong Kongs northern reaches and monitoring the border with mainland China in a search for six men suspected of robbing a luxury home and kidnapping one of the residents, a 29-year-old woman.

title: Unplugged Along the California Coast
description: It was a vacation I had been dreaming about for years: the classic California road trip up the historic State Route 1 with my husband and our 5-year-old daughter, Frankie, and 3-year-old son, Finn. It was a trip that was meant to show them the sheer magnitude of Big Sur, the jagged artistry of the coastline, the endless blue of the Pacific, the raw, wild beauty of Gods country. It was a trip that they would remember for the rest of their lives!

title: The Great American Kidney Swap
description: Before surgeons stitched a kidney from a 32-year-old former Marine into his abdomen in March, Mark Kim spent almost two years on dialysis. He had lot of time to think while hooked up to the machine, three times a week, as it pumped his blood out of his body, purified it and pumped it back in. Sometimes he found himself mulling over how odd it was that a new kidney  the one thing he needed most  was something money couldnt buy.

title: In Code We Trust
description: When Caesar Augustus minted the denarius coin, around 4 A.D., he did so with a decree that it be made almost entirely of silver. But over the coming decades, as the financial health of the Roman Empire declined  largely because of its increasingly independent army, which demanded ever more money to subdue the rebellious provinces  the emperors began, slowly at first, mixing in copper to stretch the silver further. By 280 A.D., a denarius was 98 percent copper, with a thin silver wash on the surface. The implication was clear to every Roman: Here, in their hands, was a physical manifestation of the empires deepening desperation. Whatever proclamations the emperor might make, the coin told the truth.

title: ZPM Espresso and the Rage of the Jilted Crowdfunder
description: Thank you all very much, Update 57 concluded, by way of goodbye. Working on this project was the most ambitious and meaningful undertaking any of us have ever attempted. Getting to know all of you, and working to create some seriously cool technology, was one of the most rewarding things weve ever done. We are deeply and truly sorry that despite our best efforts, we were not able to get this machine across the finish line. Love, Gleb, Igor and Janet, Team ZPM.

title: Today in Politics: Sanders Offers Clinton Both a Potential Foil and a Pitfall
description: Good Thursday morning from Washington, where Senator Ted Cruz of Texas followed Jeb Bushs recent outreach to Hispanic voters, and the Senate is using a bit of subterfuge to address the nuclear deal with Iran. But, with the news that Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont was joining presidential the race, attention turns to how Hillary Rodham Clinton might respond.

title: Morning Agenda: Salesforce Said to be Preparing for Takeover Offers
description: SALESFORCE SAID TO BE PREPARING FOR TAKEOVER OFFERS  | Who wants to buy Salesforce.com? That was the big question Wednesday following a report by Bloomberg News that the cloud software giant had hired financial advisers to field takeover inquiries after it was approached by a potential buyer. Unidentified people with knowledge of the matter told Bloomberg News that it was not certain that any deal would be struck, and they didnt name any possible buyers.

title: Baltimore Police Complete Initial Inquiry Into Death of Freddie Gray
description: BALTIMORE  The Baltimore police on Thursday handed over to prosecutors the results of their much-anticipated initial investigation into the fatal injury suffered by a young man in their custody, including the discovery that a police van carrying the man made a previously undisclosed stop en route to a police station.

title: The Problem for Bernie Sanders: The Narrow Lane to Hillary Clintons Left
description: The presidential candidacy of Bernie Sanders, a senator from Vermont and self-described socialist who will most likely champion the liberal cause, wont change that fact that Hillary Rodham Clinton is poised to win the Democratic nomination without a serious contest.

title: Updating Gigi and Other 50s Films Into Modern Broadway Musicals
description: Movie musicals from the 1950s scare me. Just when Im enjoying the lavish costumes and scenery and a glorious musical number by Rodgers and Hammerstein or Lerner and Loewe, some unseemly social attitude leaps up and reminds me of how drastically times have changed.

title: Senator Tom Cotton Gets Personal With Irans Foreign Minister
description: Republicans in Congress have been skeptical about a nuclear agreement with Iran and Senator Tom Cotton, the freshman Republican from Arkansas, has been at the forefront of the opposition.

title: Throwback Thursday | The Rodney King Verdict and the L.A. Riots
description: With the National Guard called in to restore peace in Baltimore, this weeks anniversary of the Rodney King decision  and the subsequent riots that claimed over 60 lives and caused $1 billion in damage  is especially resonant.

title: The Worth of a Song
description: Dear Diary:

title: Times Co. Reports a Loss, Tempered by Digital Growth
description: The New York Times Company posted a $14 million net loss for the first quarter of 2015, driven by a pension settlement charge and a drop in lucrative print advertising. But digital subscriptions continued to show solid growth, the company said on Thursday, and digital advertising grew at a double-digit pace.

title: Injection Offers Option to Slim Down Double Chin Without Surgery
description: Even as a pigtailed child, Ashley Gallagher was self-conscious about a certain fullness in her face. I was cute as button  and there was my double chin, she said.

title: Pakistan Sentences 10 to Life Terms Over 2012 Attack on Malala Yousafzai
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A Pakistani court on Thursday sentenced 10 men to life in prison for their role in the 2012 shooting of Malala Yousafzai, the teenage Nobel laureate who defied the Taliban with her calls for girls education and won worldwide acclaim for her courage.

title: Does Race Matter If Books, Like Anne of Green Gables, Touch Your Heart?
description: Recently as my 5-year-old daughter and I exited our local African-American Center for Arts and Culture, we stopped to browse through the gift shop. Toward the back of the room, the author Ronald Harrill stood beside copies of his book Makeda: Queen of Sheba.

title: Another Fashion Documentary You Really Should See
description: This has been something of a banner period for fashion documentaries. In April, there was Dior and I, and this week, there are not one, but two, debuts: Albert Maysless feature-length Iris and Alison Chernicks short The Artist Is Absent, about Martin Margiela. Iris, which Manohla Dargis of The New York Times loved, is about to open in theaters, but The Artist Is Absent, which had its premiere at the Tribeca Film Festival last week, is already online, courtesy of its producer, the fashion e-tailer Yoox Group.

title: U.S. Sends Ships to Strait of Hormuz to Shield Vessels After Iran Seizure
description: WASHINGTON  The Navy on Thursday began deploying warships to protect American commercial vessels passing through the Strait of Hormuz against any interference from Iran, which this week seized a cargo ship in the narrow waterway, though which about 20 percent of the worlds oil passes.

title: Jeb Bush Claims Frontrunner Status in the Big Money Race
description: Jeb Bush is still an undeclared candidate, but that didnt stop him from gathering with 350 of his richest super PAC donors Sunday evening to reportedly claim his intensive campaigning as a non-candidate has raised more money in its first 100 days than any other political machine in modern history.

title: Judge Rebuffs U.S. in Rejecting Extradition of Ukraine Billionaire
description: VIENNA  In a defeat for the United States, an Austrian judge refused Thursday to order the extradition of Dmitri V. Firtash, a Ukrainian billionaire and onetime patron of the countrys ousted president, Viktor F. Yanukovych, siding with defense lawyers who said the American request was politically motivated.

title: Lazard Names New Heads of Financial Advisory and M.&A.
description: The investment bank Lazard said on Thursday that it had named two veterans of the firm as the new heads for its financial advisory and mergers and acquisitions businesses, including a banker best known for advising Greece on its debt.

title: Ted Cruz Addresses Hispanic Group With Rare We
description: On the campaign trail, Senator Ted Cruz, the Republican presidential candidate from Texas, often tells the story of how his father immigrated to the United States from Cuba, but he rarely refers to himself as Hispanic.

title: John Mayers Wrist Is a Wonderland
description: Seated in a 30th-floor suite at the Carlyle hotel, John Mayer was noodling through a few riffs on a glimmering new PRS Custom 22 guitar. It looked like a work of art as much as a musical instrument, its clear yellow finish revealing wood grain as brilliant as a tigers stripes.

title: With LED Lights, Automakers Reveal All the Road We Cannot See
description: AUTOMOTIVE lighting is undergoing a quiet revolution, leading to new vehicle designs and providing enhanced nighttime safety. But while many of the innovations have become common in Europe and Asia, they have been slower to arrive in the United States.

title: Watching the N.F.L. Draft From a Fantasy Football Perspective
description: After an eventful college football season, months of anticipation and analysis, and the scouting combine, the N.F.L. draft is finally upon us. Any fantasy football player knows that rookies can become the underrated picks who win you a championship. With an eye toward the 2015 fantasy season, here is what we are going to be looking for on draft weekend.

title: Eric Garner Case Goes Largely Unmentioned as Prosecutor Runs for Congress
