description: The death of Eric Garner at the hands of the police on Staten Island has given rise to protests, marches and a federal civil rights inquiry, and brought national attention to the boroughs district attorney, Daniel M. Donovan Jr., when a grand jury declined to bring charges.

title: Digital Tools for Discovery: 10 New Ways to Search and Explore The New York Times
description: Finding the right article, Opinion piece or multimedia feature in the vast archives of a newspaper that has been publishing since 1851 can feel overwhelming to students and teachers alike.

title: NBC to Make New Charles Manson Drama Available to Binge Watch
description: Following in the footsteps of Netflix, the streaming video site that has released entire seasons of its TV shows all at once, NBC announced Wednesday that it would make all 13 episodes of its summer series Aquarius available to watch on NBC.com and other on-demand platforms. They will be available to stream for four weeks following the shows two-hour premiere on May 28.

title: Philip Glass: By the Book
description: The composer and author of Words Without Music says his favorite books about music are not serious books about the philosophy of music or music awareness or whatever you want to call it.

title: What To Do In Baltimore (And Elsewhere)
description: David Simon, the bard of Baltimore, walks a fine line between the essential and the insufferable in both his art and his commentary, but with his native city roiled by riots I think this interview with Bill Keller for The Marshall Project falls on the essential side of the ledger. The whole thing rewards reading, but let me excerpt from passages in whichSimon is critiquing the policing strategies  basically constant mass arrests wherever the drug trade existed, a kind of drug-focused broken windows policing on steroidsembraced during the mayoralty of Martin Carcetti OMalley, because it bears on the policy responses to whats been happening in Baltimore, and the lessons for other cities:

title: The American Way of Birth: Why Do Republicans Hate It?
description: Republicans in Congress keep coming up with new ways to drive home the point: Immigration is bad; fear it.

title: G.M. to Invest $5.4 Billion to Modernize Factories
description: DETROIT  General Motors said Thursday that it would invest $5.4 billion in its American factories over the next three years as part of a broader effort to modernize production facilities and secure jobs.

title: Review: Avengers: Age of Ultron Gets the Superband Back Together
description: Another summer season, another superhero spectacular  these are the days (and nights) of our moviegoing lives. The one under review today, Marvels Avengers: Age of Ultron, isnt half-bad, largely because of its director, Joss Whedon. Heres a guess: Some viewers will love it, others will hate it, and still others will yawn at its very existence. None of this matters because the most relevant thing about a movie like this is that its quality is almost entirely irrelevant. It was created to crush the box office, entertainment media and audience resistance, and mission, you know, already accomplished. In an age of lock-step entertainment, pushback isnt just immaterial; it is also suspect.

title: Swiss Artist Plans a Mosque Installation for Venice Biennale
description: The Swiss artist Christoph Bchel, who has become known for politically provocative pieces that address war, immigration and poverty, announced on Thursday that he plans to temporarily turn a former Venetian Catholic church into a functioning mosque  or at least an art installation that calls itself a mosque  as part of the Venice Biennale, which begins next week.

title: Quake Survivor on Being Trapped for Days
description: Pemba Tamang, the 15-year-old who was rescued after being trapped for five days under rubble from Nepals earthquake, and his rescuer and the doctor treating him described the ordeal on Thursday.

title: She Produces Reds and Whites, and She Has Her Eyes on Roses
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  They are ethereal pursuits, creating wine and fast thoroughbreds. Both require vision. Both take time. Both are at the mercy of Mother Nature. When you get it right, the rewards are lofty  a wine that scores 100 points or a horse that wins the Kentucky Derby.

title: Time Warner Cable Results Fall Short of Predictions
description: Time Warner Cable executives provided few clues on Thursday about whether the company would partake in a new round of deal activity, as it missed expectations for first-quarter profit but reported its strongest subscriber growth in years.

title: Profits at Exxon and Shell Slide, Echoing Oil Prices Plunge
description: Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Shell on Thursday reported sharply lower quarterly earnings, as improved profits from marketing and refining were offset by the impact of the plunge in oil prices since last summer.

title: Yemenis in Desperate Need of Food and Fuel After Weeks of Airstrikes
description: CAIRO  In one of Yemens largest cities, residents have been reduced to a diet of rice. In another, they sleep overnight in lines waiting for gasoline. Hospitals may soon be forced to close, bombs and shells are raining down ever more thickly and randomly, and in places snipers target anyone brave or desperate enough to walk the streets.

title: Our Short Attention Span on the Nepal Earthquake and Other Foreign Disasters
description: Saturdays huge earthquake in Nepal killed at least 5,000 people, injured more than 8,000, and affected millions more. Relief efforts have been continuing to aid the survivors.

title: Japan Makes Gift to Support Smithsonian Museums of Asian Art
description: Japan will donate $1 million to the Freer Gallery of Art and the Arthur M. Sackler Gallery in recognition of how much the sister museums of Asian art operated by the Smithsonian do to promote Japanese culture, the Smithsonian announced Thursday.

title: No Labels, No Drama, Right?
description: My Jeremy is coming to visit this weekend, Maddy whispered to me one night while we were out for a friends birthday.

title: Standard Hotels Introduce App for Same-Day Stays
description: The Standard hotels, including two in New York City and one in Miami, recently introduced a night-of instant booking application, which allows guests to make same-day reservations at any of its properties. Called One Night Standard, the app can be downloaded through the iTunes Store on Apple and Android and was created to encourage spontaneous travel, according to the companys managing partner, Amar Lalvani.

title: Bernie Sanders and Calvin Coolidge: A Vermont Tie But Not Much Else
description: The two politicians could not be more different. One was a famously taciturn northern New England Protestant, a Republican who fervently believed in tax cuts for the wealthy. The other is a Brooklyn-born Jewish politician, a self-declared socialist who believes the billionaire class is at the heart of societys ills.

title: The DJ and Nightlife Arbiter Venus X Shares Her Inspirations
description: GHE20G0TH1K, her long-running, now-cancelled underground party, will return for one night only this weekend.

title: Police Killings Rise Slightly, Though Increased Focus May Suggest Otherwise
description: Their names have become both a litany and rallying cry: Michael Brown. Tamir Rice. Eric Garner. Walter L. Scott. And now Freddie Gray.

title: First Draft Focus: Bernie Sanders on the Hill
description: Bernie Sanders, Long-Serving Independent, Enters Presidential Race as a Democrat

title: Chinese and Russian Navies to Hold Joint Drills in Mediterranean
description: HONG KONG  The Chinese Navy will hold joint exercises with Russia in the Mediterranean in May, Chinas Defense Ministry said Thursday, a further indication of the closer ties between the two countries and of the navys increasing ambitions.

title: New Avengers Movie Not Enough? Take a Free Comic Book
description: Saturday is Free Comic Book Day and visitors to participating comic book stores will once again have the chance to pick up a wide selection of comic books at no cost.

title: HanYang BunSik
description: A small restaurant in a busy Flushing, Queens, market serves substantial Korean snacks.

title: At HanYang BunSik, Snacking Is Encouraged
description: Dont be distracted by the tented stalls outside the 24-hour HanYang Mart in Flushing, Queens, with their promises of baked eggs and potato pancakes shaped like hearts. There will be time for them.

title: Penguins With Parent Problems No. 2: Welcome
description: Whats this? A Random Penguin! Read more about why its on Motherlode here, or, if you love them so much you need more, look for Penguins With People Problems soon at your local independent bookstore.

title: David Javerbaums An Act of God Adapts Tweets to Broadway
description: SANTA MONICA, CALIF.  God has been good to David Javerbaum.

title: running for president
description: candidates throw their hats in the ring

title: Obama Nominates Gayle Smith to Lead U.S.A.I.D.
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama nominated Gayle Smith, a senior White House official, on Thursday to be the next administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, administration officials said.

title: The Perils of Automated Flight
description: After Andreas Lubitz crashed a Germanwings plane in France last month, some people suggested that completely automated systems would one day make flying even safer than it already is. That idea might well be right over the very long run but there is plenty of evidence that technology is still quite fallible.

title: Letters: Spinster
description: Readers responded on the Times Facebook page and on Twitter to Heather Havrileskys review of Spinster: Making a Life of Ones Own, by Kate Bolick (April 19). Heres what some of them had to say.

title: What to Do When a Child Loses Your Trust
description: No child, no matter how well and tenderly taught right from wrong, gets through childhood without stepping over whatever lines your family has drawn. Afterward, what really hurts  and what really needs to be repaired  is the violation of your trust. You left her alone with the cookies, you gave her the iTunes password, you let her go to the party, and now the cookies are gone, the money is spent, and youre picking up your child from the back of a police car.

title: 20 Family-Friendly Travel Ideas to Get You Going
description: Suggestions for new trips and fresh attractions, by region and style.

title: Israel Detains Palestinian Boys, 7 and 12, for Throwing Stones
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  A 7-year-old Palestinian boy and his 12-year-old cousin, accused of throwing stones at an Israeli bus, were detained by Israeli security officials in East Jerusalem on Tuesday evening and interrogated for hours, relatives said Thursday.

title: Banksy Finds a Canvas and a New Fan Base in Gazas Ruins
description: GAZA  Very little of Abu Shadi Shenbaris family home remains in Beit Hanoun, in the northern Gaza Strip. Only a concrete bathroom wall was left standing when Israeli forces flattened the neighborhood near the border with Israel during the war with Hamas last summer.

title: Matthew Weiner on Mad Men and Don Drapers Failed Pitch
description: This is the beginning of something, not the end, Don Draper told his unpersuaded colleagues on  Sundays episode of Mad Men. But viewers of this AMC period drama know that nothing could be further from the truth: On May 17, it all comes to a close for Mad Men, when the story of Draper, his family, his workplace and his tormented love life reaches its conclusion.

title: Experiencing the Evolution of Muscadet
description: Wine is an intimate culinary pleasure. We may share a bottle, but we come to that wine personally and individually. The experience of two people with the same wine can differ wildly for reasons that we may never fully understand.

title: Your Next Lesson: Sonoma Chardonnay
description: Next up is one of the most maligned wines: California chardonnay. It is completely different from Muscadet, yet it shares a need to be re-examined for the 21st century.

title: MoMA to Offer Free Events for Seniors
description: Seeking to make its ever-packed galleries and programs more hospitable to older art patrons, the Museum of Modern Art announced on Thursday an initiative  Prime Time  that will offer film screenings, online courses, gallery conversations and other events free to New York City residents ages 65 and older. The new programs begin on May 9 with a daylong event that will include free museum admission to those 65 and older.

title: Lives of the Poets
description: These picture books use storytelling to bring poetry to children.

title: Study Finds Climate Change as Threat to 1 in 6 Species
description: Climate change could drive to extinction as many as one in six animal and plant species, according to a new analysis.

title: How to Make the N.F.L. Draft More Entertaining and More Fair
description: Before the N.F.L. begins its annual draft Thursday night, how about a thought experiment: What would it look like if other industries  here well use Wall Street firms  took the same approach to hiring young talent?

title: Renault Shareholders Back French Governments Voting Rights Plan
description: PARIS  Perhaps only in France can a regular shareholders meeting become an affair of state.

title: Microsoft (Yes, Microsoft) Has a Far-Out Vision
description: Last June, in the basement of the Microsoft visitor center in Redmond, Wash., Todd Holmdahl, a Microsoft hardware guru, and others nervously walked Satya Nadella, the new chief executive, through a demonstration of a secret project.

title: Paris Photo L.A.s Favorite Couple Shares Their Hometown Haunts
description: I surf, Pierpaolo Barzan says. In fact, its one of the first details imparted by the Italian art patron  one-half of the Depart Foundation, alongside his wife Valeria Sorci, the two of whom recently moved to Los Angeles. I think he went just for the surfing!, Sorci quips. But in truth, the couple had been coming to L.A. regularly for five years, and decided to move when they realized, as Sorci puts it, that it was getting harder to leave! So the partners in life, love and art packed up from Rome and began a new chapter in California, which now includes an exhibition space in West Hollywood and a storied home in the Hollywood Hills  an old Tudor house that belonged to the actress Anne Baxter, Sorci explains. She was the granddaughter of Frank Lloyd Wright, so she asked her grandfather to do some remodeling. Wright started, and then passed the job to John Lautner.

title: In Iran, Fatal Porsche Crash Unleashes Middle-Class Anger at Elites
description: TEHRAN  It was 5 oclock on a recent morning as the canary yellow Porsche raced up the treelined Shariati boulevard in Tehran. The young woman at the wheel, it later emerged, came from the poorer south side of the city. The young man next to her, the nouveau riche grandson of an ayatollah, had bought the car just two days earlier.

title: Hillary Clinton Expected to Treat Bernie Sanders Gingerly
description: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont says he is running for president to win. His campaign announcement  a short news conference outdoors in Washington before he darted back to work  was a study in contrast with Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has yet to greet the press since announcing her candidacy.

title: War, Repentance and Japan
description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan carries a huge burden as his country marks the 70th anniversary of its defeat in World War II this year. He is clearly enthusiastic about charting a future that expands Japans alliance with America in economic and security affairs.

title: Salesforces Slow Growth May Prompt Hunt for a Buyer
description: Salesforce.coms slowing growth makes this a good time to seek a suitor. The $47 billion software outfit is on the market, according to Bloomberg.

title: Times Reporters Analyze Bernie Sanderss Presidential Campaign Remarks
description: Announcing his candidacy for president on Thursday, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont chose a grassy spot outside the Capitol to hold a 10-minute news conference about his priorities for the country and his challenge to Hillary Rodham Clinton for the 2016 Democratic nomination. Over instant messages at noon, two New York Times correspondents, Patrick Healy and Maggie Haberman, analyzed Mr. Sanderss remarks. Here, lightly edited, is their full chat.

title: Proposal to Arm Sunnis Adds to Iraqi Suspicions of the U.S.
description: BAGHDAD  Despite stepped-up military assistance to Iraq to fight Islamic State militants, and President Obamas public commitment to keeping Iraq unified, Iraqis have long suspected a nefarious plot by the Americans to break up their country.

title: Nepal Survivors Lay Amid Rubble and Bodies After Earthquake
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  Five days had passed since an earthquake devastated Nepal, and rescue teams had largely given up hope of finding anyone else alive among the piles of brick and broken concrete that litter Katmandu. Then on Thursday, in a part of the city dense with cheap hotels and shops, rescuers turned off a mechanical shovel and  in the relative silence  heard a cry.

title: Billy Donovan Leaves Florida After 19 Years to Coach N.B.A.s Thunder
description: Billy Donovan, who coached the University of Florida to two national championships and four Final Fours in 19 seasons, resigned on Thursday to become the head coach of the Oklahoma City Thunder, the N.B.A. team announced on Thursday.

title: Did Psychologists Help the Government Torture?
description: One of the more disturbing aspects of the Bush administrations twisted justifications for torturing prisoners after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks was that the C.I.A.s jailers were using medical personnel to monitor interrogations and essentially give their blessing to the abuse.

title: Taxi Driver, 92, Crashes IntoLong Island Home and Is Killed
description: A 92-year-old taxi driver lost control of his vehicle on Thursday, driving through several lawns, striking multiple mailboxes and ultimately crashing into the living room of a home on Long Island, the police said.

title: A Wallpaper Pop-Up Puts Surprising Patterns on Display
description: Im into dollar store and supermarket culture  I walk around and see things, and immediately see their potential, says Este Lewis, the multidisciplinary artist and founder of the independent design company Soy Este. She has translated her fondness for the familiar into a range of wallpaper patterns, 12 of which will be featured by the Manhattan store Am Am for May and June on a hanging, motorized belt, dubbed the Swatch Roller. Among the selected arrangements: Ruth Bender Fruit Roll-Up, which overlaps prints of the yoga pioneer and scans of the snack; Blueberry Stains on Paper Towel, a kind of tie-dye motif; and Cinnamon Gum, a reference to the classic Twin Peaks line That gum you like is going to come back in style. For Lewis, the Swatch Roller is an extension of the very interactive Soy Este site  a way to sell her wares and also, an art piece in and of itself, a studio space and a space for other people to imagine being in, but its real, she says. Theres so much imagination within the Internet  and the patterns are patterns, but the wallpaper is a method of archiving our everyday.

title: Grateful for, and Wary of, Extra Force
description: Residents of Baltimores downtown areas largely view the influx of State Police and National Guard members positively. But blocks from where Freddie Gray was arrested, residents are much more wary.

title: Rolling With Mr. T
description: If this van is a-rockin, the 70s are a-knockin.

title: Bernie Sanders on His 2016 Run
description: Senator Bernie Sanders, Independent of Vermont, entered the 2016 race in challenge to Hillary Rodham Clinton, calling the current economic situation immoral, wrong and unsustainable.

title: Freddie Grays Injury and the Police Rough Ride
description: In Baltimore, they call it a rough ride. In Philadelphia, they had another name for it that hints at the age of the practice  a nickel ride, a reference to old-time amusement park rides that cost five cents. Other cities called them joy rides.

title: BrattonExplores Giving Warnings in Lieu of Arrests for Minor Offenses
description: For Police Commissioner William J. Bratton, keeping crime low in New York City hinges on the power of officers to make arrests for low-level offenses. Not that they must actually do so.

title: Alex Rodriguez Is Back at Fenway. Let the Booing Begin.
description: Fenway Park was the stage on which Alex Rodriguez was first introduced to Major League Baseball. It was a cool, rainy evening in Boston on July 8, 1994, and the gathering specter of a players strike threatened to shut down the sport.

title: Martin OMalley Was Born to Run
description: Update: Jim Rutenberg spoke with Martin OMalley this week about the events in Baltimore, a week and a half after this interview was conducted. Read that conversation here.

title: Martin OMalley: We Never Encouraged Aggressive Policing
description: When I interviewed Martin OMalley, a former Democratic governor of Maryland, in Baltimore this month, part of our conversation centered on crime and policing in that city, where he served as mayor from 1999 to 2007. A great deal has happened in Baltimore since that interview, of course. Shortly after we spoke, the citys mayor and police chief announced that the Police Department was suspending six officers after the death of Freddie Gray.

title: On Baltimore, Hillary Clinton Is Half Right
description: Give Hillary Clinton credit for stepping up, in a speech at Columbia University on Wednesday, to the rioting in Baltimore and the confounding American problems of poverty and violence, racial injustice and criminal policing.

title: Frozen Embryos Article Was Intended to Spark Debate: Mission Accomplished.
description: An Op-Ed essay titled Sofa Vergaras Ex-Fianc: Our Frozen Embryos Have a Right to Live started to draw fire almost immediately after its publication Wednesday night.

title: Things to Do in New Jersey, May 3 to 9, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: F.A.A. Orders Fix for Possible Power Loss in Boeing 787
description: Federal regulators will order operators of Boeing 787 Dreamliners to shut down the planes electrical power periodically after Boeing discovered a software error that could result in a total loss of power.

title: Hank Greenberg Still in the Ring at 90, Battling A.I.G. Charges
description: To his accusers, Maurice R. Greenberg, also known as Hank, is just one in a line of disgraced chief executives from the mid-2000s who resorted to accounting fraud to pad their lavish bonuses. But even they have to admit one thing: The man has stamina.

title: A Debate Arises Over Frank Lloyd Wright House in Phoenix
Pictures of the Day: Nepal and Elsewhere
description: Nepal and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Review: Embracing Modernism: Ten Years of Drawings Acquisitions at the Morgan Runs a Gamut
description: No museum exhibition is perfect, but some are less perfect than others. Surprisingly, even these shows sometimes turn out to be exceptionally valuable. They clarify notions of quality and the pleasures and rigors of looking, for curators and visitors alike.

title: Lil Buck at Versailles, as Apollo. Seriously.
description: The Parisian artist Jean-Michel Othoniels gilded glass fountains wont be the only things dancing at opening parties for the restored Water Theater grove in the gardens of the Chteau de Versailles in May. L.A. Dance Project will present the latest addition to its repertoire in the newly landscaped space on May 10 and 11, with a guest solo performance by the jookin street dance phenomenon Lil Buck, starring as the sun god Apollo.

title: Review: Discovering Japanese Art Presents Collections at the Met
description: Most Frank Lloyd Wright fans know that he was influenced by Japanese aesthetics. Fewer are aware that during the first quarter of the 20th century that American architect pursued a lucrative side career as a dealer in Japanese prints. When he was working on designs for the Imperial Hotel in Tokyo, Wright said that print vendors lined up outside his office door. This business helped save his architectural practice during its less solvent periods. Years later he recalled that sales of Japanese prints practically built Taliesin I and II.

title: Murder Charge for Woman Who Said Fiancs Kayak Capsized in Hudson River
description: MIDDLETOWN, N.Y.  For days, the New York State Police scoured the sandy shorelines of the Hudson River, looking for a man whose fiance said had slipped under the frigid surface when his kayak capsized during a weekend excursion.

title: Things to Do in Westchester, May 3 to 9, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: The DJ and Nightlife Arbiter Venus X Shares Her Inspirations
description: The world may know Venus X as MIAs tour DJ and backup vocalist, but X  ne Jazmin Venus Soto  is so much more than MIAs stage sidekick: shes a connector, style evangelist and most importantly, the founder of the long-running underground party GHE20G0TH1K. Its not your typical night in New York, X, 28, says of the party. Its artists, DJs and musicians who want to enjoy what the status quo enjoys, but they want to experiment with who is at the party and how people are dressing, as opposed to a club where you usually have a straight, gay, black, white or Hispanic crowd where people and music arent mixing. By combining urban and punk aesthetics  the ghetto gothic idea  Xs party, founded in 2009, has had a hand in a cultural movement, especially in the style community. A longtime friend of Hood by Airs Shayne Oliver, she has worked with the brand, making music for commercials, runway shows and after-parties, since 2010. She wore Hood by Air in A$AP Rockys first major music video, Peso, in 2011, and played an integral role in launching its womens line in fall 2014, creating a live sound installation alongside Fatima Al Qadiri. Shes also worked with Patrik Ervell and Phillip Lim, among others.

title: April 30, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Nepal, Burundi, Vietnam and the United States.

title: A Belated Retrospective for a Bauhaus Artist
description: Hannes Beckmann, a Bauhaus-trained painter who was also a photographer and stage designer, narrowly survived World War II. He fled his native Germany, ended up imprisoned in Czechoslovakia and lost much of his artwork along the way. After tracking down some of Mr. Beckmanns surviving works in recent years, David Hall, an art dealer in Wellesley, Mass., is opening a retrospective on Monday.

title: Change to a Segregated Monument Is Stymied by a Law Protecting It
description: GREENWOOD, S.C.  The bronze plaques on Main Street silently tell the toll of the two world wars on this small county: 197 men, listed by name but uncategorized by rank or age or branch of service.

title: Revolution of the Eye
description: A new exhibition at the Jewish Museum examines modern arts influence on early network television.

title: Review: Audra McDonald at Carnegie Hall, Paying Tribute to Musical Theater
description: Songs From My Living Room was the informal title of Audra McDonalds forward-looking Carnegie Hall concert on Wednesday evening. That meant a mixture of recent theater songs and vintage show tunes, many associated with her musical role models  Chita Rivera, Betty Buckley, Barbara Cook, Judy Garland  when she was growing up in Fresno, Calif., dreaming of Broadway stardom.

title: Mayor de Blasio Defends Police Response to Freddie Gray Protests in New York
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio, facing an uproar over arrests at a Manhattan rally to protest strong-armed policing, offered a spirited defense of law enforcement on Thursday, brushing off concerns that demonstrators had been mistreated even as he insisted on his own commitment to reform.

title: Review: Kate Atkinsons A God in Ruins Offers Lives Skipping Among Eras
description: In a churlish note at the end of her subtly fine new novel, A God in Ruins, Kate Atkinson talks about an authors right to remain uncertain about what she has accomplished until she has actually done it. Its as if there is a part of the writing brain that knows what its doing and another part that is woefully ignorant, she says.

title: Complaints in Baltimore About Law Offering Protections for Officers
description: As Justice Department officials began meeting with community leaders in Baltimore this week in the early stages of their civil rights inquiry into the death of Freddie Gray, they heard repeated complaints about a state law that gives special legal protections to police officers suspected of abusing their power.

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, May 3 to 9, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Gilead Hepatitis Drugs Brought In $4.55 Billion in First Quarter
description: Sales of Gilead Sciences drugs to treat hepatitis C reached $4.55 billion in the first quarter, far exceeding already lofty Wall Street expectations but likely to focus attention once again on the overall costs to the health care system of the medicines.

title: Things to Do on Long Island, May 3 to 9, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Color and Light
description: Inger McCabe Elliott, a former photojournalist for Life and a textile designer, lives in a 1914 co-op on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Review: Sarah Peters at Eleven Rivington
description: With the haunting bronze heads in this elegant show, the Brooklyn sculptor Sarah Peters scores an aesthetic hat trick: making works that appear antique, Modern and post-Modern all at once.

title: Malta Offers Citizenship and All Its Perks for a Price
description: VALLETTA, Malta  As wealthy foreigners rush to get citizenship in Malta under a new program, the residency requirement is taking many forms.

title: Review: Allan deSouza, Notes From Afar
description: In 2011, the Phillips Collection in Washington commissioned Allan deSouza to create a photographic response to Jacob Lawrences 60-painting Migration Series (1940-41), half of which is owned by the Phillips, the other half by the Museum of Modern Art in New York (where the entire work is on display through Sept. 7). The Lawrence cycle tells the story of the great diaspora of African-Americans, beginning in World War I, from the rural South to the industrialized North. Mr. deSouza, who was born in Kenya of South Asian parentage and lives in California, has long made displacement and alienation a subject of his art and does so again in The World Series, his incisive update to the older work.

title: Review: Lisa Yuskavage at David Zwirner
description: Lisa Yuskavages paintings need to push more envelopes. Their societal salvos are well aimed, but formally and stylistically they should unsettle notions about painting in more profound, less completely parodic ways. With their protruding chests, slinky pelvises and scanty dress, Ms. Yuskavages creatures inhabit greasy surfaced, pastel worlds whose acid hues often hijack the modernist love of color for colors sake. Rankling several standards of taste, she reclaims womens pleasure as their own while sometimes evoking metaphorically the repressions such freedom can invite. Triptych, the largest painting in Ms. Yuskavages previous solo show at Zwirner (in 2011), suggested the blood sacrifice of one of her sprites by stern pioneer women from the Old West.

title: Review: Pam Lins, model model model
description: Much has been made of the relationship between photography and painting; less so the one between photography and sculpture. Pam Linss current show includes two projects that explore that connection.

title: Review: Latin America in Construction: Architecture 1955-1980 at MoMA
description: Some years ago I sat on the gusty, sun-drenched roof deck of a beachside hotel in Rio de Janeiro sipping ice tea with Maria Elisa Costa. A half-century earlier, her father, Lcio Costa, had devised the master plan for Braslia, which is pretty much where a new, extraordinary exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, Latin America in Construction: Architecture 1955-1980, begins.

title: Sarah Dahlgren, New York Feds Top Bank Supervisor, to Leave
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which has recently faced strong criticism of its oversight of Wall Street, announced on Thursday that its head of bank supervision plans to leave at the end of year.

title: Grandeur to Spare
description: Lee Billings reviews Chris Impeys Beyond: Our Future in Space this week. Impey, a professor at the University of Arizona, was born in Britain, and said in a recent email interview that he came to astronomy as a teenager.

title: Review: Your Blues Aint Sweet Like Mine Takes On Race
description: RED BANK, N.J.  At a dinner party on the Upper West Side, Zeke (Brandon J. Dirden) reels off his own personal A B Cs: A is for the Arawak, victims of genocide. B is for bombings in Birmingham. C is for chains. D is for denied. E is for Emmett Till. The other guests stop him before he can get much further into the alphabet.

title: A Baby Instrument All Grown Up
description: Patsy Rogers has heard it all before.

title: Review: Revolution of the Eye Examines Arts Influence on Early TV
description: Walk into Revolution of the Eye, a revealing new exhibition that opens Friday at the Jewish Museum, and youre face to face with the 23-year-old Barbra Streisand dashing about in a riotously colored Op-Art dress, singing, Gotta find some place ... Some place where I can just be me.

title: Oliver Jefferss Art of Bearing Witness
description: On Wednesday night in Brooklyn, in an elevator that was once used to move cars between floors of a belt factory, Oliver Jeffers destroyed months of work in front of a dozen witnesses, and then offered them a drink. The Northern Irish, Brooklyn-based artist (hes exhibited at the National Portrait Gallery, but is perhaps best known for his childrens books and work with U2), had spent months creating a portrait of a middle-aged African American woman grasping a chicken in one hand and a viper in the other. Last night, he dipped it in a vat of green paint, a bright shade of sickly lime enamel, covering all but the top of her head. With that, an assistant passed around shots of whiskey and glasses were raised: Whats done is done, and whats to come is to come.

title: Comedy Listings for May 1-7
description: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Roots Remake Is Set for 2016 and Will Run on Three Cable Networks
description: A&E Networks announced on Thursday that the landmark mini-series Roots would be remade into an event series, scheduled to air in 2016.

title: Jazz Listings for May 1-7
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Dance Listings for May 1-7
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Islanders Know What Theyre Leaving; Unknowns Await in Brooklyn
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  The Islanders have just begun processing another heart-wrenching playoff loss, but this forced foray into summer feels different.

title: Shira Piven on Directing Welcome to Me, a Comedy of Disorder
description: In the new film Welcome to Me, Kristen Wiig plays Alice Klieg, an unemployed, mentally ill veterinary technician who goes off her meds, wins the lottery and buys her way into hosting a talk show. Then the fun  in the form of borderline personality disorder, reckless spending and puppy surgery  really starts. It has hilarious moments and dark moments, and I really like living in that world, the director, Shira Piven, said.

title: Review: At Paloma in Stamford, a Combination of Latin Foods
description: In this era of wall-to-wall television shows about chefs competing, fighting and sometimes even cooking, some diners like to go to restaurants with a camera-ready face at the helm.

title: Qatar Joins List of Countries Buying Fighter Jets From France
description: PARIS  President Franois Hollande of France announced on Thursday a multibillion dollar sale of military aircraft to Qatar, the countrys third such deal with a foreign government this year.

title: Pop, Rock & Cabaret for May 1-7
description: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Night Market Offers a Taste of Home
description: Long lines formed in a parking lot last Saturday at Flushing Meadows-Corona Park for delicacies like Chinese sweet cakes and Japanese octopus balls.

title: Squid Sticks After Dark at the Queens International Night Market
description: Last weekend, well before the Queens International Night Market had officially opened, long lines had already started to form. Visitors swarmed the 20 food tents set up in a corner of the roughly 100,000-square-foot parking lot outside the New York Hall of Science, at Flushing Meadows-Corona Park.

title: Easing Diabetes Risk, One Beverage at a Time
Review: Kristen Wiig as a Troubled Lottery Winner in Welcome to Me
description: Welcome to Me is the name of a television show created by Alice Klieg, a California woman  divorced, unemployed, coping with borderline personality disorder, off her medication  who financed it with money she won in the state lottery. Alice is the programs guiding creative spirit and also its star, so the content reflects her interests: low-carbohydrant cooking, swan figurines, the neutering of dogs, re-enacted episodes of childhood humiliation and, above all, herself. She is both unstable and self-absorbed, and though she has spent years studying the broadcast work of Oprah Winfrey on VHS, Alices on-air gestures and intonations can be as awkward as her self-help pronouncements are bizarre. From the start, Welcome to Me, shot in front of a sparse audience in the studios of a struggling infomercial outfit, seems to be headed for disaster.

title: New Whitney Museum Signifies a Changing New York Art Scene
description: For the last week, thousands of New York art followers have been paying their first visits to the Whitney Museum of American Arts hospitable new home and its history-stretching inaugural exhibition, the largest ever of works from its permanent collection.

title: Homeland Security Official Defends Handling of Visa Program
description: The deputy secretary of Homeland Security, Alejandro Mayorkas, conceded at a congressional hearing on Thursday that his intervention in three cases of visas for foreign investors had created an impression of political favoritism, and he said he regretted fostering that perception. But he defended the results of his involvement, saying he had helped to make sure we were adhering to the law.

title: Theater Listings for May 1-7
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for May 1-7
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Movie Listings for May 1-7
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Woman in Punjab Is Killed After Being Molested on Bus
description: NEW DELHI  A young woman traveling in Punjab on Wednesday evening was killed after she and her mother were molested and thrown from a private bus by a group of men, the mother said.

title: Jury in Etan Patz Trial Rehears Defense Summation on Day 12 of Deliberating
description: A day after announcing it was deadlocked, the jury in the Etan Patz murder case listened to a reading of the entire defense summation again on Thursday, absorbing three and a half hours of argument and watching several video clips before resuming its deliberations.

title: Anatomy | Far From the Madding Crowd
description: In this Anatomy of a Scene, Thomas Vinterberg narrates a sequence from Far From the Madding Crowd, featuring Carey Mulligan and Tom Sturridge.

title: Classical & Opera Listings for May 1-7
description: Classical

title: Far From the Madding Crowd (With Movie Trailer): Thomas Vinterberg Narrates a Scene
description: Thomas Hardys 1874 novel Far From the Madding Crowd has been adapted several times for film and television over the years. But the Danish director Thomas Vinterberg sought to bring something fresh to the story of Bathsheba Everdene (Carey Mulligan), a farm owner who is courted by three men. In this video, she secretly meets one of her suitors, Francis Troy (Tom Sturridge), in the forest. In a recent interview, Mr. Vinterberg, who usually writes the films he directs, spoke about working on this adaptation.

title: Spare Times for May 1-7
description: Museums and Sites

title: Review: Far From the Madding Crowd, the Rom-Com
description: Bathsheba Everdene  if the last name sounds familiar, thats because shes an acknowledged feminist foremother of the Hunger Games heroine  is faced with a series of complicated choices. Really, though, her predicament is simple: She wants to live on her own terms in a society where a womans freedom is tightly circumscribed by custom and expectation. As she tries to figure out what she wants to do and who she wants to be, the world keeps pushing her to answer a different question: Which man will she marry?

title: 145 Writers Sign Letter Protesting PEN Award to Charlie Hebdo
description: Junot Daz, Lorrie Moore, Joyce Carol Oates, Eric Bogosian and Michael Cunningham are among the 145 writers listed as signatories on a letter protesting PEN American Centers decision to award its freedom of expression courage award to the French satirical weekly Charlie Hebdo, because the award seems to endorse drawings of the prophet Muhammad and other images that must be seen as being intended to cause further humiliation and suffering among Frances embattled Muslims.

title: Baby Boom Among New Yorks Affluent
description: Over the past decade or so as $10 million apartments have prevailed in New York and more and more neighborhoods have been given over to the kind of luxury shopping required to fill them, it has been common to say that the city has turned into a playground for the rich. At the same time, of course, New York has turned into a playground of the more literal kind, with a child-centric ethos bearing well-established variants of urban nuisance: stroller gridlock in gentrifying areas, car services that cater to 5-year-olds, sidewalk whining that in some cases becomes its own source of noise pollution. (When you can hear Amadeus demanding a second packet of Pirates Booty from your fourth-floor walk-up on West 83rd Street, do you feel like calling 311?)

title: Lost in Nepals Quake, but Preserved in Photos
description: With thousands dead and entire communities destroyed, the Nepal Picture Librarys archives may be the only surviving record of what was lost in the recent earthquake.

title: Spare Times for Children for May 1-7
description: Folklore Family Day

title: At MoMA, Dream Designs. On Instagram, the Reality.
description: Think of the Instagram hashtag ArquiMoMA as an epilogue to the Museum of Modern Arts Latin America in Construction: Architecture 1955-1980.

title: Review: Gurrumul, an Aboriginal Singer, Makes U.S. Debut
description: Theres something preternaturally soothing about the voice of Gurrumul, an Australian aboriginal singer and songwriter who made his United States debut on Wednesday night at SubCulture. It seems to arrive from a distance, high and serene, with a hint of reediness and a humble quaver, proffering melodies like lullabies.

title: Time Away Doesnt Mean Time Off
description: How should I handle colleagues who refer to my impending six-to-eight-week maternity leave as vacation? So far, Ive received comments such as, Wow, I wish I could have a two-month vacation! and I hope you enjoy your break. I have tried referring to this period as medical disability leave, but that hasnt changed the general perception that I will be loafing around. Any ideas?

title: Days of Grace, a Mexican Film by Everardo Gout
description: Days of Grace, the debut feature from Everardo Gout, a Mexican filmmaker with a background in music videos and television commercials, weaves together three stories of violence and corruption in Mexico City. Braided narratives are a way for directors both to show off their chops and to illuminate social issues and complex themes. Mr. Gout combines a slick, kinetic style with a somber ethical sense. His movie is flashy and entertaining, but also earnestly concerned with the collapse of trust and integrity at every level of society.

title: This Weeks Movies | May 1, 2015
description: The New York Times film critics review Avengers: Age of Ultron, Iris and Welcome to Me.

title: Community Leaders Share Ideas on How to Quell Urban Violence
description: PHILADELPHIA  More than 300 community leaders at a convention about 100 miles from the turmoil in Baltimore are pondering issues of policing, urban poverty and the effects of law enforcement on urban life.

title: N.F.L. and Networks Ensure Scoops Dont Ruin Suspense
description: The N.F.L. draft should feel like Christmas for Adam Schefter of ESPN, who has established himself as the pro football reporter whose immense social media following is a testament to his ability to break news. Schefter, one could assume, might be relishing the chance to reveal what is going on in the draft before a league official announces it.

title: Review: In Far From Men, a Teacher Caught in the Crossfire
description: In Far From Men, Viggo Mortensen, his sharply planed face weathered and solemn, plays a man who looks as if he were quarried right out of the hard red-rock earth. He plays Daru, a teacher who imparts the names of French rivers to eager Algerian children in a small white schoolhouse thats nestled in a valley and ringed by jagged desert mountains. Theres something haunted about this wildly beautiful place with its thirsty ground and sparse vegetation, though only partly because the story takes place in 1954, the year the fight for Algerian independence ignited.

title: Review: In Hyena, a Rogue Cop Finds Himself in Too Deep
description: Hyena, Gerard Johnsons corrupt-cop drama, is the kind of gory British policier from which you come away with the queasy feeling that the world is essentially a butcher shop ruled by greed, murder, cruelty and lust. American equivalents like Bad Lieutenant at least have a moral compass, however twisted. British crime films in a similar mode (Im thinking particularly of Filth) begin from the Hobbesian presumption that, as Mick Jagger sings in Sympathy for the Devil, every cop is a criminal.

title: Gay Marriage Backers to Finance Anti-Discrimination Efforts
description: With gay marriage being debated by the United States Supreme Court, some of the major backers of efforts to legalize it around the country are casting their attention to the next fight: anti-discrimination bills in a variety of states.

title: Review: Cas & Dylan, a Road Movie Starring Richard Dreyfuss
description: Why another road movie about bickering mismatched travelers warily making friends on a cross-country journey? That clich weighs heavily on Cas & Dylan, the feature film directorial debut of Jason Priestley (known mostly from his acting role on Beverly Hills 90210), even after you queasily succumb to the sentimentality of this formulaic two-hander.

title: A Worse-Than-Expected $55 Million First-Quarter Loss for DreamWorks Animation
description: LOS ANGELES  After a brutal six months marked by creative retrenchments and two failed merger attempts, DreamWorks Animation on Thursday reported a first-quarter loss of $54.8 million.

title: Review: In Ride, Helen Hunt Goes Surfing
description: A more accurate title for Ride, a wobbly underdeveloped comedy starring Helen Hunt, who directed and wrote the screenplay, would be How I Learned to Surf. As an instructional movie on the sport, Ride offers some useful tips, but beyond that, it feels like a slightly bizarre vanity project.

title: Judge Reduces 3 Sentences in Atlanta School Testing Scandal
description: ATLANTA  Admitting that he was not comfortable with the seven-year prison terms he had handed down two weeks earlier, the judge in the Atlanta Public Schools cheating case on Thursday called three former administrators back to his courtroom to cut their prison terms to three years each.

title: Review: In Cathedrals of Culture, Buildings to Love
description: As houses of God, Europes cathedrals were built to be something more than mere stone, something that could transport and transform. In the omnibus film Cathedrals of Culture, subtitled A 3D Film Project About the Soul of Buildings, the secular structures on display are scarcely less ambitious, and the strongest of the films six chapters reflect filmmakers searching to express higher states of being.

title: Plan Unveiled to Overhaul School System in Detroit
description: Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan unveiled a proposal on Thursday to overhaul the failing Detroit public school system by creating two districts  one to manage paying off billions of dollars in debt, the other to oversee the day-to-day operations of the schools.

title: Review: In Gerontophilia, a Youth Is Attracted to Old Men
description: Coming from the director of No Skin Off My Ass and The Raspberry Reich, Gerontophilia might sound like just another gleefully raunchy provocation: An 18-year-old man is uncontrollably attracted to old men, despite being involved with a spirited, radical-minded young woman. But the mild style that the filmmaker Bruce LaBruce slips on for his new feature is that of tastefully observed indie romance, flavored with a sweetly droll sense of humor but never to the point of undermining the sincerity of its intentions.

title: Nepals Earthquake Recovery Begins, Even as Aftershocks Linger
description: A few rescues were among the rare bits of good news on an otherwise dreary and rainy day during which the enormity of the tragedy that has befallen Nepal continued to sink in.

title: Kentucky Derby 2015: Predictions and Analysis
description: The horses for the 141st running of the Kentucky Derby are listed in order of post position, with comments by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. The morning-line odds were set by Mike Battaglia of Churchill Downs. (Note: International Star, who was to start from the No. 12 post, was scratched Saturday morning with a hoof issue. Frammento, an alternate entry who will wear saddle No. 21, was added to the field after the scratch of Stanford, who was to start from the No. 11 post. The horses will keep their program numbers but the first hole in the gate will be left open and each will move down a gate. For example, No. 1 Ocho Ocho Ocho will break from the second post but still be considered as breaking from Post 1.)
